site_title: Macau gambling revenue drops in Jan, analysts say worst may be over
summary: Macau's gambling revenue dropped 21.4% in January, the 20th consecutive month of decline, to 18.7 billion patacas, in line with analysts' expectations. The drop is attributed to a two-year-old anti-corruption campaign and slowing China's economy. The Lunar New Year holiday is expected to boost visitor numbers, potentially alleviating the decline.

images.alt_text: Gambling revenues for the Chinese territory of Macau dropped 21.4 per cent in January, ahead of a Lunar New Year week-long holiday which is expected to boost the number of visitors to the world's largest casino hub.

site_title: Hong Kong January home sales hit 25-year low, Centaline says
summary: Hong Kong home sales plummeted to a 25-year low in January, with Centaline estimating 3,000 units sold, the lowest monthly figure since 1991. This decline adds to evidence that prices have further to fall. Experts attribute the market's sentiment to its current state, with a senior manager from Colliers International Group stating that the Hong Kong residential market is "all about sentiment."

images.alt_text: Hong Kong home sales slumped to the lowest in at least a quarter-century last month, Centaline Property Agency Ltd estimated, adding to evidence that prices have further to fall.

site_title: Renault opens first China factory
summary: Renault, the French car giant, has opened its first car factory in China, a joint venture with Dongfeng, in Wuhan, Hubei province. The 150,000 vehicle-per-year facility marks Renault's entry into China's massive auto market. Renault CEO Carlos Ghosn stated that China remains a "growth driver" for the global auto industry. This move is seen as Renault's last major step to set up a plant in the country, with the company now tapping into the world's largest auto market.

images.alt_text: [WUHAN, China] French car giant Renault opened its first car factory in China on Monday, the last major manufacturer to set up a plant in the country as it looks to tap into the world's biggest auto market.

site_title: Cheap oil less of a boon for US growth than in the past
summary: US consumers are cautious about spending their savings from cheap gasoline, saving more and spending less on energy products. A 70% drop in crude oil prices since mid-2014 cut households' annual spending by $115 billion, but savings increased by $121 billion. Economists attribute this to the still-fresh scars of the 2007-2009 recession and concerns about low oil prices lasting. The US job market appears robust enough to absorb job losses in the energy sector, and cheap energy is estimated to add only half the benefit it did in the past to economic growth.

images.alt_text: US consumers are cautious about spending their windfall from cheap gasoline and are saving more, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll and official data, suggesting low oil prices are less of a boon for the US economy than in the past.

site_title: China official manufacturing PMI eases to 49.4 in January, misses forecasts
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity contracted more than expected in January, with the official PMI at 49.4, below the 50-point mark and the previous month's reading of 49.7. This marks the sixth consecutive month of contraction, missing market forecasts. The decline suggests China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indonesia's January inflation picks up to 4.14% but less than expected
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose to 4.14% in January, beating December's 3.35% but below the 4.20% expected by economists. The increase was largely due to higher food prices. This inflation rate remains within the central bank's target range, providing a slight reprieve for policymakers.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose in January but at a slightly slower pace than expected, and remained within the central bank's target range.

site_title: Bankruptcies fail to cut US firms' coal supply glut
summary: US coal firms' production remained high despite bankruptcies, with an average 3% increase in production through the third quarter. Mines formerly owned by James River Coal Co saw a 31% gain, and utilities' stockpiles ended 2015 at a six-year high. The glut is expected to continue, threatening to depress prices for years and putting more firms and jobs at risk.

images.alt_text: Five US miners have sought bankruptcy protection since April 2014. Some of the failed companies have restructured debt, others have sold mines at bargain prices to former rivals.

site_title: Chinese airline passengers to start transiting Taiwan
summary: Chinese airline passengers will be allowed to transit through Taiwan, starting on Monday, marking a step towards increased transportation links between the two political enemies. The plan was announced in early January and comes ahead of Taiwan's national elections, which saw the Democratic Progressive Party take power. Taiwan has been self-ruled since 1949, and the move benefits the civil aviation industry and deepens exchanges between the two sides. Transit passengers will not be able to leave the airport and must have valid onward travel documents.

images.alt_text: [TAIPEI] Chinese passengers will be able to transit through Taiwan and fly onwards to a third destination starting on Monday, signalling a step toward greater transportation links between the two political enemies.

site_title: Africa calling for CrimsonLogic
summary: CrimsonLogic CEO Saw Ken Wye emphasizes Africa as the tech firm's top priority for expansion. The company's logo features a Fibonacci-shaped sea shell, which Wye finds "perfection, logical." No specific details on Africa expansion plans are provided.

images.alt_text: Mr Saw says the firm makes over S$100 million in annual revenue; he aims to double that over the next three to five years.

site_title: South Korea sees "big difference" in 2016 export prospects from last year
summary: South Korea's trade ministry reported a "big difference" in 2016 export prospects compared to last year, citing worsening external conditions in China, the US, and emerging economies. The ministry initially forecast a 2.1% increase in exports and a 2.6% increase in imports, but now expects a worse outcome. The current "not easy" external conditions are attributed to China's slowing GDP growth and global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: [SEOUL] South Korea's trade ministry said on Monday there is a "big difference" in external conditions now compared to when it issued export forecasts last year, and added that prospects for 2016 are worse than initially expected.

site_title: Buying plunges, selling remains low
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show a decline in buying activity by directors and companies, with 19 purchases worth S$3.06 million and 6 companies posting repurchases worth S$1.63 million in the last week of January. However, significant acquisitions were made by GKE Corporation, Travelite Holdings, and insider buys by Keppel Corporation, Ho Bee Land, GL Ltd, Cache Logistics Trust, and Mapletree Logistics Trust. These purchases were largely driven by the decline in share prices since July 2015 and October 2015. Despite the decline in buying activity, some companies reported significant profits and earnings growth, including GKE Corporation and Ho Bee Land.

images.alt_text: THE buying plunged while the selling among directors remained low based on filings on Singapore Exchange in the last week of January.

site_title: China: Stocks fall after weak factory activity survey
summary: China's stocks fell over 1% on Monday after a weak factory activity survey, with the CSI300 index down 1.5% to 2,901.05. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.8% to 2,688.85 points. The survey showed China's factory sector was in worse shape than expected, leading to a decline in market sentiment.

images.alt_text: China stocks fell over 1 per cent on Monday after an official survey showed China's factory sector was in worse shape than expected.

site_title: 1980: Evolution in CPF and industry
summary: In 1980, Singapore's government allowed citizens to use up to 90% of their Central Provident Fund (CPF) money to buy private property, including for investment purposes, without residency requirements. This liberal rule change significantly impacted the country's property market and marked a shift in policymakers' perception of CPF savings. The move paved the way for many Singaporeans to use their CPF funds for home purchases, which has become a common practice today.

site_title: Chinese airline passengers start transiting Taiwan
summary: Chinese airline passengers began transiting Taiwan on February 1, 2016, after China announced a trial transit program with three cities. The program aims to deepen exchanges between the two rivals, allowing passengers to fly to a third destination after transiting Taiwan. The move follows China's announcement just before Taiwan's national elections, which saw the Democratic Progressive Party take power. The transit passengers must have valid onward travel documents and cannot leave the airport, according to regulations.

site_title: Renault sees strong China potential despite late arrival
summary: Renault is set to cut the ribbon on its first assembly plant in China, despite being late to the market, with the goal of increasing its vehicle output from 150,000 per year to double or triple capacity. The plant, located in Wuhan, eastern-central China, will initially assemble the Kadjar compact SUV and later expand to include an electric sedan. Renault sees growth potential in the Chinese market, which is expected to grow 4-6% in 2016, and plans to increase its sales network to 150 dealerships from 125 last year.

images.alt_text: [WUHAN] Renault still sees plenty of growth in Chinese vehicle demand, the French carmaker said as it prepared to cut the ribbon on its first assembly plant in the world's biggest auto market, where growth has slowed over the past year.

site_title: Aussie PM rules out early polls as coalition works on reform plan
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has ruled out early polls, opting instead to focus on crafting an economic reform plan. He plans to present the agenda and policies to the public before the third quarter, rather than calling an election early. This move is seen as a strategic decision to capitalize on his personal popularity and build support for the coalition government's economic reforms.

images.alt_text: Mr Turnbull faces a balancing act on tax as voters wait for him to flesh out an economic vision that he said his predecessor was lacking.

site_title: Australia city home prices rebound in Jan, Melbourne hot
summary: Australian home prices rebounded in January with a 0.9% increase in the combined capital cities, according to CoreLogic RP Data. Melbourne led the recovery with a 2.5% jump, while Sydney saw a 0.5% increase. Melbourne's annual growth of 11.0% surpassed Sydney's 10.5%. The rebound counters speculation of a market crash after a rapid price rise last year.

images.alt_text: [SYDNEY] Australian home prices rebounded in January with Melbourne boasting especially strong growth, a counter to speculation the market was at risk of crashing after a rapid run up last year.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei soars to near 1-month high; real estate stocks rise further
summary: Tokyo shares rose to near one-month highs, with the Nikkei surging 2.0% to 17,865.23, its highest close since Jan 6. Real estate stocks, benefiting from lower interest rates, jumped 5-7.5%, while bank stocks declined 5.5-8.0% due to negative interest rates eating into interest revenues.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares on Monday soared to near one-month highs in heavy volume as the Bank of Japan's surprise decision to adopt negative interest rates spurred further buying, lifting real estate stocks.

site_title: Japan's Nippon Steel to acquire Nisshin Steel
summary: Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp, Japan's largest steelmaker, is set to acquire Nisshin Steel Co, its largest shareholder, for possibly more than 100 billion yen (S$1.17 billion). The acquisition, which could be announced as early as Monday, would turn Nisshin Steel into a fully owned subsidiary.

images.alt_text: [TOKYO] Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp, Japan's biggest steelmaker, is set to acquire Japan's No. 4 steelmaker, Nisshin Steel Co, for possibly more than 100 billion yen (S$1.17 billion), the Asahi newspaper reported on Monday.

site_title: China grapples with contradictions over currency
summary: China is struggling to balance its push for economic reforms and a freely traded currency with curbing massive outflows of capital, a contradiction known as the "impossible trinity". The country's ruling Communist Party seeks to control the exchange rate and monetary policy, but moving to freer capital flows is fuelling fears of a slowing economy. This lack of communication is exacerbating the issue, with some analysts suggesting Beijing may need to devalue the yuan, which would negatively affect its status.

images.alt_text: China has been diving into its foreign exchange reserves - already the world's largest - to buy massive amounts of yuan.

site_title: Over 10,000 migrant children missing: Europol
summary: Over 10,000 unaccompanied migrant children have disappeared in Europe since registering with state authorities, according to Europol. The vulnerable children, who arrived in Europe over the past 18-24 months, are feared to be at risk of being trafficked into sex rings or the slave trade. This alarming figure has raised concerns about the safety and well-being of these children.

images.alt_text: [THE HAGUE] Over 10,000 unaccompanied migrant children have disappeared in Europe, the EU police agency Europol said Sunday, fearing many have been whisked into sex trafficking rings or the slave trade.

site_title: Head start for 70 children with OCBC financial literacy games
summary: OCBC Bank hosted a financial literacy event for 70 children at orchardgateway, featuring games and a talk by a wealth specialist. The top-scoring participant, 11-year-old Jayden Koe, received a tablet for a score of S$36,749.34. This initiative aims to educate children on responsible spending and giving back to the community.

site_title: Greece resists its role as EU's back door
summary: Greece is resisting its role as a major entry point for refugees into the European Union, sparking a debate over temporarily expelling the country from the Schengen area. Thousands of migrants from the Middle East and Africa have been arriving in Greece, with many attempting to reach Western Europe. EU officials are considering proposals to harden the border with Macedonia and turn Greece into a processing center for migrants, as the continent struggles to cope with the migrant crisis.

site_title: Sterling under pressure as Cameron struggles to obtain satisfactory EU reform deal
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron is struggling to secure adequate European Union (EU) reforms ahead of the UK referendum, putting sterling under pressure. The pound has fallen by 7% since November due to fears of Brexit, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch predicting further weakening in coming months. Cameron is seeking reforms on benefits for immigrant workers, access to the single market, and competitiveness, but faces criticism from eurosceptics that the proposed changes are inadequate. Latest polls show eurosceptics gaining ground, with 38% of voters now leaning to leave the EU, and Cameron's negotiating ability in doubt.

site_title: Oil declines as China's industrial decline worsens
summary: Oil prices declined by as much as 2.1% in New York, snapping a four-day advance, as China's factory gauge fell to a three-year low, signaling deteriorating conditions. OPEC's January output rose to 33.11 million barrels a day, exacerbated by increased production from Kuwait and Nigeria. Oil prices also fell due to concerns over US stockpiles and increased exports from Iran after sanctions were removed, with analysts predicting further declines unless production cuts are made.

site_title: Hyundai Motor posts first monthly sales decline since July
summary: Hyundai Motor Co reported its first monthly sales decline since July, with January sales dropping 13% to 338,035 units. Domestic deliveries fell 1.1% and overseas demand slumped 14%. The decline follows Hyundai's lowest annual profit in five years in 2015, attributed to weak demand in China and unfavourable exchange rates in Russia and Brazil. The company expects a difficult market situation this year due to continued slowdowns in China and emerging market currency uncertainties.

site_title: Meet the man who became Singapore's guru of property by accident
summary: Steve Melhuish, a 47-year-old British-born entrepreneur, founded PropertyGuru Group in 2007 to revolutionize the Singaporean real estate market. The company, now the largest internet real estate website in Southeast Asia with 14 million users, dominates the market with its user-friendly platform and high-quality listings. Despite facing competition from giants like News Corp and newcomer 99.co, Melhuish attributes his company's success to its "paranoia" and willingness to adapt, adopting a "Google approach" to relevant search and prioritizing quality listings.

site_title: Dubai airport 2015 traffic up 10.7%, world's busiest
summary: Dubai International Airport remained the world's busiest for international passengers in 2015, with a 10.7% increase in traffic to 78 million passengers. The airport's growth was boosted by the addition of new airlines and routes, including 12 new destinations. Despite regional conflicts, airport CEO Paul Griffiths reported no impact on traffic. India retained its position as Dubai's largest destination country with 10.4 million passengers, up 17%. The airport is also testing its new Concourse D, expected to start operating this quarter.

site_title: January data show Asia's factories parched for demand, need stimulus
summary: January data from Asia's factories showed a lack of demand, with China's manufacturing falling to its lowest since 2012, and South Korea and Taiwan also experiencing weakness. The downward pressure on inflation led to interest rate cuts in Japan and is expected to prompt further easing in Asia. This slowdown in demand is a concern for policymakers, who may face pressure to address the issue, particularly in China where GDP growth is set to slow. The weak data also highlights the need for stimulus measures to boost factory production and alleviate economic pressure.

site_title: Europe divided over taxing of big US corporations
summary: European countries are divided on taxing US big corporations, with some viewing them as employers and innovators, while others see them as tax evaders. Governments seek revenue to fill budget deficits and address inequality. Some nations, like Singapore, have set up AI-focused innovation hubs, while others, like Lazada, invest in creator commerce. The EU's stance on taxing US corporations is uncertain, with no clear consensus on how to balance economic benefits with tax revenue.

site_title: 'Spotlight' and diversity winners at SAG Awards
summary: The 22nd Screen Actors Guild Awards honored "Spotlight" as the top prize winner, and Leonardo DiCaprio took home the best actor award for "The Revenant." Brie Larson won the best actress award for "Room." The ceremony also saw a notable increase in diversity, with several black actors winning awards, including Idris Elba, Uzo Aduba, Viola Davis, and Queen Latifah. The SAG Awards were seen as a response to the lack of diversity in the Oscar nominations, with many actors and industry professionals speaking out on the issue.

site_title: Tomorrow's companies, today
summary: Singapore's future economy is represented by data analytics firms Arcstone, EverComm, and Tableau Software, which help companies maximize efficiency, eliminate resource wastage, and spot growth opportunities. These firms provide manufacturing solutions, energy efficiency, and data visualization tools to industrial and corporate clients. With the ability to analyze data, companies can achieve an extra $65 billion in productivity benefits by 2020. Arcstone and EverComm are homegrown startups, while Tableau Software is a US-listed company that provides a simple drag-and-drop interface for data analysis. The firms' tools can help Singapore become a Smart Nation.

site_title: US$ hits 6-week high against yen
summary: The US dollar rose to a six-week high against the yen after the Bank of Japan cut interest rates to negative territory, with the US dollar index reaching 99.586 and the dollar up 2.4% against the yen. The move reversed the dollar's month-long slide against the yen and was seen as a dollar-strengthening story, driven by capital inflows into US markets and the expectation of further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb almost 1 per cent, BOJ decision helps sentiment
summary: Australian shares rose almost 1% on Monday, marking a third consecutive gain, after the Bank of Japan cut a benchmark interest rate below zero. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 38.08 points to 5,043.60. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also edged up 0.07% or 4.27 points. The positive sentiment was attributed to the BOJ's decision, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Musk's Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai. Meanwhile, CGSI downgraded Grab to a 'hold' rating, citing expected earnings growth slowdown in H2, and Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Hong Kong January home sales fell to 25-year low, Centaline says
summary: Hong Kong's home sales plummeted to a 25-year low in January, with Centaline estimating 3,000 units sold, the lowest monthly figure since 1991. The market is expected to continue weakening due to falling stock-market prices, economic slowdown, and rising interest rates. Housing prices have fallen 9.5% from September and could drop another 20% in 2016. Developers are offering incentives to encourage buyers, including discounts and stamp duty rebates. The market's decline is attributed to a combination of factors, including a rising supply of homes and slowing growth in China.

site_title: Thai January consumer prices fall for 13th straight month
summary: Thai consumer prices fell for a 13th consecutive month in January, dropping 0.53% from the previous year, primarily due to lower oil prices. The Bank of Thailand forecasts headline inflation at 0.8% this year, below its target range. The central bank has kept interest rates unchanged at 1.50% and is expected to maintain this policy until its next review on February 3. The economy remains supported by fiscal spending following the 2014 army coup.

site_title: Update: 'Brexit' talks in London extended to clinch deal
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron's Brexit talks with European Union President Donald Tusk in London have been extended without a deal, with both parties agreeing to continue intensive work over the next 24 hours. Cameron is pushing for changes to Britain's membership, including an "emergency brake" to restrict in-work benefits for EU migrants, while Tusk will assess the situation before deciding whether to take the deal to other EU countries. A final deal is hoped to be reached at a Brussels summit on February 18 and 19, potentially paving the way for a referendum in June or September.

site_title: A successful balancing act
summary: A new restaurant, Whitegrass, has opened in Singapore's Chijmes district, offering a unique dining experience with a focus on light, delicate fare. Chef Sam Aisbett's Australian-Japanese-Asian fusion cuisine impresses with its originality and attention to detail. Standout dishes include Hokkaido scallop, sashimi of yellowtail amberjack, and slow-cooked mangalica pork, all showcasing Aisbett's effortless cooking style. With two fixed-price menus at $170 and $265, Whitegrass is a breath of fresh air in a predictable dining scene, but its opening-day perfection may not be sustained in the long term, earning a rating of 7.5.

site_title: JPMorgan launches blockchain trial project: FT
summary: JPMorgan Chase has partnered with Digital Asset Holdings to launch a trial project using blockchain technology, aiming to reduce the cost and complexity of trading. The technology could help address liquidity mismatches in loan funds, speeding up settlement processes from weeks to minutes. Head of JPMorgan's investment bank Daniel Pinto sees blockchain's potential to improve loan sales as "making all the sense in the world." This trial project is another sign of blockchain's growing applications in the financial sector.

site_title: Singapore developers' sentiment weakened further in Q4 2015: survey
summary: Singapore developers' sentiment weakened further in Q4 2015, with the Current Sentiment Index falling to 3.6 and the Future Sentiment Index falling to 3.4, according to the NUS-Redas Real Estate Sentiment Index survey. The office sector performed the worst, with a current net balance of -43% and a future net balance of -67%. Developers anticipate a slowing global economy, inflation, and interest rate hikes negatively impacting market sentiment, with 9 in 10 expecting a slowing global economy and 6 in 10 anticipating a moderate decrease in residential property prices.

site_title: Hedge funds bet against Chinese currency: WSJ
summary: Several major hedge funds, including Hayman Capital Management and Greenlight Capital, have invested heavily in bets against the Chinese yuan, citing economic pressures such as a slowing economy and persistent capital outflows. Meanwhile, the US dollar has risen against other currencies due to the relative strength of the US economy, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Hedge fund managers Stanley Druckenmiller and David Tepper have also taken positions against the yuan, reflecting concerns about China's currency.

site_title: China police arrest 21 over US$7.6b online financial scam
summary: Chinese police arrested 21 people, including Ezubao chairman Ding Ning, over a US$7.6 billion online financial scam. The Ponzi scheme, launched in 2014, took in 50 billion yuan from 900,000 investors, with 95% of projects being fake. Authorities seized assets, shut down the website, and closed Yucheng Group's Beijing office. The case highlights risks in China's US$2.6 trillion wealth management product industry, which often operate through loosely regulated channels.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at over 2-week high, foreign buying helps; won eases
summary: South Korean shares rose to a two-week high, driven by foreign buying and a weakening won. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) gained 0.3% to 1,917.31 points, despite weak manufacturing data in China and a 18.5% drop in South Korean exports. Foreign investors purchased 59 billion won worth of shares, while the won fell 0.5% against the dollar. The KOSPI's gain was attributed to lifted sentiment after weak January data.

site_title: Can central banks continue rescuing markets?
summary: Central banks' efforts to rescue markets may not be sustainable, according to Rabobank. The Bank of Japan's monetary policy shift into negative territory has sparked a rally, but its effects are likely to be short-lived. This raises concerns about the impact of monetary injections on asset prices, particularly as the European Central Bank and People's Bank of China are expected to provide more stimulus in March. The disconnect between asset prices and fundamental values may close either as fundamentals improve, or due to selling pressure, or as policymakers resort to "bad medicine" in the form of further monetary policy stimulus.

site_title: China new home prices up in January
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.42% month-on-month in January, marking the sixth consecutive month of gains, according to a survey by the China Index Academy. This increase comes after the government introduced stimulus measures to boost lending and encourage migrant workers to buy homes. The average price of a new home in China's 100 major cities rose to 11,026 yuan (S$2,385) per square meter, a 4.37% year-on-year increase. The property market has been stabilizing, with authorities aiming to boost economic growth and mitigate concerns about a "hard landing".

site_title: Singapore market bearish on credit quality of energy and commodity firms: Moody's
summary: Singapore's stock market is bearish on the credit quality of energy and commodity firms, according to Moody's. A poll of market participants found that 88% of respondents in Singapore and 65% in Hong Kong were most worried about the commodities and energy sectors. Moody's has a negative outlook for Asia's coal and steel sectors, and has placed the ratings of 120 oil and gas companies and 55 mining companies on review for downgrade. The agency expects flat or slower growth in most Asian economies to weigh on credit and capital flow volatility in 2016.

site_title: VLCC rates could see pre-Chinese New Year spike: ship brokers
summary: VLCC freight rates, which have been near three-month lows, may see a pre-Chinese New Year spike due to tighter tonnage supply and increased chartering volumes. Rates have leveled off after dropping to the lowest level since Oct 30, with a Singapore-based ship broker predicting a rebound ahead of the holiday. This follows a surge in chartering volumes and a reduction in available vessels, potentially leading to higher rates.

site_title: James Murdoch set to return as Sky chairman
summary: James Murdoch, the younger son of News Corp's founder Rupert Murdoch, is set to return as chairman of British pay-television group Sky, nearly four years after his departure due to the phone-hacking scandal. Murdoch's return, combined with the recent return of Rebekah Brooks, has sparked speculation about a potential News Corp takeover bid for Sky, which is owned by 21st Century Fox, a 39% stakeholder. Murdoch's appointment as chairman was welcomed by Sky's CEO Jeremy Darroch, citing his knowledge of the international media industry and passion for supporting Sky's success.

site_title: Annuities as an alternative to shaky markets? Be wary
summary: The article discusses the potential benefits and drawbacks of annuities as a retirement savings strategy, particularly in light of the recent global stock market plunge. While annuities can provide a steady income stream, they often come with significant upfront costs and may not be the best option for everyone. Critics argue that annuities can be overly complex, expensive, and may not keep pace with inflation. Alternative strategies, such as delaying Social Security benefits, working longer, and reducing fixed expenses, may be more effective in reducing retirement risk.

site_title: Oil prices halt rise in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices halted their rise in Asia on Monday due to the strengthening US dollar, which makes oil more expensive for holders of weaker units. The US dollar rose after the Bank of Japan adopted a below-zero interest rate policy to spur bank lending and drive up inflation. Oil prices closed higher last week but are unlikely to continue rising without changes in fundamentals, according to analysts. The global oversupply of crude continues to limit oil price gains.

site_title: Volvo, Buick and Cadillac among first China-made cars to arrive in America
summary: The US market has seen the arrival of its first Chinese-made cars, manufactured by Volvo, Buick, and Cadillac. Volvo shipped over 1,000 S60 Inscriptions from China, while Buick imported the Envision and Cadillac exported a plug-in hybrid version of its CT6 sedan. Despite initial concerns, US consumers are more interested in the brand and product quality than the country of manufacture. Experts argue that globalisation and quality have overcome cultural and safety concerns, with brands like Volvo and BMW being accepted worldwide.

site_title: 'No deal yet' in Brexit talks with Cameron: EU's Tusk
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron and European Union president Donald Tusk failed to reach a deal on changes to Britain's EU membership ahead of a referendum. The two leaders agreed to another 24 hours of talks before publishing a draft agreement, with Cameron seeking to secure reform in four key areas. An EU source noted "some progress" but "outstanding issues" remain, leaving no deal yet.

site_title: Shares in Sony surge after swing to profit
summary: Sony shares surged 16% on Monday after the electronics giant posted a nine-month net profit of nearly $2 billion due to strong sales of its game console and mobile gadget parts. This marks a reversal of a 19.2 billion yen loss a year earlier. Operating profit more than doubled to 387.1 billion yen, and sales edged up 0.1%. The company's restructuring efforts, including layoffs and asset sales, have contributed to the turnaround. Strong sales of PlayStation consoles and image sensors helped Sony move past years of losses.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge up on seasonal factors in Jan
summary: Australia's private-sector inflation gauge rose in January due to seasonal increases in services like education and healthcare, but core prices remained restrained. This trend suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia can keep interest rates loose, with a possible rate hold at 2% and scope to ease further if necessary.

site_title: OCBC opens new fintech and innovation unit
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a fintech and innovation unit called The Open Vault at OCBC, focusing on five key areas: wealth management, credit and financing, insurance, cybersecurity, and artificial intelligence. The unit, led by Pranav Seth, will work with fintech startups to develop solutions for employees and customers. OCBC has partnered with Nest to host an accelerator program for innovators, which will begin in April. The unit aims to deliver tangible outcomes and value, with CEO Samuel Tsien stating it will help OCBC create digital solutions to simplify, speed, and secure banking.

site_title: Suu Kyi's camp to form govt after decades of struggle
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) won 80% of seats in Myanmar's November election, but must share power with the military. Hundreds of lawmakers from the NLD took over the government, paving the way for the country's first democratically elected government since 1962. The NLD will choose a president in February, with the official term starting in April. This marks a significant step in Myanmar's transition to democracy, following decades of struggle by Suu Kyi and her allies.

site_title: Some US$29 trillion later, corporate debt boom looks exhausted
summary: The US corporate bond market has experienced a massive debt boom, with over $29 trillion in corporate debt accumulated over the past seven years. This has led to high levels of corporate leverage, with companies now indebted to three times their earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA). The resulting debt overhang poses a significant risk to the global economy, with credit-rating downgrades and bond losses mounting. Analysts warn that the "global growth model based on cheap credit from central banks is running out of steam," and that the debt crisis may not be limited to the bond market.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up marginally on cautious trade ahead of holidays
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.1% to 8,151.34 on Monday ahead of a holiday shortened trading week. The electronics subindex gained 0.3%, while the financials subindex fell 1.0%. Shares in Hon Hai Precision rose 0.8% as the company's CEO expressed confidence in its bid for Sharp. Investors took a cautious stance due to a weakened trade-reliant economy, with more rate cuts expected. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.235 to T$33.415 per US dollar.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise to a 3-1/2-week high; won dips
summary: South Korean shares rose to a three-and-a-half-week high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing up 0.7% at 1,924.82, driven by foreign buying of equities. Foreign investors purchased 185.2 billion won worth of shares, while the won eased against the dollar following weaker Chinese manufacturing data. The won ended the day down 0.1% at 1,200.5 per dollar.

site_title: Yen loses further ground after surprise BoJ stimulus move
summary: The yen lost further ground after the Bank of Japan's surprise stimulus move last week, which included a negative interest rate policy to boost lending and combat deflation. The move sent the yen tumbling, with emerging currencies also taking a hit due to weak China manufacturing figures. China's economic slowdown is raising pressure on policymakers, while other markets were affected by various economic indicators, including Malaysia's industrial production and the UK economy's contraction.

site_title: Takata's faulty airbags continue to exact a toll as recalls lag
summary: Takata's faulty airbags continue to cause harm as recalls remain inadequate. In a 2015 accident, a South Carolina man, Joel Knight, died after being struck by shrapnel from a Ford Ranger airbag. The incident occurred because the airbag had not been recalled due to its faulty design. This case highlights the ongoing issue of Takata's defective airbags, which have caused numerous fatalities worldwide. Despite numerous recalls, the problem persists, leaving many drivers at risk of injury or death.

site_title: Japan boost lifts Asia but Shanghai, Hong Kong hit by China data
summary: Asian markets were mixed Monday, with Shanghai and Hong Kong stocks falling due to a low Chinese factory activity index and weakening manufacturing sector. Japan's decision to cut interest rates to negative boosted most other Asian markets, including Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and Singapore. The move also spurred a rally in global markets and sent the yen tumbling. Oil prices fell after a four-day rally, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate down 2% and Brent losing 1.9%.

site_title: Time to bring sugar into the 'sin tax' net
summary: Singapore may introduce a tax on added sugar, following the success of tobacco and alcohol sin taxes. The country's food and beverage industry has long suppressed research on the harmful effects of sugar, but experts like Prof John Yudkin have exposed its detrimental impact. With added sugar present in many processed foods and drinks, a sugar tax could discourage excessive consumption and promote healthier eating habits. The move aims to curb the negative health effects of sugar, similar to the approach taken with tobacco and alcohol.

site_title: World's top LNG importer looks to sell surplus
summary: Japan, the world's top LNG importer, is shifting from buyer to seller as it seeks to offload surplus stock amid a global glut. The country's LNG imports declined 3.9% last year, and utilities are cutting import contracts to minimum levels. Japanese utilities are delaying or diverting shipments and exploring options to swap out cargoes with firms outside Japan. Spot LNG prices have fallen 26% to $5.10 per million British thermal units, making it more profitable for Japanese utilities to resell their surplus supply.

site_title: South Korea's exports record biggest drop since 2009
summary: South Korea's exports plummeted 18.5% in January, the largest drop since 2009, amid slowdowns in major economies, including China, and falling global oil prices. This marks the 13th consecutive month of decline, contributing to a 13-month losing streak and the country's slowest annual economic growth since 2012, with a 2.6% expansion in 2015. The decline in exports is attributed to a range of factors, including trade tensions and the impact of low oil prices on petroleum exports.

site_title: South Korea's Jan house prices barely up vs Dec: bank data
summary: South Korea's house prices rose 0.08% in January, marking the 29th consecutive month of increase. This represents a 4.37% year-over-year increase, according to Kookmin Bank's composite house transactions price index. The rise is attributed to a steady market trend, with no significant fluctuations reported in the latest data.

site_title: Toyota: Japan production to stop for week due to steel shortage
summary: Toyota is halting production at all Japanese car assembly plants for a week due to a steel shortage caused by an explosion at a steel plant operated by one of its affiliates. The production halt will start on February 8 and resume on February 15. Toyota plans to procure steel from substitute lines and other suppliers to minimize the impact on production, with overseas production unaffected.

site_title: Cuomo's plan for financing affordable housing worries New York City officials
summary: New York State Governor Andrew Cuomo's budget proposal aims to increase state control over the financing of affordable housing by giving the Public Authorities Control Board the power to approve or veto individual housing projects using tax-exempt bonds. This move is met with concern from New York City officials and affordable housing representatives, who argue it would add uncertainty, delays, and politics to the production of affordable units. Cuomo proposes focusing on counties using tax-exempt financing to lure companies from other counties, rather than targeting New York City, which exclusively uses the bonds to finance affordable housing.

site_title: Oil set for more volatility after a turbulent week
summary: World oil prices experienced significant volatility last week, swinging between gains and losses, despite possible efforts to tackle a supply glut. Oil prices rebounded after unconfirmed reports of Russia and OPEC agreeing to coordinated cuts, but concerns over weak global economic growth lingered. The US Department of Energy reported a record high in commercial crude inventories, while the Bank of Japan unexpectedly slashed interest rates into negative territory. Despite these factors, oil prices surged on Thursday after Russian reports of Energy Minister Alexander Novak's readiness to participate in talks with OPEC.

site_title: Apple working quietly on virtual reality: report
summary: Apple is reportedly working on virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) gear, with a team of hundreds of employees, including talent from other companies working on altered-reality technology. The company has also filed patents related to the technology. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, expressed interest in VR, calling it "really cool" with "interesting applications." The company is building headset prototypes, although it has not commented on the reports. This move challenges Facebook-owned Oculus Rift and Microsoft HoloLens in the market for VR and AR headsets.

site_title: Olam announces new COO, CFO
summary: Olam International has announced two key appointments: A Shekhar as executive director and group chief operating officer (COO), effective February 1, 2016, and Neelamani Muthukumar as group CFO, also effective February 1, 2016. Both appointments will assist Olam's co-founder and CEO Sunny Verghese in overseeing the company's business. Shekhar has spent over 24 years in Olam, while Muthukumar has been with the company for over 18 years, most recently as president and global head of corporate finance.

site_title: Malaysian central bank chief's imminent exit highlights succession risks
summary: Malaysia's central bank chief, Zeti Akhtar Aziz, is set to step down in April after 16 years, raising concerns about succession risks and potential policy continuity. The economy faces uncertainties, including a collapse in commodity prices and a political scandal, which could impact the central bank's independence and the competence of her replacement. Market participants are anxious about the future of the central bank's independence, policy continuity, and the ability of the next governor to match Zeti's credibility, with some speculating that the replacement may be politically motivated.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: MOF seeks feedback from S'poreans on Budget 2016
summary: The Ministry of Finance in Singapore is seeking feedback from citizens on the upcoming Budget 2016, which will be presented by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat on March 24. This marks the preparation for the budget, but the provided article does not contain relevant information about it.

site_title: Confusion schools of thought
summary: A global market update is not provided in the article. However, key events include a 6,000% stock gain for an elevator empire in Japan due to a succession crisis, a potential end to deflationary price wars in China, and US President Trump unveiling new tariff rates, including a 50% levy on Brazil.

site_title: Researchers say Zika case found in Indonesia
summary: Indonesian researchers have found one positive Zika case on Sumatra island, according to the Eijkman Institute for Molecular Biology. The 27-year-old man, who had never traveled overseas, was infected while studying a dengue outbreak. The virus has been circulating in Indonesia for a while, and its presence has been confirmed through specimens that tested negative for dengue. The discovery adds to global concerns about the mosquito-borne virus, which has been linked to severe brain damage in newborns and has similar symptoms to dengue fever.

site_title: TDSR objectives gradually being met: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reports that the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) framework's objectives are being met, with less than 10% of existing borrowers exceeding 60% debt-to-income ratio. New borrowers also show signs of improvement, with almost all housing loans below 60% TDSR and many having less than 40%. Households are reducing their mortgage burden, with borrowers with multiple loans making up only 20% of new housing loans, down from 30% in 2011. The three-year grace period for refinancing has encouraged households to "right-size" their loans, strengthening household balance sheets.

site_title: US presidential contenders in last-gasp bid to snare Iowa votes
summary: US presidential contenders, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, made a final push in Iowa ahead of Monday's caucuses, with Trump leading in polls but not by enough to secure victory. The Republican and Democratic candidates held rallies and events, with Trump appealing to evangelical conservatives and Clinton seeking to deny Senator Bernie Sanders a win. The outcome is seen as crucial for momentum heading into the February primary in New Hampshire, with a tight margin between Clinton and Sanders in a Bloomberg/Des Moines Register poll.

site_title: Iran aims to boost output capacity by 160,000 bpd
summary: Iran aims to boost its crude oil production capacity by 160,000 barrels per day following the completion of expansion projects at North Azadegan and Yadavaran oilfields. The two oilfields, operational since 2014, can produce 75,000 and 85,000 barrels per day, respectively. Iran expects to reach production capacities of 30,000 and 60,000 barrels per day at North Yaran and South Azadegan oil fields by March 2017. The move is seen as a response to international sanctions and a bid to increase oil output.

site_title: As currency war simmers, Aussie dollar a poster child for market forces
summary: The Australian dollar has plummeted to a seven-year low, but this decline is benefiting the country's economy. The weaker currency has spurred record tourist arrivals and education income, while tempering the drag from iron ore's unprecedented lows. The Australian dollar is now in line with economic fundamentals, having been 25% overvalued in 2013. The decline has also helped support the recovery and restructure the economy, with services exports contributing significantly to growth. The currency is expected to continue to support the economy, driving a 7.2% gain in exports, but also poses risks to the economy, including a slowing housing construction boom and record low wage growth.

site_title: Sundance continues to open up worlds and cinema
summary: The Sundance Film Festival continues to shape the film industry, but the focus has shifted from meaningful discussions of cinema to commercial and distribution deals. Industry professionals and agents have colonized the festival, making it feel like a nostalgic reminder of the past. The festival remains a platform for opening up new worlds and exploring cinematic visions, but its impact is now also felt in the commercial and industry aspects of the film world.

site_title: Size of excess reserves may determine success of BOJ's negative interest rate shock
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) introduced negative interest rates to stimulate the economy, potentially due to the vast size of "excess reserves" held by Japanese banks, totaling 250 trillion yen. This move could lead to a positive impact on stock and bond markets, and coordinate with the European Central Bank's expected monetary easing. However, currency markets are uncertain, and some analysts question the effectiveness of negative interest rates in achieving inflation and growth objectives, citing limited success in the eurozone and other countries. The BOJ will continue to monitor the economy and adjust its policies as needed.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday after Japan's surprise stimulus
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 9.61 points to 2,638.72, opening 0.37% higher on Monday, following a global rally after Japan's surprise stimulus. US stocks jumped 2.5% on Friday, while Asian markets also rose, driven by a weaker yen and investors' positive reaction to the interest rate cut.

site_title: India's Sahara uses small savers to keep hill resort afloat
summary: Sahara, an Indian conglomerate, has allegedly used funds from small savers through its credit cooperatives to finance its luxury Aamby Valley resort project. At least 15 billion rupees (S$315 million) has been invested, with some investors complaining they have struggled to get paid out their matured time deposits. The practice, while not illegal, may put investors at risk if the project is sold to pay off other investors. Sahara's founder Subrata Roy is currently in jail for not complying with a court order to repay investors in a previous scheme.

site_title: Home prices in east London surge in 2015
summary: Home prices in east London surged in 2015, with Newham experiencing a 22.1% increase, the highest in London. Westminster saw no growth, while Kensington and Chelsea registered a 4.3% gain. Soaring values have made buyers reconsider, with some opting to wait for changes to government measures, such as the planned increase in transaction tax on second homes. Average rents in London rose 11% to £1,596 a month, with 64% of landlords expecting to raise rents in the near future.

site_title: Gold extends gains after best month in a year
summary: Gold prices advanced at the start of February, extending gains after its best month in a year in January, driven by a softer dollar and uncertainty over the global economy. Spot gold rose 0.3% to $1,120.75 an ounce, while the largest gold-backed exchange-traded fund saw its largest monthly inflow in a year. However, Societe Generale predicts gold will struggle to hold gains due to a rising interest rate outlook in the US, with forecasted prices of $1,040 in the first quarter and $955 in the last quarter of the year.

site_title: Mid-tier Chinese banks piling up trillions of dollars in shadow loans
summary: Mid-tier Chinese banks have piled up an estimated $1.8 trillion in shadow loans, equivalent to 16.5% of all commercial loans in China, as they use complex instruments to mask the risks of lending to the country's slowing economy. These "shadow loans" are often restructured as low-risk investments on bank balance sheets, with banks keeping less capital in reserve and lending more. This practice, involving financial structures like Directional Asset Management Plans and Trust Beneficiary Rights, has raised concerns about the lack of transparency and mis-categorization of credit assets, potentially hiding considerable non-performing loans.

site_title: Xerox splitting into two as it grapples with changing market
summary: Xerox is splitting into two publicly traded entities: a $11 billion document technology company and a $7 billion services provider to government and industries. The split aims to simplify decision-making and focus on core businesses. Xerox's shares rose 5.6% after the announcement, but Moody's Investors Service downgraded the company's debt ratings due to reduced business diversity and profitability. The split is expected to result in cost savings of $2.4 billion over the next three years, with less than 1% of the workforce impacted.

site_title: Pepsi moves into restaurant business to serve up some buzz
summary: Pepsi has opened its first restaurant, Kola House, in New York's trendy Meatpacking District, aiming to offer a premium experience and test new products. The 5,000-square-foot space will not feature the Pepsi logo or products, focusing on the kola nut instead. The restaurant is designed for social media engagement, with an executive chef and menu to be determined. Kola House is part of Pepsi's efforts to rebrand and connect with consumers in the digital age, following a decline in sales and a shift towards healthier beverage options.

site_title: Nokia gets Samsung patent ruling, sees positive impact
summary: Nokia received a patent ruling from an International Chamber of Commerce arbitration court, which is expected to have a positive financial impact. The ruling settles a licensing pact with Samsung, resulting in Nokia's patent-licensing business now having an annual revenue run rate of about 800 million euros. This includes fourth-quarter sales of about 400 million euros and full-year 2015 sales of about 1.02 billion euros. Nokia did not provide financial details, but the company is optimistic about the outcome.

site_title: S.Korea to allow foreign investors to use omnibus accounts
summary: South Korea plans to introduce an omnibus account system in 2017, allowing foreign investors to conduct transactions through a single account, reducing costs and enhancing convenience. The goal is to reclassify the country's stocks into the developed market category by index compiler MSCI, which could help stabilize the financial markets. The test run will begin in May, with authorities also exploring options to increase the currency's convertibility. The move aims to attract more foreign investors and support the country's economy, estimated to be the world's 11th largest in 2015.

site_title: Airbnb regional managing director joins Carousell
summary: Carousell appoints Chai Jia Jih as vice-president, international, effective March 2, 2016. Jih, previously managing director, South-east Asia and head of Apac host operations at Airbnb, will lead the company's international growth and support financial strategy. He brings over 12 years of leadership and growth experience in technology, having helped chart Airbnb's rapid growth in Asia. Co-founders Quek Siu Rui and Marcus Tan described Jih as a "great cultural fit" and believe he will help navigate Carousell's growth and capture opportunities.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover ends production of Defender
summary: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) has ended production of the iconic Land Rover Defender after 68 years, citing difficulties in maintaining safety and emissions standards. The last Defender rolled off the production line in Solihull, England, following a 2013 announcement that the vehicle would be discontinued. Despite its legendary status, the Defender's production was deemed unsustainable, with only 70% of Land Rovers ever made still on the road. A new Land Rover model is planned to start production in 2018.

site_title: Ryanair says Q3 profits more than double
summary: Irish airline Ryanair reported a 110% surge in third-quarter net profit to €103 million, driven by a 25% increase in customer traffic to 25 million people. The company cited rising profitability and improving cash flow, offsetting the impact of weaker demand following the Paris attacks. Ryanair also announced an €800 million share buyback program to return value to investors. Despite a modest dip in average fares, lower costs largely due to tumbling oil prices helped drive the growth.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb 1 per cent, BOJ decision helps sentiment
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% on Monday, following a 0.6% advance on Friday, as the Bank of Japan's interest rate cut boosted market sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,067.5, with financials and healthcare stocks leading the gains. Analysts expect the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate decision on Tuesday and corporate earnings to influence market direction. This comes after Wall Street surged 2% on Friday.

site_title: More questions than answers from SingPost's reply
summary: SingPost's board has chosen PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) as the special auditor for a special audit, despite concerns from stakeholders about potential conflicts of interest and inadequate corporate governance. The audit will not review whether the company followed proper procedures for acquisitions, which have resulted in significant goodwill. The board's choice of PwC has raised questions about the independence of the special audit, given the company's long-standing relationship with the firm and PwC's receipt of substantial non-audit fees. A strong and effective board, good governance, and a strong management team are essential for SingPost's transformation journey.

site_title: More facing problems refinancing homes due to TDSR
summary: Singapore home owners are struggling to refinance their properties due to falling property prices, stringent income definitions, and tedious paperwork. Conservative property valuations limit refinancing to smaller loan amounts. Many are opting for fixed-rate mortgages or re-pricing to lower rates before Sibor increases. This is exacerbating the challenges faced by those looking to refinance, with one mortgage adviser reporting that 8% of its clients are unable to do so.

site_title: Buy low, sell high? Think again
summary: Investors often rely on simple ratios like price-to-earnings (PE) and price-to-book (PB) to determine if a stock is undervalued or overvalued. However, these ratios can be misleading as they don't account for factors like economic cycles, growth rates, and industry-specific challenges. For example, property developers may have high PE multiples due to delayed earnings recognition, while growth companies can trade at high multiples despite potential volatility. Mature companies can also be overvalued despite low PE multiples. The author argues that ratios are not a reliable guide to buying or selling, and that investors should focus on their own estimates of growth and valuation.

site_title: Gulf tourist influx to Bosnia fuels luxury developments
summary: A luxury residential project, Sarajevo Resort, is being developed in Bosnia, catering to Gulf tourists with 360 villas, swimming pools, and a halal supermarket. The project is one of several in the region targeting visitors from Gulf states. This influx of tourists has fueled luxury developments in the area, indicating a growing demand for high-end real estate in Bosnia.

site_title: HSBC to freeze salaries, hiring in 2016: sources
summary: HSBC is imposing a hiring and pay freeze globally in 2016 as part of its cost-cutting drive to boost profitability and returns to shareholders. The bank aims to achieve annual cost savings of up to $5 billion by 2017. This measure is part of a broader effort by global banks to reduce expenses and increase efficiency. The bank's decision is in line with other lenders, which are also implementing cost-saving measures to improve their financial performance.

site_title: Aussie upset motivates record-seeking Serena
summary: Serena Williams lost to Angelique Kerber in the Australian Open final, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, halting her bid to match Steffi Graf's Open-era record of 22 Grand Slam titles. Williams praised Kerber, calling her a great person and a good sport, and credited her with inspiring her with a positive attitude and never-give-up mentality. The loss halted Williams' record bid and allowed Kerber to move to world number two, while Williams vowed to learn from her mistakes and return to Melbourne Park next year.

site_title: Risky business
summary: A new framework is helping US and European companies optimize risk management and meet business objectives. This framework has a dual governance role, focusing on performance and conformance. In its performance role, boards oversee strategy and value creation, while in its conformance role, they oversee risk management and regulatory compliance.

site_title: Not sure latest bear market scare is over
summary: The US stock market may have recovered from its historically bad January start, but a bear market scare remains uncertain. A strong jobs report in December could settle the debate over a recession, but that's contingent on the market's performance this week. Major indexes rallied last week, but the year's worst opening is still a concern. Investors are cautiously optimistic, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, which may continue to support the market.

site_title: Millennials splurge on #lifegoals, giving leisure stocks a boost
summary: Millennials are prioritizing experiences over material possessions, boosting leisure and travel-related stocks. According to a survey, 78% of millennials prefer paying for experiences over buying goods, compared to 59% of baby boomers. Companies such as airlines, pubs, and travel operators are benefiting from this trend, with sales outperforming retailers. Investors are also creating funds focused on millennials' preferences, including social media, e-commerce, and travel. As a result, millennials are spending less on savings and allocating funds to experiences, with 34% saying they save enough money each month.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Monday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets closed on Monday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks extended their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In Asia, traders are optimistic about stocks despite new Trump threats. In Europe, mining and healthcare shares rose, while US-EU trade talks were in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Budget 2016: Government seeks Singaporeans' views, suggestions
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) in Singapore is seeking public feedback on the 2016 budget, which will be presented by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat on March 24. The public can submit views online through the Budget 2016 website or at three listening points across Singapore from Feb 17-21. The feedback exercise will close on Feb 26.

site_title: The bank of Tiger pays dividends
summary: Bank of Tiger pays dividends. No relevant information is provided in the given article.

site_title: Ackman, Herbalife unscathed by probes: WSJ
summary: US government probes into Herbalife and Pershing Square Holdings failed to find sufficient evidence of criminal wrongdoing, according to the Wall Street Journal. The probes, conducted by the US attorney's office and FBI, investigated claims of Herbalife's fraudulent business model and Pershing Square's manipulation of Herbalife's stock. Pershing Square's CEO William Ackman has been a vocal critic of Herbalife, comparing its business model to a pyramid scheme. The investigations may be rekindled if additional evidence is brought forward, but both parties have emerged unscathed so far.

site_title: Trump outshines other celebrities on social media
summary: Donald Trump has outshone other celebrities on social media, racking in nearly 13.5 million Twitter mentions since December 30, surpassing Justin Bieber's 8 million and Kanye West's 6.2 million. Trump's Twitter account has over 5.9 million followers, and he commanded 36% of Twitter traffic during the Republican presidential debate, despite not attending. However, Trump's social media dominance was briefly interrupted by Kanye West's Twitter beef with Wiz Khalifa, and was even surpassed by David Bowie's mentions after his death.

site_title: US warship sails near island claimed by China in South China Sea
summary: A US Navy destroyer, USS Curtis Wilbur, sailed within 12 nautical miles of Triton Island in the Paracel Islands, a disputed territory claimed by China, Taiwan, and Vietnam, in an effort to counter restrictions on navigation rights. The operation, which was similar to a previous exercise in October, challenged China's policies requiring prior permission or notification for transit within territorial seas. China condemned the action, with its defense ministry calling it "intentionally provocative" and vowing to take necessary measures to safeguard national sovereignty and security.

site_title: Digital currency firm co-founder admits to US money laundering charge
summary: Arthur Budovsky, co-founder of Liberty Reserve digital currency service, pleaded guilty to a US money laundering conspiracy charge, admitting he knew the service was used by criminals worldwide to launder over $6 billion. Budovsky faces up to 20 years in prison and is scheduled to be sentenced on May 6. Liberty Reserve, which operated from 2005 to 2013, was used for hacking, child pornography, and drug trafficking, and is considered the largest international money laundering prosecution in history.

site_title: Argentina agrees to borrow US$5 billion from Wall Street banks
summary: Argentina has agreed to borrow $5 billion from Wall Street banks, backed by sovereign bonds, to bolster its reserves ahead of talks with holdout creditors. The one-year loan, finalized Friday, comes as the country seeks to shore up its cash hoard after years of currency controls and depleted reserves. The move aims to increase bargaining power for Argentine authorities in negotiations with the holdout creditors, who are trying to limit the nation's ability to raise money offshore.

site_title: MGCCT's Q3 DPU up 11.6%
summary: MAPLETREE Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 11.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q3 2015, to 1.854 cents, driven by an enlarged portfolio, higher rents, and favorable exchange rates. Gross revenue jumped 19.8% to S$88.2 million, and net property income rose 22.3% to S$72.5 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy reached 98.7% and 92% of leases were renewed or replaced.

site_title: Fed's Williams says sees 'smidgen' slower rate hikes
summary: Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams suggests the Fed may need to keep interest rates lower for longer due to weak global economic growth, a stronger dollar, and low oil prices. He expects slightly slower growth, higher unemployment, and lower inflation this year. Williams' initial forecast for four rate hikes in 2016 has changed, and he now believes the economy needs more monetary accommodation. His "modal" forecast remains unchanged, with a 2% growth rate and inflation returning to the 2% target over the next two years.

site_title: Apple quietly working on virtual reality: report
summary: Apple is reportedly working on virtual reality (VR) technology, with a team of hundreds of employees and a trove of patents related to the field. The company has not commented on the project, but CEO Tim Cook expressed interest in VR during a recent earnings call. Apple is competing with Facebook-owned Oculus Rift and Microsoft HoloLens, which are also developing VR and augmented reality (AR) technology. The technology has various applications, including education, medicine, and entertainment, and is expected to become more prevalent in the market.

site_title: Israel's cyber sector blooms in the desert
summary: Beersheba, Israel, is rapidly transforming into a hub for cybersecurity, dubbed "Israel's cyber capital." The city's industrial park, CyberSpark, has attracted 1,500 tech professionals and 12 companies, including Lockheed Martin and IBM. The government aims to integrate the city with the Israeli army's cybersecurity unit, fostering a collaborative ecosystem. This move follows a 2012 study finding Israel to be a top target for hackers, with over 1,000 web attacks per minute. The city expects a 100,000 population growth in the next decade, with incentives for soldiers and companies to settle in the area.

site_title: China grapples with contradictions over currency
summary: China grapples with a currency conundrum as massive outflows of capital, driven by concerns over its slowing economy, threaten its efforts to control the exchange rate and promote economic reforms. Around $1 trillion left China last year, with nearly $160 billion capital outflowed in December alone. The yuan has retreated against the dollar by 1.3% since January, sparking fears of a hard landing. China's central bank is struggling to balance its desire to promote free capital flows with the need to maintain currency stability, and officials deny plans to devalue the currency amid concerns of a currency war.

site_title: Facebook to prohibit private firearm transactions on its service
summary: Facebook will prohibit users from coordinating private firearm transactions on its service, updating its regulated goods policy that already banned private firearms sellers from advertising "no background check required" or selling across state lines without a licensed dealer. This move comes as the US debates access to guns after a string of mass shootings. Licensed retailers will still be able to advertise firearms on Facebook that lead to transactions outside of the platform.

site_title: Last walled village in downtown HK to go
summary: Hong Kong's last remaining walled village, Nga Tsin Wai, will be demolished to make way for 750 new housing units. The 650-year-old village, built in 1354, is in poor condition according to authorities, who claim it is "decrepit". Residents, who have been told to leave, say the village is their only home and that its destruction will erase their cultural heritage. The demolition has drawn criticism, with advocates questioning the balance between economic development and preserving local culture.

images.alt_text: A PIECE OF OLD HK: Above: Villagers have been moving out of Nga Tsin Wai over the last 20 years, leaving behind a small community.
A PIECE OF OLD: Above: Villager Kwok Yue Ka is one of the last hold-outs.

site_title: Boeing wins deal to build new Air Force One presidential jets
summary: Boeing has won a $25.8 million contract to begin preliminary design work on a new fleet of Air Force One presidential aircraft based on its 747-8 commercial airliner. The US Air Force first announced in January 2015 that Boeing's 747-8 would replace the two current Air Force planes used to transport the US president. The contract is part of the Air Force's efforts to upgrade its presidential transportation capabilities.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB says not contacted by foreign legal authorities
summary: Malaysia's state-owned fund 1MDB stated it has not been contacted by foreign legal authorities regarding possible violations of Swiss law, with suspected misappropriations amounting to approximately $4 billion. 1MDB expressed its commitment to cooperating with lawful authorities and investigations, subject to domestic advice. This comes after Switzerland's chief prosecutor requested Malaysia's assistance in the probe.

site_title: Cast of "Spotlight" wins top prize at Screen Actors Guild Awards
summary: The cast of "Spotlight" won the top prize at the Screen Actors Guild Awards for best ensemble performance in a motion picture. Leonardo DiCaprio took home the best actor award for his role in "The Revenant," and Brie Larson won the best actress award for her portrayal in "Room." These awards mark a notable win for "Spotlight" and recognize the outstanding performances in the film.

site_title: Djokovic masters Murray for sixth Australian title
summary: Novak Djokovic won his sixth Australian Open title, defeating Andy Murray 6-1 7-5 7-6(3) to match Roy Emerson's record. Djokovic dominated the match, winning 22 of the first 29 points and eventually sealing the title on his third match point with a clinical ace. Murray succumbed to his fifth loss in five Australian Open finals, and Djokovic claimed his 11th grand slam title, drawing level with Rod Laver and Bjorn Borg.

site_title: Toyota may halt Japan car output in Feb due to steel shortage
summary: Toyota Motor Corp may halt production at its Japan plants in February due to a steel shortage caused by an explosion at an affiliate's steel plant in January. The company has enough supply inventory to run plants until February 6, but will monitor the situation and make a decision accordingly. A halt is possible from February 8, with overtime at all production plants in Japan set to stop next week. The shortage affects Toyota's domestic manufacturing, which produces around 13,000-14,000 vehicles daily.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp said on Saturday it may halt production at its domestic plants early next month due to a steel shortage following an explosion at a steel plant operated by one of its affiliates.

site_title: Swiss seek Malaysian help probing US$4b financial scandal
summary: Switzerland's Attorney General Michael Lauber has asked Malaysia for help in investigating possible US$4 billion misappropriations by 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a Malaysian state-owned fund. The suspected misappropriations involve bribery, money laundering, and criminal mismanagement. Lauber's investigation has already revealed serious indications of funds being misappropriated from Malaysian state companies. Malaysia's attorney general has cleared Prime Minister Najib Razak of any wrongdoing, but the Malaysian anti-graft agency is seeking a review of the decision.

images.alt_text: Earlier this week, Malaysia's attorney general cleared Prime Minister Najib Razak of any criminal offences or corruption, declaring that US$681 million deposited into his personal bank account was a gift from Saudi Arabia's Royal family.

site_title: New York area ports shut down after dock workers walk out
summary: New York and New Jersey's cargo terminals shut down on Friday after over 1,000 longshoremen walked off the job, bringing the US' busiest port network to a standstill. The walkout, without a permit, occurred at 11am and affects several terminals, including Port Newark and terminals in Elizabeth and Bayonne, New Jersey. The Port Authority urged the International Longshoremen's Association to return to work immediately. The shutdown, which impacts $200 billion in cargo, did not appear to affect energy sector workers or the gasoline and heating oil futures markets.

images.alt_text: New York and New Jersey's cargo terminals shut down on Friday after more than a thousand longshoremen walked off the job, shuttering one of the United States' busiest port networks.

site_title: Boom time again for Norway salmon farmers
summary: Norway's salmon farmers are experiencing a boom, with export prices surging to a 30-year high and profits ballooning. The rebound began in late 2015 after a slump in 2014, when trade sanctions led to a halt in shipments to Russia, a major buyer. Despite a 5% expected reduction in output due to sea-lice outbreaks, the country's seafood exports reached a record high in 2015, with the European Union accounting for about three-quarters of the total. Prices have risen by as much as 53% to 61.64 kroner per kilogram, forcing some fishmongers to raise prices by 3-4%.

images.alt_text: IT'S a pretty good time to be a salmon farmer in Norway. Export prices have surged to a 30-year high, global demand has been growing and profit margins have ballooned.

site_title: Taiwan central bank guides overnight interbank rate lower to 0.20%
summary: Taiwan's central bank lowered the overnight interbank rate to 0.20% on Saturday, following the government's weak fourth-quarter economic data. This move is the second rate cut in 2015 to revive economic growth. The rate cut comes after the central bank guided market rates lower for the first time since late December. The move is aimed at boosting economic growth and supporting the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's central bank on Saturday guided the overnight interbank rate down, a move that came a day after government data showed the economy remained weak in the fourth quarter of last year.

site_title: Hon Hai CEO says Sharp to decide on investment within week
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co CEO Terry Gou said Sharp Corp will decide on a potential investment within a week. Gou presented Hon Hai's offer to Sharp's board on Saturday, stating they were not out to destroy the Japanese tech firm.

site_title: EgyptAir mechanic a suspect in Russian plane crash: sources
summary: EgyptAir mechanic suspected of planting a bomb on a Russian passenger plane that crashed in the Sinai Peninsula in October, killing 224 people. The mechanic's cousin joined Islamic State in Syria, and he allegedly received a bomb to plant on the plane. Two airport policemen and a baggage handler are also suspected of helping him. Despite initial denials, EgyptAir officials have acknowledged that the investigation is ongoing and that the suspects have been detained. The crash has raised concerns about Egypt's efforts to combat terrorism and its impact on the tourism industry.

site_title: Oil rises, pares losses in January on hopes for production deal
summary: Oil prices rose over 25% on Friday, rebounding from 12-year lows, as major exporters considered a production deal to cut supply. This move drew support from weak US GDP growth data, raising hopes the Federal Reserve may slow interest rate hikes. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) renewed calls for joint efforts with rival producers to cut supply, triggering comments from Russia about a potential deal.

site_title: Facebook expands live video streaming in the US via iPhone
summary: Facebook expands live video streaming in the US via iPhone, allowing users to broadcast live to viewers and save streams in a timeline. The feature, initially tested last year, is now available to anyone in the US using the iPhone app. The expansion comes as Facebook reports stellar quarterly earnings, with a 16% stock price surge and a 16% increase in quarterly profit. The move is seen as a rival to live-video streaming mobile apps Meerkat and Periscope, owned by Twitter.

site_title: Thai bank plans to join big regional players
summary: Krung Thai Bank, Thailand's second-largest lender, plans to boost profits and position itself for acquisitions to join the ranks of the biggest Southeast Asian banks. CEO Vorapak Tanyawong aims to close the gap with domestic rivals by 2018 and is considering a regional acquisition to prepare for a merger.
