summary: Hong Kong shares slipped 0.30% on Friday, closing at 19,138.42, while Shanghai and Shenzhen indices also edged down, due to investors dismissing positive cues from Wall Street. The losses follow a two-day advance, with no major catalysts identified.

site_title: Alphabet changes results format to separate Google, other bets
summary: Alphabet Inc. will report fourth-quarter earnings under two segments: Google and "Other Bets." The Google segment will include Alphabet's main internet businesses, such as search and YouTube, while "Other Bets" will detail its other businesses, including Access/Google Fiber and Verily. The move aims to provide greater transparency and fiscal discipline. Investors praised the change, and Alphabet's stock price has climbed 13% since the announcement. The company is close to becoming the most valuable US tech company, surpassing Apple Inc.

site_title: Heartbreak as historic Hong Kong village demolished
summary: A 650-year-old urban walled village in Hong Kong, Nga Tsin Wai, has been demolished to make way for development, leaving behind heartbroken residents who have called it home for generations. The village, once the last of its kind, was deemed "decrepit" by authorities and will be replaced with 750 new flats. Critics argue that the destruction of cultural heritage and community is a loss for the city, while the government claims it is necessary for the city's growing population.

site_title: Indonesia has not yet issued new export permit to Freeport: govt official
summary: Indonesia has not issued a new export permit to Freeport McMoRan Inc, despite the expiration of its six-month permit on Thursday. The permit's issuance is contingent on Freeport paying a $530 million deposit, which the US firm has yet to do. The Trade Ministry is waiting for the Energy and Mineral Resources Ministry's recommendation to proceed with the permit. Without the permit, exports cannot occur, according to Didi Sumedi, a trade ministry official.

site_title: Japan's inflation is still near zero ahead of BOJ decision today
summary: Japan's consumer prices remained near zero in December, with a 0.1% increase, and household spending dropped 4.4% from a year earlier. The jobless rate held steady at 3.3%. Pressure on the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to expand its asset-buying program grows amid declining oil prices and a stronger yen, which erodes exporter advantages. Some economists expect the BOJ to consider further easing, with 6 out of 42 surveyed economists predicting a stimulus boost at the upcoming meeting.

site_title: Reality check: Barbie now tall, curvy and petite too
summary: Mattel has announced a new line of Barbie dolls with three body types: tall, curvy, and petite, marking a 56-year evolution of the iconic doll. The new dolls join the Fashionista line, which also features seven skin tones, 22 eye colors, and 24 hairstyles, aiming to reflect a broader view of beauty. The move is seen as a response to declining sales and criticism of the doll's traditional design, which was criticized for promoting unrealistic beauty standards.

site_title: Asia: Stocks jump, yen weakens as BOJ stuns with negative rates
summary: The Bank of Japan adopted negative interest rates, charging 0.1% for excess reserves, in an effort to stimulate its long-languishing economy. The move sent Asian stocks surging, with the yen falling across the board, while sovereign bonds rallied. The dollar surged over two yen to 121.14, and US debt markets rose as investors expected the Federal Reserve to be less likely to hike rates. Global markets, including the Shanghai benchmark and US stocks, also gained, driven by the promise of extra global stimulus.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened slightly higher on Friday, edging up 3.64 points or 0.14% to 2,566.09. The benchmark Straits Times Index gained ground after Wall Street rose on Thursday. Gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 46, with actively traded stocks including City Developments, Singtel, and DBS. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid a global stocks rally.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sembcorp unit completes sale of 60% stake in gas manufacturer
summary: Sembcorp Utilities has completed the sale of its 60% stake in gas manufacturer Sembcorp Air Products (SembAP) to Eastman Chemical Singapore for approximately S$4 million. Additionally, the group sold its propylene purification plant on Jurong Island for S$5.7 million. As a result, SembAP and its 50% stake in Sakra Island Carbon Dioxide are no longer part of the group.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

Sembcorp Industries' wholly-owned entity Sembcorp Utilities has completed the divestment of its 60 per cent stake in Sembcorp Air Products (SembAP) to Eastman Chemical Singapore for about S$4 million.

site_title: New Japan econ min Ishihara: will carry out Abenomics decisively
summary: Japan's new economy minister, Nobuteru Ishihara, vowed to decisively carry out "Abenomics" economic revival policy after taking over from Akira Amari. Ishihara stated that Japan's economic fundamentals remained unchanged, but external factors affected data. Ishihara's comments follow Amari's resignation due to a funding scandal.

site_title: US dollar slips vs euro after US durable goods orders dive
summary: The US dollar fell 0.4% against the euro after the Commerce Department reported a 5.1% drop in US durable goods orders in December, further indicating a slowing economy. This decline came a day after the Federal Reserve left the door open for a potential March interest rate hike. The dollar's value also dropped against the yen, while the euro rose to 130.00 yen, amid concerns about the US economy and potential stimulus from the Bank of Japan. The Fed's decision to wait for data-dependent factors before increasing interest rates was seen as a signal that a rate hike is not imminent.

site_title: Indonesia central bank deputy gov says rupiah at competitive level
summary: Indonesia's central bank deputy governor, Mirza Adityaswara, stated that the rupiah's current exchange rate against the US dollar is at a competitive level for manufactured goods. The rupiah traded 0.2% stronger at 13,847 per dollar. However, exports remain down due to commodity exports being the primary cause.

images.alt_text: Indonesian rupiah's current exchange rate against the US dollar is at a competitive level for export of manufactured goods, Bank Indonesia's senior deputy governor, Mirza Adityaswara, said on Friday.

site_title: Update: Changi Airport welcomes United Airlines' launch of direct flight to San Francisco
summary: Changi Airport welcomed United Airlines' launch of direct flights to San Francisco, the first non-stop service between Singapore and the US. The flights, operated by a 252-seat Boeing 787-900 Dreamliner, cut travel time by up to four hours each way. United will operate 54 weekly services connecting to six American cities, and the new service will also link Singapore to the US hub in San Francisco, offering greater convenience for business travelers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

Singapore Airlines (SIA), which is the launch customer for the new A350-Ultra Long Range aircraft, will restart direct flights to New York and Los Angeles only from 2018 using the fuel-efficient aircraft.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on weaker yen, Wall St gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, driven by a weaker yen, while Wall Street rallied on a surge in oil prices. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index advanced 0.67% and the Topix index rose 0.62%. The Bank of Japan policy meeting outcome was a focus for investors, but no details were released. The rally on Wall Street was fueled by a surge in oil prices, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: German economic growth was probably minimal in Q4: finance ministry
summary: German economic growth is likely minimal in Q4 2015, with a 0.25% increase forecast, according to the Finance Ministry. The slowdown was caused by weak industrial production, but rising orders suggest a recovery in the coming months. The external environment remains tough due to geopolitical tension and a slowdown in emerging markets, including China. The ministry also noted that refugees will have a minimal impact on employment, with unemployment expected to rise modestly over the year. The economy is expected to recover, but challenges persist.

site_title: House briefs
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) and Temasek individual investments are free from government influence, operating on a commercial basis for long-term, risk-adjusted returns. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that investments linked to environmentally unsustainable practices could negatively impact their value. In contrast, foreigners' hospital bills in Singapore are not subsidized.

site_title: Facebook expands live video streaming
summary: Facebook has expanded its live video streaming feature to anyone in the US using its iPhone application, following its strong quarterly earnings results. The "Live" feature, initially tested last year, allows users to broadcast live video to friends and family. Facebook product manager Vadim Lavrusik praised the feature's potential to connect people, citing its inspiring uses. This move further enhances Facebook's live streaming capabilities, giving users more ways to share experiences and connect with others.

site_title: South Korea's December industrial output growth hits 3-month high
summary: South Korea's industrial output grew 1.3% in December, exceeding expectations, and reaching its highest pace in three months. This provides relief to concerns about the country's economy losing momentum. The growth was higher than a median forecast of 0.3% and reverses a revised 2.1% fall in November. The results are a positive sign for the country's economy, but analysts remain cautious about the overall economic outlook.

site_title: Morgan Stanley South-east Asia banker Khanna said to be leaving
summary: Morgan Stanley South-east Asia investment banker Nehchal Khanna is leaving the firm after over five years, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Khanna, a managing director focused on dealmaking in Malaysia, resigned on Thursday. He was hired from Deutsche Bank AG in 2010 to lead Morgan Stanley's Malaysia investment-banking coverage. The move comes as the US firm ranked eighth among advisers on South-east Asia mergers and acquisitions last year, up from 13th in 2014.

site_title: Oil gains help Aussie and kiwi units after Fed statement
summary: Oil prices rose above US$33 a barrel, helping the Australian and New Zealand dollars gain ground against other major currencies. The Aussie rose 0.6% to its highest level in three weeks, while the New Zealand dollar was 0.3% higher. The mixed performance followed a brief boost for the yen after Japan's Economy Minister resigned amid bribery allegations. The Bank of Japan is set to announce its monetary policy stance on Friday, with traders expecting a 50% chance of easing measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.9 points to 1,640.43. The market saw 165 gainers for every 82 losers, with a total trading volume of 79.4 million lots worth RM45.5 million.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall, hit by weak earnings and banks
summary: European shares fell 1.7% on Thursday, hit by weak earnings from Roche and pressure on euro zone banks. The healthcare sector was particularly affected, with Roche's 3.8% drop after missing profit expectations and disappointing dividend forecast. The Eurostoxx 50 index fell 2.1%, while the FTSEurofirst 300 index dropped 1.7%.

site_title: Microsoft quarterly profit slips but tops expectations
summary: Microsoft reported a quarterly profit of $5 billion on $23.8 billion in revenue, beating expectations. The company's shares rose 3% to $54.08 after the report. Key highlights include a strong holiday season for Surface and Xbox, a 29% increase in Surface tablet revenue, and a 30% increase in Xbox Live users to 48 million. Revenue from Microsoft Azure more than doubled, and the company's "Intelligent Cloud" unit grew 5%. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella attributed the success to businesses using the Microsoft Cloud as a digital platform.

site_title: Samsung warns of bleak 2016 for tech sector
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. reported a 39% drop in quarterly profit, missing analyst estimates, and warned of a bleak 2016 for the tech sector due to slowing demand and economic turbulence. The company joins Apple Inc. in forecasting a downbeat year, with Samsung investing in new screen and semiconductor technologies to boost profit. Global smartphone shipments rose only 6% in the final quarter of 2015, and Samsung shipped 97 million handsets and 9 million tablets. The company will introduce new Galaxy S models and buy back 2.99 trillion won of stock.

site_title: Further downside seen for industrial occupancy, rents, prices
summary: Singapore's industrial space supply is expected to exert downward pressure on occupancy rates, with prices and rents continuing to decline in the fourth quarter of last year. The government's JTC cited wide options for industrialists, but consultants believe business expansion may not occur due to current economic conditions, potentially leading to further drops in rents and prices.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Frasers Hospitality Trust, Ascendas Hospitality Trust, OSIM, Cogent
summary: Singapore stocks experienced significant movements on Friday, with SingPost's stock falling 6.5% to a 22-month low, attributed to market reaction to a letter in The Business Times. Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 7.5% increase in distribution per stapled security, while Ascendas Hospitality Trust saw a 1.45 cents DPS increase. OSIM International reported a 66% decline in net profit due to a one-off loss from the closure of an underperforming subsidiary. Cogent Holdings' board is reviewing the business following indications of interest from prospective buyers, with a potential deal worth over S$400 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Reclaiming Chinatown's identity
summary: Heritage activists in Singapore's Chinatown are working to revitalize the area's Chinese culture and community by rejuvenating unused spaces, jazzing up local heritage, and attracting a younger, more diverse crowd. Efforts include combining heritage with youth culture, hosting events like music festivals and art exhibitions, and collaborating with local businesses and community groups. Despite challenges from bureaucracy and commercialization, supporters believe that a strong sense of identity will remain, and that initiatives like Getai Soul, a music festival, and Spring@Bukit Pasoh, a Lunar New Year festival, will help preserve Chinatown's heritage.

site_title: United Airlines to launch non-stop service to San Francisco from June
summary: United Airlines will launch a daily non-stop flight from Singapore to San Francisco on June 3, using the Boeing 787-9 Dreamliner. The 13,593 km flight will be the longest scheduled 787 flight, offering unique benefits to customers. The airline will provide a one-stop service between Singapore and over 40 US cities, including more than 25 cities without direct flights from Singapore. United will also terminate service between Singapore and Tokyo's Narita Airport on June 2.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Britain delays full sale of state-rescued Lloyds bank
summary: Britain's government has delayed the full sale of state-rescued Lloyds Banking Group due to market turbulence. The Conservative government had been gradually reducing its 43% stake in the lender, returning billions to the state coffers. The stake now stands at around 9%, and the delay is expected to give investors more time to buy shares. Finance minister George Osborne cited market uncertainty as the reason for the delay.

images.alt_text: Britain's government's is to delay selling the final tranche of shares in state-rescued Lloyds Banking Group owing to turbulence in financial markets, finance minister George Osborne said on Thursday.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on oil jump, Facebook profits
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by higher oil prices and strong Facebook earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 125.18 points, the S&P 500 climbed 10.41, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 38.51. The gains were largely attributed to the oil price jump and Facebook's Q4 earnings, which beat expectations.

site_title: From KTV to indie
summary: A new live music bar, Hive by Wala Wala, has opened at Furama RiverFront's annex block, replacing a nightclub. The F&B operator, Stanley Yeo, has invested nearly S$2 million in the 13,800 sq ft space, which features a fully equipped stage, wine retail, and a cigar room. The venue offers a mix of music, casual food, and pocket-friendly prices, aiming to be "down to earth" and appeal to both locals and tourists. The bar serves a variety of food options, including pizzas, Chinese roasts, and Western grills, and plans to host events and workshops, including mini concerts by regional artistes.

site_title: UK announces help for struggling North Sea oil industry
summary: The UK government has announced a £250 million package to support the struggling North Sea oil industry in northeast Scotland, which has been affected by slumping oil prices. Prime Minister David Cameron visited Aberdeen and met with industry leaders, expressing the government's commitment to the sector. The funding aims to boost the industry and alleviate the impact of the oil price decline.

site_title: Iran, France hail 'new relationship'
summary: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani and French President Francois Hollande signed several post-sanctions deals, including a $25 billion Airbus aircraft purchase, a Peugeot return to the Iranian market, and Total's purchase of Iranian crude oil. The agreements aim to establish a "new relationship" between the two countries, with Hollande stating that Iran "can count on France." However, hundreds of protesters gathered in Paris to demonstrate against Iran's human rights record, citing over 2,000 executions since Rouhani's presidency.

site_title: Xerox said to split in two; Icahn gets board seats: WSJ
summary: Xerox Corp will announce a split into two companies, one for its hardware operations and another for its services business, when it reports earnings on Friday. The company will unwind its largest-ever acquisition, and Carl Icahn will be given three board seats on the services company's board.

images.alt_text: Xerox Corp will announce Friday that it's splitting itself into two companies, essentially unwinding its largest-ever acquisition, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing unnamed people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Amazon delivers big profit boost, but shares dive
summary: Amazon reported a 122% profit increase in the fourth quarter, with a profit of $482 million, but shares fell 11% to $565.19 due to missing Wall Street forecasts. Revenue jumped 22% to $35.7 billion, and the company's annual profit was $596 million, with overall revenue reaching $107 billion. Amazon Prime membership has seen significant growth, with 54 million members spending an average of $1,100 per year.

images.alt_text: US online giant Amazon on Thursday reported profits doubled in the past quarter, as it attracted more customers with video and other services, but the results missed Wall Street forecasts.

site_title: GM deceived buyers of used cars subject to recalls, FTC says
summary: General Motors (GM) and two car dealers have settled US claims that they misrepresented the inspection process of used cars, selling vehicles subject to safety recalls without disclosure. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) alleges GM marketed used cars at dealerships with open recalls for defects related to ignition switches, power steering, braking, and airbag deployment. The FTC will continue to monitor car dealers' ads, hoping the settlement sends a message to the market about transparency in safety-related recalls.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co and two car dealers settled US claims that they touted rigorous inspection of used cars, yet were selling vehicles that had been subject to safety recalls and hadn't been repaired.

site_title: Secura dips on Catalist debut
summary: Secura Group, a security solutions provider, made its debut on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on January 28, 2016. The company opened at 24.5 Singapore cents before closing at 22.5 cents, with 30.36 million shares traded. The IPO price was 25 cents per share, and the group plans to use the net proceeds of S$26 million to expand its security guarding business and upgrade its equipment. Despite the initial drop, Chief Executive Paul Lim stated that listing on Catalist would enhance the group's visibility and image.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

SECURITY solutions provider Secura Group, which made its debut on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on Thursday, opened at 24.5 Singapore cents before falling to end the day's trading at 22.5 cents. Some 30.36 million shares changed hands.

site_title: NYSE calls for coordination among exchanges to ease volatility
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has recommended reforms to the US equities market to improve stability and prevent future volatility. The measures include coordinating trading halts when securities prices move violently in a short time, a policy first introduced after the 2010 flash crash that wiped $1 trillion in paper value from US stock markets. The goal is to prevent a repeat of the August 24 wild price swings.

images.alt_text: Wall Street opened lower on Thursday after weak US economic data heightened investors' fears of a slowdown in the economy.

site_title: A purr-fect way to support local music
summary: Local singer-songwriter Ethel Yap performed at "kitty kafe" The Company of Cats as part of its Monthly Mewsic Series, which aims to support the Singapore music scene. The venue's resident cats are known to be fans of the live music, often interacting with the musicians and stealing the show. The concept was born when the cafe's director, Nick Yeo, found the cats enjoying music and thought it would be a great way to support local music. This unique event has been a hit, with the cats becoming a beloved part of the cafe's atmosphere.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Currency markets tell Kuroda he can't turn back the clock on yen
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda faces challenges in weakening the yen, as currency markets indicate a stronger yen is on the horizon. Despite a potential policy meeting, economists surveyed by Bloomberg predict the BOJ will keep its asset-purchase plan unchanged, citing a lack of bonds to buy and the yen's appreciation. A weaker yen is crucial for Kuroda's inflation target and exports competitiveness, but the yen has already climbed over 1% against the dollar this year and is seen strengthening further, making it difficult for the BOJ to reverse the trend.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's securities unit reports Q4 loss on revenue slump
summary: Deutsche Bank's securities unit reported a Q4 loss of 1.15 billion euros, citing a 30% slump in revenue, amid market upheaval and cooling emerging market growth. Co-CEO John Cryan has scaled back trading activities to bolster returns, with the investment bank's revenue falling 4.9% to US$24.2 billion. The bank's shares fell 2.1% to 16.76 euros, and its common equity Tier 1 ratio decreased to 11.1% in 2015. Deutsche Bank's net loss for 2015 was 6.8 billion euros, its first annual shortfall since 2008.

images.alt_text: Mr Cryan is shrinking the debt trading empire to boost profitability. But his efforts have been hurt by litigation expenses and fines.

site_title: Going from art to an immersive, unsettling experience
summary: Singapore Art Week's OH! Open House presents "No Man's Land," an immersive and unsettling experience. The art tour features a series of mysterious and suspenseful events, where attendees are guided through various venues, including a home setting and an actors' format, blurring the lines between reality and fiction. The experience raises sensitive themes, but its extended run until April 10 has generated significant buzz, sparking interest in unconventional art experiences.

images.alt_text: Characters in No Man's Land on set with a multimedia installation designed by Ong Kian Peng (above) and actor Ngo Thu Huong. OH! Open House's latest art tour forces visitors to look deeper into what makes up Singapore.

Characters in No Man's Land on set with a multimedia installation designed by Ong Kian Peng and actor Ngo Thu Huong (above). OH! Open House's latest art tour forces visitors to look deeper into what makes up Singapore.

site_title: Alcoa sees record aluminium shortage even as Goldman predicts glut
summary: Alcoa predicts a record 1.2 million tonne aluminium shortage this year, despite Goldman Sachs forecasting a glut. The US company believes global demand will exceed production due to unprofitable plants holding on longer due to reduced energy costs. This is contrary to predictions from Goldman and other banks, which anticipate a larger surplus. Prices have tumbled 19% last year, the most since 2008, and some producers may be able to stay afloat longer due to government support and weakening yuan.

site_title: STI closes higher as Dow futures rise
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 16.27 points higher at 2,562.45 on Thursday, driven by rising Dow futures and European markets opening in the black. Turnover was below average, with 187 rises and 192 falls. Shares of Singapore Post plummeted 10.6% in two days, while EMS Energy fell 67% in two days with no apparent reason. Pictet's Christophe Donay identified four reasons for the worst start to a new year for equity markets, including monetary policy uncertainty, commodity price drops, China concerns, and a strengthening US dollar.

site_title: Putrajaya unveils measures in revised budget to make good revenue shortfall
summary: Malaysia's revised budget aims to offset a forecast revenue shortfall of RM9 billion by prioritizing projects and optimizing expenditure. The government, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, has introduced measures to boost consumption, including cuts to pension contributions and increased aid to the poorest. Oil prices are now at US$31 a barrel, lower than the government's initial assumption of US$48. The government remains committed to meeting its fiscal deficit target of 3.1% of GDP, despite concerns from economists about the potential impact on the economy.

site_title: FHT's Q1 DPS gets a lift from Sofitel Sydney
summary: FRASERS Hospitality Trust (FHT) reported a 7.5% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.72 cents for Q1 2016, driven by full contribution from its Sofitel Sydney Wentworth acquisition. The company achieved 16.2% growth in gross revenue and 16.9% increase in net property income (NPI) for the quarter, with strong performance in Japan and Australia. Despite challenges in Singapore and the UK, FHT's diversified portfolio enabled it to ride out weaker markets and position itself for future growth.

site_title: SingPost slumps further to 22-month low as volume surges
summary: SingPost's stock price plummeted 6.5% to a 22-month low of S$1.30, falling S$0.09, amid a surge in large trades and volume of 31 million shares. This is the stock's worst performance since the 2008 financial crisis and follows a 4.5% drop on Wednesday. The unusual trading activity drew a query from the Singapore Exchange, which asked SingPost to respond immediately. Some prominent asset managers have also reduced their stakes in the company since the start of January.

site_title: Mortgages offer silver lining for India's banks as business loans ebb
summary: India's banks are experiencing a surge in mortgage-loan growth, with outstanding home loans reaching $103 billion as of November. This growth is driven by demand from smaller towns, which account for nearly a third of total loans made. The mortgage tailwind comes as banks focus on lending to individuals to counter a sluggish corporate-loan market. Home loans pose lower bad-debt risks for banks than corporate loans, and the industry expects an 18% growth in home loans for the fiscal year ending in March.

site_title: Two Singapore films at Berlin Film Festival
summary: Two Singapore films are set to debut at the 66th Berlin International Film Festival: "A Lullaby to the Sorrowful Mystery", a 480-minute epic historical drama, and "Wanton Mee", a telemovie starring Nastassja Kinski. "A Lullaby to the Sorrowful Mystery" is the first Singapore film to be included in the main competition section, marking a significant milestone for the country's film industry. The film is a co-production between Singaporean partners Potocol and Akanga Film Asia, and will compete with 14 other films from around the world for top prizes.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Dividend trend shows strength of S'pore companies
summary: Singaporean companies continue to demonstrate strength despite market concerns. OCBC's CEO Samuel Tsien notes that non-performing loans (NPLs) are at an extremely low level, matching that of DBS Group Holdings, and are unlikely to reach levels seen during the global financial crisis. In fact, several companies are paying higher dividends, indicating underlying strength. The STI ETF's dividend distribution has also increased, with the latest payout being higher than the previous interim. This trend suggests that investors may not need to panic about the market, and companies are instead choosing to return more cash to shareholders.

site_title: Preserving legacy of a forgotten lensman
summary: Mark Shaw, a renowned photographer from the 1950s and 1960s, had his archive of fashion and celebrity shots preserved after his death in 1969. His only son, David, and his wife Juliet Cuming consolidated the negatives, which included 27 covers and over 100 stories for Life magazine, and now promote his work. The archive, which includes images of the Kennedy family, was put into storage and is being restored to promote Shaw's legacy and protect his work, with a recent Asian debut exhibition at Leica Galerie Singapore.

site_title: Oil gain boosts US shares; Fed stance hits other markets
summary: US stocks rose 0.6% and the Dow added 0.8% on Thursday, boosted by a surge in oil prices and gains from large oil companies. The S&P 500 also rose 0.6%, driven by strong earnings reports from Caterpillar and Facebook. However, markets elsewhere, including Tokyo, Paris, London, and Frankfurt, finished lower due to concerns over global growth and the potential for a Federal Reserve rate hike.

site_title: Making an interesting statement
summary: The Dressmaker, a quirky comedy-drama, follows Myrtle "Tilly" Dunnage (Kate Winslet) as she returns to her Australian hometown of Dungatar 25 years after being accused of a killing she doesn't remember committing. Tilly seeks redemption and retribution, using her impeccable fashion sense to transform the town's women and exact revenge on those who wronged her. The film's multiple mood shifts and offbeat material make for an interesting statement, but its style is too all-over-the-place to qualify as a mini-classic.

site_title: China's Wanda says it's reassessing plans for Madrid project
summary: Chinese property giant Wanda is reassessing plans for a historic Madrid skyscraper, Edificio Espana, amid a dispute with the city's government. Wanda acquired the 25-storey building in 2014 and initially planned to turn it into a hotel and shopping center. However, Madrid's new anti-austerity mayor is scrutinizing big building projects, refusing to allow Wanda to demolish the building's facade before reconstructing it. Wanda has dismissed employees in its Madrid office and denied reports that its chairman, Wang Jianlin, was treated "like a dog" by the city's government.

site_title: OSIM Q4 profit slides, gross margins in '15 maintained
summary: OSIM International reported a net profit of S$9 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, down 66% from S$27 million a year ago, due to a one-off loss from the closing of underperforming subsidiary ONI Australia and legal fees. Gross profit margins were maintained in 2015. Despite revenue falling 5% to S$169 million, the company expects 2016 to bring better results, with plans to open 15 new TWG Tea stores and launch new products. Full-year net profit halved to S$51 million.

images.alt_text: AMID a slower retail environment, lifestyle products group OSIM International reported a net profit of just S$9 million for its seasonally strong fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, down 66 per cent from S$27 million a year ago.

site_title: Flatshare website highlights London housing 'crisis'
summary: London flatshare website founder Rupert Hunt is opening his home to lodgers, charging whatever they can afford, to help ease London's housing crisis. His home, in the trendy Spitalfields area, has seen over 7,000 applications for the two spare rooms. Hunt hopes this will inspire others to take in lodgers, reducing demand for housing in the city. London's average house price is £506,724, and officials are discussing solutions, including improving transport links and building more affordable homes, ahead of the May London mayoral election.

images.alt_text: Rupert Hunt appeals for flatmates in his online video.

site_title: Philippine developer not keen to buy China property assets yet
summary: Philippine developer SM Prime Holdings Inc, led by billionaire Henry Sy, is hesitant to buy Chinese property assets due to high asking prices. Despite China's slowing economy, SM Prime plans to expand in the country by adding shopping malls each year until it reaches 10 by 2019. The company aims to sustain 14-15% annual profit growth. SM Prime will continue to operate six malls in China and plans to build apartments near its mall in Chengdu, betting on the project's proximity to a shopping center.

site_title: Noble continues to have support of bankers: CEO
summary: Noble Group secured shareholders' approval to sell its remaining stake in its agriculture unit, Noble Agri, to Cofco International for $750 million. The move aims to strengthen the company's balance sheet and boost liquidity. CEO Yusuf Alireza expressed confidence in the group's ability to roll over debts and access cheap bank funding. Noble has a US$2.2 billion credit revolving facility due in May and US$360 million of bonds maturing in the next few months.

site_title: MAS to supervise exchange members
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will take over supervising exchange members, focusing on statutory requirements, while exchanges will handle risk management and trading rules. The change aims to reduce duplication and improve market surveillance, with MAS having full knowledge of activities and exposures across exchanges. The new framework takes effect this year, and MAS is investing in technology to enhance surveillance capabilities.

site_title: Roads to the future versus bridges to nowhere
summary: China's President Xi Jinping's "One Belt, One Road" plan aims to connect China with western Europe and other parts of the world, not to link the entire Eurasian continent. The plan is driven by economic potential, particularly in the populous regions at its extremes, and is seen as a pragmatic move by Xi. China is funding infrastructure projects in Europe and other countries, while nations in between opt into the plan for benefits. The project includes energy networks and has the potential to create economic activity and wealth, although its implementation has been met with skepticism from leaders in Japan and the US.

site_title: Mitsubishi Estate raises 250b yen in biggest bond sale this year
summary: Mitsubishi Estate Co raised 250 billion yen in its largest Japanese corporate bond sale this year, attracting yield-hungry investors with riskier notes. The four-part deal included 75 billion yen of 60-year notes at a yield of 1.02%, compared to 0.01% on Japanese government notes. This sale follows recent offerings by other Japanese companies, with total subordinated debt issued last year reaching 2.3 trillion yen, the highest in six years. Mitsubishi Estate has an AA- grade from Japan's Rating & Investment Information Inc.

site_title: Fair-value gains boost Yoma's Q3 earnings to S$25.2m; revenue falls 5%
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a net profit of S$25.16 million for Q3 2015, boosted by fair-value gains of S$27.7 million from its telecom tower business. Revenue fell 5% to S$23.75 million due to lower sales of residences and land development rights. The group expects a continual contribution from its telecom tower investment, which it can sell at a minimum valuation of US$40.25 million. Earnings per share rose to 1.45 Singapore cents, driven by growth in its non-real estate businesses.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hotel Lotte to list in largest Korea IPO since 2010
summary: Hotel Lotte Co, a South Korean conglomerate's lodging unit, may list on the Korea Stock Exchange as early as May, potentially the largest IPO since 2010. The move comes amid a power struggle between chairman Shin Dong Bin and his elder brother for control of the group, which has promised to improve corporate governance. The IPO could also give momentum to other Lotte Group affiliates, including data communication and convenience store units, and help reduce stakes held by Japanese affiliates.

site_title: GrabTaxi rebrands as Grab to reflect services
summary: GrabTaxi rebranded as Grab, a ride-booking platform offering private cars, motorcycle taxis, social carpooling, and last-mile delivery, asserts its market dominance in South-east Asia with 95% market share. Grab reported 200,000 drivers and 11 million app downloads across 28 cities since its launch in 2012. The rebranding aims to show Grab's services beyond taxi booking, prompting concern from rival Uber and industry watchers. Grab's market analysis and growth are disputed by Uber, which claims record-breaking growth in trip volume in the region.

images.alt_text: In the private cars sector, Grab reportedly has over half of the market share, a figure which Uber disputes. Uber regional GM Mike Brown says its data is closely held.

site_title: MBS adjusted earnings for Q4 down 35%
summary: MBS adjusted earnings for Q4 2015 fell 35% to US$338.2 million, down from US$338.2 million in the same period last year. Net revenue declined 16% to US$703.9 million, mainly due to a 21% drop in casino revenue. Despite this, the hotel segment saw a 4% decline in room revenues, while food and beverage, convention, and retail segments posted revenue increases of 9%, 12%, and 9% respectively. MBS maintained its position as the most profitable LVS property.

site_title: After win against Lyft, lawyer turns focus on Uber
summary: A lawyer who won a $12.25 million settlement from Lyft to change its treatment of drivers now vows to force Uber to overhaul its business model, citing a stronger case against the ride-share company due to a federal judge's ruling that Uber's arbitration agreement couldn't be enforced. Lyft will revise its contract to allow drivers to be deactivated only in specific circumstances, and pay fees related to arbitration claims. Uber's case is headed for trial in June, with a potential victory threatening to upend the company's business model and cut into its $60 billion valuation.

site_title: Japan's Dec retail sales fall unexpectedly as BOJ board mulls stimulus
summary: Japan's retail sales unexpectedly declined 0.2% in December, contradicting forecasts of a 1% increase. The drop, combined with weak inflation data, raises concerns about the economy's growth. The Bank of Japan is set to decide on monetary stimulus during a two-day meeting. Economists predict a possible stimulus boost, with 6 of 42 surveyed expecting a move, citing a rise in food prices and decreased consumer spending sentiment. The central bank's decision will be announced around midday on Friday.

site_title: Boost for role of major Asian economies in the IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has begun implementing governance reforms aimed at increasing the "voice and votes" of major Asian economies, including China and India. The reforms, which were ratified by the US Congress last month, increase the IMF's permanent capital base to $660 billion and give more representation to emerging markets. For the first time, countries like Brazil, China, India, and Russia will be among the 10 largest members, and the IMF's executive board will consist entirely of elected executive directors, ending appointed positions.

images.alt_text: Governance reforms enhancing the "voice and votes" of China and India, among other emerging economies within the International Monetary Fund have begun to take effect this week, while the IMF's capital base is also being beefed up significantly.

site_title: Long-term investments key to achieving nation's dreams
summary: Singapore's next 50 years of independence require long-term investments to strengthen the nation's foundations, including a retooled education system to foster innovation and equip the population with future skills. The country must also re-examine its rules and cultural norms to create a more inclusive society. Lawmakers have proposed various measures, including a more accountable government and increased diversity in the Elected Presidency, but risk being tempted by short-term gains over long-term goals, which could hinder progress in achieving Singapore's ambitious vision.

images.alt_text: As a new Parliament takes its place and Singapore embarks on its next 50 years of independence, now is the time to pick a destination for the future and, just as importantly, figure out how to get there.

site_title: Commodities junk debt faces more pain with contagion threat: UBS
summary: UBS warns that the prolonged oil slump is expected to cause more pain for commodities-related debt, with energy bonds falling 10% this year. The market may not be adequately pricing in defaults or compensating investors for risks, leading to wider spreads. If oil remains low, high-yield spreads in commodity sectors could reach up to 3,000 basis points, the report states. This could spread beyond the commodities markets, increasing the risk of contagion in the leveraged-finance market.

site_title: The origins of graffiti
summary: Graffiti art originated from an insular group that operated in studios, planning pieces with sketches and experimenting with new techniques. The art form evolved from spray-painted calligraphy, with notable contributions from artists like Dondi White, Noc 167, and Lady Pink. Graffiti enthusiasts, like Alain-Dominique Gallizia, distinguish their art from vandalism, emphasizing artistic merit and respect for the art form's history. The exhibition "Pressionism: Graffiti Masterpieces on Canvas" showcases the evolution of graffiti art, featuring over 500 works from 200 artists, until June 25 at Singapore Pinacothèque de Paris.

images.alt_text: "I am totally against vandalism - with graffiti art, I'm not talking about those who splash colours on the wall and destroy public property," says Mr Gallizia.
Jay One Ramier's Farewell, entirely executed with spray bomb, has established the graffitist's considerable skill at precise pressure control.

site_title: Asian art from far-flung corners
summary: The Prudential Eye Awards, showcasing art from "greater Asia," has seen improvement in its diversity and judging criteria. The third edition features 15 nominees from less-established art scenes, including Cambodia, Bangladesh, and Thailand. Winners include Thailand's Tawan Wattayu for painting, India's Manish Nai for a formal exploration of billboards, and Cambodia's Sareth Svay for a work drawing on the country's political context. The exhibition, now open at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore, runs until March 27.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Thailand's Tawan Wattayu creates figurative images using very dilute watercolour. He paints quickly, adding details such as eyes and lips on the still wet pools of paint - as seen in this work.

site_title: PayPal, eBay Q4 earnings validate pressure to split the companies
summary: PayPal's Q4 earnings beat forecasts, with revenue increasing due to a growing customer base and transaction volume. The company added 6.6 million new customer accounts, while eBay's sales stalled during the holiday season. PayPal's CEO Dan Schulman attributed the company's success to its one-touch buy button and growing digital payment options, which benefits prominent brands. In contrast, eBay's struggles have led to a 5.3% decline in its stock price, with CEO Devin Wenig seeking to "sharpen its focus" by simplifying the site and offering unique products.

images.alt_text: Mr Schulman (left) says the growing number of e-payment options is creating confusion, which benefits PayPal. Mr Wenig is struggling to entice shoppers and merchants back to eBay at a time when they have increasing alternatives and when consumers expect fast, free delivery offered by Amazon.

site_title: Small completed apartments worst price performer in 2015
summary: Singapore's completed small condo units and apartments were the worst performers in the NUS price index in 2015, with a 4.3% decline in prices. This marks a reversal from 2013 and 2014, when they were the most resilient segment. Experts attribute the decline to the realization that these units are often smaller than expected, making them less attractive to tenants. As a result, owners may be forced to sell or rent out the properties at a loss.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Boeing posts solid Q4 profit but stumbles on jet delivery forecast
summary: Boeing reported a solid Q4 profit, exceeding analyst estimates, but its jet delivery forecast fell short due to internal production issues and a decline in wide-body sales. The company expects 740-745 jet deliveries this year, down from 762 in 2015, and plans to reduce output of its 777 model. Despite this, Boeing's sales forecast and operating cash flow are expected to rise, and the company will increase its share repurchase authorization to $14 billion. The stock declined 8.9% due to the disappointing forecast.

site_title: Global platinum body seeks to lift demand for the metal here
summary: The World Platinum Investment Council (WPIC) has joined the Singapore Bullion Market Association (SBMA) to promote investor demand for physical platinum in Singapore. WPIC aims to increase demand for platinum from the current single-digit range to 10-15% in the next three to four years. The partnership will also help Singapore strengthen its position as a hub for precious metals trading and investment, with plans to tie up with dealers to sell platinum bars and coins, and launch platinum exchange-traded funds.

site_title: Minister's sudden resignation deals blow to Abe
summary: Japan's economy minister, Akira Amari, resigned suddenly on January 28, 2016, to "take responsibility" for allegations of accepting bribes from a construction firm. Amari denied any wrongdoing, but his resignation is a blow to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration, which is under stress with "Abenomics" policies. Amari had been instrumental in Japan's entry to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). His resignation may influence the Bank of Japan's policy meeting and could damage Abe's chances of winning an upper house election later this year.

site_title: The 4th Industrial Revolution and the US dollar dilemma
summary: The Fourth Industrial Revolution, driven by artificial intelligence, is expected to exacerbate the divide between developed and emerging markets. The US dollar dilemma is a key concern, as the US's technological innovation and investment attractiveness maintain its structural strength, potentially harming emerging markets. Countries pegged to the US dollar face increased competitive pressures, while rising US dollar strength could also affect emerging market manufacturing jobs, demographics, and employment. This shift may favor developed market assets over emerging market ones, highlighting the need for emerging markets to invest and counteract this disadvantage.

site_title: It's pure torture to watch De Niro here
summary: The movie "Dirty Grandpa" stars Robert De Niro as a 72-year-old man who coerces his grandson to drive him to Florida for a spring break adventure, where he seeks to score with younger women. Despite De Niro's generally high-quality performances, his role in this film is deemed a "total wrong number" as he leers at young women and engages in crude antics. The movie has been panned for its juvenile humor and poor writing, making it a frontrunner for worst movie of the year.

site_title: The breadth of life, in 5 rooms
summary: Joan Jonas' exhibition "They Come To Us Without A Word" at the NTU Centre of Contemporary Art in Singapore has received critical acclaim. The show, which debuted at the Venice Biennale, features a unique blend of performance, dance, video, music, and other elements in five rooms, including "Bees," "Fish," "Mirrors," "Wind," and "Homeroom." Jonas explores themes of environmental degradation and mortality through playful and childlike visuals, ultimately conveying a sense of delight in the possibilities of life. The exhibition is now open until April 3.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Performance art pioneer Jonas fills all the rooms of the exhibition with video projections, drawings and objects to evoke a strange waking dream, filled with import and meaning.

site_title: Spotify to raise US$500m in convertible debt issue
summary: Spotify plans to raise at least $500 million in new funding through a convertible debt issue, aiming to compete with Apple and other music streaming services. The company, valued at $8.4 billion, has raised over $1 billion since its founding in 2006. Spotify has 75 million users, with 20 million paying subscribers, and operates in 58 countries, including Japan, where it is rumored to be expanding. The funding may help the company prepare for a potential initial public offering or acquisition.

site_title: Elected presidency: Don't set eligibility bar too high
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong proposes revising the eligibility criteria for presidential candidates, aiming to increase the pool of qualified individuals. The current criteria require public sector officials to have held key appointments or private sector candidates to have held comparable positions in large corporations with a paid-up capital of at least S$100 million (approximately S$158 million in today's dollars). The proposal seeks to balance the need for strong candidates with the desire to maintain a diverse and representative pool of options for voters.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust Q3 DPS up despite fall in revenue
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 3.8% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.45 Singapore cents for Q3 FY2016, despite a 9.5% decline in gross revenue to S$54.9 million. Net property income dropped 9.3% to S$23.4 million due to the loss of income from Pullman Cairns International and lower events in Brisbane. The trust attributed improved performance to the China portfolio and potential growth in Japan. A potential takeover by Starwood Capital Group and Fosun International is also on the horizon, with offers expected as early as the end of January.

site_title: Freeport downgraded 4 steps to junk by Moody's
summary: Freeport-McMoRan's credit rating was downgraded four levels to junk status by Moody's due to a collapse in copper and crude prices, weakening the company's finances. The rating cut to B1 from Baa3 affects senior unsecured credit ratings, with bonds tumbling. Moody's notes that Freeport's debt is six times earnings, and the company's ability to adjust to a lower price environment is uncertain, leading to a potential sale of assets.

site_title: Reasons for optimism about the long term
summary: The global economy is expected to slow down, with the IMF forecasting a 3.4% growth rate next year, down from 3.6% previously. This slowdown is attributed to overcapacity in industries such as shipping and manufacturing, which has led to a surplus of vessels and ships. However, China's infrastructure development, particularly its "One Belt, One Road" initiative, is seen as a positive factor for the long-term future. President Xi Jinping's commitment to infrastructure investment and development is expected to stimulate growth and create jobs.

site_title: Let there be (sustainable) light
summary: The i Light Marina Bay sustainable light art festival is returning for its fourth edition, featuring over 20 light art installations from local and international artists. The festival's theme, "In Praise of Shadows," aims to challenge the notion that brighter is better and promote sustainability. This year's installations include works by local tertiary institutions, such as the National University of Singapore, and will be accompanied by over 40 programmes and events. The festival will be held from March 4 to 27 at the Marina Bay waterfront promenade, with admission being free.

site_title: SGX to relook minimum trading price, quarterly reporting in sweeping review
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is reviewing its rules and regulations, including automatic penalties for short-selling, minimum trading prices, quarterly reporting, and dual class shares. CEO Loh Boon Chye announced changes aimed at boosting interest in the equities market, such as removing penalties for buy-in trades and reviewing the minimum trading price calculation. The review is part of SGX's efforts to increase transparency and provide more timely information to investors.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is looking into a raft of potential changes to the structure of the stock market, including scrapping automatic penalties for buy-in, reviewing its calculation of minimum trading prices and studying the need for quarterly reporting and dual class shares, chief executive Loh Boon Chye announced on Thursday.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Major offshore oil and gas (E&P) companies are slashing budgets by 20-30% in 2016, marking the first time since the 1980s for consecutive budget reductions. Ezion Holdings is expected to incur a $700 million writedown, leading to a net gearing of 2.8x. Starhill Global Reit is recommended to buy with a target price of S$0.84 due to limited downside risks, while OUE Commercial Reit is recommended to hold with a target price of S$0.65 due to a challenging office sector outlook.

images.alt_text: Major offshore E&P companies are slashing budgets by a further 20-30 per cent in 2016, according to Bloomberg Intelligence.

site_title: City buzz
summary: The Laneway Festival 2016 is set to take place in Singapore, featuring a diverse lineup of indie music acts, including Battles, Grimes, and Thundercat. The festival will also include a fourth stage by dance collective Syndicate, showcasing local and international electronic DJs and visual artists. Meanwhile, Comedy Masala's open-mic comedy sessions continue to be a popular Tuesday night event, and French restaurant Cocotte offers a special Moules Frites Mondays promotion.

images.alt_text: Flying the Singapore flag are homegrown talents Cashew Chemists (left), Intriguant and Riot in Magenta, just to name a few.
Comedy Masala
Fennel cream.
"Golden Royale"
Charulatha Mani

site_title: Sweden's mortgage lender mulls over further loan curbs
summary: Sweden's state-owned mortgage lender SBAB is considering further measures to curb its exposure to the nation's housing market amid soaring prices. The bank's CEO Klas Danielsson said it may lower the loan-to-income ratio from 6 times to 5.5 times and could also require clients to amortise debt exceeding 70% of property values. This follows the bank's previous measures, including capping loans at 6.5 times income and tightening amortisation rules. The bank aims to ensure financial stability and stabilize housing prices, which Danielsson believes will stabilize in 2016.

site_title: HK's Hang Lung may not release any units this year as prices dip
summary: Hang Lung Properties chairman Ronnie Chan suggests the developer may not release any units for sale in Hong Kong this year due to declining housing prices. With prices predicted to fall by up to 20%, Chan stated the company has no pressure to sell, as it has low debt and only released 66 units in 2015. The company reported a 56% drop in net profit due to a 88% decline in Hong Kong property sales, with 694 units remaining unsold.

site_title: Fed acknowledges slower growth, leaves rates unchanged
summary: The Federal Reserve acknowledged the US economy has slowed, but left interest rates unchanged. The central bank signaled it would raise rates four times this year, but recent market turmoil has raised doubts. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, below forecast.

site_title: Abterra's independent director resigns
summary: Abterra's independent director, Victor Chew, has resigned due to new work assignments and commitments requiring extensive overseas travel and business development. Chew was chairman of the remuneration committee. This comes as the company faces scrutiny from the Singapore Exchange, which reprimanded Abterra, its executive chairman, and CEO for breaches of listing rules.

site_title: Widening gap between China, HK trade figures raises fake trade concerns
summary: China's imports from Hong Kong surged 64% year-over-year in December, while Hong Kong's exports to the mainland rose just 0.9% from a year earlier. This widening gap in trade figures raises concerns about capital outflows and potential money laundering. The discrepancy may prompt Beijing to take stricter measures to curb suspicious transactions.

site_title: Facebook thrives as ads and users turbocharge sales growth
summary: Facebook reported a 52% increase in fourth-quarter sales, driven by its ability to serve targeted ads to its vast user base. The company's shares rose 12% following the announcement. Facebook's success in capitalizing on user information for advertising has solidified its position as a major player in the digital advertising market.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US climbed last week to three-month high
summary: US consumer confidence rose to a three-month high, reaching 44.6 in the period ended Jan 24, up from 44 the prior week. This marks the seventh consecutive week of improvement, driven by favorable views on the buying climate and finances. Key factors include sustained confidence, cheaper gasoline, and rising home prices, which indicate households are looking past unsteady global markets and are optimistic about the economy and incomes.

site_title: Dec business equipment orders drop most in 10 mths
summary: US businesses significantly reduced equipment orders in December, marking the largest drop in 10 months. Non-military capital goods bookings fell 4.3% and all durable goods orders declined 5.1%, the largest decrease since August 2014. This suggests companies are cutting capital investment before the turmoil in global financial markets.

site_title: 'Plane debris' washes up on Malaysian east coast
summary: A metal object believed to be plane wreckage washed up on the Malaysian east coast, prompting speculation that it may be debris from missing Malaysian Airlines aircraft MH370. The object, measuring 2 meters long and white, was found in the waters near the town of Besut in the eastern state of Terengganu. Officials have said that debris does not belong to MH370, but are investigating the finding. This is the second time in a week that debris has surfaced in the area, following a similar discovery on Saturday in the Nakhon Si Thammarat province in Thailand.

site_title: Hamptons home prices hit new high as buyers grab US$5m properties
summary: Hamptons home prices reached a new high in the fourth quarter, with the average price of US$2.38 million, a 16% increase from last year. This marks the highest price since 2005, according to a report by Douglas Elliman Real Estate and Miller Samuel Inc. The surge in prices is attributed to buyers securing properties worth at least US$5 million, making it a record number of deals in the area.

site_title: Nico Steel changes auditor after 'no agreement' over fees
summary: Nico Steel Holdings has changed its auditors from KPMG to Baker Tilly due to a disagreement over professional fees. The company aims to manage costs and enhance the value of the audit. The appointment of Baker Tilly is contingent on shareholder approval. This change is part of the company's efforts to optimize business expenses amidst a challenging business climate.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: OCBC Bank announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO, with Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, being named her successor. The bank reported strong earnings, with revenue and net profit increasing. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Tesla marked its formal entry into the Indian market with a launch event in Mumbai, and Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in the second half of the year. These developments indicate a mix of economic growth and market shifts.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit's Q3 DPU up 0.7% at 2.85 cents
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) reported a Q3 FY2016 DPU of 2.85 cents, a 0.7% increase from the previous year. Gross revenue rose 9.5% to S$32.55 million and net property income edged up 2.7% to S$21.06 million. Distribution to unitholders stood at S$18.11 million, a 2.2% increase.

site_title: Gas tariff to be 3.8% lower in Feb-April as fuel costs decline
summary: Singapore's City Gas Trust announced a 3.8% decrease in gas tariff for households from February 1 to April 30, 2016, due to a 16% drop in fuel costs. The new tariff will be 16.80 cents per kilowatt hour, down from 17.47 cents per kWh.

site_title: Implementing IoT innovation in Industry 4.0
summary: The Internet of Things (IoT) is expected to revolutionize industrial performance and efficiency in Asia, with Bosch predicting over 14 billion connected devices by 2022. Industry 4.0 adoption is driven by the competitive nature of the industry and high accountability for technology implementation. IoT innovation in manufacturing can streamline processes, increase efficiency, and reduce costs, making it a key area for development in the industry.

site_title: 2015 job growth in Singapore at a 12-year low
summary: Singapore's employment growth in 2015 reached a 12-year low, with a total of 31,800 new jobs, according to the Ministry of Manpower. The growth was flat at 0.9% due to a soft economy and limited foreign worker supply. Most job growth came from foreign manpower, while locals experienced flat employment gains. Despite a low unemployment rate of 1.9%, redundancies increased, with 14,400 layoffs in 2015, the highest since the 2009 recession. Economists predict a continued two-tiered job market, with low-wage jobs dominated by foreigners and higher-skilled jobs dominated by citizens.

site_title: Apple to voluntarily recall some AC wall plug adaptors
summary: Apple is voluntarily recalling AC wall plug adapters used in Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Continental Europe, New Zealand, and South Korea due to a rare risk of electrical shock. The two-prong adapters, shipped with Mac and iOS devices from 2003-2015, have been linked to 12 incidents worldwide. The recall does not affect adapters for other countries or Apple's USB power adapters. Apple shares dropped 0.2% in morning trading.

site_title: China export threat to europe jobs needs deeper probe, EU says
summary: The European Union is re-examining its decision on recognizing China as a market economy, a move that could impact EU jobs and tariffs on Chinese goods. Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstroem said the EU needs a deeper probe into the potential threat to jobs, citing China's "huge" steel over-capacity and dumping in Europe. The EU is considering the impact of such a decision, which would require approval from national governments and the European Parliament. Malmstroem emphasized that the decision is not only technical but also economic, social, and political.

site_title: A weekend of Swedish cinema
summary: The Embassy of Sweden in Singapore is hosting the first Swedish Film Festival from January 28 to 31, in collaboration with indie cinema The Projector. The festival features a curated selection of Swedish films, marking the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Sweden and Singapore. The event aims to introduce Singaporeans to the Swedish film phenomenon, showcasing a range of movies suitable for diverse audiences.

images.alt_text: Force Majeure (above) is about a perfect Swedish family on an uncomfortable but hilarious journey through the French Alps while Trespassing Bergman is a documentary about the legendary Swedish filmmaker that dwells not only into his own life, but also the way his work has influenced scores of directors around the world.

Force Majeure is about a perfect Swedish family on an uncomfortable but hilarious journey through the French Alps while Trespassing Bergman (above) is a documentary about the legendary Swedish filmmaker that dwells not only into his own life, but also the way his work has influenced scores of directors around the world.

site_title: Pacific Andes Resources tells bondholders it cannot commit to next coupon due Jan 30
summary: Pacific Andes Resources Development informed bondholders it cannot commit to the next coupon payment on Jan 30, citing existing cash constraints. The company's holding company is exploring the sale of its Peruvian business to two buyers at an indicative enterprise value of US$1.7 billion, which could lead to a satisfactory settlement of the bonds. An informal committee of bondholders will be established to discuss the situation and a line of communication. The company prioritizes preserving cash for its ordinary business operations.

site_title: Shell has to repay investors who backed its biggest ever wager
summary: Royal Dutch Shell faces pressure to deliver promised benefits from its record acquisition of BG Group, as the company's value has dropped to the lowest in over 10 years due to slumping oil prices. Over 80% of shareholders backed the deal, but concerns remain about the sustainability of the dividend. Shell must improve its efficiency and cash generation to cope with the volatile oil market, with analysts calling for a more focused approach to address the challenges.

images.alt_text: Shell booked a US$7.9 billion writedown in the third quarter of last year after abandoning projects in Alaska and Canada.

site_title: Nomura joins varsity to invest in startups
summary: Keio University and Nomura Holdings Inc have partnered to raise 10 billion yen (S$120 million) over 10 years to invest in startups, aiming to boost Japan's venture capitalism efforts. The joint venture, led by Keio University CEO Kotaro Yamagishi, will focus on supporting startups and fostering innovation. This collaboration seeks to bridge the gap between academia and the financial sector, promoting entrepreneurship and economic growth in Japan.

site_title: Ford earnings soar on US auto boom, stronger Europe
summary: Ford reported a 4.1-fold increase in annual profits to $7.4 billion, driven by a US auto boom and a return to profitability in Europe. US sales rose 5% to 2.5 million vehicles, while Europe's operating profit surged to $259 million after restructuring efforts. This offset an annual loss in South America. Ford confirmed its 2016 revenue and earnings forecasts and expects to continue building on its strengths.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as oil soars on hopes of output cut
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, tracking a surge in crude oil prices, which jumped nearly 6% after Russian officials discussed cutting oil output to boost prices. The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, but investors are closely watching economic data and corporate earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.71%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indices also increased. Energy stocks led the gains, with Caterpillar and Facebook rising 6.1% and 13.4%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Wall Street was higher on Thursday morning, tracking a surge in crude oil prices, a day after the US Federal Reserve gave little indication of slowing the pace of future rate hikes.

site_title: The right way to build a modern retail firm
summary: Retailers face challenges in building a modern retail firm by relying on benchmarks. A case study shows that a retailer attempted to create an omnichannel strategy by making every merchant an omnichannel merchant, but it failed due to lack of investment in capabilities, alignment, and decision rights. To succeed, retailers must identify their unique strategy and make targeted investments in capabilities, such as coordination and quick decisions across channels. They should also redefine metrics and incentives to encourage the right behaviors and develop cross-channel capabilities to build the next generation of omnichannel leaders.

images.alt_text: A company aiming to differentiate on shipping speed and reliability will have different answers from one aiming to excel on in-store experiences.

site_title: US pending home sales almost flat in December
summary: US pending home sales index rose 0.1% to 106.8 in December, missing economists' expectations of a 0.8% increase. This indicates a mixed housing market, with pending sales still up 4.2% from the same month last year. The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate in mid-December, causing mortgage rates to initially rise before dropping below pre-rate increase levels. Regional sales varied, with a 6.1% increase in the northeast due to milder temperatures.

site_title: Workforce growth likely to fall to 1-2% in next five years
summary: Singapore's workforce growth is expected to decline to 1-2% between 2016 and 2020, with stagnation expected beyond that period due to the aging population and retirement of baby boomers. Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say made this announcement during a media briefing.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim said a mindset shift must take place in which companies keep improving their human resource practices so that they have a strong Singaporean core as well as a strong commitment to keep investing in human capital.

site_title: Political diversity crucial for good politics, says WP's Low
summary: Workers' Party chief Low Thia Khiang stated that political diversity is crucial for good politics, enabling a resilient system to withstand shocks and turbulence. He made the comment in Parliament, agreeing with President Tony Tan Keng Yam, who emphasized the need for Singapore to get its politics right. This emphasizes the importance of diverse perspectives in governance, potentially supporting the role of Non-Constitional Members of Parliament (NCMPs) in Singapore's political landscape.

images.alt_text: Political diversity is crucial to conducting good politics, which leads to the building of a resilient system that can withstand "shocks and turbulence", said Workers' Party chief Low Thia Khiang on Thursday.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts eyes Europe for more acquisitions
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is exploring opportunities for hotel acquisitions in Europe, particularly in the UK, Holland, Germany, Spain, and Ireland. The trust's CEO, Vincent Yeo, sees the euro as an "interesting entry point" from an asset value and currency perspective. CDLHT owns 15 hotels and resorts globally, with a focus on mitigating lower income from its properties in Singapore. The trust is also considering acquisitions in Australia, Japan, and New Zealand, and is watching the market for potential opportunities, including the M Social hotel in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
In Europe, the euro is now at an "interesting entry point" from the asset value and currency perspective, says Vincent Yeo

site_title: US durable goods orders plunge in December
summary: US durable goods orders declined 5.1% in December, the largest drop since August, due to lower oil prices and softer global demand. This signifies weakened economic growth at the end of 2015. The decline was in line with economists' forecasts, which also pointed to a strong dollar as a contributing factor.

site_title: Thakral Corp founder's son to become firm's CEO
summary: Thakral Corp appoints Inderbethal Singh Thakral, son of the founder, as CEO effective February 1, 2016. Inderbethal was previously managing director of the lifestyle business and joined the board in 1994. Following the sudden death of Jaginder Singh Pasricha, Kartar Singh Thakral will lead the investment division. This change comes as the company navigates its business operations.

site_title: MAS to take over some member supervision duties from exchanges, leave listings to self-regulation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will take over some member supervision duties from exchanges and will leave listing decisions to self-regulation. The change aims to improve market surveillance and reduce the burden on exchanges, which will focus on risk management and trading rules. MAS will provide an additional layer of oversight and will have full knowledge of member activities across exchanges. Exchanges will continue to self-regulate listing rules, with the Singapore Exchange remaining the primary listing authority. The new framework will take effect this year.

site_title: Japan Abe: wants new econ minister to continue structural reforms
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wants new economy minister Nobuteru Ishihara to continue structural reforms, calling them "critical" for Japan's deflation and growth. Ishihara, a former ruling party executive, was appointed to succeed outgoing economy minister Akira Amari, who resigned over a political funding scandal. Abe aims for Ishihara to use his full capacity to push through reforms, which are at a "critical juncture" for Japan's economy.

site_title: JPMorgan plans to hire in Saudi Arabia as Kingdom weighs reforms
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to hire 65 more people in Saudi Arabia as the country weighs reforms to diversify its economy. The move comes amid a drop in oil prices and efforts to reduce reliance on exports, including asset sales and opening its stock market to foreign investors. The bank's CEO, Bader Alamoudi, stated that there are opportunities in volatility, particularly in government reform measures and privatizations. Saudi Arabia's economic growth forecast has been cut to 1.2% by the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Why Goldman Sachs says US$30 oil isn't proof of weak demand
summary: Goldman Sachs' head of commodities research, Jeff Currie, disputes the notion that US$30 oil is a sign of weak demand, citing a widening time-spread between short-term and long-term oil futures. Instead, he attributes the price decline to structural supply forces, including excess supply and producers hedging sales. The low prices are causing "binding constraints" on the oil market, straining producers' ability to access capital and finance operations, and will ultimately lead to a new equilibrium, potentially triggering a bull market. This process will be protracted and arduous, with prices swinging between $20 and $40 a barrel.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust manager appoints Soilbuild Reit manager's ex-CEO as CFO and COO
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) has appointed Shane Hagan, former CEO of Soilbuild Reit's manager, as its CFO and COO, effective immediately. This comes after David Mason, CIT's former COO and CFO, resigned in January to pursue new opportunities. Hagan has prior experience as CFO at Mapletree Commercial Trust and Lippo Mapletree Indonesia Retail Trust.

site_title: A refugee will be a torch bearer in 2016, Olympic committee says
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has announced that a refugee will be a torch bearer in the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics. The torch will pass through a refugee camp in Athens, Greece, before arriving in Brazil, where one refugee will be among the torch bearers. This move aims to draw attention to the problems faced by refugees, with IOC President Thomas Bach stating that "we want to draw the attention of the world to the problems of the refugees." The torch relay will take place over 100 days, with refugees participating in the games under the Olympic flag.

site_title: US jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US jobless claims fell to 278,000 in the week ended Jan 23, beating economists' forecasts of 282,000. This suggests the labor market recovery remains intact despite recent economic slowdown and a sharp stock market sell-off. The drop in claims, the largest since July, indicates improving employment conditions.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits fell from a six-month high last week, suggesting the labour market recovery remains intact despite a sharp stock market sell-off and signs the economy has lost significant momentum.

site_title: VW chief casts doubt on whistleblower's account of emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller has cast doubt on a whistleblower's account of the company's emissions scandal, stating that he has not spoken with the whistleblower and that the information may come from sources without knowledge of the matter. Mueller also downplayed expectations for the release of VW's investigation results before its shareholders' annual general meeting on April 21. The company's supervisory board will hold a meeting on Wednesday to discuss the scandal, which has been ongoing for over four months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is reviewing its rules, including scrapping automatic buy-in penalties and reviewing its minimum trading price (MTP) calculation. Singapore's employment growth in 2015 was the lowest since 2003, growing 0.9% to 31,800. Noble Group CEO Loh Boon Chye said the company has bank support despite recent share sales and debt reduction. The market also saw a decline in industrial space prices and occupancy rates, and a rebranding of GrabTaxi to Grab. Malaysia trimmed its growth expectations due to declining oil prices.

site_title: Morgan Stanley Southeast Asia banker Khanna said to be leaving
summary: Morgan Stanley Southeast Asia investment banker Nehchal Khanna is leaving the firm after more than five years, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Khanna, a managing director focused on dealmaking in Malaysia, resigned Thursday. He was hired by Morgan Stanley in 2010 from Deutsche Bank AG to lead its Malaysia investment-banking coverage.
