The firm ranked eighth among advisers on Southeast Asia mergers and acquisitions last year. A Hong Kong-based spokeswoman for Morgan Stanley declined to comment.

site_title: India names 20 cities for US$7.5b smart makeover
summary: India has named 20 cities for a $7.5 billion smart makeover, aiming to provide uninterrupted power and water supplies, proper sanitation, and public transport. The cities, including New Delhi, Chennai, Jaipur, and Udaipur, will have internet connectivity and quality infrastructure by 2022. The plan aims to boost investment and create jobs, but faces criticism for being a slow starter. The move is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal to create 100 smart cities, with 35 million people living in the targeted cities.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust's Q3 DPS up 11.5% at 1.45 cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a Q3 FY2015/2016 DPS of 1.45 Singapore cents, up 11.5% from the same quarter last year. Gross revenue fell 9.5% to S$54.9 million and net property income dropped 9.3% to S$23.4 million, mainly due to the loss of income from Pullman Cairns International and lower contributions from other hotels. Despite this, the company believes hotels in Japan, particularly in Tokyo and Osaka, will perform better due to the growing trend of foreign visitors to Japan and a renovation project expected to be completed by March 2016.

site_title: Japan's 'Abenomics' Minister Amari to resign over graft scandal
summary: Japanese Economy Minister Akira Amari has resigned amid allegations of financial impropriety, including taking cash from a construction company. Amari, a key figure in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" program, apologized for the scandal and said he took responsibility for the actions in his office. The allegations come at a critical time for Japan's economy, which is trying to recover from deflation. Amari's resignation is the fourth ministerial exit due to financial impropriety, raising concerns about Abe's ability to maintain stability before upcoming elections.

site_title: US fed funds rate steady after FOMC statement
summary: The US Federal Reserve left its target fed funds rate unchanged at 0.38% for a fourth consecutive day, as expected. The average effective fed funds rate traded in a range of 0.33-0.56% for a third day. The Fed's policy setting group, the Federal Open Market Committee, maintained its target range of 0.25-0.50% after raising it from zero to 0.25% in December.

site_title: London home presales slump 19% as demand damped by sales taxes
summary: London's home presales have slumped 19% in the fourth quarter, with demand damped by rising sales taxes and global market turmoil. The UK capital's presales fell to 5,216 units from 6,444 in the same period last year. The market is polarizing towards expensive mansions and affordable homes, with the middle market, valued between £1,000-£2,000 per sq ft, under pressure due to high prices compared to rents. Currency fluctuations and economic uncertainty are also affecting demand, with foreign investors selling homes and some struggling to afford repayments.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust posts 1.72 cents in Q1 DPS
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 1.72 cents distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q1 2016, a 7.5% increase from the same period last year. The trust's gross revenue and net property income reached S$31.38 million and S$26.33 million, respectively, driven by strong performances in its Japan and Australian properties. CEO Eu Chin Fen attributed the results to the acquisition of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth in July 2015, which contributed significantly to the trust's growth.

site_title: Buy-in penalties, quarterly reporting targeted in sweeping review of SGX rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is reviewing its rules, including eliminating automatic buy-in penalties for short-sellers and revising its minimum trading price calculation. Quarterly reporting and dual-class shares are also under review. The exchange aims to simplify regulations and build for the future, with some changes delayed until 2018 to avoid excessive changes. SGX has also teamed up with the Institute of Banking and Finance to provide training for trading representatives and is exempting them from certain business conduct requirements.

site_title: OSIM Q4 profit plunges 66% to S$9m
summary: OSIM International reported a 66% plunge in net profit to S$9 million for its Q4 2015, due to slower sales and one-off losses. Revenue fell 5% to S$169 million. The company proposes a final dividend of two Singapore cents a share, unchanged from last year. Founder Ron Sim expects better results in 2016, despite market uncertainty.

site_title: Oil prices higher as volatility grips crude market
summary: Oil prices rose Thursday as volatility gripped the market, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate up 11 cents to $32.41 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude up 36 cents to $33.46 a barrel. The gains were driven by hopes of stimulus measures in the eurozone and Japan, as well as market talk of a possible OPEC meeting to limit supplies. Despite a record high in US commercial crude stockpiles, prices have been boosted by a pledge of nearly $10 billion by Russia's economy minister to tackle the country's financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were higher Thursday after yet more volatile trading, as dealers reacted to further evidence of a supply glut and hints at possible action to reverse the market slide.

site_title: German inflation inches up in January, state data suggest
summary: German inflation rose to 0.3-0.7% in January, exceeding market expectations, according to preliminary state data. This increase is attributed to higher food costs, and experts predict the European Central Bank may cut its deposit rate again in March to stimulate low inflation. The ECB has kept its options open, with President Mario Draghi suggesting further action could be taken as early as March. This move could embolden proponents of central bank stimulus, despite the European Central Bank's 2% inflation target still being far off.

images.alt_text: German retail sales dipped in December, marking a weak end to the year and suggesting private consumption, which has been a pillar of support for Europe's largest economy, could lose steam in the fourth quarter.

site_title: SATS to sell Senoko Way property for S$15m
summary: SATS Ltd plans to sell a property at 22 Senoko Way for S$15 million, following an option to purchase granted by its subsidiary, Country Foods. The sale is subject to approval from Jurong Town Corporation and relevant regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: SATS Ltd said on Thursday it plans to sell a property at 22 Senoko Way for S$15 million. This transaction was made through an option to purchase that was granted by its subsidiary, Country Foods, to Thong Siek Food Industry. The option was exercised on Thursday.

site_title: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba's revenue jumps 32%
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba reported a 32% year-over-year revenue increase to $5.33 billion in the December quarter, beating analyst forecasts. Despite China's slowing economy, Alibaba's net income more than doubled to $1.93 billion and gross merchandise volume rose 23% to $149 billion. The company attributed its success to its mobile leadership and the successful Singles Day shopping event, which saw $14.3 billion in online sales. Alibaba's shares have been hammered by concerns over China's economic growth, but the company's strong quarterly results suggest resilience.

images.alt_text: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba saw its revenue jump 32 per cent year-on-year for the quarter ending in December, it said in a statement Thursday, despite slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Amazon says Exclusives store sales top US$50m in first year
summary: Amazon's Exclusives store, a platform for products not available anywhere else, has generated US$50 million in sales in its first year, with over 120 brands listed. This represents a small fraction of Amazon's total site sales, which are largely driven by third-party merchants. Exclusives serves as a key avenue for Amazon to get first dibs on new products and target niche shoppers. The company plans to expand the site, which lists 10,000 products, and is attracting more merchants with its Fulfillment by Amazon program, which offers fast shipping and loyalty benefits.

site_title: Euro-area economic confidence declines to lowest in five months
summary: Euro-area economic confidence declined to 105 in January, the lowest in five months, according to the European Commission. This drop was more than expected, strengthening the European Central Bank's case for increasing stimulus. Confidence in industry and services fell, while consumer confidence also deteriorated amid uncertainty over global economic prospects. The ECB's President Mario Draghi has held out the prospect of yet-looser monetary policy as early as March to nurture growth and bring inflation back in line with the institution's goal of just under 2%.

site_title: Samsung Life to buy Samsung Electronics stake in Samsung Card for US$1.3b
summary: Samsung Life Insurance Co Ltd will acquire Samsung Electronics' 37.5% stake in Samsung Card Co Ltd for US$1.3 billion. This move consolidates control of Samsung Group's financial arms under the life insurer, as part of the conglomerate's efforts to streamline its ownership structure and cement the founding family's control. Samsung Life already owns 34.4% of the credit card business, making this deal a significant expansion of its financial presence.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.99 points to close at 1,634.53 on Wednesday, driven by 348 gainers and 522 losers in 1.82 billion lots valued at RM2.46 billion.

site_title: China: Shares flounder again, but "real economy" sound says state media
summary: China's stock market continued its downward trend, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 2.9% and the CSI300 index shedding 2.6% on Thursday, taking losses this month to about 25% or $2 trillion. State media attributed the market volatility to investors' expectations of a potential devaluation of the yuan, but insisted that the real economy remains strong. The People's Bank of China has been providing liquidity to the banking system, but investors remain cautious due to concerns about growth and capital outflows.

site_title: EU takes aim at multinationals' multi-billion tax avoidance
summary: The European Commission proposed measures to tackle corporate tax avoidance by multinational companies, allowing EU countries to tax profits generated in their territories even if transferred elsewhere. The proposals aim to deter aggressive tax planning and close loopholes that enable companies to avoid and evade taxes. Big corporations legally avoid taxes of up to €70 billion annually, with global losses estimated between $100 billion and $240 billion. The measures must be approved by all EU member states and include ceilings on interest deductions and requirements for companies to reveal financial data.

site_title: Shanghai carbon exchange aids first custody contract to build trade
summary: The Shanghai Environment and Energy Exchange announced its first "custody contract" allowing a brokerage to borrow permits from a local company and trade them. This move aims to inject liquidity into a depressed market, where permits have been trading at near-historical lows. The contract, signed with Wujing Thermal Power Plant, allows the brokerage to borrow 2 million permits with a 30% margin, with profits shared between the parties. The deal is seen as a risk-free move, as the Shanghai exchange will support the banking of older local permits for the national market.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.2% and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index down 0.6%. The Paris CAC 40 also dipped 0.4%. The declines followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks. US markets continued to edge towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: S Korea contemplates consumption boosting measures: minister
summary: South Korea's vice finance minister, Choi Sang-mok, stated that the government is considering measures to boost consumption as signs of a slowing household spending emerge. Choi noted that recent government efforts to stimulate consumption may be losing effectiveness, and the government may need to implement microeconomic measures. This comes as the country watches the private consumption situation closely, indicating potential policy changes to support economic growth.

site_title: Prices of completed condos fall 0.4% in December: NUS index
summary: Prices of completed condos in Singapore fell 0.4% in December, according to the National University of Singapore's Residential Price Index. The decline was mainly driven by a 0.6% drop in central region prices, where homes in districts 1-4 and prime residential districts 9-11 saw a decrease. Small units (up to 506 sq ft) remained unchanged in December, after a 1.3% drop in November.

site_title: Ceiling collapse at Philippines' biggest airport injures passenger
summary: A ceiling collapse occurred at the Philippines' biggest airport, Manila International Airport, slightly injuring a foreign passenger. The collapse involved a facade with overhead lights, not the building's concrete ceiling. Airport authorities will investigate if substandard materials were used. The incident follows a series of incidents at the facility, which has a reputation for poor conditions and safety concerns.

site_title: In US oil capital Houston, no cheap fuel bonanza for airlines
summary: Airlines in Houston, a major US oil hub, are offering steep discounts to attract energy executives, as the city's travel market has become a rare point of downward pressure on airline revenues due to the 70% drop in oil prices over the past 19 months. Airlines such as United Continental and Delta Air Lines are adjusting their prices, with average round-trip business and first class tickets to London and Calgary falling by 14% and 59%, respectively. Despite this, US airlines have benefited from lower fuel costs, adding hundreds of millions of dollars to their bottom lines, but some are now re-negotiating terms with airlines.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end firmer despite mainland tumble
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.8% to 19,195.83, despite mainland China's market decline. The Hang Seng Index and China Enterprises Index gained 0.9% each. Notable losses were seen in Hangfat Ginseng (-91.4%), CCT Land (-4.0%), and Jun Yang Financial (-2.1%). Total trading volume reached 2.0 billion shares.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q4 profit down 41% in absence of one-off gain
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 41% decline in fourth-quarter net profit to S$14.6 million due to the absence of a one-off gain from the previous year. The company's revenue rose 28% to S$143.4 million, driven by higher sales in its property segment. The decline was attributed to the absence of a significant gain from the acquisition of Grand Hotel Group.

images.alt_text: Property group Tuan Sing Holdings said on Thursday fourth-quarter net profit fell 41 per cent in the absence of a one-off gain from the year-ago period.

site_title: Nomura says Kuroda waiting too long risks irreversible damage
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is at risk of "irreversible damage" to its economic recovery efforts if it fails to intervene in the currency market, according to Nomura Holdings Inc. Analyst Yunosuke Ikeda predicts the yen will reach 130 this year, and the BOJ must act to prevent a weakening currency from scuppering investment and wage increases. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has been thwarted in his quest for a virtuous cycle of demand-led inflation, and Ikeda believes the central bank needs to shock markets again to reignite the trend for a weaker currency.

site_title: Australia: Shares close 0.6% higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to close at 4976.20, driven by a hunt for dividend yield and merger activity. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand remained stable. This move counters Wall Street's poor performance, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Australian shares bucked a poor performance by Wall Street to edge 0.6 per cent higher on Thursday, aided by a hunt for dividend yield and more merger action.

site_title: UK annual GDP growth slows to weakest in nearly 3 years in Q4
summary: Britain's economy ended 2015 on a soft note, with annual GDP growth slowing to its weakest in nearly three years. The fourth-quarter growth rate was 0.5%, up slightly from the previous quarter, but below the 2.1% growth rate in the third quarter. Despite domestic demand remaining resilient, the slowdown suggests the robust growth of the past two years will not return until the global economy regains strength.

images.alt_text: Britain's economy ended 2015 on a soft note after the annual pace of growth slowed to its weakest in nearly three years as the global economic slowdown weighed on its previously rapid expansion.

site_title: Indonesia telecoms firm blocks Netflix over local laws, censorship
summary: Indonesia's state-owned telecoms provider, Telkom, has blocked access to Netflix due to non-compliance with local laws, including obtaining a business license and censoring content deemed "porn" or "radical". The ban, which affects 70 million Netflix subscribers, may be lifted if the company meets these requirements. Netflix's expansion into 130 new markets, including Indonesia, was halted due to the block. Telkom has stated the ban is temporary and will be lifted if Netflix complies with local regulations.

images.alt_text: Indonesia said on Thursday a decision by the country's biggest telecoms provider to block Netflix could be reversed if the global video-streaming giant obeyed local laws, particularly on "porn" and "radicalism".

site_title: As it happened: Low Thia Khiang in Parliament on Thursday
summary: Low Thia Khiang, Workers' Party chief, commented on the President's address in Parliament, a day after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong proposed changes to Singapore's political system. No further details were provided.

site_title: China central bank to increase open market operations during Lunar New Year
summary: China's central bank will increase open market operations between Jan 29 and Feb 19 to maintain liquidity during the Lunar New Year. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) will allow more banks to participate in short-term liquidity operations, providing one- to three-day direct lines of credit to commercial banks. This move aims to supplement monetary policy tools and support market stability during the holiday period.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said on Thursday it will increase the frequency of open market operations between Jan 29 and Feb 19 to maintain liquidity in the market during the Lunar New Year.

site_title: Singapore shares close slightly higher after rise in Dow futures, Europe
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 16.27 points to 2,562.45, driven by a 120-point gain in Dow futures and Europe's opening in the black. Turnover was below average at S$901 million. Shares in Singapore Post and EMS Energy plummeted, with SingPost falling 6.5% and EMS Energy dropping 55%. The market's latest entrant, Secura Group, closed at S$0.225 on its debut. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing market uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia trims growth expectations as burden shifts to consumers
summary: Malaysia trimmed its 2016 growth expectations to 4-4.5% due to the decline in oil prices, which crimped exports and government revenue. Prime Minister Najib Razak plans to boost consumer spending by reducing mandatory employee contribution rates to the national pension fund by 3 percentage points, aiming to increase private spending by RM8 billion annually. The government maintains its budget deficit target of 3.1% and is taking "prudent measures" to save RM9 billion in operating and development expenditure.

images.alt_text: Malaysia trimmed its growth expectations for 2016 after a decline in oil prices crimped the outlook for exports and government revenue. Prime Minister Najib Razak is counting on consumers to hold up the economy, finding ways to put more money in their pockets.

site_title: HSBC curbs mortgage offering to Chinese citizens in US
summary: HSBC has stopped providing mortgages to some Chinese nationals who buy real estate in the US, amid China's efforts to limit capital outflows. The policy change affects Chinese nationals holding temporary visitor 'B' visas with majority income and assets in China. This move comes as China battles a swelling crowd of citizens trying to shift money offshore for higher returns, and as international banks compete to lend to wealthy Chinese.

images.alt_text: HSBC said on Friday that its personal banking websites in the UK have been suspended after a cyber attack, its second major service outage this month.

site_title: Secura opens lower on trading debut
summary: Secura Group, a security solutions provider, made its trading debut on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on January 28, 2016. The company opened at 24.5 Singapore cents, lower than its IPO price of 25 cents per share. As of 9:51am, 17.61 million shares had changed hands, and its warrants were trading at S$0.01.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat, won drops after Fed meeting
summary: South Korean stocks remained flat at 1,897.38 points, despite concerns about the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes. The won dropped 0.4% against the dollar, reaching a one-week low. Investors are cautious due to global economic turbulence, with the US economy showing resilience.

site_title: Noble Group repurchases part of bonds due 2018, 2020
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-listed commodity trader, repurchased US$31.6 million of its 2020 bonds and US$1 million of its 2018 bonds, trimming its debt amid a commodity market downturn. The company, which has a total of US$2.5 billion worth of loans due this year, is holding an extraordinary shareholders' meeting. Noble shares opened down 1.8% at S$0.27, near a 12-year low. The repurchases are part of the company's efforts to address its debt after attacks on its accounting practices.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebounds from early drop, won cuts loss
summary: South Korean shares rebounded 1.6% from a session low, closing at 1,906.94 on the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI). The won, however, pared losses against the dollar, closing at 1,208.5 per dollar. The rebound comes as investor appetite for risk assets regains momentum.

site_title: Philippine growth at one-year high as state spending kicks in
summary: The Philippine economy expanded 6.3% in the fourth quarter of 2015, the fastest pace in a year, driven by domestic consumption and government infrastructure spending. This growth is expected to continue, with the World Bank forecasting an expansion of over 6% this year and through 2018. President Benigno Aquino's efforts to increase spending and rising consumer spending are helping shield the nation from weak global demand, despite potential external headwinds.

site_title: Najib unveils measures to claw back RM9b of lost oil revenue through a 'recalibration' of Budget 2016
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak unveiled measures to claw back RM9 billion of lost oil revenue in a 'recalibration' of Budget 2016, following a sharp decline in oil prices. The government will reschedule non-physical projects to save RM5 billion, while prioritizing affordable homes, schools, and security. Najib emphasized the government's commitment to prudently spending on projects with high impact, despite the current global downturn.

site_title: OECD countries agree to share info to combat corporate tax avoidance
summary: More than 30 OECD countries agreed to share information about multinationals to combat corporate tax avoidance. Under the new rules, multinationals will report country by country how much they make and what they pay in taxes, aiming to stop firms from exploiting loopholes and minimizing tax payments. This move is part of a push for transparency following public anger over large corporations using tax avoidance strategies.

site_title: UBS has a warning for those seeing China stock respite
summary: UBS warns Chinese investors that a potential bottom of 2,500 for the Shanghai Composite Index may be threatened by forced sales of shares by companies that pledged their stocks to secure loans. As stocks plummeted 48% since June, thousands of companies are facing margin calls, and about 8% of Chinese market capitalization is at risk of selling holdings to pay back debts. The forced sales could increase significantly if the market declines further, putting pressure on the stock market.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Wall St losses
summary: Tokyo shares dropped 0.61% on Thursday, following a weak lead from Wall Street, as the US Federal Reserve hinted at more interest rate hikes this year. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell to 17,059.84, while the Topix index fell 0.55%. The US stock market ended the day at fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: China: Stocks head for longest losing streak in three weeks
summary: China's stocks fell 0.8% to 2,712.48, marking the third day of losses, amid concerns about a weakening economy and yuan volatility. The Shanghai Composite Index is at risk of its longest losing streak in three weeks, with analysts predicting a bottom at 2,500. Industry groups led declines, with material and industrial stocks falling at least 1.9%. The week's net injection of 590 billion yuan into the money markets was the biggest since February 2013, but policymakers are increasingly resorting to administrative measures to curb capital outflows.

site_title: Hotel Lotte to list as early as May in largest Korea IPO since 2010
summary: Hotel Lotte Co, a South Korean lodging and duty-free sales unit, may list on the stock exchange as early as May, potentially the largest South Korean IPO since 2010. The IPO could give momentum to other Lotte Group affiliates, including Lotte Data Communication Co, Korea Seven Co, and Lotteria Co. Lotte Chairman Shin Dong Bin has promised to improve corporate governance after a power struggle with his brother. The IPO's size and price range have not been disclosed, but estimates range from US$3 billion to US$5 billion.

site_title: Noble shareholders approve sale of remaining stake in Noble Agri (Amended)
summary: NOBLE Group shareholders approved the sale of their remaining 49% stake in Noble Agri to Cofco International with 90% of votes cast in favor. The sale is aimed at helping the group shore up liquidity in a difficult environment, with Noble Group receiving US$750 million. The lower sale price compared to the initial US$1.5 billion sale is attributed to a weaker commodity market.

site_title: Noble Group CEO says banks behind it as agri deal approved
summary: Noble Group's CEO, Yusuf Alireza, stated that the company's banks continue to support it, despite recent losses and a junk credit rating. Shareholders approved the sale of Noble Agri Ltd to Cofco Corp for at least $750 million, which will help improve liquidity and reduce debt. The company has $2.6 billion of maturing debt that can be rolled over, and has repurchased $31.6 million of senior notes. Noble Group's shares remain unchanged, but the company aims to restore confidence and improve its credit rating metrics.

site_title: Widening gap between China, Hong Kong trade figures raises fake trade concerns
summary: China's official trade figures with Hong Kong widened sharply in December, with China's imports from Hong Kong surging 64% and Hong Kong's exports to the mainland rising 11%. This discrepancy is the largest since 2006 and has raised concerns of fake trade and financial arbitrage. Analysts believe market players are using the wide spread between onshore and offshore yuan foreign exchange rates to disguise arbitrage activities. China is trying to curb capital outflows and has suspended new applications for the Renminbi Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor scheme.

site_title: US crude falls back after jumping on hopes of Russia, Opec cooperation
summary: US crude futures fell 1% in Asian trading, paring gains of nearly 3% from the previous session, after Russia hinted at cooperation with Opec to control global oversupply. The decline was capped by a weaker dollar following the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. US crude lost 33 cents at $31.97 a barrel, settling up 85 cents at $32.30 a barrel, a 2.7% gain, on the previous session.

site_title: Ringgit gain leads emerging markets, budget review in spotlight
summary: The Malaysian ringgit rose 0.6% to a seven-week high, as investors expect the government to revise its budget review due to declining oil prices. The currency strengthened despite Brent crude falling below the government's budget assumptions, with analysts saying sentiment has improved after the commodity's bounce above $30 a barrel. The government had forecast economic growth of 4-5% this year, assuming oil at $48, but the decline in oil has largely been priced in, according to senior economist Trinh Nguyen.

site_title: Singapore employment growth in 2015 slowest since 2003: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment grew by 31,800 in 2015, a 0.9% increase, the lowest since 2003, according to the Ministry of Manpower. This was driven by a slowdown in sectors like manufacturing and real estate services, offset by growth in administrative and support services. Foreign employment also grew at a moderate pace of 22,600. Median income for citizens rose 6.5% in nominal terms, and redundancies increased to 14,400 for the year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL Hospitality Trusts, AA Reit, Yoma, SingPost
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 3.8% decrease in distribution per stapled security to 3.01 Singapore cents for Q4 2015, down from 3.13 cents a year ago. The trust's net property income slipped 2.2% to S$37.81 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: EBay forecast misses estimates as marketplace growth stalls
summary: eBay missed analysts' earnings estimates, projecting profit of 43-45 cents per share in the current quarter, down from 48 cents. The company's sales growth stalled, with US$2.32 billion in fourth-quarter sales unchanged from last year. eBay faces competition from Amazon and is working to improve traffic from Google's search engine. Analysts say the company has lost its competitiveness and is guiding to declining profits this year.

images.alt_text: EBay Inc projected earnings that may miss analysts' estimates as growth on its marketplace stalled, revealing that shoppers went elsewhere during a holiday season that saw online spending reach new heights. Shares fell as much as 11 per cent in extended trading.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fluctuate after Fed; crude oil declines with metals
summary: Asian stocks fluctuated after the Federal Reserve signaled a gradual interest rate hike due to turmoil in global markets. US crude oil declined, and metals fell, while South Korea's won dropped. Japan's shares fluctuated, and Chinese stocks in Hong Kong gained, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1%. The Fed acknowledged uncertainty in the US economy and injected funds into China's financial system to keep borrowing costs low.

images.alt_text: Asian stocks swung between gains and losses after the Federal Reserve flagged risks to the US economy from turmoil in global markets and indicatedit will be gradual in raising interest rates. Oil led a retreat in commodities, while South Korea's won dropped.

site_title: GrabTaxi now Grab; rebranding reflects all services
summary: GrabTaxi rebrands as Grab, reflecting its expanded services beyond taxis, including private cars, motorcycle taxis, social carpooling, and last-mile delivery. The platform has experienced significant growth, with a 35% average monthly growth in GrabCar rides and a 75% growth in GrabBike rides. Grab now has over 200,000 drivers and 11 million mobile downloads across 28 cities in Southeast Asia, aiming to make transportation accessible to everyone. The company has also introduced app enhancements, including a faster booking experience and live driver tracking.

images.alt_text: Grabtaxi is now known as Grab, in a rebranding that the South-east Asian ride-booking platform says will reflect all of its services beyond just taxis, which include private cars (GrabCar), motorcycle taxis (GrabBike), social carpooling (GrabHitch) and last mile delivery (GrabExpress).

site_title: Smartphone shipments hit record high in 2015: report
summary: Smartphone shipments reached a record high in 2015, with 1.43 billion units shipped worldwide, a 10% increase from the previous year. Chinese handset makers, particularly Huawei, drove the growth, with the company shipping 106.6 million units for the year, surpassing 100 million for the first time. Samsung remained the top smartphone maker, shipping 324.8 million units, while Apple shipped a record 231.5 million iPhones, despite warning of a potential decline in sales.

images.alt_text: More than 1.4 billion smartphones were shipped worldwide last year in a new high for the sector with Chinese handset makers racking up the biggest gains, an industry tracker said Wednesday.

site_title: Prices, rents of industrial space slip further in Q4: JTC
summary: Industrial space prices and rents in Singapore declined 1.5% and 1.1% respectively in Q4, with a 1.7% and 2.1% drop in full-year figures. Transaction volumes were also lower, with only half the level seen a year ago. This year, an estimated 2.9 million sq m of industrial space will come online, significantly exceeding the average annual supply and demand of 1.7 million sq m and 1.2 million sq m. JTC notes that there is "ample space options available for industrialists" with around 2,100 units of uncompleted factory space available for sale.

images.alt_text: The upcoming supply of industrial space this year is expected to exert further downward pressure on occupancy rates, said JTC on Thursday.

site_title: Platinum industry group to develop more investment products in Singapore
summary: The World Platinum Investment Council (WPIC) has partnered with the Singapore Bullion Market Association (SBMA) to develop more investment products in Singapore, aiming to stimulate investor demand for physical platinum and increase Asian investment options. Singapore, a major wealth management market with $0.5 trillion in assets, is seen as an attractive hub for precious metals trading and investment. The partnership is expected to strengthen the country's position as Asia's precious metal trading hub, complementing the industry's efforts to consolidate its presence.

images.alt_text: Singapore, which has seen a flurry of activity in its gold sector in recent years, could now see platinum take off in a similar way as the World Platinum Investment Council (WPIC) ramps up its promotional work here.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares flat in early trade
summary: Malaysia's shares are flat in early trade on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.11 points to 1,631.43. Volume was 151 million lots worth RM59 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 166 to 101.

site_title: Last Swiss bank settles in US$1.37b tax evasion programme
summary: The US has ended a three-year tax evasion programme that forced Swiss banks to disclose secret methods helping Americans evade taxes. Eighty Swiss banks, including HSZH Verwaltungs AG, agreed to pay US$1.37 billion in penalties, clearing the way for prosecution of other excluded firms. HSZH paid US$49.8 million to settle, admitting it helped US clients deceive the IRS.

site_title: Flash: Singapore's total employment up 0.9% in 2015, slowest annual growth since 2003
summary: Singapore's total employment grew 0.9% in 2015, the slowest annual growth since 2003, amid sluggish global economic conditions and a tightened supply of foreign manpower. The annual average unemployment rate remained unchanged at 1.9% for overall, 2.8% for residents, and 2.9% for citizens.

site_title: Samsung Electronics posts 40% fall in Q4 net profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 40% drop in Q4 net profit, with October-December net profit at 3.22 trillion won (S$3.9 billion), below analyst expectations. The company's mobile division struggled with slowing smartphone demand, while weaker chip prices impacted its semiconductor unit. High-end competition from Apple and cheaper players like Huawei and Xiaomi also contributed to the decline. The result marked a 39.7% decline from the same period last year.

site_title: Apple loses lustre on fears that 'wow' days over
summary: Apple shares dropped 6.5% to $93.80 after reporting the slowest sales growth of its iPhones, sparking concerns about the end of a technological era. The company warned of worse sales to come, citing a shift from wowing the world with innovations to making steady money from loyal device users. This marks a significant change in Apple's business model, as the company has long relied on its ability to create revolutionary products to drive growth.

site_title: Bombardier shares fall below C$1 for first time in 25 years
summary: Bombardier shares fell below C$1 for the first time in 25 years, closing at 99 cents Canadian on January 27, 2016, amid the company's struggle to sell its new CSeries passenger jets. The decline puts the company at risk of being pushed out of major Canadian indices. The stock has fallen 26% since the start of 2016, and Bombardier is preparing to enter service for the jet after years of delays and cash problems.

site_title: Changi Airports Int'l to cooperate with Airports Authority of India on civil aviation
summary: Changi Airports International (CAI) has been nominated by Singapore Cooperation Enterprise to cooperate with the Airports Authority of India (AAI) on civil aviation, following a memorandum of understanding signed in November 2015. The partnership aims to promote bilateral cooperation in civil aviation, starting with airport management in Ahmedabad and Jaipur. This marks the first step for CAI to explore cooperation with AAI, with the goal of enhancing regional air connectivity and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Vietnam targets economic growth of up to 7% annually by 2020
summary: Vietnam aims to achieve an average annual economic growth rate of 6.5-7.0% by 2020, according to the country's ruling Communist Party. The growth target, which was approved by 98.74% of party members, is part of the five-yearly congress that re-elected Nguyen Phu Trong as the party's top post. The goal is part of Vietnam's efforts to maintain its position as one of the world's fastest-growing economies.

site_title: Can a besieged Malaysian PM fix the faltering economy?
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is set to announce tweaks to the country's budget, which was previously recalibrated due to slumping oil prices. The move comes as Najib faces public cynicism over allegations of graft and a financial scandal. The economy's underlying strength is tied to basic commodities, and a prolonged commodity slump could hit it hard. Najib's government is under pressure to balance the budget by 2020, but revising the fiscal deficit target could lead to a credit rating downgrade and increased borrowing costs. The fate of Najib's leadership hangs in the balance as he seeks to steady the economy amidst a faltering image.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: SingPost shares dive again on Thursday, prompting SGX query
summary: SingPost shares plummeted 6.5% to S$1.30, prompting a SGX query, after a 4.5% decline on Wednesday and a 1.4% drop on Tuesday. The company announced a stake sale in GD Express Carrier, reducing its stake to 11.2%. The sale, valued at RM239.1 million, is expected to result in a net gain of approximately S$64 million. The sale comes after the shock resignation of outgoing CEO Wolfgang Baier and concerns over corporate governance.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts Q4 DPSS slips 3.8% to 3.01 Singapore cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 3.8% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPSS) to 3.01 Singapore cents in Q4 2015, due to a 2.2% drop in net property income (NPI) to S$37.81 million. The decline was attributed to lower contributions from Singapore properties and Maldives resorts, and lower fixed rents in Australia and New Zealand due to currency weakness.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported on Thursday that its distribution per stapled security (DPSS) slipped to 3.01 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, down 3.8 per cent from 3.13 cents a year ago.

site_title: SingPost to reduce stake in GD Express Carrier
summary: SingPost has agreed to sell 137.42 million shares in GD Express Carrier (GDEX) for RM239.1 million (S$78.4 million), reducing its stake from 23.3% to 11.2%. The sale is expected to generate a net gain of approximately S$64 million. The move is aimed at freeing up capital for further investments in eCommerce logistics operations across Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Qualcomm forecasts show more competitive smartphone market
summary: Qualcomm forecasts its fiscal second-quarter sales and profit may fall short of analysts' estimates due to increasing competition in the slowing smartphone market. The company expects net income of 69-79 cents per share and revenue of $4.9-5.7 billion, lower than analysts' projected earnings of 84 cents per share and sales of $5.66 billion. The smartphone market is becoming saturated, with top-tier brands experiencing weakness, and competitors are churning out chips that rival Qualcomm's on price or performance, eroding demand.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit Q3 FY16 DPU up 0.7% to 2.85 cents
summary: AIMS AMP Reit reported a 0.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.85 cents for Q3 FY16, driven by a 9.5% rise in gross revenue to S$32.55 million and a 2.7% increase in net property income to S$21.06 million. The trust secured 18 new and renewal leases, maintaining portfolio occupancy at 93.4%. However, the share of results of joint ventures plunged 76.8% to S$3.54 million, amid a cautious outlook for the industrial market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Whichever way you slice it, these are wild days for Asia stocks
summary: Asian stocks are experiencing extreme volatility, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index moving up or down by more than 1% for six consecutive days, the longest stretch since the 2012 European debt crisis. Oil prices have plummeted, and shares from Tokyo to Shanghai have entered bear markets, with the MSCI Asia Pacific gauge falling 9.2% this year to a 3 1/2 year low. Investors are jittery due to uncertainty over economic growth, with markets continuing to trade in hours as no clear direction is known.

site_title: EU launches new tax avoidance push
summary: The European Union has launched plans to combat tax avoidance by multinational corporations, with a focus on requiring companies to report profits country by country and establishing minimum tax standards. The move aims to close loopholes that allow companies to minimize tax bills, with estimated annual revenue losses of 50-70 billion euros. The EU's push follows similar efforts by the OECD and comes after high-profile tax avoidance scandals, including those involving Google, Starbucks, and Fiat. The European Commission hopes to finalize the proposals this year.

site_title: North Korea may be readying long-range missile launch soon: Kyodo
summary: North Korea may prepare to launch a long-range missile in the next week, according to a Japanese government official citing satellite imagery analysis. This comes amid UN Security Council discussions for fresh sanctions after the country's fourth nuclear test on January 6. The last long-range rocket launch was in 2012, and experts believe North Korea is working to miniaturize a nuclear warhead. US Secretary of State John Kerry and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi agreed on a new UN Security resolution, but no concrete progress was made.

images.alt_text: North Korea may be preparing to launch a long-range missile as soon as in a week, Japan's Kyodo news agency reported early on Thursday, citing an unnamed Japanese government official.

site_title: Chanel, global chief exec part company over strategy
summary: Chanel's global CEO Maureen Chiquet will leave the company at the end of January due to "differences of opinion" over strategic direction. Chiquet, 52, held the post since 2007, overseeing the brand's successful international expansion and luxury positioning. Majority shareholder Alain Wertheimer will take over operational management pending a replacement. Chiquet's departure comes after the brand increased prices in euros and lowered them in dollars to compensate for exchange rate fluctuations, sparking customer reaction. Chanel praised Chiquet's contributions, citing her role in bringing the brand into a new era of development.

site_title: New Zealand posts NZ$53m monthly trade deficit in December
summary: New Zealand posted a monthly trade deficit of NZ$53 million in December, exceeding economists' forecasts. The annual trade deficit totaled NZ$3.549 billion. Exports rose to NZ$4.43 billion, while imports increased to NZ$4.48 billion. This marks a reversal from the previous month's NZ$131 million surplus.

images.alt_text: New Zealand posted a monthly trade deficit of NZ$53 million (S$48.8 million) in December, data from Statistics New Zealand showed on Thursday, while the annual trade deficit totaled NZ$3.549 billion.

site_title: Boeing offers weak 2016 outlook; shares tumble
summary: Boeing shares plummeted 9.1% after the company released a disappointing 2016 forecast, citing a decline in commercial aircraft deliveries to 740-745, down from a record 762 in 2015. Boeing expects flat to slightly lower revenues and core earnings per share, below Wall Street analyst expectations. The poor outlook raised concerns about the aerospace industry's weakening demand, but analysts believe Boeing's forecast is not connected to the issue.

images.alt_text: Boeing shares tumbled on Wednesday after it offered a disappointing forecast for 2016 and said it expects commercial plane deliveries to decline for the first time since 2010.

site_title: SLP to more than double agent strength in S'pore
summary: SLP International, a Singapore property agency, aims to more than double its agent strength in Singapore to 2,500 through mergers and acquisitions, defying current market conditions. The agency also seeks to have 10,000 agents regionally through organic and inorganic expansion. SLP's chairman, Kain Sim, believes the agency business will become redundant with the influx of technology, but the platform offers a suite of investment products and career path for agents. The agency plans to expand into Australia and Malaysia, and has set up offices in Jakarta and Shanghai.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher on Thursday, gaining 7.35 points or 0.29% to 2,553.53, driven by European shares recovering from a late drop in oil prices. Actively traded stocks included DBS, Global Logistic Properties, and Singapore Airlines. Losers narrowly outnumbered gainers 58 to 51, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

The Straits Times Index (STI) on Thursday finished with a rise of 16.27 points at 2,562.45 thanks mainly to an afternoon push that came when the Dow futures rose 120 points and Europe opened in the black.

site_title: Yoma's Q3 FY16 net profit boosted by other gains
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a net profit of S$25.16 million for Q3 FY16, a 217% increase from S$7.80 million in the same period last year, driven by other gains of S$30.42 million, mainly from a fair value gain of S$27.7 million for its telecom tower business. Revenue fell 5% to S$23.75 million due to lower sales of residences and land development rights.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
YOMA Strategic Holdings on Thursday reported a net profit of S$25.16 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, up from S$7.80 million a year ago.

site_title: Facebook quarterly profit doubles as user ranks grow
summary: Facebook reported a 125% increase in quarterly profit to $1.56 billion, doubling its previous year's earnings, as its user base grew to nearly 1.6 billion. Revenue rose to $5.84 billion, with 80% of ad revenue coming from mobile devices. The company's full-year net profit climbed to $3.7 billion, while revenue jumped to $17.9 billion. Co-founder Mark Zuckerberg attributed the success to investing in serving the community and connecting the world.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Wednesday reported that its quarterly profit more than doubled as its ranks of users swelled during the past year.

site_title: China should let yuan float to avoid slump, ex-PBOC adviser says
summary: A former adviser to the People's Bank of China, Yu Yongding, suggests that China should let its yuan currency float to avoid a slump. He proposes targeting the yuan against a basket of currencies within a 7.5% or 15% band, allowing market forces to determine the value. This would limit outflows and prevent a sharp depreciation, as the yuan has weakened 6% against the dollar in six months. Yu believes China's large current-account surplus and lack of capital account liberalization would prevent the yuan from falling too far.

images.alt_text: Yu Yongding, a former adviser to the People's Bank of China, has a bold idea to stem the yuan's slump: Let it float.

site_title: Singapore's biggest securities fraud investigation
summary: Singapore launched its largest securities fraud investigation, focusing on the collapse of a penny stock company. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are strengthening their collaboration on green and transition finance.

site_title: Federal Reserve hints at economic worries as it keeps rate unchanged
summary: The Federal Reserve kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged, despite hints of economic worries and slowing growth. The Fed cited improved labor market conditions but acknowledged global economic and financial developments that may impact the US economy. The decision leaves the door open for a potential second rate increase in March and follows the European Central Bank's signal to ease policy to combat deflation. Markets reacted negatively to the decision, with US stocks falling 0.6% and the dollar slipping against the euro.

site_title: Shanghai shares extend losses; Hang Seng down at open
summary: Shanghai shares extended losses, falling 0.89% to 2,711.16, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index lost 0.18% to 19,017.50. The declines followed the Federal Reserve's decision to leave interest rates unchanged, keeping the door open to a potential March hike.

site_title: Pavilion and Keppel-BG venture bags Singapore's first LNG bunkering licences
summary: Singapore has awarded its first LNG bunkering licences to Pavilion Gas and a joint venture between Keppel Offshore & Marine and BG. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) will work with the licence holders to develop infrastructure for LNG bunkering by early 2017, aligning with international regulatory requirements and stricter emissions standards. The move is expected to reduce vessel emissions and support Singapore's efforts to become an Asian LNG hub.

site_title: Greenback struggles for traction as all eyes are on Fed
summary: The US dollar struggled to gain traction on Wednesday as investors await the Federal Reserve's policy review meeting for clues on potential interest rate hikes in 2016. The Aussie dollar rose 0.6% against its US counterpart, while the Swiss franc fell to its lowest level since the Swiss National Bank removed the currency cap. Analysts expect "general choppiness" in markets, with investors cautious about the Fed's economic outlook, which may influence the dollar's direction.

site_title: Reported death in India road crash linked to Takata airbag
summary: A reported death in an Indian road crash has been linked to a malfunctioning Takata airbag. The 2007 Honda Civic was traveling at high speed when it rolled over and crashed, resulting in the driver's death. The airbag, manufactured in October 2006, deployed and ruptured, according to Honda. This is the 11th reported fatality involving Takata's airbags, with the second outside the US. The incident marks the latest safety crisis for the Japanese company.

site_title: US: Stocks slide as Fed keeps rate hike prospects alive
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 222.77 points (1.38%) to 15,944.46, while the S&P 500 fell 20.68 (1.09%) to 1,882.95. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, citing economic uncertainty, but hinted at a possible second rate increase in March. Tech stocks were hit hard, with Apple falling 6.6% after reporting minimal iPhone sales growth.

site_title: Hedge fund launches in Asia at 14-year low
summary: Hedge fund launches in Asia plummeted to a 14-year low in 2015, with 76 new funds opening, down from 117 in the prior year. The decline is attributed to investors' preference for established firms and rising regulatory costs, as well as a turbulent market. Successful new entrants, such as Zentific Investment Management and Graticule Asia Macro Advisors, point to a challenging industry where potential managers struggle to turn small single-strategy managers into viable businesses.

site_title: SingPost shares drop 4.5% to 21-mth low
summary: SingPost shares plummeted 4.5% on Wednesday, reaching a 21-month low of S$1.39, with over 12.9 million shares traded. The drop follows a 1.4% fall on Tuesday and is the steepest percentage decrease in slightly over a week. The stock has lost 15.2% since the start of 2016, amid concerns over corporate governance and stake selldowns by prominent asset managers.

site_title: Focus on 'human dimension' of entrepreneurship: Liang Eng Hwa
summary: Singapore needs to focus on developing innovation and entrepreneurship in its people, according to Liang Eng Hwa, chairman of the Government Parliamentary Committee for Finance, Trade and Industry. He suggests a three-pronged approach: refining the education system to prioritize arts and social skills, fostering a vibrant community of innovators, and encouraging life-long learning. This, he believes, is crucial for Singapore to prime itself for future growth and remain a key economic hub.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands' results trail estimates as gaming in Asia dips
summary: Las Vegas Sands Corp reported a fourth-quarter profit of 62 cents a share, missing analyst estimates of 64 cents. The company's gaming revenue in Macau and Singapore declined, contributing to a sales slump of $2.86 billion. Despite this, Las Vegas Sands raised its quarterly dividend to 72 cents a share for 2016. The results trail estimates, indicating a challenging gaming market in Asia.

images.alt_text: Las Vegas Sands Corp, the world's largest casino operator, posted fourth-quarter profit that missed analysts' estimates as gambling revenue in Macau and Singapore declined.

site_title: Airlines gain from lower fuel, but not so much for consumers
summary: Airlines are benefiting from lower fuel costs, but consumers are not seeing significant price drops. Despite the lowest jet-fuel costs in over 12 years, base fares have remained unchanged since 2014, according to FareCompare.com. Airlines are instead using the savings to pay dividends, reduce debt, and add capacity, resulting in record adjusted profits for major carriers like Delta, United, and Southwest. Consumers may see some savings in fares, but it's estimated to be around 5-10% less this year, with ancillary fees potentially offsetting some of the savings.

site_title: Lack of funds forcing businesses to abandon Italy's startup hub
summary: Italy's startup hub, H-Farm, is facing a funding crisis, with many businesses forced to abandon the incubator due to lack of capital. Despite having a large campus with 500+ entrepreneurs, H-Farm has struggled to raise private capital, with only 17.4 million euros invested over the past decade. Investors require companies to relocate to be involved in the day-to-day management, further exacerbating the problem. This departure of promising businesses hinders Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's efforts to foster a startup culture in Italy.

site_title: Chinese investors go bargain-hunting in Hong Kong for China shares
summary: Chinese investors are buying up shares in Hong Kong, exploiting a 40% discount between the Hong Kong and mainland exchanges. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index trades at a 6 times PE ratio, significantly cheaper than broader Asian markets. Mainland money is flowing into Hong Kong stocks, driven by Beijing's efforts to prop up its domestic market, with assets under management for an ETF tracking the HSCE increasing 15% this year. This trend is seen as an opportunity for investors, with some analysts suggesting that the low prices represent bargains, despite the global equities sell-off.

site_title: Emerging giants mired in graft as 66% of nations fail to score 50
summary: The Corruption Perceptions Index 2015 by Transparency International found that 66% of nations scored below 50 out of 100, with emerging giants such as Brazil, India, and China struggling with corruption. The index ranked Nordic countries as the cleanest, while Afghanistan, North Korea, and Somalia were at the bottom. The report cited massive scandals in Brazil and Malaysia, including a Petrobras kickbacks scandal and allegations against Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, as cause for concern. Transparency International urged governments to implement reforms to end corruption.

site_title: Keppel: hard to call bottom but troughs approaching
summary: Keppel Corporation's stock price has plummeted from S$9 to under S$5 a share due to the oil price rout and China's stock market jitters. However, the company's property segment, Keppel Land, remains a pillar of strength with a multi-billion-dollar portfolio. Analysts suggest applying a 30-50% discount to Keppel's property portfolio, which could value it at S$2.54-S$3.90 a share. This is due to the deteriorating Singapore property market and uncertainty in the offshore and marine sector. A trough in Keppel's value is expected, potentially in the S$3 region, but a rebound could occur with positive news on the offshore and marine front or oil prices.

site_title: Irish banking collapse inquiry criticises ECB
summary: An official inquiry into Ireland's 2008-10 banking crisis found that the European Central Bank's actions after the bailout contributed to an "inappropriate" share of the burden on taxpayers. The report stated the ECB threatened the Irish government with the withdrawal of emergency support if losses were imposed on senior bondholders. The inquiry criticized the ECB's role in the aftermath of the crisis, which led to the nationalization of Anglo Irish Bank and a €85 billion European bailout. The report concluded that the ECB's actions left taxpayers shouldering an unfair share of the burden.

site_title: SingPost saga: Untenable for PwC to stay on as special auditor
summary: SingPost's appointment of PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) as special auditor has sparked controversy due to a long-standing relationship between the two firms. PwC has provided significant non-audit services to SingPost, with non-audit fees exceeding 80% of audit fees over the past five years. This raises concerns about potential conflicts of interest and the independence of the audit committee. Only one issuer, SingPost, has appointed its external or internal auditor to undertake the special audit, while others have chosen independent firms. The appointment of PwC as special auditor is considered untenable due to these conflicts.

site_title: BHP has room to answer doubters as commodities rout batters debt
summary: BHP Billiton's debt has room to recover if CEO Andrew Mackenzie maintains a "solid A" credit rating. Despite a plunge in metal and energy prices, BHP has the flexibility to restructure by reining in shareholder dividends or raising fresh equity. The company's A+ credit rating at Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings, and its cash-flow positive status, suggest it can weather the current market conditions. Analysts believe the company's share price and debt securities are undervalued, offering opportunities for investors to capitalize on bearish sentiment.

site_title: Petronas seeks to defer delivery of second floating LNG plant
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas is considering deferring the delivery of its second floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) plant, PFLNG 2, currently under construction in South Korea. The delay comes as Petronas announces a budget cut of RM50 billion (S$16.8 billion) over the next four years. The company's chief executive Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin has confirmed the plan to slow down the project's engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) phase. A two-year delay would push the project's start-up to 2020, affecting gas production from the Rotan field development.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Temasek Holdings is discussing various options for Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries, including divesting non-core assets and selling shares, to prepare for a prolonged sector downturn. The divestment of M1 could free up S$400 million for capital recycling, while a rights issue for Keppel Corp and SCI may be arguable due to the stocks' discounts to book values. Analysts maintain "hold" calls on Keppel and Sembcorp Marine, with adjusted target prices, and reiterate a "buy" call on Sembcorp Industries.

site_title: US dollar little-changed after Fed statement
summary: The US dollar remained little-changed against the euro and yen after the Federal Reserve's statement, indicating a possible interest rate hike in March is still viable. The Fed left the benchmark federal funds rate unchanged, citing a slowing US economy and weak inflation, but predicted it would rise toward the 2.0% target in the medium term. The statement also signaled "gradual" further rate increases, with traders expecting no rate hike until the second half of 2016.

site_title: Billionaire investor suffers double-digit loss, admits to mistakes
summary: Billionaire investor Bill Ackman reported a double-digit loss of 16-20% in his firm's funds in 2015, citing mistakes, including not cutting positions in Valeant Pharmaceuticals International and Canadian Pacific. Ackman attributed the losses to a "very costly" decision not to sell Valeant shares when the stock price rose to $200, and failing to cut Canadian Pacific shares when they reached $240. Ackman acknowledged that the firm's portfolio "went into free fall" and that he couldn't sell shares due to a potential transaction.

site_title: The luxury head honcho perk that's still in good health
summary: Top CEOs continue to receive luxury executive physicals, a perk that has remained common despite the decline of other executive perks. According to executive compensation consultants, 32% of Fortune 500 companies offered this perk by 2013. The luxury checkup allows CEOs to see multiple doctors and get various tests performed, and its cost is seen as a small fraction of their overall compensation. Disclosing the cost of the physical can boost shareholder confidence, and it's considered a material factor in a CEO's health, making it a valuable perk for companies and CEOs alike.

site_title: EU to seek centralised vehicle approvals in the wake of VW scandal
summary: EU regulators plan to propose centralised market oversight for car models in response to Volkswagen's emissions test deception, aiming to give the European Commission greater authority over vehicle approvals. The proposal would also empower individual EU countries to recall vehicles approved elsewhere, and require car manufacturers to disclose software protocols. The initiative, set to be discussed in Brussels, faces potential resistance from national governments and could influence an EU verdict on real driving emission tests, which are set to begin in September 2017.

site_title: Toyota stays top-selling carmaker for fourth year as VW retreats
summary: Toyota maintained its title as the world's largest vehicle maker for the fourth consecutive year, selling 10.15 million vehicles globally in 2015. Volkswagen, struggling with a massive pollution scandal, posted 9.93 million sales, while General Motors sold 9.8 million. Toyota's sales edged down 0.8% from the previous year, despite a weak economy in its home market. The company is overhauling its production methods to slash development costs and tap into the growing market for environmentally friendly cars, including its new hydrogen fuel-cell car, the Mirai.

images.alt_text: Toyota kept its title as the world's biggest vehicle maker on Wednesday after posting global sales of 10.15 million vehicles for 2015, outpacing scandal-hit Volkswagen and US rival General Motors.

site_title: Preserve views of Tokyo Tower, developers urged
summary: The Minato Ward in Tokyo is urging developers to preserve views of the 333-meter Tokyo Tower by including scenic preservation in its landscape plan, set to become effective in April 2016. The ward has designated five viewing spots where people can see the tower in its entirety, and developers within 1.2km of these spots will be asked to consider the landscape. If they refuse, the ward may recommend changes to the building design or order them to do so, marking a rare effort by a municipality to preserve scenic views.

images.alt_text: People waiting to release balloons on new year's eve at a hotel in front of the landmark Tokyo Tower in Tokyo. With the increase in the number of condominiums in central Tokyo, the places where people can obtain an unobstructed view of the tower have been decreasing.

site_title: China may go for target growth range rather than a specific figure: report
summary: China may set a target growth range rather than a specific figure for its economic growth at the National People's Congress in March, according to a report by the Institute of International Finance. The report suggests that Chinese policy-makers are fixated on maintaining a high-growth regime, despite a possible move towards more flexible targeting, with a potential range of 6.5-7% annual growth. China's fiscal stance is expected to be increasingly expansionary, while monetary easing is likely to be more sparing, with limited wiggle room for cutting interest rates.

site_title: Updated benchmarks needed for future presidential candidates: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans to update the country's elected presidency system, including tightening qualifying criteria and ensuring periodic election of minority candidates. The government will study greater weight for presidential advisers and establish a new Constitutional Commission to make recommendations. The changes aim to strengthen the system, making it more open and contestable, and ensuring accountability to Singaporeans. The next presidential election is due by August 2017, and the government hopes to finalize the necessary legislation within the year.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Changes to Singapore's elected presidency system are afoot, chief among them the likelihood that the qualifying criteria will be tightened to ensure that only the most capable make the final cut.

site_title: Decision day for Noble Group shareholders in agri deal vote
summary: Noble Group shareholders are set to approve the sale of their 49% stake in Noble Agri Ltd to Cofco Corp for at least $750 million, aiming to cut debt and regain its investment-grade credit rating. The sale, which China's top food company already owns 51%, will result in a non-cash loss of $546 million. Noble Group's shares have lost 31% this year, with CEO Yusuf Alireza facing challenges amid a commodity rout. The deal is seen as a step towards restoring investor confidence and bolstering the company's rating metrics.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd shareholders are expected to approve the sale of the company's stake in its agricultural unit on Thursday as the commodity trader seeks to revive its fortunes by cutting debt, bolstering investor confidence and regaining its investment-grade credit rating.

site_title: New rules of engagement in the age of content
summary: In the digital age, businesses must leverage technology and content to engage individuals, as failure to do so risks being pushed to the margins of the internet landscape. Effective content output requires a comprehensive distribution strategy, including investing in talent, allocating budgets, and using targeted mediums. Businesses must also consider packaging and delivering content via relevant platforms to maximize results. Personalized content that resonates with the target audience is key to driving clear action, and advancements in technology have made it possible to deliver smart contextualization. As a result, businesses must prioritize solid content to impact the bottom line.

images.alt_text: Businesses need to present engaging content at the right time and at the right stage in the consumer journey. This is where critical consumer insights come in, including when and how consumers are connecting to their mobile phones and what type of content engages them.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover after late rally in oil
summary: European shares rose 0.4% to close at 1,340.76 points, driven by a late surge in oil prices, which surged 5% after Russia hinted at possible cooperation with major oil producers. The oil and gas sector rose 1.1%, with Britain's Sage being the top riser, while Royal Bank of Scotland dropped 2% due to a pension charge and US litigation provisions. Other weak earnings updates from Novartis and BASF also weighed on technology and chipmaker stocks.

site_title: Zika virus sends chills through travel industry
summary: The Zika virus outbreak has raised concerns among travelers, particularly those planning to visit Latin America and the Caribbean, as the US CDC advises against non-essential travel to affected areas. Airlines, hotels, and cruise operators have responded by allowing customers to postpone or reschedule trips with refunds. Despite this, some tourists are reconsidering their plans, with a record 54.4% of Americans planning a vacation in the next six months. The World Health Organization has stated that Canada and Chile are the only countries in the Americas without Zika transmission.

site_title: NCMPs to get equal voting rights as elected MPs: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced constitutional changes to give Non-Constituency Members of Parliament (NCMPs) equal voting rights as elected MPs. The minimum number of opposition MPs, including NCMPs, will be raised to 12 from 9 at the next general election. This move aims to give NCMPs the ability to vote on all issues, including confidence motions, and to re-examine the aspect of the NCMP scheme in Singapore's different phase of political development.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Slower UK house price growth in January
summary: UK house prices rose 0.3% month-on-month in January, slower than expected, but Nationwide predicts a modest pick-up in growth through 2016 due to a shortage of new homes and a strengthening labour market. Annual growth remains at 4.4%, with interest rates likely to stay on hold, fueling demand for homes and potentially increasing prices. Construction activity may lag, putting upward pressure on affordability.

site_title: Independent review unveiled for tennis' anti-graft programme
summary: Tennis officials have launched an independent review into the sport's anti-corruption programme, amid reports of match-fixing and unusual betting patterns. The review, led by British lawyer Adam Lewis, will examine the Tennis Integrity Unit's structure and governance, as well as its transparency and resources. The move comes after a mixed doubles match at the Australian Open raised suspicions of match-fixing, and a report claimed 16 top-ranked players were being scrutinized by the unit. The review aims to restore public confidence in the sport and implement all its recommendations.

site_title: World Bank lowers oil price forecast, warns of continued weakness
summary: The World Bank has lowered its forecast for crude oil prices to $37 per barrel, down from $51, due to continued weakness. The forecast reflects supply and demand factors, including Iran's resumption of exports, US production growth, and weak emerging market economies. Oil prices are expected to decline by 27% in 2016, but a gradual recovery is anticipated, driven by strengthening demand and high-cost producers making production cuts. The price outlook remains subject to significant downside risks.

site_title: Shunfu Ville up for en bloc sale again with same reserve price
summary: JLL relaunches the en bloc sale of Shunfu Ville in Singapore with the same reserve price of S$688 million. Despite an unsuccessful attempt last year, the owners remain hopeful of a positive outcome this time around, citing positive signs in the residential property market, including affordable housing and high demand for land. The estate, located near Marymount MRT Station, offers good schools, malls, and MRT connectivity, and is expected to fetch an average price of S$1,400-S$1,450 psf for new units.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Beware the pitfalls of diplomacy conducted in secret
summary: US President Barack Obama and some past presidents have conducted diplomatic initiatives in secret, bypassing the State Department and centralizing power within the National Security Council. This approach, exemplified by Obama's diplomacy with Cuba and Iran, can be disastrous. Historians note that Nixon and Kissinger's similar tactics led to the marginalization of the State Department and failed to institutionalize their vision for maintaining global balance. The article concludes that future US presidents should tread carefully in foreign policy, recognizing the risks of monopolizing relations within the White House.

site_title: Japan's decade-long wait for sumo champion ends with Kotoshogiku
summary: Kotoshogiku, a Japanese sumo wrestler, won the first top-level tournament of the year, ending a decade-long wait for a Japanese sumo champion. This victory marks the first time a Japanese wrestler has won a top-level tournament since the 1990s, when foreigners dominated the sport. Kotoshogiku's win has sparked hope that a new generation of Japanese sumo stars may emerge, but it remains to be seen if he can sustain his success throughout the year.

site_title: Apple forecasts first sales drop since 2003
summary: Apple has forecast its first sales drop since 2003, with revenue expected to be between $50 billion and $53 billion in the first quarter, below analysts' estimates. The company's record profit of $18.4 billion in the previous quarter was not enough to offset the decline, citing a slowdown in the global economy and saturated smartphone market. Apple's iPhone sales also fell short of projections, and the company's dependence on the iPhone leaves it vulnerable to demand fluctuations.

site_title: Frenzied demand for property in Canadian city Waterloo
summary: In the Canadian city of Waterloo, a condominium-sales event drew frenzied demand, with 1,600 attendees submitting paperwork for offers on units in the $85 million District Condos project. The city, home to tech companies like Google and BlackBerry, is experiencing a surge in property development, with 15 cranes visible in the sky, up from zero when a real estate mogul first arrived. The fervent demand highlights Waterloo's emergence as an investment destination, with investors seeking higher returns than in Toronto.

site_title: Prudent regulation helps Asia-Pac economies head off asset bubble
summary: Asia-Pacific economies are successfully using prudent regulation to prevent asset bubbles, with countries such as Singapore, Hong Kong, and Australia implementing macro-prudential measures to target house-price inflation. These measures, introduced in response to the 2008 global financial crisis, have led to a slowdown in housing markets, with prices in Singapore and Hong Kong falling consecutively. Experts say these measures have proven effective, with the International Monetary Fund finding they can have a "significant effect" on credit growth. However, the effectiveness of macro-prudential measures can be limited in times of economic downturn.

site_title: Soh Chee Wen 'mastermind' of penny stock crash: prosecutor
summary: Prosecutors believe Malaysian businessman Soh Chee Wen was the mastermind behind the 2013 penny stock collapse in Singapore, citing evidence from over 500 trading accounts and 20,000 emails. Soh, out on bail, is accused of orchestrating false trading and market rigging, and possibly fraud or deception. Investigators have also implicated 25 trading representatives in the scheme. Soh's lawyer argues that he cooperated with investigators and should be allowed to visit his ailing mother and attend his son's wedding in Malaysia. The judge rejected Soh's bail application, citing him as a flight risk.

site_title: Funds waiting to step in as Japan plans to cut guarantees on SME loans
summary: Japan's government is considering reducing guarantees on SME loans to cut fiscal debt and encourage banks to improve lending practices. This move could create opportunities for turnaround specialists like Topaz Capital and Keystone Partners, which may step in to provide risk money to struggling companies. The government-backed Japan Federation of Credit Guarantee Corporations currently guarantees 80% of debt for small to medium-sized companies. The plan may lead to more companies seeking funds from private equity firms, with estimated debt requiring caution totaling 20-30 trillion yen.

site_title: OUE C-Reit beats its Q4 DPU forecast by 20.4%
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.36 Singapore cents for Q4 2015, beating its forecast by 20.4%. The company's DPU for FY2015 was 4.38 cents, rising from 3.63 cents in the previous period. OUE C-Reit's net property income more than doubled year on year to S$29.68 million, driven by higher gross revenue and lower utilities costs. The company's investment properties were valued at S$3.4 billion as of Dec 31, 2015, with committed office occupancy at 94.3%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
