site_title: AIG spurns calls for a breakup, opts for streamlining instead
summary: AIG, the US insurance giant, has announced a strategic shift to streamline itself and become more profitable, despite activist investor calls for a breakup. The company will sell its financial advisory business and create nine distinct operations, offering part of its mortgage insurance unit in an initial public offering. AIG plans to spend $25 billion on stock buybacks and dividends and cut $1.6 billion from operating costs. CEO Peter D Hancock remains resistant to demands to shake off the SIFI designation, but acknowledged the need for further divestments.

site_title: Switzerland needs more robots to keep costs down: ABB CEO
summary: Switzerland's ABB Ltd is urging companies to invest in automation and robots due to high labour costs in the country. With the Swiss franc strengthening, ABB CEO Ulrich Spiesshofer believes automation will help improve production efficiency and make Switzerland competitive globally. The company is developing advanced robots that can monitor their own health and be programmed by moving their arms, with users expected to set productivity goals for both human and robotic employees. ABB sees the fourth industrial revolution, or Industry 4.0, as an opportunity to drive growth in the market for industrial robots and services.

site_title: Visa Singapore unveils new payment service
summary: Visa Singapore has launched a new payment service, Visa Checkout, aiming to reduce cancelled online transactions due to cumbersome payment processes, particularly on mobile devices. The service allows users to pay at a single point with participating merchants, eliminating the need to register or fill in credit card details. The move is expected to improve the online shopping experience, with Visa noticing that two-thirds of shoppers in Singapore abandoned purchases due to payment issues. Over 50% of these transactions were on mobile devices.

site_title: S'pore Reit managers advised to consider buying back units
summary: Religare Institutional Research advises Singapore Reit managers to consider buying back units due to depressed valuations. Some Reits are trading 20-30% below book values, offering a higher yield of 7-9% compared to 4-5% cap rates. Analyst Pang Ti Wee believes share buybacks can boost distributions per unit and demonstrate confidence in the market. Reits can finance buybacks through asset sales, debt, or issuing perpetual debt, which would not affect their leverage limits. This move is seen as a way for managers to return capital to investors and show good corporate governance.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: K1 Ventures, a 36% subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, reported a net loss of S$8.5 million for its second quarter, down from a profit of S$31 million a year ago. Revenue fell 73.6% to S$13.6 million. The firm will not make new investments but focus on managing its portfolio. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange and Taiwan Stock Exchange established a strategic partnership, and Tat Hong Holdings expects to report a loss for its third quarter due to exiting an Indonesian business and foreign-exchange losses.

site_title: Stronger second half helps Changi net 55.4m passengers in 2015
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore recorded 55.4 million passengers in 2015, a 2.5% increase from the previous year. The airport saw a rebound in the second half of 2015, driven by growth in full-service and low-cost carriers, with top source markets such as Thailand and Vietnam experiencing the strongest growth. Cargo traffic was relatively flat, but the pharmaceuticals cargo segment saw a 44% increase. The airport expects economic uncertainty to dampen travel demand, but low fuel prices and new airline services are expected to support airlines' profitability.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: December home sales surge to a 10-month high
summary: US new-home sales surged to a 10-month high in December, jumping 10.8% to 544,000 annualized pace, driven by job gains and attractive mortgage rates for a fourth consecutive year. This marks the best year for housing since 2007, with 501,000 purchases in 2015. The median sales price decreased 4.3% to $288,900, while the supply of homes dropped to 5.2 months. Economists attribute the growth to sustained hiring and income growth, which could contribute to further construction and economic growth.

site_title: Chinese storm clouds still loom, and things could get worse
summary: Chinese stock markets have fallen about 20% this year, with no signs of stabilization. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) faces difficulties in managing the renminbi, which has been trading lower in offshore markets. The central bank has raised the overnight bank lending rate to mitigate renminbi short-selling, but falling foreign-exchange reserves cast doubt on its ability to overcome a full-scale currency war. The Chinese banking system is also at risk, with high corporate debt and registered bad debts of US$700 billion.

site_title: Indonesia's Anthoni Salim to buy Rio Tinto's coal assets for US$224m
summary: Indonesian billionaire Anthoni Salim's company, MACH Energy Australia Pty, agreed to buy Rio Tinto's coal assets in New South Wales for US$224 million. The sale includes potential royalties and comes as the global coal market faces a glut and declining prices. Despite this, analysts expect demand to grow, particularly in Asia, and Australia is forecast to regain its position as the world's largest coal exporter. The deal marks the latest asset sale by Rio Tinto, which has sold assets worth US$4.7 billion over the past three years.

site_title: ZACD makes foray into financial services with senior hires
summary: ZACD Group, a Singapore-based property investment firm, is expanding into financial services with senior hires from the finance sector. The group is launching corporate finance, advisory, mergers and acquisitions, and equity and debt market advisory services, with a focus on serving small-and-medium enterprises (SMEs) in China and Europe. With a war chest of US$300 million, ZACD aims to raise US$500 million for its second private equity fund, targeting a 28% internal rate of return. The new financial services arm is expected to complement ZACD's existing real estate and agency businesses, with a projected growth rate of 18% in group earnings this year.

site_title: Procter & Gamble tops profit estimates after boosting prices
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) topped profit estimates by boosting prices and cutting overhead costs, despite a stronger US dollar. The company reported $1.04 in earnings per share, beating analysts' estimates of 98 cents. Premium-priced items like Tide Pods drove sales growth, particularly in the US. However, volume sales declined in most categories. The dollar's impact will reduce this year's earnings by 3-8% due to a 10% decline in overseas revenue. P&G shares rose 2.6% after the announcement.

site_title: Kaisa bonds up on news it will resume sales of blocked units
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings' bonds rose 1.4 cents to 66.1 cents on the dollar after the Chinese developer said it aims to resume sales of four blocked property projects in Shenzhen. The move comes as the company seeks to restructure its debt, following a proposal by creditors for a 75% recovery. Kaisa had previously defaulted on US dollar notes and is facing challenges from foreign funds, including a proposal from Farallon Capital Management for an 87% recovery. The company has received support from its creditors for its restructuring proposal.

site_title: Anti-graft agency seeks review of AG's decision to clear Najib
summary: Malaysia's anti-corruption agency announced plans to review the decision by Attorney-General Mohamed Apandi Ali to clear Prime Minister Najib Razak of any wrongdoing in a graft investigation. Najib was cleared of any criminal offences or corruption in a case involving a multi-million-dollar funding scandal, with Apandi stating the US$681 million deposit into Najib's account was a gift from Saudi Arabia's royal family. The agency will submit Apandi's decision to review panels and seek a review of another decision to close a case against a former 1MDB subsidiary.

site_title: Lockheed to separate IT services unit and merge it with Leidos
summary: Lockheed Martin has agreed to separate its Information Systems and Global Solutions division and combine it with Leidos Holdings in a $5 billion deal. The combined company will be led by Leidos management, with Lockheed owning 50.5% of the venture. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and expected to close in the second half of 2016. Lockheed's focus on hardware production, such as the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, is expected to continue, with the company reporting record order backlog of nearly $100 billion.

site_title: Change of guard at Singapore-China business councils
summary: IE Singapore announced leadership changes to the Singapore-China bilateral business councils, effective with the new Cabinet. Ong Ye Kung replaces Lui Tuck Yew as co-chairman of the Singapore-Guangdong Collaboration Council. Koh Poh Koon succeeds Teo Ser Luck as vice-co-chairman of the Singapore-Jiangsu Cooperation Council. Ng Chee Meng replaces Lawrence Wong as co-chairman of the Singapore-Sichuan Trade and Investment Committee. Lawrence Wong succeeds Khaw Boon Wan as co-chairman of the Singapore-Tianjin Economic and Trade Council. Sim Ann replaces Grace Fu as co-chairman of the Singapore-Zhejiang Economic and Trade Council.

site_title: Biotech firm shows the way onto the global stage
summary: InvitroCue, a Singapore-based biotech firm, debuted on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) four years after its birth, with sales growth doubling in the last two years. The company, founded by Steven Fang and Hanry Yu, helps drug-makers determine the safety of vaccines, products, and devices before human trials. InvitroCue licensed technologies from the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) and is in talks with global pharmas, including Novartis. The company raised A$3.15 million through a reverse takeover and plans to expand its presence in China and grow its business.

site_title: US crude inventories reach highest level on record last week: EIA
summary: US crude inventories reached a record high of 494.2 million barrels last week, up 8.4 million barrels from the previous week. This is the highest level on record, according to the US Energy Information Administration. Additionally, gasoline inventories in the Midwest rose to 58.9 million barrels, the highest overall volumes since February 2010.

site_title: Shell shareholders approve US$49b BG takeover
summary: Shell shareholders approved the US$49 billion takeover of BG Group at a special meeting in The Hague, with 83.08% voting in favor and 16.92% opposing. The deal marks one of the largest in the energy sector in the past decade, with Shell needing a majority of positive shareholder votes to seal the deal.

site_title: Two homegrown startups bag venture-capital funding from overseas
summary: Two Singapore startups, Teabox and Daylight Studios, have secured venture-capital funding from abroad. Teabox, a specialty tea company, has received an undisclosed round of financing from Ratan Tata, chairman emeritus of Tata Sons, to support marketing, customer acquisition, and hiring. Daylight Studios, a game developer, has bagged an undisclosed amount of funding from Japan's mobile marketing firm Adways, inking a partnership to create new support and advertising solutions for game developers in the region.

site_title: Restructuring of IDA and MDA a step in the right direction
summary: Singapore's government has restructured the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) and Media Development Authority (MDA) to form the Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) and the Government Technology Organisation (GTO), taking effect from April 1. The reorganization aims to adapt to the convergence of media and technology landscapes, allowing Singapore to seize opportunities presented by technological changes. IMDA will oversee regulatory and policy initiatives, while GTO will provide enterprise IT solutions and coordinate ICT masterplans. The move is seen as a step in the right direction to improve Singapore's infocomm media sector and contribute to the country's growth.

site_title: EMS plunges 27% prompting SGX query
summary: EMS Energy, an oilfield services equipment firm, plunged 26.7% to S$0.22 on the Singapore Exchange, prompting a query from the exchange. The company attributed its price drop to lack of information, despite announcing a $2.8 million contract win. The stock has nearly halved since the start of the year amid market volatility and oil market rout. EMS Energy's share consolidation late last year may also have contributed to the price fall, with brokers noting that a cheaper absolute price attracts more speculative interest.

site_title: Fingerprinting for all arrivals here by June
summary: Singapore plans to implement fingerprinting for all arrivals by June to enhance border security. The BioScreen initiative will verify traveller identities and facilitate automated self-clearance when leaving the country. This measure comes amid concerns over terrorism and public health, with two Singaporeans already in Syria and several others detained or issued Restriction Orders. The government also faces a dengue outbreak and potential Zika virus threat, but currently has measures in place to combat both.

site_title: In Atlantic City - pride, anger, worry as city teeters on edge
summary: Atlantic City, New Jersey, is struggling to reinvent itself after years of fiscal ruin and a perception as a seedy locale. Despite efforts to diversify the economy and reduce crime, the city teeters on the edge of bankruptcy. New developments, such as a summer of beach concerts and new recreation venues, have shown promise, with crime rates declining 9.3% in 2015. However, poverty and low incomes remain, and the city's transformation into a family-friendly destination is uncertain, with its history as a casino hub making it challenging to shift its image.

site_title: Tat Hong warns of Q3 loss
summary: Tat Hong Holdings expects to report a loss for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, primarily due to costs associated with exiting the excavator distribution business in Indonesia, weak performance from its Australian operations, and foreign-exchange losses.

site_title: German government pares back 2016 growth forecast to 1.7%
summary: The German government has revised its economic forecast for 2016, trimming its growth expectation from 1.8% to 1.7%. Despite this, the government maintains that Germany's economy is in good shape. The revised forecast is a fractionally slower than the earlier prediction.

site_title: China financial institutions told to support real economy
summary: China's government has instructed financial institutions to support the real economy by dealing with non-performing loans and reducing lending to loss-making firms. The government will also encourage mergers and acquisitions through preferred stock issuance and convertible bonds. These measures aim to boost economic growth, which is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: British PM defends Google tax deal
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron defended the £130 million tax deal with US tech giant Google, which is the largest amount paid by the company in back taxes to Britain. The deal follows a government inquiry into Google's tax arrangements, with critics arguing that the company pays only 3% effective tax rate on its British profits. Cameron claimed the government has cracked down on tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance, and that Google's taxes are increasing under his government.

site_title: Cathay said to delay Airbus A350 delivery as seats not ready
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has delayed the delivery of its first Airbus A350 model to the middle of the year due to unfinished business-class seats. The airline initially expected the delivery in February, but the delay is attributed to Zodiac Aerospace's struggles to meet delivery schedules. This setback comes as Cathay Pacific competes with other carriers in the region, and Airbus has experienced similar issues with its A320neo model.

site_title: STI ends flat on weak Europe opening
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on Wednesday, closing at 2,546.18 after a weak European opening and caution ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting. Despite short-covering and a 0.57-point gain, the index was capped by weakness in the Shanghai Composite and Dow futures. The FOMC meeting's zero-probability rate hike and 4% chance of a rate cut also contributed to the cautious market.

site_title: Oil rallies after US data shows spike in product demand
summary: Oil futures rose above $32 a barrel after US data showed a jump in weekly demand for heating oil during a cold front. Inventories of distillates fell by over 4 million barrels, trumping expectations. However, analysts believe the rise in prices may be short-lived due to the impact of cold weather. US crude oil stocks reached their highest on record, while Brent crude was up 10 cents at $31.90 a barrel. Despite this, oil prices have fallen nearly 16% in January, bringing total losses since 2014 to 77%.

site_title: BH Global receives in-principle approval for share consolidation
summary: BH Global received in-principle approval from Singapore Exchange to consolidate its shares from four to one, allowing the marine products firm to comply with the S$0.20 minimum trading price rule. The listing and quotation of up to 120 million consolidated shares have been approved. This move will help BH Global meet the listing requirement and maintain its mainboard listing status.

site_title: VW recalls 67,000 Caddy vans
summary: Volkswagen is recalling 67,000 Caddy light commercial vans globally due to faulty bolting of the main power supply unit, which could switch on the ignition. The recall affects vehicles built between May 2012 and January 2013, with 20,800 in Germany. No accidents have been reported, but customers have complained about the issue. The recall is a significant portion of last year's Caddy sales worldwide, and Volkswagen will address the problem without knowledge of any accidents caused.

site_title: US oil explorers seen reporting US$14b in 2015 losses
summary: US oil explorers are expected to report significant losses of nearly $14 billion in 2015 due to the steepest price collapse in a generation. Companies like Hess Corp, Murphy Oil Corp, and Anadarko Petroleum Corp are expected to report substantial losses, with Hess Corp reporting a net loss of $3.06 billion for the year, its first annual loss since 2002. The decline in crude prices and reduced drilling plans have led to the losses, with experts warning of a "not pretty" earnings season for the industry.

site_title: MCT to boost F&B offerings at VivoCity
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) is enhancing VivoCity's food and beverage offerings through an asset enhancement initiative (AEI), with a budget of S$6.1 million and expected return on investment of over 15%. The move aims to boost the mall's appeal, despite a 1.6% year-on-year decline in Q3 shopper traffic. MCT maintained its distribution per unit (DPU) at 2.08 Singapore cents and reported a 4% growth in tenant sales to over S$260 million.

site_title: New US single-family home sales jump in December
summary: US single-family home sales surged 10.8% in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 544,000 units, exceeding economists' forecast of 500,000 units. This increase follows a revised November sales pace of 491,000 units. The housing sector remains resilient despite a slowing economy and massive stock market sell-off. The jump in new home sales suggests the housing market continues to hold firm, providing a positive indication for the economy.

site_title: Mercator Lines to sell five vessels for US$32.3m
summary: Mercator Lines, a dry bulk shipping company, is selling five vessels for US$32.3 million to related companies of its syndicate lenders. The vessels, including MV Sri Prem Veena and MV Garima Prem, will be delivered by February. This sale follows the resignation of the firm's chairman and three other non-executive directors, and the suspension of trading in its shares since November. The move is part of Mercator Lines' efforts to restructure under judicial management.

site_title: Opec-led attempt for oil-cut deal under way, prospects slim
summary: Opec-led efforts to fix an oil glut and boost prices are underway, but prospects for a deal remain slim. Despite recent hints of flexibility from Saudi Arabia and Russia, challenges persist, particularly with Iran's plans to boost oil supply and Russia's refusal to cooperate. Venezuela's initiative to drum up support for joint action has faced skepticism, and a potential emergency Opec meeting is uncertain. The lack of supply restraint by Opec and rivals has sent prices to a 12-year low near $27 a barrel.

site_title: No end in sight for Europe's investment banking malaise: Gadfly
summary: Europe's investment banks are expected to report disappointing earnings as the sector continues to struggle against US peers. Despite a flat revenue performance from major US banks, European banks such as Deutsche Bank and Barclays have warned of performance shortfalls due to tough markets. Revenue for Deutsche Bank fell 15% in the fourth quarter, while Barclays reported a 11% decline in fourth-quarter investment banking revenue. The low bar set by US banks and disappointing European performances may set a disappointing tone for earnings season.

site_title: Google files patent for drone 'delivery receptacle'
summary: Google has filed a patent for a "delivery receptacle" designed to securely store packages retrieved by drones. The receptacle would use infrared beacons to guide drones to a safe location, such as a garage. The project, dubbed "Project Wing," aims to deliver packages by 2017, but regulations from the Federal Aviation Administration must be in place first. The company is part of a growing list of companies exploring drone delivery, with Alphabet and Amazon already conducting testing. Existing regulations may be sufficient for drone operations, according to project leader Dave Vos.

site_title: EU apparent steel consumption growth to slow: Eurofer
summary: The EU steel market is expected to improve over the next two years, with apparent steel consumption growing by 1.1% in 2016 and 1.7% in 2017. However, growth is expected to be more muted than in 2015, driven by investment replacing private consumption and slower real consumption growth. Heavy destocking at the end of last year and start of 2016 will limit the rise. Eurofer attributes the growth to investment replacing private consumption, with faster growth of real consumption.

site_title: Malaysia's top lawyer rejected advice to charge PM: source
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak was cleared of any wrongdoing in a multi-million-dollar scandal, but the country's anti-graft agency had previously recommended charging him with criminal misappropriation. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) had made these recommendations after investigating the transfer of $681 million into Najib's personal bank account. The attorney-general rejected the recommendations, citing insufficient evidence. The move has sparked growing outrage, with many calling for Najib's prosecution.

site_title: Pragmatic and smart, Tsai won't try to provoke Beijing
summary: Taiwan's newly elected President Tsai Ing-wen has taken a pragmatic approach to her role, choosing to maintain the status quo with Beijing rather than pursuing Taiwan independence. In her victory address, she referred to the Republic of China, acknowledging the country's historical ties to mainland China. This move is seen as a smart and non-provocative strategy, allowing Tsai to accept reality and inviting Beijing to do the same. The 1992 consensus, which defines "one China," is still a point of contention, but Tsai has recognized the meeting and may be open to alternative forms of recognition.

site_title: In coal-powered China, electric car surge fuels fear of worsening smog
summary: China's rapid growth in electric vehicle sales, driven by coal-powered grids, has raised concerns about worsening smog. Automakers like Volkswagen and BYD Co Ltd project significant growth, with 2 million electric vehicles expected to be produced annually by 2020. This surge in green car production contradicts the government's goal of cleaner energy, sparking fears of environmental degradation. The increasing demand for electric vehicles may exacerbate air pollution issues in China, threatening the country's efforts to improve air quality.

site_title: Alibaba's dependence on Chinese economy morphs into liability
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd's market capitalization has lost nearly US$29 billion in just a month due to investor concerns over the company's dependence on the Chinese economy, which is experiencing slowing growth, market volatility, and a weakening yuan. Despite reporting a 27% revenue growth in the latest quarter, Alibaba's shares have underperformed major indices, with the company's reliance on China prompting billionaire founder Jack Ma to pursue growth abroad through deals such as ride-sharing service Lyft and newspaper acquisitions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.88 points to close at 1,631.54 on Wednesday, driven by gains of 463 stocks while 375 declined. The 1.62 billion lots valued at RM1.65 billion were traded.

site_title: K1 Ventures hit by realised exchange loss
summary: K1 Ventures, a 36% stakeholder of Keppel Corporation, reported a net loss of S$8.5 million for its second quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, with revenue falling 73.6% to S$13.6 million. The loss was attributed to a realised exchange loss from the voluntary liquidation of subsidiary Focus Up Holdings. This marked a significant decline from a profit of S$31 million in the same quarter last year.

site_title: Two oil & gas MNCs plan to shift Asean HQs to KL
summary: Two major oil and gas companies plan to relocate their Asean headquarters to Kuala Lumpur due to its cost competitiveness and talent pool, according to InvestKL. This brings the city's tally of new multinational corporations to 50, with combined investments of RM6 billion (S$2.02 billion) and job commitments of 7,000. However, the country's corruption issues remain a concern, with Prime Minister Najib Razak's promises to tackle corruption appearing unfulfilled. The Malaysian government's decision to clear Najib of a criminal offence in a controversial case has also raised concerns among investors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Malaysian Public Prosecutor confirms evidence points to Soh Chee Wen as mastermind behind 2013 penny stock collapse. Iceberg Research prepares fourth report on Noble Group's accounting practices. PM Lee Hsien Loong suggests reviewing the qualifying criteria for the elected presidency. Changi Airport records 55.4 million passengers in 2015, with a 2.5% increase. Visa Singapore launches an online checkout service to address online transaction issues. Singapore shares close flat, with the STI dropping 38 points from its intraday peak.

site_title: RBS sees US$5.2b asset value hit, clouding dividend
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) reported a 3.6 billion-pound (US$5.2 billion) hit to its asset value and set aside more money for past misconduct, overshadowing CEO Ross McEwan's efforts to resume dividend payments. The bank's tangible net asset value will be hurt by 1.6 billion pounds due to measures to plug a pension deficit. RBS took charges for a US mortgage-backed securities lawsuit and wrongly-sold payment protection insurance, pushing it into a full-year loss for 2015. The bank's shares slumped 5.7% and traded at 253.40 pence.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust posts 2.08 cents in Q3 DPU
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.08 Singapore cents for Q3 2015, unchanged from the previous year. The trust's net property income increased 3.5% to S$56.6 million, driven by positive contributions from VivoCity, while gross revenue grew 1.2% to S$73.77 million. However, net finance expenses rose 14.7% due to higher interest rates on floating rate borrowings. MCT's CEO, Sharon Lim, attributed the results to active asset management and cost management.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as oil, Apple drag
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 94.44 points, or 0.58%, to 16,072.79, and the S&P 500 down 5.3 points, or 0.28%, to 1,898.33. Oil prices gave up gains, and Apple's tepid quarterly revenue forecast weighed on the market. The Nasdaq Composite index was down 20.16 points, or 0.44%, to 4,547.51.

site_title: Toyota keeps top global automaker crown, sells 10.15 million in 2015
summary: Toyota maintained its title as the world's largest automaker, selling 10.15 million vehicles in 2015, surpassing Volkswagen and General Motors. Despite struggling to recover from a pollution scandal, Toyota's sales edged down 0.8% from the previous year. Volkswagen, which had previously led the market, saw its sales drop due to the scandal and fell to 9.93 million. Toyota's focus on quality and environmentally friendly cars, such as its hydrogen fuel-cell car, is expected to drive growth in the market.

site_title: Apple's Safari browser crashing for some users worldwide: The Verge
summary: Apple's Safari browser is crashing for some users worldwide, particularly when running a search from the address bar on both iOS and OS X devices. The issue appears to be affecting devices globally. Apple has not commented on the problem. This incident may prompt the company to release a software update to resolve the issue.

site_title: ECB's Coeure: countries should spend what they can to help economy
summary: Benoit Coeure, an ECB executive board member, advises eurozone countries to spend and invest to boost growth, emphasizing the importance of responsible fiscal policies. He suggests creating independent fiscal councils to monitor compliance with fiscal rules, but acknowledges there is no appetite for a "United States of Europe".

site_title: China's growth will decline further below 6%, Hormats says
summary: China's economic growth is expected to decline further below 6%, according to Robert Hormats, a former US under secretary of state for economic growth. Hormats stated that China is undergoing a major transition from heavy dependence on exports and capital investment to more consumption and services, but this transition is not happening rapidly enough. This slower growth poses pressure on Chinese policymakers, but Hormats believes China can avoid a "crash landing" by making necessary adjustments.

site_title: BoE's Bailey wants clarity from fund managers on assets
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Andrew Bailey emphasized the need for fund managers to provide clarity on asset quality and liquidity to investors. He stated that investors should have no illusion about the liquidity of assets and that expectations should be well-adjusted to prevailing market conditions. Bailey's comments come amid concerns about the potential for difficulties in bond funds during market turmoil. The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority supervises banks, but Bailey will join the Financial Conduct Authority, which regulates the sector and aims to protect investors from unsuitable products.

site_title: As it happened: PM Lee in Parliament on Wednesday
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong spoke in Parliament about Singapore's political system, discussing potential changes to strengthen it. However, no specific details or conclusions were mentioned in this article. The article instead appears to be a collection of unrelated news headlines from various countries, including Malaysia, China, and the UK, covering topics such as asset seizures, economic growth, and trade talks.

site_title: Digital marketing helps Adidas cut ties to sports bodies
summary: Adidas is ending its 11-year funding deal with the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) due to doping and corruption allegations. This move aligns with a trend of sports brands shifting focus to sponsoring individual athletes and teams directly, allowing for more direct promotion to fans through social media. Adidas' decision reflects a shift in sponsorship strategies, with brands increasingly seeking more control over their brand messaging and fan engagement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares, unlike mainland ones, close higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.0% on Wednesday, defying sliding onshore markets, as bargain hunters sought attractively-priced shares. The Hang Seng index reached 19,052.45, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.8%. This move contrasts with the decline of mainland Chinese shares.

site_title: Boeing profit falls 30% on after-tax charge
summary: Boeing reported a 30% decline in quarterly profit to $1.03 billion, or $1.51 per share, due to an after-tax charge related to its 747-8 production cut. Core earnings fell to $1.60 per share from $2.31 per share in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to the production cut, which impacted the company's earnings.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat, STI drops 38 points from intraday peak
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Wednesday, dropping 38 points from its intraday peak of 2,584. The index ended at 2,546.18, influenced by a weak European opening and concerns ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting. The market saw 224 rises and 166 falls, with offshore and marine stocks performing better than banks. The US Dow futures also dropped 50 points in Asian trading, contributing to the index's limited gains.

site_title: Foxconn proposes detailed offer for Sharp: source
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn has made a detailed offer to buy Sharp Corp, promising not to cut jobs, challenging a Japanese government-backed fund's offer. Foxconn's previous offer was over 600 billion yen, but the company has since submitted more specific proposals. Foxconn Chairman Terry Gou met with Japanese government officials to discuss the matter. Sharp declined to comment, and Foxconn representatives were not available to comment.

site_title: SGX-TWSE tie-up to let Taiwan investors access S'pore-listed stocks
summary: SGX and the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) have established a strategic partnership, allowing TWSE member brokers to trade SGX-listed securities directly. This is the first step towards a wider partnership between the two exchanges, with trading expected to go live in the second quarter of 2016. The agreement aims to increase access for Taiwanese investors to Singapore-listed stocks, promoting economic cooperation and investment between the two regions.

site_title: German consumer confidence stable: survey
summary: German consumer confidence remains stable, according to a survey by market research company GfK, despite terror warnings and economic uncertainties. The household confidence index is forecast to remain steady at 9.4 points in February. While economic expectations and spending propensity are rising, income expectations have decreased. The stable consumer climate is attributed to overall high levels, but heightened concerns about terrorism and the refugee influx could impact consumer behavior in the coming months.

site_title: Europe: Chipmaker stocks fall after Apple forecasts lower revenues
summary: European technology and chipmaker stocks fell after Apple forecasted its first revenue drop in 13 years, citing a weakening Chinese market. ARM Holdings, Dialog, and AMS stocks dropped 1.5%, 1.5%, and 0.2% respectively. Apple's slowest-ever increase in iPhone shipments also raised concerns about the company's growth period ending.

site_title: Thailand is top Asia-Pacific tourist stop thanks to Chinese
summary: Thailand has become the top tourist destination in the Asia-Pacific region, thanks to a surge in Chinese visitors. According to the MasterCard Asia Pacific Destinations Index, visitor numbers to Thailand increased by over 10% year-on-year in 2015, with Chinese tourists playing a key role in this growth. Thailand's destinations, including Phuket and Pattaya, ranked among the top 10 most-visited places in the region, with the country expecting Chinese visitors to make up a larger proportion of its forecast 32 million visitors in 2016.

site_title: Mumbai police take Twitter by storm with pun-filled tweets
summary: Mumbai police has gained a significant following on Twitter with its pun-filled tweets, trending on the platform in India. Since joining last month, the police force has posted over 1,000 re-tweets, praising its humor and creativity. The commissioner's account has grown to 22,000 followers, while the official account has over 30,000. The police use humor to convey serious messages, such as warning against online harassment and promoting online security. The tweets are approved by the police before posting, and have been praised by Indian netizens.

site_title: Taiwan president Ma to visit disputed island for first time
summary: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou is set to visit Taiping Island in the South China Sea for the first time, amid rising tensions in the region. The visit comes after Taiwanese coastguards drove off a Vietnamese fishing boat near the island, which is also claimed by China, Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Brunei. Ma, whose term is ending soon, will visit Taiwanese personnel stationed on the island ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. The move is seen as a show of Taiwan's resolve to protect its interests in the disputed territory.

site_title: China: Stocks close slightly lower after paring sharp losses
summary: China's stocks closed slightly lower, recovering from sharp losses, with the CSI300 index falling 0.3% to 2,930.35 and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.5% to 2,735.56. The market experienced a volatile session, with the SSEC index plummeting 3.0% earlier.

site_title: NCMPs will have same voting rights as elected MPs: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong plans to amend the Constitution to grant non-constituency members of Parliament (NCMPs) the same voting rights as elected MPs. This move aims to make NCMPs "equal in powers, though not in responsibility and scope." The government also plans to increase the minimum number of opposition MPs in the House from nine to 12 in the next general election. Additionally, the government will maintain the existing Nominated MP scheme, resulting in at least 21 non-ruling party MPs in Parliament.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Toyota, Suzuki shares soar on reports of emerging market tie-up
summary: Toyota and Suzuki shares surged in Tokyo trading on reports of a potential partnership focused on compact cars for emerging markets, including India. The two Japanese automakers denied discussing a partnership, but investors welcomed the news, sending Suzuki's shares up 11.35% and Toyota's up 3.80%. The partnership would reportedly involve swapping environmentally friendly technologies and know-how to capitalize on demand for small cars in India, Thailand, and other emerging markets. Suzuki would likely benefit from Toyota's next-generation technology, including self-driving cars.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on positive US cues; won edges up
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.4% on Wednesday, tracking US market gains, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing at 1,897.87 points. The South Korean won edged up 0.2% against the dollar. The gains were limited by caution ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy rate decision later in the day.

site_title: Singapore awards first pair of LNG bunkering licences
summary: Singapore has awarded its first pair of LNG bunkering licences to PAVILION Gas and a joint bid by Keppel Offshore & Marine and BG Group. The licences were awarded after 12 bids met the set criteria, with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore working with the winners to develop necessary infrastructure for LNG bunkering by early 2017. This move aims to comply with the International Maritime Organization's sulphur emissions cap, set for 2020, and is part of Singapore's efforts to develop LNG bunkering standards and procedures.

site_title: Survey finds South-east Asia still struggling with corruption
summary: A survey by Transparency International ranks three South-east Asian nations - Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar - among the 30 most corrupt countries in the world. Singapore, however, is among the 10 least corrupt, scoring 85. The other South-east Asian countries showed varying improvements or declines in corruption perception, with Malaysia and the Philippines experiencing a decrease. The Corruption Perception Index, which tracks perceptions of public sector corruption in 168 nations, highlights the ongoing struggle with corruption in the region.

site_title: Iceberg Research to write 4th report on Noble Group
summary: ICEBERG Research is set to release its fourth report on Noble Group, a commodity trader. The report aims to validate claims that Noble overstated at least US$3.8 billion in fair values. Iceberg asserts that this claim will be recognized as fact, despite Noble's investment grade rating being cut by Standard & Poor's and Moody's. The report's findings may impact Noble's shares, which were trading at 28.5 cents, a 3.6% increase from its previous close. The report's release date has not been specified.

site_title: Gold's rally just won't last for this forecaster as rates climb
summary: Gold's rally is expected to end as US interest rates rise, according to Bank of Singapore's chief economist Richard Jerram. Despite a surge in 2016, gold prices are likely to drop as rates continue to increase, potentially sinking below $800 an ounce. The Federal Reserve is expected to leave rates unchanged, but a 25% chance of a rate hike by March suggests a longer-term decline in gold prices. Jerram advises owning gold as a hedge, but warns it may drop for a long time or forever.

site_title: Lyft settles California driver lawsuit over employment status
summary: Lyft has agreed to settle a proposed class action lawsuit in California, filed by drivers seeking to be classified as employees. The settlement, worth $12.25 million, requires court approval and provides drivers with notice before deactivation. Drivers will receive payment and notice, but the terms of employment status remain unclear. The settlement aims to resolve a lawsuit that challenged Lyft's classification of drivers as independent contractors.

site_title: Novartis quarterly profit misses estimates amid Alcon woes
summary: Novartis AG, Europe's second-largest drugmaker, reported fourth-quarter earnings that missed analyst estimates due to declining sales at its Alcon eye-care unit, which fell 13% in the quarter. The company's core net income declined 5% to $2.71 billion, missing the $2.9 billion average of 12 analyst estimates. Novartis forecasts 2016 sales and core operating income to remain largely unchanged, while Alcon is expected to show low single-digit growth. The company announced leadership changes, including the appointment of a new CEO for Alcon.

site_title: Emirates to take US$14.5b new jets; 21 Airbus superjumbos
summary: Emirates, the world's largest long-haul airline, plans to add 37 new planes to its fleet in the fiscal year 2017, valued at US$14.5 billion. The airline will receive 21 Airbus A380 superjumbos and 16 Boeing 777s, expanding its operations in Asia. Emirates will retire 26 aircraft and study orders for Airbus A350 and Boeing 787 models. The airline aims to grow and invest in new markets, with plans to fly to new destinations, including Panama, Cebu, and two cities in China.

site_title: Fed seen keeping interest rates steady amid market volatility
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady amid market volatility, with all 69 analysts in a Reuters poll predicting a 0.25-0.50% rate range. This decision comes amid concerns of a global slowdown and a plunge in US and world equities, but many economists believe the central bank will soften concerns by pointing to solid US job growth. The Fed is closely following global economic and financial events, and a March rate hike is still possible, with a 30% chance according to Fed funds futures.

site_title: China stocks slump on margin call concerns; Hong Kong rebounds
summary: China's stocks plummeted 2.2% and 2.8% on the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, amid margin call concerns and forced liquidation. Industrial profit declined 4.7% in December, the seventh straight month of declines. Hong Kong shares rebounded, gaining 0.6% on the Hang Seng index, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's policy decision. The decline in Chinese stocks follows a recent market rout, threatening another vicious downward spiral.

site_title: Fingerprint cards value is anyone's guess as analysts differ
summary: Fingerprint Cards AB, a Swedish company, is facing divergent analyst opinions on its stock value. Arctic Securities recommends buying with a target price of 850 kronor, while Carnegie rates the shares as hold with a target of 500 kronor. In contrast, ABG Sundal Collier advises selling with a probability-weighted average price target of 200 kronor. This disparity results in a ratio of 4.25 for Fingerprint, compared to 1.77 for the OMX Stockholm 30 Index. Analysts predict a harsher competitive environment in China, with Fingerprint's market share at risk.

site_title: Visa Singapore launches online checkout service
summary: Visa Singapore launched Visa Checkout, a one-stop payment service to simplify online transactions, citing that two-thirds of Singaporean shoppers abandon purchases due to lengthy payment processes. The service captures and populates consumers' payment details, allowing registered users to pay through a single payment point at merchants that have signed on. The service is set to compete with MasterCard's MasterPass and PayPal, and is available on popular online retailers such as Golden Village and Cold Storage.

site_title: China planning to build floating nuclear power plant
summary: China plans to build a floating nuclear power station as part of its goal to double its atomic capacity by 2020. The project, led by China Atomic Energy Authority, will be subject to "strict and scientific demonstration". The floating plant could provide power for offshore oil and gas drilling, island development, and remote areas. China currently has 30 operational nuclear reactors with a capacity of 28.3 gigawatts, and aims to increase its installed atomic power capacity to 58 gigawatts by 2020.

site_title: Decline in North American sentiment drags down investor confidence index in Jan
summary: The Global Investor Confidence Index (ICI) decreased to 108.8 in January, down 1.7 points from December, primarily due to a decline in North American sentiment. Asian and European indices also fell, at 1.5 and 0.1 points respectively. This decline is attributed to tumbling oil prices, slowing Chinese growth, and changing global dynamics. The ICI measures investor confidence and risk appetite, with a neutral reading of 100.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Indonesia finmin says "to move fast" in issuing a global sukuk
summary: Indonesia's finance minister Bambang Brodjonegoro urged the government to issue a dollar-denominated Islamic bond (sukuk) quickly to anticipate potential changes in US interest rates. The government raised $3.5 billion in global bonds in December as pre-funding for the 2016 state budget. Deutsche Bank, Citigroup, and other banks have been hired to arrange the sale. The move aims to capitalize on the current market conditions and secure funding for the country's budget.

site_title: Goldman Sachs's Leissner said to move to Los Angeles, take leave
summary: Goldman Sachs executive Tim Leissner, who built the investment bank's Malaysia business, has relocated to Los Angeles and is on personal leave, according to people familiar with the matter. Leissner, a 18-year Goldman Sachs employee, remains an employee and did not comment. His relocation comes after the bank's dealings with Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd drew public scrutiny due to high fees paid to Goldman Sachs. The bank's involvement in the 1MDB scandal also drew attention. Leissner's exact return to work date is unknown.

site_title: Evidence points to Soh Chee Wen as mastermind of 2013 penny stock collapse: Public Prosecutor
summary: Malaysian businessman Soh Chee Wen is believed to be the mastermind behind the 2013 penny stock collapse in Singapore, according to Public Prosecutor. Authorities have gathered enough evidence to potentially file charges by the end of the year. Soh maintained his innocence, but the High Court rejected his bail application, citing him as a clear flight risk. His passport has been impounded since 2014, and he has cooperated with investigators. The case is ongoing, awaiting further investigation before charges can be filed.

site_title: Stocks and bonds too correlated to provide distinctive sources of return: survey
summary: A survey by Natixis Global Asset Management found that 77% of Singaporean institutional investors and 54% globally believe stocks and bonds are too correlated, making them unsuitable as distinct sources of return. The accommodative monetary policy has led to a shift in focus towards alternative assets, with 50% planning to increase allocations to private equity and 46% to private debt. Asian institutional investors are particularly attracted to alternatives, with 73% in Singapore planning to increase private equity allocations. Market volatility and low-yield investing environment are major concerns for investors.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Oil prices resume slide in Asia
summary: Oil prices resumed their downward trend in Asia, falling 1.88% to $30.86 for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 1.35% to $31.37 for Brent crude. The slide is attributed to concerns over a saturated market, weak demand, and a slowing global economy. Despite hopes for possible coordination between major producers to slash output, analysts remain skeptical, citing a lack of follow-through on previous talks. A report on US stockpiles is expected to provide further insight into demand.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as oil retreats
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday, led by energy and banking stocks, as oil prices retreated despite an overnight bounce. WorleyParsons, Oil Search, and Origin Energy declined by 8.3%, 5%, and 4.6% respectively. Financial stocks also fell, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia, ANZ Banking Group, and National Australia Bank down more than 1%. Meanwhile, New Zealand shares rose 0.3%, with A2 Milk and Xero gaining 3.8% and 2.6% respectively.

site_title: Asia: STI up 0.96% while rest of markets subdued
summary: Asian stocks rose 0.96% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 0.76% to 2,564.65 points, driven by investors hunting for bargains. Australian shares fell 0.3%. The wait-and-see mood ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement and fragile sentiment following a Chinese shares rout kept investors cautious.

site_title: ANZ announces management shake-up to improve focus
summary: ANZ Banking Group announced a management shake-up to improve focus on key businesses. Shayne Elliott was promoted to CEO, and changes include Mark Whelan heading international and institutional business, Fred Ohlsson moving to Australia, and David Hisco taking on Pacific operations. Gilles Planté, Deputy CEO Institutional and International Banking, is leaving. ANZ shares slipped 0.66% amid investor concerns about the bank's Asia strategy distracting from more profitable mortgage business at home. The bank aims to refocus on retail and commercial businesses in Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: Takata air-bag crisis spreads to India with reported fatality
summary: A 2007 Honda Civic in India crashed and killed its driver, attributed to a malfunctioning Takata air-bag inflator. This marks the 11th reported fatality involving Takata's air bags, the second outside the US. The incident is linked to an inflator manufactured in October 2006, the same month as another reported fatality in the US. Takata has expanded recalls and is seeking to gauge customer receptiveness to financial aid. The company's safety crisis has spread globally, with previous reported fatalities in the US and Malaysia.

site_title: Four Chinese listed companies say major shareholders face margin calls
summary: Four Chinese listed companies suspended trading due to major shareholders facing margin calls, prompting them to raise funds or pledge more collateral. The announcement comes after the stock market tumbled 6% on Tuesday, triggering concerns of further margin calls. The actual situation may be worse than publicly known, as some companies have chosen not to make public announcements. This development raises fears of a broader market impact, particularly in a volatile market.

site_title: China achieved main economic goals in 2015: Premier
summary: China achieved its main economic goals in 2015, with a 6.9% GDP growth rate, its slowest in 25 years, according to Premier Li Keqiang. He attributed the slowdown to sluggish global economies and denied China's role in global market volatility. Li expressed confidence in China's economy's ability to overcome challenges and called for increased confidence in its future growth prospects.

site_title: With China weakening, Apple turns to India
summary: Apple Inc is shifting focus to India as sales in China slow down. Despite a 76% increase in iPhone sales in India, the company still lags behind in market share, with less than 2% of the market. Apple's CEO Tim Cook sees the Indian market as a promising opportunity, citing the country's young demographics and growing appetite for smartphones. The company plans to expand its distribution in India, with plans to open its own stores, and is optimistic about future growth in the country.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; Apple suppliers up despite company's results
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.3% to 7,851.26 points, driven by gains from Apple suppliers Pegatron and TSMC, despite Apple's slowest-ever iPhone shipment increase and first revenue drop in 13 years. Pegatron and TSMC both rose about 1%, as investors factored in Apple's results into their stock prices. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$33.591 per US dollar.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise on oil bounce, but China, Fed cap; won up
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.7% on Wednesday, driven by an overnight oil bounce and gains from LG Display Co Ltd and LG Electronics Inc. However, gains were limited by Chinese market volatility and ahead of a Federal Reserve policy decision. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) reached 1,1884.61 points, while the won rose 0.3% against the dollar. Investors remain cautious amid external and internal uncertainties, with a focus on the Fed's potential interest rate decision later in the day.

site_title: China slowdown hits consumer brands as P&G, J&J see weak results
summary: Consumer product giants Procter & Gamble Co and Johnson & Johnson reported weaker sales in China's consumer market, with growth rates 5-8% annually, slower than in the past. The slowdown affects brands such as J&J's baby care and skin lines, while P&G's premium categories like SK-II skin cream line see growth. Despite this, both companies remain optimistic about China's long-term potential, with J&J viewing the country as a "long-term opportunity" and P&G expecting an improvement in the back half of the year.

site_title: Asset bubbles may be avoidable after all, Asian results show
summary: Asian economies have successfully implemented prudential measures to curb asset bubbles, with Singapore, Hong Kong, and New Zealand experiencing falling house prices. Regulators have introduced macroprudential tools, such as caps on debt repayment costs and higher stamp duties, to slow down speculative pressure. The measures have been effective, with prices in these jurisdictions now falling. This approach is being considered by other countries, including Australia, which has recently increased capital requirements for lenders to slow down mortgage growth. Experts argue that macroprudential measures are a key tool in preventing asset bubbles, particularly in emerging markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 5.93 points to 1,632.59. The index saw 108 million lots traded worth RM41 million, with 264 gainers outpacing 56 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in early trade on Wednesday, following gains in US and European markets. The Hang Seng Index increased 1.71% to 19,183.15, while the Shanghai benchmark composite index edged up 0.23% to 2,756.08. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.35%. The rebound in oil prices contributed to the market gains.

site_title: Japan PM Abe wants econ min Amari to stay in his post
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed support for Economy Minister Akira Amari to remain in his post despite criticism over a media report alleging he accepted bribes from a construction company. Amari is expected to hold a news conference to respond to the accusations. Abe wants Amari to continue working on his economic policies, including the TPP agreement. The government is preparing to send Amari to a meeting in New Zealand, signaling its intention to keep him in the cabinet. The accusations could harm the government's approval ratings before a national election expected this year.

site_title: The bank stock analysts hate even after takeover defences eased
summary: Bank of East Asia Ltd, a Hong Kong lender, dropped a shareholder agreement that eased takeover defenses, but analysts remain skeptical about a potential acquisition. The bank's shares are trading at a significant discount to its assets, making it unlikely that a buyer would accept a low offer. Analysts attribute the low valuation to concerns over asset quality in China, where the bank has a significant exposure, and a shift in market sentiment towards China-focused banks. None of the 15 analysts tracking the bank have buy ratings, with most recommending investors sell or hold.

site_title: Taiwan to punish nine banks on yuan derivative business
summary: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) has announced it will punish nine banks, including Citibank and Standard Chartered, for selling yuan derivative products to clients, resulting in significant losses due to the currency's sharp depreciation. The FSC will require banks to set aside reserves for possible defaults and ask investors to deposit 2% of the purchase price. This move aims to prevent further defaults and stabilize the banking sector, which has been affected by the yuan's decline.

site_title: Toyota, Suzuki Motor deny report of partnership talks
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and Suzuki Motor Corp have denied reports of potential partnership talks, including a possible capital tie-up. The denial comes after a Nikkei business daily reported that the two Japanese automakers were discussing a cross-shareholding deal to capitalize on demand for compact cars in emerging economies. Despite the denials, Suzuki shares rose 10% and Toyota shares climbed 3.6% following the report. Toyota also plans to turn Suzuki's domestic competitor Daihatsu Motor Co into a wholly owned subsidiary.

site_title: Australia inflation restrained, no trigger on rates
summary: Australia's inflation remained restrained in the fourth quarter, with underlying inflation slowing to 0.55% and annual inflation dipping to 2.0%, the lowest pace in almost four years. The Reserve Bank of Australia is unlikely to cut interest rates, despite market expectations, due to a strong jobs market and concerns about a housing bubble. Investors expect a rate cut by August, but the RBA's next meeting on February 2 is unlikely to see a change.

site_title: Norway's oil wealth, an enviable nest egg in hard times
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, valued at 6.96 trillion kroner (S$1.13 trillion), cushions the country's generous welfare state by investing in stocks, bonds, and real estate. The fund, which is strictly forbidden to touch, is estimated to generate 4% annual returns, supporting about one-eighth of public spending in Norway. Despite a decline in oil prices, the fund's growth curve has slowed, but its impact on public finances remains minimal. The government is exploring alternative economic sources, such as renewable energies, to reduce dependence on oil.

site_title: Cabbies block roads as France hit by multiple strikes
summary: French taxi drivers blocked roads with burning tires, forcing hundreds of flights to be cancelled, as part of a "Black Tuesday" of strikes. The protests, which also affected civil servants, hospital staff, and teachers, were sparked by frustration over upstart competitors like Uber. The strikes resulted in 14 arrests and disrupted transportation in Paris and other cities, with thousands of protesters marching in support of the workers' demands for higher pay and better conditions.

site_title: China's Dec industrial profits fall 4.7% year on year
summary: China's industrial profits declined 4.7% in December from a year ago, marking the seventh consecutive month of drops, due to a slowing economy and high costs. This follows a 2.3% decline in 2015 from 2014. Weakened domestic and global demand, as well as industrial overcapacity, are major factors contributing to the decline. China's economic growth cooled to 6.9% in 2015, its slowest pace in a quarter of a century.

site_title: Oil price plunge threatens shale revolution
summary: US shale oil producers face a make-or-break year as ultra-low crude prices threaten their survival, with dozens filing for bankruptcy in 2015. A 70% drop in prices is forcing many to operate at a loss, with analysts predicting a sharp jump in bankruptcies by mid-2016. The estimated price for survival is $50 a barrel, and the number of active drilling rigs has fallen 60% in the US. Despite efforts to lower costs, many shale producers are at risk of failure unless prices rise.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 33.91 points or 1.33% to 2,579.52 on Wednesday, following Wall Street's gains on cheap oil and speculation about a dovish US Federal Reserve approach. Active stocks included DBS, Singtel, and United Overseas Bank. Gainers outnumbered losers 111 to 18, with 41.6 million stocks worth S$76.8 million changing hands by 9:03am.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Apple reports slowest iPhone sales since 2007 launch
summary: Apple reported its slowest iPhone sales since the 2007 launch, with 74.8 million units sold in the quarter, a fractionally higher than the previous year. Despite this, the company posted record quarterly profit of $18.4 billion and revenue of $75.9 billion. The slowdown in iPhone sales has raised concerns about the company's ability to drive growth in a sluggish global economy. Apple shares have slid 20% since last year but ended the day down 0.7% at $99.30.

site_title: Europe: Commodities stocks help shares to bounce back
summary: European stocks bounced back on Tuesday, driven by commodity stocks rebounding after oil prices rose towards $31. The STOXX Europe 600 Oil and Gas index rose 2.5%, while the European basic resources index jumped over 4% after copper and zinc prices hit multi-week peaks. Shares in mining companies such as Anglo American, Rio Tinto, and Glencore also rose, helping the FTSEurofirst 300 index provisionally close 1% higher.

site_title: Rio Tinto sells Australia coal mine to Indonesia's Salim for US$224m
summary: Rio Tinto has sold its Mount Pleasant coal mine in Australia to Indonesian conglomerate Salim Group for US$224 million plus royalties. The mine, which has 474 million tonnes of marketable reserves, will be sold under a deal where royalties are paid only when coal prices exceed US$72.50 a tonne. The sale marks Rio Tinto's exit from coal as the company battles a sharp slump in prices. The deal leaves Rio Tinto with its Hunter Valley Operations and Mount Thorley Warkworth mines.

site_title: Changi Airport handles record 55.4m passengers in 2015, thanks to uptick in H2
summary: Changi Airport set a record 55.4 million passenger movements in 2015, a 2.5% year-over-year increase. The growth was driven by a rebound in the second half of the year, with 5% stronger passenger growth in the period. Cargo traffic increased by 0.5% to 1.85 million tonnes. Top source markets were Thailand, Vietnam, and China, while Indonesia and Hong Kong experienced lower growth. Seven new carriers started operations, and nine new destinations were added, with four in China.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Yuan drop may spur new Plaza Accord deal, Deutsche Bank says
summary: Deutsche Bank predicts the world's central banks should consider a coordinated currency intervention, similar to the 1985 Plaza Accord, to support the Chinese yuan and prevent the dollar from strengthening further. The yuan has weakened 6% against the dollar over six months, prompting China to spend a record $513 billion in foreign reserves. If capital controls fail, China may have to abandon intervention and allow the currency to weaken, potentially causing the dollar to surge and harming global economies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE Commercial Reit, Far East Hospitality Trust, Parkway Life Reit, Suntec Reit
summary: Key stocks to watch include OUE Commercial Reit, Far East Hospitality Trust, Parkway Life Reit, and Suntec Reit, which made material announcements on January 27, 2016. OUE C-Reit reported a 40.1% increase in distribution to S$17.63 million, while Far East Hospitality Trust appointed a new financial controller. Parkway Life Reit saw a 16.1% rise in distribution per unit, and Suntec Reit posted a 7.7% increase in distributable income to S$69.5 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Saudi funds scandal no match for Malaysia economic risk to Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak appears to have weathered a scandal over a $681 million donation from the Saudi royal family, with investigators finding no evidence of wrongdoing. Despite this, Najib faces a more significant threat to his hold on power: the country's economic slowdown. Najib has maintained support from the ruling party's powerful division chiefs and has pledged to prioritize efforts to halt the slowdown, which is affecting ethnic Malays in rural areas. The economy's growth forecast for 2016 has been lowered, and Najib is expected to announce revised forecasts and spending cuts to manage the fiscal deficit.

site_title: Bearish views abound at elite hedge fund conference
summary: Professional money managers at an elite Morgan Stanley investment conference expressed pessimistic views on the market, citing bearish takes on the energy sector, China, and companies such as Valeant Pharmaceuticals and SolarCity. Billionaire Paul Tudor Jones believes commodity prices will stay low due to a long-term cyclical downturn, while others, including Dmitry Balyasny and Jim Chanos, have negative views on energy company equities and China's economy. Despite this, some hedge fund managers, like Eric Mindich, expressed optimism on Japan and related investment opportunities.

site_title: How useful are circuit breakers?
summary: China's circuit breakers, installed to curb market volatility, were repeatedly triggered and ultimately removed after just four trading days, sparking criticism. A US Federal Reserve governor testified that circuit breakers may not be effective in reducing volatility, and academic studies found that they can increase trading volume and volatility. In contrast, Singapore's approach, which allows trading to continue with limited interruptions, is considered more effective in managing market fluctuations.

site_title: The number every China stock investor's watching as rout deepens
summary: China's stock market is experiencing a significant downturn, with the Shanghai Composite Index potentially reaching a bottom at 2,500, according to analysts. This level would represent a decline of 9% from the previous day's close and about 50% from its seven-year high. The 2,500 level is seen as a psychologically important milestone for investors, with the government expected to intervene to stabilize the market. The Shanghai Composite has lost over $6 trillion in equity value this year, contributing to a global stock market downturn, and analysts predict further volatility ahead.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks surge more than 3% in morning trade
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 3.19% in morning trade on Wednesday, following a rebound in oil prices. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 533.37 points to 17,242.27, and the broader Topix index rose 3.18%. Investors await the outcome of US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan policy meetings later this week for fresh trading cues. The US stock market also rose, with the Dow closing up 1.78%, the S&P 500 up 1.41%, and the Nasdaq adding 1.09%.

site_title: Tennis: Authorities announce independent review into corruption fight
summary: Tennis authorities have announced an independent review into corruption after a report alleged widespread match-fixing at the Australian Open. The review, led by Adam Lewis QC, aims to strengthen the integrity of the game and make the Tennis Integrity Unit more transparent and resourced. The review follows a BBC and BuzzFeed report that claimed top players had been suspected of fixing matches without facing action. Authorities are also calling on governments worldwide to make match-fixing a distinct criminal offence.

site_title: NYSE proposal to limit dark pool trading put under review by SEC
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is reviewing the New York Stock Exchange's (NYSE) proposal to limit dark pool trading, which is part of an industry-wide experiment to boost trading in small-cap stocks. The NYSE's proposed rules are more restrictive than the SEC's original approval, causing confusion and concern about potential delays. The disagreement involves the SEC's "tick-size pilot" program, which aims to test whether wider spreads will prompt more trading in dark pools, potentially making markets more liquid.

site_title: Fed opens first meeting since historic rate rise
summary: The Federal Reserve opened its first policy meeting since a historic rate rise last month, with weak inflation and global market turbulence clouding its plans. Despite a solid jobs growth and low unemployment, inflation remains elusive, and policymakers may reassess their expectations. The meeting comes as oil prices continue to fall, sparking a sell-off in equity markets and raising concerns about deflationary pressures. No policy action is expected, but the Fed's policy statement may signal a more cautious tone, potentially delaying further rate increases.

site_title: 'Doomsday' clock remains at three mins to midnight
summary: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has kept the "Doomsday" clock at three minutes to midnight, its closest position in 20 years, due to ongoing nuclear threats, climate change, and global instability. The clock, which symbolizes humanity's proximity to destruction, was last at this position in 1983 during the height of the Cold War. Experts express concern that global nuclear arsenals are growing and climate change efforts lack teeth, despite some positive news such as the Iran nuclear agreement and the Paris climate talks.

site_title: AIG bondholders dodge break-up bullet
summary: American International Group (AIG) announced plans to spin off its mortgage insurance unit and sell its broker-dealer network, avoiding a full break-up of the company. This move is seen as a better option for creditors, who would have faced increased risk of ratings downgrades. AIG will also return $25 billion to shareholders over the next two years. The move has been welcomed by bondholders, who see it as a more favorable outcome than a complete break-up. Fitch has affirmed AIG's senior debt rating at BBB+, citing the company's capital return plans and recent loss reserve charge.

site_title: US dollar slips vs euro ahead as Fed meets
summary: The US dollar slipped to $1.0868 per euro on Tuesday as the Federal Reserve met, with analysts expecting no policy change from the historic interest rate increase in December. The Fed's policy statement will be closely watched for signs of a change in views on inflation and the impact of global market turmoil, including China's slowing growth and falling oil prices. A dovish statement could put pressure on the dollar.

site_title: EU seals bad loans accord with Italy
summary: The European Union and Italy have reached an agreement on a guarantee vehicle to help Italian banks sell bad loans, estimated at around 200 billion euros. The deal, reached after nearly five hours of talks, will allow Italian banks to sell bad loans at market prices without being considered state aid. The accord follows a year-long effort by Rome to find a solution to aid its struggling banking system. The EU and Italy will now work together to establish the guarantees, which will help Italian banks to face up to bad loan losses and limit lending to households and firms.

site_title: China climbs back up Janet Yellen's worry list amid market rout
summary: China's economic woes, including a 13-month low Shanghai Composite Index and a 5% decline in the yuan against the dollar, have bolstered calls for the US Federal Reserve to hold off on another interest-rate increase. Experts say the Fed must consider China's economic slowdown and market volatility, particularly given the uncertainty surrounding the yuan's devaluation. Despite the slowdown, China's GDP is expected to expand 6.5% in 2016, and the Fed may be cautious in its response to maintain a dovish outcome.

site_title: COE allocation should take a leaf from IPO system
summary: A Straits Times Forum letter writer suggests the COE allocation system take a cue from the IPO system, allocating a certain percentage of COEs to private bidders. This could provide greater transparency and fairness in the bidding process, which has seen a 50-fold increase in COE prices since 1990 due to factors such as increased affluence and limited COE availability. The writer proposes requiring dealers to provide two sets of prices, allowing private buyers to compare and bid.

site_title: Oil prices rise on talk of Russia, Opec coordination
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as Saudi Arabia and Russia discussed possible coordination to cut petroleum output. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose $1.11 to $31.45 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude rose $1.30 to $31.80 a barrel. Iraqi Oil Minister Adel Abdulmahdi said Baghdad was ready to cooperate on production cuts, but only if non-Opec producers did so as well. Analysts remain skeptical about the likelihood of an agreement, citing Saudi Arabia's reluctance to cut output and US shale producers' potential response to higher prices.

site_title: Europe's junk bonds see greater losses from Brazil than China
summary: European investors are facing significant losses on junk bonds sold by companies with operations in Brazil, exceeding those with exposure to China. More than half of the region's worst-performing euro bonds were sold by Brazilian companies, totaling 10 billion euros. The Brazilian economy is heading towards its deepest two-year recession in over a century, and a corruption scandal is undermining growth efforts. European firms, including Casino Guichard-Perrachon and Vallourec, are among those struggling with losses.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit posts higher Q4 DPU, bolstered by One Raffles Place
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 40.1% year-over-year increase in Q4 2015's distribution per unit (DPU) to S$17.63 million, driven by the acquisition of One Raffles Place. DPU rose to 1.36 Singapore cents, exceeding the forecast of 1.13 cents. Net property income more than doubled to S$29.68 million, and gross revenue doubled to S$40.34 million. The company's full-year DPU was 4.38 cents, beating the forecast of 4.12 cents.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Bloomberg could be next political Snowzilla
summary: Former New York City mayor Michael Bloomberg is considering a third-party bid in the 2016 presidential election, which could hurt Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton's chances of winning the White House. Analysts predict that a third-party candidate would likely take votes from one of the major candidates, potentially affecting the outcome of the election. Bloomberg's calculations are based on concerns that a nationalist like Donald Trump and a socialist like Bernie Sanders could win their respective parties' nominations, leading to unpredictable election results.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on higher oil, Fed speculation
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by higher oil prices and speculation that the Federal Reserve will issue a dovish statement on future interest rate increases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.78% to 16,167.23, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.41% and 1.09%, respectively. Oil prices rose 3.7% to $31.45 a barrel, lifting shares of petroleum-linked companies. Analysts expect the Fed to signal a go-slow approach to future rate hikes, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: McDonald's reports strong earnings, helped by all-day breakfast
summary: McDonald's reported a 10% increase in Q4 profit to US$1.2 billion, driven by strong same-store sales growth of 5.7% in the US and 5% globally. The company's all-day breakfast menu helped boost sales, with customers returning to the brand and new customers attracted to the convenience. Profit was also boosted by price increases and cost-cutting measures, but customer traffic in the US declined 3% year-over-year. McDonald's shares rose 2% in early trading.

site_title: Sony moves PlayStation business to Silicon Valley
summary: Sony is moving its PlayStation business to Silicon Valley, consolidating its game console offerings under one roof. The new company, Sony Interactive Entertainment, will be based in San Mateo, California, and will unify Sony Computer Entertainment and Sony Network Entertainment International. The move aims to accelerate the growth of the PlayStation business, with the latest generation of consoles outselling rival consoles. As of April, the PlayStation hardware, software, and online businesses will be under one entity, bringing together teams working on virtual reality, streaming music, and online gameplay.

site_title: Amazon and Netflix lead the way as Sundance's top buyers
