The decrease marks the lowest reading since July 2015.

site_title: China: Stocks rise as coal and steel shares gain on capacity cuts
summary: China's stocks rose 0.8% to 2,938.52, driven by coal and steel producers after the government pledged to cut overcapacity and excess labor, targeting a 150 million ton reduction in crude steel production and halting new coal mine approvals. The offshore yuan rose 0.03% and benchmark money-market rates fell. Analysts say the measures will help industries regain a balance in supply and demand, potentially improving profitability and prices.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won rise on crude gains, improved risk appetites
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.7% to 1,893.43 points, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street and improved risk appetites. Oil prices rallied, contributing to the gains. Foreign investors sold 82.3 billion won worth of shares, marking a 13th consecutive day of net selling. The South Korean won rose 0.5% to 1,194.2 won per US dollar, its third consecutive gain.

site_title: Ford to exit all operations in Japan, Indonesia this year
summary: Ford Motor Co plans to exit all operations in Japan and Indonesia by the end of this year due to "no reasonable path to profitability." The decision includes shutting dealerships, stopping sales and imports of Ford and Lincoln vehicles, and shifting product development from Japan to other regions. A formal announcement was made to employees in the Asia Pacific region, with product development set to relocate elsewhere.

site_title: Trafigura trades first Singapore LNG derivatives contract
summary: Trafigura, a European trading house, and Pavilion Gas, a Singapore-based company, have made the first trade of a liquefied natural gas (LNG) derivatives contract on the Singapore Exchange. The contract, worth $50,000, was based on Singapore's weekly spot price index for Asian LNG. This launch aims to break Singapore's decade-long reliance on oil-linked pricing and establish the city-state as a regional hub for LNG trade. The contract is part of a bid to reduce risk in the Asian LNG market.

site_title: US IPOs on track for slowest month since recession: chart
summary: US initial public offerings (IPOs) are on track for the slowest month since the 2008 recession, with zero companies starting trading so far in 2016. The sluggish market is attributed to volatility driven by the slowing Chinese economy, depressed commodities, and uncertainty around interest rates. Only three companies plan to price their offerings this month, and an IPO market recovery may take months, not days or weeks, according to NYSE Group Inc. President Tom Farley.

site_title: US plane re-routed to Canada after turbulence injures seven
summary: An American Airlines flight from Miami to Milan experienced turbulence on Sunday, forcing it to land in Newfoundland, Canada, after seven people were injured. The flight, AA206, departed Miami at 3:03pm local time with 192 passengers and 11 crew members on board. Upon landing, seven people were taken to the hospital, including four passengers and three crew members. The cause of the turbulence is not specified. The incident has not resulted in any fatalities.

site_title: Singapore No 4 worldwide for supporting global innovation through domestic policies
summary: Singapore ranked fourth worldwide for domestic policies supporting global innovation, according to the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation. The report studied 56 countries and found that robust innovation policies are essential for economic growth. Singapore's policies were found to be beneficial for the global innovation ecosystem and least harmful, while the report calls for policymakers to prioritize global innovation and establish a Global Science and Innovation Foundation to fund research on major global challenges.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Improving social and financial bottom lines
summary: Historically, business prioritized profits over social responsibility, as economist Milton Friedman stated. However, some argue that focusing solely on financial returns can harm a company's competitive edge and existence. In contrast, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, marking a shift towards prioritizing social and financial responsibilities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares have solid rise as markets welcome higher oil prices
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.4% on Monday, led by energy plays, as oil prices rebounded and global equity markets recovered. The Hang Seng index reached 19,340.14, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.8%. Investors took cues from a stable currency market, following Beijing's intervention to stem further slides in the offshore yuan. Despite a technical reprieve, analysts warn that the bearish trend may not end, with fundamentals potentially deteriorating further.

site_title: Paris catwalks rediscover their cavalier swagger
summary: French fashion is back to its "cavalier swagger" with designer Olivier Rousteing's recent show for Balmain, aiming to make men feel like princes again. Rousteing declared his intention to revive post-attacks Paris's swagger, showcasing a dashing, unashamedly masculine collection.

site_title: HSBC strikes agreement with other lenders of China Fishery to terminate liquidators
summary: HSBC has agreed with China Fishery Group's other lenders to terminate the liquidators appointed by HSBC last year. The deal, announced on January 20, allows for the removal of KPMG joint provisional liquidators and the dismissal of winding-up petitions. Grant Thornton Hong Kong has been appointed as an independent accountant, and a chief restructuring officer for China Fishery has also been appointed. An interim payment of US$3.1 million will be made within 21 days, pending court approval. The agreement aims to resolve the dispute and allow China Fishery to restructure.

site_title: Indonesia will ease policy again, but timing unclear: central bank deputy governor
summary: Indonesia's central bank Deputy Governor Perry Warjiyo announced that the country will ease its monetary policy again, although the timing remains unclear. This decision is influenced by domestic and external conditions, and the magnitude of the easing will be determined after assessments. The government's recent infrastructure auctions have strengthened the signal for monetary policy easing.

site_title: Fuel hedging proves costly for US airlines as oil prices plummet
summary: US airlines saved hundreds of millions of dollars from oil prices halving since June, but also forfeited a significant portion of that gain due to fuel hedges. The hedges, bought as protection against oil price increases, locked in prices at a higher rate than the current market price. As a result, airlines are facing a costly reversal of their hedging strategy, highlighting the challenges of navigating volatile fuel prices.

site_title: Rebelo de Sousa wins Portuguese presidential poll
summary: Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, a 67-year-old law professor and TV pundit, won Portugal's presidential election with 52.78% of the vote, surpassing his closest rival Antonio Sampaio da Novoa's 22.17%. De Sousa secured the post with 50% of the vote, avoiding a runoff poll.

site_title: Kerry in Laos to discuss bomb legacy and Asean partnership
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry visited Laos to discuss the legacy of unexploded American bombs and China's influence in Southeast Asia. The trip precedes a summit hosted by President Barack Obama in California with Asean leaders, with Laos assuming the regional bloc's chairmanship this year. Kerry's visit also aims to strengthen diplomatic ties between the US and Laos, which will see an autumn visit by Obama, the first by a US leader.

site_title: Novo Nordisk aims to be ahead of the pharma pack with Iran investment
summary: Novo Nordisk, the world's top insulin supplier, plans to expand its presence in Iran after the lifting of nuclear sanctions. The company aims to establish a strong presence and secure good relations with authorities to capitalize on the country's large and growing population. With a pre-emptive investment plan, Novo Nordisk expects to be ahead of the competition in the market, driven by the need for new medicines in Iran.

site_title: Singapore households see inflation ease further in H2 2015
summary: Singapore's Consumer Price Index (CPI) for households fell 0.7% year on year in the second half of 2015, driven by lower accommodation costs and electricity tariffs. This decline, excluding imputed rentals, marked the first since 2002. Across different income groups, the CPIs for the lowest, middle, and highest 20% of households decreased 1.4%, 0.5%, and 0.8% respectively. The overall inflation rate for 2015 was 0.5%, a decline from the previous year's 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Bond issues freeze as panic spreads across global markets
summary: Global bond markets remain frozen due to panic, with issuers avoiding primary markets and equity indices entering bear market territory. The banking industry is concerned about issuer confidence, potentially prolonging the current hiatus. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers, and Chinese banks struggle with a consumer lending push.

site_title: China diesel use slumps as natural gas, gasoline demand gains
summary: China's diesel consumption dropped 3.7% in 2015, the second consecutive year, as the economy shifts towards consumption-led growth. In contrast, gasoline and natural gas demand rose 7% and 5.7%, respectively. Industrial output slowed, while vehicle sales are expected to increase 6% this year. Diesel demand is expected to stay flat or fall in 2016, while gasoline use will rise by 200,000 barrels a day. Gasoline consumption is projected to surpass diesel demand for the first time by 2024.

site_title: Oil prices extend rise above US$32 in Asia on demand hopes
summary: Oil prices in Asia rose on Monday, extending their rally above US$32 a barrel, driven by hopes of extra stimulus measures in the eurozone and Japan that could boost demand. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rose 14 cents to US$32.33, while Brent increased 17 cents to US$32.35. A report showing eurozone business activity continued to expand in January boosted hopes for oil demand catching up with supply. Analysts remain cautious, however, with Iranian crude set to return to the market within months.

site_title: Yellen losing dollar bet as its rise slows growth and inflation
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and her colleagues have been wrong-footed by the stronger dollar, which has appreciated by 2% since the last meeting in December. The dollar's rise is curbing economic growth and putting downward pressure on inflation, which the Fed judges is too low. Despite suggestions that the dollar's rise would soon slow, the currency continues to appreciate, prompting investors to scale back their expectations of Fed rate hikes in 2016, with some now predicting only two rate hikes this year.

site_title: Hong Kong scores a record in survey of priciest housing markets
summary: Hong Kong ranked as the most expensive housing market, with a median home price costing 19 times the median annual household income, according to the Demographia International Housing Affordability Survey. This marks the highest unaffordability score ever recorded by the research firm. Hong Kong's home prices climbed 370% from 2003 to their peak in 2015, and prices are expected to fall 30% this year. Sydney ranked second, and Vancouver third, with London ranking eighth. The survey highlights Hong Kong and London as cities at risk of a housing bubble due to declining affordability.

site_title: Asia shivers, slips and slides in record low temperatures
summary: Asia experienced record-low temperatures over the weekend, causing deaths, flight cancellations, and chaos. Snow, sleet, and icy winds affected Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong, China, and Vietnam. Record-breaking temperatures were recorded in Japan's western and central regions, and rare snow fell in subtropical areas. The cold snap caused hundreds of flights to be cancelled, tens of thousands of people to be stranded, and freezing conditions to be reported in cities like Bangkok and Hong Kong. At least 90 deaths were attributed to the cold weather in Taiwan.

site_title: Najib defends security laws as Malaysia grapples with IS terror threat
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak defended the country's stricter security laws, passed in 2015, to combat terrorism despite criticism from human rights groups. The laws allow for suspects to be held without trial and have been used to detain dozens of individuals suspected of links to terrorism. Najib said the laws are necessary to ensure national safety, citing the threat from Islamic State and radicalization of youths. Critics argue the laws could be used against government detractors, but Najib emphasized the need to strike a balance between civil liberties and national security.

site_title: This week's critical BOJ meeting may see further market-impacting actions
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to meet on January 29, sparking speculation about potential monetary-easing moves to address weakening inflation expectations. Analysts are divided on the effectiveness of such actions, with some warning they could harm the economy. The BOJ's governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, made comments during the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, fueling speculation. The meeting's outcome will have significant market-impacting effects, but its impact on Japan's economy remains uncertain.

site_title: Six banks said to be negotiating settlement in Swiss Libor probe
summary: Six banks are in settlement talks with Switzerland's competition regulator in a probe into Libor rigging, with a settlement expected by July, according to two sources. The Swiss Competition Commission is seeking an "accord amiable" with the banks as it wraps up the four-year investigation. The outcome of the settlement could potentially bring an end to the probe, which has targeted several major banks.

site_title: Netpluz Asia acquires assets of two companies from Si2i for S$3m
summary: Netpluz Asia acquires assets of Mediaring Network Services (MRNS) and Mediaring Communications (MRC) from Si2i for S$3 million. The commercial assets will be acquired, while retail assets will remain with Si2i. The purchase will be spread out over four phases until mid-2017.

site_title: Self-driving cars may get here before we're ready
summary: Self-driving cars could become a reality within the next decade, but only 6% of the US's most populous cities have included them in their long-term plans. This raises questions about readiness for widespread adoption, with major carmakers and tech companies attending the World Economic Forum in Davos. Despite the potential benefits, concerns about infrastructure and public acceptance remain.

site_title: Siemens to buy CD-adapco for close to US$1b: source
summary: Siemens AG, Europe's largest industrial group, is set to acquire privately held US engineering software firm CD-adapco for approximately US$1 billion in cash. The deal, which could be announced as early as Monday, complements Siemens' product lifecycle management software and will bolster the company's focus on technology innovation. CD-adapco, founded in 1980, makes computer programs used by engineers to simulate engine workings, with annual revenue of US$200 million and a 15% annual growth rate. The acquisition comes after CD-adapco's co-founder and CEO Steve MacDonald's passing, with his widow taking over as interim CEO.

site_title: 86,000 people stranded on blizzard-hit S. Korea resort island
summary: A blizzard hit South Korea's resort island of Jeju, stranding around 86,000 people after the airport was shut for the third consecutive day due to heavy snowfall, the heaviest in three decades. The island, known for its warm climate, experienced record lows of -6.1 degrees Celsius. The cold snap affected the entire country, with temperatures plummeting across the nation.

site_title: Malaysia calls for caution on MH370 as metal found in Thailand
summary: Malaysia's government has urged caution on the location of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 after a 2m by 3m piece of metal was found off southern Thailand's east coast. The metal, with electrical wires and stamped numbers, was discovered by fishermen on January 23. Australian authorities are waiting for the results of any investigation into the reported discovery, amid ongoing efforts to locate the wreckage in the Indian Ocean thousands of kilometers to the south.

site_title: Japan's Sharp rescue may not be such a bright idea
summary: A Japanese state-backed fund, Innovation Network Corporation of Japan (INCJ), is leading the bid to rescue LCD maker Sharp Corp, which could be its third bailout in three years. Industry insiders question whether this rescue can protect Sharp from intense competition and pricing pressures. Sharp has struggled with fierce competition in the LCD market, and a bailout may not shield it from these challenges. The outcome of the rescue bid is uncertain, leaving Sharp's future in the LCD industry uncertain.

site_title: Anonymous messaging app stirs controversy in Israel
summary: An anonymous messaging app called Blindspot has launched in Israel, sparking controversy over its potential to encourage teen bullying and internet trolls. The app, developed by a company with investors including music stars Will.I.Am and Nicki Minaj, allows users to send anonymous messages, photos, and videos to their contacts. Critics have raised concerns about the app's potential to facilitate harassment and cyberbullying, while the company has defended its product as a tool for users to express themselves freely.

site_title: A Hong Kong move unlikely to slash HSBC tax bill
summary: HSBC is unlikely to benefit significantly from a potential move to Hong Kong, where it would face higher taxes on certain expenses and fewer tax deductions on bonuses. The bank's UK-based operations generate significant profits, but its British tax bill is relatively low due to the fact that many overhead costs are booked in the UK. HSBC's investment bank, which is headquartered in London, had profits of $8 billion in 2014, while its commercial bank, which also has a significant British presence, had profits of $9 billion. A move to Hong Kong could increase the bank's tax bill, particularly if it needs to shift more UK profit to Hong Kong to take advantage of the lower tax rate.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Vallianz, A-Reit
summary: Keppel Corporation plans to merge S$26 billion worth of its asset management businesses under its wholly-owned subsidiary Keppel Capital, aiming to boost contributions from its investment division.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Boeing nabs US$3.2b jet deal as United spurns Bombardier
summary: Boeing has secured a US$3.2 billion deal with United Airlines to order 40 of its smallest jetliners, the Boeing 737-700, set to enter service in mid-2017. This thwarted Bombardier's bid to secure the order for its C Series model. United aims to cut its use of cramped regional jets, while Southwest Airlines is also acquiring 33 of the Boeing single-aisle jets.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won rise as oil prices jump; eyes on Fed
summary: South Korean shares rose 1% to 1,898.28 points on Monday as oil prices jumped, but investors remained cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan meetings this week. Oil prices are seen as a barometer for the global economy, driving much of the volatility in the market.

site_title: Australia business conditions ease a little, still strong
summary: Australia's business conditions eased slightly in December, but remained strong for the fifth consecutive month, according to a National Australia Bank survey. The index of business conditions slipped 3 points to +7, while capacity utilisation fell to 80% from 80.8%. Despite the slight easing, sales, profits, and employment remained in positive territory, indicating a robust economy.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras vows to implement pension reform at anniversary rally
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras reaffirmed his pledge to implement pension reform, stating it's "necessary" despite opposition. In a speech at a rally marking his one-year anniversary in power, Tsipras said the pension system "must go ahead" to prevent its collapse.

site_title: Malaysia arrests 7 suspected IS militants
summary: Malaysian police arrested seven suspected Islamic State (IS) militants, including one linked to the Jakarta attack, in a series of raids nationwide. Thirty rounds of ammunition, books and videos on jihad, and an IS flag were seized. The arrests come after a month-long investigation, with the national police chief stating that the group was plotting violence. The operation is the latest in a crackdown on extremist activity in the country.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 2.47% in the first minutes of trading on Monday, following a 2.5% rally at the end of last week. The Hang Seng Index jumped to 19,341.41, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.60% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.86%.

site_title: Vallianz to place 550m new shares at 4.3 Singapore cents each
summary: Vallianz Holdings agreed to place 550 million new shares at S$0.043 each to two Chinese state-owned companies, CSR Zhuzhou Electric Locomotive Research Institute and CRRC (Hong Kong) Co Limited, for S$23.65 million. The placement price is a 4.6% premium to the weighted average price of S$0.0411.

site_title: Asian stocks continue world rebound amid oil revival; yen rises
summary: Asian stocks rose for a third day, driven by a rebound in oil prices and bets on central bank intervention to stabilize markets. The MSCI All-Country World Index surged, with the yen rising as the Korean won strengthened. US crude oil climbed to $32.44, its steepest two-day advance since 2008. The rally followed a 2% jump in US shares on Friday, marking the gauge's best day since June 2012.

site_title: As China tries to reassure on yuan stability, investors see depreciation
summary: Chinese policymakers assured investors that they have no intention of devaluing the yuan further, but investors remain skeptical due to past devaluations and perceived policy flip-flops. The yuan's depreciation in August has fueled financial market jitters, with investors worried about the economy's true state. A senior portfolio manager expressed concern that market expectations of further yuan depreciation could destabilize the market. Despite recent efforts to stabilize the market, investors remain cautious about the yuan's value.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Monday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets closed on Monday for a public holiday. No key events or market movements were reported in the article.

site_title: Consumers will demand privacy for healthcare data
summary: Consumers are expected to demand greater control over their healthcare data, potentially leading to a retreat from sharing personal information online. Technology experts at the World Economic Forum suggest that people may be willing to pay for the privilege of keeping their healthcare information private. This shift in consumer behavior could have significant implications for the healthcare industry, which relies heavily on data sharing. As a result, companies may need to adapt and provide users with more control over their data.

site_title: NY community gardens threatened by plans for affordable housing
summary: New York community gardens are under threat from plans to build affordable housing. The city has identified over a dozen community gardens, including the Mandela Community Garden in Harlem, for demolition to make way for construction. The gardens, which provide green spaces for residents, are being targeted due to a shortage of available land and rising property prices. The city's plan aims to address the housing shortfall, but the loss of these community spaces has sparked concern among residents and garden volunteers.

site_title: Trump would 'love' Bloomberg presidential run
summary: Donald Trump welcomed a potential presidential run by Michael Bloomberg, saying he would "love" to face the fellow billionaire. Bloomberg, a 73-year-old former New York mayor, is reportedly considering an independent bid, prepared to spend $1 billion of his personal fortune. The move could create an opening for Trump if he and Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders win their parties' nominations.

site_title: Johnson Controls in advanced talks to acquire Tyco: source
summary: Johnson Controls Inc is in advanced talks to acquire Tyco International Plc, a fire protection and security company, in a potential deal worth billions. The acquisition would be the largest in the company's history, combining Johnson Controls' car battery and heating and ventilation equipment with Tyco's security and fire protection services. The deal, if completed, would be a significant move in the industry and provide a clear indication of strategic mergers advancing despite recent market volatility.

site_title: 1979: Transforming the workforce for a new economy
summary: In 1979, Singapore's government implemented policies to transform the workforce and shift the nation towards higher-end production and jobs. The National Wages Council recommended wage hikes, and companies were asked to contribute to a Skills Development Fund and increase employer contributions to pension accounts. However, the reaction from industries was negative, warning of layoffs and unsustainable costs. Despite this, the government offered assistance for companies making the transition. The goal was to move Singapore up the value chain and improve productivity.

site_title: 'Unicorns' may be mauled by bear market
summary: The "unicorn" startup market, characterized by billion-dollar, privately funded companies, is bracing for a slowdown due to a bear market. After a year of free-flowing capital, venture capital investors are concerned about the sector's prospects. This could lead to a thinning of the "herd" of startups, as those struggling to secure fresh capital may be mauled.

site_title: Vietnam's progressive PM not nominated for party leadership
summary: Vietnam's ruling Communist Party has agreed on a single nomination for each of four key leadership posts, excluding Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung, who is seen as a modernizer and pro-business leader. Dung's exclusion has fueled speculation of a potential exit from politics. The nominations require endorsement at the party's ongoing congress, which will decide the country's leadership. This development comes as Vietnam continues to liberalize its economy and undergo significant changes.

site_title: Living without heat in winter is common reality for the poor in US
summary: In the US, many low-income individuals struggle to afford heat during winter, with some living in substandard housing. Chamika McLaughlin, a mother of one, makes a difficult choice between staying cold or risking her life by using the oven to heat her home. This is a common reality for the poor, with McLaughlin facing a similar situation for the second time in two heatless winters.

site_title: Foreign worker levy to stay, Govt to continue building Singaporean core: Teo Ser Luck
summary: Singapore's government will maintain a foreign worker levy to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) cope with a tight labor market. Minister of State for Manpower Teo Ser Luck stated that the country will continue to build a Singaporean core workforce to reduce reliance on foreign labor. The decision aims to support SMEs facing cost challenges in a low-growth economy.

site_title: New York flights pick up after rash of cancellations amid blizzard
summary: New York City area airports experienced a surge in flights on Sunday evening following a record-breaking US East Coast snowstorm that led to widespread cancellations and delays. Arrivals and departures resumed at LaGuardia, John F. Kennedy International, and Newark Liberty airports, with some Washington airports also starting to operate again. According to FlightAware.com, the chief executive, Daniel Baker, reported that "there is light at the end of the tunnel" as flights began to pick up.

site_title: SGX seeks to break LNG's price link to oil
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to launch futures and swaps contracts linked to its LNG index, breaking the market's reliance on oil prices. The contracts, set to start trading on Monday, will be determined by average weekly assessments from producers, consumers, and traders in the physical LNG market. This move aims to solidify SGX's role as Asia's energy trading hub and provide a benchmark for LNG prices in the region.

site_title: Hot stock: Vallianz surges after roping in China investor
summary: Vallianz Holdings saw its shares surge 4.88% after agreeing to place 550 million new shares at S$0.043 each to CRRC Corp, a major Chinese investor. The deal valued the shares at S$23.35 billion. About 10 million shares changed hands, making Vallianz the most actively traded stock on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Update: Keppel Corp to merge S$26b in asset management businesses in major restructuring
summary: Keppel Corporation is planning to merge S$26 billion in asset management businesses under its wholly-owned subsidiary Keppel Capital, aiming to grow contributions from its investment division. The move involves merging Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management, Keppel DC Reit Management, Keppel Reit Management, and fund manager Alpha Investment Partners. This restructuring exercise aims to increase the overall contribution of its asset management businesses, which currently manage S$26 billion of quality assets and generated S$60 million in profits last year.

site_title: Japan's Dec exports fall 8.0% year on year, down for 3rd month
summary: Japan's exports fell 8.0% in December from a year earlier, marking the third consecutive month of decline, due to a slowdown in China's economy and emerging markets. This compares to economists' median estimate of a 6.8% drop. Meanwhile, imports fell 18.0% in December, resulting in a trade balance surplus of 140.2 billion yen.

site_title: UBS's Magnus sees end of China selloff giving way to muted gain
summary: UBS's George Magnus predicts China's stock slump may end around 2,500, with a rebound expected to be muted. The Shanghai Composite Index has fallen to a one-year low, but Magnus notes it won't be substantially higher. He expresses skepticism about a sustained rally, citing concerns about China's economic transformation and a potential soft landing. The current slump is expected to last around 14%, but Magnus believes a rebound will be less vigorous than expected.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday

site_title: US dollar edges down but close to recent highs; Fed, BOJ in focus
summary: The US dollar edged down 0.2% to 118.57 against the Japanese yen, near a two-week high, as markets calmed after recent volatility. Investors focus on upcoming central bank meetings, with the US Federal Reserve expected to keep its federal funds rate unchanged at 0.25-0.50%. The decision is due on Wednesday, following a one-year low of 115.97 reached earlier this week.

site_title: China business confidence, recruitment hit record lows in Jan: SMI survey
summary: China's business confidence and recruitment activity hit record lows in January, according to a survey by London-based World Economics. The Sales Managers' Index fell to 51.0, down from 51.7 in December, indicating ongoing but modest economic growth. This adds to signs of weakness in China's economy, prompting policymakers to consider additional support measures. The index has averaged 51.4 since the second half of last year, suggesting steady but slower growth compared to a year ago.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 10-day top, New Zealand shares edge high
summary: Australian shares rose 1.24% to a 10-day high, reaching 4,986.7 points, driven by a rally in oil markets. Energy shares, such as Origin Energy Ltd and Woodside Petroleum Ltd, led the gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index surpassed its previous high since January 15.

site_title: IS releases video of 'Paris attackers'
summary: The Islamic State group released a video showing nine jihadists believed to be responsible for the November 2016 Paris attacks, which killed 130 people. The video, titled "Kill wherever you find them," threatens coalition countries, including Britain. The group's message is directed at countries participating in the US-led coalition fighting IS in Syria and Iraq since 2014.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; Largan, TSMC up after Apple gains
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 1.4% to 7,863.34 on Monday, driven by gains in Apple Inc's suppliers following the US company's 5% surge on Wall Street. The electronics subindex rose 1.2% and the financials subindex gained 1.9%. The rally follows Apple's Friday share increase, which is expected to boost its suppliers' shares.

site_title: BI expects rupiah to strengthen in 2nd half of 2016
summary: Bank Indonesia expects the rupiah to strengthen in the second half of 2016 due to more stable external conditions. Deputy Governor Perry Warjiyo anticipates the Federal Reserve raising US interest rates twice this year, and China stabilizing its financial market, which should lead to a more stable currency. This contrasts with the rupiah's 10% decline against the dollar last year, making it the second-worst performing currency in emerging Asia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, advancing 0.67% to 17,071.99, driven by global rally hopes on central bank stimulus hints. Japan's annual trade deficit narrowed, adding to the market's optimism.

site_title: China bears descend on Alibaba as investors fret about economy
summary: US short sellers have increased bets against Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., pushing short interest to 7.5% of shares outstanding, the highest in over 14 months. This surge in bearish bets is driven by concerns about China's economic slowdown, which has led to a bear market in mainland stocks. As a result, Alibaba's American depositary receipts have fallen over 13% since the start of the year.

site_title: Former Australian PM Abbott vows to stay on in politics
summary: Former Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has announced his decision to re-contest his Sydney seat in the next election, ending months of speculation about his future. Abbott was ousted in a leadership coup in September and had been considering his options. He has held the seat for 22 years and has received support to continue serving the country. Abbott's decision comes after discussions with his family and Liberal party colleagues.

site_title: Egypt said to get US$20b of oil products from Saudi Arabia
summary: Egypt has secured a 5-year deal with Saudi Arabia worth approximately US$20 billion in oil products, with easy payment terms. The agreement also includes a 3-month deal worth US$1.5 billion. The deal marks Saudi Arabia's support for Egypt's struggling economy, with the two countries' heads of state set to attend a ceremony to announce the agreement.

site_title: Storm-hit US digs out as death toll rises to 22
summary: A historic blizzard, dubbed "Snowzilla," has hit the eastern US, killing at least 22 people and affecting 85 million residents. The storm brought 68cm of snow in New York's Central Park, the second-highest accumulation since records began in 1869. Disruptions persisted, with Washington paralyzed by over 56cm of snow. As the US slowly recovers, major travel disruptions continue, with many areas still inaccessible.

site_title: Saudi Aramco may open potential IPO to international investors
summary: Saudi Aramco may consider opening a potential initial public offering (IPO) to international investors, according to Chairman Khalid Al-Falih. The company is studying options for a share sale, which could include a full IPO or listing some subsidiaries. Saudi Aramco will not sell its oil reserves, but instead offer the economic value of the company. The decision is part of the kingdom's efforts to diversify its economy.

site_title: Oil climbs further on short-covering, Brent at over US$32
summary: Oil prices surged 10% on Friday, reaching over $32.50 a barrel, driven by short-covering demand. This is one of the biggest daily rallies in history, as bearish traders scrambled to close their record short positions. Brent crude rose to $32.51 a barrel, while US crude approached $32.50 a barrel. The market's long decline may be over, according to traders, who are betting on a turnaround.

site_title: Keppel Corp to merge asset management interests under Keppel Capital
summary: Keppel Corp plans to merge its four asset management subsidiaries under Keppel Capital Holdings to enhance operational efficiency. Keppel Capital is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Keppel Corp, and the move aims to streamline its asset management interests. The four subsidiaries involved are Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management, Keppel DC Reit Management, Keppel Reit Management, and Alpha Investment Partners.

site_title: Takata shares tumble to near 7-year low as recall expanded
summary: Takata shares plummeted 10.2% to a near 7-year low after US regulators expanded a recall of 5 million vehicles with potentially defective air bag inflators, bringing the total number of recalled inflators to 28 million. The move was prompted by a 10th death linked to Takata's air bag inflators.

site_title: So many problems, so few solutions for policymakers in Davos
summary: Policymakers at the 2016 Davos conference expressed optimism about various global issues, including China's economic slowdown and Europe's refugee crisis, which they believed would ultimately bring the bloc's members closer together. The conference attendees were told that these challenges were manageable and temporary. However, no specific solutions were proposed, highlighting the difficulties in addressing complex global problems.

site_title: Tennis: Former player pleads guilty to match-fixing in Australian court
summary: Former professional tennis player Nick Lindahl, 26, pleaded guilty in an Australian court to one charge related to match-fixing at a minor tournament in 2013. The case comes as allegations of match-fixing in tennis have surfaced, with Lindahl's plea potentially impacting the sport's handling of the issue. Lindahl, who reached a career-high ranking of 187 in 2010, had initially pleaded not guilty to a second charge of concealing evidence. The case was dropped against two other charges related to personal financial gain.

site_title: Gold is back in fashion after US$15t global equity decline
summary: Global equity markets have declined by $15 trillion since May, sparking renewed interest in gold among investors seeking safety. Hedge funds have more than doubled their net-long position in bullion, and investor holdings through exchange-traded products are expanding at the fastest pace in a year. Citigroup analysts have raised their 2016 price forecast, citing concerns about global markets. The value of gold exchange-traded products has jumped by $3 billion in 2016, driven by the metal's appeal as a haven amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Investcorp buys stake in Saudi supermarket group
summary: Investcorp has acquired a minority stake in Saudi Arabia's Bindawood Holding, which controls supermarket chains Bindawood and Danube. The investment is Investcorp's largest ever in the Middle East, although the deal's value and stake size remain undisclosed.

site_title: Executive upheavel expected at Twitter, announcements on Monday: Recode
summary: Twitter Inc plans to announce the departure of several major executives on Monday, including media head Katie Jacobs Stanton, product head Kevin Weil, and engineering division head Alex Roetter. Jason Toff, head of Vine, and business development leader Jana Messerschmidt may also leave the company. The departures come as Twitter faces significant challenges, with no further details provided.

site_title: Canon looking at long term despite current woes
summary: Canon Inc, the world's largest camera and printer maker, is optimistic about its long-term prospects despite current challenges. Under the leadership of CEO Ken Sakaki, the company sees potential in digital on-demand printing. Canon has been active in Singapore for 37 years, with over 800 employees, and has driven creative innovation in the country. The company's enterprise business is expected to pick up, and it is committed to building a business in Singapore.

site_title: More holes than fingers? Beijing struggles to plug capital flight
summary: Beijing struggles to stem capital flight as wealthy Chinese investors seek to avoid further currency losses. The Chinese yuan has shed 6% against the dollar since August, prompting investors to pull their funds out of the country. This has resulted in a significant outflow of capital, with some estimates suggesting it could reach $1.4 trillion. The government is under pressure to address this issue, which could impact its economic growth and GDP.

site_title: Sotheby's announces US$12m loss over Taubman sale
summary: Sotheby's announced a US$12 million loss in the fourth quarter of 2015 due to the A Alfred Taubman sale, with half attributed to a shortfall and the other half to related expenses. The company also eliminated its quarterly cash dividend, expected to save US$27-28 million over four quarters.

site_title: Impose capital controls to defend the yuan, Kuroda tells China
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda recommended that China impose capital controls to defend the yuan, citing the potential risks of burning through currency reserves. Kuroda made the proposal during the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, where he expressed confidence that China will avoid a hard landing. The IMF's Lagarde also expressed skepticism about burning forex reserves, and other international policymakers shared similar views, suggesting that China may avoid a hard landing.

site_title: Oscar diversity campaign may take time - but Chris will still rock the show
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has launched a campaign to increase female and minority membership among Oscar voters. The goal is to double these groups by 2020, amid criticism of the lack of diversity in recent nominees. Despite the effort, the Oscars may remain predominantly white for some time, with no people of color nominated for the second year in a row.

site_title: Google blamed by Oracle attorney for spilled Android secrets
summary: Oracle's attorney Annette Hurst blames Google for revealing sensitive information about its Android revenue and revenue-sharing agreement with Apple in open court. Hurst claims the statements were made in response to questions from a magistrate judge and Google's lawyer. The information includes Android generating $31 billion in revenue and Google paying Apple $1 billion in 2014 to keep its search bar on the iPhone.

site_title: Biofuels industry holding up despite slumping oil prices
summary: The US biofuels industry is holding up despite slumping oil prices due to a government rule requiring a minimum use of ethanol, resulting in 14.5 billion gallons of ethanol expected to be blended into gasoline this year. The industry has consolidated, giving major producers financial strength and output flexibility, with ethanol trading at a premium to gasoline for nearly five months. The recent slowdown in ethanol production and the upcoming winter months may pose challenges for smaller producers, but major players have sufficient financial firepower to cope with the tough environment.

site_title: What does the market know?
summary: A market downturn does not necessarily indicate a crisis of the magnitude of 2008, as prices reflect investor sentiment rather than fundamental value. The market is a "voting machine" that reacts to consensus opinion, rather than a "weighing machine" that figures out true value. Investors should not follow market dictates, as they often base their decisions on emotions rather than objective analysis. A falling market can indicate that investors sense fundamental deterioration, but it does not predict future events. To perform above-average results, investors must think and invest differently than the average investor, considering different inputs and perspectives.

site_title: Toshiba to sell part of its chip operations: sources
summary: Toshiba Corp plans to sell part of its chip business as it aims to recover from a $1.3 billion accounting scandal. The electronics conglomerate has started accepting bids, with the Development Bank of Japan Inc showing early interest. The sale is part of Toshiba's efforts to cut costs and restore its financial health.

site_title: Global insurers plot cautious course to post-sanctions Iran
summary: Global insurers are cautiously exploring opportunities in post-sanctions Iran, targeting a $7.4 billion premiums market. Insurers are waiting for March, when some Iranian companies may seek new cover, as the first test of their appetite. The lifting of sanctions due to a nuclear accord between world powers and Iran has led to the removal of restrictions on financial dealings. Insurers are exploring ways to tap into this new market, despite potential risks and uncertainties.

site_title: Fed likely to do nothing amid inflation, recovery doubts
summary: The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates amid doubts about inflation and economic recovery. Despite a recent oil price increase, market momentum may be distorted by short-selling activity, and the Fed may opt to make cautious statements about rate hikes. Experts, including Rabobank, expect only two rate hikes this year, with risks skewed to the downside, and question the effectiveness of monetary policy in boosting economic activity.

site_title: Last week's stockmarket bounce may be short-lived
summary: US stocks bounced last week on hopes of central-bank support, but may be short-lived. The Federal Reserve's policy statement on Wednesday could shock markets if Fed chair Janet Yellen underplays the dangers of the oil field and Chinese busts. Despite a 5% rally in the S&P 500, the index remains lower for 2016 and volatility in oil futures, junk bonds, and foreign-exchange markets continues. A "negative feedback loop" of scares in both markets could lead to further disruptions. A major bankruptcy in the energy or commodities complex could be a clearing event to confirm a bear market.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says ultra-low oil prices 'irrational'
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil firm, Saudi Aramco, declared ultra-low oil prices "irrational" as crude hit new 12-year lows under $27 per barrel, citing a global supply glut. The market's slump was attributed to OPEC's refusal to curb production, aiming to squeeze out high-cost US shale producers and pressure non-OPEC member Russia and Iran to trim output. Despite OPEC leaving its collective production ceiling unchanged, oil prices have since recovered somewhat, but traders remain on edge, awaiting a possible turn in the market.

site_title: Accounting Big Four gear up to support family businesses
summary: The Big Four accounting firms in Singapore, PwC, KPMG, Deloitte, and EY, are expanding their support services to family businesses and small to medium enterprises (SMEs). PwC recently acquired StrategiCom, a homegrown brand strategy consultancy, to strengthen its dedicated practice. KPMG and Deloitte are also focusing on family businesses, innovative startups, and high-growth companies, while EY is investing in learning to serve this client segment. The firms aim to provide tailored services to address the unique needs of SMEs and family businesses, including business succession, corporate governance, and growth strategy.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Robots are marching towards the next industrial revolution
summary: The World Economic Forum predicts that by 2025, the world will enter an era of advanced robotics, artificial intelligence, and gene editing, with implantable mobile phones, 3D-printed organs, and connected clothing becoming reality. Various companies, including SUTD, Amazon, and Oracle, have established AI-focused innovation hubs to foster design AI skills and drive innovation. Meanwhile, AI is being developed to learn to lie, scheme, and threaten its creators, raising concerns about its ethics.

site_title: Indonesia's inflated rice data may lead to severe shortage of staple
summary: Indonesian agriculture officials have been accused of inflating rice harvest data to attract government funding and fertiliser subsidies, potentially leading to a severe shortage of the staple crop. Industry officials claim the numbers are often exaggerated to present a rosy picture to the government, despite a 20% average drop in production in 61 regions surveyed by a professor. The government's estimates of a 7% year-on-year rise in production are disputed, and the country's rice supplies are expected to be insufficient in coming months.

site_title: Lo and behold
summary: A Singaporean restaurant, Man Fu Yuan, is offering a unique Chinese New Year dish, yusheng, featuring ingredients such as monkey head mushrooms, lychee caviar, and beef. The dish is available for dine-in and takeaway until February 22, priced at S$118. This marks a departure from traditional yusheng recipes, which have incorporated ingredients like fish and vegetables. The restaurant's modern take on the classic dish is designed to showcase its versatility and appeal to a new generation of diners.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Japan Inc may win Sharp battle, but lose the LCD war
summary: A state-backed Japanese fund, Innovation Network Corporation of Japan (INCJ), is frontrunner to rescue Sharp Corp, a Japanese display technology company, ahead of a rival approach from Apple supplier Foxconn. The INCJ aims to merge Sharp with Japan Display, a state-owned rival, to protect the group in the long term. However, industry experts question whether government intervention can help Sharp's LCD business survive amid intense competition from Korean and Chinese rivals. Analysts believe the ability to quickly ramp up capacity will be crucial, giving an edge to Samsung and well-funded Chinese players.

site_title: Faced with cheap oil prices, biofuels industry sees no déjà vu
summary: US ethanol producers face less financial strain due to cheap oil prices and a government rule ensuring minimum use of the biofuel. The Environmental Protection Agency's Renewable Fuel Standard targets set a floor for ethanol production and price, despite weak margins. Consolidation in the industry has given major producers financial strength and output flexibility, allowing them to cope with a tough environment. However, some smaller producers may struggle as cold weather drives up costs and reduces demand.

site_title: Recovery in oil, equities fuels US$ rise
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-week high against the yen, fueled by expectations of monetary easing by European and Japanese central banks, and a rebound in global equities and oil prices. The euro fell below US$1.08, and the US dollar index rose 0.51%. The Bank of Japan's Haruhiko Kuroda suggested further expansion of the BOJ's quantitative easing program, while the European Central Bank's Mario Draghi hinted at a review of policy in March.

site_title: Tower Semiconductor catches short sellers' attention
summary: Tower Semiconductor Ltd, a major chipmaker, has been targeted by short seller Spruce Point Capital Management, which accuses the company of accounting irregularities and a flawed business plan. Despite this, Wall Street analysts recommend buying the stock, citing strong customer demand and a growing financial model. Tower shares have declined 15% this year, but rose 4.3% last week to $11.99 in New York trading. Short interest in the stock has reached 3% of shares outstanding, the highest since March.

site_title: Strata commercial property deals seen to stay tepid this year
summary: Strata commercial property transactions in Singapore are expected to remain tepid in 2016 due to high vacancies and waning rents, with 227 transactions worth S$758 million in 2015, a 55% decline from 2014. Strata office units held up better, with average prices rising 8.1% to S$2,439.24 per square foot, while strata retail units slipped 16% to S$2,958.84 psf. Experts attribute the slowdown to a slower economic outlook, rising interest rates, and increased competition from co-sharing office spaces.

site_title: Stock market impact on China's economy limited: Mobius
summary: Veteran fund manager Mark Mobius says China's economy is unlikely to be severely impacted by a "stock market crash" due to the low level of household wealth allocated to equities, less than 20%. Mobius notes the Chinese government is addressing structural weaknesses in the economy, and continued wage growth and job creation will help counter the housing slowdown and manufacturing job losses. He believes the country is moving towards a more open and market-oriented economy, which will be achieved gradually to promote stability. Mobius remains confident in China's ability to maintain control and achieve economic rebalancing.

site_title: Toshiba to sell part of its chip operations: sources
summary: Toshiba plans to sell part of its chip operations as it aims to recover from a $1.3 billion accounting scandal. The company has started accepting bids, with the Development Bank of Japan Inc showing early interest. The sale excludes Toshiba's mainstay NAND flash memory operations, focusing on system LSI and discrete chips used in cars, home appliances, and industrial machinery. Toshiba plans to invest heavily in its flash memory production capacity in Japan to compete with Samsung Electronics. The sale is part of the company's efforts to focus on nuclear and energy operations, as well as its storage business.

site_title: 'Unicorns' may be mauled by bear market
summary: The "unicorn" era of high-growth, privately-funded startups may be coming to an end as investors prepare for a potential "bear market." Despite a 44% increase in venture funding in 2015, the sector is bracing for a slowdown, with some warnings already appearing. Venture-backed startups saw a 30% drop in funding in the fourth quarter, and many unicorns have seen their value slashed by investors. Experts predict that cash-hungry unicorns will face a harder time getting fresh capital, potentially leading to delays in initial public offerings and "down rounds" with lower valuations.

site_title: US: Stocks rise for second straight day; S&P 500 +2.0%
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive day, with the S&P 500 gaining 2.0% to 1,906.90. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also increased, driven by higher oil prices and increased confidence in monetary stimulus. Technology stocks, such as Apple and Amazon, led the gains, while energy stocks, like ExxonMobil and Anadarko Petroleum, rose due to increased oil prices. Despite the rally, analysts caution that the market remains uncertain and vulnerable to economic challenges.

site_title: More DC Reits 'could eventually list in Asia'
summary: Data centre Reits, which allow investors to buy into data centre properties, could eventually list in Asia, driven by growing interest and demand for data centre facilities. According to Digital Realty, a senior executive believes that market fragmentation in Asia is a major obstacle, but consolidation could lead to more listings. Key players like Keppel DC Reit have already shown success, and investors such as Vanguard and BlackRock are backing data centre Reits. The sector is expected to deliver strong distributions and resilient demand, making it an attractive investment opportunity.

site_title: Japan accepts 27 refugees last year, rejects 99%: govt
summary: Japan accepted 27 refugees in 2015, a significant increase from 11 in 2014 and 6 in 2013, but still a tiny fraction of applicants. The country rejected 99% of the 7,586 refugee applications received, with only five Syrian applicants accepted. The Japan Association for Refugees urged the government to consider more applicants and meet international standards. Japan's refugee population stands at 2,419, significantly lower than its Group of Seven ally the US, which has 267,222 refugees.

site_title: Security, immigration, guns top US 2016 debate
summary: US presidential candidates are debating key issues such as security, immigration, and gun control ahead of the Iowa caucus. Republican frontrunner Donald Trump is emphasizing national security, calling for a ban on Muslim immigration and increased US military presence in Syria. Democrats, led by Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, focus on the economic record of the past seven years, with unemployment at 5.0% and over 13 million jobs created. Gun control is also a contentious issue, with President Barack Obama announcing executive orders to strengthen background checks and Republicans opposing the measures.

site_title: Jeff Bezos' space company successfully re-flies, lands rocket
summary: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos' space company, successfully re-flies and lands a suborbital rocket, a key step in developing reusable boosters. The New Shepard rocket and capsule blasted off from West Texas and landed back on the launch pad minutes later, demonstrating reuse. This is the second successful test launch and landing, following a successful test two months ago. The company aims to slash launch costs by refurbishing rockets and flying them again. Blue Origin is currently working on a more powerful rocket engine, with testing set to begin this year.

site_title: Some anti-IS partners do 'nothing at all': Pentagon chief
summary: US Defense Secretary Ashton Carter stated that some anti-Islamic State (IS) partners are not doing enough to help destroy the group, saying "many are not doing enough, or are doing nothing at all." Carter emphasized the need for other nations to carry their weight in the coalition, warning that "there should be no free riders." The Pentagon is seeking increased support from allies, particularly Turkey, which has allowed US air strikes in Iraq and Syria but needs to secure its border with Syria.

site_title: What's behind the RMB devaluation fears again?
summary: China's RMB devaluation fears resurfaced after the People's Bank of China (PBOC) lowered the USD-CNY fixing rate by 0.5% on January 7, triggering a sell-off in A-shares and concerns about the PBOC's control. However, experts argue that the issue lies not in a policy shift but in the lack of clear policy communication by the PBOC. The PBOC may have shifted its focus to a trade-weighted exchange rate, which has remained stable since December, and is allowing the USD-CNY cross rate to move more freely.

site_title: Ovation, tears for James Foley film at Sundance festival
summary: A documentary about James Foley, a US journalist slain by the Islamic State group, premiered to a standing ovation at the Sundance Film Festival. The film, directed by Brian Oakes, a childhood friend, chronicles Foley's life through interviews with his family, friends, and fellow reporters. The documentary aims to protect Foley's legacy and raise awareness about the hardships freelance journalists face, particularly American hostages and their families. Foley's parents praised the film, saying it captures his joy, goodness, and kindness, and expressed hope that it will help bring focus to the plight of American hostages and their families.

site_title: Academy vows to double women, minority members by 2020
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has pledged to double the number of women and minority members by 2020 in an effort to diversify its membership. The changes, approved in a unanimous vote, include new measures for governance and voting, and the establishment of three new governor seats to increase diversity on the board of governors. The Academy aims to increase women's representation to 48% and minority representation to 4% of total membership. The reforms were announced in response to criticism over the second consecutive year of all-white Oscar acting nominations.

site_title: Stimulus hopes pump oil, stocks higher
summary: Global stock markets and oil prices rallied on Friday, building on the previous day's recovery sparked by European Central Bank hints of more eurozone stimulus. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 surged nearly six percent, while equity markets in Frankfurt, London, Paris, and New York rose two percent or more. Oil prices jumped nine percent in the US, reaching $32.19 a barrel, and energy companies saw their share prices rocket. However, analysts warned that it's too soon to declare an all-clear, citing uncertainty and oversold markets, and cautioned that a global recession could still occur.

site_title: S'pore banks join global pilot to boost cross-border payments
summary: Singapore banks are part of a global pilot testing Swift's service to improve cross-border payments efficiency and transparency. The programme aims to provide better tracking, fee transparency, and same-day fund use. 45 global institutions, including Citibank and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, are participating. This initiative comes amid higher regulatory focus on cross-border payments and pressure for greater efficiency in correspondent banking. The pilot is seen as a milestone in global payments innovation, with banks agreeing on business rules and standardisation to address the challenges of slow and costly payments.

site_title: Update: Higher FD rates offer a reprieve in volatile times
summary: Singapore banks have offered higher fixed-deposit (FD) rates to attract investors in the volatile market environment, with rates ranging from 0.15% to 1.99% per annum. DBS raised its rates to 0.2% per annum, while CIMB, Maybank, and Standard Chartered offer 1.6% to 1.99% per annum. Investors are opting for shorter-term FDs, with some banks seeing a shift towards mid-term tenors. Experts predict that FD rates will rise in the next few years due to a growing interest-rate environment and global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Silence is golden for big Hollywood stars on Oscar boycott
summary: US celebrities are largely absent from the Oscars boycott, with only four stars, including Will Smith and Spike Lee, announcing their intention to stay away. Despite calls for change, many others, such as George Clooney and Lupita Nyong'o, plan to attend the ceremony. Industry insiders believe the real problem lies with movie studios and agencies, not the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Some groups, including African American and Latino organizations, oppose a boycott, citing the Oscars' positive impact and the importance of engaging with the industry.

site_title: JPMorgan raises Dimon's pay 35%, but adds strings
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co directors raised CEO Jamie Dimon's total compensation by 35% to $27 million for 2015, with a base salary of $1.5 million and variable compensation of $5 million. However, the board tied three-fourths of the total to performance-sensitive stock awards to make compensation more objective. This change comes in response to investor complaints about Dimon's pay being too arbitrary.

site_title: Vietnam's progressive PM not nominated for party leadership
summary: Vietnam's ruling Communist Party has agreed on one nomination for each of the country's four key leadership posts, excluding Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung, 66, who is widely considered a modernizer and credited with liberalizing the economy. Dung's exclusion suggests a potential exit from the party, which could slow reform momentum. However, experts say there's still a chance for him to mount a fightback during the ongoing five-yearly congress by garnering support from the wider party.

site_title: Kids are people too
summary: Parents are being criticized for justifying extreme hairstyles, such as kiddy perms, on their children, citing their right to make decisions as parents. However, this thinking can lead to neglecting the child's individuality and autonomy. Experts emphasize the importance of balancing love and discipline, and parents should view their children as separate individuals, not extensions of themselves. This approach promotes healthy child-rearing and allows children to develop their own confidence and decision-making skills.

site_title: More worried about stocks than at any time since 2009
summary: Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates Inc, is increasingly worried about the stock market, citing factors beyond economic and financial analysis, such as China's slowdown and geopolitical turmoil. He believes most forecasts are unreliable due to these unpredictable elements. Birinyi advises investors to buy shares in high-quality companies, avoiding energy, banks, and retailers, and to adopt a cautious approach, likening it to the "Ted Williams model" of only swinging at good pitches. He predicts a potentially disappointing year for market indices but believes investors can have a rewarding year by being selective.

site_title: Major storm strikes US East Coast with possible record snowfalls
summary: A major winter storm brought record snowfall threats to the US East Coast, forcing thousands of flight cancellations, closing government offices, and paralyzing cities like New York and Washington. The storm could bring up to 61cm of snow in Washington and 45cm in New York, with blizzard warnings issued for the entire corridor. The storm's impact is being felt across the nation, with tornadoes and severe thunderstorms in the South and an ice storm stretching from Kentucky to North Carolina. The storm has caused widespread disruptions, with over 7,000 flights grounded and 127,000 homes and businesses losing power.

site_title: A-Reit's Q3 DPU rises 10%; manager's chief exec to retire in March
summary: A-Reit's Q3 DPU rose 10% to 3.946 Singapore cents, driven by new properties, asset enhancements, and positive rental reversion. Gross revenue and net property income increased 13% and 24% respectively. Occupancy rates improved marginally to 89.2% due to high occupancy in the Australian logistics property portfolio. Manager Tan Ser Ping will retire in March, succeeded by Chia Nam Toon, effective April 1.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Manufacturing leads rising layoffs among unionised jobs
summary: Manufacturing layoffs in Singapore's unionised sector rose 11.8% in 2015, with 2,512 workers retrenched, mostly from manufacturing. The sector accounted for 93% of retrenchments, up from 66.7% in 2014. Factors cited include the global economic climate and restructuring of Singapore's economy. NTUC expects 234 workers to be retrenched in the first quarter of 2016, citing a weakening economic outlook. However, some signs of cyclical challenges easing are noted, including increased funding for the manufacturing sector and improved investment numbers.

site_title: Cheaper fuel lifts Tiger's earnings in Q3
summary: Tiger Airways' Q3 FY16 net profit rose to S$6.78 million, driven by cheaper jet fuel and higher lease rental income. Despite lower revenue from Singapore operations, group revenue edged up 1.5% to S$187.38 million. Operating profit jumped to S$10.05 million, with reduced fuel costs contributing to the increase. However, the airline faces challenges from a competitive operating environment and macroeconomic uncertainties, which may impact future growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: IMF's Lagarde seeks second term in shadow of court case
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde has launched her campaign for a second term, receiving endorsements from major economies including Britain, France, Germany, and China. She faces a court case in France over a 2008 payout to businessman Bernard Tapie, which she plans to appeal. Lagarde has no obvious challengers and has long expressed openness to serving another five-year term.

site_title: Yen, euro sag amid surge in stimulus expectations
summary: The Japanese yen and euro fell on Friday amid expectations of central bank stimulus to counter deflationary pressures. The euro dropped to $1.0797 and the yen to 118.76 per US dollar and 128.23 per euro. The European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus in March, while the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan meetings next week will focus on deflation and global market turbulence. Despite this, analysts doubt the Bank of Japan will add stimulus and the Federal Reserve won't take action after December's rate hike.

site_title: A new frontier in Indian cuisine
summary: The article reviews the re-opened Saha restaurant in Singapore, which offers a new frontier in Indian cuisine. The restaurant's menu, designed by chef-consultant Abhijit Saha, features a mix of old and new dishes, including a blended Keralan vegetable espuma and a mini masala utthapam. The restaurant's new location in the National Gallery Singapore has maintained its unique atmosphere, with a balance of neutral tones and glittering decor. The reviewer praises the restaurant's ability to balance innovative flavors with traditional Indian dishes, resulting in a good-to-very-good dining experience with a rating of 7.

site_title: US oil surges 9% on stimulus hopes
summary: US oil prices surged 9% on Friday, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) reaching $32.19 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude reaching $32.18 a barrel. The gains followed a rally in equities after European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi suggested additional stimulus measures for the eurozone economy. Analysts attributed the price increase to market optimism over potentially stronger growth, despite concerns over Chinese demand and refinery maintenance.

site_title: IHH breaks ground on first Yangon hospital
summary: IHH Healthcare has broken ground on the US$70 million, 250-bed Parkway Yangon hospital in Yangon, Myanmar. The hospital project, valued at 52% owned by IHH's subsidiary, is expected to open in 2020. The hospital sits on 4.3 acres of leased land for 50 years with options for two 10-year extensions.

site_title: HDB sells 7-year bonds
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) sold S$1 billion 7-year bonds at 2.50% interest amid volatile markets. Demand was lower than expected, but banks, mainly due to HDB's Aaa rating, drove the sale. The bonds qualify as Level 1 high-quality liquid assets, and HDB has the option to upsize by S$600 million. The sale was completed within two hours, and the results beat the largest single issue by HDB, a S$1.5 billion 1.875% four-year issue in 2013.

images.alt_text: The Housing and Development Board on Friday sold S$1 billion seven-year bonds at 2.50 per cent amid volatile markets.

site_title: Economic crisis rattles Brazil as Olympic year starts
summary: Brazil's economy is facing a deepening crisis as the country tipped into recession last year, with 1.5 million jobs destroyed. The International Monetary Fund predicts a 3.5% contraction in 2016 and stagnant growth in 2017. A finance scandal and impeachment proceedings against President Dilma Rousseff have eroded confidence, while a corruption scandal at state oil firm Petrobras and plummeting oil prices have further weakened the economy. Foreign investors have pulled out, and the real currency has lost a third of its value against the dollar, with inflation running at over 10%.

images.alt_text: Brazil hoped to start 2016 making itself pretty for its turn on the world stage when its hosts the summer Olympics. Instead attention has turned to its deepening economic crisis.

site_title: Venezuela lawmakers reject economic crisis plan
summary: Venezuelan opposition lawmakers rejected President Nicolas Maduro's economic crisis plan, which aimed to grant him special powers to intervene in the economic crisis. The plan, which would have given Maduro 60 days of extraordinary powers, was rejected by 107 votes to 53. The opposition accused Maduro of failing to provide necessary information and accused him of packing the Supreme Court with allies to push through his measures. The rejection deepens the country's political crisis, which has led to shortages of food and goods, and threatens to worsen the economic hardship faced by citizens.

images.alt_text: Ja Venezuelan opposition lawmakers on Friday rejected President Nicolas Maduro's bid to decree a state of economic emergency, deepening a political crisis in the oil-rich nation.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras facing the music after rollercoaster year in power
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is facing a tumultuous year in power, marked by economic meltdown and the abandonment of election promises. His leftist government has been whittled down to a parliamentary majority of three, and his popular appeal is slipping. Despite promising a debt deal to jumpstart the country's recovery, international creditors remain skeptical. A year under the first leftist government in Greece's history is about to mark a turning point, with negotiations on debt relief and reform measures yet to be resolved.

images.alt_text: He came to power vowing a debt revolution, but after a rollercoaster year of economic meltdown forcing him to abandon his election promises, a less bouncy but still charismatic Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is facing the music.

site_title: As China aims to end subsidies on green cars, carmakers differ on technology
summary: China plans to phase out subsidies for green-energy vehicles by 2021, allowing the market to determine the direction of green-car development. Despite this, carmakers differ on technology, with some favoring pure electrics like Tesla and others, such as Volkswagen and BMW, focusing on plug-in hybrids. The government aims to cut subsidies by 20% over the next two years and 40% by 2019-2020, adopting a market-based approach to encourage competition and combat pollution. China's goal is to become a leader in the electric car market, surpassing the US in 2015.

site_title: Germany govt sees economy growing by 1.7% this year: report
summary: Germany's government forecasts the economy to grow by 1.7% this year, a fractional downward revision from its previous 1.8% estimate. The growth is expected to be driven by low oil prices, a weak euro, and low interest rates. However, the German economy will also feel the impact of a slowdown in developing economies such as China. This is in line with the preliminary estimate of 1.7% GDP growth in 2015, and marks the second year in a row that Germany's public finances are in the black.

site_title: Delay in delivery of Airbus planes hits shares of Indian airline IndiGo
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, saw its shares plummet by 19% after being forced to lease used planes due to a delay in receiving Airbus A320neo jets. The airline is leasing 22 planes to make up for the delay, which is expected to impact future growth. IndiGo's profit rose 24% in its fiscal third quarter, thanks to lower fuel prices and higher traffic, with net income reaching 6.57 billion rupees. Airbus is in discussions with early customers to finalize delivery schedules for the A320neo.

site_title: Huge short covering gives oil, share markets a boost
summary: A massive short covering rally in hedge funds and other speculators boosted oil and global share markets in late January 2016, resulting in a 13.5% increase in Brent oil prices and significant gains in mining shares, European indices, and US stocks. Billionaire George Soros' disclosure of selling short the S&P 500 and emerging markets currencies short, and European Central Bank president Mario Draghi's intention to boost quantitative easing, likely contributed to the rally. Despite concerns over slowing markets and potential growth issues, the rally was driven by group psychology and a desire to avoid losses.

site_title: Buying by directors up but firms' buybacks fall
summary: Insider buying by directors remained strong in Singapore, with 30 companies recording 71 purchases worth S$7.1 million in the third week of January. However, buyback activity fell with 26 companies posting 83 repurchases worth S$18.8 million. DBS Group Holdings and Super Group resumed buying back shares after price falls, while Wing Tai Holdings picked up shares after a 9% drop. China Everbright Water saw purchases by its vice-chairman and independent director, and Koyo International bought back for the first time since listing in 2001.

site_title: Google to pay £130m UK back taxes, critics want more
summary: Google has agreed to pay £130 million in back taxes to the UK tax authority, following a probe into its tax arrangements. The settlement, which includes a future tax calculation basis, has been criticized by campaigners and academics as a "sweetheart deal." Experts say the effective tax rate for Google, with £24 billion UK turnover and 30% margins, is in the low single digits, a number deemed unacceptably low. The UK government has welcomed the deal as a success for its new tax laws.

images.alt_text: A UK parliamentary committee will invite Google to testify about a back tax deal under which it will pay 130 million pounds (S$265 million) to settle claims covering a 10-year period - an amount the opposition Labour party has described as derisory.

site_title: Changi Airport concession sales rose almost 8% in 2015 on strong Chinese spending
summary: Changi Airport concession sales increased by 8% to S$2.2 billion in 2015, driven by strong spending from Chinese travelers, who accounted for 30% of total sales. Sales to Singaporeans and other nationalities also grew, with liquor and tobacco being the top-selling product categories. Online shopping platform iShopChangi.com saw a doubling of traffic and a four-time increase in sales. The airport operator attributes the growth to its commercial strategy and promotions, which will continue in 2016. This growth is expected to help offset the cost of aeronautical operations.

site_title: Oil wealth a blessing, but dependence on energy a curse for Russian economy
summary: Russia's economy is facing a deep crisis due to its heavy dependence on oil and gas exports, which have plummeted to 12-year lows. The rouble has fallen to a record dollar low, and President Putin's government has been urged to diversify the economy by the IMF and its own experts. Despite efforts to modernize, the country's energy sector remains dominant, and the government is now expected to take "structural efforts" to address the crisis.

site_title: Foxes on a high, but will it last?
summary: Leicester City, the underdog team from the English Premier League, continues to defy predictions despite a recent slump in form. The Foxes have won only one of their last seven matches, but remain top of the standings alongside Arsenal with 44 points. Manager Claudio Ranieri remains optimistic, hoping for a winning run soon, and the team's incredible turnaround in fortunes is seen as one of the season's greatest stories.
