Leicester's chances of winning the league title are considered long-shot, but a top-four finish and Champions League qualification are within reach.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

STILL A LONG SHOT: High-flying Leicester City (in blue) lost 0-2 to Tottenham in the FA Cup third round on Wednesday, which means they've won just once in seven games in all competitions. But manager Claudio Ranieri is hopeful of going on another winning run soon.

STILL A LONG SHOT High-flying Leicester City (in blue) lost 0-2 to Tottenham in the FA Cup third round on Wednesday, which means they've won just once in seven games in all competitions. But manager Claudio Ranieri (above) is hopeful of going on another winning run soon.

site_title: AmEx shares sink on weak outlook, spending cuts
summary: American Express shares plummeted 12.6% to $54.78 after the company offered a dim profit outlook, citing economic sluggishness and intense competition in the payments industry. The company plans $1 billion in spending cuts, which failed to impress investors seeking details on how to better exploit its affluent client base. Analysts say AmEx needs to back up its talk of using big data with a specific game plan to persuade vendors of the benefits of higher fees. The company's 2017 forecast fell short of expectations, and investors are concerned about the company's ability to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Lower oil prices failing to bring usual benefits to US economy
summary: US oil prices have fallen to historic lows, but the expected economic benefits are not materializing as anticipated. JPMorgan Chase estimates that lower prices may have shaved 0.3 percentage points off the growth rate in 2015, while Goldman Sachs predicts no effect. The decline in oil prices is also weighing on inflation, jeopardizing the Federal Reserve's plans to raise interest rates this year. Economists attribute this to the rapid response of the domestic oil and gas industry to falling prices, and a potential shift in consumer behavior, with some arguing that consumers are saving due to debt concerns.

images.alt_text: Russia's economy contracted the most since 2009 last year as the price of oil, a key export, sank and sanctions over the conflict in Ukraine curbed access to international financing.

site_title: CNY cookies with a twist
summary: Independent bakeries offer unique Chinese New Year treats, such as chix (chicken) skin pineapple tarts, green curry tempeh cookies, and hae bee hiam cookies. Various bakeries, including Out of the Cake Box, Carpenter and Cook, Sinpopo, MilkBar, Pantler, and others, showcase creative flavor combinations and traditional recipes. Some popular items include cereal prawn cookies, salted egg yolk cookies, and pineapple coconut tarts. The offerings cater to both traditional and adventurous palates, with some bakeries offering custom orders and unique ingredients.

images.alt_text: DARING: Out Of The Cake Box's chix (chicken) skin pineapple tarts taste a lot less questionable than the name suggests, while their green curry tempeh cookies (purple label) deliver a potent kick of spices and basil.
MUST-TRY: Carpenter and Cook offers a harmonious mix of old and new with their treats - hae bee hiam and ikan bilis cookies and chocolate sea salt sables.
GOODIES IN A BOX: Sinpopo's hamper, at S$88, includes two bottles of salted egg yolk cookies, and also items off their regular menu like the signature gula melaka cake and sugee biscuits.
MUST-TRY: The unsalted seaweed in MilkBar's seaweed meringue cuts through the sugary light vanilla base, so it's not too cloying.
DARING: Pantler's pineapple coconut tart is done in the fruit tart-style with pate sucree and almond cream, a dense crumbly pastry, and topped with a whole pineapple slice.
MUST-TRY: Bloomsbury Bakers' bak kwa sesame and pork floss seaweed cookies.
GOODIES IN A BOX: Flourish's salted egg yolk cookies have a very sharp and salty finish, whereas the lucky green pea cookies sport a golden roasted flavour.
ADDICTIVE: inthebrickyard's milk pineapple tarts and sesame red bean tarts.
ADDICTIVE: Peony Jade's salted egg yolk-flavoured crispy salmon fish skin and salted egg yolk cookies.
4 YOU: Pies & Coffee is offering four different kinds of cookies this year, including green pea cashew cookies, salted egg yolk cookies, and parmesan cheese cookies.

site_title: Poll king Trump faces Iowa reality check
summary: Donald Trump, the poll-leading Republican presidential candidate, faces his first test on February 1 when Iowa Republicans vote to elect a new US president. Trump has maintained a 16-point lead over his nearest rival, Senator Ted Cruz, despite controversy and criticism. If he wins, it could be a significant blow to the Republican establishment, but Iowa's results often don't align with the national outcome, leaving uncertainty about his chances in November's election.

images.alt_text: Poll-leading showman Donald Trump faces the first test of his meteoric political career on February 1, when voting to elect a new US president begins.

site_title: Forget the glut, as oil prices enter irrational territory
summary: Oil prices have plummeted nearly 30% to below $30 a barrel, breaching the line between a rational response to fundamentals and irrational fear. Commodity funds using algorithms drive the sell-off, fueled by a deep supply glut and economic weakness in China. Analysts and executives are calling out the market's "irrationality," with some predicting prices could rebound to higher ground. However, overreaction is common in oil markets, and a quick recovery is unlikely. Distressed oil producers may hold out longer, and Saudi Arabia shows no signs of abandoning its shock therapy.

images.alt_text: BIG ROUT: Overreaction in oil markets tends to be the norm rather than the exception, and the view that oil is now far oversold does not mean that a recovery is imminent.

site_title: Analysts split over Keppel's S$230m default risk provision
summary: Keppel Corporation has sparked debate among analysts over its S$230 million provision for the Sete Brasil contract, which is at risk due to the client's financial struggles. Analysts disagree on the adequacy of the provision, with some estimating an additional S$442 million in asset impairment costs if the contract is cancelled. Others believe Petrobras will still need the rigs, which are customized for pre-salt fields. The provision has raised concerns about Keppel's default risks, particularly on its outstanding order book of jack-up rigs worth over US$5 billion.

site_title: S'pore supports second term for Lagarde at IMF's helm
summary: Singapore has expressed support for Christine Lagarde to serve a second term as International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director. The country joins a growing list of supporters, including officials from China, France, Germany, Mexico, the UK, and the US, in backing Lagarde's reappointment. Lagarde, who led the IMF through challenging international times, has been praised for her exceptional capability and inclusive leadership style. The IMF's nomination period for a new five-year term began on January 21, with Lagarde's reappointment seen as a strong possibility.

site_title: US issues recall for 5 million more Takata airbags
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has issued a recall for an additional 5 million Takata airbags in cars, bringing the total to 33 million worldwide. The driver-side airbags, which can cause shrapnel to erupt and injure occupants, are being recalled for the first time in cars from Volkswagen and Audi. The recall comes after nine US deaths and one international death linked to the airbag problem. The Japanese company Takata has been fined $200 million for providing inadequate information and failing to recall airbags quickly.

images.alt_text: Safety officials announced on Friday the recall of another five million Takata airbags in cars in the United States just a month after a ninth airbag-linked US death was revealed.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Analysts from KGI Fraser and CIMB have issued mixed views on Singapore's key sectors. KGI Fraser downgrades Keppel Corp to "sell" due to potential provision for Sete Brasil semisubs and a cyclical downturn in the offshore rig industry, which may impact its ROEs below 10%. In contrast, CIMB upgrades the Singapore property sector to "overweight" as developers trade at a 45% discount to RNAV, with opportunities for asset monetisation. Credit Suisse maintains its "underweight" rating on Singapore telcos, citing the impact of OTT services on pay TV operators.

site_title: Anonymous messaging app stirs controversy in Israel
summary: A new Israeli app, Blindspot, has sparked controversy due to its anonymous messaging feature, which allows users to send messages, photos, and videos without being traced. The app has gained popularity, but politicians and campaigners have called for it to be banned, citing concerns over online bullying and potential harm to young users. The app's CEO claims it has sufficient checks and balances, but critics argue that anonymity can lead to harassment and threats, and have pointed to similar apps that were shut down due to similar issues.

site_title: Davos elites fear weakened EU
summary: Business leaders and politicians at the World Economic Forum in Davos are concerned about the weakening of the European Union due to border closures and the risk of a British exit. The EU faces multiple crises, including migration, security, and anti-European populism, which could lead to a "turning point" in EU integration. A WEF report warns that a British vote to leave the EU could lead to a "possibly irreversible setback" for European integration, while European leaders, including French and German officials, urge caution and warn of a "tragedy" and "disaster" if the UK leaves the bloc.

images.alt_text: GAME-CHANGER: 'A Brexit would be a turning point in EU integration, which has, so far, been seen as largely irreversible,' says former Swedish prime minister Carl Bildt.

site_title: French economy minister doubts China growth data
summary: French economy minister Emmanuel Macron expressed doubt on China's official economic growth figures, stating they likely overstate the pace of expansion. Macron warned that the slowdown in Chinese growth, combined with global economic volatility and other factors, will not help Europe. He emphasized the need for radical economic reforms in France, citing joblessness and internal EU tensions as major concerns. France's economy has been struggling, with growth of over 1.0% last year and a jobless rate of 10%.

images.alt_text: France's economy minister, Emmanuel Macron, said on Friday he believes China's official figures overstate the true pace of its economic expansion, warning that the tough international climate will not help Europe.

site_title: Boeing to cut 747-8 production in half as demand slows
summary: Boeing plans to cut production of its 747-8 jumbo jet in half due to dwindling sales, citing a stalled air cargo market recovery. The company will take a US$569 million charge in the fourth quarter and reduce output to half a plane a month in September. This move comes after Boeing disclosed costs outstripped sales, with an estimated imbalance of US$1 billion. The decision is a result of the 747-8 being eclipsed by more fuel-efficient twin-engine jets for passengers and being used mainly for cargo.

site_title: HDB resale prices up for first time in 10 quarters
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 0.1% in Q4 2015, marking the first quarterly increase in 10 quarters. Despite a full-year decline of 1.6%, prices are expected to remain stable in 2016, with a flat price movement of about -1 to +2%. The increase in resale transactions, driven by lower asking prices, is expected to exceed 20,000 units. Experts attribute the increase to the Proximity Housing Grant, which made resale flats more affordable.

images.alt_text: SPECIALISTS' TAKES: PropNex Realty CEO does not believe HDB's enlarged supply of 18,000 BTO flats this year will affect resale demand, going by what happened in Q4 when HDB launched a bumper crop of new flats. ERA Realty Network key executive officer warns that with higher interest rates to come and a further slowdown of Singapore's economy expected, it may be too early to say that the market has turned.

site_title: Touch of class for Macau
summary: The St Regis Macao, a luxury hotel, has opened in Macau, China, marking a shift towards entertainment and tourism beyond gaming. The 400-room property offers bespoke hospitality, including a signature butler service, and connects to the Sheraton Macao for business travelers. The hotel's unique features include a lobby bar serving a local version of the Bloody Mary and an Iridium Spa with panoramic views. Macau, once a gaming capital, is reinventing itself as a major entertainment destination, with the St Regis Macao aiming to attract leisure tourists and business travelers.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

GLITZ AND GLAM: The 400-room St Regis Macao is the newest kid on the block and the casino-less hotel is clearly in sync with Macau's reinvention from gaming capital of the world to a major entertainment destination ala Las Vegas.

GLITZ AND GLAM: The 400-room St Regis Macao is the newest kid on the block and the casino-less hotel is clearly in sync with Macau's reinvention from gaming capital of the world to a major entertainment destination ala Las Vegas.

GLITZ AND GLAM: The 400-room St Regis Macao is the newest kid on the block and the casino-less hotel is clearly in sync with Macau's reinvention from gaming capital of the world to a major entertainment destination ala Las Vegas.

TIME TO CHILL: The lobby bar serves another St Regis signature, a unique localised version of the Bloody Mary. The potent local concoction fuses classic ingredients with spices that Portuguese sailors originally brought to Macau, such as pink peppercorns, piri-piri and cinnamon.

site_title: 'Legal convergence needed in Asean for region to soar'
summary: Singapore Minister for Law K Shanmugam emphasized the need for legal convergence in Asean to boost the region's economic growth. The minister cited surveys that found diversity in legal and regulatory regimes hindered investment and business growth. He highlighted the potential of Asean, which could become the world's fourth-largest economy by 2050. The Asean Economic Community aims to achieve legal convergence on e-commerce and regulatory standards, but Shanmugam stressed that serious action is needed to improve the region's legal infrastructure. This convergence is crucial for unlocking the region's full economic potential.

images.alt_text: Common norms and practices developed by the Asian Business Law Institute can ease cross-border trade in Asia and facilitate dialogue between countries, which can lower costs and increase business flows, Minister for Law K Shanmugam has said.

site_title: Noble sees its future as a smaller, nimble company: Elman
summary: NOBLE Group, Asia's largest commodities trader, plans to transform into a smaller, asset-light company to ride out market downturns and recover from accounting-related allegations. Founder and chairman Richard Elman aims for a more cautious approach, citing the need to "go back to being modest and economical." Despite past allegations of inflating assets, Elman believes the company has complied with international rules and is "behind us." Noble's plans to bring in new investors are taking time, with Elman stating that new money will be selective due to the current market conditions.

site_title: Android has generated US$22b in profit: Oracle
summary: Google's Android operating system generated US$31 billion in revenue and US$22 billion in profit, according to an Oracle attorney, but Google objects to public disclosure of the figures, calling them "extremely sensitive." Android makes money through adverts and Google Play revenue, and the non-public financial data is highly sensitive, with potential negative effects on Google's business. The five-year-old lawsuit between Google and Oracle seeks damages potentially exceeding US$1 billion.

site_title: Francis Seow dies in Boston aged 88
summary: Francis Seow, a former Singapore solicitor-general and opposition politician, has died in Boston at the age of 88. He had fled Singapore in 1988 after being accused of tax evasion and detained without trial. Seow had lived in the US since 1988 and became a US citizen. He was a vocal critic of the Singapore government and wrote several books critical of the government and judiciary. His nephew stated that Seow died of pneumonia, while Singapore Democratic Party chief Chee Soon Juan said Seow's cause of death was not mentioned.

site_title: Phey Yew Kok sentenced to 60 months in jail
summary: Former NTUC chairman Phey Yew Kok, 81, was sentenced to 60 months in jail for 12 charges, including criminal breach of trust and abetting the fabrication of false evidence. Phey, who was on the run for 30 years, pleaded guilty and apologized for his actions, which he said had let down the union movement. He will serve the sentence backdated to June 23, 2015.

site_title: It's time Asia rebranded itself
summary: Asia's airports are dominated by international brands, stifling local culture and ingenuity. In contrast to the region's rich cultural heritage, airports in cities like New Delhi, Bangkok, and Singapore feature an overwhelming presence of luxury brands such as Chanel, Dior, and Louis Vuitton. This trend is driven by the pursuit of higher rents, rather than a genuine desire to showcase local art, textiles, and handicrafts. As a result, airports have become dull, commercialized spaces that fail to reflect the vibrant cultures they claim to represent. It is time for local brands to fight back and for governments to intervene to promote a more authentic and culturally rich airport experience.

site_title: No plans to devalue yuan: China's VP
summary: China's Vice-President Li Yuanchao has stated that the country has no intention to devalue its currency, the yuan, amidst market fluctuations. He attributed the yuan's volatility to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, rather than China's policies. This comes after a volatile start to the year, with the yuan dropping 1.5% in January, sparking concerns about China's policy intentions. Li's comments aim to reassure investors and maintain the country's reform program, which has seen China move away from investment reliance and slow its growth.

site_title: China's Wanda Group boss plans US$10b park project in India
summary: China's Wanda Group, led by billionaire Wang Jianlin, has agreed to invest $10 billion in a massive industrial park project in northern India's Haryana state. The project, dubbed "Wanda Industrial New City," will span 13 square kilometers and feature companies in various industries. This could be one of the largest foreign investments in India, supporting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to attract foreign capital. Wanda will be responsible for initial infrastructure investment and will attract international companies to participate in the development.

site_title: US existing home sales surge a record 14.7%
summary: US existing home sales surged a record 14.7% in December to 5.46 million units, rebounding from a 19-month low. The increase was driven by unseasonably warm weather and a snap-back in sales after a 19-month low in November. Despite a sharp moderation in economic growth, the housing market recovery remains intact. The sales pace in 2015 was the strongest since 2006, with economists attributing the boost to a strengthening labor market and a dearth of homes available for sale.

site_title: Trying to hold firm amid sinking global markets
summary: Global financial markets are experiencing volatility, with the S&P 500 down 9% in 2016, and oil prices plummeting to below $27 a barrel. Economists attribute this to a mix of factors, including the slowdown in China's economy, the drop in the Chinese stock market, and potential losses in the financial sector due to bad loans for oil exploration. Researchers at the Bank for International Settlements suggest that these loans could trigger a broader financial crisis, similar to the 2007 subprime mortgage crisis.

site_title: 2016 office vacancy rate seen hitting double digits
summary: Singapore's office vacancy rate is expected to hit double digits in 2016 due to a supply overhang of over 4 million sq ft. Despite a 1.8% decline in Q4 rents, vacancy rates held steady at 9.6% in Q4. Analysts attribute the weak leasing demand to business sentiment and macroeconomic conditions, with prime rents projected to slide 10-12% in 2016. Office prices remained resilient, with a quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year dip of just 0.1% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: SoftBank worth less than its Alibaba stake after 4-day stock slide
summary: SoftBank's market capitalization fell to $66 billion after a four-day stock slide due to concerns about its struggling US wireless carrier Sprint Corp. The company's stake in Alibaba is worth $55 billion, and investors are questioning SoftBank's ability to pay down debt. SoftBank's billionaire CEO Masayoshi Son has struggled to turn Sprint around since buying a controlling stake in 2013, with the company now worth only $8.1 billion. The company may book a charge of up to $1.2 billion related to the Sprint deal in its earnings report next month.

site_title: Markets latch on to 10% bounce in oil prices
summary: Oil prices rebounded 10% in a single day, with Brent prices jumping 6.4% to $29.80, after European Central Bank President Mario Draghi hinted at possible monetary easing in March. Asian markets rallied, with Japanese stocks surging 5-6% and the yen weakening against the US dollar. Analysts suggest the rebound may be temporary, as HSBC notes the Japanese economy is on track for a gradual recovery and easing may not effectively solve the problem of lower global demand.

site_title: CMTML sees positive rental reversions (Amended)
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMTML) expects positive rental reversions for 2016 despite a trend of falling reversions. The trust's portfolio saw 3.7% rental reversions in 2015, the lowest since 2009. CMTML CEO Wilson Tan noted that while there may be short-term changes to lease structures, these are unlikely to be permanent. The trust posted a 3.8% increase in DPU for 2015 and a 5.83% distribution yield. CMTML is also planning to redevelop Funan DigitaLife Mall into a "mall of the future" with co-working and experiential spaces.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as oil prices jump
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a cold wave that surged oil prices for a second day. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's comments on easing monetary policy in March also boosted investors. The Dow Jones rose 0.76%, the S&P 500 gained 1%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.84%. The rally comes despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Investors growing sceptical about Abenomics
summary: Investors are losing confidence in Japan's Abenomics stimulus program, citing stagnant growth, inflation concerns, and a plunge in the Nikkei stock index. The program, which combines monetary easing, fiscal stimulus, and structural reforms, has failed to deliver on its promise of a 2% inflation target. Speculators are now buying the yen, driving its value to a one-year high, and inflation-linked bonds are pricing in the lowest inflation expectations since 2013. This erosion of investor confidence puts at risk voter support for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic policies, which have been a major achievement for his government.

site_title: China's godmother of biotechnology eyes blockbuster second act
summary: Dr. Samantha Du, a Chinese biotechnology pioneer, is leading a new wave of ambitious entrepreneurs and scientists in developing China's first blockbuster innovative drugs. Du's company, Zai Lab, has secured $130 million in funding and is advising the government on accelerating pharmaceutical approvals. Despite facing challenges, Du aims to build a national biotech champion and believes China's improving ecosystem will enable Chinese companies to succeed globally.

site_title: Govt to review ways to cut business costs
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to review regulations to reduce business costs and leverage technology to improve services for companies. The government aims to support innovative businesses and create a conducive environment for restructuring, innovation, and internationalization. The minister emphasized the need for firms to create value through innovation and deep skills, and the government will invest in workers through the SkillsFuture movement. The government also plans to partner with trade associations and chambers, and capitalize on private-sector financing and expertise to help firms grow and transform.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Spring clean
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

For Chinese New Year, Singaporeans can decorate their homes with auspicious items. A vase from Japanese copper cast maker Odakou Douki Co and a book lamp from Autoban can add a touch of elegance. Traditional items like the Lo Hei Plate and golden harvest collection fruits are also popular. For those who prefer more subtle decorations, bouquets from Bouclair Home and Lycksalig cushions from Ikea can add a pop of color. Unique items like the Mini Window from Scene Shang and the Nanimarquina Formosa rug from Space Furniture can also add a touch of luxury to the home.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: The trouble with being SMART
summary: In today's dynamic business environment, traditional SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Timely) goals hinder collaboration and innovation. As global companies transform to decentralized structures, SMART goals can subtract from these environments. Measurable goals, often cited as essential, can actually hinder performance, while "Achievable" goals can limit organizational performance. "Relevant" goals can create silos, and "Timely" goals prioritize speed over other meaningful goals. To succeed, executives should reassess their goals and adopt non-SMART, qualitative objectives that inspire discretionary effort and collective judgment.

site_title: Thai tycoons competing for Casino's SE Asia units
summary: Thai billionaire families TCC Holding Co, led by Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, and Central Group, controlled by the Chirathivat family, are competing to buy Casino's South-east Asian operations, including Big C Supercenter chains in Thailand and Vietnam. The companies have submitted first-round bids, with TCC potentially spending over $3 billion and Central Group possibly spending up to $800 million. The sale would be part of Casino's plan to cut debt by over $6.2 billion this year, following a 45% drop in its share price in 2015.

site_title: VW admits cheating in US but not in Europe
summary: Volkswagen (VW) has admitted to cheating on emissions testing in the US, but claims its practices in Europe are legal under European rules. The company installed software in millions of vehicles worldwide to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions, but only admitted to using the software in the US, where about 500,000 affected diesel cars were sold. In contrast, European regulators found that VW used an illegal defeat device, and the company's stance has sparked criticism and potential litigation. VW promises to fix affected vehicles worldwide, but its refusal to admit wrongdoing in Europe has raised questions about the regulatory system.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OLAM International Ltd repurchased $10.3 million of its convertible bonds, reducing outstanding principal to $44.3 million. EZRA Holdings CEO Lionel Lee acquired 1 million shares, increasing his stake to 19.162%. Wilton Resources entered a non-binding framework agreement with Yunnan Chihong Resources Exploration & Development Company Limited for the development of the Ciemas Gold Project in Indonesia. Singapore Airlines acquired 85.62% of Tiger Airways Holdings, completing its privatization bid. Meanwhile, OCBC announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor.

site_title: In with the old
summary: Chinese New Year in Singapore is marked by traditional festive foods, each carrying symbolic meanings of luck, prosperity, and longevity. Dishes such as Spring Lychee Oolong Chicken Broth, Abalone, Seared Golden Oyster, Shad, and Mi Fan are popular choices for the reunion dinner table. Local restaurants and vendors are offering unique and high-quality versions of these traditional foods, including hand-made pastries and premium seafood. The article highlights the importance of these foods in Chinese culture and the creativity of modern Singaporean chefs in updating traditional recipes.

site_title: Amex CEO braces for 'new reality' as profit falls 38%
summary: American Express Co reported a 38% decline in profit in the fourth quarter, driven by lower-than-expected revenue and higher expenses. CEO Ken Chenault attributed the decline to a strengthening US dollar, increased competition, and falling petrol prices. The company plans to cut costs by $1 billion by 2017 and has already implemented restructuring measures. Revenue fell 7.6% to $8.39 billion, while worldwide billed business rose 2% to $273.2 billion.

site_title: Zika virus may be linked to rare syndrome that causes paralysis
summary: Brazilian officials and doctors warn that the Zika virus, linked to severe brain damage in infants, may also be causing a surge in Guillain-Barré, a rare condition that causes paralysis. Hundreds of cases have been reported in Brazil and other Latin American countries, with some patients experiencing a creeping inability to feel sensations, followed by complete paralysis. While researchers caution that more studies are needed to prove the link, the CDC is viewing Guillain-Barré as a serious risk and is conducting a study to evaluate the connection between the two conditions.

site_title: BlackRock's Fink sees buying opportunity as Soros cautions
summary: BlackRock CEO Laurence D. Fink believes the recent stock market decline presents a buying opportunity, despite warnings from top investors such as George Soros and Jeffrey Gundlach. Fink expects markets to gain over the next year, citing China's need to expand international markets and allow more foreign investors to create a more stable market. Fink diverges from others, including Goldman Sachs' Gary Cohn, who predicts a possible currency devaluation to address slowing growth.

site_title: Hard cell
summary: A Singaporean company, Calecim, has developed a line of anti-aging cosmetics utilizing stem cell technology from umbilical cord lining, a breakthrough achieved by its parent biomedical company, Cellresearch Corporation. The company's products, including a serum and moisturizer, contain growth factors, cytokines, and proteins secreted by stem cells to regenerate skin cells and reduce signs of aging. While plant stem cells have been touted for their regenerative properties, the efficacy of these products remains uncertain, with dermatologists emphasizing the need for specific concentrations and delivery methods for optimal results.

site_title: Preventing sudden cardiac death
summary: Sudden cardiac death (SCD) is a leading cause of unexpected death, especially in young and middle-aged individuals. It occurs when the heart stops pumping effectively due to abnormal heart rhythms. Risk factors include underlying heart disease, high cholesterol, smoking, high blood pressure, and diabetes. Warning symptoms often include chest pain and shortness of breath. Taking precautionary measures, such as regular check-ups and exercising under medical supervision, can help reduce the risk of SCD. Additionally, identifying and addressing underlying inherited heart disease is crucial for young athletes. By being aware of these risks and taking proactive steps, individuals can lower their likelihood of experiencing SCD.

site_title: Court orders WP-run town council to appoint accountants from one of 'Big Four' firms
summary: A Singapore Court of Appeal ordered a town council run by the Workers' Party to appoint accountants from the Big Four firms within two weeks to examine its financial books, citing public interest. The court also set a deadline for the first progress report on April 15. The move comes after the town council faced criticism over its financial management.

site_title: Testing time for TRs but there's still hope
summary: Stockbrokers are facing declining trading volume and reduced commissions, leading to a challenging industry landscape. However, recent data suggests that retail interest in local equities is increasing, with 18% more new Central Depository accounts opened in 2015 and a 4% rise in average monthly transactions. This modest growth offers hope for existing and prospective trading representatives, with the number of dealing licenses still appearing attractive despite industry difficulties.

site_title: Stocks rout adds to property market woes
summary: The private housing market in Singapore is expected to continue facing challenges due to the stock market rout, weak economic growth, and rising interest rates. Despite a slight dip in the official private housing price index in the fourth quarter, property consultants warn that the market may languish due to a decrease in sentiment among potential buyers. The resale market is also expected to soften, leading to a potential drop in prices. With elevated completion levels and rising vacancy rates, rents are expected to decline further, with some experts predicting a drop of 5-8% in the overall rental index for private homes this year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Public Transport Council takes on advisory role to the Transport Minister
summary: Singapore's Public Transport Council has taken on an advisory role to the Transport Minister, aiming to assess and improve the island's public transport system through research studies and surveys. The assessment will compare Singapore's bus and train services with those of other Asian cities and examine commuter needs and expectations. The move is part of efforts to enhance the overall public transport experience for commuters.

site_title: Seven wonder
summary: The Toyota Sienta, a second-generation minivan, boasts a unique, curvaceous design inspired by a trekking shoe. Its boxy proportions are replaced by a more dynamic appearance, featuring contrasting plastic trim and an iridescent brown Flexstone finish on higher models. Inside, the cabin is futuristic and well-contoured, with a slim orange line brightening the dashboard when the glove compartment is opened. The Sienta offers ample space for three rows of seats, with clever foldable seats allowing for a flat cargo floor. Priced from S$109,988, it is currently the cheapest Japanese-made seven-seat model available.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended higher on Friday, closing at 1,625.21 after adding 24.29 points. 1.93 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion were traded, with 712 gainers and 217 losers.

site_title: Prudent spending remains priority: MOF
summary: The Ministry of Finance in Singapore has emphasized prudent spending as a priority amid an uncertain economic environment. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the government must focus on getting value for money despite increasing costs in transport infrastructure, healthcare, and housing. This decision comes as the global economic environment continues to pose challenges, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Francis Seow, former solicitor-general and opposition politician, dies in Boston aged 88
summary: Former Solicitor-General and opposition politician Francis Seow, 88, has died in Boston. The cause of death was not disclosed. Seow, who fled Singapore after being charged with corruption, lived in the US. His nephew confirmed his death on LinkedIn.

site_title: ECB's Coeure says QE is working
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program is working, according to executive board member Benoit Coeure. This has led to a "tremendous improvement" in eurozone capital markets. Coeure stated the ECB remains committed to pushing inflation back to its 2% goal. In contrast, UBS chairman Axel Weber warned that central banks are "tempting fate" by pushing interest rates deep into negative territory, citing recent market turbulence as a result of easy monetary policy.

site_title: UK government sells London project stake for US$531 million
summary: The UK government sold its 36.5% stake in the 67-acre King's Cross project in London to AustralianSuper for US$531 million. The stake was part of the government's efforts to chip away at its debt. The project, which has undergone significant transformation, will feature 5.8 million square feet of space across 50 buildings near King's Cross and St. Pancras railway stations. Google plans to construct its London headquarters there, further solidifying the area's growth potential.

site_title: Eurozone 2016 inflation expectations fall to 0.7%: ECB survey
summary: Eurozone inflation expectations fell to 0.7% in 2016, according to the European Central Bank's Survey of Professional Forecasters. Longer-term projections also declined, with 2017 and 2018 inflation expectations at 1.4% and 1.6%, respectively. The ECB may review its policy stance in March, potentially leading to policy easing. The decline in inflation expectations reflects concerns over stagnant growth and high unemployment in the Eurozone.

site_title: German private sector growth slows at start of new year: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector growth slowed at the start of 2016, according to a survey, with the Markit PMI falling to 54.5 from 55.5 in December. Despite this, the steady expansion marked a 33rd month of continuous growth, comfortably above the 50 line that separates growth from contraction. The slowdown was attributed to weaker growth in emerging markets, particularly China, but a stable labor market and European Central Bank's monetary stimulus are expected to support further growth.

site_title: The changing face of employee loyalty
summary: Employee loyalty is shifting from a lifetime contract to a level of engagement and commitment, with workers valuing meaningful work and personal growth. In today's unpredictable business climate, companies can foster loyalty by focusing on training, engaging staff, and providing opportunities for career development. A company's purpose and values are also crucial in determining employee loyalty, particularly among millennials who prioritize purpose beyond financial success. By putting aside assumptions about the future and focusing on the present, both employers and employees can benefit from a dynamic and active relationship.

site_title: Google paid Apple US$1b in '14 to keep search bar on iPhone
summary: Google paid Apple $1 billion in 2014 to keep the Google search bar on the iPhone, according to a Bloomberg report citing a court transcript. The arrangement involves Google giving Apple a percentage of revenue generated through the iPhone, but the exact percentage is unclear. The payment was made as part of a larger deal related to a copyright lawsuit filed by Oracle against Google, which accuses the search giant of using Java software without permission. The terms of the deal remain private.

site_title: Update: Former NTUC chairman and ex-MP Phey Yew Kok sentenced to 60 months' jail
summary: Former NTUC chairman and ex-MP Phey Yew Kok, 81, was sentenced to 60 months in jail for 12 charges, including criminal breach of trust and failing to attend court. He pleaded guilty to the charges and will serve the sentence. This update does not appear to be related to the other news articles provided.

site_title: US blocks Philips' US$3.3b sale of Lumileds to Asian buyers
summary: The US has blocked Philips' $3.3 billion sale of its Lumileds lighting components division to Asian buyers, citing national security concerns. The deal, which would have seen an 80% stake sold to a consortium led by GO Scale Capital, was rejected by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US. The decision leaves Philips under pressure as it tries to spin off its lighting businesses to focus on its core medical scanner and healthcare technology businesses. Philips will revive talks with alternative buyers and press ahead with plans to spin off its main lighting division by June.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: OCBC Bank announced its latest earnings, with Tan Teck Long set to succeed Helen Wong as CEO. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. CGS Investment also downgraded Grab's stock to 'hold', citing slowing earnings growth in the second half. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to $3.1 million. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai, following China's GDP growth slowdown.

site_title: Ascendas Funds Management CEO to retire in March
summary: Ascendas Funds Management CEO TAN Ser Ping will retire on March 31, 2016, after 11 years as CEO. He will be succeeded by Chia Nam Toon, currently CFO and COO of the Ascendas-Singbridge Group, effective April 1, 2016. To ensure a smooth transition, TAN Ser Ping will serve as adviser to the AFM board for 12 months following his retirement, credited by AFM chairman Koh Soo Keong for the strength of the management team that led A-Reit's expansion.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Chilli crabs whet Samsung Asset's appetite amid S'pore stock losses
summary: A Hong Kong-based money manager, Alan Richardson of Samsung Asset Management, sees potential in Singapore companies such as Singapore Airlines, Jumbo Group, and Sheng Siong Group amid the country's worst stock performance in four years. Richardson is taking a cautious approach, avoiding commodity-related stocks and focusing on those with good growth potential. He notes that Singapore growth may be subdued but still growing, and sees opportunities in sectors like real estate investment trusts.

site_title: Malaysia media industry downsizing as economy weakens
summary: Malaysia's media industry is downsizing due to a weak economy and shrinking ringgit. Groups such as The Edge Media Group and Kinibiz are reducing headcount and terminating operations to focus on core businesses. Star Publications is reportedly looking to offload its Chinese radio stations, while HCK Media closed its weekly newspaper and news portal. The Edge Group's two papers, Kinibiz, and others are struggling, with some banking on the Rio Olympics for a much-needed lift. The industry is also watching the progress of Bloomberg TV Malaysia, which relies heavily on ad revenues for its longevity.

site_title: Global iron trade faces disruption following port closure
summary: A Brazilian court ordered Vale SA, the world's largest iron ore producer, to temporarily close one of its main ports due to alleged environmental breaches, disrupting the global iron ore trade. The closure affects Vale's export and import activities at Tubarao port, which could impact iron ore prices. Futures surged in Asia, with the SGX AsiaClear iron ore contract rising 6.9% to US$39.90 a tonne. The length of the closure will determine its consequences, with analysts suggesting a short-term impact may be manageable.

site_title: Ringgit rallies to 3-month high on oil rebound
summary: Malaysia's ringgit surged to a 3-month high, reaching 4.3175 against the US dollar, following a rebound in Brent crude prices, which rose 7% in two days. The currency's appreciation trimmed its 2016 decline to 0.6% and strengthened against the Singapore dollar. Bank Negara Malaysia cut the reserve requirement, injecting RM6.2 billion into the banking system, which boosted sentiment and stabilized the ringgit after its worst drop since the Asian financial crisis. The move is seen as a response to global market turmoil and the European Central Bank's potential stimulus.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares soar 5.88% on stimulus hopes
summary: Tokyo shares surged 5.88% on Friday, driven by hopes for fresh European and Japanese central bank stimulus. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 941.27 points to 16,958.53, while the Topix index gained 5.59% to 1,374.19. This followed strong gains in US and European markets, with investors optimistic about potential stimulus measures.

site_title: UK's Osborne takes his 'dangerous cocktail' warning to Davos
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne warned at the World Economic Forum in Davos that the global economy faces a "dangerous cocktail" of risks due to slowing China's growth and low oil prices. He noted that while oil prices are beneficial for British consumers, they create volatility. Osborne stated that 2016 has been the worst start to a year for financial markets in his lifetime. The International Monetary Fund has cut its world growth outlook to 3.4%, citing a hazardous mix of factors, including a weak corporate earnings season and higher US interest rates.

site_title: Jin says AIIB may lend US$2b, announce projects in June
summary: Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) President Jin Liqun announced plans to lend at least $2 billion to various projects in 2016, with possible investments announced by June. The AIIB, led by China, aims to raise $300-$500 million through bond sales in April or May. With 30-40 nations waiting to join, membership could reach 100 countries, surpassing the founding 57. Jin also expressed concerns about China's stock market and the need for broader and deeper development, while noting the US economy is "picking up."

site_title: Barclays, Deutsche Bank face slowdown at investment banks
summary: Barclays and Deutsche Bank, two major European investment banks, face challenges in boosting profitability due to market turbulence and concerns over the industry's profit sustainability. Barclays is accelerating its plan to focus on core strengths and shutting offices in nine countries, while Deutsche Bank reported a 16% drop in revenue in the fourth quarter. European bank shares have fallen 14% this year, with Deutsche Bank dropping 23% and Barclays declining 15%. Industry experts say the banks must adapt to changing market conditions and reduce volatility in their business models.

site_title: 'Corrupt' Chinese officials seized nearly US$1.4b: analysis
summary: Chinese officials convicted in President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption drive have embezzled or misused over 6.3 billion yuan (US$1.37 billion) in public funds. Nearly 1,500 officials have been targeted, with 231 convicted and sentenced in Chinese courts. Critics argue the drive lacks transparency and has been used to settle political scores, with officials from Xi's provincial power bases receiving relatively lighter treatment. The campaign, launched in 2012, aims to target both high-ranking officials and low-level "flies," but its effectiveness and fairness are disputed.

site_title: Fewer orders at Apple suppliers could signal first iPhone sales decline
summary: Apple's suppliers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Largan Precision Co Ltd, forecast a decline in orders and revenues for the first quarter, signaling a possible annual decline in iPhone sales. Industry executives attribute the decline to the lack of new features in the latest iPhone, raising concerns about Apple's innovative streak. Suppliers, such as Foxconn and LG Display Co Ltd, expect a 10-11% decline in revenues, with some analysts predicting iPhone sales could pick up in the second half of the year.

site_title: Tiger bolstered by cheaper fuel, higher lease rental income in Q3
summary: Tiger Airways, a Singapore budget carrier, reported a net profit of S$6.78 million for Q3 FY2016, up from S$2.19 million, driven by cheaper jet fuel and higher lease rental income. Revenue increased 1.5% to S$187.38 million, despite a decline in airline operations in Singapore and lower yields. The group expects uncertain macroeconomic conditions to continue exerting downward pressure on yields, but the low fuel price environment offers some respite.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Schlumberger says non-Opec producers keeping "taps wide" open
summary: Schlumberger CEO Paal Kibsgaard stated that non-Opec oil producers are maintaining high production levels, or "taps wide open," to maximize cash flow amidst a global oil supply glut. This has contributed to the nearly 73% decline in global oil prices since June 2014. Despite this, Kibsgaard expressed optimism for positive oil price movement in 2016, depending on the shape of the non-Opec decline rates. The company has also reported a slightly better-than-expected profit and announced a $10 billion share buyback program.

site_title: STI down 2% at the end of a volatile week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week down 2% following a volatile week of trading, despite improved liquidity with daily averages above S$1 billion. Oil price weakness and China's market volatility contributed to the losses, with offshore and marine stocks leading the gains. Engineering firm Koyo International was the week's largest percentage loser, while China's market regulator apologized for shortcomings in handling volatility. The market's performance is seen as a reflection of the country's economic challenges, with Schroders' Robin Parbrook warning of significant consequences if outflows continue.

site_title: Gran van
summary: The BMW 216d Gran Tourer is the most expensive Cat A MPV, priced at S$163,800. It's a seven-seater compact premium model, offering a unique positioning as the only upmarket seven-seater in its class. The Gran Tourer has a longer wheelbase, 55mm taller height, and a 65kg weight advantage over the five-seater Active Tourer. It features a 1.5-litre three-cylinder turbodiesel, smooth engine, and decent handling. The interior is designed for young families, with a versatile cabin, folding tray tables, and a panoramic sunroof.

site_title: China: Shares end higher on global stimulus hopes
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.25% on Friday, its first weekly gain in 2016, as investors cautiously welcomed hints of global stimulus and robust oil price rallies. Despite a 17% slump in the first half of the year, China's fragile markets showed resilience, but trading volumes remained low. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has been injecting liquidity to prevent volatility, but analysts expect policy measures to curb the yuan's depreciation. European and US markets took heart from comments from the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan, which hinted at potential stimulus measures, sending the euro and yen higher.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end almost 3% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged almost 3% on Friday, driven by hopes for fresh stimulus measures from Japan and the eurozone, as well as a rally in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.90% to 19,080.51, while Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also increased. The gains came as traders brushed off new US President Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Friday but lower for the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 2% lower for the week, despite a 44.39-point rebound on Friday. The index lost 53 points over the week, largely due to oil price weakness and volatility in China. However, liquidity has improved, with daily averages above S$1 billion, 20-30% higher than a month ago. The STI has been tracking market developments, including China, Hong Kong, oil, and US Dow futures, before releasing its GDP data next week.

site_title: Oil prices surge past US$30 on eurozone stimulus pledge
summary: Oil prices surged past $30 a barrel on Friday after the European Central Bank signaled further stimulus measures to help the struggling eurozone economy. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 4.44% to $30.84 a barrel, while Brent rose 5.2% to $30.77. Despite a supply glut and weak demand, the ECB's remarks lifted global markets, but analysts expect the gains to be short-lived due to oversupply woes. The rebound is seen as a temporary relief after oil prices plummeted 75% in 18 months.

site_title: China central bank says won't rush to cut bank reserve ratio despite liquidity squeeze: sources
summary: China's central bank has decided not to rush to cut the reserve ratio of banks despite a liquidity squeeze ahead of the Lunar New Year, according to sources. Assistant governor Zhang Xiaohui said the central bank could use other policy tools to add liquidity, rather than cutting the cash amount banks must hold as reserves. The central bank may instead inject over 600 billion yuan in liquidity before the holiday, keeping the yuan stable against a basket of currencies. This move aims to maintain economic stability and avoid sending a strong signal of policy easing.

site_title: HDB sells S$1b seven-year bonds at 2.50%
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) sold S$1 billion seven-year bonds at 2.50% on Friday, amid volatile markets. Demand was lower than expected, but banks mainly bid for the bonds due to HDB's Aaa rating. The sale was completed within two hours, with the option to upsize by S$600 million available. This deal size would beat HDB's largest single issue, a S$1.5 billion 1.875% four-year issue in 2013. The bonds qualify as high-quality liquid assets under the Monetary Authority of Singapore's rules.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's currency faces its 4th annual decline, with local selling due to economic concerns. The unionized sector saw 11.8% more layoffs in 2015, and private home prices fell 0.5% in Q4. Keppel Corp's uncertainties over the oil-rig market continue, and employers plan moderate salary hikes of 3-6% this year. Noble Group's founder expects to turn the company into a nimble, asset-light entity to recover from recent market downturns.

site_title: Global stocks rebound on stimulus bets as oil surges with ruble
summary: Global stocks rebounded 2% on speculation of central bank stimulus measures, with commodity companies leading the advance. Oil surged with emerging-market currencies, while the euro fell to a two-week low. The Bank of Japan is expected to enlarge stimulus, while China will continue to intervene in its equity market. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose, and Asian markets followed, with shares in Hong Kong rebounding from a low since June 2012.

site_title: At least 19 dead in Somalia restaurant attack by Shebab militants
summary: At least 19 people, including women and children, were killed in a bombing and attack by Shebab militants at a restaurant in Mogadishu, Somalia's capital. The attack occurred when five gunmen detonated a bomb before storming the restaurant on Thursday evening. The Al-Qaeda-linked Shebab have claimed responsibility for the attack, with four of their gunmen killed and one captured. The attack was described as "barbaric and brutal" by Somali police.

site_title: A-Reit posts 9.9% jump in Q3 DPU
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) posted a 9.9% jump in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.946 Singapore cents in the third quarter, driven by new property acquisitions, asset enhancement initiatives, and positive rental reversion. Gross revenue rose 13% to S$193.8 million, while net property income jumped 24% to S$142.2 million. Tan Ser Ping will retire as CEO of Ascendas Funds Management on March 31, 2016, and will be succeeded by Chia Nam Toon.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: IMF boss Lagarde says will run for 2nd mandate
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde announced she will run for a second term, citing the backing of several major countries including France, Britain, Germany, China, and Korea. Lagarde has no apparent challengers and has previously expressed openness to serving another term. This move is seen as a significant development in the IMF's leadership.

site_title: Noble Group's Elman sees future as smaller, nimble company
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodities trader, plans to transform into a nimble and asset-light company to recover from recent accounting allegations and market downturns. Founder and chairman Richard Elman, 75, aims to return to being "modest and cautious" after Iceberg Research's allegations of inflated assets were rejected by the company. Elman sees no further disruptions and expects the business to recover as global commodity prices bottom out. New investors are selective, and Noble's plans to bring them in are taking time, according to Elman.

site_title: Airbus delay wipes US$1.2b off India's biggest airline
summary: India's largest airline, IndiGo, has delayed its delivery of Airbus A320neo planes due to industrial reasons, resulting in a US$1.2 billion loss in market value. The airline is leasing 22 used planes while waiting for the new model, which has been delayed following issues detected at the last minute in software used by Pratt & Whitney engines. This delay is expected to impact IndiGo's future growth, with fuel costs declining 20% and passenger numbers increasing 28% in the third quarter.

site_title: The Edge media group to cut jobs, restructure
summary: The Edge Media Group, a Malaysian media firm, is restructuring its operations and laying off staff due to "hard times" and a shifting media landscape. The group, owned by tycoon Tong Kooi Ong, has not sold, despite market rumors, and aims to maintain its core financial news business. The move follows a two-month suspension of its publications and the challenges posed by rapidly changing news consumption patterns. The group's daily financial newspaper and property portal have also been launched in recent times, and its digital platform for financial news and data analytics has been rolled out.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Eurozone business activity slows sharply in January: survey
summary: Eurozone business activity slowed sharply in January, with the Composite Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) falling to 53.5 points, an 11-month low. Despite this, the economy continues to expand overall, with quarterly growth estimated at 0.3-0.4 percent. Uncertainty from financial market volatility and a slowdown in China's economy have contributed to the decline, but business confidence appears to be improving and employment prospects remain resilient. The European Central Bank has expressed concern over "downside risks" to the economy, but analysts caution that the figures are not disastrous and still indicate reasonable new business growth.

site_title: Singapore's Kuo Oil seeks ships for Iran now sanctions lifted
summary: Singapore-based oil trading company Kuo Oil is seeking ships to load Iranian fuel oil after the US lifted sanctions imposed in 2012. The sanctions were lifted as part of the US's relaxation of sanctions against Iran for compliance with a nuclear agreement. Kuo Oil is seeking tankers to lift 120,000 tonnes of fuel oil from Bandar Abbas and Bandar Mahshahr between January 29 and February 8. However, securing insurance coverage remains a challenge due to ongoing restrictions, including a prohibition on using US dollars.

site_title: Indonesia central bank gov sees some inflation pressure from tax on cattle imports
summary: Indonesia's central bank Governor Agus Martowardojo expects temporary inflationary pressure due to a recently imposed 10% value-added tax on imported cattle, lasting 2-3 months. This comes as Indonesia's annual inflation rate was 3.35% in December. The tax was introduced earlier this week, adding to the already existing inflationary concerns.

site_title: Europe: Shares sharply higher, commodities stocks lead
summary: European equities rose 1.9% to 1,318.99 points, driven by a 2.1% gain on Thursday after ECB hints of March policy review. Oil and mining stocks surged 4.1% and 3.2% respectively, while Philips fell 0.9% after a deal breakdown. The gains followed European Central Bank's comments on financial market turmoil and concerns over China.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on Europe stimulus hopes, commodities bounce
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% on Friday, ending a two-day winning streak for the year, as hopes of European stimulus and commodity price rebounds boosted sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 52 points to 4,916, a 0.5% weekly gain. Despite a 7.2% decline in 2016 so far, the market is entering positive territory for the week.

site_title: China's AgBank may lose US$578m through suspected bill fraud: Caixin
summary: China's Agricultural Bank of China Ltd (AgBank) may lose $578 million due to a suspected bills of exchange scam allegedly carried out by two employees in a Beijing branch. The employees allegedly sold the bills to a third party, invested the proceeds in the stock market, and then used the funds to cover losses. The employees are under investigation by the Ministry of Public Security and the China Banking Regulatory Commission. This incident highlights ongoing corruption issues in China's banking industry, with several senior executives recently sentenced to prison for bribery.

site_title: Fibre broadband outage in some areas of Sengkang
summary: A fibre broadband outage occurred in some areas of Sengkang, Singapore, on January 22, 2016, due to a contractor cutting a portion of the underground fibre optic network in Ang Mo Kio. Restoration services began early in the morning and are expected to be completed by 11am.

site_title: China money rates climb despite cbank injections as holiday cash binge begins
summary: China's money rates spiked this week as banks hoarded cash ahead of the Lunar New Year festival, despite massive central bank injections. The one-day repo rate rose 9 basis points to 2.0275%, while the 14-day repo surged 105 basis points to 3.6988%. Analysts attribute the rise to seasonal cash demand and tax payments, rather than capital flight. The central bank injected a record 315 billion yuan into money markets and added liquidity through its short-term operations tool to maintain holiday liquidity.

site_title: SAP raises 2017 revenue and operating profit outlook targets
summary: German software maker SAP has raised its 2017 revenue and operating profit outlook targets to the upper end of expectations, exceeding analyst forecasts. SAP now expects 2017 revenue of 23.0-23.5 billion euros and non-IFRS operating profit of 6.7-7.0 billion euros. This marks progress in its transformation from a packaged software firm to an internet-based, cloud supplier. The company's 2016 outlook remains cautious, following strong 2015 results fueled by year-end renewals by existing customers.

site_title: Billionaire James Packer and Mariah Carey said to be engaged
summary: Australian casino billionaire James Packer, 48, and Grammy Award-winning singer Mariah Carey, 45, are reportedly engaged after Packer gave Carey a 35-carat diamond ring. The couple, dating less than a year, has not set a wedding date. Packer, with a net worth of US$3.7 billion, has been married twice before, and Carey has two children. The engagement was not publicly announced, but confirmed by a person familiar with the situation.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest daily gain in 4-1/2-mths; won climbs
summary: South Korean shares rose 2.1% to their largest daily gain in 4.5 months, driven by improved sentiment after oil prices rebounded and the European Central Bank raised hopes for further monetary policy easing. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended at 1,879.43 points. The won climbed 1.1% against the dollar, marking its first weekly gain in three weeks. Despite foreign investors selling shares for a 12th straight session, the gains were attributed to a rebound in oil prices and ECB's positive outlook.

site_title: Australia's ASX set to lead in blockchain for public companies
summary: Australia's ASX, a major stock exchange operator, has acquired a 5% stake in US-based blockchain developer Digital Asset Holdings for A$14.9 million. This investment positions ASX to become the first stock exchange to use blockchain technology for public companies, aiming to cut costs, speed up transactions, and enhance security. The move follows similar initiatives by other financial firms and exchange operators, including Nasdaq and Deutsche Boerse, which are testing blockchain technology for private and public companies.

site_title: George Soros says he expects hard landing for China economy
summary: Billionaire investor George Soros expects China's economy to experience a hard landing, contributing to global deflationary pressures. Soros has shorted the Standard & Poor's 500 Index and advised against buying equities, citing the slowdown in China and deflation. He also believes the Federal Reserve may not meet its 2% inflation target and may even cut interest rates. Soros predicts a difficult year in the markets, which could see further declines, echoing comments from other top investors.

site_title: Singapore employers plan moderate salary hikes this year: Hays
summary: Singapore employers plan moderate salary hikes of 3-10% this year, with 47% opting for 3-6% and 11% for 6-10%. 63% intend awarding staff bonuses, while 60% expect business activity to increase. Despite a skills shortage, most employers will keep salaries in check, focusing on strategies like developing pipeline talent and recruiting overseas. The Hays Salary Guide, based on 3,000 employers, highlights regional trends and role-specific salary ranges for six million employees across Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, China, and Japan.

site_title: Indian banks to get commission for unlocking household gold: cbank
summary: The Indian government will pay banks a 2.5% commission to unlock the country's massive stash of gold under the Gold Monetisation Scheme. Launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in November 2015, the scheme aims to trim India's import bill but has received little interest from banks and customers due to low returns. The government has decided to pay banks a total commission of 2.5% for the first year, including 1.5% handling charges, to make the scheme attractive for banks.

site_title: Miners surge as metals poised for first weekly rise this year
summary: Miners surged as copper prices rose 1.6% to $4,426 a metric ton, marking the biggest advance in five weeks. BHP Billiton and Glencore Plc rose 8.7% and 10% respectively. The Bloomberg World Mining Index gained 0.7%, poised for the first weekly gain this year. European Central Bank head hinted at further monetary easing, while Chinese officials sought to ease concerns over the leadership's ability to steer the world's biggest metals consumer into slower growth.

site_title: Singapore unionised sector sees 11.8% more lay-offs in 2015
summary: Singapore's unionized sector saw a 11.8% increase in layoffs in 2015, with 2,512 workers displaced from their jobs. Most layoffs (93%) occurred in the manufacturing sector. Despite this, the healthcare, security, air transport, and pharmaceutical sectors are expected to have a positive outlook for 2016. The NTUC also expects 234 workers to be retrenched in the first quarter of 2016, a 31% increase from the previous year.

site_title: Japan lifts nuclear sanctions on Iran
summary: Japan has lifted nuclear sanctions on Iran, aligning with major world powers after the UN atomic energy agency confirmed Tehran's compliance with its nuclear programme. The move allows tens of billions of dollars worth of Iranian assets to be unfrozen, and Japanese businesses to invest in Iran's oil and gas sector. This comes after the US and other countries formally lifted banking, steel, shipping, and other sanctions on Iran, ending five years of international isolation. Japan aims to strengthen its relationship with Iran and contribute to regional stability.

site_title: Oracle lawyer says Google's Android generated US$31b revenue
summary: Google's Android operating system has generated US$31 billion in revenue and US$22 billion in profit since its release in 2007, according to an Oracle lawyer. The figure was revealed during a US court hearing in a copyright lawsuit between the two companies. The Android mobile operating system was first released in November 2007 and its first commercial version was released in September 2008. Google has expressed willingness to disclose more information about Android's revenue as part of the court proceedings.

site_title: Templeton's US$42b manager says the gloom has gone too far
summary: Heather Arnold, director of research at Templeton Global Advisors, believes the global economic gloom has gone too far, despite China's slowdown and low oil prices. She sees Europe as the cheapest market and emerging markets, particularly Asian financial companies, as opportunities for investment. Arnold is buying more shares and is optimistic about the global economy, despite concerns over debt levels in developed economies. She notes that China's slowing growth is a normal transition and that the yuan's decline is not an act of competitive devaluation.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as ECB soothes nervous markets, oil extends bounce
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday as the European Central Bank hinted at potential monetary easing, soothing nervous markets. The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, suggested that the bank could review its policy stance in March, citing fading growth and inflation concerns. This led to a bounce in crude oil, with US oil extending its gains. The Nikkei jumped 3.5%, while Australian and South Korean shares rose 1.3% and 1.8% respectively. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 2%, breaking a four-year low.

site_title: Oil prices stretch gains on cold US, European weather
summary: Oil prices rose for a second session, moving further away from 12-year lows, due to cold US and European weather and firmer financial markets. Benchmark crude futures rose 17 cents to $29.70 per barrel, poised for a 1% weekly gain. Despite soaring inventories and persistent overproduction, analysts caution the price rally is unsustainable. The current cold snaps are expected to be short-lived, and fundamental reasons for low oil prices remain unchanged, with producers pumping over 1 million barrels daily beyond demand.

site_title: KKR, China Orient team up to invest in property-related bad debt
summary: KKR & Co has partnered with China Orient Asset Management Co to invest in China's growing distressed debt market, particularly in the property sector. The venture, which provides flexible capital solutions, has already invested in one deal and aims to capitalize on the increasing number of borrowers defaulting on loans due to slowing economic growth. China's non-performing loans grew 36% in 2015, with the property market accounting for 22% of total yuan-denominated loans. The partnership is seen as a sign of growing foreign interest in China's distressed debt market.

site_title: Japan fin min Aso says closely watching forex moves
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso is closely watching foreign exchange moves as the yen reached a one-year high against the dollar, briefly falling below 116 yen. Aso declined to comment on currency levels but emphasized the government's commitment to achieving 2% inflation. He reiterated the need for the government and Bank of Japan to stick to their joint statement, which aims for 2% inflation.

site_title: Keppel uncertainty prolonged as key Brazil client delays decision
summary: Keppel Corp, the world's largest oil rig builder, faces uncertainty after a key Brazilian client, Sete Brasil Participacoes, postponed a meeting on restructuring, pushing back a decision on the company's restructuring plans. Keppel stopped work on projects for Sete Brasil in the fourth quarter, taking a S$230 million charge on the delinquent projects. The delay prolongs Keppel's uncertainty about the oil-rig market, which is expected to continue.

site_title: As oil slump rocks Petronas, Malaysians brace for hard times
summary: Malaysia's oil giant Petronas has announced sharp spending cuts amid a dismal outlook due to high costs, a plunging currency, and fewer jobs. The company's business review includes a plan to cut spending by up to 50 billion ringgit (US$11.4 billion) over the next four years. This move is expected to have a significant impact on the country's economy, which is already struggling with a slowdown in growth, rising debt, and unemployment. Prime Minister Najib Razak faces pressure to address the economic challenges, which may fuel social unrest ahead of the 2018 general election.

site_title: Oil's collapse hurting states that were counting on US$50-a-barrel
summary: US oil prices have plummeted to a 12-year low, causing significant fiscal strain on oil-producing states, including Louisiana, Alaska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and North Dakota. The price drop has led to budget shortfalls and job losses, with Louisiana projected to have a $1.9 billion deficit and Oklahoma expecting a 7.7% shortfall in tax collections. To address the issue, states are revising budget forecasts and considering tax increases or spending cuts. Texas, with its diversified economy, is better buffered, but still faces a cut in energy-severance tax contributions to the state's funds.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise 0.1% in Q4, down 1.6% for full-year 2015
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.1% quarter-over-quarter in Q4 2015, resulting in a 1.6% decline for the full year. Resale transactions increased by 2% in Q4, reaching 4,992 cases, and 11.5% for the full year.

site_title: China: Shares retreat, shrug off global stimulus hopes
summary: China's shares retreated, shrugging off global stimulus hopes, as investors remained cautious amid the country's economic decline. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.3% and the CSI300 index also dropped 0.3%. Despite Vice President Li Yuanchao's reassurances, regulators' efforts to curb volatility have failed. Economic indicators confirm China's declining growth, putting the country at the top of global investors' worry list. The yuan currency remains under pressure, but concerns about a near-term devaluation are fading, and the People's Bank of China is expected to keep the currency's fall in check.

site_title: URA office rental index falls 6.5% in 2015
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) office rental index in Singapore fell 6.5% in 2015, contrasting with a 9.8% increase in 2014. The index dipped 0.1% quarter-on-quarter in Q4 2015, with a 1.8% quarterly decline. Total office space supply in the pipeline stood at approximately 993,000 square meters at the end of 2015. This marks a reversal from the 4.5% increase in 2014.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday
summary: The Singapore market opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 46.18 points or 1.8% to 2,578.88, driven by an overnight Wall Street recovery, European Central Bank easing hints, and crude oil price recovery. Gainers outpaced losers 123 to 28. Key gainers included Ezra Holdings, Sembcorp Industries, Keppel Corp, and CapitaLand, with gains of 5.36%, 3.65%, 3.13%, and 2.37% respectively.

site_title: Olam repurchases US$10.3m of convertible bonds due 2016
summary: Olam International Limited announced the repurchase of US$10.3 million of its US$500 million 6% convertible bonds due 2016. The repurchased bonds have been cancelled, reducing the outstanding principal amount to US$44.3 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 12.80 points to 1,613.72. The market saw 271 gainers for every 52 losers, with volume reaching 83.87 million lots worth RM 33.74 million.

site_title: Sharp US$5.5b bailout plan likely to be decided by next weekend: sources
summary: A Japanese state-backed fund, Innovation Network Corporation of Japan (INCJ), is likely to agree on a US$5.5 billion bailout plan for struggling display maker Sharp by next weekend. The plan would involve INCJ investing 300 billion yen and banks offering up to 350 billion yen in financing. Sharp's main creditors, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group, are also considering a proposal from Taiwan's Foxconn. The bailout comes after Sharp's last rescue in May provided around US$1.7 billion in financing, but the company has shown few signs of a turnaround.

site_title: KKR, COAMI, COS-Capital team up to explore China opportunities
summary: KKR & Co has teamed up with China Orient Asset Management (International) Holding Limited and China Orient Summit Capital (COS-Capital) to co-invest in credit and distressed opportunities in China, focusing on the real estate sector. The partnership aims to provide flexible capital solutions. KKR will work with COS-Capital to explore opportunities in China, with Edward Han, managing director and head of special situations, leading the collaboration. The partnership will be beneficial for both parties, providing access to Chinese markets and capital.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CMT, FCT, Soilbuild Reit, Keppel Corp
summary: Local investors can focus on earnings reports from CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) and Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT), which reported a 0.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) and a 4.4% increase, respectively. CMT's DPU rose to 2.88 cents due to gains from the disposal of Rivervale Mall and higher rents, while FCT's DPU increased to 2.87 cents, thanks to lower property expenses.

site_title: Singapore dollar facing record 4th annual decline prompts local selling
summary: The Singapore dollar is set for a record fourth annual decline, with a 6.6% drop last year, its worst performance since the Asian crisis in 1997. Analysts predict further weakening, with a median estimate of S$1.47 to the US dollar by the end of the year, marking the longest streak of annual losses. The decline is attributed to China's struggling economy, which is Singapore's largest trading partner, and may prompt the Monetary Authority of Singapore to ease monetary policy this year.

site_title: Retail property prices and rentals fall further in Q4: URA
summary: Retail property prices in Singapore fell 0.1% in Q4 2015, after a 0.3% decline in Q3, resulting in a 0.8% decline for the year. Rentals also fell, decreasing 1.3% in Q4 and 4.1% for the year. This marks the second consecutive quarter of price and rental declines.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 3.2% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 3.2% on Friday, driven by overnight gains in the US and Europe. The Nikkei 225 index gained 512.12 points to 16,529.38, while the Topix index rose 41.40 points to 1,342.89. The gains followed hints of additional European Central Bank stimulus and a rise in oil prices from 12-year lows.

site_title: JPMorgan chief Dimon gets 35% raise
