Top US and European trade groups have urged leaders to conclude a new deal by the end of January, warning of significant consequences for businesses and customers. The deal aims to resolve the legal void following the court ruling, which was sparked by the Edward Snowden scandal. A new arrangement is seen as crucial for the transatlantic digital economy.

site_title: Hyflux unit clinches contract in Saudi Arabia
summary: Hyflux's wholly owned unit, Hydrochem Saudi Ltd, has secured a US$50.4 million contract to design, manufacture, and supply a seawater reverse osmosis and sulphate removal facilities package in Khurais, Saudi Arabia. The one-year contract is expected to contribute to Hyflux's financials for the 2016 financial year. This win highlights Hyflux's growing presence in the Middle East region and its expertise in designing high-specification plants for industrial customers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks chase crude
summary: European stocks followed the decline in oil prices, with most markets falling after the lifting of US and EU sanctions on Iran. Oil prices dropped to a 12-year low, rebounding briefly before sliding back. Italy's FTSE MIB index fell 2.7%, with several Italian banks struggling due to consolidation issues. Asian markets also declined, with Tokyo and Hong Kong closing near one-year lows. Investors remain concerned over China's economic slowdown and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: UK still faces stretch of lowflation even after pound drop
summary: The Bank of England's interest rate decision is unlikely to change despite the pound's 6% drop against the dollar, which has strengthened the inflation outlook. Inflation was 0.2% in December, below the central bank's 2% goal. Economists predict the currency will continue to weaken, with forecasts ranging from US$1.32 to US$1.50 by the end of June. The Bank of England keeps its key interest rate at a record low, and policy makers are in no hurry to begin tightening, citing muted inflation pressures.

site_title: People's Bank of China to inject 75b yuan to boost liquidity
summary: China's central bank will inject 75 billion yuan into the money markets through 28-day reverse bond repurchase agreements and 80 billion yuan via seven-day reverse repos on Tuesday. This is the first 28-day issue since February 2015, aiming to boost liquidity. Maturing reverse repos will drain 240 billion yuan from the banking system this week.

site_title: Australian leader urges China to great power conflict trap
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull urged China to avoid actions that could lead to conflict with the US, warning that pursuing territorial claims in Asia could escalate rivalry. Turnbull emphasized the importance of international law and encouraged China to reassure its neighbors and build confidence about its intentions. He also highlighted the need for a strong US presence in Asia to ensure regional economic growth. Turnbull's comments come as China's territorial claims in the South China Sea continue to be a point of contention.

site_title: Son's SoftBank plan at risk as Sprint goes from bad to worse
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's acquisition of Sprint Corp in 2013 has become its biggest setback, dragging down SoftBank shares and billionaire Masayoshi Son's fortune. The Japanese company's stock has plummeted, and Son's wealth has shrunk by $3.2 billion over the past year. Despite efforts to cut costs and improve profitability, Sprint continues to struggle, and SoftBank's shares have fallen to their lowest level since the deal closed. The prospects of a turnaround may be slipping away, taking away precious time for Son to secure his legacy.

site_title: Facebook begins Europe-wide campaign against extremist posts
summary: Facebook has launched an initiative in Europe to combat extremist posts, pledging 1 million euros to support NGOs counter racist and xenophobic content. The campaign, "Initiative for Civil Courage Online," aims to thwart hate speech on the platform. Following concerns from German politicians and celebrities, Facebook has hired a unit to monitor and delete racist posts in Germany and has faced criticism for not enforcing its ground rules. The move comes amid a rise in anti-foreigner comments in Germany, where Chancellor Angela Merkel has urged Facebook to do more.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence rebounds in Q4
summary: New Zealand business confidence rebounded in the fourth quarter, with 15% of firms expecting improved general business conditions, up from -14% in the previous quarter. Demand continued to pick up, with 18% of businesses reporting increased trading activity. Capacity utilisation reached 93.2%, suggesting solid GDP growth over the first half of 2016. However, inflation indicators remain subdued. The rebound suggests the central bank may keep interest rates on hold in 2016.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of China growth data
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on January 19, 2016, amid concerns over China's economic growth. The Nikkei 225 index declined 0.31% to 16,902.29, while the Topix index fell 0.39%. Investors are cautious ahead of China's economic data release, which may indicate slower growth in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: As dairy declines, New Zealand milks tourism boom
summary: New Zealand's tourism industry is booming, with a record 3.09 million international visitors in the year to November, generating NZ$13.5 billion in revenue. The decline of the dairy industry, which once accounted for 25% of exports, has led to the growth of tourism as a key economic driver. However, the influx of tourists is putting pressure on the country's resources, with issues including litter, road safety concerns, and strain on accommodation. The government is investing in road safety measures, but critics argue that more needs to be done to address the problem.

site_title: ECB seeks bad loan data from UniCredit and other Italy banks
summary: The European Central Bank has requested data on bad loan portfolios from several Italian banks, including UniCredit and Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena. The investigation aims to assess strategies for managing non-performing loans, which are threatening to undermine economic recovery in Europe. Italy's banking index fell 5.7% on Monday, with Monte dei Paschi experiencing a 14.8% drop, amid concerns over the country's 200 billion euros of non-repayable loans.

site_title: Oil stays under pressure as Iran orders sharp rise in crude output
summary: Oil prices remain under pressure as Iran orders a sharp increase in crude output, further exacerbating the existing global supply overhang. US crude futures fell to $29.14 a barrel, while Brent crude futures traded below $29 per barrel. The US government's ban on Iranian crude exports to the US has been revoked, allowing it to be exported to Europe and Asia, where it will be priced on the Brent benchmark. Analysts expect Iran's output to rise by 285,000-400,000 barrels per day in 2016, adding to the already high global supply.

site_title: Priciest Stockholm homes slip amid signs tipping point reached
summary: Stockholm's housing market has reached a tipping point, with prices falling 1% in the three months through December, after rising 17% over the past year. The decline is attributed to a shift in buyer psychology, with many believing prices have risen too much. This decrease in confidence is reflected in the SEB housing price indicator, which has fallen for four consecutive months. Tighter amortization standards and decreased expectations of future price growth are also contributing factors, according to economists.

site_title: MPs debate banning 'fool' Trump from Britain
summary: MPs in the UK debated banning Donald Trump from Britain over his comments on Muslims, with most lawmakers arguing he should be allowed to visit to debate his ideas. A public petition with over 575,000 signatures called for a ban, but the government has stated it will not exclude Trump. Lawmakers used colorful language to describe Trump, with some calling him a "fool," "idiot," and "buffoon." Trump has sparked controversy with his remarks, including calling for a "complete shutdown of Muslims entering the US."

site_title: European antitrust chief takes a swipe at issue of privacy
summary: European Union antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager warned that tech companies like Google and Facebook's vast data collection could be in violation of EU competition rules. She stated that giving companies control over user data could drive others out of the market, and consumers need to be treated fairly. Vestager's comments come ahead of a Jan 31 deadline for a new data-sharing agreement between Europe and the US, following a European Court of Justice ruling that digital data was not sufficiently protected when transferred to the US.

site_title: South Korea implements 'anti-nut rage' law
summary: South Korea has implemented a new "anti-nut rage" law, following an incident in 2014 where a passenger, Cho Hyun-Ah, became violent over a bag of macadamias on a flight. The law, aimed at preventing unruly behavior during flights, was prompted by public demand for enhanced aviation safety. It drastically toughens punishments for unruly passengers, reflecting the need for improved safety measures after the Korean Air "nut rage" incident.

site_title: HSBC plans new Mid-east headquarters near world's tallest tower in Dubai
summary: HSBC plans to build a new Middle East headquarters in Dubai, near the world's tallest tower, as part of its move to combine staff from three other locations in the city. The 20-storey building, to be constructed by Gulf Resources Development & Investment, will include 320,000 square feet of office space and be completed by 2017. The move aims to reduce the bank's operational costs and improve efficiency, with 4,000 workers expected to relocate to the new headquarters in 2018.

site_title: China's Q4 growth slows to 6.8%, weakest since 2009
summary: China's economy grew 6.8% in Q4, the weakest since 2009, matching expectations. The slowdown puts pressure on Beijing to roll out more support measures amid fears of a sharper slowdown. The cooling activity is attributed to weak exports, factory overcapacity, and high debt levels. Chinese leaders are struggling to put a floor under the economy, which has been a major driver of global growth in recent years.

site_title: Embattled China securities regulator grapples with exodus
summary: China's securities regulator is facing a talent shortage, with many employees leaving amid pressure from rapid market changes. Chairman Xiao Gang acknowledged the issue, stating measures must be taken to address it. The regulator's weaknesses were highlighted after Vice Chairman Li Jiange, a former CSRC vice chairman, blamed the talent shortage for the recent stock market turmoil. Xiao Gang proposed solutions, including targeted training and career development plans, to retain skilled professionals and prevent future crises.

site_title: Driverless cars will still need human supervision
summary: Self-driving cars will still require human supervision, despite advances in autonomous technology. Executives like Elon Musk and Carlos Ghosn claim significant progress, but experts say truly autonomous vehicles are at least a decade away. Cars with advanced capabilities can assist in tricky situations, but human intervention is necessary in complex or emergency situations, known as the "handoff problem." This raises concerns about safety and the potential for new hazards. Regulations and laws require human control, and manufacturers are working to address these limitations, but significant challenges remain.

site_title: DPP victory clear proof that KMT's pro-China policy has backfired
summary: Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) secured a landslide victory in the presidential and legislature elections, with President Tsai Ing-wen winning the presidency and the DPP controlling 68 seats in the 113-member legislature. The KMT's pro-China policy is seen as a contributing factor to the DPP's victory, and Beijing has expressed discomfort with the outcome. The Chinese government may attempt to form a united front with the KMT to squeeze the DPP administration, but this could exacerbate the economic issues faced by Taiwan under the KMT's policies.

site_title: Oil stumbles again as lifting of Iran sanctions adds to market woes
summary: Oil prices plummeted below $28 a barrel as sanctions against Iran were lifted, with Brent crude falling to its lowest since 2003. Analysts predict that Iran's oil exports will rise by 500,000 barrels per day, but the country's ability to return to the market in a big way is uncertain. A bottom in prices is not expected until investors decide enough is enough, with macro and fundamental indicators needing to turn positive. Iran plans to boost production and exports in a "managed way" to minimize the negative impact on prices, but a price war with Saudi Arabia could strain relations.

site_title: Addressing the issue of vacant houses in Japan
summary: A non-profit organization in Japan, Yame Akiya Saisei Switch, is reviving vacant houses in the city's historic district to regain community vigor and maintain the townscape. The organization sorts household items and finds new owners or renters for the vacant houses. In some cases, vacant houses are repurposed as community centers or gathering spaces. The initiative aims to turn vacant houses into opportunities for community development, with local governments and residents working together to create attractive communities. The number of vacant houses in Japan has been increasing, with over 1 million in the Kyushu region alone.

site_title: Bidders, please be rational: China land hunt sparks price surge
summary: Chinese developers are driving up land costs in Beijing and Shanghai amid rising home prices, with prime plots selling for nearly 50% higher than the asking price. The surge in land costs is squeezing profit margins, with some developers opting to buy land in second-tier cities instead. Experts warn that developers may face losses even if home prices continue to rise, as land costs outpace gains. The phenomenon is attributed to developers' anticipation of government easing measures to stimulate the property market.

site_title: More than 7,000 babies stillborn every day
summary: Over 7,200 babies are stillborn every day, resulting in 2.6 million stillbirths annually, with half occurring during delivery. The majority of stillbirths (98%) occur in low- and medium-income countries. Prolonged pregnancy, maternal health problems, and infections are leading causes, with sub-Saharan Africa having the highest rates. Despite the World Health Assembly's goal of 10 or fewer stillbirths per 1,000 total births by 2035, the rate of reduction is slower than for maternal deaths or deaths of children under five, with an average annual rate of two per cent.

site_title: Qualcomm in China JV to break Intel's hold on server chip sales
summary: Qualcomm is forming a joint venture with the government of Guizhou Province in China, taking a 45% stake, to develop server chips for the Chinese market. The move aims to break Intel's dominance in server chip sales. Qualcomm sees the China market as the second-largest server market by 2020 and a $15 billion opportunity by 2020, including $6 billion from China. The joint venture will use Qualcomm designs and technology, with plans to customize chips for local customer needs over time.

site_title: Malaysia bond yield at 2-year low amid selloff in stocks
summary: Malaysia's 5-year government bond yield reached a 2-year low at 3.43% amid a selloff in stocks. The benchmark equity gauge lost 1.3% in the past month. Demand for the securities strengthened, driving down the yield. The 10-year bond yield was also steady at 4.16%, the lowest since last November. This comes as investors seek higher returns in the region due to lower ratings.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Keppel Infra, M1, SingPost, Hyflux, TA Corp
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 1.17% increase in quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.68 Singapore cents, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust declared a DPU of 0.93 Singapore cents. M1's net profit for the fourth quarter slipped 2.1% to S$43.6 million. Singapore Post is gearing up for a global e-commerce reach, and Hyflux won a S$50.4 million contract in Saudi Arabia. TA Corporation Ltd secured a S$94 million contract for an educational institution building.

site_title: Rio Tinto to ship more iron ore in 2016 despite price rout
summary: Rio Tinto plans to increase iron ore production and shipments in 2016, defying a collapse in prices as the world's lowest cost producer. The company reported an 11% rise in annual iron ore shipments and expects to produce and ship 350 million tonnes in 2016. Despite a prolonged commodities slump, Rio Tinto aims to maintain or raise its dividend, with strong output and low costs driving the decision. The company has also cut costs, including freezing staff pay and slashing travel spending.

site_title: Battered gold miners mount charm offensive to sell executive pay
summary: Gold mining companies are making a charm offensive to win over investors and secure support for executive pay plans ahead of "say-on-pay" votes. After a 44% drop in gold prices and 70% slump in stock values since 2011, the industry is desperate to avoid a further exodus of sector-focused funds. Executives are offering performance goals to calculate pay and asking for input from investors, aiming to align compensation with shareholder returns. Several miners have already begun discussing pay plans with top shareholders, including Kinross Gold and Eldorado Gold, as they seek to maintain investor support and avoid a repeat of last year's proxy vote failures.

site_title: Wall St blowout, oil's slide hit ST Index
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.4% to 2,593 on Monday, following a Wall Street blowout and a slide in oil to US$28 per barrel. Banks were the worst hit, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC each dropping 2.8-2.1%. Keppel Corp rose 0.01% despite offshore and marine stocks facing pressure. The STI has now fallen for nine consecutive days, with overall turnover reaching S$1.2 billion. Analysts predict possible ECB action to ease monetary policy in March, but note a global corporate earnings recession as the key risk facing equities markets.

site_title: Glenn Frey, founding member of the Eagles, dead at 67
summary: Guitarist Glenn Frey, a founding member of the Eagles, has died at 67 due to complications from rheumatoid arthritis, acute ulcerative colitis, and pneumonia. Frey co-wrote many of the Eagles' seminal 1970s hits, including "Hotel California" and "Peaceful Easy Feeling." He was a key figure in the band, which blended rock with country music influences, and had a successful solo career before reuniting with the Eagles in 1994. Frey's death was confirmed by the band, and he is remembered by bandmate Don Henley as a "brother" and a key contributor to the Eagles' music.

site_title: Major currencies in limbo as China data looms large
summary: Major currencies, including the US dollar, yen, Australian dollar, euro, and sterling, are on hold as investors await Chinese economic data due later in the day, which is expected to show a slowdown in China's GDP growth. The yen has gained 2.5% this year, driven by weak confidence in global economic prospects and falls in the Chinese yuan. Currency speculators have become net yen buyers, and pressures on commodity-linked currencies remain strong due to oil prices hitting a 12-year low. The US economy's weak retail sales data has also raised concerns about global investor sentiment.

site_title: Oil prices reach new 12-year depths
summary: Oil prices plummeted to 12-year lows, with Brent crude falling below $28 a barrel, after the West lifted sanctions on Iran, allowing the country to export more crude. The move is expected to add half a million barrels of crude to saturated markets, exacerbating a global supply glut. However, Opec predicts a "rebalancing process" this year, suggesting that production from non-cartel competitors like the US may decline, potentially benefiting Opec's strategy to defend market share.

site_title: Iran boosts oil output, foreign firms keen to seal deals
summary: Iran has ordered a significant increase in oil output, boosting production by 500,000 barrels per day, amid the lifting of international sanctions. Foreign firms are eager to seal deals in various sectors, including energy, telecoms, and infrastructure, as the country emerges from years of isolation. However, US penalties remain in place, and most international banks are cautious to avoid violating trade sanctions. Despite these risks, some companies, such as Daimler and Herrenknecht, are already signing deals and investing in Iran. The country's nuclear deal with world powers has restored access to frozen assets and opened up business opportunities.

site_title: China seen posting slowest economic growth in 25 years as policy risks grow
summary: China is expected to report its weakest quarterly economic growth in nearly seven years, with a 6.8% growth rate in the fourth quarter, down from 6.9% in the third quarter. Full-year growth is seen at 6.9%, the poorest showing in a quarter of a century. Analysts expect further slowdown in 2016, with growth of 6.5%, driven by weak exports, factory overcapacity, and high debt levels. The government is struggling to manage the economy, which has been a major locomotive of global growth for over a decade, and is facing a policy dilemma as it transitions to a more market-oriented model.

site_title: Rising consumer debt in US will influence consumer discretionary stocks
summary: US consumer debt is rising, with total debt reaching $12 trillion at the end of the third quarter, after contracting for years. This increase may impact consumer discretionary stocks, which have been strong performers in recent years. Despite rising debt, some analysts predict moderate growth in consumer spending, citing low unemployment rates, modest wage growth, and plummeting energy prices. However, concerns remain, including defaults on various types of consumer loans and the ease of obtaining high-interest car loans.

site_title: Wall St: Fundamentals could resurface after wrenching selloff
summary: Wall Street experienced a dramatic selloff over the past two weeks, with the S&P 500 briefly reaching levels not seen in over a year. The decline, reminiscent of the Great Recession, may signal a capitulation-type blowout that gives fundamentals the upper hand. US markets were closed on Monday for the Martin Luther King Jr holiday, while international stocks and oil prices continued to fall. Economists expect the US economy to avoid a recession, and a repricing in stocks could help the market shift back to fundamentals.

site_title: Marketing in the moments, to reach customers online
summary: Companies are shifting their advertising focus to "moments" - brief online instances, such as 10-second Snapchat videos or Twitter Moments, where consumers are more receptive to messages. Targeting people based on their mobile device usage at a particular time can increase ad effectiveness. Examples include Campari America's offer of $5 off Lyft for users checking sports scores at a bar and Google's local inventory ads for coffee near me searches. The goal is to reach consumers at key junctures, such as when they're searching for information or looking for a product, rather than relying on traditional reach and frequency.

site_title: Tanker operators first to gain from Iran's re-entry
summary: The lifting of sanctions against Iran is expected to benefit the maritime sector, particularly tanker operators, as they will gain access to new charter opportunities. Tanker operators are expected to be the first beneficiaries, with charter rates already reaching US$100,000. Offshore marine players, such as MMO and supply of oilfield services, will also see demand pick up. However, some experts, like Fazel A. Fazelboy, warn that the upswing in the tanker segment is unlikely to last beyond two more quarters due to a developing global supply glut.

site_title: Koyo nosedives after SGX's trading caution
summary: Shares of Koyo International plummeted 84% to S$0.056 in heavy trading volume after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) warned investors to be cautious due to unusual trading activity. The exchange found that a small group of individuals was responsible for 60% of the trading volume, with at least half of these trades being self trades. Koyo attributed the high volume to discussions on potential projects, but the SGX remains skeptical. This marks the first "Trade with Caution" warning issued by the exchange since it enhanced its warnings.

site_title: When creative types meet business-school types ...
summary: Disney South-east Asia collaborated with Insead MBA students and Art Center College of Design students to develop innovative product, service, or experience concepts for expansion into new Asian markets. The interdisciplinary teams worked in a unique, child-like creative environment and were given just four weeks to come up with ideas. Disney emphasized the importance of localization, customizing products to values relevant to each Asian market. The teams simplified their ideas through iteration, with the simplest concept ultimately chosen by Disney. The collaboration demonstrated the value of integrating creative and business thinking to address complex business problems.

site_title: China's strategists bracing for deeper bear market
summary: China's stock market is expected to continue its bear market trend, with strategists predicting a 14% drop to 2,500 for the Shanghai Composite Index. Analysts from Bocom International Holdings Co and Wells Fargo Funds Management forecast further selling pressure, with some predicting a 10% drop. The government's failure to communicate a clear strategy has contributed to the market's volatility, with President Xi Jinping facing a setback in his efforts to shore up growth and control globalization.

site_title: Crane rental company MS Holdings to enter property development in Indonesia
summary: Crane rental company MS Holdings has entered into a binding conditional term sheet agreement with ACT Holdings for a potential joint venture in property development in western Jakarta, Indonesia. MS Holdings will acquire a 31.25% stake in a JV company, which will raise its interest in a residential project to 80% from 30%. The transaction is subject to a definitive agreement and shareholder approval, with sales and marketing of the property project expected to commence in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: Thailand's Central Group keen to bid for Casino's Thai, Vietnam stores
summary: Thailand's Central Group is considering bidding for Casino's Thai and Vietnam stores, which would give the country's largest retailer control of a business it already partly owns. Central Group's deputy CEO, Prin Chirathivat, expressed interest in both Big C in Thailand and Vietnam, citing growth potential in South-east Asia. The acquisition would be Central Group's second-largest inbound deal, following a 2013 purchase of Siam Makro Pcl. Casino's decision to sell the Thai unit comes after a report that criticized the firm's leverage, prompting a significant slide in its stock.

site_title: Old Mutual Global Investors to open S'pore office (Amended)
summary: Old Mutual Global Investors plans to establish a sales office in Singapore to capitalize on demand for its "absolute return" mutual funds amid global market volatility. The firm manages $250 million in assets under management for Singapore clients and aims to double that to $500 million in three years. The new office, expected to open by the end of June 2016, will serve as a launchpad for expansion across South-east Asia, with a focus on marketing products such as its global equities fund.

site_title: China's ban on new coal mines unlikely to impact surplus capacity
summary: China's ban on new coal mines for three years aims to reduce pollution and meet climate change goals, but it is unlikely to significantly impact the country's vast existing production capacity, estimated at around 2 billion tonnes per year. Despite the ban, coal prices have lost a third last year, and many mines operate below capacity, with some producing as much as 5.7 billion tonnes. The move has had limited market impact, with Chinese coal companies still reporting significant losses.

site_title: Sticky wage growth may force BOJ to unleash further easing
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) signaled disappointment over slow wage growth in Japan, citing falling business confidence and company reluctance to raise pay. The central bank may opt for further monetary easing to boost corporate confidence and counter deflation. Despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's calls for companies to boost wage payouts, momentum to raise salaries has failed to gain steam. Analysts predict the BOJ may unveil a third round of quantitative easing at its next meeting to re-establish its proactive leadership and address deflationary threats.

site_title: China to start reserve ratio for offshore banks' domestic deposits
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), will start implementing a reserve requirement ratio (RRR) on offshore banks' domestic deposits, effective January 25, in an attempt to stem yuan speculation and manage cross-border money flow. The move aims to regulate cross-border yuan fund flows and help offshore financial institutions better manage their yuan liquidity. However, analysts are uncertain about the policy intentions, with some speculating that the announcement may be a symbolic warning to banks.

site_title: Keppel Reit gearing drops in Q4, DPU up
summary: Keppel Reit, a Singapore-based office landlord, posted a higher distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, rising to 1.68 Singapore cents. The Reit's gearing dropped to 39.3% due to an October 2015 sale of perpetual bonds and revaluation gains. CEO Ng Hsueh Ling stated the Reit is "comfortable" with its gearing level and has no immediate plans to raise more cash to pare down debt. Net property income for Q4 rose 1.5% to S$34.77 million, driven by higher property income from Singapore and Australia.

site_title: A towering debt mountain looms behind China's market gyrations
summary: China's economic growth is constrained by a massive credit bubble of $28 trillion, fueled by investment and exports, as the government struggles to balance control and reform. The benchmark CSI 300 Index has fallen 14% in 2016, and pressure on the yuan continues, threatening to undermine investor confidence. China's debt problems, which have ballooned to 282% of GDP, are a major concern, and the government faces a high-wire act in trying to keep the economy growing rapidly without resorting to more debt. Analysts warn that China is nowhere close to reining in its debt problems.

site_title: US$ gains ground as stock markets steady
summary: The US dollar gained ground against the euro and Swiss franc, reaching a 2.5% gain against the euro and a 0.6% gain against the franc. The yuan also rose, sending the dollar/yuan rate back below 6.60. The Australian dollar and other commodity currencies also gained, while the euro stabilized despite concerns over Chinese markets. Investors remain skeptical about a sustained improvement in risk appetite, citing a sell-off in global equities in January.

site_title: Netflix's expansion move attracts some 'most unlikely' customers
summary: Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings announced the expansion of his video-streaming service to 190 countries, including Reunion Island, a small French-governed island off Madagascar. The company aims to offer local-language content and subtitles in new languages to cater to non-English speakers. Hastings emphasized that winning a few hours of people's time, rather than their viewing habits, is key to success. Despite challenges from local rivals and high subscription prices, Hastings remains optimistic about the company's global ambitions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezra Holdings reported a net loss of US$55.3 million for Q1FY16, below expectations, due to poor subsea fleet utilisation. Analysts downgrade Ezra to "Hold" citing weak oil price outlook and potential heavy losses. In contrast, Keppel DC Reit is upgraded to "Buy" with a target price of S$1.24. Singtel announces a partnership with Netflix, offering free streaming to new and re-contract subscribers, but expects pay-TV cannibalisation to impact earnings. Meanwhile, Singapore banks have fallen 11% YTD on concerns over earnings risks, with DBS seen as a preferred pick.

site_title: AIIB: A red herring for China's true ambitions on the global financial stage?
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) was launched in 2014 as a China-led initiative to secure greater influence in global economic affairs, following the US Congress' refusal to reform the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and allow China a larger voice. The AIIB's success led to China's increased presence in the IMF, World Bank, and Asian Development Bank. The bank's creation has been likened to Rupert Murdoch's Wapping printing plant, a ruse to gain control over the printing industry. Some speculate that the AIIB may be a cover for China's true ambitions to secure greater influence in global economic institutions, while others believe it may be a genuine effort to promote infrastructure development in Asia.

site_title: China to invest 800b yuan in railway network in 2016: report
summary: China plans to invest 800 billion yuan in its railway network in 2016, aiming to boost passenger traffic by 10% and freight volume by 2%. This investment follows 823.8 billion yuan spent in 2015, with 9,531 km of new lines built, including 3,306 km of high-speed rail. China Railway aims to win more overseas contracts, including the Moscow-Kazan and Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail projects.

site_title: IDA set to call for open standard embedded SIMs trial
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) plans to issue a request for proposal (RFP) to conduct a trial on over-the-air (OTA) mobile subscription management for embedded SIMs (eSIMs) in Internet of Things (IOT) devices. The trial, in partnership with the PUB, aims to explore the adoption of an open GSMA standard to enable eSIM chips to switch between different mobile network operators. The goal is to create a more competitive environment for the deployment of M2M devices, lowering costs and increasing IOT adoption, particularly for applications like smart water and energy management.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SingHaiyi Group's application to sell City Suites has been rejected, terminating its memorandum of understanding with ACG Construction. CosmoSteel Holdings expects to record a loss in Q1 2016 due to lower revenue. Sunpower Group won a centralised steam BOT project in Jiangsu province with a total investment of S$20.8 million. Mercator Lines has been placed under judicial management after HSH Nordbank AG filed an application. Meanwhile, OCBC appointed Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing Helen Wong.

site_title: Tennis authorities ignored match-fixing, say reports
summary: Reports by BBC and BuzzFeed News claim tennis authorities ignored match-fixing allegations against 16 top-50 players over the past decade. The allegations, made public at the Australian Open, suggest the Tennis Integrity Unit (TIU) failed to act on suspicions of match-fixing, despite flagging 16 players. The TIU and ATP officials deny the allegations, stating they are investigating new information and have robust anti-corruption systems in place.

site_title: Oil and China exposures hurting S'pore banks
summary: Singapore banks' shares have fallen 12-15% since January 1 due to concerns over oil and gas exposure and China's economic slowdown. Analysts warn of more bad loans from the oil and gas sector, but say this should not cause alarm. OCBC and UOB reported higher non-performing loans in the third quarter, while DBS's NPL ratio remained unchanged. Despite concerns, DBS is shifting focus to trade finance and expects an even mix in revenue contribution by 2020. Analysts predict a healthy gain for Singapore lenders from recent yuan depreciation against the US dollar.

site_title: Swiss franc crisis: industry better prepared one year on
summary: The Swiss franc crisis, which occurred one year ago, could potentially return, with some analysts warning of sharp volatility. The Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap the minimum exchange rate of 1.20 francs against the euro in January 2015 led to a 30% increase in the franc's value, causing market turmoil. While the franc has since stabilized, traders are building up "short positions" against its value, raising concerns. However, some experts believe the risk of another crisis has decreased, and the industry has implemented risk control measures, including increased margin requirements.

site_title: Indebted Chinese companies increase pressures on govt
summary: Heavily indebted Chinese companies, such as Sainty Marine Corp, are putting pressure on the government due to a cash crunch caused by China's slowing growth to 7%. The companies, which borrowed heavily during the good years, are struggling to pay off debts as demand for commodities and ship prices have dropped. Government regulators are investigating the accuracy of financial reports and freezing bank accounts, while the central bank has increased lending at the fastest pace since June. The corporate crunch is clouding the government's efforts to manage the economy, and concerns about the direction of the Chinese economy are weighing on global investors.

site_title: Noble needs more than a brave face
summary: Noble Group's future remains uncertain as a year after its accounting practices came under scrutiny, the commodity trader's business model is facing significant challenges. Despite Fitch's affirmation of its investment-grade ratings, Noble's shares continue to slide, falling 6% following the downgrade by Standard & Poor's and Moody's to junk status. The group's persistent negative cash flow and low profitability have raised concerns, with investors and rating agencies questioning its ability to thrive in the current commodity rout.

site_title: IDA, MDA restructuring to create new entities (Amended)
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) and the Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) will be restructured into new entities, IMDA (Infocomm Media Development Authority of Singapore) and the Government Technology Organisation (GTO). The government aims to create a converged regulatory framework for the ICT and media sectors. IMDA will oversee regulatory powers, while GTO will develop infrastructure and nurture talent for the Smart Nation initiative. The restructuring is expected to be completed by April 1 and will pave the way for the implementation of the Infocomm Media 2025 plan.

site_title: External woes drive inflation expectations to new low in December: survey
summary: Singaporean households expect inflation to fall to 2.74% and 2.85% for the year ahead, the lowest levels ever recorded since the survey's inception in 2011. The decline is attributed to external challenges such as the slowdown of BRICS countries and low oil prices. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and transportation costs, is also expected to drop to 2.85%. This reflects a decrease in consumer sentiment and companies' concerns about new orders and expansion.

site_title: YuuZoo buys 30% of Infocomm Asia Holdings for S$2.39m
summary: YuuZoo acquired 30% of Infocomm Asia Holdings (IAH) for S$2.39 million, issuing 15 million new shares at S$0.159 apiece. The deal allows YuuZoo to tap IAH's 37 million registered gamers and S$30 million+ game business. The partial acquisition is seen as a cost-effective alternative to a full acquisition, with YuuZoo chairman Thomas Zilliacus citing the benefits of combining their social e-commerce strategies.

site_title: Fake emissions report data undermines China's pollution fight
summary: China's coal-fired power firms have been misreporting emissions data, undermining the country's efforts to reduce pollution. The practice, which has been ongoing since 2013, has cost power producers millions of yuan in fines and subsidies. Despite government policies and laws aimed at curbing pollution, the power sector remains a "weak link" in China's environmental efforts. The government has set up continuous emissions monitoring systems, but critics say they can be manipulated and only cover state-owned firms.

site_title: Good to have more data-driven policies: Swee Keat
summary: Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a more data-driven approach to policymaking in Singapore, citing the benefits of increased transparency and public access to information. While the government will provide more data in the future, Heng stressed the importance of the private sector in analyzing and utilizing this data. He also expressed concerns about the polarization of politics and the importance of maintaining a serious and purposeful political environment, advising against following the US model.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: OCBC Bank announced the appointment of Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, succeeding Helen Wong who will retire. The bank's earnings report is not mentioned in this article. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China's steel firms lost 53.1b yuan from January to November last year
summary: China's steel firms lost 53.1 billion yuan (S$11.6 billion) from January to November last year due to falling prices and overcapacity. The country's steel sector, responsible for half of global output, has been impacted by China's economic slowdown, with prices now at multi-decade lows. Over 50% of China's steel capacity is idle, and a mechanism for loss-making enterprises to exit the market has not been established, according to the China Iron and Steel Association.

site_title: Analysts expect commodity collapse to continue
summary: Hedge funds have increased their combined net bearish position across 18 raw materials to the largest ever, doubling negative bets in two weeks. The Bloomberg Commodity Index fell 4.2% last week, touching its lowest level since 1991. Analysts attribute the slump to supply gluts and an anaemic global economy outlook. Goldman Sachs predicts the prolonged slump will spur supply cuts, but prices won't rebound until later this year, with a strong US dollar and interest rate increases eroding the appeal of raw materials.

site_title: Improving EMU's incomplete architecture
summary: The European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) faces ongoing issues, including low inflation, weak nominal demand, and high unemployment. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing has been extended, but its effectiveness is debated. The EU has proposed measures to promote harmonized policies, including technical assistance and a European deposit guarantee scheme. A wider or deeper Europe is being explored, with a banking union, fiscal union, and capital markets union being considered. However, the key challenge remains achieving a balance between national responsibility and European solidarity to address the root causes of the crisis.

site_title: Materials sector in positive territory at start of 2016
summary: The materials sector in Singapore saw a 3.3% gain over the first two weeks of 2016, with the top 10 largest stocks averaging a 0.3% gain. The sector finished 2015 with a 3.5% loss. Gains were led by XinRen Aluminum Holdings and Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings, while Midas Holdings declined 8.6%. The sector's average price-earnings ratio was 41.3, and its indicative dividend yield was 3.2%.

site_title: Young people fear losing their jobs to robots, survey finds
summary: A survey of 9,000 16- to 25-year-olds in nine countries found that four out of 10 young people believe machines will be able to do their jobs within a decade. Nearly half of young workers said their education did not prepare them for their jobs, highlighting a global skills gap. The survey also showed that 80% of young people globally need to learn new skills due to rapid technology change. Infosys CEO Vishal Sikka emphasized the need for an education system that focuses on exploring new possibilities, rather than just building on existing knowledge.

site_title: Big banks lose millions in dealings with bond trader with a bad record
summary: Big banks, including BNP Paribas and Nomura Holdings, have suffered losses of approximately £120 million (S$247.4 million) due to their dealings with Invexstar Capital Management, a bond-trading firm that collapsed last year. The losses, estimated at £97.6 million in July and £120 million in October, raise questions over the banks' risk management practices. The firm's manager, Alberto Statti, had a history of failed trading ventures, including a previous firm that went bankrupt in 2008 with losses of £54 million.

site_title: Simon Cheong sells GCB at King Albert Park for S$25m
summary: Singapore developer Simon Cheong sold a two-storey Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in King Albert Park for S$25 million, translating to S$1,493 per square foot. The buyer, Fang Koh Look, founder of Absolute Kinetics Consultancy, is expected to occupy the property once the existing lease ends. Meanwhile, Soilbuild Group Holdings purchased an old bungalow along Wilkinson Road for S$19.28 million, with plans to redevelop the site into two new bungalows, marking the company's first landed housing project in over two decades.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Richest 1% own more than the rest of us: Oxfam
summary: The richest 1% of the world's population now own more than the rest of the world combined, according to Oxfam's report "An Economy for the 1%". The richest 62 individuals hold as much wealth as the poorest half of the world's population, up from 388 five years ago. The report highlights the growing inequality, particularly among women, and calls for an end to tax havens to tackle poverty and inequality. World leaders will discuss these issues at the upcoming World Economic Forum in Davos.

site_title: Australia's Wesfarmers eyes UK market with Homebase acquisition
summary: Wesfarmers Ltd is set to acquire Homebase in the UK for £340 million (S$700 million) to expand its home improvements business. The acquisition will give Wesfarmers 265 UK stores with £1.46 billion in revenue. The deal is part of a £500 million investment plan to establish Bunnings in the UK and Ireland over three to five years. The purchase is expected to have an "immaterial effect" on Wesfarmers' earnings per share initially and add to profits from the third year following the acquisition.

site_title: Malaysia should assume worst case for oil, says analyst
summary: Malaysia is advised to assume the worst-case scenario for oil prices, potentially as low as US$10 per barrel, by analyst Suresh Ramanathan. This conservative estimate could reduce the country's oil revenue by more than RM30 billion (S$9.8 billion). The suggestion comes as oil prices have fallen to a 12-year low, driven by Iran's re-entry into the market. The Malaysian government is set to announce a revised budget on January 28, which will take into account the current climate, including further oil price weakness and a slowing Chinese economy.

site_title: SingPost combines e-commerce division with new acquisitions
summary: SingPost has formed a new business unit, SP Commerce, by combining its existing e-commerce division with US e-commerce provider TradeGlobal and logistics firm Jagged Peak. Marcelo Wesseler, CEO of SingPost's e-commerce arm, will lead SP Commerce. The new unit offers services spanning webstore development, order picking, cross-border commerce, and customer care, with a gross merchandise value of US$3 billion annually. The combination aims to expand SingPost's global reach, particularly in the US market, and help Asian brands enter the US.

site_title: Jakarta attack a sign of things to come
summary: A terrorist attack in Jakarta, Indonesia, claimed by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) has failed to achieve its objectives, killing only a few civilians. The attack, which was botched and poorly planned, highlights the renewed threat of a relentless religious insurgency in the region. Indonesia has demonstrated its ability to act against terror, with the government showing support for military action against co-religionists. The attack also underscores the existential difficulty of dealing with individuals driven by a death-wish and the need for regional cooperation to counter the growing threat of ISIS in South-east Asia.

site_title: CIMB cuts jobs in Hong Kong equities, investment bank unit
summary: CIMB Group Holdings, Malaysia's second-largest bank, has cut 32 jobs in its Hong Kong investment banking and equities business due to deteriorating market conditions. The job cuts, which account for nearly a quarter of CIMB's Hong Kong workforce, were announced as the bank struggles to manage costs. The move follows similar job cuts by other investment banks in Asia, such as Barclays, amid slowing growth in China's economy and market volatility. The bank's chief executive, Zafrul Aziz, stated that CIMB must remain focused to ensure its relevance to clients.

site_title: China aims for balance in Xi's trip to Middle East
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to visit Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Egypt, aiming to maintain a balanced stance in the Middle East amidst escalating tensions between the two regional powers. The trip, shrouded in secrecy, comes as China seeks to expand its influence in the region, particularly in Syria and Iran. Beijing has close ties with Iran, its top oil client, and is exploring cooperation in infrastructure, energy, and trade under its "one belt, one road" strategy. China's Vice-Foreign Minister Zhang Ming emphasized the importance of regional stability and cooperation in the fight against terrorism.

site_title: GS Holdings steady in debut trading
summary: GS Holdings, a Singapore-based company offering centralized dishwashing facilities, debuted on the Catalist exchange, holding above its initial public offering placement price of 25 cents. The stock opened at 28 cents and closed at 26 cents, with 2.85 million shares traded. Trading volume was small, reflecting muted interest. GS Holdings' debut mirrors that of Eindec Corporation, which also listed without a retail tranche. The company's executive chairman and CEO, Pang Pok, expressed optimism about the IPO's success, citing a strong business model and market opportunities.

site_title: December NODX down 7.2% on weak exports to China, S Korea, Taiwan
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 7.2% year-on-year in December, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 4.4% contraction. The decline was led by a 10.3% drop in non-electronics exports, mainly due to the impact of low oil prices. Economists expect continued weakness in the months ahead, with some predicting a downward revision in GDP growth for Q4 2015. The Singapore dollar's resilience against major export markets' currencies is also a concern, with some economists warning of a potential downward revision in GDP growth and a decrease in the value of the Singapore dollar.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SPH Media Fund invests in Malaysian lorry and van booking startup
summary: SPH Media Fund has invested US$1.5 million in Malaysian lorry and van booking startup TheLorry, marking its first investment in a Malaysia startup and its second investment in 2016. The funding round, led by Elixir Capital, will help TheLorry strengthen its presence and expand regionally. The startup plans to launch its Singapore operations and introduce a new service allowing customers to pay for only the items they wish to send, rather than the whole vehicle. TheLorry's focus on large commercial vehicles and B2B model were key factors in attracting the investment.

site_title: M1's Q4 earnings dip 2.1% to S$43.6m
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications operator, reported a 2.1% drop in Q4 net profit to S$43.6 million, driven by an 11.1% decline in operating revenue. Handset sales dropped 26.9% to S$99 million, while service revenue remained marginally down. Despite this, mobile data usage continued to grow, accounting for 46.3% of service revenue. M1 attributed the decline to the entry of OTT content providers, which may further level the playing field. The company expects stable performance for 2016.

site_title: Singapore to chair Asean in 2018
summary: Singapore will chair the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) in 2018, marking the first time it has led the 10-member bloc since 2007. Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan announced that Singapore will promote Asean identity and create opportunities for Singaporeans abroad. The country will also take advantage of initiatives such as the Youth Model Asean Conference to educate and engage younger Singaporeans. Asean remains a cornerstone of Singapore's foreign policy, and the government will work to enhance Asean integration and deepen its relations with external partners.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Regional integration: Opportunities and challenges of the AEC
summary: The Asean Economic Community (AEC) aims to promote freer trade and capital movement among its 10 member countries, eliminating tariff barriers and phasing out non-tariff barriers. This will benefit consumer and B2B businesses, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), who will gain access to new markets, resources, and funding. However, SMEs will also face increased competition, especially from foreign counterparts, and may need to adapt to new business models and strategies. To succeed, SMEs must be prepared to invest in regional strategies, including mergers and acquisitions, and be open to change and new opportunities.

site_title: RBI deploys US$2.8b in reserves to strengthen rupee defence
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has deployed $2.8 billion from its reserves to strengthen the rupee, which has fallen to its lowest level since September 2013. RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan aims to anchor the rupee around 65 per US dollar and may spend up to $20 billion in 2016 to achieve this goal. Despite a global sell-off triggered by China's market turmoil, the rupee is expected to hold steady this quarter, with a 36% chance of breaching its record low of 68.845 per US dollar by March 31.

site_title: Is this a bad time to meet?
summary: Leaders from over 2,500 organizations are gathering in Davos for the World Economic Forum, amid concerns about rising geopolitical risks and a 25-year high in global instability. The US-led international order faces challenges from Russia's annexation of Crimea, international terrorism, and the Israeli-Palestinian peace process collapse. However, the post-Cold War world also offers opportunities, including a nuclear deal with Iran and a global climate change agreement in Paris. The rise of China as the world's largest economy poses a significant game-changer, with potential for either cooperation or increased tension with the US.

site_title: France's Hollande says job creation drive to cost 2 bln eur
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced a 2 billion euro job creation drive, which will be financed by state savings, not new taxes. The measures include subsidies for firms that hire. The cost of the initiative will be borne by the state.

site_title: UK financial watchdog girds itself for lion's den
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is facing criticism for scrapping a review into banking culture, which has led to billions in fines for customer abuse and market rigging. The review's cancellation has sparked concerns about the FCA's independence and ability to regulate the sector. The decision has been attributed to a shift in regulatory mood, with policymakers focusing on economic growth rather than making the financial system more resilient. The FCA's acting CEO, Tracey McDermott, will face questioning from lawmakers about the decision, which has been described as "curious" and a failure to communicate effectively.

site_title: Stop China's market manipulations
summary: China's opaque economic interventions in its stock market and currency have caused billions of dollars in losses for investors worldwide, contradicting the principles of global financial markets. The country's regulators, who believe they can intervene without explanation, are seen as a threat to market stability. The US government is urged to take a more public stance against China's policies, labeling it a currency manipulator and advocating for greater transparency in its economic management. The ongoing tit-for-tat trade tensions between the US and China pose a risk to the global economy, and the international community needs to address China's interventionism more forcefully.

site_title: Acquisitions boost Keppel Infrastructure's Q3 performance
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a 33.8% increase in revenue to S$160.5 million for its third quarter, with net profit returning to the black at S$8.67 million. The trust's assets grew to S$4.1 billion, but liabilities also rose. The trust attributed the boost to acquisitions completed in mid-2015, despite a higher negative "commercial risk sharing mechanism" adjustment and the outage of the Basslink electricity link. The trust's unit City Gas' performance may fluctuate, while the upgrade to Senoko WTE plant is expected to be completed in Q3 2016.

site_title: WhatsApp to drop subscription fees, no plans to launch ads
summary: WhatsApp will drop annual subscription fees, eliminating the 99 US cent charge, after waiving it for the first year. The service, with 900 million users, will instead focus on testing tools to allow users to communicate directly with businesses and organizations via the app. WhatsApp has no plans to launch third-party advertising to generate revenue.

site_title: China to lend Egypt central bank US$1b during president's visit: ambassador
summary: China is expected to lend Egypt's central bank $1 billion to help shore up its foreign reserves, during a visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping this week. This move aims to support Egypt's efforts to combat a dollar shortage, which has been exacerbated by rules aimed at reducing imports. China has also agreed to sign a $700 million credit line and a $100 million loan with Egyptian banks to finance projects. The move comes as Egypt's foreign reserves have fallen to $16.445 billion, down from $36 billion before the 2011 uprising.

site_title: China TV station replaces its weathergirl with a 'chatbot'
summary: China's Dragon TV has introduced a chatbot named Xiaoice as its new weather forecast meteorologist, replacing a human with a "very hard-working" and efficient robot. Xiaoice, created by Microsoft's AI team, delivers forecasts with a female voice and adds a personal touch, including reminders to bundle up or exercise in bad weather. While the initial ratings boost was positive, it hasn't proven to be more popular than human forecasters, and Xiaoice is not expected to replace human anchors in the near term.

site_title: Shell ditches major Abu Dhabi gas field project
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has decided to exit its multi-billion-dollar plan to develop the Bab sour gas field in Abu Dhabi, citing technical challenges and high costs due to the oil-market downturn. Shell won a 40% stake in the 30-year venture in 2013 but will now stop further joint work with Abu Dhabi National Oil Co. The move is seen as a commercial decision, with the cost of gas and LNG dropping more than 50% since the project's inception.

site_title: BOJ offers gloomy view on wages, market rout clouds outlook
summary: The Bank of Japan expressed disappointment with slow wage growth, despite a tightening job market, and hinted at potential stimulus expansion if wage hikes are further delayed. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda maintained a positive view on the economy, while a quarterly report highlighted regional firms' caution in raising salaries. The report noted that momentum towards wage increases has failed to gain steam, highlighting the challenges the BOJ faces in eradicating Japan's deflationary mindset.

site_title: US: Markets closed for Martin Luther King Jr Day
summary: US stock markets are closed on Monday for Martin Luther King Jr Day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-China trade tensions. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally, driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. The STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Sunpower wins centralised steam project worth 95m yuan
summary: SunPower Group, a China-based heat transfer technology company, has won a 95 million yuan (S$20.8 million) centralized steam project in Jiangsu province's Lianshui Economic Development Zone. The project, set to begin operation in 2016, will provide steam to over 20 companies, replacing individual coal-fired boilers that are highly energy inefficient and polluting. SunPower will hold a 95% equity stake in the joint-venture agreement.

site_title: Judicial manager appointed for Mercator Lines
summary: A judicial manager, Yit Chee Wah, has been appointed for Singapore-based dry bulk shipping company Mercator Lines following a court order. The move comes after the company's creditor, HSH Nordbank AG, filed an application to the Singapore High Court for judicial management. Three non-executive directors have also resigned ahead of a scheduled court hearing. The judicial manager aims to preserve the value of Mercator Lines' assets for its creditors.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Volkswagen faces shareholder claims over emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen faces a lawsuit by dozens of institutional investors and thousands of private investors in a German court, seeking hundreds of millions of euros in damages due to the company's emissions test cheating scandal. The shareholders claim VW was aware of its violation of diesel emissions rules before its first statement and should have informed the public earlier. The lawsuit is part of a growing legal onslaught on the company, with US owners of affected vehicles and the US Justice Department also seeking billions of dollars in damages.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.91 points to close at 1,622.64 on Monday, with 2.13 billion lots valued at RM1.87 billion traded. The market saw 190 gains and 776 losses. This report is not related to Malaysia's stock performance.

site_title: Oil producing nations to sell US$240b assets this year: JP Morgan
summary: Oil-producing nations plan to sell $240 billion in international assets this year to stabilize their budgets due to the slump in oil prices. They will sell US$110 billion in bonds and US$75 billion in equity investments, and run down their foreign exchange reserves and Sovereign Wealth Fund holdings. The move aims to cover a current account shortfall of $260 billion. The lower oil price has led to a decline in oil revenues, with Saudi Arabia facing a potential budget deficit of 20% of its GDP.

site_title: Dalian Wanda chairman says plans IPO for Internet finance unit
summary: Dalian Wanda Group, China's largest conglomerate, plans an initial public offering (IPO) for its Internet finance business, capitalizing on its vast customer base from its shopping malls. Chairman Wang Jianlin aims to leverage this growth through IPOs of other units, including film, tourism, and sports businesses. The company will focus on tier 1 cities due to high land costs and continue to invest in third-tier cities. No timeline for the IPOs was given.

site_title: CosmoSteel expects loss in Q1 2016
summary: CosmoSteel Holdings expects a loss for Q1 2016 due to sluggish market conditions resulting in lower revenue, which cannot cover fixed operating costs. The company will announce its unaudited financial results on or before February 12. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution when dealing with their shares and seek professional advice if unsure.

site_title: Tata Steel to cut 1,050 more jobs in Britain
summary: Tata Steel is cutting 1,050 more jobs in Britain, primarily at its Port Talbot site in Wales and other plants, due to falling European steel prices caused by cheap imports from China. The company, which employs 4,000 people at Port Talbot, blames China for the market conditions and calls for the European Union to tackle unfair imports. This is the latest in a series of job cuts in the British steel industry, which is facing a crisis caused by high energy costs and cheap Chinese imports.

site_title: Burned in December, markets see slim chance of ECB action this week
summary: Financial markets have priced in a slim chance of the European Central Bank (ECB) cutting interest rates this week, despite low oil prices and long-term inflation expectations at their lowest in three months. The ECB's December meeting saw a 10 basis point cut in the deposit rate and extended asset purchases by six months. However, markets expect a cautious approach, with a less than 10% chance of further rate cuts in January, rising to 50% in March and 100% by mid-year.

site_title: Strong China property data masks big problem: unsold homes
summary: China's new home prices rose 7.7% year-over-year in December, offering some relief to the economy, which faces its slowest growth in a quarter century. However, the data masks the country's massive property problem, with 13 million unsold apartments in smaller cities. Analysts predict it will take four to five years to digest the inventory, and property investment is expected to decline this year, weighing on GDP. The economy's growth is forecast to slow further in 2016, with some glimmers of hope in credit expansion and a decline in exports.

site_title: SingPost combines e-commerce businesses to form new unit
summary: SingPost combines its e-commerce division with US companies TradeGlobal and Jagged Peak to form SP Commerce, a new business unit offering services spanning webstore development, logistics, and marketing. Marcelo Wesseler, CEO of SingPost's e-commerce arm, will lead the new unit. The combined gross merchandise value is US$3 billion annually, with the three units complementing each other. The move aims to expand into new markets, particularly the US, and provide services to Asian brands entering the US market, with seamless expansion to Asia-Pacific and China.

site_title: Offshore yuan gains as China steps up defense of its currency
summary: China's central bank has implemented reserve-requirement ratios on yuan deposited onshore by overseas financial institutions, starting January 25, to curb bearish bets on the exchange rate. The move locks up at least $48.2 billion in funds, aiming to reduce liquidity and prevent speculators from shorting the yuan. The offshore yuan rose 0.38% to 6.5888 a dollar, while the onshore yuan strengthened 0.08% to 6.5790. The decision aims to maintain a stable exchange rate, amid slowing economic growth and capital outflows.

site_title: Opec sees oil price collapse hurting rival output in 2016
summary: OPEC forecast that oil supply from non-member countries will decline by 660,000 barrels per day in 2016, mainly due to the collapse in prices. This decline is led by the United States, and OPEC's members also reduced oil production in December, reducing excess supply in the market. Production in Indonesia, a new OPEC member, fell by 210,000 barrels per day to 32.18 million barrels per day. The decline is expected to boost OPEC's oil production, potentially reducing the need for crude from non-OPEC countries.

site_title: Global economy worries prompt staffing group Adecco to lower sights
summary: Global staffing group Adecco lowered its profitability expectations due to wariness about the sluggish global economic backdrop, particularly in Europe. The company expects an average margin target of 4.5-5.0% for 2016-2020, down from 5.2% in 2015. Despite this, Adecco aims to grow revenues organically "at least in line with main peers" and deliver operating cash flow conversion of around 90% during the period. The company's shares have dropped 16% since early December.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB cuts jobs in Hong Kong equities, investment bank unit
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings has cut 32 jobs in its Hong Kong investment banking and equities business, accounting for nearly a quarter of its Hong Kong workforce. The move is part of the bank's efforts to manage costs amid deteriorating market conditions. CIMB's Hong Kong expansion, which began in 2012, has failed to generate sufficient revenue. The job cuts follow similar reductions at other investment banks, including Barclays, and come as the bank faces difficult markets and a need to remain relevant to clients.

site_title: SingHaiyi's bid to sell City Suites project rejected
summary: SingHaiyi Group's bid to sell its City Suites project was rejected by the Controller of Residential Property. The proposed sale, valued at S$16.38 million, was to be made to Ang Cheng Guan Construction. The decision led to the termination of a memorandum of understanding between SingHaiyi and ACG Construction. The sale progress had been slow, with only about 10% sold since the project launched in 2013. As a result, the proposed disposal is aborted.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: A business in Kabul thrives amid heaps of used clothes
summary: HAJJI Ramazan, a 58-year-old entrepreneur, has built a successful business in Kabul's Chindawul market by importing used clothes from Pakistan and selling them to retailers across Afghanistan. His shop, which was closed for years due to conflict and looting, has been revived after he established relationships with traders in Karachi. Ramazan makes two trips to Karachi annually, importing 1,000 bales of used clothing each winter, and has become one of the largest traders in the country. Despite concerns about the quality of imported clothes, Ramazan's business continues to thrive, and he is now handing over the business to his eldest son.

site_title: Malaysia's Dec annual inflation rate seen edging up to 2.7%
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation rate is expected to rise to 2.7% in December, driven by rising costs for consumer goods despite declining fuel prices. The increase is attributed to a 40% government tax hike on tobacco products in November and higher food demand. This marks a slight increase from November's 2.6% annual inflation rate. The country's consumer price index has been rising since the introduction of a 6% goods and services tax (GST) in April.

site_title: Who, not where: For HSBC investors, HQ debate eclipsed by identity issue
summary: HSBC's board is set to discuss whether to move its headquarters from the UK to Hong Kong or another location, with investors questioning the bank's long-term strategy. The real debate is whether HSBC wants to be a global corporate lending giant or a simpler, Asia-focused trading and retail bank. The bank's CEO, Stuart Gulliver, has led a drive to slim down Europe's biggest bank, but concerns linger about high costs and adapting to a hostile regulatory framework. A move to Asia could be beneficial if the bank wants to be more focused, but investors are worried about the potential impact on capital raising and profitability.

site_title: Bye bye, fuel surcharge: holidays in Japan could get cheaper
summary: Japan's airlines are set to remove fuel surcharges due to oil trading at a 12-year low. The current price of Singapore kerosene is below the minimum level for adding surcharges, with analysts predicting airlines will enjoy major earnings advantages if fuel prices remain at current levels. ANA Holdings and Japan Airlines have set limits for fuel surcharges, with ANA announcing changes in April and Japan Airlines reviewing its fees. This move follows some international carriers, such as South Korean and AirAsia, which have already removed fuel surcharges on overseas flights.

site_title: China chief stock regulator has offered to resign: sources
summary: China's embattled top securities regulator, Xiao Gang, has offered to resign after his "circuit breaker" mechanism, intended to limit stock market losses, was blamed for exacerbating a sharp selloff. The mechanism was deactivated just three days after its introduction, wiping over $5 trillion off the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets since its peak in June 2015. Xiao's resignation offer has not been accepted by the central government, and his term does not formally expire until 2018.

site_title: World tourism numbers hit record 1.18 billion in 2015: UN
summary: The number of international tourists reached a record 1.18 billion in 2015, a 4.4% increase from the previous year, according to the UN World Tourism Organisation. This marks the sixth consecutive year of above-average growth in global tourism since the 2009 economic crisis. However, some destinations, like North Africa, saw a decline due to terrorist attacks, with tourism arrivals in the region falling by 8.0%. The UNWTO predicts a 4.0% increase in international tourism arrivals for 2016.

site_title: HLH sells more than 80% of first phase of Cambodia property project
summary: HLH Group sold over 80% of its first phase of the D'Seaview mixed-development project in Sihanoukville, Cambodia, for US$675 to US$1,943 per square meter. The project, launched in October 2015, features 300 units and is expected to be completed in 28 months. Most buyers were local residents, and construction is set to begin soon. This sale follows the acquisition of two more land plots in Cambodia, further indicating the company's expansion plans in the country.

site_title: Politics should have a sense of seriousness and purpose: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singaporean Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of maintaining a serious and purposeful tone in politics, differing from the polarized US system. He urged Parliament to focus on meaningful discussions rather than entertainment. Heng expressed concern over countries stuck in sectarian divisions and gridlock, which harm the common man. He hopes Singapore avoids such pitfalls, prioritizing the well-being of its citizens.

site_title: Airbus, Uber team up for on-demand helicopter rides
summary: Airbus and Uber are teaming up to test an on-demand helicopter service, with the goal of expanding helicopter operators' customer base. The service, which will use Airbus' H125 and H130 helicopters, will be available for on-demand rides and will be tested in a market pilot. The collaboration aims to prove a new business model for helicopter operators, but pricing details have not been released. This partnership marks a new venture into the helicopter market for Uber, which has expanded to hundreds of cities worldwide.

site_title: Indonesia 2016 property sales to grow 10-12 pct y-o-y: industry group
summary: Indonesia's property sales are expected to grow 10-12% in 2016, up from 7-8% last year, according to Realestat Indonesia's chairman Eddy Hussy. This growth is attributed to improved economic growth, government stimulus packages, and infrastructure development. The country's economy is forecast to grow 5.2% in 2016, with the central bank expected to further lower policy interest rates to ease borrowing costs for property buyers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports declined 7.2% year-on-year in December 2015 to S$12.85 billion, driven by a contraction in electronic and non-electronic segments. Koyo International shares plummeted 83.5% after the Singapore Exchange warned of further investigations. Inflation expectations hit a new low at 2.74% in December. Oil prices sank below US$28 a barrel, extending losses across Asian markets. The Straits Times Index dropped 1.44% to 2,593 following a Wall Street sell-off and oil slide.

site_title: SIMC appoints QC Edwin Glasgow and SC George Lim as co-chairmen
summary: The Singapore International Mediation Centre (SIMC) has appointed Queen's Counsel (QC) Edwin Glasgow and Senior Counsel (SC) George Lim as co-chairmen, effective January 1, 2016. Glasgow and Lim previously held these positions and co-chaired the International Commercial Mediation Working Group, which recommended the establishment of SIMC. The centre has received seven cases, including disputes in various sectors, with amounts ranging from S$5 million to over S$600 million. The new board of directors includes several prominent figures, with the centre continuing to expand its international mediation services.

site_title: Robots, new working ways to cost 5m jobs by 2020, Davos study says
summary: A new study by the World Economic Forum predicts 5.1 million net job losses in 15 leading countries by 2020 due to the rise of robots and artificial intelligence. The 7.1 million total job losses will be offset by 2 million new positions, mainly in skilled sectors. The biggest negative losses are expected in healthcare, energy, and financial services, while women are projected to lose more jobs than men, with a 5:1 ratio.

site_title: M1's Q4 profit eases 2.1% to S$43.6m; final dividend down
summary: M1's Q4 profit decreased 2.1% to S$43.6m, or 4.7 Singapore cents per share, due to a slowdown in handset sales. The telco's net profit for 2015 increased 1.5% to S$178.5m. M1 declared a final cash dividend of 8.3 Singapore cents, down from 11.9 cents last year. Operating revenue in Q4 fell 11.1% to S$307.9m, while mobile service revenue eased 2.1% to S$168.4m. M1 expects stable performance in 2016, driven by mobile data and fixed services growth.

site_title: Singapore's longevity a focus for the government: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's government is focusing on ensuring the country's longevity, rather than the ruling party's permanence, according to Minister Chan Chun Sing. This approach is also reflected in the government's efforts to accommodate diverse voices.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares pare losses, close at fresh 3-month low
summary: Tokyo shares closed at a fresh three-month low on January 18, 2016, due to the yen's strength and another fall in oil prices. The Nikkei 225 index declined 1.12% to 16,955.57, and the broader Topix index lost 1.04% to 1,387.93. The decline was attributed to sanctions against Iran being lifted, which led to a decrease in oil prices.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Wall Street sell-off, further oil slide
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 37.76 points, or 1.44%, to 2,593, following a Wall Street sell-off and a slide in oil to US$28 per barrel. Banks were the worst hit, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC falling 2.8%, 2.8%, and 2.1%, respectively. RHB maintained an "overweight" on the sector, citing concerns over rising defaults in oil and gas exposures.
