Overall turnover was 1.45 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, marking the ninth consecutive day above S$1 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall to lowest close since September 2012
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index fell 1.5% to 19,237.45, its lowest close since September 2012, due to declining oil prices and share price tumbles in the US and Europe. The China Enterprises Index also dropped 1.2%. Total trading volume reached 2.1 billion shares. The decline was attributed to investors' risk aversion.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q4 DPU rises to 1.68 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Reit reported a Q4 DPU of 1.68 Singapore cents, a 11.4% increase from the same period in 2014. The Reit's income available for distribution rose 17.8% to S$54.03 million, driven by higher property income and contributions from associates and joint ventures. Net property income remained largely unchanged at S$34.77 million. The improvement was attributed to stronger performance from Singapore and Australian assets.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Taiwan, US exchange diplomatic visits after election despite China warnings
summary: Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party, led by President Tsai Ing-wen, has won a landslide election, prompting China to warn Taiwan against pursuing independence. In response, a senior DPP member, Joseph Wu, will visit the US, highlighting the importance of ties with its major ally and source of arms. The US has congratulated Tsai on her victory and expressed support for Taiwan's continued prosperity and growth. China has warned Taiwan to abandon its "hallucination" about independence, but the visit by Wu underscores the growing importance of Taiwan-US relations.

site_title: Carney's 2016 BOE policy view awaited as wage growth slows
summary: UK Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is set to share his views on the economy for the first time in 2016, amid slower wage growth and a tumultuous start to the year. The Bank of England's benchmark interest rate has remained at a record low of 0.5% since 2009. Economic data, including employment and retail sales, will provide insight into the economy's performance. Carney's remarks will be closely watched for clues on the evolution of prices, with inflation expected to remain below the 2% target.

site_title: Hong Kong's central bank says has no plan to change currency peg
summary: Hong Kong's central bank chief Norman Chan stated that the Hong Kong dollar will not be changed to the US currency despite recent market volatility. The Hong Kong dollar fell to four-year lows earlier in the day due to weak global markets and capital outflows. Chan noted that the money market had operated smoothly, despite the volatility. The central bank has no plans to change the currency peg, indicating stability in the financial sector.

site_title: Emirates Q4 profit jumps 74% as impairments drop
summary: Emirates NBD PJSC reported a 74% increase in Q4 profit to 2.13 billion dirhams, beating analyst estimates, due to a decline in bad loan charges and a rise in lending. Impairment allowances dropped by nearly half. The bank proposed a 40 fils dividend, up from 35 fils the previous year, and its shares rose 6.4%. Full-year lending and deposits increased 10% and 11% respectively, while the impaired loan ratio fell to 7.1%.

site_title: China investigates senior Beijing official for corruption
summary: Chinese authorities are investigating Lu Xiwen, a former deputy Communist Party official in Beijing, for suspected corruption. Lu is under investigation for taking bribes and was previously sacked after being accused of "serious breaches of discipline." This is part of President Xi Jinping's campaign to root out deeply ingrained corruption in China, which has been ongoing since his assumption of office three years ago.

site_title: Gold gains for second day as risk aversion fans demand for haven
summary: Gold prices rose for a second day as investors sought safe-haven assets amid a global equity selloff, driven by weakness in China and falling crude prices. The metal gained 0.4% to US$1,093.46 an ounce, with investors adding to exchange-traded product holdings for the sixth time in seven days. A stronger US dollar typically damps gold's appeal, but investors see gold as a safe haven, despite shorter-dated bonds and currencies attracting attention as a store of value.

site_title: Asian markets extend rout as oil sinks below US$28
summary: Asian markets continued their rout on Monday as oil prices plummeted below $28 a barrel, extending losses across the region. The US and EU lifted sanctions on Iran, allowing it to resume crude exports, contributing to a global supply glut and further depressing oil prices. Energy firms and mining companies were among the big losers, with Tokyo and Hong Kong markets closing near one-year lows. The decision also raised concerns about the state of China's economy, with analysts forecasting the slowest rate in 25 years, and markets waiting for the release of Chinese economic growth data on Tuesday.

site_title: Many young people fear losing their jobs to robots, survey finds
summary: A global survey of 9,000 16- to 25-year-olds found that four out of ten believe machines will replace their jobs within a decade. Nearly half of young workers in Western countries feel their education is inadequate to prepare them for their jobs. The skills gap is pronounced, with 80% saying they need to learn new skills not taught in school due to rapid technology change. Infosys CEO Vishal Sikka emphasized the need for education to focus on future possibilities, rather than past knowledge, to adapt to the "Fourth Industrial Revolution."

site_title: MS Holdings venturing into property development in Indonesia
summary: MS Holdings Limited has entered into a binding conditional term sheet agreement with ACT Holdings Pte Ltd for a potential joint venture in property development in western Jakarta, Indonesia. The joint venture will raise MS Holdings' interest in a residential project to 80% from 50%. MS Holdings will acquire a 31.25% stake, while ACT and Aspen Development will hold 61.87% and 6.88% respectively. Sales and marketing of the property project are expected to commence in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: China to invest 800b yuan in railway network in 2016
summary: China plans to invest 800 billion yuan in its railway network in 2016, boosting passenger traffic by 10% and freight volume by 2%. The investment is part of ongoing efforts to expand the country's railway network, with a total fixed asset investment of 3.58 trillion yuan from 2011 to 2015. China Railway Corp aims to win more overseas contracts, including the Moscow-Kazan and Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail projects.

site_title: China steel firms suffered US$8b in losses in Jan to Nov 2015
summary: China's major steel firms suffered a combined loss of 53.1 billion yuan (S$11.6 billion) from January to November 2015 due to overcapacity and slumping demand. The country's steel sector, accounting for half of global output, saw prices fall to multi-decade lows. The industry's total annual crude steel capacity is now 1.2 billion tonnes, with about a third standing idle. China still lacks a mechanism for loss-making steel enterprises to exit the market, with local governments urging firms to produce for local economic development.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat as institutional buying helps sentiment; won up
summary: South Korean shares closed flat on Monday as institutional buying of beaten-down stocks supported the market, despite a slump in oil prices and a big sell-off on Wall Street. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended at 1,878.45, unchanged from Friday's close. Foreigners were net sellers for an eighth straight session, offloading 344.9 billion won worth of shares, while the won gained 0.2% against the dollar.

site_title: Thai Central says 'keen to bid' for retailer Casino's Thai, Vietnam stores
summary: Thailand's Central Group, the country's biggest retailer, may bid for French supermarket firm Casino's Thai and Vietnam stores, including its 58.6% stake in Big C Supercenter Pcl, which has a market value of $5.5 billion. Central Group's deputy CEO, Prin Chirathivat, expressed interest in bidding, citing growth opportunities in Southeast Asia. The potential takeover bid would be Thailand's second-largest inbound acquisition, following a 2013 purchase by CP All Pcl.

site_title: Maybank opens first Punggol branch
summary: Maybank has opened its first branch in Punggol, Singapore, as part of its strategy to attract young families. The branch, which will operate on Sundays, aims to double its customer base in the Punggol and Sengkang area within four years. Punggol has the highest proportions of children in Singapore, with 11% in 2014 and 10.9% in 2015. This move is part of Maybank's expansion plans, which now include 22 branches in Singapore.

site_title: Asian junk bonds one cent away from 2012 low after fund flight
summary: Asian junk-rated dollar bonds are near a four-year low after a global market selloff and economic slowdown in China. Average prices of company debentures fell to 93.55 cents on the dollar, with 58 out of 178 members in the Asian junk-bond index losing market value this month. Investors are demanding 800 basis points to own debt sold by borrowers without investment-grade ratings, up from 756 at the end of last year. The decline is attributed to China's equity rout, weakening yuan expectations, and plunging oil prices.

site_title: China's stocks rise as small-cap companies spearhead rebound
summary: China's stocks rose 0.4% to 2,913.84, led by property developers and technology companies, as the Shanghai Composite Index rebounded from a bear market. The ChiNext index of small-cap stocks jumped 2.9% and the offshore yuan strengthened. Analysts expect a rebound, but some strategists and fund managers predict a deeper bear market. China's GDP growth is expected to slow to 6.9% in the fourth quarter, with some predicting a further decline to 6.5% this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2½-yr low as oil weakness saps confidence
summary: Australian shares hit a 2½-year low as the price of oil fell, reinforcing concerns about faltering global economic growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 34.1 points, or 0.7%, to 4,858.7, its lowest close since July 2013. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 1.1% to 6,101.4. The decline is the benchmark's fifth consecutive drop, with the index down over 8% for the year.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound as Ericsson and LVMH rise
summary: European shares rebounded on Monday, rising 0.6% to their lowest level since mid-December 2014, as Ericsson and LVMH shares surged 2.9% and 1.4% respectively. The gains were partly attributed to upgrades from Nordea Markets and Goldman Sachs. However, French supermarket retailer Casino fell 3.2% after Standard & Poor's threatened to downgrade its debt. Despite the mixed results, the FTSEurofirst 300 index remained 0.6% higher, with the eurozone's Euro STOXX 50 and Britain's FTSE 100 also advancing.

site_title: India's Dec exports fall for 13th month, exporters brace for tough times
summary: India's merchandise exports fell 14.75% in December to $22.3 billion, marking the 13th consecutive month of decline. Orders from the US and Europe dwindled, while a weaker Chinese yuan further hurt exports. Engineering exports, which account for a quarter of total exports, could fall to $60 billion, with over 100,000 jobs at risk. The government's fiscal package and Finance Minister Arun Jaitley's budget for 2016/17 are unlikely to provide significant relief to exporters, who face a tough time due to the deteriorating global economic growth outlook.

site_title: Missing Hong Kong bookseller to answer 11-year-old conviction
summary: Gui Minhai, a Swedish bookseller, has voluntarily returned to China to answer a 2004 conviction for killing a student. He had been missing since his disappearance in Thailand last October, sparking fears of Chinese government involvement. Gui, who holds a Swedish passport, surrendered to authorities and expressed remorse, stating he was taking personal responsibility for his actions. His daughter believes he was abducted and detained due to his work, while the Chinese government has called it a personal choice. The case has raised concerns about China's treatment of Hong Kong residents and the "one country, two systems" formula.

site_title: Tepid reception to DBS Tier-2 bonds shows risk aversion
summary: DBS Group's Tier-2 bond offering in Singapore received a tepid response, with a S$250m 12-year non-call seven subordinated bond selling at a yield of 3.8% to attract S$300m in bids. The deal's pricing came in slightly higher than initial guidance, highlighting investors' risk aversion in current volatile markets. Despite this, the 3.8% yield translated into a tight spread of 110bp over Singapore dollar SOR. The episode suggests that foreign banks seeking to raise subordinated bank capital in Singapore may need to adjust their expectations.

site_title: China housing prices rise 1.6% in December
summary: China's home prices rose 1.6% in December, marking the third consecutive month of year-on-year gains. This increase follows a 0.9% rise in the previous month. Compared to the previous month, prices rose 0.3%. The National Bureau of Statistics reported these numbers.

site_title: Hot stock: Koyo Int'l dives after SGX's hints of further investigations
summary: Koyo International's shares plummeted 83.5% to 5.6 cents on Monday after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) warned investors to trade the shares with caution due to unusual trading patterns. The SGX found that a small group of individuals was responsible for 60% of the trading volume, with at least half of the trades being self-made. Koyo International attributed the unusual trading to potential projects and business opportunities. The regulator is working with relevant agencies on the matter, but the company's shares continue to slide.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: British PM Cameron attacks isolation of Muslim women
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron has called for more efforts to help Muslim women learn English to combat discrimination and segregation in their communities. He launched a £20 million language fund for women in isolated communities, stating that migrants must improve their English fluency to stay in Britain. Cameron highlighted that 190,000 Muslim women, or 22%, speak little or no English, contributing to economic inactivity and social isolation. He also linked the issue to extremism, urging the government to be more assertive in promoting liberal values and breaking down barriers.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda keeps upbeat view on Japan economy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed optimism about Japan's economy, stating it will continue recovering moderately despite emerging market slowdowns. The BOJ will monitor policy adjustments to address upside and downside risks. A report analyzing regional economic conditions in Japan, including corporate wage-hike plans, will be released later.

site_title: China to start implementing RRR for some banks in offshore yuan market: PBOC
summary: China will implement a reserve requirement ratio (RRR) on some banks involved in the offshore yuan market, starting January 25, in an effort to stem speculation. The move aims to reduce liquidity in the market and discourage speculation, following the currency's lowest level since 2010. The PBOC confirmed the move without increasing restrictions, with analysts viewing it as a symbolic warning to banks. The RRR will apply to yuan deposits from offshore financial institutions placed with onshore financial institutions, excluding foreign central banks and sovereign wealth funds.

site_title: IDA to trial interoperable SIM
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) will issue a request for proposal to trial interoperable SIMs for Internet of Things (IoT) devices, enabling data to be carried on different mobile networks. The trial, in partnership with PUB, aims to explore the use of open GSMA standards for eSIM chips to switch between mobile network operators, promoting a competitive environment for M2M devices and increasing IoT adoption. This could lead to easier introduction of IoT applications in smart homes, monitoring and managing water and energy consumption.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 12.82 points to 1,615.73 on Monday, with volume reaching 230.73 million lots worth RM 65.78 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 446 to 44.

site_title: Asia: Stock rout deepens as Japan, Australia bear markets loom
summary: Asian stocks plummeted, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 indices on the cusp of joining China in a bear market. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 1% to 118.94, extending this year's decline to 9.9%. Oil prices dropped below $30 a barrel for the first time in 12 years, exacerbating concerns over global growth and driving volatility in markets. China's stock market entered a bear market last week, and investors expect continued share market weakness and volatility in the short term.

site_title: China's yuan firms as central bank takes fresh step to curb speculation
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar as the central bank implemented new measures to curb offshore speculation, including a reserve requirement ratio for some banks involved in the offshore yuan market. The move aims to dampen speculative flows that bet on a fast depreciation of the currency. However, Chinese shares remained volatile, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.2% and the CSI300 index flat. The PBOC's actions come as China heads towards its slowest growth in 25 years, with the yuan having weakened sharply offshore in recent days.

site_title: Thailand's ousted Shinawatra clan defies junta with publicity drive
summary: Thailand's ousted Shinawatra clan is launching a publicity drive to reconnect with supporters, defying the military junta that toppled their governments. Former Prime Ministers Thaksin Shinawatra and his sister Yingluck are distributing free books and engaging in social media, signaling their intention to one day return to power. The move is seen as a way to reassure their base and needle their enemies, but the junta has vowed to restrict their movements and has taken note of their recent self-publicity.

site_title: Jokowi under pressure to revamp terror laws after Jakarta attack
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo faces pressure to revamp terror laws after a Jakarta attack linked to Islamic State, killing four civilians. The attack highlights the need for stronger anti-terrorism laws to tackle the threat of returnees from the Middle East. Police and military officials have called for greater powers to arrest and track extremists, with some suggesting revoking citizenship of Indonesians fighting with IS abroad. Revising the law requires parliamentary approval, which could be difficult due to opposition from Islamic parties. Widodo's government has largely focused on economic issues, and the attack may force him to shift his attention to defense and security matters.

site_title: Prosecution files appeal against City Harvest sentences
summary: The prosecution has filed an appeal against the sentences of six individuals, including City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee, who were found guilty of misusing millions of dollars in church funds. The AGC claims the sentences were "manifestly inadequate" and is seeking harsher punishment. Kong received an 8-year sentence, while others received sentences ranging from 21 months to 5.5 years. The six defendants had also filed their own appeals against conviction and sentences in December, indicating their intention to appeal further.

site_title: CEFC International wins tender to supply diesel to Dyneff SAS
summary: CEFC International Limited has won a tender to supply diesel to Dyneff SAS, a leading independent fuel distributor in France and Spain, for a one-year period starting January 1, 2016. Under the agreement, CEFC will sell 800kt to 900kt of diesel to Dyneff. The deal marks the expansion of CEFC's trading business into Europe and is expected to bring in additional business opportunities and facilitate the growth of its European business network.

site_title: China home-price recovery spreads to more cities amid easing
summary: China's home-price recovery spread to more cities in December, with new-home prices rising in 39 cities and dropping in 26, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Authorities eased measures targeting regions with unsold homes, aiming to reduce the 12% increase in unsold new homes nationwide since last year. Average new-home prices rose 0.74% in December from November, and prices in 51 cities gained month-on-month, up 10 from November. The easing measures aim to address the surplus of unsold homes and stabilize the market.

site_title: Brent oil briefly falls below US$28 after Iran sanctions lifted
summary: Brent crude oil briefly fell to a 11-year low of $27.67 a barrel, down 4.4% from Friday's close, due to fears of a worsening supply glut after Western sanctions on Iran were lifted, allowing the country to resume oil exports. The US and EU lifted the sanctions on Sunday after the UN confirmed Iran had complied with its nuclear obligations. Analysts predict a bigger oil glut with Iranian crude exports returning to the market, leading to lower oil prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks extended losses in early trade on Monday, following a decline in oil prices after Iran's export sanctions were lifted. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.84%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 2.04%. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index declined 1.20%, as energy firms were impacted by the drop in oil prices. The losses followed a similar trend seen last week.

site_title: Singapore IDA, MDA to merge for more holistic approach to ICT and media
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) is restructuring the Info-communications Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) and the Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) to form the Info-communications Media Development Authority of Singapore (IMDA) and the Government Technology Organisation (GTO). The new entities will be set up in 2016, with the IMDA focusing on developing and regulating the converging infocomm and media sectors and the GTO leading digital transformation efforts in the public sector. The restructuring aims to create a more holistic approach to ICT and media development.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Hot stock: Catalist debutant GS Holdings up 6% despite market rout
summary: GS Holdings, a Catalist debutant, rose 6% to 26.5 cents, its debut day, despite a global market rout. The company's centralised dishwashing facilities operator is one of two Catalist IPOs to gain traction, with Eindec Corporation Ltd also up 21.4% on its IPO. Analysts attribute the gains to private placements, with anchor investors providing support to prevent immediate selling pressure. The strong debut mirrors the performance of other Catalist IPOs, which have been listed through private placements to reduce selling pressure.

site_title: Australia: Stocks hit 2½-yr lows, NZ shares fall hard on global headwinds
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Monday, with the NZ benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index down 1.7% and the Australian S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.7%. Global growth concerns, particularly over China's economy, drove the decline. Energy shares, such as Santos and Origin, were severely beaten, while mining stocks like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also fell. Despite some gains in financial stocks like Woolworths and Wesfarmers, the overall market remained under pressure, with the ASX index dropping 7.6% this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GS Holdings, Keppel Reit, YuuZoo, ISEC
summary: GS Holdings, a Singapore-based dishware washing company, made its market debut on the Catalist, with 24 million shares priced at S$0.25 each. Keppel Reit is set to announce its fourth-quarter results and divest its Sydney building for A$160 million. YuuZoo Corporation acquired 30% of Infocomm Asia Holdings for S$2.39 million. ISEC Healthcare Ltd entered into a joint venture agreement with a Vietnamese company, while allowing a non-binding pact with another Vietnamese partner to lapse.

site_title: World tennis hit by match-fixing reports, authorities back integrity unit
summary: Allegations of widespread match-fixing in world tennis have surfaced, with reports suggesting 16 top-50 players were flagged to the Tennis Integrity Unit (TIU) over suspicious behavior in the past decade. Despite this, players were allowed to continue competing in the Australian Open, and authorities rejected claims that evidence was suppressed. The TIU has investigated 18 players, with 6 issued life bans, and tennis officials have invested $14 million in anti-corruption programs, rejecting suggestions of under-resourcing and inadequate enforcement powers.

site_title: Seoul: Shares skid to near 5-mth lows on oil slump; won nearly flat
summary: South Korean shares dropped to near 5-month lows, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) falling 0.3% to 1,872.40 points. The decline was driven by an extended slump in oil prices and soft US economic data, with tech and energy shares suffering the most. Foreign investors dumped KOSPI shares for the eighth consecutive session, and the won rose slightly against the dollar. Despite China's troubles, a resurgent yuan brought some relief, and construction firms saw a slight gain.

site_title: Singapore's inflation expectations hit new low at 2.74% in Dec: SMU survey
summary: Singapore's inflation expectations have hit a new low at 2.74% for the year ahead, according to a Singapore Management University (SMU) survey. This is significantly lower than previous quarters and below the historical median headline inflation expectations average of 3.69%. The low expectations are attributed to global economic challenges, including turmoil in the Chinese equity market and weak global demand. This is also the lowest level of core inflation expectations, excluding accommodation and private transportation costs, at 2.85%.

site_title: Australian inflation gauge stays benign in Dec: TDMI
summary: A private-sector inflation gauge in Australia remained low in December, with consumer prices rising 0.2% and the annual pace at 2.0%, below the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. The survey suggests the official inflation report due on January 27 will likely show a 0.5% increase in underlying inflation, consistent with the RBA's projections. The data could lead to further interest rate cuts if needed, with the RBA's chief economist stating a possible rate cut if beneficial.

site_title: China investors brace for volatility as global markets slide
summary: China's financial markets are bracing for volatility as the central bank prepares to raise the reserve requirement ratio for deposits placed in yuan clearing banks, aiming to curb yuan speculation. The Shanghai index closed lower than at any time since December 2014, leaving investors with significant losses. Analysts attribute the market's vulnerability to the recent crashes and Beijing's inability to prevent speculation. The central bank's measures come as global markets also tumble, with Asian shares set to slide to near 2011 troughs due to weak US economic data and sharp oil price falls.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday amid global rout
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) opened 35.88 points or 1.4% lower on Monday, extending a global rout amid concerns over tumbling oil prices and bearish signs of the Singapore economy. Non-oil domestic exports declined 7.2% year-on-year in December 2015. Top losers included Noble Group, Ezra Holdings, and MMP Resources, while the market saw 71.5 million shares worth S$79.4 million change hands.

site_title: ISEC enters into MOU with new Vietnamese partner
summary: ISEC Healthcare Ltd has entered into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Hai Yen Anh Tran Company Limited and Tran Hai Yen to form a joint venture company. ISEC will hold a 51% stake, while Hai Yen Group will hold the remaining 49%. This follows the lapse of ISEC's non-binding MOU with Cao Thang Corp and Nguyen Danh Khoi, which was intended to form a joint venture company.

site_title: Gold rebounds to 6-week high on China, US woes
summary: Gold prices surged to a 6-week high due to concerns over China's economic woes and the US retail sales, which marked the weakest year since 2009. Chinese stocks fell into a bear market, while US equities were headed for their lowest levels in 15 months. The decline in retail sales and crude oil prices below $30 a barrel increased demand for gold as a safe-haven asset.

site_title: Man dies after being left brain-dead in French drug trial
summary: A man participating in a Phase I clinical trial for a pain and mood disorder medication in France died after suffering serious side effects, leaving him brain-dead. The trial, conducted by Bial, was testing the safety of the drug on 108 volunteers, with six men hospitalized due to adverse reactions. Five of the hospitalized men are in stable condition, while the sixth, who was left brain-dead, has died. Bial's CEO has apologized for the incident and pledged an investigation, with France launching three probes to determine the cause.

site_title: China: Stocks sharply lower at market open
summary: China's stocks plummeted 1.6% to 3,068.23 points on the CSI300 index and 1.8% to 2,847.54 points on the Shanghai Composite Index, amid strengthened oversight efforts by the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) to address "abnormal" volatility. The regulator's pledge to avoid risks and promote healthy development in capital markets led to a decline in Hang Seng index in Hong Kong as well, down 1.2% to 19,287.38 points.

site_title: Quick takes: Challenging year ahead for Singapore exports, economists say
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 7.2% year-on-year in December 2015 to S$12.85 billion, driven by contractions in the electronic and non-electronic segments. NODX to top 10 markets, excluding the US, Japan, and Hong Kong, also contracted. Economists predict a challenging year for Singapore exports due to slower global value chain expansion and rebalancing towards consumption and services-led growth in China. The resilient Singapore dollar and uneven US recovery also weigh on export performance.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Keppel Data Centres picks Epsilon to deliver local access networks in Singapore
summary: Keppel Data Centres Holdings has selected Epsilon as its provider for local access networks in Singapore, offering IP Transit services and global connectivity. This partnership will enable Keppel Data Centres to support its customers' cloud services globally. Epsilon's flexible network infrastructure will provide customers with enhanced connectivity and flexibility, allowing them to scale quickly. The move aims to add value to Keppel Data Centres' services beyond data centre colocation, supporting customers' businesses with secure and proven infrastructure.

site_title: US and EU firms warn of "enormous" consequences if data pact talks fail
summary: US and European trade groups warn that failure to reach a data transfer pact by the end of January could have "enormous" consequences for thousands of businesses and millions of users. The pact, which enables firms to transfer personal data across the Atlantic, was struck down by a top EU court last year due to US snooping concerns. Businesses, including over 4,000 firms, are in legal limbo and face dire economic impact if data flows are disrupted. The groups urge a transition period to comply with any revised framework, especially for small and medium-sized businesses.

site_title: Richest 62 people own same as half world's population: Oxfam
summary: The wealthiest 62 people now own as much as half the world's population, with their collective wealth increasing by 44% since 2010, while the poorest 3.5 billion have seen their wealth decline by 41%. This stark inequality has led Oxfam to call for governments to take action to collect taxes owed by companies and the rich, with an estimated $190 billion available annually if tax were paid on offshore wealth.

site_title: Bowie posthumously tops US chart for first time
summary: David Bowie's final album "Blackstar" debuted at number one on the US Billboard album chart, marking his first US number one album posthumously. Released on his 69th birthday, the album was a critical and commercial success, following his death from cancer on January 10. This achievement also made Bowie one of the rare artists to have two albums in the top five, with his greatest hits collection "Best Of Bowie" reaching number four.

site_title: SpaceX launches climate satellite but botches ocean landing
summary: SpaceX successfully launched a climate-monitoring satellite, Jason-3, into orbit on Sunday, but botched an attempted return landing on a platform in the Pacific Ocean. The rocket's first stage made it back to the platform, but one landing leg failed to latch, causing it to tip over. This marks the company's second unsuccessful ocean-landing attempt, following previous failures in 2015. The satellite will monitor ocean heights, currents, and other climate indicators, with data expected to help track human-caused climate change.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.87% lower, extending global rout
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 1.87% on Monday, extending a global rout, due to tumbling oil prices, a slowing Chinese economy, and a stronger yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index declined to 16,826.93, while the Topix index lost 1.87% to 1,376.24. This follows a global market downturn from last week, with investors worried about the impact of these economic factors on exporters.

site_title: YuuZoo acquires 30% of Infocomm Asia for S$2.4m
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has acquired 30% of Infocomm Asia Holdings Pte Ltd (IAH) for S$2.39 million, issuing 15 million new shares. IAH, a leading distributor of online and box games in South-east Asia, has a registered user base of over 37 million users and annual revenues of over S$40 million. The acquisition allows YuuZoo to expand its e-commerce platform and benefit from IAH's publishing and marketing partners. This partial acquisition provides YuuZoo with similar benefits as a full acquisition at a lower cost to shareholders, also repaying a S$6.5 million loan.

site_title: Singapore non-oil domestic exports continue decline in Dec
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 7.2% year-on-year to S$12.85 billion in December 2015, with electronic and non-electronic segments contracting. Total trade fell 8.4% to S$71.54 billion, and exports dropped 6.4% to S$38.35 billion. Contraction was led by China, South Korea, and Taiwan, with NODX to emerging markets also declining 10.0%.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: With liftoff done, the Fed revisits a US$4.5 trillion quandary
summary: Federal Reserve officials are debating how to manage the US$4.5 trillion balance sheet, which is equivalent to Japan's economy, amid global financial market turmoil. The Fed is considering maintaining the balance sheet to hold down longer-term Treasury yields while lifting the short-term policy rate. New York Fed President William Dudley and Fed Chair Janet Yellen suggest reinvesting maturing bonds and delaying a balance sheet reduction until the federal funds rate is raised higher. The decision may be contentious, with some Fed members favoring an "expeditious" unwinding of the balance sheet.

site_title: Loyz Energy unit inks supplemental agreement with Carnarvon Thailand
summary: Loyz Energy Limited's wholly owned unit, Loyz Oil Thailand Pte Ltd, has entered into a supplemental sale and purchase agreement with Carnarvon Thailand Limited to amend certain terms in a 2014 deal. The agreement pertains to a 20% participating interest in SW1/L33/L44 oil concessions in Phetchabun Basin, Thailand, valued at US$65 million. The supplemental agreement adjusts post-completion receivable payments, with the first payment now due by December 30, 2015, and the second payment due by January 31, 2016.

site_title: Oil slides to lowest since 2003 as Iran sanctions lifted
summary: Oil prices plummeted to their lowest since 2003 as international sanctions on Iran were lifted, allowing the country to increase its crude exports by 500,000 barrels a day. London Brent crude fell to $27.80 a barrel and US crude to $28.56 a barrel, amid concerns about economic trouble in China and a bearish outlook from US President Trump's tariffs. The move sent Asian equities into a torrid session and boosted the safe-haven yen.

site_title: Steering Yangzijiang to calmer waters amid rough weather
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, a privately-owned Chinese shipbuilder, is expanding its business despite the industry's crisis. Chairman Ren Yuanlin projects the number of Chinese shipyards may decline to under 50 in three years. YZJ has remained profitable and secured new contracts, including orders for liquefied natural gas carriers and self-loading bulkers. The company aims to diversify into higher-value vessels and expand its market share. Ren Yuanlin also considers acquiring Rongsheng Heavy Industries to boost capacity and potentially list on the Hong Kong bourse.

site_title: US$ sags on weak data, drop in oil prices
summary: The US dollar tumbled to a near five-month low against the yen and a 2 ½-week trough versus the euro due to weak US economic data and a drop in oil prices. The dollar index fell 0.2% to 98.933, with the euro rising to its highest level since December 29. Commodity-based currencies like the Australian, New Zealand, and Canadian dollars also plummeted. The poor US data and low oil prices may slow the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, making the dollar less attractive.

site_title: US, Iran leaders hail nuke deal but US imposes new sanctions
summary: US President Barack Obama and Iranian President Hassan Rouhani hailed the implementation of the nuclear deal, but the US imposed new sanctions on Iran's ballistic missile program. The US lifted sanctions on Iran, allowing it to increase oil exports and access foreign investment. However, the US also targeted Iranian nationals and companies in the UAE and China with new measures. The decision came after four Iranian-Americans, including a Washington Post reporter, left Tehran following a prisoner swap with the US. Rouhani warned that Iran would react to the sanctions, and the UN's atomic watchdog confirmed Iran's compliance with the deal.

site_title: Iran to buy 114 Airbus aircraft to renew Iran Air's ageing fleet
summary: Iran has agreed to buy 114 Airbus aircraft to renew its ageing fleet, with deliveries expected to begin as early as July after international sanctions are lifted. The deal includes a mix of new and used jets from the A320 and A340 families. The purchases come as Iran fulfills its commitments under the nuclear accord with world powers, paving the way for the purchase of planes to expand international flying and meet domestic demand at its 50 airports.

site_title: US issues travel advisory to Latin America on Zika virus
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued a travel advisory to 13 Latin American and Caribbean countries due to the Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in babies. Pregnant women are advised to postpone travel and consult doctors before traveling to affected areas. The advisory applies to countries with Zika cases, including Brazil, Colombia, and Puerto Rico, and urges all travelers to avoid mosquito bites. The CDC is monitoring the situation and will reassess the advisory as needed, but the warning is expected to affect the travel industry and potentially impact the Summer Olympics in Brazil.

site_title: Relevance lies at heart of proposed SGX reporting rules
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) proposes introducing regulated sustainability reporting for listed companies, with a "comply or explain" model allowing for flexibility. The reporting regime will require companies to publish a sustainability report annually, covering five primary components, but will give issuers discretion on material issues, reporting framework, and implementation timeline. The goal is to make the reporting meaningful to all stakeholders, including investors and issuers, and to attract a wider pool of investors. Enforcement powers will remain, but market pressure is expected to induce companies to improve reporting quality over time.

site_title: In Maine, local control is luxury fewer can afford
summary: In Maine, a small town called Cary Plantation has voted to dissolve its local government, joining the unorganized territory, a vast area of forest and townships governed by a partnership between the state and counties. This move is part of a trend of local governments in the US seeking to reduce costs by privatizing services, consolidating, or even dissolving altogether. The process, which requires 12 steps and legislative approval, aims to spread costs across the state or county, reducing overhead and making it more affordable for residents.

site_title: Keppel Reit sells Sydney property for A$160m
summary: Keppel Reit has sold its 100% stake in a Sydney commercial building, 77 King Street, for A$160 million to ARE Noble, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Invesco Asia Core Fund. The sale results in a divestment gain of about A$28 million. The proceeds will be used to pay off existing debt and fund general corporate and working capital. After the divestment, Keppel Reit will still own four office assets in Australia.

site_title: Underwhelming Q4 earnings a sign of what's to come: analysts
summary: Singapore-listed companies' Q4 earnings are expected to be underwhelming due to a tough global environment, soft domestic property market, and rising interest rates. Analysts warn that 2016 earnings growth is likely to be weak, with vulnerable sectors including offshore & marine, telcos, and retail real estate investment trusts. Despite this, some sectors like healthcare and consumer companies, plantation companies, and manufacturing stocks may fare well. Analysts expect Q4 earnings to be relatively weak, with a high risk of dividend cuts and earnings visibility being low.

site_title: Mid-East stocks plummet as sanctions on Iran ease
summary: Middle East stocks plummeted as sanctions on Iran eased, with Saudi Arabia's Tadawul All Share Index dropping 7.2% and Abu Dhabi's ADX General Index falling into a bear market. Iran targets an immediate 500,000 barrel daily increase in oil shipments, threatening to put further pressure on prices and hurting oil-dependent economies. The easing of sanctions has sparked concern about a surge in oil supplies, contributing to a global stock rout and a 36% drop in Saudi Arabia's Tadawul over the past year.

site_title: R&D investment is investing in future: DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of investing in research and development (R&D) in Singapore, stating it will benefit the city-state's future by creating economic value, improving lives, and increasing global collaboration. Examples of successful R&D investments include the growth of companies like Garena and Razer, and technological solutions for improved living environments. Singapore's R&D efforts have also strengthened its international linkages, with researchers returning from abroad to lead local institutions.

site_title: Britain's falling home ownership rate blamed on buy-to-let small-time landlords
summary: The UK's falling home ownership rate is attributed to the decline of small-time landlords, known as buy-to-let (BTL) investors. These investors, who own few properties, have enjoyed high returns, but now face increased taxes and potential mortgage size limits. The government aims to reduce BTL investors to make it easier for ordinary people to buy homes. Experts predict this could lead to a decrease in the housing market, while alternative investment options, such as Property Partner, may fill the gap.

site_title: Qualcomm unveils US$280m joint venture with Chinese province
summary: Qualcomm has unveiled a US$280 million joint venture with the Guizhou province in southwest China, designed to develop and sell advanced server technology. The joint venture, Guizhou Huaxintong Semi-Conductor Technology Co Ltd, will be capitalized with 1.85 billion renminbi and will be supported by Qualcomm's licensing of server technology, research and development assistance, and expertise implementation. This move is part of Qualcomm's efforts to deepen its cooperation and investment in China, as stated by Qualcomm President Derek Aberle, underscoring the company's strategic partnership in the region.

site_title: Three US prisoners freed by Iran on their way to Germany: official
summary: Three US prisoners, including Tehran correspondent Jason Rezaian and former US Marine Amir Hekmati, were released by Iran and headed to a US military base in Germany after a brief stop in Geneva, Switzerland. The release came just hours before Iran's historic nuclear deal with world powers was implemented. US President Barack Obama praised the release, but cautioned that the US would continue to have problems with Iran's "destabilizing activities" in the region. The fourth prisoner, Nosratollah Khosravi-Roodsari, remains in Iran.

site_title: WP can move motion to fill NCMP seat: Fu
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore needs to move a parliamentary motion to propose a new candidate for the Non-Constituency Member of Parliament (NCMP) seat that Lee Li Lian has declined. The seat was offered to the best losers at the general election, with Lee having won the most votes with 48.23%. WP supports Lee's decision not to return to Parliament, but will consider Daniel Goh for the seat if Parliament decides to fill the vacancy. Leader of the House Grace Fu stated that WP must move a motion to propose an alternative candidate.

site_title: Industry critics rue all-white ballot in 2016 Oscar nominations
summary: The 2016 Oscar nominations were met with criticism for being all-white, with no nominees from films with black themes in the best picture category. Industry experts pointed to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' lack of diversity among its members and the preferential voting system as contributing factors. The snub of films like Creed and Straight Outta Compton, which focus on black characters, was seen as a missed opportunity for the industry to recognize diverse storytelling. Academy President Cheryl Boone Isaacs defended the nominations, saying there was no pattern of exclusion, but the incident sparked renewed calls for greater diversity in the film industry.

site_title: HSBC, BNP Paribas plan to cut securities units if they fail
summary: HSBC and BNP Paribas plan to cut their securities units if they fail, while American International Group will spin off its non-life insurance divisions. The US regulators have released living wills from around 125 financial firms, showing that many banks will leave subsidiaries operating while parent companies go to bankruptcy court. Non-US banks, such as Royal Bank of Canada and Royal Bank of Scotland, also have plans to shed assets or sell units to other banks. The strategies aim to minimize systemic risk in the event of collapse.

site_title: Will 2016 be a repeat of 2008?
summary: Experts say 2016 is unlikely to be a repeat of 2008, despite recent market volatility, due to China's slowing but still robust economy and the US economy's steady growth. While China's stock market is sentiment-driven and volatility remains high, a hard landing is unlikely, and a global recession is also unlikely. The US economy's numbers are "OK," and valuations can suddenly become too high, leading to a change in market perception. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike decision may now look premature, and some experts question whether it will bail out Wall Street again if the market continues to plunge.

site_title: China's shift from manufacturing to services may disappoint: IIF
summary: China's shift from manufacturing to services may not be as effective in driving growth as previously thought, according to a report by the Institute of International Finance (IIF). The report suggests that while the services sector will continue to grow, it may not be able to sustain its recent pace, and that the manufacturing sector will remain under pressure. China's services sector has grown significantly in recent years, but faces obstacles such as heavy regulation and limited competition. The report concludes that the manufacturing sector will remain crucial to China's growth, and that policymakers should focus on reforming it to make it more inclusive and competitive.

site_title: Walmart to close record number of stores in US and overseas
summary: Walmart is closing a record 154 US stores and 115 overseas locations, affecting approximately 16,000 employees. The closures, part of the retailer's effort to adapt to online shopping, will also end its Walmart Express small-store format. The move underscores the challenges faced by brick-and-mortar retailers, with Amazon accounting for nearly a quarter of retail sales growth last year. Walmart aims to grow despite the closures, with plans to open over 300 new stores worldwide next year.

site_title: Bird flu back in US, H7N8 strain found in Indiana turkey flock
summary: The US government has confirmed a highly pathogenic strain of avian influenza, H7N8, in a commercial turkey flock in Indiana, the country's first case since the end of last year's outbreak. The strain, different from those that caused last year's outbreak, has prompted federal and state authorities to monitor and test the nearby area. The US Department of Agriculture is working to minimize trade impact and has stockpiled doses of a new vaccine designed to fight the 2015 strain. No human cases have been reported, and the risk of illness to humans is considered low.

site_title: Amazon takes first step towards maritime shipping operations
summary: Amazon has taken its first step towards maritime shipping operations by registering with the US Federal Maritime Commission via a Chinese subsidiary, Beijing Century Joyo Courier Service. This move aims to improve Amazon's ability to move goods into its logistics network and potentially reduce its reliance on outside shippers. The company has also been exploring air cargo options with drones and has plans to acquire French delivery group Colis Prive. Analysts believe Amazon's massive resources and experience with Amazon Web Services could enable it to run its own shipping and delivery operations, although it is an expensive bet.

site_title: The case for and against sustainability reporting
summary: Sustainability reporting may be a costly burden for listed companies in Singapore, particularly smaller ones, but proponents argue it provides crucial information on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks. Experts say meaningful disclosures can attract investors and lower a firm's cost of equity. However, critics warn that the costs may outweigh the benefits, and the information may be meaningless or boilerplate. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has released guidelines, but the effectiveness of these reports remains uncertain, with some arguing that companies may simply make generic statements rather than providing transparent and meaningful disclosures.

site_title: Check Point goes from safe stock to short sell
summary: Check Point Software Technologies Ltd, a leading firewall provider, has seen its stock price decline 13% in the past month and 12.9% of shares outstanding are now short sold. Analysts predict the company may have to sacrifice profits to stay competitive, with rival Palo Alto Networks forecast to report sales growth nearly five times faster. Despite this, Check Point remains a buy to the majority of analysts, citing its strong earnings and attractive pricing. The company is also in preliminary merger discussions with CyberArk.

site_title: Tsai vows to fix economy, keep peace with China
summary: Taiwan's President-elect Tsai Ing-wen has vowed to overhaul the country's struggling economy and maintain peace with China, despite her party's rejection of the 1992 consensus on Taiwan's status. Tsai, the first female president of Taiwan, won 56% of the vote, defeating the ruling Kuomintang party. Her Democratic Progressive Party has a slim majority in the legislature, but Tsai has not endorsed the 1992 consensus, which both sides agree on but disagree on. China has expressed concern over Tsai's stance, warning of strained relations and potential economic consequences.

site_title: Booming halal sector opens global path for local firms
summary: Singapore's halal sector is experiencing significant growth due to increasing global demand for halal products and services. The country's stringent food safety standards and well-recognized halal certification are attracting companies from emerging Muslim tourism markets, such as Japan and Korea. The global halal market is estimated to be worth over $1.1 trillion and potentially $10 trillion by 2030, presenting opportunities for local companies. Singapore's halal industry has been recognized as a success story, with the country's halal certification being sought after globally, and the government is positioning itself strategically in fronting the halal market.

site_title: Banks return China investment quotas as clients bypass middlemen
summary: Several global banks, including Barclays, Commerzbank, SEB, and ING, have returned US$800m in investment quotas granted by Chinese authorities under the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) scheme, citing declining demand and increased competition from alternative channels such as the Hong Kong Shanghai Stock Connect scheme. Quota rental fees have plummeted to 20 basis points from 200 basis points, making the business unprofitable for banks. The trend is expected to continue with the upcoming addition of the Shenzhen stock market to the Connect scheme.

site_title: Constructive about US stocks
summary: US stocks are seen as having a positive outlook in 2016 due to strong employment numbers, rising wages, and robust consumer confidence. The economy is expected to grow 2-3% annually, driven by the consumer sector, which accounts for two-thirds of the economy. The technology sector is also expected to perform well, with cloud computing and e-commerce driving growth. However, the industrials sector is seen as underweight due to depressed commodities and challenges in China.

site_title: Bright ideas on the right track
summary: Two new restaurants, Kite and Red Eye Smokehouse, have garnered attention for their youthful energy and innovative ideas. Kite, with its small plates concept, offers dishes like cold somen with garlic bits and warm shrimp, but is marred by distractions and inconsistencies. Red Eye Smokehouse, on the other hand, excels with its simple, affordable meats like smoked chicken thighs and gammon ham. Both restaurants show promise, but lack the sophistication of more established peers. With continued refinement, they may reach their full potential.

site_title: Belgium's ageing nuclear plants worry neighbours
summary: Belgium's seven ageing nuclear reactors at Doel and Tihange have raised concerns among its neighbours, the Netherlands, Germany, and Luxembourg, due to a series of problems including leaks, cracks, and unsolved sabotage incidents. The Belgian government has extended the life of some reactors until 2025, despite concerns from neighbours and environmental groups, who warn that the reactors are too old and vulnerable to accidents. Inspections and joint visits by officials from Belgium and its neighbours are planned to address the safety concerns, amid fears of a potential catastrophe similar to the Fukushima disaster in Japan.

site_title: Modi launches several initiatives to support India's startups
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi launched initiatives to support the country's startups, including a 100 billion rupee fund and tax breaks for companies and investors. The government also promised exemptions from tax and compliance inspections for three years. Modi urged entrepreneurs to create companies that solve India's problems and create jobs. The initiatives aim to accelerate India's economic recovery and create millions of jobs as the workforce expands.

site_title: US carmakers agree to share safety data
summary: US carmakers have agreed to share safety data with regulators, aiming to improve industry-wide collaboration and communication with consumers. The voluntary agreement, reached with 18 American and foreign carmakers, includes principles to increase recall response rates, analyze fatal accidents, and ward off digital attacks on vehicles. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) chief Mark Rosekind emphasized that the plan does not replace enforcement actions, but rather complements existing measures to enhance safety.

site_title: Investors want to see environmental, social and governance aspects
summary: Investors in Singapore increasingly demand environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information from companies, with 90% of institutional investors considering ESG factors in their investments. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) proposes introducing sustainability reporting on a "comply or explain" basis, allowing companies to identify material ESG risks and disclose policies and practices. The goal is to provide more informed information for investors, enabling them to assess a company's ESG risks and business case beyond financial figures.

site_title: China-led AIIB to have compliance unit to oversee management
summary: China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) will establish a compliance and integrity unit to oversee management, with a division of power and responsibility between the board and management. The unit will report directly to the board, aiming to meet China's pledge for high governance standards. The AIIB plans to raise capital and make loans, with a pipeline of projects and co-financing with institutions like the World Bank and Asian Development Bank. The bank aims to boost infrastructure investment and economic growth in Asia and the world, with Chinese President Xi Jinping stating it will enhance China's role as a global leader.

site_title: Iran set to boost oil exports once sanctions are lifted
summary: Iran plans to boost oil exports by 500,000 barrels a day once sanctions are lifted, aiming for an immediate increase and another 500,000 barrels within months. This move is expected to lower crude prices amid a global supply glut. The country's oil exports fell to 1.4 million barrels a day in 2014 due to US and EU sanctions, and now holds the world's fourth-largest reserves of crude. Iran's oil exports could raise output by 600,000 barrels a day over the next six months and add another 800,000 barrels daily this year.

site_title: Airport workers plan disruptions on Martin Luther King Jr Day
summary: US airport workers, part of the Service Employees International Union, plan civil disobedience on Martin Luther King Jr Day, seeking better wages, benefits, and job protections. Over 200 workers in nine cities, including Washington, will block bridges, march through terminals, and protest at airline headquarters, risking arrest. The campaign aims to raise awareness about low hourly wages, which force workers to take on multiple jobs to sustain their families, and alleged discrimination and hostile work environments.

site_title: More directors buying in a weak market
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

In a weak market, 20 companies in Singapore recorded 56 purchases worth S$11.74 million, with 30 companies posting 98 repurchases worth S$29.2 million. Directors and buyback activity remained high, with firms like BreadTalk Group, Global Palm Resources, and Raffles Education Corporation resuming buying back at lower prices. However, insider sales were also reported, with Dutech Holdings' CEO Johnny Liu Jiayan selling 650,000 shares. Despite the falls in share prices, some companies remain up due to previous purchases, with Primacy Investment's stake up by 121% since January 2013.

site_title: No sign of hard landing for China
summary: China's currency markets have weakened, with the Shanghai exchange dropping 7% on the first trading day of 2016, attributed to a weaker-than-expected PMI print and the impending expiration of a ban on sales by large stakeholders. However, the weakness is considered technical rather than fundamental, with the Chinese equity market carrying little leading information on global macroeconomic health. A gradual depreciation of the yuan may be encouraging outflows, particularly against the offshore yuan, but a one-off large devaluation could be preferable to drive down the trade-weighted exchange rate and mitigate risks for emerging markets.

site_title: KepLand buys 22.4% of 112 Katong for S$51.4m (Amended)
summary: Keppel Land acquired a 22.4% stake in 112 Katong lifestyle mall for S$51.4 million from BHG, BreadTalk, and Perennial. The remaining 77.6% is owned by Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund. Keppel Land will be the retail manager for the property. The deal is expected to strengthen the mall's positioning as a lifestyle and dining destination in the East. BreadTalk sold S$7.2 million of secured fixed-rate junior bonds as part of the deal, expecting to record a gain of S$8.5 million.

site_title: WP can propose alternative to fill Lee Li Lian's NCMP seat, says Grace Fu
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) can propose an alternative candidate to fill the vacant NCMP seat left by Lee Li Lian, who declined the offer. WP leader Grace Fu stated that the party must move a parliamentary motion to propose a new candidate. Lee Li Lian, who had 15,800 votes in her favor, had announced her decision not to take up the seat, citing the will of her constituents. WP has suggested Daniel Goh as a potential candidate if the motion is passed.

site_title: Oil glut grows and takes a toll globally
summary: The world is experiencing a severe oil glut, with a surplus of one million barrels of crude oil per day, enough to fuel all of Britain or Thailand. The price of oil has dropped below $30 a barrel, causing global stocks to sink sharply and investor anxiety to rise. The glut is attributed to a near doubling of US domestic oil production since 2008 and increased production from other countries, including Iran and Saudi Arabia. The industry is facing a painful shakeout, with many companies and countries at risk of financial damage.

site_title: Update: At least 20 dead in ongoing Burkina Faso hotel siege
summary: At least 20 people have been killed in an ongoing hotel siege in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, with 63 hostages rescued and 33 wounded. The attack, claimed by Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, is ongoing with French special forces supporting Burkinabe troops. The attackers, believed to be members of the Al-Murabitoun group, are still inside the hotel, and the death toll could rise. The attack comes less than two months after a similar incident in the Malian capital Bamako.

site_title: Investment in R&D is investing in Singapore's future: DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of investing in research and development (R&D) for Singapore's future. The country plans to allocate S$19 million over the next five years under its Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2020 plan, a 18% increase from the previous plan. This investment aims to create economic value, improve people's lives, and increase cross-border collaboration, ultimately building a knowledge-based economy and shaping Singapore's future.

site_title: Uber not to blame for rise in Manhattan traffic congestion, says report
summary: A New York City traffic report released by the mayor's office has found that ride-hailing services, including Uber, did not contribute to the recent increase in traffic congestion in Manhattan. The report attributed the congestion to population growth, more tourists, and an increase in deliveries and street construction. Despite the report's findings, Uber and its rival Lyft praised the mayor and the report, while experts expressed disappointment over the brevity and lack of supporting data. The city will consider legislation to reform the taxi and for-hire vehicle industries, but a cap on Uber's surge pricing was not included.

site_title: Apple could face Europe tax bill of over US$8b
summary: Apple may face a European tax bill of over $8 billion due to a European Commission investigation into its tax policies. The probe, launched in 2014, accuses Apple of using Irish subsidiaries to avoid paying taxes on revenue generated outside the US. If the commission decides to enforce a tougher accounting standard, Apple could owe taxes at a 12.5% rate on $64.1 billion in profit generated from 2004 to 2012. Apple has said it will appeal against an adverse ruling, and the decision could come as soon as March.

site_title: Sainsbury mulls over offer for Argos owner Home Retail Group
summary: Sainsbury is considering a potential £1.3 billion offer for Home Retail Group, the owner of Argos and Homebase, amid struggling sales for both retailers. A rejected cash-and-shares bid in November has given Sainsbury until Feb 2 to decide on a formal offer. The deal could produce cost benefits of £100-150 million and yield revenue growth from selling to each other's customers. Sainsbury has already expanded Argos concessions in its stores and has seen growth in its non-food sales. However, analysts question the feasibility of the deal, citing Sainsbury's declining margins.

site_title: Lessons from Lian Beng for remuneration committees
summary: Two Lian Beng Group Ltd independent directors resigned in 2015 due to disagreements with management over how performance bonuses for the chairman, managing director, and two executive directors should be computed. The disagreement centered on whether to include minority interest in the calculation, with the company's approach being to exclude it. The directors argued that including minority interest would be more aligned with shareholders' interests, and their alternative approach resulted in a potential S$2 million difference in bonuses for the 2014 financial year. The incident highlights the importance of remuneration committees carefully considering factors when determining management bonuses.

site_title: Maryland governor targets blight in Baltimore with plan to raze vacant buildings
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan has announced a plan to demolish thousands of vacant buildings in Baltimore, replacing them with parks and green space, and offering incentives to developers. The plan, which includes $75 million over four years, aims to address the city's blight problem. However, residents in the targeted Sandtown-Winchester neighborhood are skeptical, citing the need for affordable housing. Officials estimate 20 blocks will be demolished in the first year, with the state providing $600 million in financing for private developers. The move is seen as a step towards revitalizing the area, but concerns remain about the impact on long-term residents.

site_title: Odds of a bear market rising in US; earnings reports unlikely to lift spirits
summary: The US stock market is experiencing a decline, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Standard & Poor's 500 entering official correction territory. Earnings reports from banks and industrial companies are unlikely to lift investor spirits, and the odds of a bear market are rising. Oil futures have closed below $30 a barrel for the first time in over 12 years, and the Federal Reserve is monitoring "dislocations" in junk bond markets. Strategists believe some sectors, like financials and technology stocks, may recover faster than others, but a major bounce in energy, industrial, and material stocks is likely to come.

site_title: Amazon dips toes into maritime shipping
summary: Amazon has taken its first step into maritime shipping by registering with the US Federal Maritime Commission via a Chinese subsidiary. This move aims to improve its ability to move goods into its logistics network, potentially reducing its reliance on outside shippers like FedEx and UPS. Amazon has already announced plans to acquire French delivery group Colis Prive and is also exploring drone delivery, with regulatory approval pending. This entry into maritime shipping could be a significant move into the $350 billion ocean freight market.

site_title: Citi posts Q4 profit, revenue surge; braces for energy sector loss
summary: Citigroup reported a surge in Q4 profit and revenue, with adjusted profit reaching $3.4 billion, up from $340 million in the same period last year. Revenue exceeded analyst estimates at $18.6 billion. However, the bank's exposure to emerging markets and the energy sector, particularly China and oil prices, raised concerns about its ability to sustain earnings growth. Citigroup's total exposure to China was $20.5 billion, and its exposure to the energy sector was $58 billion. The bank's non-accrual corporate loans increased 32% due to strain in the oil and gas sector.

site_title: The business of halal certification
summary: The halal certification industry is experiencing significant growth, offering a global path for local firms. Royal Healthcare plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, while a startup by NUS researchers aims to reduce the cost of sustainable marine fuel by half. The halal sector is also driving innovation, such as rebranding heritage for the younger generation in the otah business. The growing demand for halal products and services is expected to create opportunities for local businesses, with OCBC targeting S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028.

site_title: China to invest additional US$50m in AIIB: President Xi
summary: China has announced an additional investment of US$50 million in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), marking a significant boost to the bank's operations. This investment is seen as a key foreign policy success for China, following the bank's establishment in 2015 as a response to delayed reforms at the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Keppel Reit divests Sydney property for A$160 million
summary: Keppel Reit is divesting its 100% interest in a Sydney building, 77 King Street, for A$160 million, resulting in a divestment gain of A$28 million. The sale is 40% above the original purchase price of A$116 million and 28% higher than the last valuation of A$126 million. The proceeds will be used to pay debt, fund corporate purposes, and invest in future opportunities, according to Keppel Reit Management.

site_title: 1978: A freer market and a historic blast
summary: In 1978, Singapore lifted its 40-year-old currency controls, allowing for a freer market and global financing. This move was welcomed by businesses and investors, enabling banks to provide unlimited global financing and investors to deal in US dollars. Meanwhile, a devastating explosion on the Greek tanker Spyros at Jurong Shipyard killed 76 people, prompting a workplace safety campaign. The Singapore Finance merger between Hong Leong Finance and United Overseas Bank was also a notable event, with Hong Leong emerging as the largest finance company at the time.

site_title: Europe's top soccer teams turn to US bond market for funding
summary: European soccer teams are turning to the US bond market for funding, with London-based XXIII Capital selling $73 million of bonds backed by media-rights payments and player-transfer fees. The bonds pay investors through cash streams, mostly insured, from agreements across top leagues. This move comes as soccer teams struggle to raise funds, having turned to boutique investment funds and esoteric securities in the past. The senior notes yielded a coupon of 3.7%, with sales of these securities rising 16% to $40 billion through November.

site_title: When big help may ultimately be no help
summary: Singapore's business community is calling for greater government support, but this approach may hinder building a nimble and creative economy. The Singapore Business Federation's position paper proposes increasing government intervention, including appointing a minister to oversee local enterprises and providing more reserves for firms to expand overseas. However, this reliance on government support can lead to a crutch mentality, where businesses rely too heavily on state assistance and avoid taking risks. To create a truly innovative culture, Singapore needs to strike a balance between government support and entrepreneurship, and consider unwinding aid schemes to encourage risk-taking and self-adjustment.

site_title: Foreign brewers eye China as locals develop taste for craft beers
summary: China's middle class is driving a shift towards premium beers, with imports and local craft beers gaining popularity. The country's affluent young professionals are willing to spend on brands, while many still consider beer affordable. Major brewers Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller are betting on premium products, with sales of their premium offerings making up nearly a quarter of their sales by volume. As the market moves towards premium offerings, the companies are expected to prune their portfolio in China, potentially divesting a domestic brand like Snow.

site_title: India's finance minister says will help bankers lend more
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced that the government and central bank will work together to increase banks' lending capacity over the next few months. This move aims to boost credit growth and support India's sluggish economic growth. The Reserve Bank of India and government will add to banks' ability to lend with greater vigor and amounts, addressing the issue of crippling bad debts and insufficient capital.

site_title: Tapping the power of connected data through the cloud
summary: The proliferation of connected devices is transforming the way we interact with each other and objects around us, with Asia expected to be at the forefront of the connected ecosystem revolution. Governments across Asia are pushing ahead with digital economy initiatives and smart city projects, leveraging cloud computing to harness data from billions of connected devices. Key examples include Singapore's Smart Nation programme, which uses cloud computing to support better living, and healthcare provider Lifetrack Medical Systems, which uses cloud-based solutions to accelerate radiology training. Other companies, such as GrabTaxi and Akindo Sushiro, are using cloud computing to improve location-based services and real-time analytics, respectively.

site_title: Softbank CEO says will 'seriously' accelerate investments in India
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son announced plans to "seriously accelerate" investments in India, exceeding the previously stated $10 billion over 10 years. He cited the growing mobile internet market as a key driver for increased investment. Son believes the Indian economy will be large enough to support significant investment, paving the way for a major expansion in the country.

site_title: Death toll in Indonesia attack rises to 8
summary: A militant attack in Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, has resulted in an 8-death toll, with 5 attackers among the dead. The attack, claimed by Islamic State, injured around 30 people and raised concerns about a resurgence of homegrown militancy. Police arrested 12 suspects linked to the attack, who planned further attacks in cities like Bandung. The incident highlights Indonesia's vulnerability to extremist groups despite its efforts to suppress homegrown militancy.

site_title: StarHub partners Netflix to offer streaming service
summary: StarHub has partnered with Netflix to offer its streaming service to Fibre TV customers, with access expected by the second quarter of this year. Customers can pay for subscriptions via their StarHub bills. This partnership comes days after Singtel signed a similar deal with Netflix. StarHub's chief marketing officer, Howie Lau, stated that the partnership provides convenience for customers and a seamless viewing experience.

site_title: Nuclear sanctions lifted as Iran, US agree on prisoner swap
summary: The US and Iran have agreed on a prisoner swap, resulting in the lifting of crippling nuclear sanctions against Iran. The deal, which also includes the release of five American hostages, including Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, allows Iran to unfreeze tens of billions of dollars in assets and re-enter the global market. The agreement reduces hostility between Tehran and Washington, but its long-term impact is uncertain, with US Republicans expressing skepticism and Iran's allies in the Middle East viewing the move with suspicion.

site_title: China to raise offshore yuan reserve requirements for some banks-sources
summary: China's central bank is set to raise the reserve requirement ratio for yuan deposits placed in yuan clearing banks from January 25 to stem speculation in the currency. The move aims to soak up liquidity in the offshore yuan market, where the currency has fallen to its lowest since 2010. The People's Bank of China will return the reserve requirement ratio to a normal level, increasing the cost of arbitrage and controlling domestic banks conducting exchanges offshore. The move follows pressure from policy advisers to let the currency fall quickly and sharply.

site_title: Yahoo says Canyon Capital letter to board contains misperceptions
summary: Yahoo responded to a letter from investor Canyon Capital, stating that the letter contained misperceptions about the company's spending on acquisitions. The company emphasized its commitment to acting as good stewards of capital and delivering sustainable shareholder value. Yahoo plans to share more details on its future plans during its upcoming earnings call. This comes amid increased pressure from activist investor Starboard Value LP, which has raised concerns about CEO Marissa Mayer's leadership.

site_title: Keppel Land acquires stake in 112 Katong for S$51.4m
summary: Keppel Land acquired a 22.4% stake in 112 Katong lifestyle mall for S$51.4m through its subsidiary DC Reit Holdings. The remaining 77.6% is owned by Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund (AAMTF), managed by Alpha Investment Partners. Keppel Land Retail Management will also manage the property. The deal is expected to have no material impact on Keppel Land's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Banks give back China investment quotas as clients bypass the middlemen
