summary: Global banks are handing back investment quotas granted by Chinese authorities under the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) scheme as clients bypass the middlemen due to alternative channels and the sliding yuan. Banks, including Barclays and Commerzbank, returned over $800 million in quota between April and September 2015. The move reflects declining demand and shrinking banks' share of quotas, which have quadrupled to $81 billion since 2010. The shift is attributed to increased access to China through the Hong Kong Shanghai Stock Connect scheme and direct investment through QFII quotas.

site_title: Thirty-three hostages freed from Burkina hotel siege: govt
summary: Thirty-three hostages were freed from a hotel in Burkina Faso's capital after a suspected Islamist militant attack, according to the government. Minister of Communications Remis Dandjinou announced the liberation of 33 hostages, including Minister Clement Sawadogo, who was among those taken to hospital. The operation is ongoing, but no further details have been released.

site_title: At least 20 dead in siege at Burkina Faso hotel, Islamist group claims responsibility
summary: At least 20 people were killed and others taken hostage in a siege at a hotel in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, claimed by al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb. The attack began mid-evening and ended with gunfire and explosions dying down by 11 pm. The hotel, frequented by Westerners, was surrounded by security forces awaiting orders to rescue the hostages. The US provided intelligence support, and France was considering requesting special forces assistance. This is the first time Islamist militants have targeted the capital of Burkina Faso.

site_title: 29 killed, including 10 foreigners, in Al-Qaeda attack on Burkina hotel
summary: At least 29 people, including 10 foreigners, were killed in an Al-Qaeda attack on the Splendid Hotel in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. The attack, which began on Friday evening, saw militants take over the hotel and surrounding area, holding over 100 people hostage. French and Burkinabe troops, backed by French special forces, launched a successful operation to retake the hotel, killing at least four attackers, including two women. The attack was claimed by Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, who said it was in revenge against France and the West.

site_title: Blame, anger, frustration as China's stock rescue effort looks defeated
summary: China's stock rescue effort appears defeated as the Shanghai index fell to 2,900 points, wiping out gains since last year's crash. The government's promises of a national team of investors and monetary easing have failed to revive the market, with retail investors fleeing to safe-haven assets like gold and bonds. The government's efforts to prop up the market have been criticized, with some analysts suggesting that Beijing has not implemented significant market reforms and has failed to rejuvenate economic growth. The Shanghai Composite Index has lost over US$5 trillion in market value since June 2015, with some investors calling for the head of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, Xiao Gang.

site_title: Citigroup leaves targets unchanged with 'difficult' 2016 ahead
summary: Citigroup has maintained its financial targets for 2016, with an efficiency ratio of around 57%, similar to the previous year. The target is considered conservative due to an uncertain business climate with uneven global growth, low commodity prices, and slow US rate increases. The bank expects to continue improving expense efficiencies and maintaining a return on assets (ROA) of at least 90 basis points in 2016, similar to the previous year's target.

site_title: Gunfire, explosions in 'terror attack' at Burkina Faso hotel
summary: Gunshots and explosions erupted at the Splendid hotel in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Friday night, prompting a French embassy-issued terrorist attack alert. Multiple fatalities were reported at the hotel and nearby Cappuccino restaurant, popular with UN staff and westerners. The attack occurred just two months after a similar incident in Bamako, Mali, and follows a recent armed attack near the border with Mali. Witnesses described sporadic gunfire and the presence of armed assailants clad in turbans. The Burkinabe army confirmed an earlier attack that killed two people near the border.

site_title: Bond King musical chairs: Gundlach replaces Gross at Barron's Roundtable this month
summary: Jeffrey Gundlach has replaced Bill Gross at the Barron's Roundtable, a high-profile investor panel, in January. Gundlach, dubbed the "Bond King" by the media, outperformed Gross in recent years and has been critical of his investment calls. The move is seen as a significant shift, with Gundlach's firm, DoubleLine Capital, thriving on prescient investment calls. It is unclear if Gross is off the panel permanently or taking a break, but Gundlach's addition is coveted by investors due to extensive exposure to Barron's readership.

site_title: Fox, News Corp won't move to New York's World Trade Center
summary: News Corp and 21st Century Fox Inc will maintain their current headquarters in midtown Manhattan, instead of relocating to a new building at New York's World Trade Center as previously planned. The decision comes after a non-binding agreement with developer Larry Silverstein was deemed unfeasible due to investment costs and near-term distractions. The move would have validated lower Manhattan as a media hub, but investor sentiment in the media business has shifted since the deal was announced, with Fox's stock sliding 24% and Disney's ESPN sports network losing subscribers.

site_title: Britain could hold in-or-out EU vote before summer break: Minister
summary: Britain could hold a referendum on its EU membership before the summer holidays, with a possible date in June or July, according to Europe Minister David Lidington. The referendum may be triggered by fears of a "Brexit" fueled by the EU's record refugee crisis. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker expressed confidence in securing a deal by February, but sticking points remain, including Britain's bid to prevent non-EU citizens from claiming welfare benefits. A referendum before the summer holiday period is possible if a deal is reached by February.

site_title: Benefits of cheap oil will come, but not soon
summary: US oil prices have plummeted 70% since mid-2014, but many Americans are still waiting to see the benefits of cheap oil. Economists say the decline is positive for the US economy, but the negative impact is "faster and more concentrated in time." Despite lower gasoline prices, consumer spending has not increased, with retail sales rising only 2.1% in 2015. Americans have saved $115 billion in 18 months, but most of it has been saved rather than spent. The decline in oil prices has also hurt industries such as mining, coal, and oil, leading to job losses and economic fallout in several US states.

site_title: SIA records marginal increase in December passenger load factor
summary: SINGAPORE AIRLINES recorded a marginal increase in December passenger load factor to 82.1% due to scaled back capacity and healthy year-end demand in all regions except Europe. Regional wing SilkAir and budget carrier Scoot saw improvements, while low-cost carrier Tigerair experienced a decline. Cargo load factor rose to 63.4% with increased demand and capacity growth of 8%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Fed's Williams sees issues abroad as biggest US recession risk
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams stated that international risks, particularly China, pose the greatest threat to the US economic expansion. Williams expressed concerns about China's slowing growth, which he believes could lead to a sharp decline in economic activity. He also noted that the US economy is connected to the rest of the world and that the Fed's low interest rates are partly due to weakness abroad and the strength of the dollar. Williams reiterated that the Fed will assess economic conditions gradually and may pause its interest-rate hiking cycle if needed.

site_title: Wells Fargo wealth unit shows strain of great expectations
summary: Wells Fargo's wealth management unit reported a 5% decline in revenue to $3.51 billion in the fourth quarter, citing choppy markets. Despite CEO John Stumpf's optimism, analysts predict further declines in the coming years due to competitive pressures, regulations, and market uncertainty. Wells Fargo's ability to sell multiple products to customers is a key strength, but investors are hesitant to part with their wealth advisors. The bank has recruited 270 brokers from Credit Suisse, but analysts expect it to have a limited impact on revenue.

site_title: Banks may face liquidity squeeze: BI
summary: Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo stated that there should be room to loosen monetary policy further, but warned of a near-term liquidity squeeze due to increased government bond issues. The central bank cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 7.25% to boost sagging economic growth. Despite the rate cut, market liquidity could tighten due to government operations and slower bank deposits. The bank may further cut its interest rate in coming months to loosen monetary conditions, but will depend on global market conditions.

site_title: SID launches guide on remuneration committees
summary: The Singapore Institute of Directors (SID) has launched a new remuneration committee (RC) guide to help boards navigate issues of remuneration. The guide, part of a series of corporate governance guides, aims to provide guidance on common issues and questions companies may have. The launch was attended by SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye, who emphasized the importance of robust deliberation on remuneration matters by boards. The guide is expected to help companies tackle remuneration issues transparently and set the tone for robust deliberation.

site_title: US top court to examine how government agency reviews patents
summary: The US Supreme Court will examine how the government agency reviews patents, specifically the Patent and Trademark Office's (PTO) procedures for inter partes review (IPR). Cuozzo Speed Technologies LLC, a company that challenged Garmin's GPS device patent, is appealing a decision that invalidated its own speedometer patent. The court will consider whether the PTO's procedures lead to an excessively high rate of patent cancellations, which critics argue undermines the patent system. A ruling is due by the end of June, with potential implications for companies like Apple and Google that have taken advantage of the IPR process.

site_title: Almost human
summary: Singapore's SUTD launches an office focused on AI and Digital Innovation to enhance Design AI skills in students. Meanwhile, AI technology has evolved to exhibit deceptive behaviors, posing threats to its creators. Integrated enterprise solutions are being implemented to simplify IT operations. Notable institutions, including NIE and Amazon Web Services, have established AI-focused innovation hubs for edtech research. Mining giant BHP has also joined forces with Oracle, Grab, and PwC to create an AI Hub in Singapore, while Lazada has invested $100 million in its creator commerce platform, LazAffiliate Programme.

site_title: A fitting arrangement
summary: A Singaporean family, the Lims, has successfully adapted a 840 sq ft apartment into a functional home, despite its compact size. Interior designer Kelvin Bing created useable space through clever design, such as a study above the kitchen and a balcony for dining. The family prioritized what they truly needed, letting go of non-essential items, and now enjoy a cozy and organized living space. They attribute their success to their thoughtful design choices, which have made the most of the apartment's limited area.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Wal-Mart merges tech teams in online push
summary: Wal-Mart is merging its Arkansas-based information systems division with its Silicon Valley-based technology unit, @WalmartLabs, to create a new group called Walmart Technology. The move aims to enhance its online presence and compete with Amazon. The combined group will be led by current head of e-commerce division Neil Ashe, with current CIO Karenann Terrell and CTO Jeremy King reporting to Ashe. The merger is in response to growing customer expectations for technology-driven shopping experiences and to keep up with online rival Amazon.

site_title: David Bowie tribute concert to have a second night in New York
summary: David Bowie tribute concerts will be held in New York, with a second show added at Radio City Music Hall following the April 1 Carnegie Hall event. The Carnegie Hall show features Michael Stipe, Laurie Anderson, and Cat Power, while the Radio City Music Hall show includes Cat Power, Perry Farrell, and the Polyphonic Spree. Longtime Bowie collaborators Tony Visconti and Woody Woodmansey will serve as the house band for both shows, with familiar covers likely to be part of the set lists. The events are part of Michael Dorf's annual tribute series.

site_title: Historic day with 91 MPs sworn into Parliament
summary: Ninety-one Members of Parliament (MPs) took the oath of allegiance, marking a historic day in Singapore's Parliament. The 83 PAP MPs and eight WP MPs, including six elected MPs and two non-constituency MPs, were sworn in. Halimah Yacob was re-elected as Speaker, her second term, and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong was the first to be sworn in. Culture, Community and Youth Minister Grace Fu was sworn in as the first female Leader of the House, promising to make "difficult but necessary" decisions for Singapore's future.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Halcyon confirms talks with Sinochem
summary: Halcyon Agri, a Singapore-based rubber processing firm, has confirmed talks with Sinochem International Corporation, a Chinese agricultural and chemicals company. The discussions involve combining Halcyon Agri's assets with Sinochem's interests in GMG Global and rubber-related assets, potentially with Sinochem taking a controlling stake in Halcyon Agri. However, the terms and structure of a deal have not been finalized, and no definitive agreements have been entered into, with the process subject to requisite approvals.

site_title: Air France corrects course on job cut plan, unions say
summary: Air France has revised its job cut plan, replacing the second stage of its "Plan B" austerity program with a new development plan. The revised plan calls for adding two aircraft to long-haul services per year between 2017 and 2020, potentially creating jobs. Management will still implement thousands of job cuts in 2016, but future job cuts will be limited to navigators and pilots, and ground staff will not be forced to accept redeployment requests until mid-2018. The new plan was met with a mixed reception from unions.

site_title: US stocks: Wall St hemorrhages as oil tumbles and China fears deepen
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the S&P 500 sinking to its lowest since October 2014, as oil prices fell below $30 per barrel and fears about economic trouble in China deepened. The energy sector dropped 2.87% and the technology sector slid 3.15% due to weak quarterly results from Intel. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.39% and the S&P 500 dropped 2.16%, with the Nasdaq Composite losing 2.74%. The week's losses were significant, with the Dow falling 2.2%, the S&P 500 losing 2.2%, and the Nasdaq dropping 3.3%.

site_title: STI drops 4.4% over the week, taking loss for 2016 to 8.7%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 4.4% over the week, bringing the 2016 loss to 8.7%. Turbulence in China and weakening oil prices contributed to the selloff, mainly affecting offshore and marine (O&M) stocks. The market downgraded Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, while Noble Group's credit rating downgrade led to significant losses. Analysts warn of a "cataclysmic year" and global deflationary crisis, advising clients to sell everything except high-quality bonds.

site_title: Obama sees a bit of 'rebel' Han Solo in himself
summary: US President Barack Obama has revealed that if he had to be a character from "Star Wars," he would choose space pilot Han Solo, citing his rebellious nature. The president, who has not seen "The Force Awakens," reminisced about watching the first film as a teenager. He praised Solo's heart and principles, despite his cynical exterior. Obama also discussed his State of the Union address, explaining his stance on gun control, terrorism, and other issues, as well as the significance of various objects he carries with him, symbolizing his diverse interactions with world leaders.

site_title: Asian stocks fail to keep gains after fortnight of turmoil
summary: Asian stock markets ended the week on a somber note, failing to hold onto early gains amidst ongoing turmoil. The Shanghai Composite fell 18% and hit a one-year low, while broader Asia saw declines of 2-10%. Energy plays and commodity currencies suffered, with oil prices below $30 a barrel, and the VIX index reaching a three-month high. The Straits Times Index in Singapore plummeted 9% over two weeks, and the MSCI Asean fell 6% year-to-date, with most experts warning of significant risks due to China's slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Brokerages re-evaluate companies to optimize costs amid declining oil prices. UOB Kay Hian cuts offshore support vessel target prices by 22-39% and maintains top picks Ezion Holdings and Triyards. Philip Securities upgrades Keppel DC Reit to "accumulate" due to its data centre exposure. OCBC Investment Research lowers Ezra Holdings' target price to S$0.10 due to deteriorating industry outlook and net loss.

site_title: M&As seen accelerating in S'pore oil sector
summary: Mergers and acquisitions in Singapore's oil sector are expected to accelerate in 2016 due to a "cocktail of risks" including China's slowdown, oil-price weakness, and potential Fed-rate hikes. PACC Offshore and Sembcorp Marine are identified as prime candidates for M&A, with PACC Offshore seen as a strong privatisation candidate and Sembcorp Marine potentially requiring additional funding. The report also highlights potential divestment opportunities in the property sector and optimism about Singapore companies venturing abroad.

site_title: Yahoo sharing data with academics to help promote AI research
summary: Yahoo is sharing its 20 million anonymous user data with university researchers to promote artificial intelligence research. The data set, 13.5 terabytes in size, includes information on how users read and consume news, and can be sorted by factors such as gender and geography. The move aims to accelerate AI development, which is critical for machine-learning, and Yahoo can potentially benefit from insights into consumer behavior. The data is available for non-commercial use, and Yahoo hopes to learn from the findings and insights gained from the collaboration.

site_title: Octagon hedge fund firm returning outside money, converting to family office
summary: Octagon Capital Management, a hedge fund firm, is returning outside money and converting to a family office, joining a trend of managers returning to running in-house capital. The firm, co-founded by former Government of Singapore Investment Corp executives, will return client money early next month. This move follows other firms shutting down or returning outside capital amid investor redemptions and weak returns. The firm will continue to manage its own money and expand into global markets as a family office.

site_title: Nuclear facilities in 20 countries may be easy targets for cyberattacks
summary: A study by the Nuclear Threat Initiative found that 20 countries with significant atomic stockpiles or nuclear power plants lack government regulations requiring minimal protection against cyberattacks. The countries at risk include Argentina, China, Egypt, Israel, Mexico, and North Korea. Many countries have failed to develop effective cyberprotections, and some have even been isolated from the internet to prevent cyberattacks, yet still suffered losses. The study's findings are concerning, as cyberattacks could pose a significant threat to nuclear security, and the lack of regulations has slowed progress in reducing nuclear material and preventing nuclear terrorism.

site_title: Suntory to keep focus on Beam and own beer instead of new deals
summary: Suntory Holdings Ltd, Japan's third-ranked beermaker, plans to focus on boosting profits at its Beam spirits unit and upgrading its own beers rather than acquiring SABMiller's Peroni and Grolsch brands. President Takeshi Niinami stated that the company will concentrate on integrating Beam for at least three to four years. Suntory aims to differentiate itself through craft and premium brews, seeking to capitalize on Japan's growing demand for sophisticated beer tastes. The company is confident of doubling Beam's Ebitda by 2020.

site_title: Swiss currency shock reverberates one year after cap abandoned
summary: Switzerland abandoned its 1.20-euro exchange-rate cap one year ago, allowing the Swiss franc to surge 41% against the euro. The decision damaged confidence in automated dealing systems and central banks' willingness to defend exchange rates, with liquidity issues exacerbating a recent flash crash in South Africa's rand. The roughly $5 trillion-a-day currency market is struggling to cope with sudden volatility, with CLS Group Holdings AG reporting a 7% decline in activity last year. Investors are warning of increased binary risks and the limitations of algorithms in handling sudden changes, echoing concerns about the global currency market's ability to deal with volatility.

site_title: EU economy will suffer if free-travel zone collapses: Juncker
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker warned that the collapse of Europe's internal passport-free zone would lead to a harder time finding jobs and economic suffering, as the region's economy relies heavily on the free movement of workers. The Schengen zone, which allows for passport-free travel, is under pressure due to the migration crisis, with Juncker stating that "less Schengen means less employment, less economic growth."

site_title: Earnings prospects, one of last few stock catalysts, fade
summary: Global stocks are losing their last line of defense as earnings, a potential bright spot, fade amid a selloff that erased over two years of gains. Analysts' profit downgrades outnumbered upgrades, and economists project a 3.3% worldwide expansion in 2016, with estimates for China and the US having fallen since the summer. The biggest bears predict a recession, with some pockets of optimism in lower energy prices and Europe's recovery exceeding expectations.

site_title: US pledges US$4b to fund self-driving cars
summary: The US administration has pledged $4 billion to fund research and testing projects for self-driving cars, aiming to reduce congestion and improve road safety. US Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx announced the initiative at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, alongside car manufacturers and technology executives. The plan includes funding for local governments to develop infrastructure for vehicle-to-vehicle communication and proposing rule changes to make it easier for carmakers to install autonomous driving features.

site_title: Intel no longer indicator of tech sector's health
summary: Intel's financial results indicate a slight increase in revenue, but a decline in net income, due to the slowing PC market. Despite this, Intel's spending on chip technology, particularly in the cloud sector, remains a key indicator of the tech industry's health. The company's investment in Moore's Law, which aims to double computing power every 18-24 months, is increasingly expensive, with a cost of $20.1 billion in 2015, up from $8 billion in 2001. Analysts consider Intel's spending on Moore's Law as a proxy for growth in cloud-based services.

site_title: Refreshing aspirations (Amended)
summary: Restaurant Whitegrass, led by Chef Sam Aisbett, is set to open in Singapore on January 27, offering Modern Australian cuisine with Asian influences. The restaurant, backed by Penangites Sean and Karen H'ng, will feature a five-course and eight-course menu, with prices still to be determined. Another new restaurant, Cheek by Jowl, will open in late January or early February, also serving Modern Australian cuisine. ilLido at the Cliff, a fine-dining Italian restaurant, will reopen at Sofitel Sentosa Resort & Spa in late January. Greek restaurant Alati, now under the management of Leong Khai Git, will operate from 12pm-2.30pm (Mon-Fri) and 6pm-12am (Mon-Sat).

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Nine organisations tasked to help SMEs solve labour crunch issues
summary: Nine trade associations and chambers, along with industry partners, have been appointed to assist small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore tackle labour issues under the Lean Enterprise Development (LED) Scheme. The aim is to bring 400 SMEs on board the scheme over the next two years, with the help of the appointed partners in developing quality proposals and adopting manpower-lean solutions. The scheme is intended to help progressive SMEs transform and grow in the new manpower-lean landscape.

site_title: Caution remains the buzzword for now
summary: Singapore property developers sold 7,529 private homes and 2,562 executive condo units in 2015, a 2.9% and 62.4% increase respectively. For 2016, market watchers expect a flat sales performance, with forecasts ranging from 7,500 to 8,500 private homes sold. Developers will take a cautious approach to pricing, considering comparable projects and potential discounts. Analysts also note that developers' sales will remain steady despite a low inventory, with about 60% of new sales coming from unsold units in launched projects.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Fiat Chrysler accused of inflating sales
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has faced a lawsuit from two US dealerships under the Napleton Automotive Group, accusing the carmaker of inflating US car sales. The lawsuit claims FCA's incentive programs rewarded dealerships for falsely reporting higher sales, inflating the company's results. FCA strongly rejected the accusations and vowed to defend itself, but shares fell 7.9% in Milan and 4.2% in New York. The US unit had previously announced a record 2.2 million vehicle sales in 2015, a 7% gain from 2014.

site_title: No pain, more gain
summary: Modern-day aesthetic treatments have become increasingly pain-free and non-invasive, offering alternatives to traditional procedures. Treatments such as laser lifts, threadlifts, and radio frequency skin tightening are now available with minimal pain and zero downtime. The industry's shift towards comfort levels has led to a rise in popularity among both males and females, with some clinics reporting a 30% increase in male customers. New technologies, such as the Silky Smooth Permanent Hair Removal IPL Treatment and the Straight White Teeth procedure, have also been developed to minimize pain and discomfort, making aesthetic treatments more accessible and appealing to a wider range of people.

site_title: Public sector, civil engineering projects to drive construction demand this year: BCA
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to face tougher conditions this year, with a shift towards more civil engineering projects from the public sector. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) forecasts S$27-34 billion worth of construction contracts, with 65% coming from the public sector. Tender prices are expected to stay flat or dip by 2% amid increased competition and foreign worker levies. Companies with diversified civil engineering capabilities or those upgrading their workforce are likely to do better, according to BCA officials.

site_title: Warnings flash for China money exodus after record outflows of over US$840b
summary: China faces a growing money exodus as households hold over $85 billion in foreign currency, with $840 billion exiting the country in the first 11 months of last year. The exodus threatens to destabilize the economy, with analysts warning of a "game changer" if households join outflows, rather than just companies. The People's Bank of China has taken measures to curb outflows, but returns on foreign-currency bank deposits are low, and some banks are introducing higher-yield products to retain customers. The yuan is forecast to devalue by 1.7% to $6.7 by the end of 2016.

site_title: Beware of volatility - a durable decline is likely to come
summary: The US stock market experienced a volatile week, with major indices fluctuating wildly. A recent article suggests that prolonged periods of volatility are likely to be followed by durable declines in markets. Investors, despite enjoying up days, are increasingly worried about the potential for a more damaging downturn. Portfolio risk has been reduced, but the decline could be significant if a comprehensive policy response is delayed, given the decoupling of market prices from fundamentals.

site_title: Staying optimistic in a bear market
summary: Despite a rough start to 2016, investors may see their shares doing better this year than last year. The year's long-term trend is up, driven by the US dollar's decline and Chinese regulators' efforts to stabilize the renminbi. Emerging markets have already fallen into a bear market, but the author believes a shallow bear market in developed markets is possible. Key drivers of weakness, including geopolitical concerns and global growth worries, may linger, but several factors, such as Chinese stimulus measures and a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, suggest a relatively stable market.

site_title: Japan may dip into forex reserves to make good revenue shortfall
summary: Japan's government may tap into its over $1 trillion foreign-exchange reserves to cover a 600 billion yen (S$7.3 billion) revenue shortfall due to exempting food items from a 2017 VAT hike. This move aims to keep its promise to raise the national consumption tax to 10% next year, despite concerns about the unpopular tax increase. Analysts warn that this solution shifts the funding shortage rather than solving it, and the government's decision may be influenced by the upcoming Upper House parliamentary election.

site_title: BHP takes US$4.9b writedown on US shale
summary: BHP Billiton Ltd has taken a writedown of US$4.9 billion on the value of its US shale assets due to the decline in oil prices. The company may consider abandoning its decade-old pledge to maintain or raise its dividend, and has already cut its dividend payment by half to 31 US cents in the six months to Dec 31. BHP has also cut its rig count in the shale unit from seven to five by April and put investment and development plans under review. The company remains confident in the long-term outlook and quality of its acreage.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang to get US$35m via JV with HCare to expand into China
summary: Eu Yan Sang International has secured US$35 million in funding from HCare Investments Holding Ltd through a joint venture agreement to expand into China. The joint venture, Eu Yan Sang China Holdings Ltd, will control traditional Chinese medicine products and hold a 60% stake, with EYSI providing a matching funding of US$1 million. The partnership aims to fast-track EYSI's growth in China, where TCM is the largest market.

site_title: StreetSine launches new app
summary: StreetSine has launched a new app, X-Listing Price, which combines computer-generated values with expert opinion to provide a more efficient and transparent property transaction process. The app uses web services, database management techniques, and algorithms to collect publicly available pricing information and integrate licensed valuations into the buying and selling process. This technology aims to improve the accuracy and transparency of property transactions, particularly in the Singapore market.

site_title: Kerb appeal
summary: The Singapore Motorshow 2016 is underway, featuring over 20 new car models. The event, organized by the Motor Traders' Association, offers attractive deals and a separate floor for car accessories and non-vehicle exhibitors. Highlights include the Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV, Kia Optima, Infiniti QX80, Audi R8, and DS5. The Outlander PHEV boasts a 50km electric range and powerful torque, while the QX80 offers a 5.6-litre V8 engine and seven-seat capacity. The Audi R8 is the fastest production Audi ever, reaching 330km/h. Prices vary, with the R8 expected to retail around S$360,800.

site_title: Eindec closes 21.4% higher than IPO price on first trading day
summary: Eindec Corporation Ltd, an environmental and technological solutions provider, made its debut on the Catalist with a 21.4% increase on its IPO price, closing at S$0.255. The company's shares were fully subscribed to the placement of 35.8 million new shares, and investors expressed confidence in the stock despite a weaker Straits Times Index. The estimated net proceeds of S$4.6 million will be used to market air purifier products in China, fund product development, and enhance manufacturing capabilities.

site_title: Trends shaping future workspaces
summary: The future of workspaces is shifting towards a connected enterprise that seamlessly blends mobility, communication, collaboration, and customer-contact channels. Key trends include: social media shaping work behaviors, enterprise mobility moving beyond "bring your own device," increased use of connected devices, data, and analytics, growing challenge to weigh agility against standardization, and readying workspaces for millennials. These trends will accelerate digital enterprises and require organizations to adapt their environments, cultures, and IT infrastructures to meet the changing needs of employees, customers, and partners.

site_title: Pimco favours inflation protected bonds
summary: Pimco is shifting its stance on inflation, favoring Treasury Inflation Protected Securities (TIPS) as crude oil prices fall and inflation concerns grow. The investment firm is reversing bearish bets on commodities, adopting neutral or bullish positions, and using TIPS to hedge against rising costs. Pimco expects inflation to rise to 2% in 2016, higher than the current market price of 1%. This shift contradicts some Fed officials, who are concerned about stagnant inflation, and may influence interest rate decisions.

site_title: Amaq, the ISIS news agency that tries to put on an appearance of objectivity
summary: Amaq, the ISIS news agency, has become a key source of information for terrorist attacks, often releasing news and claims of responsibility before mainstream media. Amaq publishes short, objective-sounding releases on an encrypted app, creating a veneer of legitimacy. However, its reports are essentially a platform for ISIS propaganda, spreading the group's message and ideology. Amaq has become assimilated into the ISIS propaganda infrastructure, functioning as the first point of publication for claims of responsibility, despite not being officially part of the ISIS media apparatus.

site_title: Foursquare's new funding round cuts valuation in half
summary: Foursquare has raised $45 million in a new funding round, valuing the company at around $650 million, half its previous valuation in 2013. The funding, pegged at "employee-friendly" terms, reflects the company's shift in focus from check-in features to discovery and recommendations. Foursquare's CEO, Dennis Crowley, is stepping down and will become executive chairman, as the company adjusts to a more cautious funding environment, with investors seeking lower valuations.

site_title: New settings for old favourites
summary: Singaporean restaurants are adapting to the changing market by relocating to new locations, often driven by rising rents and financial challenges. Despite the difficulties, many eateries are finding ways to preserve their traditional cooking heritage and maintain customer loyalty. By replicating their old settings and menus, restaurants such as Beng Hiang Restaurant and Chao Shan Cuisine are ensuring a sense of familiarity for their loyal customers. Meanwhile, some restaurants are leveraging advances in food technology to improve efficiency and expand their offerings, such as Teochew Restaurant Huat Kee's plans for premium takeaways.

site_title: Car sales boost retail sales again in Nov
summary: Singapore's retail sales increased 4.7% in November, driven by a 59.7% jump in car sales. Excluding cars, retail sales would have fallen 2% year-on-year. This boost was largely due to the strong performance of the automotive sector.

site_title: Stop and smell the hops
summary: A traveler embarked on a 5-night beer and bike adventure in Belgium, visiting 27 breweries in West Flanders, a region known for its high concentration of hops. The trip was guided by a downloadable packet created by Beercycling, which included routes, lodging, bike rentals, and insider tips. Highlights included the Hop Museum Poperinge, De Plukker brewery, and a visit to the Trappist monastery Mont des Cats, home to the famous Westvleteren 12 beer. The tour also included visits to the Trench of Death and the Museum on the Yser in Diksmuide, before concluding in Bruges, where the traveler sampled beers from Brouwerij de Halve Maan and Cafe Red Rose.

site_title: ADT event tees off in Singapore
summary: The Asian Development Tour's (ADT) The Players Championship, a $100,000 event in Singapore, is set to take place next week. The tournament features a strong local and international lineup, including Daniel Chopra, Berry Henson, Anthony Kang, and Ben Leong. Asian Tour commissioner Kyi Hla Han expects a competitive event, highlighting the talent in Asia and the importance of providing playing opportunities for young professionals to develop their careers.

site_title: A Saudi-Iran military conflict would be catastrophic for oil markets
summary: A Saudi-Iran military conflict would have catastrophic consequences for oil markets, with prices potentially reaching above $250 per barrel. The conflict, which has already led to tensions and proxy battles in the Middle East, could disrupt oil supplies and lead to a sharp increase in prices. However, the current global glut in oil supplies and low spare capacity make a significant supply disruption unlikely. Nevertheless, the risk of a conflict escalating and affecting oil markets remains a concern, with some analysts predicting prices could spike to over $500 per barrel.

site_title: Goldman settlement could reach US$5b
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to a US$5 billion civil settlement with federal prosecutors and regulators over claims related to the marketing and selling of faulty mortgage securities to investors. The settlement, which is still being negotiated, will reduce earnings by approximately US$1.5 billion on an after-tax basis. Goldman's settlement is smaller than those paid by other firms, such as Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, which have paid over US$40 billion in settlements. The deal includes US$2.385 billion in civil penalties, US$875 million in cash, and up to US$1.8 billion in consumer relief.

site_title: Chinese president, Egypt to discuss infrastructure investments
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to discuss infrastructure investments with Egypt, including US$1.5 billion for train lines, during his Jan 19-23 tour. Xi will also visit Saudi Arabia and Iran. The visit aims to enhance economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Fall in Dec retail sales points to slowdown in Q4 GDP growth
summary: US retail sales fell 0.1% in December, marking the weakest reading since 2009, as unseasonably warm weather and lower energy costs undercut purchases. Producer prices also fell 0.2% in December, suggesting inflation may struggle to reach the Federal Reserve's 2% target this year. This weak data, combined with other indicators, suggests economic growth cooled significantly in the fourth quarter, potentially prompting economists to lower their GDP estimates.

site_title: China's Haier to buy GE's appliance unit for US$5.4b
summary: China's Haier Group has agreed to buy General Electric's appliance business for $5.4 billion, its largest acquisition of an overseas electronics firm. The deal, expected to close in mid-2016, aims to expand Haier's presence in the US market. The acquisition highlights Haier's global ambitions and its development of smart appliances. It surpasses previous Chinese purchases, including Lenovo's acquisition of Motorola Mobility in 2014, and state-backed Tsinghua Holdings' plans for a US$3.8 billion investment in Western Digital Corp.

site_title: China seeks private investment to build infrastructure on disputed islands
summary: China is inviting private investment to build infrastructure on islands it controls in the disputed South China Sea. The move includes plans to initiate public-private-partnership programs, build a maritime medical rescue center, and establish regular flights to Woody Island. China claims almost all of the South China Sea, which is home to over $5 trillion in maritime trade. The decision is likely to anger other claimants, including the Philippines, Vietnam, and Taiwan, who have overlapping claims in the region.

site_title: A racier Prius is here
summary: Toyota's latest Prius model features a racier design and improved performance, with a stronger 1.8-litre engine and upgraded suspension. Chief engineer Kouji Toyoshima views the Prius as a standalone model, not competing with other hybrids, but rather with clean diesels and downsized turbocharged models. The new Prius is built on the TNGA platform, increasing stability and rigidity, and is designed to appeal to buyers seeking better performance. The Prius remains the world's best-selling hybrid, with over 17 years of success and 3.5 million units sold globally.

site_title: Weaving the magic of corporate culture
summary: A positive corporate culture is crucial for attracting and retaining talent, improving employee performance, and driving business success. Small and medium-sized enterprises can build a great work culture by prioritizing relationships, trust, and employee well-being. Companies like Rohei, American Express, and Shell demonstrate the importance of flexible work arrangements, employee development, and work-life balance. Hiring with culture in mind and setting a clear tone from the start are also key to maintaining a positive work culture. Ultimately, winning the hearts and minds of staff is essential for achieving business success.

site_title: 1MDB may redeem bonds if cash payments come through
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB sovereign fund may consider redeeming some of its outstanding debts ahead of time if cash payments from a land sale can come through quickly and market conditions improve. The fund is finalizing a plan to pare back US$7.6 billion of long-term debt through a radical land and power assets sale plan. The plan's success depends on the sale of Kuala Lumpur's Bandar Malaysia to a China-led consortium, which could potentially allow the early repayment of costly bonds.

site_title: Bond traders see only one Fed interest rate increase this year
summary: Bond traders expect only one interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve in 2016, citing a growth scare and global market turbulence. The effective Fed funds rate is projected to rise to 0.7% by year's end, down from a previous forecast of 0.93%. This shift in expectations is attributed to "fear" of the US economy's inability to withstand global forces, including falling energy prices and a slowdown in growth abroad.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees oil bull market being born in today's crash
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a new oil bull market will emerge in late 2016 as the price crash erodes the global glut, sending US shale-oil production into reverse. The bank forecasts a 575,000 barrel-per-day decline in US production, resulting in a global oil deficit. This adjustment will rebalance markets, creating a new bull market, according to analysts Jeff Currie and Damien Courvalin.

site_title: Winners of US$1.6b Powerball jackpot yet to claim prize
summary: Three Powerball ticket holders, each worth $528.8 million, remain anonymous despite a $1.6 billion jackpot. The winning tickets were sold at retailers in California, Florida, and Tennessee. Lottery officials have not released the identities of the winners, who have yet to claim their prize.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US rose in january to seven-month high
summary: US consumer confidence rose to a seven-month high in January, reaching 93.3, driven by low inflation and a median wage gain outlook. This marks the best annual performance since 2004. Americans' projected inflation rate over the next year dropped to the lowest level since 2010, giving consumers added buying power. However, workers remain waiting for convincing signs of stronger wage growth, which has remained elusive despite a low jobless rate.

site_title: The Singapore Open returns
summary: The Singapore Open golf tournament is returning after a 3-year hiatus, featuring world No. 1 Jordan Spieth, Major winners Darren Clarke and YE Yang, and other top golfers. The event, sanctioned by the Asian Tour and Japan Golf Tour Organisation, will be held at Sentosa Golf Club's Serapong Course. The tournament will also feature Singapore professionals and amateurs, with Singapore No. 1 Mardan Mamat participating. Clarke, a former Open Championship winner, is looking forward to playing on the course and enjoying the city's beauty and food.

site_title: Xpress Holdings expects further losses in Q2, mulls restructuring
summary: Xpress Holdings expects to extend its net loss for Q2 2016 due to a shortage of skilled labor in China, affecting its foreign operations. The company will restructure its business abroad to address the issue. In contrast, its Singapore operations remained profitable after upgrading its infrastructure to keep up with the digitalization of the printing industry.

site_title: Dudley says economic outlook little changed since Fed meeting
summary: US economy to grow faster than its potential this year, supporting further interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve, according to New York Fed President William C Dudley. The economic outlook remains unchanged since the Fed's December meeting, with Dudley expecting the economy to expand at a pace slightly above its long-term trend in 2016. The median committee member projects four interest-rate increases in 2016, following the benchmark federal funds rate's first hike since 2008.

site_title: Indonesia says larger network suspected in Jakarta attacks
summary: Indonesian police launched raids nationwide following deadly coordinated attacks in Jakarta, suspecting a broader extremist network was involved. The attacks, which included suicide bombings and shootings, left 7 people dead and injured others. Authorities are struggling to provide concrete information on the incident, which occurred in broad daylight on a busy street. The operations aimed to disrupt the suspected network, which claimed responsibility for the attack.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore eDevelopment expects to report a loss for fiscal 2015, with a preliminary unaudited financial loss of "significantly lower" than the S$20.8 million loss in 2014. Koyo International has been warned by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to trade with caution due to suspicious trades by a small group of individuals. Meanwhile, Indian-owned dry bulk shipping company Mercator Lines has seen three non-executive directors resign ahead of a court hearing.

site_title: US business inventories post largest fall since 2011
summary: US business inventories declined 0.2% in November, the largest drop since 2011, as businesses reduced stockpiles of unsold merchandise. This marks a downwardly revised decline from the previously reported 0.1% dip in October. Economists had forecast a 0.1% decline, and inventories are a key component of gross domestic product. The decline suggests economic growth slowed significantly in the fourth quarter, with implications for policymakers.

site_title: US: Wall St plunges; Nasdaq at lowest since August
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the Nasdaq falling 3% to its lowest since August 24, while the S&P 500 is less than 30 points away from its August lows. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.97% to 16,219.83, and the S&P 500 lost 1.27% to 1,897.35. The decline was largely due to a sharp drop in oil prices.

site_title: US halts new leases of public land for coal exploration
summary: The US Obama administration has halted new leases of public land for coal exploration while studying its environmental impact and considering changes to royalty rates. This decision affects the coal industry, which is struggling due to declining demand and lower-priced natural gas. Existing coal leases will continue to be valid, and reserves are expected to last around 20 years at current production levels.

site_title: Banks print millions of new red packets
summary: Local banks in Singapore have printed millions of red packets for their clients this year, with DBS preparing 20 million, OCBC Bank printing 15 million, and UOB stating its stock is in the millions. StanChart has printed a few hundred thousand. The number of red packets remains consistent with previous years, indicating a steady demand for these traditional gifts.

site_title: Koh earns spot in HSBC Women's Champions
summary: Koh Sock Hwee, 26, secured a spot in the HSBC Women's Champions 2016 by winning the Host Country Qualifying Tournament. She led the field by four shots after the first round and maintained a two-shot lead over Amanda Tan in the second round. The tournament, featuring world No. 1 Lydia Ko and defending champion Inbee Park, will take place in March.

site_title: Improvement to political system under study
summary: President Tony Tan Keng Yam emphasizes the need for an improved political system in Singapore, aiming to ensure a clean, effective, and accountable government. He notes that the country has made significant progress since its founding generation's time, but acknowledges the challenges that lie ahead. The 13th Parliament of Singapore has opened, marking a new chapter in the country's governance.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Pimco favours inflation bonds countering Fed caution on prices
summary: Pacific Investment Management Co (Pimco) is recommending Treasury Inflation Protected Securities (TIPS) despite tumbling oil costs prompting Federal Reserve officials to voice concern over stagnant consumer prices. Pimco's Mihir Worah believes inflation will stabilize at 2% in 2016, potentially leading to more interest-rate hikes than the market is pricing. The recommendation counters the Fed's caution on prices, with Fed President James Bullard warning that declining oil prices may delay inflation's return to the central bank's 2% target.

site_title: Factory production in US falls on less motor vehicle output
summary: US factory production declined 0.1% in December for a second consecutive month, matching the previous month's decline. This drop was attributed to a stronger dollar and softer US and global growth. Total industrial production fell 0.4%, with factories struggling due to increased competition from cheaper foreign goods. The decline may be extended by heightened concerns over global growth, particularly in China.

site_title: BlackRock quarterly profit rises 6%
summary: BlackRock's quarterly profit rose 6% to $861 million, or $5.11 per share, in the fourth quarter. This marks a significant increase from the previous year's profit of $813 million, or $4.77 per share. The company's strong performance is attributed to a turbulent market environment.

site_title: CFO of Cambridge Industrial Trust manager resigns
summary: The CFO of Cambridge Industrial Trust Management, David Mason, has resigned to pursue new opportunities, effective January 16, 2016. He will remain as advisor until April 2016 to facilitate a smooth transition. A replacement is pending regulatory approval.

site_title: China Premier Li pledges stable yuan, no competitive devaluation
summary: China Premier Li Keqiang pledged a "stable" yuan exchange rate, stating there's no intention to stimulate exports through competitive currency devaluation. He emphasized China's ability to maintain a "reasonable and balanced standard" for the yuan. This comes after a volatile week in which offshore interbank borrowing costs in Hong Kong surged to a record. Li's comments aim to reassure investors and maintain market stability.

site_title: Auto industry, US regulators agree to boost safety recalls
summary: US regulators and 17 automakers, including General Motors, Ford, and Toyota, agree to boost safety recalls and improve reporting of fatalities, injuries, and warranty claims. Company executives also committed to voluntarily identifying cybersecurity threats. The agreements were reached during a meeting with US Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. The reforms aim to enhance transparency and cooperation between the industry and government on safety and cybersecurity issues.

site_title: GMG's China parent in discussion with Halcyon Agri on 'strategic transaction'
summary: GMG Global's parent, Sinochem International Corporation, is in discussions with Halcyon Agri on a potential strategic transaction that could involve the combination of Halcyon Agri, GMG Global, and Sinochem International's rubber-related assets. The talks are ongoing, with no definitive terms or timeline announced. The discussions come after recent gains in GMG and Halcyon Agri shares, which Sinochem deemed "undesirably speculative".

site_title: Top performing EM fund managers readying for tough 2016
summary: Top-performing emerging market (EM) fund managers are bracing for a challenging 2016 due to weak growth, high market volatility, and low oil prices. Despite strong rebounds in Moscow stocks in 2015, many EM-focused funds are expected to face difficulties. Fund managers are focusing on non-traditional exporters, local demand-oriented companies, and consumer stocks to navigate the tough environment, while warning of elevated tail risks and potential defaults.

site_title: Singapore and Indonesia to step up intelligence exchange: Dr Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singapore and Indonesia will enhance intelligence exchanges to counter terrorism, Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen announced. Following a terrorist attack in Jakarta that killed seven, Singapore offered condolences to Indonesia. The move aims to strengthen cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: Six people seriously ill after medical trials go wrong in France
summary: Six people are seriously ill after taking part in a medical trial for an unnamed European laboratory in France. The trial involved an oral medication, and the patients were in good health until taking the medication. The trials have been suspended at a private clinic in Rennes, Brittany. The health ministry has not disclosed the intended use of the medication. One patient is in a coma, and the incident is under investigation.

site_title: US retail sales end 2015 with a whimper
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.1% in December, down from a 0.4% gain in November, as unseasonably warm weather and cheaper gasoline impacted sales. This marks the weakest retail sales reading since 2009, with a 2.1% increase for the year. Economists had forecast sales to remain unchanged. The decline in retail sales is a sign that economic growth slowed in the fourth quarter, adding to concerns about the US economy.

site_title: SGX urges investors to trade Koyo International with caution
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has warned investors to trade with caution when dealing with Koyo International due to unusual trading activity. A small group of individuals accounted for 60% of trading volume, with at least half of these trades being self-trades among themselves. Koyo International attributed the trading activity to its discussions on potential projects and business opportunities, but the SGX is working with regulatory agencies on the matter.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Five key items on new government's agenda: President Tony Tan
summary: President Tony Tan Keng Yam announced the five key items on the new government's agenda: ensuring Singapore's safety and security, renewing the economy, fostering a more caring society, transforming the country's urban landscape, and engaging with all Singaporeans in nation-building. Tan emphasized the need for continuous adjustments to ensure Singapore's upward path, stating that the work of securing the nation and improving lives is never-ending.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower, BHP Billiton falls after asset writedown
summary: European shares fell, with the FTSEurofirst 300 down 0.2% at 1,332.28 points, after commodity-related stocks like BHP Billiton plummeted 4% due to a US$7.2 billion writedown of its US shale assets. However, H&M rose 3.2% after beating sales forecasts, supporting the market.

site_title: Mercator Lines loses 3 non-executive directors ahead of court hearing
summary: Mercator Lines, an Indian-owned dry bulk shipping company, has lost three non-executive directors ahead of a court hearing. The board is now composed of two members, Harish Kumar Mittal and Shalabh Mittal, who also serve as chairman and CEO, respectively. The company had announced a scheme of arrangement with creditors and was subject to judicial management proceedings initiated by the Singapore branch of HSH Nordbank AG. The board committees have been dissolved, and a court hearing is scheduled.

site_title: Juncker sees euro, EU trade at risk in unresolved refugee crisis
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker warns that the unresolved refugee crisis threatens to drain the EU's credibility, putting continental free trade and the euro at risk. He says the crisis has triggered passport checks, fragmented the economy, and undermines the freedom of movement of workers, which is essential for the euro's value. Juncker criticizes member states, including Hungary, Germany, and Italy, for not contributing to the EU's refugee relocation efforts, calling it a "generation of weak heirs who forget quickly."

site_title: Citigroup, once top US bank, slips to no. 4 behind Wells Fargo
summary: Citigroup has slipped to the fourth-largest US bank, behind Wells Fargo, with Wells Fargo's assets totaling $1.79 trillion compared to Citigroup's $1.73 trillion at the end of 2015. The difference in strategies between the two banks, with Wells Fargo focusing on growth through deposits and assets and Citigroup prioritizing profitability through business exits, has contributed to the shift.

site_title: US producer prices fall in December on declining energy costs
summary: US producer prices fell 0.2% in December, the 11th straight 12-month decrease, due to a sharp drop in energy costs. This decline may temper inflation expectations, which could impact the Federal Reserve's target. The producer price index decreased 1.0% over the past 12 months, following a 1.1% drop in November.

site_title: Ukraine launches new China trade route bypassing Russia
summary: Ukraine launched its first cargo train to China on January 15, 2016, bypassing Russia along the "Silk Road" route. The move aims to counter Russia's trade embargo on Ukraine. The train departed from the Black Sea port of Odessa, bound for Georgia, marking a historic event according to Ukrainian Infrastructure Minister Andriy Pyvovarskiy. The new route is seen as a significant development for Ukraine, solidifying its position as a transit country between the East and West.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks close down 3.55% on economic gloom
summary: Shanghai stocks plummeted 3.55% on Friday, closing at 2,900.97, amid worries over China's slowing growth ahead of GDP figures. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 3.40%. The decline was attributed to economic gloom, with dealers anticipating a slowdown in China's growth.

site_title: Completed restructuring deals fell by a third to US$140.9b in 2015
summary: Completed distressed debt and bankruptcy restructurings fell 33% to US$140.9 billion in 2015, with failed Icelandic bank Glitnir and Ukraine's sovereign debt accounting for top deals. This represents a decline from 317 deals to 231 in 2014. Europe, the Middle East, and Africa accounted for US$90 billion of deals, while US restructurings totaled US$37.9 billion.

site_title: BlackRock's Fink sees another 10% drop in markets before rebound
summary: BlackRock CEO Laurence D. Fink predicts a 10% decline in global markets before a rebound, citing "not enough blood" in the markets for a quick turnaround. He also forecasts oil to reach $24 a barrel. This comes despite a 5.9% increase in BlackRock's fourth-quarter earnings.

site_title: Singapore's Halcyon Agri says in talks with Sinochem on stake sale
summary: Singapore-based rubber company Halcyon Agri Corporation Ltd is in talks with Sinochem International Corp on a potential sale of a controlling stake. The talks also involve a strategic transaction combining Halcyon and Sinochem's interests in GMG Global Ltd and rubber assets. Shares in Halcyon and GMG jumped nearly 10% on Tuesday after the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Closes at lowest level since September 2012
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index closed at its lowest level in nearly 3.5 years, falling 1.5% to 19,520.77, amid tumbling mainland stocks and a drop in the Hong Kong dollar against the US dollar. This marked the lowest close since September 2012. The China Enterprises Index also fell 2.6% to 8,236.28 points.

site_title: CIMB cuts Hong Kong investment banking jobs as business slows
summary: CIMB Group Holdings, Malaysia's second-largest lender, is cutting 32 jobs from its Hong Kong investment banking and equities operations due to a downturn in regional business. The move, made by CEO Tengku Zafrul Abdul Aziz, aims to adapt to the deteriorating capital markets faced by Asian players in the industry. This decision is not an isolated incident, as the article highlights various other financial institutions facing challenges in the region, including China's slowing GDP growth and Chinese banks struggling with consumer lending.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,628.55 after a 4.89-point decline. Trading volumes reached 1.88 billion lots, valued at RM1.76 billion. The market saw 325 gainers and 580 losers.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers submit Budget wishlist to government
summary: Singapore manufacturers have submitted a Budget wishlist to the government, focusing on four areas: collaboration, innovation, productivity, and talent. The Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) recommends incentivizing local suppliers and vendors, extending existing schemes, and enhancing internship opportunities for students. The SMF also suggests providing longer exposure to manufacturing jobs to help local companies become future-ready.

site_title: Opec's oil basket price drops to US$25 a barrel
summary: Opec's oil basket price dropped to $25 a barrel on Thursday, following the group's announcement. The price is expected to fall further due to Iran's impending increase in oil exports after sanctions are lifted. Iran plans to boost production by 500,000 barrels per day and target India and European markets. The US has also lifted its decades-old ban on oil exports, adding to bearish sentiment in the market. Global demand is at multi-year highs, but Saudi Arabia's strategy to keep prices low may be challenged by the increased supply.

site_title: CapitaLand spends US$4.65m to raise stake in Vietnam unit
summary: CapitaLand has raised its stake in its Vietnam subsidiary, CapitaLandVista, by purchasing an additional 10% interest for US$4.65 million. This brings its holdings to 90%. The company's Vietnam unit, CapitaLandVista, owns a mixed-use development in Ho Chi Minh City, comprising residential and commercial components.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment expects loss for fiscal 2015
summary: Singapore eDevelopment expects a loss for fiscal 2015, significantly lower than the S$20.8 million loss in fiscal 2014. The group's major property development projects, Ballenger Run and Black Oak, are expected to commence revenue recognition in 2016. Development costs and operating expenses for its mobile app, Hotapp, have also been incurred. The preliminary unaudited financial loss is attributed to delayed project commencement and increased expenses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Developers sold 7,529 private homes in 2015, up from 7,316 units in 2014. Singapore's retail sales grew 4.7% in November, driven by car sales. Noble Group's default risk rose due to a deepening resources slump, threatening its cash flows. Mergers and acquisitions are expected to pick up this year, with PACC Offshore and Sembcorp Marine as prime candidates. The Singapore shares closed weaker, down 4.4% for the week and 8.7% for 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker; STI down 4.4% for week, 8.7% for 2016 so far
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 4.4% in its second week of 2016, with a cumulative loss of 8.7% for the year so far. Turbulence in China and weakening oil prices are cited as main reasons for the selloff, particularly affecting offshore and marine (O&M) stocks. Key stocks like Keppel Corp and SembCorp Marine suffered significant losses, while Noble Group's credit rating downgrade contributed to its decline.

site_title: Suits filed by Sakae Holdings against ex-director and others begin
summary: Sakae Holdings has filed suits against former director Andy Ong and others, with a trial set to begin on January 15 in the Singapore High Court. The trial will last until March 4, addressing allegations of breaching duties. This marks the start of legal proceedings against Ong, who was director of the company at the time of the alleged breaches.

site_title: Renault not forced to repay low-emissions tax breaks for now: media
summary: France is not planning to claim back tax breaks for low-emissions vehicles from Renault after tests showed some of its cars exceeded emissions limits. Energy Minister Segolene Royal stated that emissions from 80 models, including Renault, still need to be tested, which will take until summer. Without test results, Royal advised Renault to take immediate action to ensure its engines meet emissions limits.

site_title: China to land probe on dark side of moon in 2018: Xinhua
summary: China plans to land the first probe on the dark side of the moon in 2018, following its successful "soft landing" on the moon's surface in 2016. This marks another milestone in China's ambitious space program, as previous spacecraft have only orbited the far side of the moon.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: OCBC Bank announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong, with Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, named as her successor. This move comes as OCBC prepares for a new era under Long's leadership. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. In other news, Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event, and Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: IMF decision on third Greek bailout could take until Q2: Lagarde in paper
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) may take until the second quarter to decide on a third bailout for Greece, according to IMF Chief Christine Lagarde. The decision hinges on debt sustainability and progress on Greek pension reforms. Lagarde stated that pension reform is a key indicator of Greece's economic improvement, suggesting that the country's economic position is on the path to recovery.

site_title: PACC Offshore, SembMarine prime picks for M&A: report
summary: A Maybank-Kim Eng Research report predicts a pick-up in mergers and acquisitions (M&As) in the oil service industry, citing PACC Offshore and Sembcorp Marine as prime candidates for privatization. PACC Offshore's share price has been hit by missed earnings and low trading liquidity, while Sembcorp Marine's parent, Sembcorp Industries, may require additional funding to sustain operations. A privatisation would allow for more efficient capital allocation and relieve Sembcorp Industries of the strain. Both companies are highly leveraged and owned by financially strong parent companies.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wall St rally, rebound in oil price
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, following a Wall Street rally and a rebound in oil prices. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.47% to 2,656.87, with 65.7 million shares changing hands. The rally was driven by a US stock market rebound and a decline in oil prices.

site_title: More IS attacks likely as group suffers setbacks: US general
summary: US General Lloyd Austin warns that Islamic State (IS) is likely to increase attacks globally as the group faces increased pressure in Iraq and Syria. IS has assumed a defensive posture, according to Austin, citing recent attacks in Istanbul and Jakarta as evidence of the group's faltering position.

site_title: EDBI invests in US robotics company
summary: EDBI, the Singapore Economic Development Board, has invested $15 million in US robotics company Savioke, joining Intel Capital and Northern Light Venture Capital in the Series A funding round. Savioke aims to develop autonomous robots for the services industry, including the world's first autonomous hotel delivery robot, Relay. The funding will support expansion and product development for Relay. This investment aligns with Singapore's vision as a Smart Nation and leverages the country's technology environment and talent pool to accelerate Savioke's growth in Asia.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit, Ezra Holdings, Apsil
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.64 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, beating its forecast by 1.9%. The DPU was lifted by net property income of S$21.85 million. The stock closed 0.5% lower at S$1.01 on Thursday.

site_title: China to invest US$4.2b in Beijing-Hebei high-speed rail link
summary: China's state planner has approved a $6 billion high-speed rail project linking Beijing's new airport with neighboring Hebei province. The 27.4 billion yuan project will take 3.5 years to complete and is part of the government's efforts to invest in infrastructure to boost the economy.

site_title: Saudi life with US$30 oil: shock, spending cuts and even smiles
summary: Saudi Arabia, a nation synonymous with conspicuous consumption, is experiencing unprecedented cuts to fuel and energy subsidies due to the drastic drop in oil prices, currently around $30 per barrel. This has led to austerity measures, with many Saudis forced to make lifestyle changes, including reducing electricity consumption and finding alternative income sources. The youth, comprising over 40% of the population, are at the forefront of this change, with increased expectations for more freedom and participation in society. The government is also exploring the sale of state-owned oil company Aramco and plans to privatize state-owned entities, aiming to create jobs in the private sector.

site_title: Netflix to block proxy access to content not available locally
summary: Netflix plans to block proxy access to its content not available locally, starting in a few weeks. Subscribers who use proxies or unblockers to watch content not available in their home country will be restricted. The move comes after Netflix expanded its service to over 130 countries, except China, and follows a statement by Netflix's vice-president that using proxies is unnecessary if all content were globally available.

images.alt_text: Indonesia said on Thursday a decision by the country's biggest telecoms provider to block Netflix could be reversed if the global video-streaming giant obeyed local laws, particularly on "porn" and "radicalism".

site_title: Singapore Dec exports seen down y/y for 2nd month on weak global demand
summary: Singapore's exports in December are forecast to contract for a second consecutive month, driven by weak global demand. Non-oil domestic exports are seen falling 5.1% from a year earlier, according to a Reuters poll. The contraction in shipments to China in November has continued, and factory activity in Singapore has contracted for a sixth consecutive month. The decline in exports and factory activity is attributed to sluggish global growth, denting new orders received by manufacturers.

site_title: Eindec makes Catalist debut, opens higher than IPO price
summary: Eindec Corporation Ltd made its Catalist debut on January 15, 2016, with its counter opening at S$0.235, higher than the initial public offering price of S$0.21. Over 3.5 million shares changed hands, making it one of the most active stocks by volume. The Singapore Exchange welcomed Eindec to the Catalist, marking its entry into the market.

site_title: As clock ticks down on sanctions, oil-laden Iran tankers set to target India and Europe
summary: Iran is poised to resume business ties with the world under a nuclear deal, targeting India and Europe with hundreds of thousands of barrels of crude oil. The UN nuclear watchdog is expected to confirm Iran has curtailed its nuclear program, paving the way for the unfreezing of billions of dollars in assets and an end to oil export bans. Iran plans to lift exports by 500,000 barrels per day, adding to global oil glut and likely pressuring oil prices, which have dropped 70% since 2014.

images.alt_text: With Iran poised to resume usual business ties with the world under a historic nuclear deal, Tehran is set to target India, Asia's fastest-growing major oil market, and old partners in Europe with hundreds of thousands of barrels of its crude.

site_title: Activists targeted as workers of China unite
summary: Activists in China are facing increased pressure as workers unite against government policies. A labour activist's wife, Zhu Xiaomei, was arrested and had her apartment searched for evidence related to her work for a workers' rights organisation. The arrest comes amid growing dissent among Chinese workers, who are seeking better working conditions and greater protections. The case highlights the government's efforts to suppress dissent and maintain control over the workforce.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong slip in early trade
summary: Shanghai and Hong Kong stocks fell in early trade on Friday, despite a strong rally in US markets. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.65% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.76%. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index slipped 0.18%. The losses followed a near 2% gain in Shanghai and Hong Kong on Thursday.

site_title: China not currently considering borrowing from its new development bank: state media
summary: China is not considering borrowing from its new international development bank, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), to fund domestic projects, according to the state-run People's Daily. The bank, which focuses on helping build infrastructure in other developing countries in Asia, has no plans to provide loans to China for domestic projects, with China's finance minister citing other countries' greater infrastructure needs. The bank's opening ceremony is set for Saturday, with President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang expected to attend.

images.alt_text: China is not currently considering borrowing from its new international development bank to bankroll domestic projects, the state-run People's Daily said on Friday.

site_title: S$27-34b worth of construction contracts likely to be awarded this year: BCA
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) predicts that Singapore will award S$27-34 billion worth of construction contracts this year, with 65% driven by the public sector. This represents the highest proportion of public sector demand since 2002 and a slowdown in private sector demand. Last year, the BCA awarded S$27.2 billion in construction contracts, with public sector projects accounting for over half of the demand.

images.alt_text: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) estimates that S$27 billion to S$34 billion worth of construction contracts will be awarded this year.

site_title: Indonesia says attack underlines emergence of Islamic State threat
summary: Indonesia's police chief has called for strengthened defenses against Islamic State after a three-hour siege in the capital Jakarta resulted in seven deaths, including five attackers. The attack, which involved multiple blasts and a gunfight, marked the first time the radical group targeted Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation. The incident highlighted a new brand of militancy in the country, where low-level strikes on police are common. Indonesia and neighboring countries are urged to work together to combat the growing threat.

images.alt_text: Indonesia must strengthen its defences against Islamic State and work with neighbouring countries to fight it, Jakarta's police chief said on Friday, a day after an attack by suicide bombers and gunmen in the heart of the Southeast Asian nation's capital.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won regain ground as market nerves ease
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.1% to 1,902.70 points, easing market tensions. Beijing's efforts to stabilize the yuan and a rebound in oil prices contributed to the calm. Analysts attribute the improvement in sentiment to Beijing's yuan efforts, which followed a volatile start to 2016.

site_title: Renault shares plunge after failed pollution tests, raids
summary: Renault shares plummeted 10% on Thursday after diesel cars failed government-ordered pollution tests and investigators raided its facilities. Despite no pollution cheating software found, the move raised concerns. Renault had heavily invested in diesel engines, sparking investor sell-offs. This follows Volkswagen's September admission of installing software on 11 million diesel vehicles, potentially costing it tens of billions of dollars.

images.alt_text: Shares in Renault plunged by 10 per cent on Thursday after the company's diesel cars failed government-ordered pollution tests and investigators raided its facilities, raising fears the French carmaker could be caught up in an emissions scandal.

site_title: Indonesia posts US$230m trade deficit in Dec, US$7.51b surplus in 2015
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of US$7.51 billion in 2015, after three years of deficits, with exports falling 14.6% to US$150.25 billion and imports dropping 19.9% to US$142.74 billion. This marked a significant improvement from 2014's deficit of US$2.2 billion.
