images.alt_text: Indonesia's trade balance moved back into surplus in 2015, following three years of deficits, the statistics bureau said on Friday.

site_title: 1MDB may tackle debt mountain early if cash comes in quickly: fund's president
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB sovereign fund may consider early debt redemption if it receives cash from a land sale quickly and market conditions improve. Fund President Arul Kanda made the statement amid graft allegations surrounding Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak. The fund is in the final stages of a land and power assets sale plan to pare back $7.6 billion of long-term debt.

images.alt_text: Malaysian sovereign fund 1MDB may consider redeeming some of its outstanding debts ahead of time if cash payments from a land sale can come through quickly and if market conditions improve, President Arul Kanda told Reuters.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise before presidential vote; TSMC jumps
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.6% to 7,789.85 ahead of Saturday's presidential polls, where the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is expected to return to power. TSMC, the world's top contract chip maker, jumped 4.9% after reporting better-than-expected fourth-quarter net profit. The rally was seen as a cautious response to the polls, with market sentiment remaining cautious.

site_title: BHP makes US$7.2 billion writedown on US shale assets
summary: BHP Billiton announced a US$7.2 billion pre-tax writedown on its US shale assets due to tumbling oil prices, with a US$4.9 billion after-tax hit. The company will also reduce its US onshore rigs from 26 to 5 in the March quarter. This follows a US$2.8 billion pre-tax writedown on the same assets last year. The move aims to adapt to the decline in oil prices and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: Mining giant BHP Billiton Friday said it expects to book a US$7.2 billion pre-tax writedown against the value of its struggling onshore assets in the United States as tumbling oil prices hit shale gas.

site_title: Headland Capital loses half investment team after fund scrapped
summary: Headland Capital Partners Ltd, a Hong Kong-based buyout firm, has lost nearly half its investment professionals after scrapping a $1 billion fundraising effort. The firm, which manages $1.5 billion in assets, will focus on managing and improving its existing portfolio companies over the next 18 months. The decision resulted in the team size falling to 11, with notable departures including senior partners Paul Kang and Brian Chang.

images.alt_text: Headland Capital Partners Ltd, the Asian buyout firm spun out of HSBC Holdings Plc, lost nearly half its investment professionals after scrapping a fundraising.

site_title: Hot stock: LionGold's counter heavily traded at start of Friday session
summary: LionGold Corp's counter was heavily traded at the start of the Friday session, with over 101.9 million shares changing hands at 9:25am. The stock was down 20% or S$0.001 to S$0.004.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open sharply higher on Wall St rally
summary: Tokyo shares opened 1.63% higher on Friday, mirroring a Wall Street rally, driven by a bounce in oil prices and a weak yen boosting exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 281.51 points to 17,522.46, while the Topix index gained 21.10 points to 1,427.65. The rally comes as traders brush off new Trump threats, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Emerging currencies lifted by oil, equity market rebound
summary: Emerging currencies rose on Friday as investors shifted into riskier assets after a Wall Street rebound and a surge in oil prices. Oil prices rallied from multi-year lows, boosting confidence and driving gains in currencies like the yuan and the peso. The rally came after a volatile week in markets, where trillions of dollars had been wiped off valuations since the start of the year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's annual inflation rate likely increased slightly to 2.7 per cent in December, a Reuters poll showed, as rising costs for consumer goods offset declining fuel prices.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at more than 4-mth low; won flat
summary: Seoul shares closed at a 4-month low, down 1.1% at 1,878.87 points, following a weak risk appetite. Oil prices resumed their fall, while China stocks turned lower. The Kospi index lost 2% for the third straight week, its lowest closing level since September 8, 2015.

site_title: Twitter sued by US widow for giving voice to Islamic State
summary: Twitter is being sued by the widow of an American killed in a Jordanian attack, who claims the company gave Islamic State a platform to spread propaganda and recruit members. Tamara Fields alleges Twitter knowingly allowed the group to maintain official accounts, contributing to its explosive growth into the world's most-feared terrorist group. The lawsuit seeks damages and calls for Twitter to crack down on online terrorism.

images.alt_text: Twitter said on Tuesday its social network was suffering outages in some parts of the world and it was working to resolve the issues, which appear to be concentrated in Europe, according to external monitoring sources.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up in cautious trade
summary: Asia markets rebounded on Friday, with most stocks rising as investors cautiously traded amid ongoing volatility. The surge on Wall Street was driven by oil price gains, upbeat earnings reports, and comments from a Federal Reserve official suggesting no immediate interest rate hike. In Australia, BHP Billiton scored gains despite announcing a multi-billion-dollar loss due to the decline in crude prices. The rally extended a 5-day winning streak for Singapore stocks, which await GDP data release.

images.alt_text: The volatility that has characterised the start of the year extended another session Friday, with most markets rebounding from another sell-off but with investors remaining on edge.

site_title: Uber China unit valued at over US$8b after fundraising: Kalanick
summary: Uber China's ride-hailing unit was valued at over US$8 billion after its latest fundraising round, exceeding initial estimates of US$7 billion. The Series B fundraising raised "well over US$1 billion" according to CEO Travis Kalanick. The exact figure was not disclosed, but the spokeswoman confirmed it was over US$1.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc's chief executive Travis Kalanick said on Friday the ride-hailing firm's China unit was valued at more than US$8 billion after its latest fundraising round, over US$1 billion more than before the effort.

site_title: Australia: Shares cautiously higher, NZ also firmer
summary: Australian shares rose 4.52 points, or 0.09%, to 4,913.90, extending last week's 5.8% drop, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.84% to 6,160.43, flat on the week. The rebound follows a rally on Wall Street, but investors remain cautious due to recent global market volatility and commodity price fluctuations.

site_title: Obama administration to announce remake of coal programme
summary: The Obama administration is set to announce an overhaul of the US coal development program, potentially freezing new coal mining, to address climate change concerns. Interior Secretary Sally Jewell is expected to make the announcement in New Mexico. The new plan will require federal officials to consider the environmental impacts of coal burning when making land use decisions. This move follows President Obama's State of the Union address, which called for a shift in managing oil and coal resources to better reflect their costs to taxpayers and the planet.

images.alt_text: Humanity must stop burning coal, oil and gas to power the global economy or face an irreversible climate catastrophe, scientists, business chiefs and analysts warned at an elite gathering in the Swiss Alps.

site_title: Hyatt says data breach started in August
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp reported a data breach that occurred between August 13 and December 8, primarily at its restaurants worldwide. The company stated that the malware attack aimed to steal payment card data, but the exact number of affected customers is unknown. Hyatt listed affected locations and the risk period on its website. The incident occurred at various locations globally, with no further details provided.

images.alt_text: Hyatt Hotels Corp said a previously reported malware attack to steal payment card data occurred between August 13 and Dec 8, primarily at its restaurants.

site_title: Global earnings downgrades haven't been this bad in seven years
summary: Global stocks are on the brink of a bear market due to a selloff erasing nearly $14 trillion in gains since 2009. Analyst profit downgrades outnumbered upgrades for the first time since 2009, with economists' projections for worldwide expansion in 2016 dropping to 3.3%. The slowdown in global growth is attributed to declines in oil, European recovery concerns, and China slowdown fears. Despite some pockets of optimism, strategists warn that the earnings bar is low, and the scope for positive surprises is great, but many expect a recession in 2016.

site_title: Foursquare CEO steps down; company raises US$45m in funding
summary: Foursquare's CEO, Dennis Crowley, is stepping down and will be succeeded by Jeff Glueck, the company's current COO. The company raised $45 million in funding, led by Union Square Ventures, to aid its plans to fill 30 new positions. The funding will also support Foursquare's growth and expansion, with no specific timeline mentioned.

images.alt_text: Foursquare's chief executive, Dennis Crowley, is stepping down and will be succeeded by Jeff Glueck, the company's current chief operating officer.

site_title: Singapore Nov retail sales up 4.7% year-on-year, boosted by car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 4.7% year-on-year in November, driven by a 59.7% surge in car sales. Excluding car sales, retail sales actually fell 2%. The total retail sales value in November 2015 was S$3.5 billion, higher than the S$3.3 billion in November 2014.

images.alt_text: In year-on-year terms, retail sales grew 4.7 per cent, according to data released by the Department of Statistics on Friday.

site_title: Update: Developers sold 7,529 private homes in 2015, up from 7,316 units in 2014
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 7,529 private homes in 2015, up from 7,316 units in 2014. In December 2015, 384 private homes were sold, down from 759 units in November and 230 units in December 2014. This data excludes executive condos.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Developers sold 384 private homes in December 2015, down from 759 units in November 2015.

site_title: Slowing data center revenue growth dims Intel's profit beat
summary: Intel Corp reported a strong quarterly profit beat, but its data center revenue growth slowed, missing estimates. The company's shares fell 5.6% after the report. CEO Brian Krzanich is shifting focus from personal computers to high-end server chips to drive growth. Data center revenue was $4.31 billion in the fourth quarter, below the consensus estimate of $4.42 billion.

images.alt_text: Intel Corp's strong quarterly profit beat was overshadowed by concerns about slowing revenue growth in its highly profitable data center business, sending its shares down about 5.6 per cent in after-market trading.

site_title: Ousted Thai PM Yingluck in court for corruption trial
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra appeared in court on Friday to face corruption charges related to her management of a rice subsidy scheme. The charges, filed in the Supreme Court, stem from a policy that critics say hemorrhaged billions of dollars. Yingluck's supporters claim the charges are a ploy by the ruling junta to curtail her influence, as her brother Thaksin remains a divisive figure in Thai politics. The trial marks a significant development in the ongoing saga of corruption and power struggles in Thailand.

images.alt_text: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra appeared in court on Friday to face corruption charges that her supporters say are a ploy by the ruling junta to curtail the influence of her and her family.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rebound fizzles to close at 3-month low
summary: Tokyo stocks closed at a 3-month low due to a stronger yen, which dented exporters. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.54% to 17,147.11, while the Topix index slipped 0.29% to 1,402.45. The brief rally fizzled out, leaving the market at its lowest close in over three months.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares closed sharply lower on Tuesday, as oil prices resumed their downward slide and investors eye the first policy meetings of the year by the US and Japanese central banks.

site_title: Yuan opens firmer on Friday
summary: China's yuan strengthened at its open on Friday, trading at 6.5864 per dollar, despite the People's Bank of China setting a marginally weaker midpoint of 6.5637 per dollar. The spot market opened at 6.5920 and is currently allowed to trade within a 2% range of the official fixing. The yuan's firmer opening is a departure from the previous day's closing quote of 6.589.

images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed at its open on Friday, shrugging off the central bank's marginally weaker midpoint.

site_title: Qatar to hike petrol prices by 30%
summary: Qatar's state fuel company, Woqod, announced a surprise 30% hike in petrol prices, effective Friday, amid a slump in global oil prices. The move was made to adjust to the new market reality. The price increase has led to immediate queues at some petrol stations in Qatar.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 1.62 points to 1,635.06, with 156 gainers outnumbering 43 losers. The market volume was 59.8 million lots worth RM 24.3 million.

site_title: Oil heads for third weekly drop as global surplus set to worsen
summary: Oil prices are set to drop for the third consecutive week due to a worsening global surplus, with US crude stockpiles reaching a record high and Iran poised to increase exports following potential sanctions lift. The Energy Information Administration reported a 6% decline in oil futures, down to below $30 a barrel. The global glut is exacerbated by Opec's reduced oil demand forecast for the next four years, further weakening the market.

site_title: Chinese yuan steady, stocks down after weak lending data
summary: China's yuan steadied on Friday, 0.1% up on the week, after central bank support eased market concerns, but Chinese shares dropped 1.4% against the dollar due to weaker-than-expected bank lending data and falling oil prices. The yuan has lost nearly 5% since August and is nearly 1.4% weaker than its start to the year. This follows a turbulent start to 2016, with concerns over Beijing's policymakers' ability to manage the economy, which is heading towards its slowest growth in 25 years.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to pay US$5b to resolve claims on RMBS sale
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay US$5.06 billion to resolve civil claims related to the sale of residential mortgage-backed securities from 2005 to 2007. The bank will pay a US$2.385 billion civil monetary penalty, US$875 million in cash payments, and US$1.8 billion in consumer relief. The settlement will reduce Goldman's fourth-quarter earnings by about US$1.5 billion after tax. The bank will offer consumer relief, including principal reductions and debt support, to affected homeowners and borrowers.

site_title: Haier nears deal to buy GE's appliances business for over US$4b: WSJ
summary: China's Haier Electronics Group Co Ltd is nearing a deal to buy General Electric Co's appliances business for over US$4 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. Haier beat other foreign bidders to secure the deal, which could be announced as soon as Friday. The acquisition would mark a significant expansion for Haier, a leading Chinese appliance manufacturer.

site_title: It's not a sign of economic health when soapmakers lead S&P 500
summary: Consumer staples stocks, including Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola, have outpaced the S&P 500 for seven consecutive weeks, driven by uncertainty about the economy and investors seeking defensive industries. Utility shares, in particular, have surged, with the sector trading at its highest level since 2014. Despite concerns about a growth slowdown, investors are gravitating towards staples and utilities, which historically perform well during economic downturns.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang to get up to US$35m from HCare to boost China business
summary: Eu Yan Sang International will receive up to US$35 million in funding from HCare Investments Holding, a Singapore-based investment vehicle, to boost its business in China. HCare will provide US$10 million initially and up to US$25 million in additional funding. Eu Yan Sang will match this funding with US$1 million in the initial stage and up to US$2.5 million in future stages. The deal aims to support the integrative health and wellness company's expansion in the Chinese market.

site_title: Noble default risk rises most in Asia on debt payment challenge
summary: Noble Group's default risk has surged to 2,593 basis points, the highest in Asia, due to a deepening resources slump and liquidity issues. The company is preparing to refinance $2.1 billion of loans and reported short-term debt of $3 billion. Following rating cuts by Standard & Poor's and Moody's, Noble has been successful in raising cash and maintains creditor support. Despite Fitch's affirmation of its investment-grade ranking, the company's cash flows and liabilities remain at an imbalance.

site_title: Banks vying for largest-ever HDB bond issue
summary: Banks in Singapore are bidding for the largest-ever Housing & Development Board (HDB) bond issue, totaling up to S$1.6 billion. The HDB is seeking proposals for a seven-year bond with a target size of S$1 billion and a S$600 million greenshoe. This would be the largest single issue by the HDB, surpassing its previous record of S$1.5 billion set in 2013.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler accused of inflating sales
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) faced a lawsuit filed by two US dealerships, Napleton Automotive Group, accusing the company of inflating US car sales by rewarding dealerships for falsely reporting higher car sales. The lawsuit casts a cloud over FCA's record 2.2 million vehicle sales last year, a 7% gain from 2014. The company's shares plummeted in Milan and New York. The lawsuit could lead to a reevaluation of FCA's financial results and potentially impact its stock price.

site_title: Developers sold 384 private homes in Dec 2015, down from 759 in Nov: URA
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 384 private homes in December 2015, down from 759 units in November, but higher than the 230 units sold in December 2014. Excluding executive condos, this represents a decrease from the 945 units sold in November and 406 units in December 2014.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Developers sold 384 private homes in December 2015, down from 759 units in November 2015 but higher than the 230 units sold in December 2014.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase profits up, upbeat on US economy
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a 10.2% increase in fourth-quarter earnings to $5.4 billion, lifting annual profits to $24.4 billion. The bank's CEO, Jamie Dimon, expressed a positive outlook on the US economy, citing 2.0-2.5% growth, job creation, and solid consumer spending. Despite a hit to the oil industry from falling crude prices, Dimon believes the economy is "pretty good" and expects some benefits from lower oil prices for consumers.

site_title: US pledges US$4b to speed self-driving cars
summary: The US administration has pledged $4 billion to support the development of self-driving cars through research and testing projects. Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx made the announcement at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, alongside executives from Google, General Motors, Ford, Volvo, Fiat Chrysler, and Honda. The investment aims to create the transportation system of the 21st century, with much work still to be done.

site_title: IHH Healthcare inks deal with Perennial for ParkwayHealth Chengdu Hospital
summary: IHH Healthcare has signed a deal with Perennial Real Estate Holdings to lease space for its 350-bed ParkwayHealth Chengdu Hospital in China, marking the hospital's first foreign tertiary hospital in the country. This is IHH's first hospital in Western China, operated by its largest subsidiary, Parkway Pantai.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed IHH Healthcare Berhad on Friday sealed the deal with Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd to lease a space in Perennial International Health and Medical Hub for its 350-bed ParkwayHealth Chengdu Hospital.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says no plan to ease policy now
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated there are no plans to ease monetary policy, citing sharp declines in oil costs that have kept consumer inflation distant from the 2% target. He expressed optimism about the economy, citing improving underlying price trends and a tightening labor market. However, Kuroda emphasized his willingness to adjust policy if the price trend changes, and the BOJ is expected to cut quarterly inflation forecasts and push back its target at a review on January 28-29.

site_title: Investor Canyon tells Yahoo it cannot waste any more capital
summary: Canyon Capital Advisors, a Los Angeles-based investment firm, sent a letter to Yahoo's board, urging it to prioritize a sale of its core business, assets, or the entire company due to excessive spending on acquisitions totaling over $3 billion. Canyon argues that the company's management has wasted capital and believes the board must commit to preserving its cash reserves. The firm's letter comes as Yahoo faces financial struggles and a decline in its stock price.

site_title: Celine Dion's husband, manager Rene Angelil dies
summary: Celine Dion's husband and manager, Rene Angelil, died on January 14, 2016, at 73, after a long battle with cancer. The news was announced by Dion on Twitter, with the family requesting private mourning time. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau offered condolences to Dion and Angelil's children. Angelil discovered Dion and managed her career, playing a significant role in her success.

images.alt_text: Celine Dion's husband Rene Angelil, who discovered the Canadian pop diva and long managed her career, died on Thursday aged 73 after a struggle with cancer.

site_title: Return of oil slump haunts Najib as fiscal targets appear beyond reach
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is facing fiscal challenges as the country's budget gap may reach 4% of GDP, surpassing its target of 3.1%. The oil slump has forced a reassessment of public spending plans, with potential cuts to operating expenditure and revisions in growth forecasts. Economists warn that spending cuts would weigh on expansion, while a weakening yuan and China's slowdown pose additional headwinds for Malaysia exporters. Najib's plan to balance the budget by 2020 is under threat, with Moody's Investors Service cutting its positive outlook on the sovereign.

site_title: Perennial to jointly operate eldercare home in Chengdu
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Shanghai Summit Property Development and Shanghai RST Chinese Medicine to establish a joint venture that will operate a premium eldercare and retirement home in Chengdu, China. The 40-40-20 joint venture will be managed by a new company, marking Perennial's entry into the Chinese eldercare market.

site_title: Uber CEO says China to soon surpass Silicon Valley in innovation
summary: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick predicts China will soon surpass Silicon Valley in innovation, citing the country's growing cohort of entrepreneurs. Uber's domestic unit in China is valued at over $8 billion after a recent funding round, further solidifying the company's presence in the market. Kalanick believes China's entrepreneurs will eventually eclipse those in Silicon Valley, making it a major player in global technology innovation.

site_title: Fitch affirms Noble's ratings but sounds note of caution
summary: Fitch Ratings has affirmed Noble Group's investment-grade ratings, including a BBB- long-term foreign-currency issuer-default rating and senior unsecured rating, citing the company's improved balance sheet and commitment to access unsecured bank funding. The affirmations come after rival agencies cut the commodity trader to junk, and a record-high credit-default swap price. Noble shares have extended losses in 2016, with a 6.2% decline on Thursday, and the company's bond risk is the highest in Asia.

site_title: Tougher rules on trading books target global banks
summary: Global regulators have unveiled new trading book rules requiring banks to set aside an additional $77 billion in capital by 2019. The rules, part of the Basel Committee's efforts to prevent another financial crisis, ease initial proposals and will mainly impact big trading banks, such as JP Morgan and Deutsche Bank. The new rules increase capital requirements for non-securitized assets by 27% and for securitized assets by 22%. Policymakers hope the rules will provide clarity and promote sustainable businesses, while some lenders are scaling back on trading activities due to the increased costs.

site_title: Germany defies global slowdown in 2015 with 1.7% GDP growth
summary: Germany's economy grew 1.7% in 2015, beating global slowdown expectations. Record employment, rising wages, and expansionary monetary policy fueled domestic consumption. The country's largest economy benefited from the European Central Bank's stimulus, with the government achieving a fiscal surplus of 0.5% of GDP. Despite concerns over China's economic slowdown, Germany's central bank predicts 1.8% GDP growth this year and 1.7% in 2017.

site_title: Oil price plunge seen delaying US$380b worth of projects
summary: Oil price plunge delays $380 billion worth of projects, with 68 major upstream projects impacted, accounting for 27 billion barrels of oil equivalent and 2.9 million barrels a day of production. The decline in crude prices, capped at a third yearly decline in 2015, is expected to remain "lower for longer," limiting confidence for new investments. Companies are reducing costs and deferring projects, with some, like BP and Petroleo Brasileiro, cutting jobs and spending plans. The industry is entering a period of survival mode, with further project deferments and reduced budgets expected.

site_title: Top Philippine fund keeps cash on China volatility
summary: The Philippines' top fund manager, Smith Chua, is maintaining a cash holding due to volatility in China's economy and stock market. His cash allocation is similar to August and September 2015, when it doubled as a result. Chua, chief investment officer at Bank of the Philippine Islands, is cautious about investing in the Philippine equity market amid China's economic slowdown, which is expected to put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Winners of US$1.6b US Powerball jackpot still unknown
summary: Three Powerball ticket holders won the record US$1.6 billion jackpot, each taking home US$528.8 million. The winning tickets were sold at a 7-Eleven in California, a Publix supermarket in Florida, and a Naifeh's Food Mart in Tennessee. The winners have not come forward, with lottery officials in California and Tennessee stating they have not claimed the prize. Winners have up to a year to claim the prize, with the option to accept a multi-year annuity or a lump sum cash payout of approximately US$983.5 million.

site_title: Harry Potter star Alan Rickman dies at 69
summary: Alan Rickman, a renowned British actor known for his villainous roles, has died at 69 after a battle with cancer. Rickman, who won a Golden Globe and a Bafta, was best known for his portrayal of Severus Snape in the Harry Potter films and Hans Gruber in Die Hard. He began his career in theatre and supported himself as a dresser before finding work with the Royal Shakespeare Company. Rickman was also a devoted Labour party supporter and remained politically active throughout his life.

site_title: Art hotel
summary: One Farrer Hotel & Spa in Singapore has published a 240-page book on its extensive art collection, featuring over 700 contemporary Asian artworks. The hotel's art collection, commissioned by the Farrer Park Company, includes abstract works from 68 artists, with each piece carefully selected to complement the hotel's design. The collection is not for sale, but some works are available for purchase through "vertical galleries" in the hotel's lifts. The book aims to provide insight into the art and its spatial context, allowing visitors to appreciate the works in relation to the hotel's space.

site_title: GrabTaxi surprises with move to open engg centre in Seattle
summary: GrabTaxi is opening an engineering center in Seattle, its first in the US, to develop capabilities in machine learning, cloud computing, and predictive analytics. The new hub complements GrabTaxi's existing R&D centers in Singapore and Beijing, and will focus on back-end capabilities to enhance the user experience. The move is seen as a strategic effort to bolster global recruiting efforts and leverage the US technology community. GrabTaxi's entry into the US market is viewed as a positive development, driving innovation and competition in the ride-hailing space.

site_title: US: Stocks rally with oil, tech leading
summary: US stocks rallied on Thursday, rebounding from a previous day's rout, driven by strong earnings from JPMorgan Chase and a rebound in oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.41%, the S&P 500 climbed 1.67%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.97%. These gains pushed the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty and tariff concerns.

site_title: European dark pools expand in face of rules limiting their use
summary: European dark pools expanded by 45% in 2015, outpacing public exchanges, despite EU plans to limit their use. The EU's MiFID II regulations will restrict dark trading to 4% of individual stock trading and 8% of total volume. Despite this, dark pools have seen a 7.8% increase in market share since 2014. Regulators have fined dark venues, including ITG, for rule-breaking, but the practice continues to gain popularity among buy-side investors, with demand expected to continue.

site_title: GE moves HQ to Boston as it embraces digital age
summary: General Electric (GE) is relocating its headquarters from Fairfield, Connecticut, to Boston, Massachusetts, as part of its efforts to adapt to the digital age. The move aims to create a leaner, faster, and more open environment with a constant flow of industry partners, customers, and innovators. GE will maintain a workforce of approximately 800 employees in Boston, with a focus on digital industrial product managers, designers, and developers. The relocation is part of GE's strategic commitment to digital technology and reflects the company's evolution as an industrial company in the digital era.

site_title: Singapore will stay relevant as a trading hub: Sohmen-Pao
summary: Singapore Maritime Foundation's new chairman, Andreas Sohmen-Pao, believes the city-state will remain a significant trading hub despite Shanghai surpassing it as the world's No. 1 port in 2010. Sohmen-Pao argues that Singapore's focus should shift from competing for top port status to facilitating regional trade flows. To retain its hub position, Singapore must attract and retain talent, maintain an open economy, and uphold trustworthiness in its institutions.

site_title: Coal India plans tech overhaul to check widespread theft
summary: Coal India plans a major technological overhaul to combat widespread coal theft and shed its inefficient image, amid the government's plans to open up the sector to private firms. The move aims to boost productivity and cut losses estimated at $1 billion annually. A GPS-based tracking system and electronic "fencing" of mining areas are set to be implemented, with Indian software giants and international companies bidding for contracts to supply tracking and monitoring devices. The overhaul is expected to cost around $75 million initially and is seen as a crucial step to meet the company's target of doubling production to one billion tonnes by 2020.

site_title: Goldman too opposes unfair edge sought by proposed exchange IEX
summary: Goldman Sachs and other major investment firms oppose the proposed exchange IEX, citing concerns that it would give itself an unfair advantage by withholding trade data from other exchanges for fractions of a second. IEX proposes to slow trading by delaying the sharing of buy and sell orders on its exchange by 350 microseconds, while retaining access to information from others. This has sparked complaints from rival exchanges and broker-dealers, who argue that IEX's proposed system would allow it to engage in latency arbitrage and unfairly discriminate against other broker-dealers.

site_title: Jason's internal audit uncovers potential S$2m error
summary: Jason Holdings, a parquet firm, has discovered potential errors in its S$2m financial reporting for the half year ended June 30, 2015. The internal audit found that the company's subsidiary, Jason Parquet Specialist, failed to pay employee salaries on time, did not comply with banking covenants, and made erroneous submissions for trade facilities. The audit also revealed a system design gap that led to a potential overstatement of S$2m in the profit-and-loss position. The company has commissioned external auditors and a special committee to review the findings and strengthen internal controls.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Four adjoining Joo Chiat shophouses up for sale
summary: A row of four adjoining three-storey shophouses in Singapore's Joo Chiat area has been put up for sale via public tender by CBRE. The site, zoned as 'commercial', has a combined land area of 7,616 sq ft and a gross floor area of 17,980 sq ft. Possible uses include offices, banks, restaurants, and cinemas, with a potential to increase the GFA to 22,848 sq ft. The site is within the Joo Chiat Conservation Area and has a plot ratio of 3.0, with a guide price of S$8.8 million.

site_title: Europe: Shares partially recover after 13-month low, Renault slumps
summary: European stocks plummeted to a 13-month low, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index falling 1.5% to 1,334.36 points. The automobile sector led the decline, with Renault slumping following emissions inspections at three of its sites. However, the index recovered slightly after a surge in crude oil and metals prices boosted commodities-related stocks, with Anglo American jumping 13%. The recovery was limited, with the index still at its lowest level since December 2014.

site_title: No business too small to be hacked
summary: Small and mid-size businesses are increasingly susceptible to ransomware, a type of malware that holds data hostage for a ransom. Companies like Rokenbok Education, a California-based toy company, have been hit by ransomware attacks, resulting in significant revenue loss. Specialists warn that limited security budgets and outdated security measures leave companies vulnerable to attacks. To protect against ransomware, businesses can take simple steps such as updating anti-virus software, adding firewalls, and creating strong passwords. Experts also recommend conducting security audits and hiring firms specializing in digital security.

site_title: Why I will not vote for Donald Trump
summary: A prominent Republican voter expresses reluctance to support Donald Trump for president, citing his lack of qualifications, ignorance on national issues, emotional instability, and vindictiveness. Trump's temperament is deemed erratic and inconsistent, with a history of ridiculing opponents and making derogatory comments. The author believes Trump's nomination would redefine the Republican Party, turning it into an "angry, bigoted, populist" one, and potentially lead to national catastrophe. The writer, who has worked in Republican administrations, concludes that party loyalty must be reevaluated in light of Trump's candidacy.

site_title: Sydney apartment rents drop to three-year low on oversupply
summary: Sydney apartment rents have dropped to a three-year low due to an oversupply of new units, according to a Domain report. The median weekly rent for units fell to A$500 from A$510 in the September quarter, while house rents remained at a record level of A$530 a week. The decline suggests that the record levels of new apartments are exceeding rental demand, contributing to a cooling Sydney property market. This comes as the city recorded its worst quarter in four years, with home values doubling since 2008.

site_title: The 3 missing links in the entrepreneurial ecosystem
summary: Singapore's entrepreneurial ecosystem is growing, but gaps remain. Parents, educators, and mid-life entrepreneurs need to be involved to foster a more entrepreneurial culture. Parents' influence on children's entrepreneurial aspirations is a significant obstacle, with many students dropping out due to parental pressure. To address this, schools can offer family engagement programs and involve parents in curriculum design. Educators also need experience in entrepreneurship to effectively teach the subject, and policy-makers can provide resources and funding for teacher training and industry partnerships. Additionally, support for mid-life entrepreneurs is lacking, and initiatives like the Young Entrepreneurs Scheme can be expanded to target this demographic.

site_title: A new global economic crisis may be brewing, says top China official
summary: China's top diplomat, Yang Jiechi, warns of a possible new global economic crisis, citing market volatility and concerns over the country's slowing economy. The warning comes amid a painful market rout, with Asian stocks sliding and China's 2015 trade falling 8% year-on-year. Yang reassures that China's economy will maintain "sustainable and stable growth," but acknowledges the need for policymakers to address challenges and prevent negative effects from domestic policy measures. The G20 has also "resolutely opposed" protectionism.

site_title: BOJ chief again says he stands ready to act as machine orders slump
summary: BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated the central bank's commitment to achieving 2% annual inflation, despite a drop in core machinery orders for November, a leading indicator of business investment. Core machinery orders fell 14.4% seasonally-adjusted from October, exceeding economists' predictions. The yen's recent appreciation against the dollar threatens to undermine Japan's economic gains, leading some to speculate that the BOJ may announce further monetary easing to boost corporate earnings.

site_title: Banks, O&M stocks hit as selling resumes
summary: Singapore stocks plummeted 1.93% to 2,644.57 on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 51.93 points. Offshore and marine (O&M) stocks were heavily sold, led by Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, while banks were also hit due to worries over commodity finance, China, and non-trade US$ lending. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.2% on Wednesday, taking its 2016 loss to 7.3%, with Facebook, Amazon, and Google among the most affected stocks.

site_title: Internet set to cut cord with US government this year
summary: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is set to cut its ties with the US government by the end of September 2016, marking a significant shift towards asserting the independence of the web. ICANN's CEO, Fadi Chehade, says the transition will not change how the Internet works, but will reassure users, businesses, and governments about its integrity. The move is a symbolic gesture, as the US government's role has been largely symbolic, and ICANN has been handling its functions effectively for years.

site_title: Three winners of record US$1.6b Powerball jackpot
summary: Three winners of the record US$1.6 billion Powerball jackpot remain anonymous, with each ticket worth US$528.8 million. The winning numbers were 08 27 34 04 19 and Powerball 10. The jackpot was the largest in North America, with odds of 1 in 292 million. Winners must accept a multi-year annuity to receive the full prize, with a cash payout of US$983.5 million. The California store where one winning ticket was sold will receive a US$1 million bonus.

site_title: India's power reforms, salary hikes spook investors in state bonds
summary: India's power reforms, which aim to rescue the ailing power sector and end blackouts, are causing concern among state governments as investors shy away from their debt. Foreign bond investors are giving state government debt a wide berth due to the plan's potential for a flood of new issuance at a higher cost. State governments, which rely heavily on debt markets to fund their fiscal deficits, are facing increased bond yields and potential interest payment shortfalls, with one official stating that his state may need to borrow an additional 80 billion rupees.

site_title: Ezra slips into the red in Q1, plans to boost vessel utilisation
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singapore-based shipping company, reported a net loss of US$55.35 million in the first quarter of 2016, primarily due to a decline in revenue at its Emas Offshore unit. Despite this, revenue rose 19% to US$152.3 million, driven by an increase in turnover from its yard operating subsidiary, Triyards. The company plans to boost vessel utilisation and cut costs, aiming to lift utilisation at its Emas Offshore unit to 75% from 67%.

site_title: Return of risk is root cause of market shock
summary: The recent market shock is attributed to a return of risk, rather than the previously cited factors of weak oil, deflation, or China's slowdown. The seeds for the collapse were sown in misplaced faith in the "wealth effect" of artificially inflated asset prices, which was fueled by central bank monetary stimulus programs. This approach distorted resource allocation and took risk off the table, but ultimately proved flawed as markets now face a re-pricing of risk. Investors are grappling with the painful return of risk, and it is doubtful that monetary policy tools will have a significant effect.

site_title: Over 16 per cent more COEs for next three months
summary: Singapore's next quota period (February-April 2016) will have 25,210 COEs, a 16.4% increase from the current period. The increase affects most categories except goods vehicles and buses, with Cat A (cars under 1,600cc) seeing a 22.5% rise and Cat E (open category) experiencing a 23.9% increase. Passenger car COEs meet expectations, with some dealers hoping for a bigger increase. The decrease in Cat C (commercial vehicles) is attributed to high take-up rates under the Early Turnover Scheme.

site_title: City buzz
summary: Exhibition on Screen, a film series about renowned art pieces, will be screened at The Projector from Jan 16-24. The series, directed by Phil Grabsky, features five films on artists Matisse, Van Gogh, Rembrandt, Vermeer, and The Impressionists. The films, averaging 90 minutes, delve into the lives and works of the artists, providing insights that viewers may not know unless they talk to the curators themselves. Tickets start at S$8.

site_title: Euro gains on report ECB may hold back action
summary: The euro gained around half a percent against the US dollar after the European Central Bank's policy makers expressed skepticism about the need for further policy action in the near term. Oil-rich Canada's dollar fell to its lowest level since 2003, fueling speculation that the Bank of Canada could cut interest rates as early as next week. The ECB's initial 2018 growth and inflation forecasts will be released on March 10, but rate-setters remain wary about further action despite falling oil prices and low inflation.

site_title: Class act
summary: Singapore Art Week begins on Saturday, featuring over 100 events, including the premier art fair, Art Stage. The fair will showcase works by top artists from 33 countries, including Raqib Shaw and Ronald Ventura. Art Stage director Lorenzo Rudolf is concerned about the current economic market but aims to position contemporary art as a significant part of contemporary life and society. Collectors Livia and Marc Straus will be attending the fair, adhering to their four rules of collecting art: buying what you love, looking for durable artists, buying the best of an artist's work, and paying the right price. The Strauses plan to explore Asian art in greater depth during their visit and may offer a residency to a young Filipino painter.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Central banks should heed longer-term economic interest
summary: Central banks should prioritize long-term economic interest over short-term political gains, maintaining their independence from external influences. This ensures effective monetary policy management, particularly in managing inflation and maintaining price stability. In countries like Nigeria, central bank independence has led to improved macroeconomic stability and better governance. However, there are contradictions between central bank independence and elected governments' political legitimacy, and central banks must strike a balance between defending their independence and avoiding becoming overly politicized.

site_title: Default rate expected to rise further in 2016: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service predicts a rise in global speculative-grade default rates in 2016, with a forecasted 3.9% rate by the end of the year, below the historical average of 4.2%. The US speculative-grade default rate is expected to rise to 4.4% and Europe to 3%. The oil-and-gas industry is forecasted to have the highest default rate in Europe, while metals- and-mining industries will lead defaults in the US. In 2015, 35 corporate issuers defaulted, with 108 defaults overall, a significant increase from the previous year.

site_title: Higher provisions seen at US banks exposed to energy loans
summary: US banks exposed to energy loans are expected to set aside more money to cover potential losses as oil prices near 12-year lows. BOK Financial Corp, Hancock Holding Co, and Associated Banc-Corp have increased their provisions for bad loans. Analysts predict energy loans will be conservatively underwritten, and regional banks with heavy energy exposure will weather the downturn. However, some analysts, such as those at Goldman Sachs, forecast oil prices could fall to $20 a barrel, raising concerns about the banks' energy reserves.

site_title: Committee on Future Economy has its work cut out
summary: Singapore embarks on a major economic review, the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE), to assess its standing and possibly refresh its economic blueprint. The review aims to identify Singapore's priority growth industries and clusters, design growth strategies, and address domestic challenges such as rising costs and labour/skill constraints. The CFE will build on the 2010 Economic Strategies Committee report, incorporating new global and domestic realities, including the Internet of Things and disruptive innovation. The government has allocated S$19 billion for R&D and skills development to boost the economy.

site_title: Drones spark debate on air space ownership rights
summary: A Kentucky landowner, William Merideth, shot down a drone owned by hobbyist John Boggs, claiming it was trespassing over his property. Boggs is suing Merideth, arguing that the government controls the nation's air space and Merideth has no right to shoot down the drone. The case raises questions about property rights and air space ownership, with the Federal Aviation Administration stating that every inch above the ground is the government's jurisdiction. The issue is becoming more urgent as drones crowd America's skies, with 700,000 estimated to have been sold last year.

site_title: A fair world doesn't have to be an inefficient one
summary: Economists often focus on efficiency, defined as the same as gross domestic product (GDP), to measure a country's productivity. Critics argue that this focus ignores issues of equality, fairness, and the welfare of future generations. However, some argue that economic growth can enrich the poor as well as the rich, and that efficiency can lead to gradual improvement through institutional or policy tweaks. Economists should consider the trade-off between efficiency and equality, but not give up on the pursuit of a more efficient world.

site_title: Growing up in a crawl space
summary: A young boy, Jack, celebrates his 5th birthday in a windowless room with his mother, Ma, who was kidnapped at 17 and imprisoned by a man. The room serves as their only world, with Ma creating a normal upbringing for Jack. As they escape the room and enter the outside world, Jack struggles to adjust to the new reality, missing the familiar confines of his childhood home. The film, Room, conveys hope and despair, exploring the unbreakable bond between a mother and child amidst captivity and freedom.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint JV tops bids, plans 800-900 units on plum seafacing site
summary: A consortium led by Frasers Centrepoint has secured the top bid of S$624.18 million for a 99-year site near East Coast Park, planning to build an 800-900 unit condo with sea-facing units. The site's proximity to the future Siglap MRT Station and East Coast Park/beach are expected to attract buyers. The consortium, which includes Sekisui House and KH Capital, plans to launch the project within a year, with an average selling price estimated at S$1,500 to S$1,600 psf.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' take on Thai Beverage, Overseas Education, Dutech Holdings, and China Aviation Oil. Thai Beverage is exploring acquisition opportunities, including Peroni and Grolsch, to diversify its presence geographically. Overseas Education's earnings are expected to decline due to a softer economy and restructuring of multinational corporations. Dutech Holdings has a strong track record of sales growth and is poised for further expansion. China Aviation Oil is initiated with a "buy" rating due to its low-risk profits and potential for mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Take apocalyptic market calls with sackful of salt
summary: A strategist at Societe Generale has forecasted a US recession, with US policy rates slashed to -5%, the S&P 500 losing 75% of its value, and a global trade war. However, this apocalyptic scenario is considered highly uncertain and lacks a specific timeframe. Royal Bank of Scotland analysts advise investors to "sell mostly everything," but this advice is also difficult to follow due to the lack of a clear timeline. Investors should approach such forecasts with caution and consider alternative views, as even the most pessimistic predictions can be wrong for extended periods.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jumbo Group has opened its third restaurant in Shanghai and plans to expand to at least three more outlets in China and Singapore within two years. The new restaurant, located at the Shanghai International Finance Centre, occupies 650 square meters and features a luxury shopping mall with high-spending business community. Revenue from Jumbo's operations in China accounted for 8.5% of total revenue in the 2015 financial year, up from 5.8% in the previous year. Jumbo aims to explore acquisitions and joint ventures to strengthen its market position and expand its network of F&B outlets.

site_title: Cleaning it up for jazz fest
summary: Local hip-hop trio Mediocre Haircut Crew (MHC) will perform at the Singapore International Jazz Festival's (SingJazz) LushLovesLocal Stage. The group, comprising Aditya Mirchandani Rodrigues and Fahim Fazil, will share the stage with international jazz artists such as Candy Dulfer and Joss Stone. MHC, which only formed last year, is known for their explicit rhymes and will need to tone down their performance for the festival. The 3rd SingJazz will take place at Marina Bay Sands from March 4-6, with tickets ranging from S$85-250.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Attacks in Indonesian capital kill 7, including 5 of the gunmen
summary: Multiple attacks in Jakarta, Indonesia's capital, killed seven people, including five of the assailants. Gunmen armed with explosives and assault rifles targeted the Sarinah shopping center and other areas, leaving 20 others wounded. Indonesia blames the Islamic State (IS) for the attack, which marks the group's violence in the country for the first time. President Joko Widodo condemned the assault, appealing for calm, and ordered troops to provide reinforcements to police.

site_title: How debt chiefs deal with QE's bond scarcity in eurozone
summary: Debt chiefs in the eurozone are addressing a perceived issue of bond scarcity caused by the European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) program. To mitigate this, issuers such as France's AFT and Germany's Finance Agency are selling "off-the-run" bonds, which help preserve liquidity along the entire bond curve. This strategy is seen as a way to tackle the distortion impact of QE and increase the diversity of available securities for national central banks to buy.

site_title: Qatar may leave Oneworld over US access dispute
summary: Qatar Airways may leave the Oneworld alliance if American Airlines continues to push for limits on US access for Gulf airlines. CEO Akbar Al Baker stated that Qatar Airways will not tolerate unfair business practices and may form its own mini-alliance if necessary. Al Baker argued that US carriers have also benefited from government subsidies, contradicting claims of Gulf airlines receiving illegal aid. A potential split could impact British Airways, with which Qatar Airways has a 10% stake, and affect the US airline industry.

site_title: Most Singaporeans lack trust in financial planning industry: poll
summary: A survey conducted by the Financial Planning Standards Board (FPSB) found that 7 in 10 Singaporeans lack trust in the financial planning industry, citing barriers such as lack of knowledge, excessive paperwork, and perceived complexity. Despite this, Singaporeans working with certified financial planners (CFPs) express greater financial confidence. The survey, which polled over 19,000 adults, including 1,001 Singaporeans, also found that 53% rely on friends and family for financial matters, while 45% work with financial planners. The FPSB is calling for efforts to build trust in the industry.

site_title: Dying for football
summary: A biographical drama "Concussion" tells the story of Dr. Bennet Omalu, a medical outsider who diagnosed a former NFL player with CTE, a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head trauma. Despite initial dismissal by the NFL, Omalu's findings forced the league to reevaluate its stance on concussions. The film, directed by Peter Landesman and starring Will Smith, explores the consequences of Omalu's discovery and its impact on the sport. The movie received mixed reviews, but highlights the importance of speaking up for those who cannot, especially the deceased.

site_title: Korean TV on the move
summary: Viu, a Hong Kong-based OTT video service, has launched in Singapore, offering a wide range of Korean dramas and variety shows. Securing a pan-regional deal with top four Korean broadcasters, Viu provides subtitles in both Mandarin and English. The "freemium" model offers free content with optional paid subscription for additional features and content. Launched in Hong Kong in October, Viu has been downloaded over 500,000 times and plans to expand into Malaysia, Indonesia, and India in 2016, with a premium subscription service to be rolled out within six months.

site_title: Investing in UK property has become more complicated
summary: The UK government has proposed a 3% increase in stamp duty for investors buying second homes or investment properties in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. This new tax, similar to Singapore's Additional Buyer Stamp Duty, aims to address the growing housing affordability gap. However, it may cost overseas investors thousands of pounds more in taxes, and the rules will also apply to joint owners, spouses, and properties held in trusts or companies. The changes are expected to net the UK government an extra £600 million in 2016, with a potential £900 million in 2017, primarily spent on measures to extend home ownership.

site_title: Car industry's green push challenged by low petrol prices
summary: The US car industry's green push is being challenged by low petrol prices, which have reduced consumer pressure to buy fuel-efficient cars. Despite a 26% rise in fuel economy since 2004, the industry has seen a decline in fuel economy for the fleet overall in 2015, with fuel-efficient pickup trucks and SUVs dominating sales. Carmakers are now focusing on improving the performance of these vehicles, with some officials expressing concerns that meeting future fuel economy targets will be difficult. Industry leaders, including Honda and Toyota, are adapting to the changing market and investing in alternative technologies.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's Q4 DPU beats forecast by 1.9%
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.64 Singapore cents for Q4 2015, beating its forecast by 1.9%. The Reit's net property income (NPI) surpassed expectations, driven by rental contributions from Intellicentre 2 in Sydney and lower-than-expected property expenses. The company's annualised yield is 6.97% based on its IPO price, and its portfolio occupancy remains healthy at 94.8%. Despite volatile macro-economic conditions, the Reit's manager remains optimistic about the industry's fundamentals and plans to expand its portfolio of quality data centre assets.

site_title: Singapore bourse mauled by flood of negative news
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted nearly 2% on Thursday, joining a regional sell-off sparked by negative news including a terror blast in Jakarta, oil price volatility, and China's economic woes. The Dow Jones fell 2.2% overnight, while China's Shanghai Composite rebounded 2% after a volatile session. Experts warn of a prolonged market downturn, citing an "artificial" economic boom fueled by cheap money, which has led to inflated asset prices and a lack of confidence in the global economy.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Value investors go dumpster diving during sell-off
summary: Value investors are taking advantage of the market's recent sell-off, buying shares in beaten-down companies such as China Mobile, Microsoft, and Dialog Semiconductor. Funds like the Smead Value Fund and the Wells Fargo Special Mid Cap Value Fund are deploying cash to purchase undervalued stocks in sectors like retailers, banks, and energy. These contrarian strategies aim to capitalize on the market's volatility, with the funds seeking to deliver positive returns over the year.

site_title: US$ and energy prices hold back US growth
summary: The US economy showed mixed signals from late November to early January, with improvements in the labour market and consumer spending offset by a strong dollar and low energy prices. Economic activity expanded in nine of 12 districts, with half reporting a mostly positive outlook for future growth. Labour markets improved, but manufacturing sectors weakened due to weak global demand and low energy prices, with most districts citing a strong dollar as a negative impact.

site_title: Indonesia cuts key rate to help weak economy
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 7.25% in a bid to boost its economy, which is growing at its slowest rate in six years. The decision was made despite recent attacks in Jakarta, and analysts expect it to be the first step in an easing cycle. The move is seen as a long-overdue boost to the struggling economy, with economists welcoming the rate cut and citing a six-year low inflation rate and a 6.2% jump in the rupiah in the fourth quarter of 2015.

site_title: WHO declares Ebola epidemic over as Liberia gets the all-clear but warns of more flare-ups
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the end of the Ebola epidemic in Liberia, the last affected country, after 42 days without new cases. The declaration comes after Liberia's last two patients were tested negative, marking the end of the outbreak that killed over 11,000 people across West Africa. However, the WHO warned that "more flare-ups are expected" and urged continued engagement to prevent further outbreaks. This is the third time Liberia has been given the all-clear, following previous declarations in May and September.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 9.1 points to close at 1,633.44, with 681 losers and 222 gainers in Thursday's trading. The market saw a significant drop despite no major news events.

site_title: Merchant shipping unaffected by Chinese military presence in South China Sea
summary: China's growing military presence in the South China Sea has raised concerns about control over key shipping lanes, but merchant shipping operations remain unaffected. Despite diplomatic tensions, ship owners say business as usual, with the US military warning that Beijing's actions threaten freedom of navigation. Insurers also report no impact on trading, citing the region's low risk status. Chinese President Xi Jinping has stated that freedom of navigation will not be a problem, but tensions have risen with China's construction of man-made islands in disputed waters.

site_title: British actor Alan Rickman dies at 69
summary: Veteran British actor Alan Rickman, known for roles in Harry Potter and Robin Hood films, has died at 69. His agent confirmed the news, citing cancer as the cause. Rickman was a renowned stage actor and portrayed villainous characters throughout his career. He will be remembered for his iconic portrayal of Professor Snape in the Harry Potter series.

site_title: Twitter is sued by widow over ISIS attack
summary: A widow, Tamara Fields, has sued Twitter for allegedly allowing ISIS to spread its message on the platform, contributing to the growth of the terrorist group. Fields claims that without Twitter, ISIS would not have become the most-feared terrorist group in the world. The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages for Twitter's alleged "knowingly or with willful blindness" provision of material support to terrorists. Twitter has not commented on the lawsuit.

site_title: New local acts take flight in StageFright
summary: Singapore's StageFright music showcase, now in its third year, is set to feature a diverse lineup of local and foreign musicians, including Japanese folk-pop singer Hiroki Sunayama and indie acts Mt Spencer and Wan from the band Oligarchy. The event aims to promote original music made in Singapore, with a focus on showcasing emerging talent. StageFright XXII will take place on January 20 at Artistry Cafe, with a lineup that includes singer-songwriters Yeow An and Skye Soon. The event is curated by veteran local singer-songwriter Kevin Mathews, who emphasizes the importance of original music made in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Shell to expand Asia lubricants business on population, vehicle growth
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to expand its lubricants business in Asia over the next five years, driven by growing vehicle sales and population in China and Asean countries. The company will open a new plant in Singapore in 2016, and has already invested in China, including a plant in Tianjin. Shell expects strong demand growth in Asia, particularly from Asean markets, and is focusing on selling premium fuels and exploring biofuels and gas-to-liquid jet fuel. The expansion aims to capitalize on Asia's growing demand for lubricants, which is seen to be strong due to private car sales.

site_title: US jobless claims rise
summary: US jobless claims rose by 7,000 to 284,000 in the week ending January 9, according to the Labor Department. This modest increase follows a downward trend, and the four-week moving average rose by 3,000 to 278,750. The unemployment rate remains at 5.0%, near full employment. Despite volatility in jobless claims, economists predict the labor market will continue to tighten, with payroll growth expected to remain strong beyond the initial seasonal fluctuations.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher, helped by JPMorgan, oil
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by rising oil prices and JPMorgan's strong results, which boosted bank stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 54.24 points, or 0.34%, to 16,205.65, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes also increased.

site_title: Bank of England sees oil slump weighing a bit on inflation
summary: The Bank of England kept interest rates at a record-low 0.5% for the sixth month in a row, citing a recent oil slump as a factor weighing on inflation, but acknowledging it may boost economic growth. Policymakers expect slower-than-forecast economic growth and noted the impact of oil prices on global inflation is unclear. The decision comes amidst market volatility and growing signs of weakness in Britain's economic recovery.

site_title: The China bubble pops
summary: China's economy has experienced a significant slowdown, with annual growth rates dropping from 10.6% in 2007-2011 to 6.9% in 2015. The country's stock market turmoil and global repercussions are a result of this decline. China's massive trade surplus and huge importer status have led to a global crash in oil and commodity prices, affecting commodity exporters and Asian suppliers. Experts warn that China may stagnate, with growth rates potentially dropping to 1-2%, and that high debts and an ageing population are major concerns.

site_title: Travel to Jakarta could take a hit after attacks
summary: Travel demand to Jakarta may soften after blasts at Sarinah shopping mall in central Jakarta, killing at least seven people, including four attackers. The attacks occurred just weeks before Chinese New Year, a peak travel period. Travel agents expect bookings to decline in the short term, with some advising travelers to register with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and consider purchasing travel insurance. Airlines such as Singapore Airlines and Jetstar continue to operate flights to Jakarta, but passengers are advised to arrive early due to potential traffic congestion. Travel trends are expected to rebound in 6-9 months.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Bowie's lasting legacy of imagination
summary: David Bowie's new album, Blackstar, released just days before his death, explores mortality and the art of creation while dying. The album's themes and lyrics, including the song "Lazarus," have been reinterpreted by critics and those close to the artist. Bowie's death on January 10, 2016, was a shock to fans, but his legacy as a creative force continues to inspire. His friend and producer Tony Visconti described Blackstar as "a parting gift," and the album's meaning has been reevaluated in the wake of Bowie's passing.

site_title: Oil rout forces BOE to keep key rate at record low
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has decided to keep its key interest rate at a record-low 0.5% amid concerns about the UK's economic growth and inflation. Eight out of nine MPC members agreed, citing market volatility and weakened forecasts for inflation and growth. The decision reflects the BOE's cautious stance on tightening monetary policy, with policymakers showing little inclination to raise rates soon. This maintains the BOE's stance for almost seven years, as domestic cost growth remains weaker than desired.

site_title: German GDP grew 1.7% in 2015, strongest rate in 4 years
summary: Germany's economy expanded by 1.7% in 2015, the strongest rate in four years, according to a preliminary estimate from the Federal Statistics Office. The growth was driven by strong private consumption and higher state spending, offsetting a weaker contribution from trade amid a slowdown in emerging markets. This surpasses economists' expectations of a 1.6% growth rate.

site_title: Singapore shares close sharply weaker as O&M stocks, banks take beating
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted 51.93 points or 1.9% to 2,644.57, marking the start of 2016 with a sharp sell-off. Offshore and marine stocks, led by Keppel Corp's 6.4% drop, were heavily sold off, while bank stocks also took a beating. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 2.2% on Wednesday, taking its 2016 fall to 7.3%. The US market showed signs of recovery on Thursday, with futures trading 100 points higher, but selling persisted in Singapore.

site_title: Tougher rules on trading books target global banks
summary: Global regulators have unveiled new trading book rules requiring major banks to set aside US$77 billion in extra capital from 2019. The rules, part of Basel Committee of banking supervisors' efforts to prevent another financial crisis, ease initial proposals and target big banks like JP Morgan and Deutsche Bank. The changes, while not a huge hike in capital requirements, may dampen ambitions to expand trading activities. The rules aim to end incentives for banks to shift assets between their banking and trading books and promote more consistent capital calculations.

site_title: Would-be comeback kid Tinkler says coal is far from doomed
summary: Australian entrepreneur Nathan Tinkler, 39, is re-entering the coal industry, despite its decline, citing forecasts of continued demand from Asian markets, particularly India. Tinkler believes coal is not "far from doomed" and that its lower cost compared to natural gas and solar power will keep it in demand. Australia is forecast to regain its position as the world's largest coal exporter, with shipments expected to grow 4.5% a year through 2020. Tinkler's company, Australian Pacific Coal, has agreed to buy a stake in a coal venture in New South Wales state, valuing the company at A$86 million.

site_title: Fed's Bullard says oil's fall may delay inflation return to 2%
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis President James Bullard said the recent decline in oil prices may delay the return of inflation to the central bank's 2% target, citing a "very substantial" drop in oil prices contributing to low inflation. Under a scenario where oil prices fall through June, a return to 2% inflation wouldn't occur until mid-2017. Despite this, Bullard described falling oil prices as a net positive for the US, citing strong automobile sales and accelerated real personal consumption expenditures growth.

site_title: ECB policy makers wary of further action despite uncertain future
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) policy makers are skeptical about further policy action in the near term, despite inflation expectations sinking. Some ECB officials believe it's time for fiscal policy, infrastructure investments, and structural reforms to address economic challenges. The ECB's next rate meeting is expected to be relatively uneventful, with the big test coming when the bank releases its initial 2018 growth and inflation forecasts in March. ECB President Mario Draghi's December measures were seen as insufficient, and investors are holding out hope for further easing, but ECB rate setters remain wary of taking action.

site_title: Hot stocks: Keppel and Sembcorp Marine fall more than 6%
summary: Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, offshore and marine conglomerates, fell 6.4% and 6.8% respectively on Thursday due to renewed concerns over the potential bankruptcy of their largest client, Sete Brasil. The stocks are being haunted by media reports speculating on the potential financial impact if Sete Brasil files for bankruptcy. The companies have outstanding orders worth S$11.6 billion and S$10 billion with Sete Brasil, and analysts warn that if the bankruptcy occurs, both companies may have to impair their orderbooks and revenues.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: CIT posts 9% drop in Q4 DPU
summary: Cambridge Indl Trust (CIT) reported a 9% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter due to reduced capital distributions. Despite a 10.7% increase in net property income to S$21.61 million, CIT units closed 3.6% lower. The trust manager plans to seek acquisitions to achieve sustainable growth and increase unitholder returns, with a focus on domestic opportunities. CIT's gross revenue grew 13% to S$112.2 million, and portfolio occupancy stood at 94.3%. The trust expects rental pressures amid a softer economic environment this year.

site_title: Selldown in O&M stocks hammers Keppel, SembMarine
summary: Singapore-listed offshore and marine (O&M) stocks, including Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, plummeted on Thursday after Brent crude oil dipped below US$30 per barrel, sparking fears of writedowns of up to S$2 billion for the two companies. Keppel shares fell 6.4% and Sembcorp Marine shares plummeted 6.8%, with valuations hitting their lowest in nearly 15 years. Analysts warn of a sector-wide downturn, with predictions of oil prices staying low indefinitely. The sector's prospects are dim, with analysts predicting a net loss for Sembcorp Marine in Q4 and Keppel facing a massive writedown if Sete Brasil goes bankrupt.

site_title: More turbulence looms over Singapore bond market: S&P
summary: Singapore's corporate bond market is expected to remain turbulent in the next 12 months, according to a note from Standard & Poor's. Defaults or distressed exchanges, which have recently occurred in the energy and commodity sectors, are unlikely to remain concentrated in these areas. The agency cited two recent cases, including a default by Indonesian mobile-phone distributor Trikomsel Oke Tbk and a potential default by Hong Kong-based Pacific Andes Resources Development Ltd, as evidence of the widespread nature of the problem. S&P attributes the issue to the market's shift towards riskier bonds in search of yield.

site_title: Update: Several winners hit US$1.6b Powerball jackpot
summary: Several US Powerball jackpot winners, including one in California, Florida, and Tennessee, shared a record-breaking $1.6 billion jackpot. The winning numbers were 4, 8, 19, 27, and 34, with a 10 as the Powerball number. The odds of winning were 1 in 292 million, with ticket sales reaching record levels, generating over $1 million an hour in the final hours before the draw. The winners have the option to take the full jackpot in 29 years or a one-off payment of at least $930 million.

site_title: GrabTaxi to open engineering centre in Seattle
summary: GrabTaxi plans to open an engineering centre in Seattle, Washington, to build a dedicated team for cloud computing, Big Data management, and machine learning capabilities. This move aims to attract top US talent and expand its global reach. The centre will complement GrabTaxi's existing R&D centres in Singapore and Beijing. Anthony Tan, co-founder and CEO, sees this as crucial for GrabTaxi's success in its mission to build an on-demand ecosystem in South-east Asia.

site_title: Next COE quota up 16.4%
summary: Singapore's next Certificate of Entitlement (COE) quota period from February to April 2016 will have 25,210 COEs, a 16.4% increase from the previous period. All COE classes except commercial vehicles will see an increase, with Cat A (cars under 1,600cc) up 22.5%, Cat B (cars above 1,600cc) up 18%, and Cat E (open category) up 23.9%. The decrease in Cat C (commercial vehicles) is 32.6%. COE premiums have also risen across the board, with Cat A premiums exceeding S$100,000.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall close to 3-month lows, Tesco outshines
summary: European shares fell 1.4% to near three-month lows due to weak oil prices and concerns over global economic growth. Despite this, Tesco rose 6.5% after posting better-than-expected results during the Christmas period. Weaker-than-expected results from Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Spruengli and Cartier owner Richemont also impacted the market.

site_title: Silent upon a peak in Darien
summary: A wine enthusiast shares their newfound favorite wine, Montrachet by Domaine Romanee-Conti, after tasting it twice in recent days. The small, 8-hectare vineyard, situated in Puligny-Montrachet and Chassagne-Montrachet, produces highly expensive and sought-after wines due to its limited production and high price. Other notable Montrachet wines, such as those by Domaines Ramonet, Leflaive, and Lafon, are also discussed, with the author concluding that Montrachet is the wine they most admire and enjoy.

site_title: Waning central bank power cuts forex market adrift
summary: Central banks' efforts to boost growth through currency devaluation are yielding mixed results, with investors becoming increasingly skeptical of their ability to influence exchange rates. Despite policy easing, currencies such as the yen, euro, and Swedish crown have strengthened, rather than weakened, against major currencies. The impact of currency devaluations on inflation and exports has also waned, making it harder for central banks to achieve their goals. As a result, investors are turning to safe-haven currencies like the yen and commodities, and market volatility is expected to continue.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's Q4 DPU beats forecast by 1.9%
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a Q4 DPU of 1.64 Singapore cents, beating its forecast by 1.9%. The Reit's net property income (NPI) also surpassed its forecast by 1.9%. The company attributed the better-than-expected results to rental contributions from Intellicentre 2 and lower property expenses. This translates to an annualised yield of 6.97% based on the IPO offer price. The Reit's DPU for the full year surpassed its forecast by 1.9%, with a total of 6.84 cents.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint-led JV tops bids for plum housing site at Siglap Rd
summary: A consortium led by Frasers Centrepoint topped bids for a 99-year leasehold private residential site in Singapore, with a bid of S$624.18 million or S$858 per square foot per plot ratio. The 1.9-hectare site is estimated to yield 750 private homes, near the future Siglap MRT Station on the Thomson-East Coast Line, set to complete in 2023. The second-highest bid was from a tie-up involving Hong Leong Holdings, City Developments, and TID Residential at S$600.12 million.

site_title: Perennial enters eldercare and retirement home space in China with new MOU
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd has entered into a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) for a joint venture to operate a premium eldercare and retirement home in Chengdu, China. The joint venture will be managed by a 40-40-20 company, marking Perennial's first foray into eldercare and retirement home operations in China. The home will be located at Chengdu East High Speed Railway Integrated Development Plot D2.

site_title: Asia-Pacific unlikely to drive global growth: UN
summary: The United Nations reported that Asia-Pacific's developing economies have plateaued, with a 4.5% growth rate in 2015, the slowest since 2009.
