site_title: EU Commission says changing China's status would impact EU economy
summary: The European Commission stated that changing China's economic status under EU anti-dumping rules would impact the European economy. The Commission plans to consult with trade partners and European industry on the decision, which would alter the methodology for calculating anti-dumping duties. This change is expected to affect the European economy's output.

site_title: Amid oil price plunge, price-setting Brent supported by Shell sales to Asia
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has accumulated a significant portion of British Forties crude oil cargoes, leading to tighter supplies and strengthening in the Brent market despite a global oil price plunge. Shell is shipping around 8 million barrels of Forties to Asia, more than half of the month's production, due to a free trade agreement with South Korea. This has resulted in higher Forties price differentials, backwardation in short-term swaps, and a widening spread between prompt and second-month Brent futures prices.

site_title: World feels the impact of China's economic woes
summary: China's economic slowdown is having a ripple effect globally, with countries from South Africa to Brazil facing risks of prolonged slumps, rising inflation, and unemployment. China's decline in demand for commodities has led to deep recessions in South America, with Venezuela and Brazil experiencing high inflation and unemployment. The US economy remains relatively insulated, but economists warn of potential job losses if China's economy worsens. Petro-states Saudi Arabia and Russia are also facing domestic financial challenges due to the collapse in oil prices, which are linked to China's reduced demand.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Analysts have issued buy and hold recommendations for several Singaporean companies. Jumbo Group and Sheng Siong are expected to see earnings upside, while Singapore Airlines is predicted to break even in the first quarter of 2016. Singapore Press Holdings reported a 17.3% profit increase in Q1 2016, but saw a 3.5% dip in revenue. Analysts have also taken note of the upcoming change in leadership at OCBC, with Tan Teck Long set to replace Helen Wong as CEO. The market is expected to remain resilient despite macroeconomic headwinds.

site_title: White men, boardrooms, and a diversity push
summary: A proposal by the Maldonado family, a Dominican-American family, is set to be voted on by Apple shareholders in February 2016, pushing for greater racial diversity among the company's leaders. The move is part of a growing trend in the US, with institutional investors increasingly considering diversity as a metric for making investment decisions. Since 2012, the number of investors considering diversity has increased by 40%, with over 80% of proposals being withdrawn after companies negotiate with shareholders. Despite past failures, proponents argue that the push for diversity will lead to change, citing examples of companies like Apple and CF Industries Holdings, which have added women to their boards after resolutions were put to a vote.

site_title: Renminbi's slide against the yen may dampen Japan's tourism boom
summary: Japan's tourism boom may be threatened by the slide of the Chinese renminbi against the yen, with estimated tourist arrivals and spending in 2015 reaching a record high of nearly 20 million and 3.5 trillion yen, respectively. The renminbi's expected further 10% decline against the yen could dilute Japan's attraction to tourists, particularly from China, which makes up the bulk of free-spending tourists. This could have negative effects on Japan's economy, including deflationary pressure and upward pressure on the yen.

site_title: Rents for 1st-floor retail space dip 1.2% in Q4
summary: Rents for 1st-floor retail space in Singapore fell 1.2% in Q4 2015, marking a third straight quarter of decline. The average rent dropped to S$30.50 per sq ft, with Orchard/Scotts Road experiencing a 1% quarter-on-quarter decline and 5% year-on-year decline to S$38.05 per sq ft. However, suburban areas saw a steeper drop in rents, with a 1.2% quarter-on-quarter decline and 5.7% year-on-year decline to S$30.70 per sq ft.

site_title: Vietnam's consumer promise beckons in M&A
summary: Vietnam is forecast to hit a record for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in 2016, driven by foreign buyers' interest in the country's growing consumer sector. Announced acquisitions involving Vietnamese companies rose 40% last year to $4.3 billion, with the financial sector and consumer sector leading the way. Free-trade agreements and streamlined investment rules are expected to boost dealmaking. Overseas buyers are attracted by Vietnam's expanding economy and consumer market, with consumer spending forecast to grow 47% in the next four years.

site_title: Yuan gets a booster as China's Dec exports jump and trade surplus swells
summary: China's trade surplus widened to $60 billion in December, helping to offset capital outflows and pressure on the yuan. Exports rose 2.3% in yuan terms, while imports fell 4% in yuan terms, with a 7.6% drop in US dollar terms. The trade data suggests China's economy is stabilizing, weakening the case for a substantial yuan depreciation. Asian equities and currencies, including the Australian dollar, rose, while China's shares fell. A sustained pick-up in exports may relieve pressure on the yuan and help China regain competitiveness.

site_title: New charges slapped on 3 ex-ST Marine senior executives
summary: Three former senior executives of Singapore Technologies Marine (ST Marine) have been slapped with additional charges in a corruption scandal. Mok Kim Whang, Tan Mong Seng, and Han Yew Kwang face a total of 1,744 new charges, including conspiracy to make false entertainment claims and bribery. The charges stem from corrupt payments in granting of ship-repair contracts. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) says Singapore has a zero-tolerance approach to corruption, and those found guilty can face up to 10 years in jail or fines. The pre-trial conference is set for January 20.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US home loan applications jump as mortgage rates fall
summary: US home loan applications surged 21.3% to 398.5 in the week ended Jan. 8, the largest weekly rise in three months, driven by falling mortgage rates. The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate dropped to 4.12% from 4.20%. Refinancing applications increased 23.8% and home purchase requests grew 17.8%. The strong fourth-quarter job growth and low rates are expected to continue supporting the purchase market.

site_title: Some euro banks fall short of ECB mark on liquidity: Lautenschlaeger
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has expressed concerns over some large euro zone banks' ability to manage liquidity risk, with top supervisor Sabine Lautenschlaeger stating that some banks are "failing to meet our expectations." The ECB will closely scrutinize banks' internal liquidity management, highlighting the issue as a priority for the year.

site_title: Wall Street frets Fed proposal will become a US$550b headache
summary: The Federal Reserve's proposal to make the banking system safer may require US banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, to raise up to $550 billion in the bond market by 2019. This estimate is nearly four times the amount initially estimated by the Fed, sparking concerns among investors and banks. The proposal, known as the Total Loss Absorbing Capacity rules, aims to ensure that a troubled bank is bailed out by its stock and bondholders, rather than taxpayers. If the rule remains unchanged, banks may face increased costs, and the market prices of US bonds could fall in 2016.

site_title: China Faces Longer Wait for Any EU Plan to Cut Import Duties c
summary: The European Union has delayed a potential proposal to lower import duties on Chinese goods, citing a need to assess the impact on EU manufacturers. The EU Commission, led by Frans Timmermans, plans to present any proposal in the second half of the year, following 15 years of preparation. China is pressing for market-economy designation, which would allow the EU to use Chinese data for trade investigations, but EU industries are resisting the move, fearing it would lead to cheaper imports and reduced protection for European manufacturers.

site_title: Volvo returns in style, driven by new owners
summary: Volvo, a Chinese-owned Swedish luxury brand, has seen record sales in the US market, with a 24% increase to 70,000 vehicles in 2015, outperforming major automakers. The company's new sedan, S90, and flagship SUV, XC90, have been well-received, and Volvo has begun building a factory in North America to meet growing demand. Under new owners Geely Auto, Volvo is focusing on safety and quality, with a goal of having no crash fatalities or serious injuries in its vehicles by 2020.

site_title: iPhone's likely China surge giving Apple holiday bright spot
summary: Apple's iPhone sales surged in China, its largest market outside the US, with a 33% increase in the final quarter of 2015, according to government and analyst data. China shipments of non-Android smartphones rose to 24.3 million, with iPhones making up the majority. This unexpected boost could counter investor sentiment and help Apple's holiday sales, despite overall smartphone market concerns. China's smartphone market has slowed, with domestic brands Xiaomi and Huawei gaining ground, but Apple's strong presence in the country remains crucial to its business.

site_title: Hopes rise for VW diesel deal despite CEO faux pas
summary: Volkswagen shares rose 1.3% ahead of a meeting between CEO Matthias Mueller and US environmental regulators, despite a tough statement from California regulators. Mueller's comments, in which he downplayed the seriousness of the cheating scandal, have raised concerns over VW's handling of the crisis. The meeting represents VW's best chance to resolve the issue, with a potential fix for affected US vehicles, including a new catalytic converter system. The outcome is crucial in reducing civil or criminal penalties, with Barclays analysts saying obtaining goodwill from US authorities is essential.

site_title: Hong Kong sets eyes on aerospace financing amid air travel boom
summary: Hong Kong aims to become a major player in aerospace financing, with Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying announcing measures to develop the city into a center for aerospace financing. This move comes amid rising competition, with China set to outpace the US as the world's largest air travel market over the next two decades. Hong Kong's tax policies need to be adjusted to compete with established hubs like Dublin and Singapore, which offer more favorable tax regimes for the industry.

site_title: Auto sales underpin demand for Asia refiners
summary: Crude oil prices have fallen to their lowest in over a decade, trading close to $30 a barrel, but strong car sales in India and China are supporting demand for refined products, giving refiners healthy margins. Refiners with little or no crude production are outperforming crude producers, and analysts predict demand for refined products will outpace capacity growth in 2016. However, the boost in sales could fade if Beijing closes the tap on new car subsidies, which are set to expire on January 1, 2017.

site_title: Bonuses may be clawed back after UK bankers move, BOE says
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority proposes a plan to claw back bonuses from UK bankers who switch firms after taking part in losses at their previous employer. The proposal aims to ensure that employees are held accountable for excessive risk-taking, and would apply only to senior staff. Buyout packages from new employers could undermine existing regulations, the PRA says, and would be subject to consultation and potential waiver applications. The plan would target material risk takers and focus on misconduct or failures of risk management as grounds for clawback or penalties.

site_title: Starland names IFA for advice on GRP Chongqing's offer
summary: Starland Holdings has appointed Canaccord Genuity Singapore as its independent financial adviser to advise on the mandatory unconditional cash offer made by GRP Chongqing Land, which has offered S$0.236 per share. Starland advised shareholders to exercise caution and refrain from taking any prejudicial actions. The move comes as Starland considers the offer, which was made to acquire the company.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: IBM has most US patents for 23rd year in cloud, Watson push
summary: IBM received 7,355 US patents in 2015, the most for the 23rd consecutive year, as it focuses on expanding its cognitive computing and cloud services. The company's Watson brand, which uses machine learning and data analytics, saw over 2,000 patents related to cloud and cognitive computing. This is part of IBM's efforts to grow its portfolio in these areas, with a focus on providing services and products to businesses.

site_title: US: Shares seek third straight gain as GM boosts outlook
summary: US stocks opened higher, aiming for a third straight gain, as General Motors boosted sentiment with an improved 2016 earnings forecast and a dividend hike. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 60.64 points, the S&P 500 advanced 9.35, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 22.41. GM shares jumped 3.1% after the company lifted its earnings forecast, raised its dividend, and increased its share repurchase program by $4 billion. Despite a 2.4% fall in the Shanghai stock exchange, crude oil prices stabilized, and US stocks remained on track for a strong day.

site_title: China to publish external investment data in IMF survey
summary: China will publish data on its external portfolio investment in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Coordinated Portfolio Investment Survey (CPIS), joining the global survey and aligning with the IMF's Special Data Dissemination Standard (SDDS). This move follows China's previous changes to GDP data calculation and foreign exchange reserve publication, indicating a shift towards greater transparency.

site_title: Self-braking cars top 2016 wish list of US safety agency
summary: The US National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has released its 2016 "Most Wanted" list, highlighting nine areas to improve transportation safety. The top priority is the adoption of self-braking technology for cars, trucks, and trains, as well as devices that monitor operators with video. The NTSB aims to reduce accidents and fatalities on US roads, airways, and railroads, with automatic braking, lane-departure warnings, and blind spot monitoring being key features. The agency believes these technologies can prevent thousands of crashes and save lives, despite their often limited availability on high-end vehicles.

site_title: Duty Free International's Q3 profit jumps 64.7%
summary: Duty Free International posted a 64.7% increase in Q3 net profit to RM16.8 million, driven by a 12.5% rise in revenue to RM152.9 million. The growth was mainly due to increased demand and higher selling prices for certain products, as well as contributions from seven new outlets at Kuala Lumpur International Airport 2.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Europe's worsening inflation outlook spurs calls for ECB action
summary: Analysts at Mizuho International and Royal Bank of Scotland Group are urging the European Central Bank (ECB) to increase monetary stimulus due to a declining five-year forward inflation swap rate, now at a three-month low. The rate, which measures price growth five years from now, has fallen since China's market turmoil began. The ECB is expected to increase its bond-purchase program at the March policy meeting, potentially leading to a 0.4 percentage point rate cut and a rally in regional bonds.

site_title: Gold drops for fourth day on stronger dollar, shares
summary: Gold fell for the fourth consecutive day, dropping 0.4% to $1,082.30 an ounce, due to a stronger US dollar and a rebound in stock markets. The dollar strengthened after better-than-expected Chinese trade data, making gold less attractive as a safe asset. Analysts expect further US interest rate hikes to lower demand for gold. Despite this, some analysts believe gold may not lose too much ground due to ongoing uncertainty about the global economy.

site_title: US$ rise hits emerging market borrowers
summary: The US dollar's surge is squeezing emerging-market and sovereign borrowers, with interest and repayments of foreign debt underpinning the US currency. Since 2009, countries like China, Brazil, India, and Indonesia have borrowed heavily in US dollars, attracting low interest rates and dollar weakness. As the dollar strengthens, borrowers are stepping up repayments, selling local currencies, and purchasing US dollars, causing a decline in other currencies, particularly the Russian rouble, Brazilian real, and Indonesian rupiah. This debt unwinding is driving dollar strength, corporate foreign exchange losses, and potential defaults, according to experts.

site_title: Container and cargo throughputs fall at Port of Singapore
summary: Container and cargo throughputs at the Port of Singapore contracted by 8.7% to 30.9 million TEUs and 1.1% to 574.9 million tonnes in 2015, respectively, due to weak global economic conditions and structural changes in the maritime industry. The government has introduced measures to help container lines cope, including a 10% concession on port dues for short-term cargo works and enhancements to vessel productivity and network planning at the port. Despite the decline, the Port of Singapore still saw a 5.6% year-on-year increase in annual vessel arrival tonnage to 2.5 billion gross tonnage.

site_title: Dollar stabilises as risk aversion eases
summary: The dollar stabilised against the yen and euro on Wednesday as China's yuan steadied following Beijing's intervention to prop up the currency. The offshore yuan remained flat, and the dollar index rose 0.3% to 99.246. The euro fell 0.3% to US$1.0822, while the Australian dollar rose 0.6% to US$0.7022. Improved Chinese trade data, showing exports and imports were better than expected, contributed to the improved sentiment in global markets. However, analysts say the long-term policy outlook for the yuan remains unclear, and volatility in currency markets is likely to stay.

site_title: GE to cut up to 6,500 jobs in energy units acquired from Alstom
summary: General Electric plans to cut up to 6,500 jobs in Europe in the energy units it acquired from Alstom last year. The restructuring plan will impact 6,500 jobs out of 35,000, with 765 jobs due to go in France despite a promise to create 1,000 net jobs. The cuts are driven by the energy industry's disarray due to low oil and gas prices. GE will begin talks with French labour unions about voluntary departures and offer retraining to affected employees.

site_title: Fifa fires Secretary General Valcke
summary: Fifa has fired Secretary General Jerome Valcke amid alleged corruption involving World Cup ticket sales. Valcke was dismissed with immediate effect, following an ethics investigation that recommended a nine-year ban. This move comes as part of a larger corruption scandal engulfing the soccer governing body, with 41 people and sports entities indicted by US prosecutors for offenses including corruption, fraud, and money laundering. Valcke, who previously held the position from 2003-2015, has been sacked twice by Fifa.

site_title: ST Electronics secures S$435m contracts in Q4
summary: ST Electronics secured about S$435 million worth of contracts in Q4 2015, bringing the full-year total to around S$1.61 billion. The contracts cover rail electronics, satellite communications, and advanced electronics services, with projects set to be completed until 2020. This includes S$91 million in rail contracts, S$107 million in satellite communications contracts, and S$237 million in advanced electronics and ICT contracts.

site_title: Nissan shuts websites after anti-whaling cyber attack
summary: Nissan shut down its global websites after a cyberattack that may have been motivated by anger over Japan's whale and dolphin hunts. The attack, attributed to the loose hacking collective Anonymous, came after Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's official website was hit in a similar attack in November. The move angered activists and governments opposed to the hunts, including Australia and New Zealand. Nissan's websites were temporarily suspended to prevent further risks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.17 points to close at 1,642.54, driven by 459 gainers and 371 losers. Total traded volume reached 1.93 billion lots valued at RM1.89 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher in line with Dow futures, Hang Seng
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.72 points to 2,696.50 in the eighth session of 2016, providing relief to battered traders after a volatile start to the year. The index was driven by heavy trading in offshore and marine stocks due to the oil slump, but China stocks slid sharply in the final half hour. The Dow futures rose 100 points, and the Hang Seng Index gained 1.1%, contributing to the stable session. The O&M sector remained under pressure, with Keppel Corp and SembCorp Marine leading the decline.

site_title: SNB's Zurbruegg pledges willingness to intervene on strong franc
summary: Swiss National Bank (SNB) Vice President Fritz Zurbruegg stated that the economic backdrop is far from normal and the central bank is prepared to intervene in the foreign exchange market to tackle the strong franc. The SNB has a deposit rate of minus 0.75% and has relied on negative rates and interventions to keep the franc in check since dropping its currency cap a year ago. Zurbruegg warned that the global economic recovery is still not firmly established and the SNB predicts Swiss growth will accelerate 1.5% this year, with inflation forecast to rise to over 1% in 2018.

site_title: China won't cut fuel prices when crude trades below US$40 a barrel
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has announced it won't cut fuel prices as long as oil trades below US$40 a barrel. The decision was made to curb demand and redirect profits towards enhancing energy conservation, fuel quality, and energy security. This move comes after oil prices have fallen 33% in the past year, with Brent oil currently trading at US$31.42 a barrel. The NDRC previously suspended fuel price cuts in December to curb demand, citing worsening air pollution in China.

site_title: China's Baidu says in talks to invest in Indian e-commerce start-ups
summary: China's Baidu is in talks to invest in Indian e-commerce start-ups, including Zomato, BookMyShow, and BigBasket. The move aims to tap into India's booming technology start-up market, which is expected to grow to $220 billion by 2025. This investment follows similar moves by global technology giants such as Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and SoftBank Group Corp. Baidu's spokesman declined to comment on possible investment amounts or time frames, but stated the company plans to put more resources into the Indian market in the future.

site_title: 'I heard a strange sound and shouted "run"': tourist guide in Istanbul
summary: A Turkish tour guide, Sibel Satiroglu, described the moment a suicide bomber detonated himself in Istanbul's Sultanahmet district, killing 10 German tourists. Satiroglu heard a 'click' sound and saw the bomber, who blended in with the group, pull the pin before shouting 'run!' to her clients, who escaped the blast. Satiroglu was injured and suffered temporary hearing loss. The attack, blamed on Islamic State, occurred at the Obelisk of Theodosius, a popular tourist site, and injured 15 others, including nine Germans.

site_title: Emerging markets currencies rise on upbeat China data
summary: Emerging markets currencies rose on Wednesday as upbeat Chinese trade data boosted regional markets, contrary to the global trend. The Malaysian ringgit, Australian dollar, and Indonesian rupiah gained against the dollar, while the yen retreated. The positive trading day was attributed to China's December exports pick-up and oil price rebound from 12-year lows. Despite oil concerns, investors now focus on the Federal Reserve's Beige Book report for interest rate guidance, with markets anticipating only two interest rate hikes in 2016.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank resists new challenge to independence
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is resisting a proposal from lawmakers to audit its foreign-exchange transactions, which could limit its ability to intervene in the market to stabilize the rupiah. Governor Agus Martowardojo argues that the additional scrutiny may spook already-shaky markets. The proposal comes amid pressure on the central bank to lower interest rates to boost the economy, which grew 4.8% in 2015, the slowest in six years. Analysts expect the central bank to lower its key policy rate, but the audit proposal may continue to test its independence.

site_title: ING Bank appoints regional head for corporate transaction services in Asia
summary: ING Bank has appointed Andy Dyer as regional head of transaction services corporate sales Asia, tasked with growing its corporate transaction services business and supporting growing interest in trade finance services and working capital solutions in the region. Dyer, with over 25 years of experience in financial services, will also facilitate Asian clients' business expansion in Europe through ING's capabilities in payments and cash management.

site_title: Singapore interest rates continue to rise as worries over China persist
summary: Singapore's interest rates continue to rise, reaching levels last seen in 2008, amid concerns over China's economic woes. The benchmark Sibor and SOR rates rose for the fourth consecutive day, with Sibor reaching 1.25200% and SOR reaching 1.75581%. The Sing dollar is expected to weaken further, and interest rates are expected to rise to compensate, driven by China's economic slowdown and the yuan's depreciation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is predicted to keep monetary policy status quo, allowing interest rates to test the 2% handle.

site_title: Russia says it can balance budget at oil price of US$82 per barrel
summary: Russia's Finance Minister Anton Siluanov stated that the country can balance its budget at an oil price of US$82 per barrel, despite the current price being US$31. Last year's budget deficit was around 2.6% of gross domestic product. Siluanov emphasized that decisions on budget policy will be made when the oil price reaches US$82.

site_title: US law firm Butler Snow opens office in Singapore, will focus on estate and tax planning
summary: US law firm Butler Snow has opened its first office in Singapore, focusing on estate and tax planning for high net worth families and family-controlled businesses in South-east Asia. The office, led by partner Kurt Rademacher, will serve clients in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. This expansion establishes the firm's presence in Asia amid a growing client base. Butler Snow has over 300 practicing lawyers and 18 offices globally, with a virtual office in Hong Kong. The firm sees opportunities in the region due to tax compliance regulations.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore interest rates continue to rise, reaching levels last seen in 2008, amid concerns over China's economic woes. Rental prices in the non-landed private residential sector are expected to decline 5-8% this year, while transactions will hold firm. CapitaLand Commercial Trust is selling an office tower, and three former ST Marine executives face additional charges. Salaries in Singapore's life sciences sector are expected to rise 3-5% this year, driven by industry progress.

site_title: Lian Beng's Q2 2016 profit down 2.8% to S$22.9m
summary: Lian Beng Group reported a 2.8% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$22.9m for Q2 2016, driven by a 35% plunge in revenue to S$130m. The construction and civil engineering firm attributed the decline to lower revenue from construction and ready-mixed concrete segments. Despite challenging market conditions, Lian Beng remains cautiously optimistic due to its existing pipeline of S$350m worth of construction projects, expected to provide a sustainable flow of activities through FY2017.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah says portfolio value rose to US$34.3b in 2015
summary: Malaysia's state investor Khazanah reported a portfolio value of 150.2 billion ringgit (S$49.2 billion) in 2015, up from 145.5 billion ringgit in 2014. The fund expects global and domestic volatility to continue this year. Its investments include stakes in Axiata Group, UEM Sunrise, Tenaga Nasional, and CIMB Group.

site_title: IHG unveils its 5,000th hotel in New York
summary: IHG has unveiled its 5,000th hotel globally, the Hotel Indigo Lower East Side New York, in a joint venture with Brack Capital Real Estate. This milestone marks a significant expansion of the Hotel Indigo brand in New York City and follows the addition of 1,500 hotels since 2003. The company's CEO, Richard Solomons, attributes the growth to its network of owner relationships and powerful digital platforms, which have driven consistently strong performance.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose in opening deals on Wednesday, driven by upbeat Chinese trade data and oil price gains. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.6%, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gained 1.3% and 1.1%, respectively. Asian markets also climbed, buoyed by China's export data, after a week of losses fueled by economic worries.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust said to seek sale of Singapore office tower
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust is selling its 23-story One George Street office tower in Singapore's central business district. The building, valued at S$975 million as of 2014, has 41,564 sq m of lease area and tenants including Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc and Diageo Singapore Pte. The sale is part of the trust's efforts to diversify its portfolio.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up 1% as yuan stabilises
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.1% to 19,934.88, driven by the yuan's stabilization, which eased fears of sustained depreciation and bolstered stocks. China's central bank held the yuan's daily midpoint steady and used state banks to absorb liquidity, making it expensive to bet against the yuan offshore. All main sectors rose, with energy and telecommunications shares among the biggest gainers, including a 19% surge in lifestyle magazines publisher One Media Group Ltd.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won climb on better-than-expected China trade data
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.3% to 1,916.28 points, the largest daily gain since December 16, 2015, driven by better-than-expected China trade data and investor buying. Local institutions purchased 226 billion won worth of shares, while foreigners sold 55.8 billion won. The South Korean won gained 0.5% against the dollar, closing at 1,204.0 to the dollar.

site_title: Tigerair plane makes emergency landing at Bangkok airport after Singaporean passenger dies on flight
summary: A Tigerair plane made an emergency landing at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi airport on January 12, 2016, after a Singaporean passenger, 58-year-old man, died on board Flight PR 2177 from Chiang Mai. The passenger was suffering from a chronic illness and was traveling with his Thai wife and their family of five. The cause of his death is unknown, and the flight was diverted to Bangkok for an emergency landing. The incident is currently under investigation.

site_title: Glaxo may consider spinoffs after Novartis deal integration
summary: GlaxoSmithKline CEO Andrew Witty considers spinoffs after integrating with Novartis, citing the potential for creating different structures in the future. Investors have called for a breakup to boost the stagnant stock, with some suggesting spinning off the consumer health division. Witty notes that a spinoff won't happen for at least a year or two, but the integration of the deal has created new options for the company, including the potential for different structures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oil and gas, SPH, Qian Hu
summary: US crude oil prices fell below $30 a barrel for the first time in 12 years, reaching $29.93 a barrel. The West Texas Intermediate (WTI) for February delivery, a benchmark for US oil prices, dropped to its lowest level since December 2003.

site_title: Retail rents down 1.2% in Q4, culminating in 5.9% full-year drop: DTZ
summary: Retail rents in Singapore declined 1.2% in Q4 2015, marking the third consecutive drop since Q2 2015, to S$30.50 per square foot. This resulted in a 5.9% full-year drop in average first-storey rents, faster than the 0.3% decline in 2014.

site_title: China developers in rush to refinance costly bonds
summary: Chinese property developers are rushing to refinance costly bonds as they face tighter conditions in the domestic market. In 2015, they shifted to domestic markets, raising over 200 billion yuan (S$43 billion), four times greater than in overseas markets. This shift is a response to cheaper funding costs at home. However, the developers' foray into offshore debt markets has become a growing headache, and they are now struggling to refinance their bonds.

site_title: Philippines' San Miguel eyes SABmiller's Grolsch and Peroni
summary: Philippine conglomerate San Miguel Corp expressed interest in acquiring SABMiller's Grolsch and Peroni beer brands, following Anheuser Busch InBev's $100 billion acquisition of SABMiller. San Miguel President Ramon Ang stated his interest in the brands, joining international suitors for the beer brands. The move comes after Anheuser Busch InBev began seeking potential bidders for Grolsch and Peroni.

site_title: China: Shanghai Composite drops below 3,000 as selloff resumes
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index dropped below 3,000, resuming this year's selloff, as better-than-expected trade data failed to ease investor concerns about the economy. The index slid 1% to 2,991.84, marking a 16% decline in 2016, the world's worst-performing global index. Market sentiment remains damaged, with fund manager Wu Kan stating that trade data is not enough to turn around sentiment.

site_title: Progress in Singapore's life sciences sector to drive salaries up 3-5%: Randstad
summary: Salaries of professionals in Singapore's life sciences sector are expected to rise 3-5% this year due to progress in industry requirements. Bonuses are expected to average 1-2 months. The biotechnology industry will see the highest demand for candidates with commercial skills, technical capabilities, and ability to empathize with end users. These professionals will be in high demand, particularly those capable of transitioning into commercial roles.

site_title: Google creates virtual reality arm, names key exec to run it: Re/code
summary: Google has created a virtual reality computing division and appointed Clay Bavor, the executive running its product management team, to lead the new arm. Bavor will oversee key apps such as Gmail, Drive, and Google Docs, which will be taken over by Senior Vice President Diane Greene. This move marks a significant shift in Google's focus on virtual reality, with Bavor's experience in product management expected to drive innovation in the field.

site_title: Hong Kong leader pushes integration with China in policy speech
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Leung Chun-ying, announced steps to boost integration with China in a policy speech, focusing on the success of Beijing's "One Belt, One Road" initiative. He pledged HK$1.2 billion to support the program, primarily through scholarships, and stated Hong Kong's role in promoting the initiative. The speech came amidst dissatisfaction with Leung's administration, with four lawmakers removed from the chamber for heckling. The move aims to address Hong Kong's economic challenges, including a housing affordability crisis, and solidify the city's ties with China.

site_title: Amid global price rout, China crude oil imports hit record
summary: China's crude oil imports hit a record 7.82 million barrels a day in December, exceeding earlier estimates, as the country took advantage of low crude prices to fill strategic reserves. This move may challenge the US as the world's top importer of crude. Chinese monthly imports surpassed US imports in April 2015 and have increased by 21.4% from the previous month and 9.3% from the previous year.

site_title: AirAsia X says taking carrier private is an option on valuation
summary: AirAsia X and sister company AirAsia Bhd are considering taking the airlines private due to a 65% decline in shares over the past year, making them Asia's worst-performing airline stocks. The companies' valuation is deemed "very cheap," but finding investors to take them private is a challenge. AirAsia X CEO Benyamin Ismail stated that taking the airlines private is a "very good" option, but no current plans exist. The decline is attributed to a fatal crash, increased competition, and a weaker ringgit, which has dampened investor demand.

site_title: Foreign investment plummets in junta-ruled Thailand
summary: Foreign investment in Thailand plummeted 78% in 2015, reaching 93.8 billion baht, due to the country's prolonged military rule and economic struggles. The decline includes significant drops in investment from Japan (81%), EU (86.7 billion baht to 2 billion), and the US. Analysts attribute the trend to fragile foreign investor confidence and declining economic competitiveness, but some argue that new investment incentives favoring high-tech industries will propel Thailand to the next stage of development.

site_title: New and enhanced programmes to groom poly grads in Singapore's power sector
summary: Singapore's power sector is facing a talent shortage, with 40% of technical workers nearing retirement age in 10 years. To address this, the Ministry of Education will enhance internships in the power engineering sector by extending them to six months, improving mentorship, and better structure. This move aims to attract and groom more talent in the sector.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality adds property in Geneva
summary: Frasers Hospitality has launched its first gold standard serviced residence in Geneva, Switzerland, with 67 units, expanding its European portfolio to 55 properties. The addition brings the company's total units across the UK, Germany, France, Hungary, Turkey, Spain, and Switzerland to over 4,300. This follows recent openings in Spain and Germany, with a pipeline of several properties planned. Frasers Hospitality's European outlook remains bullish, with steady occupancies of over 80% on average, and its global portfolio now stands at 136 properties in 78 cities.

site_title: Oil rebounds from below US$30 as threat of more declines persists
summary: Oil prices rebounded by 2.2% after falling below $30 a barrel for the first time in 12 years, but the threat of further declines persists due to a persistent oversupply. Industry reports indicate a 3.9 million barrel drop in US inventories, but government data is expected to show an expansion. Analysts say the "big picture" remains oversupply, making US$30 oil "painful."

site_title: China 2015 coal imports plunge 30% on demand slump
summary: China's coal imports dropped 30% to 204.1 million tonnes in 2015 due to a slowdown in domestic demand and a collapse in locally produced coal prices. Analysts predict further decline in imports this year, with demand still weak, and coal facing twin headwinds of pollution cuts and a weaker currency eroding cost advantages. Experts expect imports to fall another 10% in 2016.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong track US and European stock gains at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stock markets rose early on Wednesday, driven by positive leads from Europe and New York. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.60%, while the Hang Seng Index rose 1.61%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, adding 0.47%. The gains come after a tumultuous start to the year, with investors gaining confidence to start buying.

site_title: With Ebola in check, are we ready for next outbreak?
summary: The world is expected to breathe a sigh of relief as the Ebola epidemic in west Africa is declared over after claiming over 11,000 lives in two years. Despite this, experts question whether the world is better prepared for the next outbreak due to the lack of a cure and vaccine. Key lessons were learned from the devastating outbreak in Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone, and experts emphasize the need for improved preparedness and engagement in the event of future outbreaks.

site_title: Lego changes sales policy following Ai Weiwei row
summary: Lego has changed its sales policy after facing criticism for refusing to sell to Chinese artist Ai Weiwei. The company will no longer ask about the intended use of its bricks in bulk sales, following a social media storm after Ai claimed Lego had refused his order due to its use for "political works." The move comes after Lego faced criticism for its handling of Ai's situation, particularly in relation to the upcoming Legoland theme park in Shanghai.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; ETFs targeting China market jump
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 1.1% to 7,856.84 points, driven by gains in exchange-traded funds targeting the Chinese market. The move follows China's efforts to curb bets against its currency and reassure skeptical investors. Electronics shares led the gain, while financials rose 0.9%. This marks the first positive day for the market in six sessions, ending a losing streak.

site_title: South Korea president wants stronger response to North's nuclear test
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye called for a tougher response to North Korea's latest nuclear test, describing it as a "gross provocation" and an "unacceptable challenge" to global peace and security. She pledged to push for punitive sanctions against Pyongyang, stating that the international community's countermeasures must differ from the past. Park's comments came after North Korea's nuclear test last week, which sparked concerns over regional stability and global security.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won recover, boosted by China trade data
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.4% to 1,918.63 points, boosted by gains on Wall Street and eurozone stocks, as well as improved China trade data. China's efforts to stabilize its currency also lifted sentiment. The gains followed better-than-expected China trade data, which helped improve recently damaged market sentiment.

site_title: Weak 2016 outlook for Singapore rental pricing, even as demand holds, says ERA
summary: Singapore's rental prices for non-landed private residential sectors are forecast to decline by 5-8% in 2016, despite maintaining rental transactions. This decline is attributed to falling private residential sector rents, which may push down HDB rents. The SRX Property Price Index also reported relatively flat rents in December, while public housing rents slipped. The outlook suggests a continued decline in rental pricing, with rental demand remaining resilient.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.46 points to 1,642.83 on Wednesday, driven by gains over 149 stocks. Volume reached 42.13 million lots worth RM 18.66 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 149 to 46.

site_title: Hotel Lotte could raise up US$5b in South Korea's largest-ever IPO: IFR
summary: Hotel Lotte Co Ltd may raise up to US$5 billion in South Korea's largest-ever IPO, surpassing Samsung Life Insurance Co Ltd's 2010 record of US$4.04 billion. The deal, potentially worth US$3 billion to US$5 billion, is subject to regulatory approval and expected to take place in March or April.

site_title: Obama tells US to embrace time of 'extraordinary change'
summary: President Barack Obama delivered a farewell State of the Union address, urging Americans to not fear the future despite concerns over terror and economic change. He described the current period as "extraordinary change" with both opportunity and risk, particularly in terms of inequality. Obama sought to present himself as an optimistic alternative to critics who claim the country is heading in the wrong direction.

site_title: SPH and TRS editors reach out-of-court settlement
summary: Singapore Press Holdings Ltd (SPH) and the duo behind the now-defunct socio-political website The Real Singapore (TRS) have reached an out-of-court settlement over a copyright infringement suit. SPH claimed 244 of its news articles were reproduced on TRS without permission. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed. This ends a lawsuit filed in May 2015.

site_title: Australia: Shares end longest losing streak in over half-decade
summary: Australian shares ended a 9-session losing streak, rising 1.26% to 4,987.4, snapping the longest losing streak in 5-1/2 years. The S&P/ASX 200 index touched a 2-1/2-year low earlier in the week, supported by better-than-expected Chinese trade figures.

site_title: Abraaj Group agrees to buy majority stake in India's 5th largest healthcare provider
summary: Abraaj Group has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Quality CARE India Ltd, India's 5th largest healthcare provider, from Advent International. The transaction is expected to conclude in the first quarter of 2016. Headquartered in Hyderabad, CARE operates 2,600 beds across 16 hospitals in nine cities.

site_title: Google reveals self-driving car slip-ups
summary: Google's self-driving cars experienced "anomalies" requiring human intervention 272 times in California test cars over 14 months, resulting in over 420,000 miles traveled. These system failures occurred despite the cars having safely driven over a million miles. The incidents were reported to the California Department of Motor Vehicles, and Google emphasized the overall safety of its self-driving technology.

site_title: Coal India plans biggest tech overhaul to check rampant theft
summary: Coal India is undertaking its largest tech overhaul in four decades to combat rampant theft and shed its image as an inefficient company. The move comes as the government prepares to open up the sector to private firms, and the company aims to double production to 1 billion tonnes by 2020. Coal India plans to implement a GPS-based tracking system and electronic "fencing" of mining areas to prevent theft, which costs the company up to $1 billion annually. The upgrade is expected to cost around $52 million initially.

site_title: Shanghai Disneyland set to open in June
summary: Shanghai Disneyland is set to open on June 16, 2016, as a joint venture between Disney and Shanghai Shendi Group. The $5.5 billion resort in Shanghai's Pudong district will feature new attractions and characters tailored for the Chinese people, with 10,000 workers involved in the project, considered one of the largest foreign investments in China's history.

site_title: Singapore stocks open 0.65% higher on Wall St gain
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.65% higher on January 13, 2016, driven by a strong Wall Street session, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,709.32 at 9:02am. Trading volume was high, with 58.4 million shares changing hands, and gainers outnumbered losers 106 to 33.

site_title: China's December exports rise 2.3 % year on year in yuan-denominated terms
summary: China's December exports rose 2.3% year-on-year in yuan-denominated terms, while imports dropped 4.0%. The resulting trade surplus was 382.1 billion yuan, exceeding economists' expectations of a decline. Dollar-denominated figures have not been published, but the data contradicts forecasts of an 8.0% export decline and 11.5% import decline.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on China data, US and Europe gains
summary: Asian markets rallied on Wednesday following upbeat Chinese trade data, which showed exports picked up in December, providing respite from a volatile start to 2016. The data indicated authorities' weakening of the yuan currency against the dollar was beginning to filter through. Markets in the US and Europe also gained, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The rally came after a week of sharp losses fueled by worries over China's economy.

site_title: Wall Street frets Fed proposal will become US$550b headache
summary: The Federal Reserve's proposal to make the banking system safer may require US$550 billion in additional bond sales by 2019, forcing major banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co and Citigroup Inc to raise funds. This estimate is nearly four times the Fed's previous estimate of bonds needed. The proposal is part of the ongoing debate between Wall Street and regulators to prevent a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: MH370 search finds new shipwreck, but no plane
summary: An Australian-led search team has discovered a shipwreck in the southern Indian Ocean, but no evidence of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370. The wreckage, found almost two years after the plane vanished, is the second such discovery since the search began. The first concrete evidence, a two-metre-long flaperon wing part, was found on a beach in Reunion Island in July last year. The search continues for the final resting place of MH370, which was carrying 239 people when it disappeared on March 8, 2014.

images.alt_text: The hunt for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 has uncovered a shipwreck deep underwater, officials said Wednesday, the second such discovery since the search began almost two years ago.

site_title: China's president says anti-graft drive gaining ground: Xinhua
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the country's anti-corruption drive is gaining ground, with the Communist Party Central Committee remaining determined to fight graft. The drive has led to the downfall of top officials in the ruling party, government, military, and state-owned companies over the past three years. However, analysts have raised concerns that the drive may be contributing to slow investment growth due to officials' fear of corruption accusations. Xi emphasized that anti-corruption efforts should not be relaxed in 2016.

images.alt_text: China's president Xi Jinping said on Tuesday that China's more than two year anti-corruption drive was showing good results and the Communist Party Central Committee remains determined to fight graft, the state news agency Xinhua reported Tuesday.

site_title: 3 ex-ST Marine senior execs face additional charges in court
summary: Three former Singapore Technologies Marine (ST Marine) senior executives, Mok Kim Whang, Tan Mong Seng, and another unnamed executive, have been charged with additional corruption offenses. Mok Kim Whang faces 826 counts of making fake entertainment claims totaling S$3 million, while Tan Mong Seng faces 445 counts of making false entries in petty cash vouchers for entertainment expenses amounting to S$1.64 million. The charges are related to corrupt transactions with Hyundai Engineering and Construction Ltd. agent Pyo Sei Jin.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Council of Europe sees French state of emergency risks
summary: The Council of Europe's human rights commissioner, Nils Muiznieks, expressed concerns that France's state of emergency since the November 13 attacks could threaten democracy. Muiznieks stated that the measures, which give security services greater powers, could lead to a "drift" in human rights, including ethnic profiling and repression. The commissioner questioned the need for these measures, citing that only a few searches have led to terrorist acts. He warned that heightened surveillance could stigmatize certain communities, and the Council is closely monitoring the situation.

images.alt_text: France's decision to install a state of emergency following the deadly November 13 attacks in Paris could constitute a "threat" to democracy, a European Council human rights observer said Tuesday.

site_title: US dollar steadies vs euro as equities rebound
summary: The US dollar steadied against the euro on Tuesday as global equity markets rebounded from days of China-driven turmoil. The euro traded at US$1.0858, unchanged from the previous day. Despite concerns about plummeting oil prices and potential European risks, the euro's weakness is expected to be limited. Traders are watching the Federal Reserve's Beige Book report for clues about interest rate hikes, with some predicting only one increase in 2016. The euro's vulnerability to selling due to its cheap value is also a concern.

site_title: China's yuan formula baffles analysts who can't predict the fix
summary: China's central bank is struggling to maintain a market-driven yuan, with the daily fixing rate defying forecasts and sparking speculation that authorities have reverted to a more restrictive approach. The disconnect has fueled turmoil in global markets, erasing over $5 trillion in equity values. Analysts are baffled by the formula, which has raised concerns about China's exchange-rate policy. The move has added to uncertainty, affecting commodity prices and global markets. The central bank's methodology has been questioned, fueling speculation about a potential shift back to a more controlled approach.

images.alt_text: For a rate that China's central bank says is largely determined by easy-to-track market prices, the yuan's daily fixing is proving surprisingly hard for analysts to predict.

site_title: China trade volume falls 7.0% in 2015: Customs
summary: China's total trade volume fell 7.0% year-on-year to 24.59 trillion yuan (around $3.74 trillion) in 2015, missing the government's target of 6% growth. Imports slumped 13.2% and exports were down 1.8%. This was the fourth consecutive year external commerce failed to meet its growth goal, highlighting the challenges facing the world's second-largest economy. The decline was attributed to slowing growth and plunging commodity prices.

images.alt_text: China's total trade volume fell seven per cent year-on-year to 24.59 trillion yuan (around US$3.74 trillion) in 2015, Customs said Wednesday, as slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy and plunging commodity prices took their toll.

site_title: Twitter adds live Periscope broadcasts to timelines
summary: Twitter has begun integrating live Periscope video broadcasts into its mobile app timelines on Apple devices, marking the first time the two services are combined. The feature, which was previously accessed through a separate app, now automatically plays in users' timelines, going full screen if tapped. This rollout is part of a larger effort to distribute Periscope content more widely, following Twitter's acquisition of the video streaming app last year. Over 100 million Periscope broadcasts have been created since its launch in 2023.

images.alt_text: The widow of a man killed in a attack on a Jordanian police training center has sued Twitter Inc , accusing it of making it easier for ISIS to use the social media company's platform to spread its message.

site_title: MetLife plans to split off US retail business; shares rise
summary: MetLife plans to split off its US retail business, which generates about one-fifth of its earnings, due to regulatory pressures. The move aims to reduce capital requirements and increase flexibility. The company is considering an initial public offering, spinoff, or sale, with shares rising 8% to $45.06 following the announcement. The separation would result in a new company with approximately $240 billion in assets and 20% of MetLife's operating earnings. The decision is driven by the need to address higher capital requirements triggered by being designated a "systemically important financial institution."

images.alt_text: MetLife Inc, the largest US life insurer, plans to separate a substantial portion of its US retail business from the core company, saying on Tuesday that the "regulatory environment" helped drive its decision.

site_title: Crude oil tumbles below US$30 a barrel for first time in 12 years
summary: Crude oil prices plummeted below $30 a barrel for the first time in 12 years, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude falling to $30.44 a barrel. This decline was driven by concerns over China's economic slowdown, which has soured investors on fuel demand, and a rapid appreciation of the US dollar. The global oil benchmark, Brent, also fell to $30.86 a barrel, with some analysts predicting a potential drop to $20 a barrel. The decline sent energy equities lower, with the S&P 500 Oil & Gas Exploration and Production Index dropping 1.9%.

images.alt_text: China, the world's second-biggest oil consumer, won't cut fuel prices as long as oil trades below US$40 a barrel, the National Development and Reform Commission, the country's top economic planner, said in a statement Wednesday.

site_title: China holds line on yuan, stocks remain fragile
summary: China's central bank held the yuan steady for a fourth consecutive session, easing fears of sustained depreciation. This move came after a near 5% slide in the yuan since August, but was bolstered by forecast-beating Chinese trade data for December. The news calmed global investor sentiment, with share markets and the Australian dollar rising and the yen falling. The stabilisation has at least temporarily alleviated concerns about the slowdown in China's economy, which is set to slow further.

images.alt_text: China's central bank held the line on its yuan for a fourth straight session on Wednesday while putting the squeeze on offshore sellers of the currency, calming fears of a sustained depreciation - at least for now.

site_title: New lease accounting rule aims at clearer view of company health
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) has published a new rule requiring leases of more than a year to be placed on balance sheets starting January 2019. This change aims to provide a clearer view of companies' debt and liabilities, affecting around half of all companies globally, particularly in industries like airlines, shipping, and retail. The rule change is expected to significantly alter financial statements for these companies.

site_title: Europe: Shares end off highs as oil turns back to US$30
summary: European stocks rose 1% to 1,349.16 points, snapping a four-session decline streak, despite oil prices falling to a 12-year low of $30 per barrel, dragging energy stocks down. Retailers such as Metro, Tesco, and Morrisons posted strong updates, lifting shares. Analysts expect a strong earnings season for European companies, citing positive tailwinds like accelerating growth and a weaker currency.

site_title: Behind yuan's tiny drop, indications of true crisis lurk
summary: The Chinese yuan has declined by 6% over the past five months, but behind the scenes, the People's Bank of China is taking drastic measures to stabilize the currency, including buying yuan in Hong Kong to push overnight borrowing costs to a record 67% and burning through over half a trillion dollars in foreign reserves. These efforts rival those of other emerging markets and aim to prevent panic, while also restricting cross-border transactions and tightening capital controls. The goal is to keep the yuan stable against a basket of currencies, rather than pegging it to the rising dollar.

images.alt_text: The Chinese yuan's 6 per cent decline over the past five months is hardly anyone's idea of a crisis.

site_title: Greek central banker urges swift conclusion of bailout review, start of debt talks
summary: Greek central banker Yannis Stournaras urged a swift conclusion to the bailout review, expected to start on January 18, to pave the way for debt talks. The review aims to reduce Greece's 1.8 times debt burden and include reforms such as pension cuts and agricultural taxation changes. Stournaras warned that failure to conclude the review could lead to a return to November 2014, when a snap election delayed the process. A successful review could speed up the lifting of capital controls and lead to debt relief negotiations, including longer repayment terms and interest rate concessions.

images.alt_text: Greece's central bank chief urged political parties to reach a swift consensus to wrap up a bailout review which will pave the way for long-awaited talks on debt relief.

site_title: Ford unveils resurrected Lincoln Continental, targets China market
summary: Ford Motor Co unveiled a revived Lincoln Continental luxury sedan at the Detroit auto show, targeting the Chinese market. The new Continental, built in Flat Rock, Michigan, is slightly smaller and lower than its predecessor, the MKS. Ford aims to triple Lincoln's global sales by 2020, from 100,000 vehicles, and has made "meaningful progress" in reviving the brand. The Continental will go on sale in China and the US this fall, with enhanced features for Chinese buyers, including greater connectivity and backseat comfort.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor Co unveiled on Tuesday a new luxury flagship full-size Continental sedan aimed at Chinese and American consumers.

site_title: New Zealand house prices rise in December
summary: New Zealand's house prices rose 14.2% in the year to December, according to Quotable Value's residential property price index. This represents a 34.7% increase from the market's peak in 2007. Auckland house prices surged 22.5% in the year, with nearby regions such as Hamilton and Tauranga experiencing 19.5% and 18.2% increases, respectively. The price growth is attributed to strong demand in the Auckland region, which has spilled over to nearby areas.

images.alt_text: New Zealand house prices rose in December, the government property valuer said on Wednesday, as house sales in regions surrounding Auckland surged.

site_title: Kandi jumps as 2015 Chinese electric car sales exceed forecast
summary: Kandi Technologies Group Inc saw a 1.6% increase in its American depositary receipts to US$8.86 after the company exceeded its forecast of 2015 electric vehicle sales by 5% or more. China's push for alternative-energy transportation, with 1% of passenger cars sold being electric, is expected to benefit Kandi in the long term. The company's partner Geely aims to make new-energy vehicles 90% of sales by 2020, while Kandi has signed agreements with major companies to promote connected electric cars.

site_title: German banks must do more to counter low interest rates: watchdog
summary: Germany's financial watchdog, Bafin, has warned that banks must take action to counter the effects of low interest rates on earnings. Bafin President Felix Hufeld stated that banks have the possibility to steer against low rates by cutting costs, revamping business models, and reinforcing capital bases. He also emphasized the need for banks to demand adequate prices for services. Bafin will review banks' equity capital to cover interest rate risks, amid a growing interest rate reserve required by German life insurers, which has increased by over 10 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Germany's banks can and must do more to counter the effects of rock bottom interest rates on earnings, the head of the country's financial watchdog, Bafin, said on Tuesday.

site_title: Careful what you wish for: Powerball win could bring unexpected stress
summary: A record-setting US$1.5 billion Powerball jackpot winner should be prepared for unexpected stresses, including huge expectations and requests from family and friends. Financial advisors advise winners to take at least six months to develop a plan, change their cell phone number, and learn how to say no to requests. Winners may also face public scrutiny and debt repayment, with the first payment alone enough to wipe out average household debt. Experts warn that lottery winners often experience stress and financial difficulties due to unpreparedness.

site_title: PC shipments fall a record 10.6% in fourth quarter: IDC
summary: Global personal computer shipments declined 10.6% in the fourth quarter of 2015, according to IDC, the largest decline since tracking began. Competition from mobile phones and tablets, and longer lifecycles for PCs, contributed to the decline. Shipments totaled 71.9 million units, with Lenovo leading the market with 21.4% market share, followed by HP and Dell. The industry is expected to see a business increase later this year as companies upgrade to Windows 10.

images.alt_text: Global personal computer shipments fell 10.6 per cent in the quarter ended in December compared to a year earlier, research firm IDC said on Tuesday, the largest decline since IDC started tracking PC shipments.

site_title: US authorities rebuff VW diesel recall plan
summary: US environmental regulators rejected Volkswagen's initial recall plan for its diesel cars with illegal emissions cheat devices, citing the plan as "incomplete and substantially deficient." The California Air Resources Board and the Environmental Protection Agency agreed, with the EPA stating that Volkswagen has not submitted an approvable recall plan to bring the vehicles into compliance. The issue affects nearly 600,000 US vehicles and has damaged Volkswagen's reputation, with the company facing potentially tens of billions of dollars in fines.

images.alt_text: US environmental regulators turned down Volkswagen's initial recall plan for its diesel cars equipped with illegal emissions cheat devices Tuesday, a day before its chief holds high-level talks on the scandal in Washington.

site_title: EU probes Halliburton's planned purchase of Baker Hughes
summary: The European Commission has launched an in-depth investigation into Halliburton's planned $35 billion acquisition of Baker Hughes, citing concerns that the deal could reduce competition and increase prices for oil and gas services in the EU. Commissioner Margrethe Vestager stated that the commission will review the proposed takeover to ensure it does not harm consumers. Halliburton has promised to offer a substantial remedies package, but US antitrust officials have expressed dissatisfaction with proposed concessions. The deal, if approved, would create an oilfield services behemoth to rival market leader Schlumberger.

images.alt_text: The European Commission said on Tuesday it had launched an in-depth investigation into oilfield services provider Halliburton's planned purchase of its smaller rival Baker Hughes.

site_title: Petrobras cuts spending again as oil-price drop bites
summary: Petrobras, Brazil's state-controlled oil producer, has cut its 2015-2019 capital spending budget by a quarter to $98.4 billion, due to low oil prices and debt concerns. The company trimmed its 2016 investment plans to $20 billion and reduced its oil production forecast by nearly 2%. The move aims to preserve cash to pay debt, but threatens to crimp future output and satisfy longer-term obligations.

images.alt_text: Petróleo Brasileiro SA, Brazil's state-controlled oil producer, on Tuesday slashed its investment budget for the third time in just over six months, to preserve cash to pay debt, the industry's largest.

site_title: Deutsche Bank targets top five slot in wealth management
summary: Deutsche Bank aims to become one of the world's top five wealth managers, a goal previously set in 2012 but seen slipping as rivals UBS, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, Credit Suisse, and Royal Bank of Canada now occupy the top five spots. The bank's global head of Wealth Management, Fabrizio Campelli, says priorities include minimizing risks, investing in a modern operating model, and building around client needs. Under new co-CEO John Cryan, Deutsche Bank is restructuring its business, including splitting its investment bank and wealth management arms, to adapt to tighter banking rules and costly litigation.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank aims to become one of the world's top five wealth managers, it said in a memo to staff on Tuesday, after losing ground to rivals over the last couple of years.

site_title: Harper Kitchen being sold for S$51.1 million
summary: Harper Kitchen, a 23,893 sq ft freehold industrial building near Tai Seng MRT Station in Singapore, is being sold for S$51.1 million to a four-member consortium led by Nanshan Group Singapore. The sale price works out to S$834 per square foot of potential gross floor area, lower than the S$923 per square foot paid for the nearby Irving Industrial Building in 2014. The building is zoned for Business 1-White use and will be redeveloped by the consortium, with plans to add an additional 29,374 sq ft of gross floor area.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: North Korea's Kim calls for expansion of nuclear arsenal
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has called for an expansion of his country's nuclear arsenal, stating the need to bolster the nuclear force to deter US-led "imperialists" and protect the nation's sovereignty. The call comes after a recent nuclear test, which some experts doubt was a more powerful hydrogen bomb. The US has also taken action, with the House of Representatives voting to pass legislation broadening sanctions on North Korea's nuclear program.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un called for an expansion of the size and power of his country's nuclear arsenal, state media said on Wednesday, a week after a nuclear test that drew condemnation from its neighbours and the United States.

site_title: Latest North Korea sub missile test a 'catastrophic failure': analysts
summary: North Korea's submarine-launched ballistic missile test, announced as a "successful" test, was actually an explosive failure that was not even launched from a submarine, according to separate expert analyses. The video released by North Korea showed the test, but it was not from a submarine and the missile ignited in mid-air. The test's failure raises concerns about the credibility of North Korea's military capabilities.

images.alt_text: North Korea's "successful" submarine-launched ballistic missile test last month was, in fact, an explosive failure that was not even launched from a submarine, separate expert analyses concluded Wednesday.

site_title: FIFA investigators to seek longer Blatter, Platini bans
summary: FIFA investigators are seeking a longer ban for Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini, who were initially banned for eight years for a two million Swiss franc payment. The investigators want to appeal against the decision, citing a lack of evidence. Blatter and Platini deny any wrongdoing and plan to make appeals to FIFA and other courts. The ban, which was imposed by a FIFA tribunal, was rejected by the ethics judges, who found no corruption charges but deemed the pair had abused their positions.

images.alt_text: FIFA corruption investigators will demand an extension to the eight-year bans ordered against world football leaders Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini last month, a spokesman said on Tuesday.

site_title: China's Wanda Group buys US filmmaker Legendary for US$3.5b
summary: China's Wanda Group has acquired US film studio Legendary Entertainment for $3.5 billion, marking the country's largest cross-border cultural acquisition. Legendary's productions have grossed over $12 billion at the box office worldwide. Wanda Group's CEO Wang Jianlin aims to change the industry's dynamics, but denies the deal is intended to increase Beijing's cultural influence. The acquisition is the latest in Wanda's string of overseas acquisitions, and will see Legendary's chairman and CEO Thomas Tull continue in his role.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.34% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.34% on Wednesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street, as concerns about China's economy eased. The Nikkei 225 index gained 230.16 points to 17,449.12, ending a six-day losing streak. Analysts attribute the rebound to a technical correction, with Chihiro Ohta stating that Japanese stocks are "falling too quickly" and expecting a technical rebound.

site_title: Republicans in US Congress show welcome signs of pragmatism
summary: US Republicans in Congress have shown signs of pragmatism, moving away from nationalistic and xenophobic rhetoric. Despite their presidential candidates' hardline stances, GOP leaders have reached deals with the White House on key issues, including the IMF overhaul and the renewal of trade promotion authority. This shift is seen as a return to the party's traditional centre ground, particularly in the global economic arena. The decision reflects a recognition of US failure to exercise leadership in the global economy and the growing power of China.

site_title: Stat board reshuffle under MOE and MOM to oversee skills, jobs
summary: Singapore is reorganizing its workforce development and private schools, with the Singapore Workforce Development Agency and Council for Private Education being merged into two new statutory boards: SkillsFuture Singapore and Workforce Singapore. The reorganization aims to foster lifelong learning and integrate education and training throughout a person's life. SkillsFuture Singapore will oversee skills and jobs, while Workforce Singapore will help develop a strong Singaporean core in each sector of the economy, with a focus on quality jobs and careers.

site_title: EU to propose binding multinational tax rules: official
summary: The European Commission will propose binding multinational tax rules by January 27 to curb corporate tax avoidance. The new measures will make some of the existing guidelines, known as BEPS, binding legislation for EU countries. The proposals aim to close gaps in international tax rules, including interest deductions and controlled foreign companies. The rules will also make company tax declarations more transparent, potentially making tax bills public. This move counters unfair tax practices of multinationals, following previous crackdowns on deals with individual EU states and multinational companies like Starbucks and Apple.

images.alt_text: Treating China as an economy driven by the market, not by the state, would have an impact of Europe's economic output, the European Commission said in a statement on Wednesday following a discussion among commissioners in Brussels.

site_title: Analysts see room for 40% rise in Samsung shares despite profit miss
summary: Analysts reaffirmed "buy" recommendations on Samsung Electronics Co, estimating a 40% rise in shares to $1,910 due to its potential to tap memory chips and displays. Despite missing profit estimates, Samsung's second consecutive profit report and restructuring efforts have boosted analyst confidence. 46 of 51 analysts rate the shares a "buy," with many citing the company's cheap valuation and potential for growth in non-smartphone segments.

site_title: SiS unit launches new fund that targets distressed residential assets in Singapore
summary: A new fund, the SiS Real Estate Opportunity Fund, has been launched in Singapore targeting distressed residential assets. The S$50m fund, with a five-year term, will opportunistically buy undervalued properties, give them a spruce-up, and reposition them to exit at a profit. The fund will focus on residential, commercial, and hospitality assets in Singapore and other Asian markets. It aims to capitalize on disruptions in the market and offers a more conservative AUM target and smaller minimum subscription denominations, targeting individual accredited investors.

site_title: US: Stocks hold up even as oil touches below US$30
summary: US stocks ended the day up 0.72% at 16,516.22, driven by a rebound in tech stocks, despite oil prices dipping below $30 a barrel for the first time since 2003. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 117.65 points, while the S&P 500 advanced 15.01 points. Large tech companies, including Alibaba, Intel, and Apple, led the gains, while oilfield services companies slipped. The market remains cautious ahead of fourth-quarter earnings season, with traders expressing uncertainty about the outlook for stocks.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday as oil prices rose and JPMorgan's strong results boosted bank stocks.

site_title: DBS Group is top stock among sells with S$261.8m
summary: Global mutual funds sold S$816.5 million worth of Singapore stocks, mostly finance stocks excluding real estate investment trusts, in the three months to Jan 6. The top-selling stock was DBS Group Holdings with S$261.8 million, while Global Logistics Properties was the top-buying stock with S$45.9 million. This trend indicates that fund managers are focusing on finance stocks, likely due to market sentiment and sector performance. The data is based on transactions from ShareInvestor and Ipreo, but may not reflect the entire market activity.

site_title: Use GIC returns as component in CPF OA rate: NUS prof
summary: Singaporean economics professor Chia Ngee Choon suggests linking the interest rate paid by the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Ordinary Account (OA) to the returns generated by sovereign wealth fund GIC. This could allow Singaporeans to enjoy GIC returns if the fund does well, while still maintaining a 2.5% guarantee. Currently, OA monies earn either the legislated minimum interest or the three-month average of local banks' interest rates. GIC has achieved a 20-year annualized real rate of return of 4.9%.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singaporean brokers are seeking shelter in selective dividend plays due to volatility. Key picks include Venture, M1, and Ascott Residence Trust, with a focus on sustainable dividends and yields above 3%. The telco sector is expected to remain overweight, despite Netflix's launch in Singapore, as local telcos collaborate with the US streaming operator. The plantation sector is neutral, with palm oil stocks expected to fall 6% month on month, driven by lower demand and El Nino.

images.alt_text: We seek shelter in selective dividend plays in view of volatility.

site_title: Syrian suicide bomber kills 10 in Istanbul's tourist heart
summary: A Syrian suicide bomber detonated explosives in Istanbul's tourist district, killing 10 people, mostly Germans, and wounding 9 others. The bomber, identified as a Syrian national from the Islamic State extremist group, targeted the area around the Blue Mosque. Turkish Prime Minister Davutoglu offered condolences to German Chancellor Merkel and warned tourists to avoid areas in Istanbul. An investigation is underway to identify the type of explosive used and any others involved in the attack, which comes after several deadly attacks in Turkey in recent months.

site_title: Rupert Murdoch to marry Jerry Hall
summary: Media mogul Rupert Murdoch is set to marry actress and former supermodel Jerry Hall, the couple announced in British newspaper The Times after a four-month romance. The pair started dating in the late summer and got engaged over the weekend in Los Angeles. This will be Murdoch's fourth marriage and Hall's first. The couple has a combined 10 children from previous marriages and has gone on holiday together. No date for their wedding has been given.

site_title: SPH's Q1 profit up 17.3% at S$81.3m
