site_title: Factory rents fell in Q4, will likely weaken further: DTZ
summary: Factory rents in Q4 2015 fell 2.3% to S$2.10 per sq ft for first-storey space and 2.9% to S$1.65 per sq ft for upper-storey space, marking the second consecutive decline in 2015. This drop is attributed to a contraction in net demand and excess supply of multiple-user factory space. With 4.6 million sq ft of new space entering the market in 2016, DTZ expects industrial rents to "trend downwards" this year.

site_title: Externally oriented industries will be subdued in short term: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that externally oriented industries in Singapore will experience subdued performance in the short term, mirroring the global economy's modest growth. However, opportunities exist for the country to shift manufacturing services to niche production, leveraging Asian consumption spending and modern financial services. Asia is expected to outperform the rest of the world with an average 6% growth rate from 2015 to 2020, driven by economic restructuring and innovation.

site_title: US crude falls below US$31 in Asian trade
summary: US crude oil prices fell below $31 a barrel in Asian trade, extending a 12-year low due to a global supply glut, strong dollar, and weak demand. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) dropped 45 cents to $30.96 per barrel and Brent tumbled 47 cents to $31.08 per barrel. Prices plummeted 10% last week as investors worried about the supply glut and geopolitical risks, including the Saudi Arabia-Iran row. Analysts expect prices to remain supported at $30, but production cuts may take months to materialize.

site_title: Singtel launches programme to tackle business challenges with global startups
summary: Singtel has launched Singtel Innov8 Connect, a programme that partners global startups with the Singtel group to develop innovative solutions for business challenges. Selected startups will receive up to S$75,000 to test and validate their solutions with Singtel, potentially leading to commercialization and access to 575 million mobile customers across Asia, Australia, and Africa. The programme aims to bring together entrepreneurs and businesses to tackle real-world challenges and drive growth.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks tick up after open
summary: Stocks in Shanghai and Hong Kong rose in early trading, tracking US gains. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.31%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.94%. In contrast, the Hong Kong Hang Seng Index slipped 0.65%. The market movements followed a day of selling due to concerns about China's economy.

site_title: Hyundai aims to 'set benchmark for luxury' with Genesis brand
summary: Hyundai has launched its luxury brand Genesis, aiming to compete with Japanese rivals and redefine the customer experience. The brand's flagship sedan, the G90, was unveiled at the Detroit auto show, featuring best-in-class performance and features. Hyundai seeks to overcome its reputation for poor quality and "cheaper alternative" perception by separating its premium offerings into a separate brand, similar to Honda, Nissan, and Toyota's luxury brands. The brand plans to expand into six offerings by 2020, with a focus on offering unique experiences and appealing to a new generation of luxury customers.

site_title: Ringgit extends worst start since 2009 as oil slump hits revenue
summary: Malaysia's ringgit slumped to a 0.5% drop to 4.4030 a dollar, extending its worst start to a year since 2009, due to a slump in Brent crude and uncertainty over China's economy. Prime Minister Najib Razak is reviewing the 2016 annual budget amid a potential RM300 million loss for every dollar drop in oil. Moody's cut the nation's credit outlook to stable from positive, citing the impact on government revenue. The currency has declined 2.5% in 2015, its worst annual loss in Asia.

site_title: Banks' borrowing rate for yuan in Hong Kong hits record
summary: Banks in Hong Kong have set a record high borrowing rate for yuan, with the overnight Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (HIBOR) surging 53 percentage points to almost 67% due to tight liquidity. This comes as concerns grow about China's economy, which has been experiencing a slowdown, and the People's Bank of China's decision to lower the yuan's value against the dollar. The move aims to deter speculators and tighten liquidity, lifting the yuan's value in Hong Kong.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, SIA, POSH
summary: Noble Group's founder and chairman Richard Elman has increased his stake in the commodity trader after it was downgraded to junk status. He bought 10 million shares on Monday and another 10 million shares on Tuesday, raising his stake to 22.28%. Singapore Airlines made its takeover offer for Tiger Airways unconditional, with a stake of over 80% still required.

site_title: UBS to double China staff as it implements its 'strategic plan'
summary: UBS Group AG plans to double its staff in China over the next five years, adding approximately 600 people, as CEO Sergio Ermotti believes volatile markets are an ideal time to expand operations. Ermotti stated that China's challenges are not unique and that planning for the future is crucial, leading to the implementation of the bank's strategic plan.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower on Shire slump and commodities slide
summary: European shares ended the day 0.4% lower on Monday, following a decline in Shire's stock price after it announced a deal to buy Baxalta. Shire fell 8.2% due to concerns over the offered price. The FTSEurofirst 300 index also slid 7% last week.

site_title: Volkswagen determined to win back American consumers
summary: Volkswagen has vowed to regain the trust of American car consumers after the emissions-cheating scandal. Chairman Herbert Diess stated the company's determination to "reignite America's love for Volkswagen." To achieve this, Volkswagen will invest in fresh products and announce new investments on American soil, starting with the Detroit auto show. The company's efforts aim to rebuild its reputation and win back US customers following the scandal.

site_title: China: Stocks rise in volatile early trade on reports of proposed financial reforms
summary: China's major stock indexes rose on Tuesday, driven by reports of proposed financial reforms to strengthen the nation's financial regulatory system. The CSI300 index rose 1.2% to 3,229.69 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.7% to 3,036.39. The reforms aim to upgrade the cabinet's financial department to bureau level, with a working group led by deputy secretary-general Xiao Jie. This move is seen as a response to concerns globally that China may be losing its grip on policy as economic growth cools.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.55 points to 1,641.14 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 94.93 million lots worth RM40.74 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 170 to 77, indicating a positive start to the day.

site_title: Albedo jumps on proposed S$3m placement deal but ends flat
summary: Albedo's shares jumped to S$0.013 on a S$3 million share placement to a Shanghai-based Malaysia businessman, aiming to enter China's medical aesthetics market. However, the stock ended trading flat at S$0.011.

site_title: Shire buys US pharma firm Baxalta for US$32b
summary: Shire, a Dublin-based pharmaceutical group, has agreed to buy US-based pharma firm Baxalta for $32 billion, creating a global biotech giant targeting rare diseases. The deal is expected to be completed in mid-2016 and will boost Shire's position in the market for rare-disease treatments. This acquisition is part of the pharmaceutical sector's rapid consolidation.

site_title: Snapchat's daily mobile video views said to rival Facebook's
summary: Snapchat surpasses Facebook in daily mobile video views, delivering over 7 billion video clips each day, rivaling the social media giant's 8 billion daily video views. With over 100 million users, Snapchat is gaining on Facebook, which has 15 times as many users and 1.55 billion users. This achievement marks Snapchat's growth as a mobile-video juggernaut.

site_title: STI slips 1.5% in line with regional bourses
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.5% on Monday, closing at 2,708.85, its sixth consecutive loss of 2016. The decline was attributed to China's slowdown, slumping oil prices, and the Middle East conflict, weighing on trading sentiment. The key index is now down 6% for the year, following a 5-day rally.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Four principles to guide Future Economy group
summary: The Future Economy group, led by Singapore's Minister Chan Chun Sing, will identify strategies to grow priority clusters and markets driving the global economy. The group will focus on how Singapore can remain competitive as global trends reconfigure the economy. Members, including Mariam Jaafar from Boston Consulting Group, will study how to maintain Singapore's position as a key hub despite emerging trends. The group's recommendations will aim to drive the global economy forward.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 1.02% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.02% lower on Tuesday, despite US shares mostly gaining, due to lingering worries over China's economy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 180.38 points to 17,517.58, while the Topix index of all first-section shares fell 1.39% to 1,427.14.

site_title: Amazon to launch portable version of Echo speaker: WSJ
summary: Amazon plans to release a portable version of its Echo speaker, code-named "Fox", which is expected to be priced lower than the existing US$180 Echo. The device, made by Flextronics International Ltd, is expected to be released soon. This new product will join Amazon's existing voice-activated Echo speaker, allowing users to give voice directions and control smart home devices.

site_title: Malaysia's 'Repco Low' found guilty in 16-year-old share manipulation case
summary: Malaysia's Repco Low, a notorious stock operator, was found guilty of market manipulation involving Repco Holdings Bhd shares 16 years after the Securities Commission initiated a case against him in 1999. The Sessions Court delivered the guilty verdict on Monday. This verdict marks a significant outcome for Low, who was once considered one of the biggest stock operators of the 1990s Malaysian equities bull run.

site_title: VW CEO says 6.7b euro provisions sufficient to cover repairs
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller stated that the company has prepared 6.7 billion euros to cover repairs for US cars capable of cheating diesel emissions tests. Mueller expressed confidence in the company's sales prospects for the year despite difficult market conditions. He proposed a new catalytic converter system to the US Environmental Protection Agency, which could be fitted to approximately 430,000 rigged US cars. Mueller believes the provision is sufficient to cover all repairs globally.

site_title: VW starts journey to win back Americans
summary: Volkswagen executives are attempting to regain consumer trust at the Detroit auto show after admitting to cheating on diesel emissions tests in the US. The company aims to persuade regulators that it has found a solution to the problem. VW's US sales have plummeted since the scandal in September. Executives will showcase new models and discuss their plan to fix the issue, hoping to win back American consumers and restore their market share.

site_title: Israel's best-performing tech stock hasn't sold a single product
summary: Nano Dimension, an Israeli tech company, has become the country's best-performing technology stock in 2015 despite having no customers or revenue. The company, which specializes in 3D printing, went public through a reverse merger and saw its stock value increase 261% last year. Its strong performance is a stark contrast to rival 3D printing giant Stratasys, which lost nearly three-quarters of its value during the same period.

site_title: Asian auto makers export more SUVs to US in bid to meet demand
summary: Asian auto makers are increasing SUV exports to the US to meet strong demand, with Hyundai planning to boost Tucson sales by over 25,000 units this year and Nissan moving to ship more Rogue SUVs from Japan. The move comes as lawmakers debate the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade liberalization deal that could impact US manufacturing jobs. Hyundai and Nissan are seeking to capitalize on the trend, with Hyundai also developing a new subcompact crossover SUV. The increased exports aim to meet growing US demand for SUVs.

site_title: Merkel under pressure as Cologne police detail assaults
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel faced growing pressure to harden her stance on refugees after the first detailed report on New Year's Eve violence in Cologne documented widespread sexual assaults by migrant gangs. At least 11 foreigners were injured in counter-attacks, deepening skepticism towards Merkel's migrant policy. The Cologne police report highlighted the need for Merkel to take a stronger stance on refugees, amid rising anti-immigrant sentiment in Germany.

site_title: Icahn buying up Time Warner shares: sources
summary: Billionaire investor Carl Icahn is reportedly buying up Time Warner shares, potentially leading to a major shake-up of the media conglomerate. The move comes after Time Warner's key domestic entertainment networks experienced declining ratings, with shares falling 30% since last July. Icahn, who previously waged an unsuccessful break-up campaign against Time Warner in 2006, is believed to be building an equity stake in the company. Time Warner declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Trafigura appoints Singaporean as Asia Pacific head honcho
summary: Trafigura Group, a major commodity trader, has appointed Tan Chin Hwee, a 45-year-old Singaporean, as its CEO for Asia Pacific, marking the first Asian to hold a senior management position at the company. The appointment follows Trafigura's relocation of its global headquarters to Singapore in 2012. Tan will oversee the company's operations in the Asia Pacific region, which handle approximately three million barrels of oil daily.

site_title: China FX reserve sell-off to soon move beyond US Treasuries: BAML
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves are expected to sell off beyond US Treasuries, with US corporate and euro zone sovereign bonds at risk, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch. China sold a record $510 billion of reserves last year, with the majority coming from US Treasury debt. This move aims to counter the impact of capital outflows on China's decelerating economy. The unwinding of reserves could lead to increased volatility in financial markets.

site_title: UK small business euro transfers cost 4 billion pounds a year: study
summary: A UK study found that small businesses spend nearly 4 billion pounds (US$5.8 billion) annually transferring money abroad due to a lack of transparency in banking fees. The study, commissioned by Money Mover, analyzed six major UK banks and found that on average, banks charge 2.43% of the transferred value, equivalent to 3.96 billion pounds. The study's conclusions are limited due to the volatility of foreign exchange markets and a lack of transparency in exchange rate calculations.

site_title: Explosive year for energy sector
summary: A prominent economic analyst, Kenneth Courtis, warns that the energy sector is expected to experience a "blood bath" in 2016 due to distortions in markets caused by central bank interventions. This mayhem will also affect commodities and financial markets, potentially leading to a global crisis. The analyst attributes these distortions to the actions of central banks, which are now causing producer distress and investor fears. Courtis predicts a turbulent year ahead for energy and other markets.

site_title: Base investments on fundamentals
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has called for the Government Investment Corporation (GIC) to invest Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies in the local stock market, sparking debate over nationalistic motives and risk management. Critics argue that such investments should be based on sound fundamental principles and reward-vs-risk ratio, rather than emotional appeals. The proposal has been met with skepticism, citing past examples of governments losing billions trying to prop up markets. A balanced approach to investing is recommended to avoid "gambling" with CPF monies.

site_title: SAP Q4 operating profit rises 7% on license renewals
summary: SAP reported a 7% rise in operating profits to 2.28 billion euros (US$2.47 billion) in Q4, driven by year-end software license renewals and customer conversions to cloud-based software. Full-year operating profit rose 13% to 6.35 billion euros. The company exceeded analyst forecasts, with Q4 results beating expectations and setting a 2016 target of 6.4-6.7 billion euros. SAP attributed the growth to higher-margin licensed software renewals and the weaker euro.

site_title: Strategies for digital brand building
summary: Digital branding has seen exponential growth, becoming a crucial channel for global brand building. Instagram's global expansion to over 200 countries has significantly impacted its advertising revenue, projected to reach $2.8 billion by 2017. This growth is attributed to the increasing importance of digital branding, with skills and confidence in metrics holding organizations back from achieving success. The shift to digital branding has also led to increased investment in the industry, with eMarketer predicting a significant rise in advertising revenue.

site_title: Electric in US: More options, fewer sales
summary: US electric vehicle sales dipped to 0.7% of the overall market in 2015, despite a record 17.5 million new car sales. This comes as consumers prefer larger vehicles due to cheap gas prices. Automakers have introduced 30 electric or plug-in hybrid vehicles since 2009, with many offering models in addition to conventional designs. Policymakers and industry leaders argue that fuel economy standards and incentives are necessary to promote electric cars, citing examples of Norway's 17.1% market share and the UN's global emissions reduction agreement.

site_title: Arch Coal files for bankruptcy, hit by mining downturn
summary: Arch Coal, the US's second-largest coal miner, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection with a plan to cut $4.5 billion in debt. The filing comes as the coal industry faces a prolonged downturn due to low coal prices, stricter pollution controls, and decreased demand from China. The company's debt has been a concern since its 2011 acquisition of International Coal Group. This move is expected to have a ripple effect on the coal industry, with shares of Peabody Energy Corp hitting a record low.

site_title: UK stores suffer "disappointing" Christmas as sales growth slows: BRC
summary: UK retail spending recorded its weakest quarterly growth in over a year, with a 0.9% increase in Christmas sales, the slowest since November 2014. Despite positive economic indicators, retailers offered deeper discounts, contributing to the disappointing result. After stripping out price changes, retail sales volumes rose 3.0% in December. The British Retail Consortium attributes the slowdown to rising consumer borrowing and falling store prices, but warns of increasing costs from local property taxes and a higher minimum wage.

site_title: Delta passes United to become No. 2 in US after American Airlines
summary: Delta Air Lines surpassed United Continental Holdings to become the second-largest US airline by traffic, according to industry yardstick revenue passenger miles. Delta now trails only American Airlines Group Inc. The shift is attributed to Delta's better service and product compared to United, following its merger with Continental Airlines.

site_title: United Airlines sales hurt by Paris attacks, weaker oil industry demand
summary: United Airlines reported a potential drop of 5.75-6.25% in passenger unit revenue for the fourth quarter, exceeding its earlier forecast of 4-6%. The decline was attributed to the November Paris attacks, which reduced traveler demand, and lower oil prices affecting energy sales to the airline's clients.

site_title: Rand sinks as China weakness batters emerging currencies
summary: South Africa's rand dropped 2.9% against the US dollar as commodity prices fell, eroding investor confidence in the country's economy. Chinese inflation remained below target, with factory gate prices sinking for a 46th consecutive month. This further weakens the global commodities market, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Noble chairman continues to lift stake in doubly-junked firm
summary: NOBLE Group chairman Richard Elman increased his stake in the commodity trader by buying 10 million shares on the open market for S$3.34 million, bringing his stake to 22.28%. The stock fell 8.8% after the announcement, closing at S$0.335. This comes after Elman bought 10 million shares last Friday for S$3.19 million, raising his stake to 22.13%. The company plans to hold a special general meeting on January 28 to seek shareholder approval for the sale of its agricultural unit, Noble Agri.

site_title: Fantasy sports sites allowed to operate in New York during appeal
summary: New York's Appeals Court has granted a temporary stay, allowing daily fantasy sports sites FanDuel and DraftKings to continue operating in the state while they appeal a civil action by Attorney General Eric Schneiderman. The decision extends a prior injunction granted on December 11, allowing the companies to keep operating during the appeal process.

site_title: Singapore's next bond default looms amid Pacific Andes skirmish
summary: Singapore's bond market may face its second default in months after Pacific Andes Resources Development Ltd failed to honour some obligations on S$200 million of notes. The Hong Kong-based firm has halted trading in Singapore and received a letter from bond trustee HSBC alleging breaches on the 2017 securities. Investors can request immediate repayment if the company's shares are suspended, adding to the troubled fishery group's court battles and regulatory probes. This default could lead to a "can of worms" in Singapore's corporate bond market, with few local bonds rated and issuers having weak credit profiles.

site_title: Stocks may fall more, then it'll be time to buy, Goldman says
summary: Goldman Sachs strategist Christian Mueller-Glissmann predicts that global stocks may fall further, but that's when investors should consider buying, citing European shares as a cheaper and more attractive option. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index is expected to rally 18% in the next 12 months, driven by earnings growth and support from the European Central Bank. Investors are advised to focus on financial, staples, and healthcare companies linked to Europe's economic recovery, while maintaining a allocation to US stocks, which are nearing the end of a long bull market.

site_title: China creates new office to coordinate finance, economy
summary: China's Cabinet has created a new department to coordinate financial and economic affairs, aiming to restore investor confidence in the government's regulation of markets. The department, under the State Council's general office, will gather data and coordinate between financial and economic regulators. Agricultural Bank of China vice-president Li Zhenjiang was appointed as deputy director, tasked with daily operations. The move is seen as a response to slowing GDP growth, which may put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Nations vow better intel sharing to halt terror attacks
summary: Foreign ministers from over 50 nations agreed to improve intelligence sharing to prevent terrorists from crossing borders and carrying out attacks. The nations pledged to share information better, smarter, and faster, following a day-long meeting at Europol's headquarters in The Hague. The concrete resolutions aim to address intelligence lapses and prevent extremist groups from exploiting these gaps, ultimately reducing the risk of terror attacks.

site_title: Southeast Asian palm output seen rebounding as El Nino fades
summary: Southeast Asian palm oil production is expected to rebound as El Nino fades, boosting output this year. Following a dry spell, recent rains in the region are forecast to increase production, reversing the price rise seen in 2015. Palm oil prices jumped 30% in the last four months of 2015 due to the El Nino weather pattern, which affected Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's largest producers.

site_title: Alcoa posts Q4 loss due to charges from shuttering capacity
summary: Alcoa Inc reported a quarterly net loss due to charges from shuttering parts of its traditional smelting business. The company has been curtailing smelting capacity amid tumbling aluminum prices and rising trade tensions with China. This move brings US aluminum output to its lowest level in over 65 years. London Metal Exchange aluminum prices have fallen to 6-1/2 year lows, and the Midwest premium has fallen over 60% due to decreased demand in top-consumer China.

site_title: Ascendas bond sale 1st SGD issue in 2016
summary: Ascendas Pte Ltd sold a seven-year Singapore-dollar bond, the first public issue in 2016, with orderbooks exceeding S$300 million. The bond offered a 3.5% yield, a tight price guidance. This sale provides a safe haven investment amid market turmoil, particularly in equity and currency markets.

site_title: US, major automakers to announce safety accord Friday: sources
summary: The US government and major automakers, including Fiat Chrysler, Honda, and General Motors, are set to announce a voluntary safety accord at the Detroit auto show on Friday. The agreement aims to improve industry safety, vehicle cyber security, and early warning systems to detect potential defects. This comes after a record-setting year of safety fines, recalls, and investigations into malfunctioning vehicles. The accord could mark a new era of cooperation between automakers and regulators.

site_title: Six bankers charged, five absent as UK begins first Euribor rigging case
summary: Six former Deutsche Bank, Barclays, and Societe Generale employees have been formally charged in a British court with conspiring to manipulate Euribor benchmark interest rates. The case, Britain's fourth prosecution of rate-fixing allegations, involves 11 former employees and marks the first to cover Euribor manipulation allegations. The charges follow a global inquiry initiated by US regulators in 2008, which has led to rate-fixing cases worldwide.

site_title: US bull market coming to an end soon, says Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts the US bull market is nearing its end, citing modest single-digit returns for a moderate-risk portfolio due to high equity valuations and interest rates. The bank's 2016 outlook report advises caution.

site_title: Digital or paper planner? Either way, there still isn't enough time
summary: A recent article discusses the universal struggle of finding enough time in one's life, despite having a digital or paper planner. Many individuals feel overwhelmed with responsibilities, leaving little time for self-care, socializing, or simply being still. The article highlights the need for better time management and prioritization.

site_title: Noble's chairman increases his stake as shares sink
summary: NOBLE Group Ltd chairman Richard Elman increased his stake in the commodity trader by buying 10 million shares worth S$3.19 million, raising his holding to 22.13%. The stock sank 8.8% to 31 cents amid a region-wide drop in raw material shares, after its credit rating was cut to junk and analysts scaled back price targets.

site_title: Oil dive deepens to 12-year low; US$20 warning on China
summary: Oil prices plummeted 6% to new 12-year lows, reaching US$20 a barrel, amid an accelerating selloff and further ructions in the Chinese stock market. The biggest one-day loss since September triggered panic trading and long-term futures contracts fell nearly as hard as immediate delivery contracts. Producers rushed to hedge, while a key options gauge surged to nearly its highest since 2009. The market's bearish outlook, exacerbated by Trump's tariff threats, continues to weigh on the oil market.

site_title: Kakao to acquire Korean music streaming operator
summary: Kakao Corp has agreed to acquire a 76.4% stake in Loen Entertainment Inc, the owner of South Korea's top music streaming service MelOn, for 1.9 trillion won (S$2.3 billion). The acquisition aims to find new revenue streams for Kakao. To fund the deal, Kakao will issue 754 billion won worth of new shares to top Loen shareholders.

site_title: Malaysia's November factory output growth slips to weakest in 16 months
summary: Malaysia's factory output in November grew 1.8% from a year earlier, its slowest pace in 16 months, due to weaker global demand and a decline in mining production, falling short of the 4% median forecast.

site_title: Yahoo's brain drain shows loss of faith in tech giant's chief executive
summary: Yahoo's CEO Marissa Mayer is facing a brain drain and low morale, with some employees referring to her as "Evita" due to her perceived ego. Despite efforts to turn around the company, Mayer has resorted to job cuts, prompting some investors to call for her dismissal. The situation highlights a loss of faith in Mayer's leadership and the struggling tech giant.

site_title: China needs to order hundreds more planes: Avolon CEO
summary: China needs to order hundreds more planes over the next decade, according to Avolon Holdings Ltd CEO Domhnal Slattery, citing the country's demographic growth. With a middle class expected to grow to 2.6 billion people by 2035, China needs US$1 trillion worth of aircraft, but has under-ordered by around 750 planes. This suggests Boeing Co and Airbus Group SE will receive more orders, highlighting the growing demand for aircraft in the Chinese market.

site_title: Wall Street faces profit recession as earnings season begins
summary: Wall Street's fourth-quarter earnings season is set to begin, with some warning of a potential profit recession, defined as two consecutive quarters of declining profits. Consumer discretionary companies, which have been warning about profits at an unusual pace, may lead the decline. Energy and materials companies are also expected to be affected, but the severity of the recession may depend on the performance of these firms. This could have implications for the US economy, which may be doing well despite declining corporate profits.

site_title: 2016: Obama's year of living dangerously
summary: President Barack Obama's presidency is nearing its end, with his last year in office marked by potential geopolitical and geoeconomic tensions. Despite his economic recovery, Obama's major policy successes, such as the Affordable Care Act and Iran nuclear deal, remain controversial and may be repealed by a Republican president. This could impact his legacy, which could be overshadowed by tensions over trade, healthcare, and foreign policy.

site_title: Detroit's car industry is changed, but not as Washington planned
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to Detroit's annual car show on January 20, 2016, will highlight the industry's changes since his 2009 rescue. However, the show's lineup may not reflect the green transport revival he envisioned. The auto industry has undergone significant changes, but many have opted for traditional designs rather than adopting more sustainable models. Obama stated that the industry must truly change, not just pretend to do so.

site_title: UK's Lloyds set to keep £2,000 cap on cash bonuses, say sources
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc, Britain's largest mortgage lender, is set to maintain its £2,000 cap on cash bonuses until after the UK government sells its shares in the bank. The decision, made in talks with UK Financial Investments Ltd, aims to finalize 2015 compensation plans. No final decision has been made, and the talks are private.

site_title: SGX seeks feedback on proposed rule changes
summary: SGX is consulting the public on proposed mainboard and Catalist listing rules changes to align with the amended Companies Act of 2014. The regulator seeks feedback on allowing companies to electronically transmit materials to shareholders without explicit consent. This change aims to simplify the listing process and align with global practices. The public can provide feedback on the proposed rule changes.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Why Disney won't be taking magic wristbands to Chinese park
summary: Disney will not use its magic wristbands at the Shanghai Disney Resort in China, instead allowing guests to use their smartphones to enter the park, purchase merchandise, and access attractions. This decision comes as technology continues to advance and the mobile revolution gains momentum, particularly in China. According to Phocuswright, China is expected to become the first market where the majority of online travel purchases are made on mobile devices this year. By using smartphones, Disney aims to reduce costs associated with the devices and provide guests with a seamless experience.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound in choppy session
summary: US stocks rebounded 0.32% in the final hour of trading, driven by a decline in oil prices below $32 for the first time in 12 years. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 52.12 points to 16,398.57, while the S&P 500 index advanced 1.64 points to 1,923.67. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite lost 5.64 points, however. Investors await the start of earnings season, which is expected to bring significant market movements.

site_title: Temasek fund invests in homegrown store-fixtures firm
summary: Temasek Holdings' Heliconia Capital Management has invested in Singapore-based store-fixtures company Futuristic Store Fixtures. The investment will be used to expand and upgrade manufacturing facilities in Malaysia and China, as well as explore strategic partnerships and acquisitions to expand its regional reach. This move comes despite the challenging economic conditions in Asia, with Futuristic maintaining its confidence in the region as a key market for global lifestyle retail brands.

site_title: Henderson's Bennett flirts with depressed oil majors
summary: Veteran fund manager John Bennett, director of European equities at Henderson Global Investors, has been buying depressed European oil supermajors despite expensive European stocks. Bennett notes that the oil majors' valuations could correct another 10% before his views change, citing a lack of conviction in his positions. He is taking a contrarian approach, looking to capitalize on undervalued stocks.

site_title: Apple buys start-up that sees what's behind your smile
summary: Apple has acquired Emotient, a facial recognition technology startup that specializes in interpreting people's emotions while watching videos and other media. The San Diego-based company's software is used in advertising, media testing, audience response, and research. The terms of the purchase were not disclosed, but Apple confirmed the acquisition without providing further details. Emotient's technology will likely be integrated into Apple's services, although its specific uses have not been specified.

site_title: A powerful young prince in a hurry to transform Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia has executed dozens of militants and severed ties with Iran in a week, amid a radical modernization effort led by 30-something Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The prince aims to privatize oil giant Saudi Aramco and has announced numerous steps to transform the traditionally conservative society. The actions are partly driven by tumbling oil prices and regional turmoil, but some fear he is overextending himself. The prince's ambition has drawn praise, but his decisions have raised concerns about the country's stability and future.

site_title: Mortgagee auctions expected to rise
summary: Mortgagee auctions in Singapore are expected to rise this year, with foreigners defaulting on high-end investment property loans being a key factor. This month, several properties, including a factory, shop units, and a detached house, are making their auction appearances. A banker attributes the growth of mortgagee listings to foreigners who typically do not live in Singapore and fail to repay their loans. The increase in mortgagee listings is a concern for the property market, indicating potential issues with high-end investment properties.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China to invest US$12b in civil aviation this year
summary: China plans to invest approximately US$12 billion in civil aviation this year, focusing on 11 key projects and 52 aviation-related expansions. The country aims to improve infrastructure to meet growing air-travel demand and boost economic growth. A blueprint for new airports will be launched by 2030, with plans to start over 200 new overseas routes this year.

site_title: Olam buys Nigeria's BUA assets for US$275m
summary: Olam International has acquired Nigeria's BUA Group assets for US$275 million, including wheat mills and pasta manufacturing facilities. The deal is expected to boost Olam's presence in the Nigerian market, where pasta imports are banned and the market is projected to grow 8% annually. The acquisition is part of Olam's strategy to expand its operations in Africa.

site_title: Irreverence, and a few winners, at the Golden Globes
summary: The 73rd Golden Globe Awards ceremony took place on January 11, 2016, with television awards dominating the first half of the show. USA's "Mr. Robot" won the Globe for best drama, beating HBO's "Game of Thrones," and Christian Slater won best supporting actor for the series. The ceremony featured irreverent moments, including profanity from the stage and disengaged A-list dinner guests, but still awarded some trophies, including the drama award to "Mr. Robot."

site_title: DP Architects names new chairman, CEO
summary: DP Architects has announced key appointments, effective January 1, 2016. Francis Lee has taken over as chairman and CEO, replacing Chan Sui Him who now holds a mentorship role as senior director. Angelene Chan has been appointed as the group's CEO.

site_title: Louis Vuitton sues 3 Chinese online sellers of counterfeits
summary: Louis Vuitton has filed a lawsuit against three Chinese online sellers convicted of offering counterfeit versions of its luxury goods on Alibaba Group's Taobao website. The Beijing district court accepted the lawsuit on January 4, seeking damages from the individuals. This move comes as the luxury goods firm continues to face challenges in the Chinese market, where even high tariffs have not deterred counterfeiters.

site_title: POSH bags Shell's towing contract
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings secured a contract to tow Shell's first floating liquefied natural gas plant, Prelude, to the Prelude gas field off Western Australia. The Prelude FLNG is the largest offshore production structure being built, measuring 488m by 74m. This contract marks a significant milestone for the joint venture with Seabridge Marine Services and Ezion Holdings.

site_title: Climate-change effects on middle class 'have political implications'
summary: The middle class worldwide will face significant costs due to climate change, potentially influencing global policymaking. Rising costs will prompt this mobile class to seek asset protection measures. Meanwhile, economic indicators show China's GDP growth slowing, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Chinese property developers rush to print private Panda bonds
summary: Chinese property developers are rushing to issue Panda bonds, a type of onshore bond issued by overseas companies to access China's onshore market. Country Garden Holdings led the way with a 1 billion yuan (S$218 million) five-year bond. This move aims to lock in more attractive funding costs. The development follows previous Panda bond issuances, including a sovereign offering from South Korea, which were approved by the People's Bank of China. The trend is expected to test demand for Singapore prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark in Q3.

site_title: CJ Menon unveils plans to strengthen Singapore judiciary
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon of Singapore unveiled plans to strengthen the country's judiciary, including a network connecting courts of key global commercial centers for cross-border insolvency cases. The network aims to enhance cooperation and efficiency in resolving international disputes. Menon also emphasized the importance of adapting the legal system to meet the demands of the future.

site_title: L Capital Asia's growth still a 'strategic priority'
summary: L Capital Asia, the Asia-focused private equity arm of LVMH, is a "strategic priority" for L Catterton, the merged entity of LVMH and Catterton. L Capital Asia is on track to raise Fund III, valued at over US$1 billion.

site_title: Oil prices fall to US$32.87 for Brent, US$32.71 for WTI
summary: Oil prices dropped to US$32.87 for Brent and US$32.71 for WTI, amid concerns over China's slowing growth and a supply glut. Analysts note that tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia could provide some support.

site_title: Stiglitz feels 'less optimistic' about China's market reforms
summary: Nobel Laureate Joseph Stiglitz expressed reduced optimism about China's ability to drive global growth, citing Beijing's recent market stabilisation efforts as uncertain. He predicted a similar growth prospect to 2015, contradicting China's status as a major player in the global economy. Stiglitz's comments come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Hedge funds greet 2016 by cutting bullish oil bets to 5-year low
summary: Hedge funds have cut their bullish oil bets to the lowest level in over five years, as oil prices tumbled due to a global glut and economic concerns in China. The decline accelerated after turmoil in China's markets and a rise in tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran.

site_title: AB InBev lining up expected record mega-bond
summary: AB InBev is holding investor calls to sell a potential record-breaking $30-60 billion bond as part of its financing for the purchase of SABMiller. The sale, arranged by Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays, and Deutsche Bank, could top the current record holder, a $49 billion deal from Verizon in 2013.

site_title: Merkel being pressed on all sides
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel faces a challenging year as Germany struggles to resolve euro area problems, particularly with debt-strapped Mediterranean countries. Greece's bailout package may not be enough to prevent a return to financial crisis, with indications from Athens suggesting the issue will soon resurface. Merkel's efforts to address these problems may be reaching their limits, making the road ahead steeper and more complex for Europe.

site_title: British music legend David Bowie dies
summary: British music legend David Bowie has died after a long battle with cancer, according to his official social media accounts. The 69-year-old musician died on Sunday surrounded by family. His 25th studio album, Blackstar, was released just a week before his death, coinciding with his 69th birthday. Tributes poured in from fans and fellow artists, honoring Bowie's legacy as a music icon.

site_title: Brazil probes 13 banks for Schahin, Petrobras operations: report
summary: Brazil's federal tax authority and prosecutors are investigating 13 banks, including Itaú BBA, Banco Bradesco, and HSBC, for allegedly facilitating loans to Grupo Schahin, a Brazilian engineering conglomerate, potentially for money laundering. The investigation follows a separate probe into Schahin's alleged ties to the ruling Workers' Party and state-run oil firm Petrobras. The banks under investigation are accused of being originators, underwriters, or managers of loans to Schahin.

site_title: PTTEP to sanction expansion of gas field off Myanmar in Q2
summary: PTTEP, a Thai state-owned company, plans to sanction Phase 1C of the Zawtika gas field development off Myanmar in the second quarter, aiming to stabilize export-gas volumes amid a domestic output shortfall. The project, valued in the hundreds of millions of dollars, features up to four wellhead platforms and will be tendered out under an engineering procurement contract. This move is crucial in maintaining export gas volumes in the face of decreasing domestic output from the field.

site_title: Temasek fund invests undisclosed sum in homegrown store-fixtures firm
summary: Temasek Holdings' Heliconia Capital Management has invested an undisclosed sum in Singapore's Futuristic Store Fixtures Pte Ltd. The investment will be used to expand and upgrade manufacturing facilities in Malaysia and China, as well as pursue strategic partnerships or acquisitions to expand its regional reach. Futuristic, which works with global brands such as Victoria's Secret, plans to utilize the funds to tap into China and Asia's growing consumer market.

site_title: Little evidence China's outlook has darkened dramatically - analysts
summary: China's stock markets have plunged, sparking concerns about the country's economy, but analysts say there's little evidence of a dramatic downturn. Despite a loss of steam in 2015, vehicle and property sales are showing signs of life, and economists are divided over when the economy will bottom out. Economists attribute the recent market decline to specific factors rather than a broader economic decline, citing economic indicators that showed the economy gaining momentum in November.

site_title: China central bank to keep yuan largely stable against currency basket
summary: China's central bank plans to maintain the yuan's stability against a currency basket, allowing for fluctuations against the US dollar. Chief economist Ma Jun stated that the yuan won't be strictly pegged to the basket, allowing for increased flexibility. The decision was made following aggressive intervention by Beijing, which guided the yuan higher and led to offshore surges against the dollar. However, Chinese stocks fell as doubts persisted over policymakers' intentions.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as earnings season starts
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as the corporate earnings season began, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 73.14 points to 16,419.59. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: White House joins Snapchat ahead of State of the Union address
summary: The White House has joined Snapchat ahead of President Barack Obama's last State of the Union address, marking the administration's latest effort to reach a younger generation through social media. The White House aims to "meet people where they are" and provide Americans with multiple ways to engage with their government. The administration's first Snapchat post featured a video of a bowl of apples on a coffee table in the Oval Office. This move is part of the administration's strategy to engage with Americans through non-traditional media platforms.

site_title: Singapore shares close 42 points lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 42.38 points or 1.5% to 2,708.85, following regional market declines due to concerns over China's growth prospects and equity slump. 1.8 billion shares worth S$1.05 billion were traded, with losers outpacing gainers.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Consumer spending plans drop amid pessimism over wages, Fed says
summary: US consumers have reduced their spending expectations for the next year, with median forecasts of 2.9% growth, the weakest since 2013. This pessimism stems from concerns over stagnant wage growth, with expected earnings growth falling to 2% and median expected household income growth at 2.3%. The Federal Reserve's recent rate hike has also contributed to this outlook, with expected inflation one year ahead dropping to 2.5% and three years ahead rebounding to 2.8%.

site_title: Samsung has room to rise 40% even with profit miss, analysts say
summary: Samsung Electronics Co's fourth-quarter earnings miss did not deter analysts, who reaffirmed their "buy" recommendations, expecting a 40% rise in the company's stock price in the coming year. Despite losing ground to Apple and Chinese brands, analysts believe Samsung's focus on memory chips and displays can help it recover. The company's restructuring efforts and potential shift to software innovations may also contribute to its growth, with some analysts suggesting the release of a foldable smartphone as a way to revive its brand.

site_title: Illumina, partners make US$100m bet to detect cancer via blood test
summary: Illumina, a gene sequencing company, has formed a new company, Grail, with a $100 million investment to develop a universal blood test for early-stage cancer detection in healthy individuals. The test uses Illumina's DNA sequencing technology to scan for cancer genes in the bloodstream. Grail aims to conduct clinical trials on 300,000 human genomes and launch the test by 2019, with a target price of $500. Experts believe it will take significant clinical trials to prove the effectiveness of DNA blood tests for cancer screening.

site_title: Is the stock market foretelling the next recession?
summary: The US stock market experienced a 6% drop, a paper loss of $1.5 trillion, in the previous week, raising concerns about a potential recession. The sell-off began in China due to a weaker-than-expected manufacturing report, which triggered a global chain reaction. The shift in economic power from advanced to emerging-market nations, particularly China, Brazil, Russia, and India, is seen as a contributing factor to the market's volatility. Experts note that the stock market's record in forecasting recessions is poor, but the recent downturn may be a sign of a larger economic trend.

site_title: SIA makes offer for Tiger unconditional
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has made its S$0.45-per-share takeover offer for Tiger Airways unconditional, with the closing date extended to Feb 5. SIA's stake in Tiger currently remains under 80% and cannot be increased further. Shareholders who accept the offer will receive payment and be granted the option to subscribe to SIA shares. The offer was initially due to close on Dec 28 but was revised after SIAS urged SIA to revise the offer. Minority shareholders may face difficulties if they do not accept the offer, as they would need to find a buyer for their shares.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: German carmakers see steady US sales in 2016: VDA
summary: German carmakers, including Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW, expect steady US sales in 2016, with deliveries potentially reaching 1.4 million cars, comparable to last year's sales. VDA President Matthias Wissmann attributed this to the uncertainty surrounding diesel cars. Overall US passenger car and light truck sales are forecast to increase 1% to 17.5 million autos in 2016.

site_title: Why Singapore's central bank is unlikely to make another off-cycle policy move
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is unlikely to make another off-cycle policy move, according to 8 out of 9 economists surveyed. The MAS eased policy in January 2016 after declining oil prices, but economists expect a less severe impact this time due to lower oil prices. The MAS may consider policy changes if China's economic growth momentum deteriorates, but no immediate action is expected due to recent stabilization of Chinese data and the MAS's cautious approach.

site_title: Involve boards of VWOs in talent management
summary: The National Council of Social Service (NCSS) in Singapore has released salary guidelines for the voluntary welfare organisation (VWO) sector to attract and retain talent. However, boards of VWOs play a crucial role in sustaining talent growth in the social services sector. Effective involvement of boards in talent management involves setting up HR committees to monitor strategic talent management areas, fostering a strong organisational culture, and providing oversight on human capital issues. With sufficient human capital expertise among board members and quality information, VWO boards can contribute to the sector's growth and attractiveness as a career choice.

site_title: Hong Kong offshore yuan interbank rate hits record highs
summary: Hong Kong's Interbank Offered Rates (HIBOR) hit record highs on January 11, 2016, as investors fled offshore yuan for dollars amid concerns over a potential deepening devaluation. Overnight HIBOR spiked to over 13%, while all other tenors reached record highs, ranging from 11% to 5.2%. This is significantly higher than onshore rates in Shanghai, which remain below 2%. The offshore market is pricing the yuan at a deep discount to the onshore version, driven by investor concerns over Beijing's economic policies.

site_title: Eurozone economic growth stable, China stabilising: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) reported that economic conditions are stabilising in China and the eurozone, with steady growth expected. The eurozone economy remains at 100.6, while the US and UK economies are losing steam, with the US reading at 99.1 and the UK reading at 99.1. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: David Bowie dies after 18-month battle with cancer: Twitter account
summary: David Bowie died after an 18-month battle with cancer, as announced on his official Twitter account on January 11, 2016. The statement asked for respect of his family's privacy during their time of grief. Bowie's death came after a courageous fight against cancer, leaving fans and loved ones to mourn his loss.

site_title: China: Stocks extend world's worst selloff amid growth concern
summary: China's stocks plummeted 5.3% at the close, extending the world's worst selloff this year, amid concerns over the government's efforts to revive the economy. The Shanghai gauge slid for a 46th consecutive month of factory gate deflation, and shares declined even after the yuan gained. The stock market's extreme swings and a sliding yuan have revived concerns over the Communist Party's ability to manage the economy, which is expected to grow at its weakest pace since 1990.

site_title: More RMB volatility seen as central bank takes a back seat
summary: China's renminbi (RMB) is expected to drop further and be more volatile this year due to ongoing downward pressures and the central bank's gradual step back amid financial reforms. The RMB has fallen by over 4% against the dollar since November, with some analysts predicting a drop to 7.1 yuan/USD. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has been buying RMB on both onshore and offshore markets, but is now allowing market forces to play a bigger role in fixing the currency. This shift is seen as a signal that the PBOC is ready to let market forces dictate the RMB's value.

site_title: Australia: Shares stumble as China gloom weighs
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.2% to 4,932.2 on Monday, their worst opening week since 2011, amid concerns about China's financial markets. The S&P/ASX 200 index shed 58.64 points. Early losses were partially offset by late buying of banks and select stocks, but the benchmark still fell to a 2-1/2 year low. The decline follows Wall Street's worst starting week in history.

site_title: China says to impose quota limit on local government debt
summary: China plans to cap the debt local governments can issue, adjusting the quota based on economic performance. The finance ministry will comprehensively evaluate local government debt risks and provide early warnings to those with high debt burdens. This move aims to control the massive local government debt pile, estimated at 15.4 trillion yuan, without hindering municipal investment and growth. China has previously implemented a 1 trillion yuan debt swap programme to help municipalities refinance high-interest debt. The goal is to balance debt control with economic growth.

site_title: Hedge funds greet 2016 by cutting bullish oil bets to 5-year low
summary: Hedge funds cut bullish oil bets to a 5-year low in January 2016, as oil prices tumbled amid a global glut and concerns over an economic slowdown in China. The decline accelerated after Saudi Arabia severed ties with Iran and turmoil in China's markets. Speculators' net-long position in West Texas Intermediate crude fell 24% in the week ended January 5, with longs dropping to a 5-month low and shorts rising. Oil prices dropped 5% to $35.97 a barrel, with crude stockpiles at Cushing, Oklahoma, reaching a record high.

images.alt_text: Money managers began the new year by reducing wagers on rising oil prices to the lowest level in more than five years.

site_title: Lloyds said to maintain 2,000-pound restriction on cash bonuses
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc, Britain's largest mortgage lender, is set to maintain a 2,000-pound restriction on cash bonuses until the UK government sells its shares, which is expected to happen after Chancellor George Osborne sells the remaining 9.2% stake this year. The bank is entering talks with UK Financial Investments Ltd to finalize its compensation plans for 2015, with no final decision made yet. This move aims to reduce bankers' bonuses, which have been a political issue since the government bailed out Lloyds and Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc during the financial crisis.

site_title: Global turmoil darkens path to Bank of England rate increase
summary: The Bank of England is unlikely to raise interest rates in the near future due to global turmoil, including a 12-year low in oil prices and a slowdown in global growth. The World Bank cut its global growth forecasts, and China's yuan devaluation wiped $4 trillion from global equity markets. Economists predict the BOE will keep rates at 0.5% until the third quarter, citing soft inflation and stagnant wage growth. The UK's economic outlook is also uncertain due to the potential Brexit referendum and tensions in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: If Mark Carney made a New Year's resolution to raise UK rates, the rest of the world isn't helping.

site_title: Reality check for Dubai developer's US$20m project
summary: Dubai developer Dubai Holding is revising its US$20 billion Mall of the World project, scaling down its ambitions to three malls built in stages instead of one large shopping center. The new plan aims to generate cash quickly, prioritizing projects that attract tenants and provide income. Despite the challenges of political turmoil, falling oil prices, and declining Dubai home values, regional investors remain interested in Dubai real estate, but international funds are cautious due to development risk. The project's revised plan includes 850,000 square meters of retail space, 35 office buildings, and 8,000 homes, with a focus on reducing congestion and supporting local businesses.

images.alt_text: Big investors nowadays prefer to be involved in realistic projects that generate cash quickly instead of expensive buildings intended to burnish Dubai's international image.

site_title: Singapore reviewing quarterly financial reporting rule
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd is reviewing a 13-year-old rule requiring listed companies to provide quarterly financial reports, amid moves by other regulatory jurisdictions to drop the practice. The rule applies to companies with a market value of at least S$75 million. Proponents argue it instills financial discipline, while opponents claim it encourages "short-termism." The review aims to assess the rule's relevance in today's regulatory landscape, with consultation with the public if necessary.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Ltd is reviewing a 13- year-old rule requiring listed companies to provide quarterly financial reports in light of moves by other regulatory jurisdictions including the UK to drop the practice.

site_title: ADB says global carbon trade could help Southeast Asia
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) says a global carbon trade market could help Southeast Asia combat climate change by allowing countries to buy and sell emissions allowances. The region, which includes Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam, is a major contributor to global greenhouse gas emissions. A global carbon market could benefit Southeast Asia, as it is a net exporter of emissions allowances. The ADB warns that if no steps are taken, the region's GDP could decline by up to 11% by 2100, and countries must meet the Paris climate deal to avoid catastrophic climate change.

images.alt_text: A global carbon trading market could boost Southeast Asia's efforts to combat climate change, the Asian Development Bank said on Monday.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as worries over China linger
summary: European shares declined, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index falling 0.1% near its lowest level in three months, amid lingering concerns over China's economic management. China strengthened its yuan currency for a second session, but failed to calm investor doubts. Consumer inflation remained subdued at 1.6% and producer prices declined 5.9%, fueling global deflation concerns. Despite some sector gains, mining and healthcare stocks, European shares slipped, with Britain's FTSE 100 and Germany's DAX also weakening.

images.alt_text: European shares fell on Thursday following two sessions of gains, with sentiment depressed by continued weakness in oil prices, which briefly dipped below the key $30 level, and worries over global economic growth.

site_title: China's cabinet to have greater financial supervision role: source
summary: China's cabinet is set to take on a greater role in overseeing financial markets, with the State Council establishing a working group to prepare for upgrading its financial department to bureau level. The move comes amid concerns about Beijing's grip on economic policy, with the country's slowest growth in a quarter of a century. A potential merger of banking, insurance, and securities watchdogs into a single 'super-commission' is being considered to restore confidence in markets and ward off financial risks.

site_title: Belgium's tax breaks for multinationals illegal: EU
summary: The European Union has ruled that Belgium's tax breaks for multinationals, including AB InBev and British American Tobacco, were illegal and ordered the companies to return 700 million euros. The EU's competition commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, stated that the tax breaks distorted competition by giving multinationals an unfair advantage over smaller competitors. This decision follows the "Luxleaks" scandal, which revealed tax breaks given to major firms in Luxembourg. The EU has also launched investigations into tax deals with other countries, including Ireland, The Netherlands, and Luxembourg.

site_title: BMW sales growth in 2015 decelerated to slowest pace since 2009
summary: BMW's sales growth in 2015 slowed to the lowest pace since 2009, with deliveries in China increasing only slightly. The company reported a 5.2% increase in sales to 1.9 million autos last year, while Audi's sales rose 3.6% and Mercedes-Benz surged 13% to become the second-largest global luxury car brand. Mercedes-Benz surpassed Audi to top BMW for the first time since 2010, driven by strong sales in China, which rose 33% to 373,459 vehicles.

images.alt_text: Sales of BMW vehicles like the X5 sport utility vehicle and top-of-the-line 7-Series sedan rose at the slowest pace since 2009 as deliveries in China, the world's biggest car market, gained only slightly.

site_title: Game of chicken could result in more than just ruffled feathers
summary: A game of chicken is unfolding between Singapore Airlines (SIA) and minority shareholders of Tiger Airways as SIA's revised offer price of 45 cents per share is met with resistance from long-term shareholders who initially paid 41 cents and later 0.67 cents per share. SIA has waived its 90% control condition and extended the offer closing date to Feb 5, but the slow trickle of acceptances raises the possibility of Tiger remaining listed, which could hinder SIA's restructuring efforts and growth plans.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
A game of chicken is playing out between Singapore Airlines (SIA) and the minority shareholders of Tiger Airways - one which could take the bite out of Tiger's restructuring efforts.

site_title: The Revenant and The Martian take top Golden Globes
summary: The Revenant and The Martian took top honors at the 73rd Golden Globes, with Alejandro Inarritu winning best director for The Revenant and Leonardo DiCaprio winning best drama actor for the film. The Martian also won awards for best comedy actor and best comedy/musical movie. Other winners included Brie Larson for best drama actress and Sylvester Stallone for best supporting film actor. The ceremony, hosted by Ricky Gervais, featured humorous remarks and bleeped-out words, setting the tone for a raucous night.

images.alt_text: Revenge drama The Revenant and space adventure The Martian took the top film awards at Sunday's Golden Globes, setting them up as formidable Oscar contenders after a night of surprises and stinging barbs from return host Ricky Gervais.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees US$20 a barrel oil on US dollar appreciation
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts a potential drop in oil prices to US$20 a barrel due to a rapid appreciation of the US dollar, which could drive prices down 10-25% if the currency gains 5%. A global oil glut has already pushed prices under US$60 a barrel, and the analysts attribute the difference to the US dollar. This prediction comes amid volatility in Chinese markets and a 3.2% increase in the US dollar, which could lead to a decline of 6-15% in oil prices.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley Southeast Asia investment banker Nehchal Khanna is leaving the firm after more than five years, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Property launches in 2015: Blowing hot and cold
summary: A year after its launch in 2015, the Singapore property market continues to experience fluctuations. The US mortgage market saw a reversal in trends, with rates rising after five consecutive weeks of declines. In Singapore, the Q3 condo launch wave will test demand for projects above S$3,000 per square foot. Meanwhile, Manhattan rents have hit a record high, and UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, according to recent market reports.

site_title: China central bank to push forward relending pilot scheme
summary: China's central bank will push forward a relending pilot scheme to support the farming sector and small, micro companies. The scheme, launched in 2014, allows banks to refinance high-quality credit assets. Since its start, the program has lent 4.97 billion yuan to 31 institutions. The relending program aims to address the country's economic growth slowdown and provide relief to struggling businesses.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said on Monday it will push forward a pilot scheme on relending in a bid to support the country's farming sector and small and micro companies.

site_title: Nasdaq suspends currency-trading plans while rivals race ahead
summary: Nasdaq Inc has suspended its foreign-exchange plans due to insufficient customer demand, despite rivals spending billions on platforms to trade currencies. The company had focused on derivatives, but now puts its FX initiative on hold. This decision comes amid increased scrutiny of the currency market and a shift towards more transparent trading. Nasdaq's revenue from FX trading fell to $23 million in the third quarter, leading to the suspension of its foreign-exchange ambitions.

images.alt_text: Nasdaq Inc has put its foreign-exchange ambitions on hold because of a lack of demand from customers, even as its rivals spent about US$1.2 billion last year on platforms to trade the world's biggest asset class.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 20.02 points to close at 1,637.59 on Monday, with 1.91 billion lots valued at RM1.95 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 300-657. The article does not provide a reason for the decline, but it mentions other market news, such as Singapore's 5-day rally and US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Four principles to guide Future Economy panel
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has set four guiding principles for the country's future economic development: investing in people and knowledge, innovation, integration, and internationalization. The 30-member panel, chaired by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, aims to create a sustainable growth model that generates value and opportunities for all. The CFE will focus on five sub-committees, which will meet regularly to develop strategies for driving growth in key sectors and markets. The panel's report is expected to be released later this year, with the goal of positioning Singapore for long-term competitiveness and productivity.

images.alt_text: The four "I"s are what the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) will focus on, said its chairman, Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, after the panel's first meeting on Monday.

site_title: Moody's downgrades M'sian sovereign rating to stable
summary: Moody's Investors Services downgraded Malaysia's sovereign rating outlook to stable, affirming its A3 rating due to deteriorating growth and external credit metrics, high system-wide leverage, and limited fiscal consolidation improvements. The downgrade reflects large capital outflows, a falling current account surplus, and sharp exchange rate depreciation. The stable outlook is expected to be maintained unless there is greater convergence in debt metrics or a worsening of debt dynamics.

images.alt_text: Moody's Investors Services has downgraded the outlook of Malaysia's issued and unsecured bonds to stable from positive but affirmed its A3 rating in a move analysts said was in line with consensus given the tough external challenges ahead.

site_title: US troops put on highest alert for any North Korea provocation
summary: US forces in South Korea were put on their highest alert on January 11, 2016, amid concerns of North Korean provocation following a nuclear test last week. The alert was issued by Commander Curtis Scaparrotti at the Osan Air Base, operated jointly by the US and South Korea. This move comes as tensions between the US and North Korea remain high.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore banks are shifting focus from growth and net interest margins to credit spreads and asset quality due to collapsed commodity prices and possible bankruptcy filings. Moody's and S&P cut Noble Group's credit rating to below investment grade, posing price and default risks. Analysts maintain "negative" views on the sector, with some recommending sells or undervalued stocks like Olam International and Uni-Asia Holdings. Others, such as Triyards Holdings, are buying stocks due to revenue visibility and undervaluation.

images.alt_text: Recent events have shifted focus for Singapore banks from growth and net interest margins to credit spreads and asset quality.

site_title: JPMorgan: Potential capital outflows from China have become "practically boundless"
summary: China has seen nearly $1 trillion in capital leave the nation since 2014, with potential outflows becoming "practically boundless" according to JPMorgan analysts. Capital outflows include foreign direct investment and portfolio instruments, totaling over $3.6 trillion. The People's Bank of China has tapped its war chest of reserves to support the currency, but analysts believe Beijing's ability to defend its currency may be limited due to a "Swiss cheese-like" capital account and onshore demand for dollars.

images.alt_text: China has seen nearly US$1 trillion in capital leave the nation since the second quarter of 2014, and according to analysts at JPMorgan Chase & Co, the sky's the limit for outflows going forward.

site_title: China: Stocks fall 2% on deflation worries, shrug off firmer yuan
summary: China's stocks fell 2% on Monday, defying a firmer yuan, amid growing deflation concerns. The CSI300 index dropped 2.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index fell 2.4%. Deflation risks in China's economy, indicated by December inflation data, and a weakening yuan have caused market instability. Analysts expect further losses, citing the yuan's recent depreciation and slowing economy.

site_title: Five sub-committees formed to oversee Singapore's future
summary: Singapore has formed five sub-committees to oversee its future economy, focusing on sustainable growth that creates value and opportunities for all. The sub-committees, co-chaired by government and private-sector representatives, will explore areas such as corporate capabilities, growth industries, connectivity, city development, and jobs and skills. The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) was announced in December 2015, with Minister Heng Swee Keat at the helm. The goal is to drive Singapore's next stage of economic development and ensure its continued prosperity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down as mainland markets tumble
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 2.8% on Monday, closing at 19,888.50, as mainland markets hit their lowest levels since September. Technology and financial equities led the decline, with Tencent and banking stocks being major movers. The China Enterprises Index dropped 3.9% to 8,505.16 points. Total trading volume was 2.2 billion shares.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's benchmark index bounced off fresh 2-1/2 lows hit after a Wall Street slide on Thursday, paring losses after a sharp rebound in mainland stocks eased the gloom stemming from a tumble in global stocks.

site_title: Iran sees Opec lack of member quotas as contributing to glut
summary: Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh says the lack of individual production quotas within Opec makes it impossible to hold any member accountable for excessive oil production, contributing to a global glut. The absence of formal quotas has led to a third consecutive year of falling Brent crude prices. Iran is poised to boost production and exports as sanctions are lifted, with President Hassan Rouhani predicting an "economic revival" in the coming year. Zanganeh calls on Saudi Arabia and other Opec members to cut production to make room for Iran's expected increase.

images.alt_text: The lack of production quotas for individual Opec members means none can be held accountable if they pump too much crude, according to Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh.

site_title: Thai tourism revenue to hit US$66b in 2016: minister
summary: Thai tourism revenue is forecast to reach 2.4 trillion baht (S$95 billion) in 2016, a 9% increase from last year, driven by increased focus on ASEAN and domestic travelers. Tourism accounts for 10% of Thailand's GDP, a key contributor to the country's economy. The government plans to boost tourism by adding new attractions, increasing flights, and organizing conventions, with a target of 32 million visitors this year, a record high. This growth is expected to help offset a slowdown in exports due to global economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Thai tourism revenue is forecast to grow nearly 9 percent in 2016 to touch 2.4 trillion baht (S$95 billion), the country's tourism minister said on Monday, on the back of increased focus on visitors from the ASEAN region and domestic travellers.

site_title: Eurozone sentiment index falls in January on China worries: Sentix
summary: Eurozone economic sentiment declined to 9.6 in January, the first drop since October, due to concerns over China's economic slowdown. The Sentix research group's index, tracking investor morale, fell short of expectations, with a sub-index of eurozone economic expectations dropping to 6.3. China's economic growth slowdown has unsettled investors, with the yuan's largest fall in five months in early 2016 triggering global market volatility. The eurozone's Germany sub-index also weakened to 18.1, its lowest level since October.

images.alt_text: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls warned on Thursday that it would be a "very bad thing" if Britain left the EU, but warned that British demands cannot be met at any price.

site_title: Sapphire's Ranken wins S$81m Taiyuan rail infrastructure project
summary: Sapphire Corporation's rail engineering specialist, Ranken Infrastructure Limited, has secured an S$81 million contract in Taiyuan City, Shanxi province, China, to design and develop part of the city's first metro line. The 1.6km project, including two tunnels and a station, is expected to be completed within 30 months. The contract brings the total value of new orders to RMB1.3 billion, with the new orders expected to positively impact Sapphire's earnings per share and net asset value per share for 2016 and 2017.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy formed five sub-committees to oversee the country's future. SIA made an unconditional offer for Tiger Airways, and Olam International acquired Nigerian wheat milling assets for $275 million. The Singapore judiciary plans to enhance cross-border insolvency arrangements. The Shanghai stock gauge fell 5.3% amid concerns over China's growth, while Singapore shares dropped 42 points, or 1.5%, to close at 2,708.85.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has made its S$0.45-per-share takeover offer for Tiger Airways unconditional, it said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Monday morning.

site_title: Trafigura appoints Tan Chin Hwee as Asia-Pacific CEO
summary: Trafigura has appointed Tan Chin Hwee, a 45-year-old Singaporean, as its Asia-Pacific CEO, marking the first time an Asian has held a senior management position at the global commodity trader. Tan previously worked at Apollo Global Management and Amaranth Advisors, and was courted by Trafigura to drive its growth in the region after he expressed a desire to retire. His appointment follows Trafigura's relocation of its global headquarters to Singapore in 2012.

site_title: 47% ramp-up in data centre supply set to dampen rents
summary: A 46.6% increase in data centre supply in Singapore by the end of 2016 is expected to dampen rents, but Cushman & Wakefield predicts a bottoming out next year due to sustained demand from technology and network-content companies. The average DC occupancy rate is around 70%, and demand is expected to remain strong, with annual absorption growing at a compounded annual rate of 28% since 2008.

images.alt_text: A ramp-up in supply of data centres (DCs) in Singapore by a whopping 46.6 per cent of the total current stock by megawatt (MW) by the end of this year islandwide is expected to dampen rents in the near term.

site_title: Moody's cuts Malaysia's sovereign rating outlook due to growth risks
