summary: Noble Group's shares and bonds plummeted after being downgraded to junk status by a second rating agency. The firm remains on credit watch and may face higher borrowing costs with banks. Analysts warn that the worst may not be over, with potential further cuts to the credit rating.

site_title: Samsung offers a glimpse of 2016's tech slowdown
summary: Samsung reported a disappointing fourth-quarter operating profit of 6.1 trillion won ($7.3 billion), below expectations, due to weaker demand for its gadgets. Falling prices and overcapacity in chips and television displays are also factors. The company's smartphone division is likely to see a 30% drop in operating profit due to lower prices. This slowdown in demand is a preview of this year's tech slowdown, according to Samsung.

site_title: Poly grads' pay up 5% in 2015 after 2 flat years
summary: Polytechnic graduates in Singapore saw a 5% increase in median gross monthly salaries to S$2,100 in 2015, ending two years of stagnation. This growth follows the 2013 and 2014 median salaries of S$2,000. Despite the salary rise, fewer graduates opted for full-time jobs, with a smaller proportion choosing employment.

site_title: 2016 home improvement
summary: Industry experts predict that the color Monarch Gold, a gold-influenced ochre, will dominate home color schemes in 2016, offering opulence without being over the top. Paint companies, such as Dulux Paint, recommend this shade to attract attention while combining well with other tones.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: China poised to solve its real estate inventory problem: JPMorgan
summary: China's real estate market is expected to recover from its inventory problem, according to JPMorgan analyst. Despite a 35% decline in the China Developers Index from its 2015 peak, the sector began outperforming the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index in the final two months of 2015. This trend may continue as China addresses its inventory issue, potentially stabilizing the market.

site_title: Saudi Arabia considers IPO for Aramco: report
summary: Saudi Arabia is considering issuing shares in state-owned oil giant Saudi Aramco, according to Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. This decision is likely to be made within the next few months. The move comes after the country posted a record budget deficit due to falling oil prices. The IPO would be a significant step towards diversifying Saudi Arabia's economy.

site_title: Pieces to have this year
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

This year's top home decor and furniture pieces include marble accessories, copper lamps, and unique designs from brands like Hiromatsu and FLOS. The "Guppy Love" resin piece by artist Cheok Keng Lye is also a highlight, featuring aquatic worlds made of paint and resin. Other notable pieces include the Grip side chair, Maxdesign Offset Shelf, and the Munkii Wang Lounge Chair, showcasing a mix of traditional and modern styles. These items can be found at various stores and galleries in Singapore, offering a range of options for those looking to upgrade their home decor.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US meets tech leaders, forms task force to fight online militants
summary: The US government has formed a task force to counter online propaganda, following a meeting with tech industry leaders in Silicon Valley. The meeting, led by White House Chief of Staff Denis McDonough, aimed to improve cooperation between the tech industry and the intelligence community. This comes after a rift between the two following Edward Snowden's disclosures about government surveillance. The task force is part of the Obama administration's efforts to combat the use of the internet by online militants.

site_title: New diet rules would take 20% bite out of US sugar use
summary: The US government has issued new dietary guidelines suggesting Americans limit added sugar consumption to less than 10% of a recommended daily intake of 2,000 calories, a 20% reduction in sugar use. This move aims to combat negative health effects associated with excessive sugar consumption. The guidelines are the latest blow to the sugar industry, which has faced criticism over its impact on public health.

site_title: China December inflation quickens to 1.6% year-on-year, meeting forecasts
summary: China's consumer inflation quickened to 1.6% year-on-year in December, meeting market expectations. The producer price index remained unchanged at -5.9% in the same month. This inflation rate is a slight increase from the previous month's 1.5%. The data suggests the Chinese economy is showing signs of stability, but may face pressure from slowing growth.

site_title: Wall Street stocks start 2016 on weak note
summary: US stocks started 2016 on a weak note, falling 4.2% in the last five sessions due to global threats and corporate weakness. Investors remain cautious amid international uncertainties, including a weakening China and geopolitical tensions. Shares are considered pricey, and investors are sticking to the sidelines for now, with little reason for optimism.

site_title: S'pore banks to partner Chongqing government, Chinese lenders
summary: Singapore banks have partnered with the Chongqing government and Chinese lenders to promote cross-border trade and investment between Chongqing and Southeast Asia, including Singapore. DBS has also formed ties with Chinese banks and financial institutions.

site_title: Scandal-hit VW posts first full-year sales drop since 2002
summary: Volkswagen reported its first full-year sales drop since 2002, with 5.82 million vehicles sold, a 5% decline from the previous year. The company's overall VW group sales, including brands Audi, Porsche, and Skoda, fell 2% to 9.93 million units. This marks the first decline since 2002. The decline is attributed to the company's struggles to recover from the massive pollution cheating scandal.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification as investors seek alternative safe-haven assets. A low-profile property trust is investing in data centers, and Ant, backed by Jack Ma, plans to add a stablecoin to its global network. Meanwhile, Amundi predicts massive growth in retail investors driving ETFs in Asia and Europe, and the S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the trade war may be ending. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarization is shifting safe-haven assets.

site_title: US dollar gets short-lived bounce from jobs report
summary: The US dollar initially rose after a strong jobs report, with 292,000 new positions added in December, but then remained little-changed as wage gains were deemed too low. The report marked the second-biggest annual gain since the 1990s. Market volatility continued due to concerns over global growth, China's slowdown, and falling oil prices.

site_title: Twitter slumps to all-time low as product changes loom
summary: Twitter's shares have fallen to an all-time low of $19.98, a 1.4% drop, after disappointing investors with slowing user growth and sales. Since its 2013 IPO, the company's stock has declined 35% in 2015. Despite CEO Jack Dorsey's efforts to improve products, the decline comes amid a worsening US equity market, which suffered its worst week since 2011.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire Lippo Mall Kuta in Bali for 800 billion rupiah (S$81.6 million). The total estimated cost, including acquisition fees and value-added tax, is S$92.7 million. This acquisition marks a significant move for the trust.

site_title: Yahoo said to reconsider sale of web business instead of spinoff
summary: Yahoo is reassessing its plans to sell its main internet business, considering both a sale and a spinoff. The company has shifted its thinking due to an expected proxy fight by an activist investor and has not yet concluded it needs to sell. No official process or potential buyers have been contacted, but internal thinking has changed. A final decision has not been made, and no bank has been hired to run an official sale process.

site_title: Europe: Stocks suffer worst week of losses in more than four years
summary: European stocks suffered their worst week of losses in over four years, falling 1.5% on Friday, resulting in a 7% weekly loss. This marked the worst weekly performance since August 2011 during the euro zone's sovereign debt crisis. The decline was attributed to lingering worries about China, causing concerns in the region.

site_title: Shutting down markets to stem panic is often the wrong medicine
summary: China's new trading "circuit breaker" mechanism, intended to limit market volatility, proved counter-productive, triggering panic selling and deepening slumps on the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges. The mechanism, which includes 15-minute trading halts at 5% and 7% drops, was suspended after two instances of triggering, with regulators citing a negative effect outweighing the positive one. Analysts say the problem lies in the market's immaturity, with individual investors prone to panic selling, and that authorities should use pauses to actively soothe investor nerves rather than simply shutting down markets.

site_title: Beijing's devaluation seen as means to fully liberalise yuan
summary: Beijing has devalued the yuan by 0.5% to 6.5646 to the US dollar, seen as a step towards fully liberalizing the currency and boosting growth. The move aims to calm nerves and reduce pressure from outflows, allowing the central bank to cut interest rates. Analysts say it's a three-step process, with the yuan expected to continue depreciating towards a freely traded currency by 2020. The devaluation is part of Beijing's efforts to meet its economic growth target of 7% and address market concerns.

site_title: Lenovo's new smartphone can map your room, show you the way
summary: Lenovo has unveiled a smartphone incorporating Google's 3D-scanning technology, Project Tango, allowing it to map and display its surroundings. The device will be the first to use this technology, which superimposes digital information onto real-world displays. This innovation marks Lenovo's entry into using Alphabet's Tango technology, providing a new way for smartphones to interact with their environment.

site_title: Diversification backs revenue but dents profit at Triyards
summary: Triyards Holdings, a subsidiary of Ezra Holdings, reported a 38% increase in Q1 revenue to US$78.1 million, driven by diversification beyond the oil price-linked offshore & marine sector. However, net profit declined 25% to US$6.2 million due to lower gross profit margins and the absence of a one-time gain, resulting in earnings per share down to 1.9 US cents from 2.61 US cents last year.

site_title: Facebook Messenger has over 800m users a month
summary: Facebook's Messenger application has surpassed 800 million monthly users, with the platform continuing to develop new features to attract more users. The company aims to make Messenger the best place for communication with businesses and people worldwide. Improvements include speed, photo sending, video calling, customer service, and money transfer capabilities. Facebook is also testing its 'M' digital virtual assistant and partnering with Uber to integrate transportation services into the app. Plans for this year include expanding business and service interactions, e-commerce, and travel industries.

site_title: Hotpot indulgence
summary: High-end steamboat restaurants are emerging in Singapore, offering luxurious options to cater to a more sophisticated crowd. Establishments like Tang Restaurant Bar and Supper Club and Hua Ting Steamboat have joined the market, providing comfortable surroundings and premium ingredients. These restaurants offer unique features such as pre-cooked ingredients and specialty broths, setting them apart from traditional steamboat restaurants. The steamboat dining scene is becoming increasingly competitive, with establishments aiming to take it to a new level and attract a wider range of customers.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: New technology puts health care in the palm of your hand
summary: New wearable sensors and smartphone-enabled technology are revolutionizing healthcare, allowing for "virtual checkups" and treating various ailments. French-based VisioMed introduced a health management suite with a smartphone app that monitors blood pressure, glucose, and oxygen levels, and provides potential diagnoses and connects users to doctors. MedWand, a US$250 hand-held device, measures temperature, heart rate, and oxygen levels, and includes a camera for online exams. Other startups, such as Omron and iTens, are introducing wearable devices for continuous monitoring and pain treatment.

site_title: China woes drag STI 4.5% lower in 1st week of 2016
summary: China's stock market woes contributed to a 4.5% decline in the Singapore Stock Index (STI) in the first week of 2016, with global equities also suffering losses. China's regulatory attempts to stem the bleeding in its stock markets were deemed ineffective, with circuit breakers removed just days after being installed. However, a spike in volume mid-week provided some consolation for Singapore market players, with turnover reaching S$1.6 billion. The decline in China's stock market has raised concerns about the country's GDP growth, which is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Revving up for 2016
summary: The Singapore Motorshow 2016 is set to take place from January 14-17, featuring a slew of new models, mostly from Japanese manufacturers. Key launches include the Suzuki Vitara, Lexus GS F, Renault Kadjar, Honda Legend, Nissan Pulsar, and Mazda CX-3. Other notable models include the Toyota Hilux, Toyota Prius, Audi A4, and the upcoming MG ZS Hybrid+. The event is expected to attract replacement buyers due to the expanding COE quota.

site_title: New association minted for real estate agents
summary: A new association called the Singapore Estate Agents Association (SEAA) is set to be launched by the first quarter of 2016 to raise professionalism in real estate agency work and provide a unified voice for agencies and their salespersons. SEAA has been registered as a society with the Council of Estate Agencies (CEA) and aims to enhance industry standards. This industry-led initiative seeks to promote a higher level of professionalism in the real estate sector in Singapore.

site_title: As January goes, let's not bet on that yet
summary: The January barometer, a stock market predictor developed by Yale Hirsch, has been accurate 87.7% of the time since 1950, suggesting a correlation between January's stock performance and the full-year market trend. However, experts argue that this may be due to the reaction of traders and analysts to new political agendas emerging in January, rather than a causal link. The stock market tends to rise more often than it falls, and using January to predict the full-year outcome biases the prediction. The accuracy of the January barometer may be due to chance, with a 50% success rate in recent years comparable to a coin toss.

site_title: Europe faces confidence test as borderless ideal fades
summary: Europe is facing a confidence test as borderless travel within the Schengen zone becomes increasingly restricted, raising concerns about the economic impact on trade and the eurozone. Denmark's temporary border controls, coupled with similar measures in Sweden and Germany, may signal a shift away from the free movement of people and labor, which is a cornerstone of the Schengen Agreement. Analysts warn that this could lead to a decrease in labor mobility, potentially hindering economic growth and investment, and may even undermine investor confidence in the eurozone.

site_title: Shale explorers pump oil on the cheap from slumbering US wells
summary: US shale explorers will bring new supply to the market this year by completing thousands of mothballed wells, despite idle rigs and cut drilling budgets. Companies like Exxon Mobil and EOG Resources have 3,994 wells with active permits that were not completed as of December. Finishing these wells will reduce costs for these companies, allowing them to maintain output without new drilling expenses. However, overall US output is expected to decline this year due to reduced drilling in other regions, with production falling 570,000 barrels a day.

site_title: Europe commercial property sales may slow
summary: Europe's commercial property sales may slow in 2016 due to concerns over high prices and shrinking demand from Asian and Middle East investors. Knight Frank LLP predicts a little change in the value of commercial property sales this year, following a 20% rise in 2015. Rising interest rates and concerns that prices have climbed too far are potential headwinds for the market. Despite this, European commercial properties still offer higher returns than bonds, with yields of 4% for well-maintained office buildings.

site_title: Luxury hostel Adler ready to expand footprint
summary: Adler Hostel, Singapore's first luxury hostel, is expanding its footprint with plans to enter Japanese and Australian markets through management contracts. After a year of S$1 million expansion, the hostel aims to fine-tune its operations in Singapore and establish a bar. Founder Adler Poh aims to recoup his investments within five years, despite increased competition from other luxury hostels and platforms like Airbnb. With occupancy rates ranging from 60-70%, Poh plans to boost marketing efforts and establish a bar to raise awareness and attract guests.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Robert Baldwin, who transformed Morgan Stanley, dies at 95
summary: Robert Baldwin, who transformed Morgan Stanley from a staid old investment bank into a modern financial services corporation, died at 95. As president from 1973 to 1982 and chairman until 1983, Baldwin expanded the firm into a full-service financial brokerage, changing its culture from exclusive services for blue-chip clients to a more competitive environment. He adapted to new regulations, hired traders, and established offices in Europe and Asia, but historians say the cost was the firm's soul. Baldwin's legacy is a testament to his force and clear vision, but also criticized for politicizing the firm.

site_title: Renaissance city Yangon
summary: Yangon, the capital of Myanmar, is undergoing a renaissance despite its dusty, potholed roads and antiquated infrastructure. The city's resilience and willingness to adapt are exemplified by its rapid transformation, with investment pouring in and new developments emerging. The country's first KFC outlet has opened, and luxury hotels like the Sedona Hotel Yangon are being built. With a growing tourism industry, Yangon is expected to reach 7.5 million visitors by 2020, driven by first-adopter tourism in Southeast Asia. The city's unique blend of traditional and modern elements has created a captivating atmosphere, with locals embracing change with a mix of humor and confidence.

site_title: Appetite for apps
summary: Food apps have emerged to guide users to the best meal deals and eateries, but many deals come with caveats and fine print. Despite this, several apps have caught attention, including Thevar 2.0, which offers mod-Indian cuisine, and The Social Kitchen, which sets up shop at Bank of Singapore. These apps aim to simplify the process of finding affordable and high-quality dining options, but the reality is that many deals are short-lived or have hidden conditions.

site_title: Hollywood awards season kicks off with Golden Globes
summary: The 2016 Golden Globes kick off Hollywood's awards season with a show promising suspense and cheeky humor, hosted by British comedian Ricky Gervais. The event is seen as a strong indicator of Oscar glory, with 75% of past winners also taking home Oscars. Spotlight, starring Leonardo DiCaprio, is the frontrunner for best drama, while The Big Short is the top contender for best comedy. DiCaprio is heavily favored to win best actor in a drama, with all 17 GoldDerby experts predicting his win.

site_title: Creating connections through tourism
summary: Singapore and New Zealand strengthened their 50-year partnership in 2015, with tourism playing a key role in driving two-way economic growth and cultural exchange. Record 48,000 Singaporeans visited New Zealand in 2015, while 80,000 Kiwis traveled to Singapore. Tourists are now seeking off-the-beaten-track experiences, with 58.4% visiting cities and towns outside main centers. To encourage tourism, New Zealand has made it easier for international travelers, with minimal visa costs and code-share flights. The partnership is expected to continue growing, with tourism remaining a vital component of the relationship.

site_title: Global stocks recover after China scraps trading curbs
summary: Global stocks recovered on Friday after China removed trading curbs, which had caused volatility in Asian markets earlier in the week. European shares rebounded, with the FTSE 100 up 0.5% and the DAX 30 climbing 0.6%. Asian markets, however, remained volatile, with Shanghai's main index closing up 2% but losing about 10% of its value for the week. The US employment report, overshadowed by China's economic concerns, saw no significant impact on markets.

site_title: Roadmap to a healthy 2016
summary: A new year offers a roadmap to better health through weight loss, exercise, cholesterol control, blood pressure optimization, and supplement management. Losing excess weight requires a combination of dietary measures and exercise, with new medication options available for diabetics. Exercise in moderation, rather than excessive intensity, is recommended, and statins and PCSK-9 inhibitors can effectively lower bad cholesterol. Optimizing blood pressure through medication can reduce cardiovascular risk, while avoiding calcium supplements and focusing on Vitamin D can help prevent heart disease. By following these tips, individuals can set themselves on the path to a healthier 2016.

site_title: December payrolls surge in boost to economic outlook
summary: US job growth surged in December with a 292,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls, exceeding expectations. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5% despite more people entering the labor force. This suggests a temporary slowdown in economic growth, contrary to recent manufacturing-led concerns. The revised employment numbers for the prior two months also showed a sharp increase.

site_title: Mining's US$1.4 trillion plunge exceeds total market value of Apple, Google, Exxon
summary: The US$1.4 trillion decline in global mining stocks since 2011 surpasses the total market value of Apple, Google, and Exxon. This downturn is largely attributed to China's unrelenting impact, with investors anticipating a prolonged decline. The Bloomberg World Mining Index reached an 11-year low, reflecting investor concerns.

site_title: Noble's lenders matter more than its credit score
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based energy and metals trader, has faced a downgrade to "junk" status by Standard & Poor's, despite raising US$750 million from a sale of its agricultural affiliate. The downgrade led to a 5.8% drop in Noble's shares, but lenders remain supportive. This move is a blow to the company's market value, which has crashed to US$1.5 billion from US$5.6 billion in a year. Accounting concerns and the commodity rout have already weakened Noble, making lenders' continued support a key factor.

site_title: Norway's oil fund reviews equity weighting
summary: Norway's Finance Ministry has appointed experts to evaluate the country's US$818 billion oil fund's equity weighting. The fund, the world's largest, currently invests about 60% of its assets in stocks. The review aims to determine the optimal balance between stocks and other investments, with the goal of maximizing returns. The move comes as global economic uncertainty increases, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. The review's outcome will have significant implications for Norway's sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Boeing orders fall by half in 2015 but deliveries hit record
summary: Boeing reported a 48% decrease in net orders for commercial aircraft in 2015 to 768, but delivered a record 762 aircraft, surpassing its forecast. The company's backlog of orders stood at 5,795, representing over seven-and-a-half years of production. Despite Airbus' expected net orders of over 1,000, Boeing's delivery record and healthy passenger growth in the airline industry are expected to boost its earnings. Boeing Commercial Airplanes president Ray Conner attributed the success to a "solid year of orders" and a "steady stream of deliveries" for years to come.

site_title: 'Not a bad thing' for Singaporeans to be in demand abroad: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said it's not a bad thing for Singaporeans to be in demand abroad, allowing them to gain experience and ideas before potentially returning to contribute to the country. This attitude is part of being a global community, and Singapore should accept that its talent will be distributed globally. Lee emphasized the importance of retaining and attracting talent, noting that Singapore needs to create opportunities and a sense of excitement to encourage its people to return.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Colliers Singapore's senior executives for industrial services quit
summary: Colliers International Singapore has lost several senior executives, including division head Tan Boon Leong, who are joining Knight Frank Singapore. Tan and three other executives will form the new industrial department at Knight Frank, increasing the team to 11 executives. This follows recent departures, including five industrial brokers who joined CBRE last June and a team of valuers who moved to Savills Singapore in September. The losses leave Colliers with only two industrial brokers, while Knight Frank's team will significantly expand its presence in the market.

site_title: China says will further liberalise interest rates: PBOC
summary: China's central bank announced plans to further liberalize interest rates and make the yuan more international. The bank also pledged to maintain prudent monetary policy and deepen reforms of the foreign exchange management system. To support the economy, it will use medium-term loans and supplementary loans. The move is expected to help keep liquidity in the banking system.

site_title: Record S$19b set aside for R&D until 2020
summary: Singapore has set aside a record S$19 billion for research, innovation, and enterprise (RIE) activities from 2016 to 2020, accounting for 1% of the country's GDP. This is an 18% increase from the previous plan, with a focus on competitive and open funding, now at 40%. The government aims to sustain this spending, while also encouraging private sector investment in R&D, which currently stands at 1.5% of GDP.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Between the devil and the deep sea
summary: China faces a dilemma as North Korea openly challenges its leading benefactor by claiming a miniature hydrogen bomb test, defying China's explicit advice against further nuclear tests. Despite annoyance, China is unlikely to punish North Korea due to its long-term strategic interests. China will summon the North Korean ambassador to lodge a formal protest, but its dependence on North Korea for food and energy shortages limits its ability to take drastic action. China's relations with North Korea are driven by history and geopolitics, making a clean break unlikely, and it is expected to continue supporting Pyongyang as long as it doesn't deviate significantly from the status quo.

site_title: Samsung's operating profit rises 15%, a sharp slowdown
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 15% increase in operating profit, but this slowdown is attributed to global weakness in demand for electronics. Despite efforts to diversify by using components such as chips and screens, prices for these items have recently dropped, hindering the company's recovery. The results indicate Samsung's vulnerability to global market fluctuations.

site_title: China regulator orders some banks to limit January dollar buying: sources
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator has ordered banks in major import and export centers to limit US dollar purchases in January, aiming to stem capital outflows. This move comes after China reported its largest annual drop in foreign exchange reserves and a sharp slide in the yuan to multi-year lows. The regulator's attempt to control capital flight and stabilize global markets follows a record-low yuan value.

site_title: German, French industrial production down slightly in November
summary: German and French industrial production declined in November, with factory output in Germany contracting 0.3% and in France slipping 0.9%. The declines were attributed to weak manufacturing activity in Germany and falling output in France's energy, water, and extractive industries.

site_title: EU clears FedEx takeover of TNT
summary: The European Commission has cleared FedEx's $4.8 billion acquisition of TNT Express, a Dutch logistics company. The deal was investigated due to concerns it could lead to higher prices for consumers, but the Commission concluded that the merged entity would face sufficient competition from rival companies. EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager stated that European consumers will not be adversely affected by the transaction, and the deal was approved unconditionally.

site_title: ABN Amro sees oil prices lower for longer
summary: ABN Amro has cut its oil price forecasts, citing oversupply and lower prices for longer. The bank now expects Brent and WTI prices to be around $50 per barrel in 2016, down from $65 and $60 previously. Senior energy economist Hans van Cleef attributed the cut to ongoing high volatility in oil prices due to US crude inventories, geopolitical tensions, and Opec policy. Despite this, ABN Amro still expects moderate price appreciation in 2016 due to economic expansion in the US, Europe, and Asia.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after upbeat jobs data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by Chinese stocks' recovery, rising oil prices, and strong hiring data in the US. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 54.58 points, the S&P 500 gained 7.7 points, and the Nasdaq composite added 33.94 points. The jobs data showed hiring surged in December, contributing to the market's upbeat tone.

site_title: London fails EU annual pollution limits
summary: London failed to meet EU annual air pollution limits just eight days into 2016, with 19 instances of nitrogen dioxide exceeding the limit of 200 micrograms per cubic metre. This is the 19th consecutive year the city has breached EU rules, posing a health risk to its 8.5 million inhabitants. The UK government faces potential EU fines of hundreds of millions of pounds.

site_title: Senior execs leave Colliers for Knight Frank
summary: Senior executives at Colliers International Singapore, including division head Tan Boon Leong and three others, are leaving for rival firm Knight Frank Singapore. The team, which will increase to 11 executives, will be led by Tan after a two-month gardening leave period. This marks the latest exodus of executives from Colliers, following recent departures to CBRE and Savills. Colliers' industrial services division has been deemed "non-performing" and will be rebuilt by Michael Bowens, who will maintain client relationships.

images.alt_text: The exodus of executives at Colliers International Singapore has continued this week. This time, senior executives in its industrial services team including the division head are leaving for a rival firm.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower for the week on rout in China
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.5% for the week, marking a fifth consecutive decline, due to the global rout in equities triggered by China's stock market woes. Despite a brief rebound on Friday, the index closed at 2,751.23. Regulatory ineptitude in China, such as the removal of circuit breakers, contributed to the contagion selling. However, a rise in the yuan and short-covering in the region helped stabilize the market. The STI still lost 131 points for the week.

images.alt_text: TO say it hasn't been a good start to 2016 might be an understatement, given the plunges global equities have suffered this past week. China has been blamed for the losses, perhaps a convenient scapegoat for overvaluation of risk assets rooted in the easy money policies pursued by major central banks for several years now, starting with the US Federal Reserve and adopted by the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan.

site_title: Chinese firms step up dollar debt redemptions as yuan weakens
summary: Chinese companies are stepping up dollar debt redemptions amid the weakening yuan, with companies like China SCE Property Holdings and SUNAC China Holdings planning early repayments of their dollar-denominated loans and bonds. The expected yuan depreciation over the next few years is expected to push more companies to reduce their exposure to dollar debt. Many Chinese companies have sold dollar-denominated bonds with call options, allowing them to redeem bonds early, and some are now doing so to reduce their debt exposure and hedging costs. The yuan's record yearly loss against the dollar and high volatility are driving companies to adjust their debt structure.

images.alt_text: A renewed plunge in Chinese stock markets has stoked concerns among global investors about the health of the world's second-biggest economy, but there is little evidence that the outlook for China has darkened dramatically in recent weeks.

site_title: Weak US wholesale inventories point to slower Q4 growth
summary: US wholesale inventories fell 0.3% in November, beating expectations, indicating a moderation in economic growth in the fourth quarter. The decline in inventories, which are a key component of GDP, suggests businesses are reducing stockpiles of unsold goods. This, combined with weak data on construction spending and export growth, is likely to lead to further revisions of GDP growth estimates, potentially lowering them from 0.4-1.1% to 0.4% or lower.

images.alt_text: US wholesale inventories fell more than expected in November amid a push by businesses to reduce a stockpile of unsold goods, the latest indication that economic growth moderated sharply in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Albedo raises S$3m to ratchet up its extreme makeover
summary: Albedo, a Catalist-listed firm, is raising S$3 million through a proposed share placement to fund its extreme makeover and tap the medical aesthetics market in China. The firm, which was previously undeterred by a botched reverse takeover, has appointed a Shanghai-based businessman, Frankie Kiow, as a majority owner with a 9.84% stake. Albedo plans to bring Taiwanese medical experts to China, open a clinic in Qingdao, and roll out a 300-bed haemodialysis hospital. The company aims to expand into community clinics specializing in elderly care, but will do so step by step.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: German industrial output falls unexpectedly as China slows down
summary: German industrial output unexpectedly fell 0.3% in November, led by a 3.3% slump in investment goods, as a slowdown in emerging markets like China and Brazil may weigh on economic growth. French industrial production also declined 0.9%. Despite concerns, the Bundesbank remains confident in Germany's economic recovery, citing robust private consumption and global trade. China's economy is expected to slow to 6.3% this year, and German exporters are shifting focus to recovering economies like the US.

site_title: VW to unveil new SUV in electric-car push to win back US buyers
summary: Volkswagen plans to unveil a battery-powered SUV version of its Tiguan at the Detroit auto show, as part of its efforts to regain US market share. The Tiguan plug-in hybrid is expected to hit US dealerships after the release of a new midsize crossover and long-wheelbase Tiguan next year. VW aims to expand its electric offerings and meet US emissions regulations, following its diesel emissions scandal. The company plans to launch 20 battery-powered or plug-in hybrid vehicles by 2020 and increase its US sales to 507,794 cars by 2020.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen will unveil a battery-powered SUV at the Detroit auto show on Monday, according to company sources, part of a push into electric vehicles as it seeks to win back US buyers following its emissions test cheating scandal.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: OCBC Bank announced its new CEO, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. The bank's latest earnings data is not mentioned in the article. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are collaborating on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release. CGS Investment Research downgraded Grab's rating to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth in the second half.

site_title: Mao Ze-gone as giant statue of Communist leader 'demolished'
summary: A 37-meter gold-painted statue of Mao Zedong, China's founding father, has been demolished in Henan province, apparently due to a lack of government approval. The 3 million yuan ($460,000) structure, which was completed in December, was funded by local entrepreneurs and sparked controversy online due to its location, which coincides with the site of a devastating famine under Mao's rule. The demolition is seen as an effort by the Communist Party to control public discussion of history and maintain its support.

images.alt_text: A gargantuan gold-painted statue of Communist China's founding father Mao Zedong has suddenly been demolished, apparently for lacking government approval, state media said Friday, days after images of it went viral.

site_title: RMB slide expected to end soon, despite Japanese minister's fears
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso warned of further falls in the Chinese renminbi, citing China's sharp decline in foreign exchange reserves, but analysts say the currency may have stabilized at around 6.50 to the dollar. China's reserves fell by $512.66 billion in 2015, with the RMB experiencing a rapid slide despite the People's Bank of China guiding its RMB fixing rate to a slightly higher level. Some experts believe the yuan may continue to depreciate, while others think it has reached a stable level.

images.alt_text: Japan's finance minister Taro Aso on Friday warned indirectly of further falls to the Chinese renminbi, though the rapid slide the currency has experienced so far this year has slowed in response to the People's Bank of China (PBOC) guiding its RMB fixing rate to a slightly higher level during the day.

site_title: Payrolls in US rise more than projected, jobless rate at 5%
summary: US payrolls surged 292,000 in December, exceeding forecasts and marking the second-best year for American workers since 1999. The jobless rate remained at 5% while wage growth rose less than expected. The resilient job market has prompted the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, with Fed policymakers citing tighter labor conditions as a key factor. Despite broad hiring gains, worker pay has yet to show a sustainable pickup, with average hourly earnings unchanged from the prior month.

images.alt_text: Payroll growth surged in December, capping the second-best year for American workers since 1999 and further evidence of a resilient job market that prompted the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.

site_title: Albedo raises S$3m via placement to expand in China
summary: Albedo, a Catalist-listed company, plans to raise S$3 million through a share placement exercise. The placement involves 300 million shares priced at one Singapore cent to Frankie Kiow, a Shanghai-based businessman. The funds will be used for growth and expansion, with up to 70% allocated to these purposes. This follows Albedo's transformation from a metal trading business to one providing medical aesthetics and healthcare services, including its recent S$19 million purchase of a stake in China iMyth Company.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Barclays to close most of Asia-Pacific cash equities business: sources
summary: Barclays plans to close most of its cash equities business in the Asia-Pacific region, part of a broader effort to eliminate 50% of jobs at its wider equities unit in the region. The move is attributed to the slowing Chinese economy and the non-profitability of the Asia securities operations. The bank's Asia-Pacific operations generated £776 million in revenue in 2014, but will likely be reduced due to rising costs and tougher capital requirements. Barclays' CEO Jes Staley aims to refocus the business on the UK and US.

images.alt_text: NEAR EXIT: The closure of most of the cash equities business is part of Barclays' plans to eliminate 50 per cent of jobs at the wider equities unit in the region.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch higher as Chinese stocks rebound
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Friday, signaling a possible stabilization after a sell-off this week, as Chinese stocks rebounded after Beijing axed its circuit breaker mechanism. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index was on track for its steepest weekly drop since late August. Mining stocks led the rebound, benefiting from the easing of market volatility and China's influence on the global metals market.

site_title: Budget to be revised soon, GST a saviour: Najib
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak confirmed the country's 2016 budget will be revised due to a revenue shortfall stemming from low oil prices. The current revenue shortfall is estimated at RM30 billion, which could widen to RM39 billion if oil prices remain low. The implementation of the 6% Goods and Services Tax (GST) is seen as a savior, expected to rake in RM39 billion this year. Najib attributed the fiscal deficit target of 3.1% of GDP to the GST, despite criticism from many who blame the unpopular tax for price increases.

images.alt_text: MR NAJIB: Feels the fiscal deficit target of 3.1% GDP could still be met.

site_title: M&S's shrinking fashion share gives new boss familiar challenge
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) has appointed a new CEO, Steve Rowe, to address its struggling fashion sales. Under Rowe's predecessor, Marc Bolland, M&S's share of the UK apparel market declined from 12% to less than 10%. Rowe, a company veteran, aims to balance younger customers with middle-aged women who have relied on M&S for decades. Analysts suggest he should cut prices, improve product quality, and invest in stores to rejuvenate the brand. M&S's leadership change is seen as a step to change the company's mindset and regain market share.

images.alt_text: WORKING HIS WAY UP: Mr Rowe is a company veteran who started stacking shelves as a teenager.

site_title: Battle of the boxes
summary: A growing number of subscription services are catering to consumers who prefer not to shop online or physically visit stores. These services deliver essentials and surprises to customers on a regular basis, often with a focus on necessities like feminine hygiene products, razors, and gourmet meals. Companies like Blissybox, Shave It Club, and Lowinsky offer customized boxes based on customers' preferences, while others, such as Pint Society and Infusion de Vie, specialize in unique products like ice cream and rare teas. However, the subscription box model can be challenging, with concerns about sourcing products, managing inventory, and maintaining customer satisfaction.

images.alt_text: THINKING OUT OF THE BOX: Fashion box service Lowinsky (above) is for the trendsetting female shopper, and aims to customise a selection of apparel and accessories for its subscribers every month through its in-house team of buyers, stylists and proprietary algorithms.

THINKING OUT OF THE BOX: Fashion box service Lowinsky (above) is for the trendsetting female shopper, and aims to customise a selection of apparel and accessories for its subscribers every month through its in-house team of buyers, stylists and proprietary algorithms.

THINKING OUT OF THE BOX: Fashion box service Lowinsky (above) is for the trendsetting female shopper, and aims to customise a selection of apparel and accessories for its subscribers every month through its in-house team of buyers, stylists and proprietary algorithms.

'What sets Blissybox apart is that we are the only subscription box in Asia providing feminine hygiene products - something that all menstruating women are in need of every month. It's not as glamorous as some other subscription services, but it serves an already (naturally) established need.' - Anna Karlsson (above), founder of Blissybox

NOT FEELING BOXED IN: Blissybox offers a wide range of feminine hygiene products from familiar brands such as Kotex, Whisper and Tampax to organic tampons and pads by Natracare. It also includes other surprises in each box such as sachets of Woman's Moon Cycle Tea by Oregon-based tea company Yogi, that relieve minor menstrual tension with ingredients such as American Sinesis (tangkwei); Ferrero Rocher chocolates and beauty product samples and accessories.

'Subscription boxes can be a passing fad if the entire business is dependent on this model. However, for companies which already have a business with products in the market, using a subscription box is an additional channel to reach out to a larger customer base.' - Founder Brian Chen (above) of Infusion de Vie. His brand of 100% organic teas do not contain additives such as infused flavours and sweeteners

'Subscription boxes can be a passing fad if the entire business is dependent on this model. However, for companies which already have a business with products in the market, using a subscription box is an additional channel to reach out to a larger customer base.' - Founder Brian Chen of Infusion de Vie. His brand of 100% organic teas (above) do not contain additives such as infused flavours and sweeteners

JOIN THE BOX CLUB: Subscription service for healthier snacks Boxgreen (above) helps its clientele binge on healthier alternatives which they put together based on constantly updating their data and feedback.

JOIN THE BOX CLUB: Shave It Club (above) offers four new cartridges, each made from titanium-coated stainless steel blades and an aloe vera base for lubrication. Members of the club also enjoy discounts with other retailers such as motorbike stores, lifestyle boutiques and cafes.

'Receiving too many products from different brands means the customer may get things they don't like, which leads to disappointment.' - Natasha Chiam (above), founder of Singapore's first ice-cream subscription service Pint Society.
Singapore's first ice-cream subscription service Pint Society.

site_title: Support for 'unicorn' tech startups wane in Q4: report
summary: Investor enthusiasm for "unicorn" tech startups, valued at $1 billion or more, significantly decreased in Q4 2015, with only 9 companies achieving unicorn status, down from 23 in the previous two quarters. This decline is attributed to increased market turbulence and investors' growing caution, reflected in a 39% decrease in mega-deals of $100 million or more in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter. The data from CB Insights suggests a shift in investor sentiment, with many startups opting to stay private longer due to abundant funding.

site_title: Singapore banks ink agreements with Chongqing government to promote cross-border trade
summary: Singapore banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS signed agreements with the Chongqing government to promote cross-border trade and investment between Chongqing and South-east Asia. The agreements, including memorandums of understanding and tripartite agreements, will help companies based in Chongqing tap into the South-east Asia market. DBS also signed bilateral agreements prioritizing its financing services. The move is seen as part of Singapore's role as a gateway city for Chinese companies expanding into South-east Asia, with Chongqing expected to benefit from trade connectivity initiatives such as the One Belt One Road.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore banks on Friday said they have signed agreements with the Chongqing government to promote cross-border trade and investment between Chongqing and South-east Asia, including Singapore. DBS's agreements also include tie-ups with the Chinese banks and financial institutions.

site_title: More property agents throwing in the towel
summary: Singapore's real estate agency industry faces further losses as 22 of the 30 largest agencies shed a significant number of agents in the latest licence-renewal period. Despite this, some agencies, such as ERA Realty and PropNex Realty, remain the largest, with ERA expecting a bottoming-out for the industry and PropNex projecting continued growth. Others, like OrangeTee.com and Onehome Property, have expanded their agent pools through digital platforms and service support. The industry's outlook remains uncertain, with some experts attributing the losses to external shocks and a deteriorating economy.

images.alt_text: Just over half of the businesses in Singapore have said they are "adversely affected" by the current economic climate, according to the findings of the latest National Business Survey released by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) on Tuesday.

site_title: London needs one million homes over next decade, report says
summary: London is expected to need at least 1 million new homes over the next decade to meet demand, according to a report by the Adam Smith Institute. The report suggests building on less than 4% of the city's Green Belt could provide the necessary homes, with almost all of them located within 800 meters of a commuter train station. The report comes as London faces a housing bubble, with house prices surging 40% since 2013 and rents averaging £1,544 a month, more than double the UK average.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore commits S$19 billion for its Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 plan, an 18% increase from the previous five-year plan. Neptune Orient Lines bondholders face losses due to a junk-rated French company's takeover, while Noble Group's bonds fall to distressed territory. Singapore banks sign agreements with the Chongqing government to promote cross-border trade. Alitrip-STB ties up to boost Singapore's online travel products, and the country's shares close lower for the week due to a global market rout, largely blamed on China's economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: THE government is committing S$19 billion for its new Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 plan, which is 18 per cent higher than the S$16.1 billion set aside for the previous five-year plan.

site_title: An action-packed year in store
summary: Sports enthusiasts can look forward to a thrilling year in 2016, with major events like the Summer Olympics in Brazil and the European Championships in France. Notable sports storylines include Manny Pacquiao's final boxing match, the intense English Premier League title race, and the Golden State Warriors' quest to break the NBA record for most wins. Other highlights include the Olympic fever in Rio, the dominant performances of Serena Williams and Novak Djokovic in tennis, and the potential rise of Tampines Rovers in the S.League.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
RAISING THEIR GAME: Serena Williams speaking after receiving the Sports Illustrated Sportsperson of the Year trophy during a ceremony in New York on Dec 15.

RAISING THEIR GAME: Golden State Warriors guard Stephen Curry (30) celebrating in front of Cleveland Cavaliers centre Timofey Mozgov (20) in the third quarter of a NBA game on Dec 25 at Oracle Arena in Oakland, California.
RAISING THEIR GAME: Tampines Rovers players are jubilant after their win over Geylang International in an S.League match on July 29.

site_title: Lenovo unveils first smartphone powered by Google's Tango
summary: Lenovo has unveiled the first smartphone powered by Google's Tango technology, a 3D-scanning technology that superimposes digital images onto real-world displays. The device, set to launch for under $500, uses infrared and wide-angle cameras to map its surroundings and provide precise measurements. Lenovo and Google will offer developers funding and assistance through an incubator program to explore applications in location, games, and utilities. The technology may also complement Google's virtual reality efforts, and is seen as a way for Lenovo to differentiate itself in a crowded market.

site_title: ADB president dismisses fears of a possible currency war
summary: Asian Development Bank (ADB) President Takehiko Nakao has dismissed fears of a currency war triggered by China's recent yuan decline. He attributes the depreciation to market forces, not artificial intervention. Nakao also rules out a significant slowdown in China, citing its strong fiscal position and subdued inflation. ADB reaffirms its 6.9% growth forecast for China in 2015 and 6.7% this year.

site_title: Yuan estimates slashed at Goldman, CICC as PBOC's grip loosens
summary: China's central bank weakened its reference rate, sparking speculation that it is becoming less willing to support the yuan. Five banks and brokerages, including Goldman Sachs and Standard Chartered, cut their yuan forecasts, citing concerns over the currency's depreciation. The yuan slumped to a five-year low, with the People's Bank of China ending an eight-day reduction to the rate. Analysts predict a significant policy easing in the Chinese economy in 2016, with the potential for greater yuan depreciation remaining a source of uncertainty.

images.alt_text: At least five banks and brokerages cut their yuan estimates in the past two days after the central bank's weakening of its reference rate fueled speculation China is becoming less willing to support its currency.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,657.61, up 2.48 points, with 2.07 billion lots valued at RM1.93 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 529 to 375. The market ended higher despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: A battered start to the New Year
summary: The start of 2016 has seen a continuation of weaker currency values, lower FTSE STI, and higher domestic interest rates. The Chinese yuan has depreciated (-1.5%) against the US dollar, raising concerns of greater regional currency volatility and global deflationary pressure. This has led to a sharp selloff in the Chinese stock markets, with the FTSE STI losing 4.5% in five trading days. Investors with a long-term horizon may see the recent selloff as an opportunity, particularly for defensive stocks with attractive dividend yields.

images.alt_text: The depreciation of the Chinese yuan (-1.5 per cent) against the US dollar has led to questions over the government's intentions for the currency, and is raising concerns of greater regional currency volatility and global deflationary pressure.

site_title: Indonesia central bank puts priority on stability: governor
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo has prioritized financial stability amid global market sell-offs, particularly in China and tumbling oil prices. The rupiah's exchange rate will be managed to prevent volatility. A two-day policy meeting is set for January 13-14.

site_title: Consumer Electronics Show awash with altered realities
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show featured a wide range of altered realities, including virtual reality (VR) headsets and augmented reality (AR) eyewear. Companies like Oculus and HTC showcased their VR headsets, while Lumus demonstrated its AR technology. Applications for VR and AR include education, medicine, sports, entertainment, and even space exploration. The technology is being used to enhance experiences, such as fan experiences at sports events and training for professional football quarterbacks. Experts predict that VR and AR will become increasingly integrated into daily life, with applications in fields like manufacturing, healthcare, and travel.

images.alt_text: Altered realities abounded at the Consumer Electronics Show gadget-fest on Thursday, touching everything from sex and sports to sales and space exploration.

site_title: Noble Group said to raise US$200m by selling receivables
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, has raised approximately US$200 million by selling receivables to shore up its balance sheet. The sale comes after the company cut its credit rating to junk by Standard & Poor's, citing weak liquidity and a weakened standing with capital markets and lenders. Noble Group has also agreed to sell its remaining 49% stake in agricultural unit Noble Agri Ltd to China's Cofco Corp for at least US$750 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end painful week with gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.59% on Friday, ending a tumultuous week dominated by Chinese market sell-offs and fears about the global economy. The benchmark Hang Seng Index closed at 20,453.71, a gain of 120.37 points. This follows a worldwide market rout sparked by raised concerns about the global economy.

site_title: China's economic outlook is a concern, Hitachi president says
summary: Hitachi president Toshiaki Higashihara expressed concern over China's economic outlook, stating that the company may need to lower product prices if the situation remains unchanged. China's economic growth is expected to slow due to restructuring efforts, a rapidly aging workforce, and a surplus of apartments. This may lead to a decline in sales for Hitachi's construction machinery and elevator businesses, with estimates suggesting a contraction of the Chinese excavator market to less than one seventh of its 2010 peak.

site_title: Chinese economy stable: ADB president
summary: China's economy is unlikely to slow down sharply this year, according to Asian Development Bank president Takehiko Nakao, despite recent stock turmoil. Nakao maintained a 6.7% economic growth forecast for China, slightly lower than the 6.9% projection for 2015. The bank expects developing Asia to grow 6.0% this year, citing China's successful reforms, including a shift towards domestic consumer demand and a strengthened fiscal position. Nakao also ruled out a deliberate yuan depreciation by the Chinese authorities to weaken exports.

site_title: Noble's ugly duckling is no Singapore swan in disguise: Gadfly
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodities trader, experienced a 65% slump in 2015, making it the worst-performing stock on the Straits Times Index. The company's credit rating was downgraded to junk by Standard & Poor's, and its bond price has dropped to a record low. Despite selling its agriculture unit, Noble's liquidity is considered "adequate" but not "strong," and investors are pricing in a higher risk of default. The company's debt maturing this year includes $3.61 billion, and its credit-default protection costs are among the highest in Asia, making it the riskiest company for bondholders to hedge against non-payment.

site_title: Singapore commits S$19b for new research, innovation and enterprise plan
summary: Singapore has committed S$19 billion for its Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 plan, an 18% increase from the previous five-year plan. The plan prioritizes funding in domains such as advanced manufacturing, health, and digital economy, and aims to sustain spending at about 1% of GDP. This is comparable to public spending in small research-intensive economies like the UK and US. The funding will support national needs and competitive advantages, with a focus on key areas.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: China's currency stance tests world policymakers' sense of perspective
summary: China's rapid depreciation of the yuan has sparked differing reactions from policymakers worldwide. While some, like Mexico's Finance Minister Luis Videgaray, warn of a potential "currency war," others, such as Asian neighbors, believe China has more to lose from capital outflows than gain from increased exports. The US, Japan, and European Central Bank officials also express concerns about the yuan's impact on their economies, but a senior official at Japan's Ministry of Finance suggests China is unlikely to pursue a weaker yuan. The People's Bank of China has intervened in the currency market to ease pressure, but some analysts predict further depreciation.

images.alt_text: Assessments of China's intentions after it let the yuan depreciate more quickly this week possessed some qualities of a fairground mirror, with policymakers in nearby Asia far less alarmed about risks of a"currency war" than those further away.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars bounce on China; still vulnerable
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Friday after China's central bank set a higher yuan guidance rate than expected, breaking a four-day losing streak. The Australian dollar surged to US$0.7060, while the New Zealand dollar jumped 0.5% to US$0.6625. Despite this, analysts warn that China's erratic policies and need for a weaker currency suggest volatility is far from over, and both currencies remain vulnerable.

site_title: Wall St analysts lower Apple price targets
summary: Wall Street analysts have lowered Apple's price targets due to reports of slowing iPhone shipments. At least five analysts cut their targets, with the median now set at $145, down from $142. Despite near-term weakness, analysts expect a rebound in demand after the launch of iPhone 7, citing growth potential in the 7 cycle. The cuts come after Apple lost about $50 billion of its market value in the first four days of the year.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc has lost about US$50 billion of its market value in the first four days of the year, forcing some Wall Street analysts to adjust their view on the iPhone maker.

site_title: China: Stocks regain some ground at the end of a dismal week
summary: China's stocks regained ground, ending the week up 2% after regulators suspended a circuit breaker mechanism, citing its failure to calm investors. The CSI300 index rose 2.0% to 3,361.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.0% to 3,186.41 points. This marks the worst weekly performance since the market crashed in summer 2015. Analysts attribute the rise to Beijing's efforts to reduce excess capacity, which they believe will lead to industry consolidation and benefit major listed players.

site_title: Chinese commodities funds see weaker metals, yuan; eye oil, agriculture
summary: Chinese commodity funds expect weaker metal prices in 2016 due to a continued slowdown in domestic economic growth. However, they are eyeing potential buying opportunities in agricultural products and oil as prices near the bottom of the cycle. Funds plan to increase hedging or take out currency protection for the yuan, which they expect to depreciate further in 2016. Supply cuts and stockpiling by the Chinese government could lead to periodic price rebounds. Meanwhile, oil prices are seen as a potential buying opportunity after a 70% price plunge over the past 18 months.

site_title: Asia: Shares rally as China drops circuit breaker
summary: Asian shares rallied on Friday as China suspended its market circuit breaker system, boosting stocks and supporting the yuan's firmer midpoint rate. The CSI300 index rose 2.7% and the Shanghai Composite climbed 2.6%, paring losses for the week to less than 10%. The gains also supported MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan, which erased earlier losses to be up 0.5%. The People's Bank of China set a stronger yuan midpoint rate against the dollar, easing market concerns.

site_title: Campbell Soup says supports mandatory GMO labeling
summary: Campbell Soup Company, the world's largest soup-maker, supports mandatory GMO labeling for foods derived from genetically modified organisms. The company believes a single federal standard would raise consumer awareness. If a federal solution is not achieved, Campbell will label its US products for GMO ingredients and seek FDA and USDA approval. The company also supports a national standard for non-GMO claims on food packaging.

images.alt_text: Campbell Soup Company said it supports the enactment of federal legislation for a single mandatory labeling standard for foods derived from genetically modified organisms (GMOs).

site_title: Oil prices steady around multi-year lows
summary: Oil prices remain steady around 11-1/2-year lows, influenced by global oversupply and a bleak demand outlook. Brent rose 9 cents to $33.84 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) remained flat at $33.27 a barrel. China's yuan currency firmed, boosting its stock market, but persistent oversupply and reduced global demand growth expectations weigh on prices. The International Energy Agency expects global demand growth to slow to 1.20-1.25 million barrels per day in 2016.

site_title: Samsung flags 15% increase in Q4 operating profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 15% increase in Q4 operating profit to 6.1 trillion won (US$5.1 billion), beating analyst estimates of 6.64 trillion won. Despite struggling with competition, the company's chip and display businesses offset losses in its mobile division. Samsung's shares declined 5.1% in 2015, and the company's flagship smartphone business failed to generate excitement with the Galaxy S6 launch. The company is expected to release audited results this month and is investing in a new $14.3 billion chip plant.

site_title: Gold falls further from 9-week high after upbeat US data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.8% to $1,100.65 an ounce after the US Labor Department reported stronger-than-expected job growth in December, boosting the dollar and stock markets. The data, which also revised employment for the prior two months, suggests a temporary slowdown in economic growth. The US dollar rose 1% versus the euro, putting pressure on gold prices. Analysts attribute the drop to the dollar's strength and the potential for the Federal Reserve to lift interest rates at a faster pace, weighing on gold.

images.alt_text: Gold fell on Wednesday as a stronger dollar and a rebound in stock markets reduced its appeal as a safe asset.

site_title: Car talk is electric at Vegas tech show
summary: Automakers including Ford, General Motors, and Volkswagen showcased electric vehicles at the CES tech show in Las Vegas, emphasizing their commitment to the segment. The Chevrolet Bolt, a final version of GM's electric car, aims to capture buyers without the high price of Tesla. Faraday Future unveiled its FFZERO1 concept car, and Volkswagen introduced the BUDD-e, a connected electric minivan. The industry expects electric vehicles to gain traction, with GM and Ford investing heavily in electric car development, and analysts predicting a shift towards autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won recover after China stocks and yuan pick up
summary: South Korean shares recovered from a 4-month low, ending higher on Friday. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.7% at 1,917.62 points, driven by a strong rebound in Chinese stock markets and a rising Chinese yuan. This eased pressure on global markets, which had seen foreign investors offload KOSPI shares and led to a 2.2% weekly decline. The South Korean won also rose 0.2% against the dollar.

site_title: Winter comes to China shipyards facing near-record maturing debt
summary: China's shipyards and shipping firms face a year of near-record bond repayments, with 50.3 billion yuan in notes to be repaid this year, the second-highest ever. Several companies, including state-owned shipbuilder Zhoushan Wuzhou Ship Repairing & Building Co, have gone bankrupt in a decade, with default risks high for smaller shipbuilders. The industry's struggles come amid a slowing economy and government curbs on overcapacity, with Premier Li Keqiang allowing mergers and acquisitions to boost competitiveness.

site_title: China regulator orders banks in some hubs to limit dollar buying this month: sources
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator has ordered banks in some trading hubs to limit dollar purchases this month, aiming to curb capital outflows. The move follows growing spreads between the onshore and offshore yuan markets since the devaluation last year. All banks in affected hubs, including Shenzhen, are restricted from making dollar purchases. This is part of Beijing's efforts to stem outflows of capital and address economic concerns.

site_title: ECB's Lane says can do more QE if needed: report
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) governing council member Philip Lane stated that the ECB has room to do more quantitative easing if needed, citing the effectiveness of the current asset-purchase program in increasing credit growth and reducing lending rates in some countries. Lane emphasized that no door has been closed, and the ECB will reassess its measures if economic data suggests further action is required. The comments come amid concerns over global economic uncertainty and the impact of low oil prices, particularly in the context of China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Geely-owned Volvo car sales top half a million in record 2015
summary: Volvo Car Group, owned by Geely, reported a record 503,127 car sales in 2015, up 8% from 2014. The sales were boosted by the new XC90 SUV model and strong growth in the US and Europe. Volvo aims to reach 800,000 sales in the medium term and plans to become a truly global premium car company. US sales grew 24.3%, while European sales rose 10.6%, with China sales remaining flat for the year. Volvo expects continued improvement in sales trends for 2016.

site_title: Noble Group bonds at 53 US cents push debt to distressed grade
summary: Noble Group's debt has reached distressed territory, with its dollar bonds due in 2020 falling to a record low of 53 US cents on the dollar. The company's credit rating has been downgraded to speculative grade territory by Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service, citing liquidity issues and depressed commodity markets. This has pushed Noble Group into distressed territory, with credit-default swaps contracts indicating a 75.6% probability of default in five years. The company's shares have also fallen, with a 10% drop in Singapore, and investors are warning of further difficulties in obtaining liquidity.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall in worst yearly start ever on China worries
summary: Australian shares fell for the sixth straight session, marking their worst start to a year on record, due to concerns over China's slowing economy and policymaking ability. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 0.4% and fell 5.8% for the week, its largest weekly decline since 2011. This followed a similar decline in New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index, down 2.6% for the week. The downturn was attributed to worries about China's economic slowdown and its impact on global markets.

site_title: SNB suffers record 23b-franc loss amid stronger currency
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) incurred a record loss of 23 billion francs (S$33 billion) in 2015 due to the appreciation of the franc after abandoning its currency cap in January. The loss resulted from a 20 billion-franc loss on foreign-currency positions. The SNB will pay a dividend of 15 francs per share and 1 billion francs to the federal government and cantons to ease strain on cantonal finances. The Swiss currency finished 2015 more than 10% stronger against the euro.

site_title: Oil prices rebound from 12-year lows
summary: Oil prices rebounded from 12-year lows in Asia, rising 1.35% and 1.21% for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude, respectively. The rebound comes after China's central bank set the yuan's reference rate against the dollar at a five-year low, sparking a global market rout. Despite the price increase, concerns about global demand remain, driven by worries over China's economic slowdown and the persistent crude supply glut. A diplomatic spat between key Opec members Saudi Arabia and Iran also makes a cut in output less likely.

site_title: Fewer Japan households see prices rise ahead: BOJ survey
summary: Japan households are less optimistic about price rises and the economy, a Bank of Japan survey shows. The ratio of households expecting prices to rise a year from now fell to 77.6% from 81.9% in September. Households also became less optimistic about the economy, with a sentiment index worsening 2.1 points. The BOJ aims to accelerate inflation to 2% through money printing, but private consumption remains weak due to declining bonus payments and tumbling oil prices, making it difficult to reach the target.

site_title: Neptune bondholders burned as AAA Singapore connection loosens
summary: Neptune Orient Lines bondholders are facing significant losses after a French company, CMA CGM SA, agreed to take over the shipping firm. The company's notes, which were initially AAA-rated due to implicit Singapore state backing, have lost up to 13% in value. Yields on unrated bonds have surged to over twice the levels they were first sold at, with some notes having clauses that could trigger early repayment or compensation. Analysts attribute the losses to the removal of implicit government support following the planned sale of the majority stake to CMA CGM.

site_title: Thai economic fundamentals can cope with China uncertainty: deputy PM
summary: Thai deputy prime minister Somkid Jatusripitak expressed confidence that the country's economy can withstand the impact of uncertainty in China. He stated that the central bank can maintain a "appropriate" baht level, citing strong Thai fundamentals. China's economic slowdown may cause global market volatility, but Somkid believes Thailand's economy is resilient.

site_title: China meddling shows official doubts over markets: analysts
summary: China's short-lived stock circuit breaker, intended to limit volatility, was scrapped after only four days due to a "negative" effect, demonstrating the government's distrust of markets and its instinct to intervene. The mechanism, which halted trading on Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges, was criticized for causing panic and sending markets down. Analysts say circuit breakers work better in mature markets and that China's individual traders were already volatile, making the mechanism ill-conceived. The move is seen as another sign policymakers are reluctant to let market forces set share prices, fueling concerns about the country's economic management.

site_title: Malaysia PM Najib will table amendments to budget soon: Bernama
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that he will table amendments to the 2016 budget "soon" to address the year's realities, focusing on optimizing spending and the role of government-linked firms. The amendments aim to ensure strong economic growth while upholding the people's welfare.

site_title: Gold dips from nine-week top as China sets yuan higher, stocks climb
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.5% to $1,103.26 an ounce, after reaching a nine-week high of $1,112, due to China's stronger yuan and rising Asian equities. The People's Bank of China set the yuan's midpoint rate higher, boosting Chinese shares by 2% on Friday. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets amid global market uncertainty, but gold prices tend to be short-lived.

site_title: China state planner approves US$2b urban rail project
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission approved a US$2.9 billion urban rail project in Shijiazhuang, Hebei province, to boost economic activity. The 80.4km project, set to finish in 2021, involves three rail links. The approval aims to stimulate the region's economy, which has been flagging.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 4.1 points to 1,651.03, with losers outnumbering gainers 257 to 85. Volume was 177.8 million lots worth RM66.7 million.

site_title: Angst as first 'Mein Kampf' reprints hit German bookstores
summary: New copies of Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" are set to hit German bookstores for the first time since World War II, as the book's copyright expires. The annotated version, which includes historical context and counterarguments, is intended to demystify the anti-Semitic manifesto. However, Jewish community leaders and Holocaust survivors have expressed concerns, with some calling the re-release "incendiary" and arguing that it serves no educational purpose. The book's re-release has sparked debate over its impact and whether it should be taught in schools.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounce after global rout
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded after four days of heavy losses, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.08% to 20,553.31. The rally followed wild volatility in mainland Chinese markets, fueling a global rout. The gains came despite ongoing concerns over the US-China trade tensions and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The rebound is seen as a sign of market resilience, with investors seeking to take advantage of the sell-off.

site_title: Japan: Nikkei opens the year with five straight days of declines
summary: Japanese stocks fell on Friday, marking the first year since 1949 with five consecutive losing sessions. The Nikkei share average dropped 0.4% to 17,697.96, with all but three of its subindexes in negative territory. Investors sought to reduce exposure ahead of US jobs data and a Japanese three-day weekend, amid concerns over an economic slowdown in China and currency volatility. The benchmark Topix index lost 6.5% for the week, its largest weekly decline since early September.

site_title: Beijing imposed US$28m in pollution fines last year: Xinhua
summary: Beijing imposed US$28m in pollution fines last year, with a total of 183 million yuan (US$27.76m) levied for violations of pollution laws. The fines included nearly 2,000 cases of air pollution and 181 cases of water pollution. The city has also put 20,000 pollution sources under strict supervision. Despite this, Beijing's PM2.5 density rose 75.9% year-on-year, highlighting ongoing air quality issues. The move is part of China's efforts to tackle pollution and equip its environmental inspection offices with greater powers.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble falls 6% on S&P downgrade to 'junk'
summary: Noble Group's shares fell 6% in heavy trading after Standard and Poor's downgraded its credit rating to "junk" from investment-grade, citing increased collateral requirements. The downgrade follows similar moves by Moody's last year. Despite this, Noble Group stated that the change is not expected to impact its operations, citing its ability to manage increased collateral calls. The stock closed at 32.5 Singapore cents, with 80.2 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, falling 28.45 points to 2,701.46, amid a wave of selling in Asian markets.
