The depreciation of the yuan led to Chinese stock market plunges, with some 66.6 million shares worth S$87.2 million changing hands. The decline was partly attributed to a credit rating cut to junk status by Standard & Poor's for Noble Group and other oil-related stocks.

site_title: Some BOJ members doubted need to fine-tune QQE-Dec meeting summary
summary: Bank of Japan board members expressed doubts about fine-tuning its massive stimulus programme at their December review. One member stated that reorganizing the programme could make communication with markets more difficult. The decision was made by a 6-3 vote, maintaining the base money target but reorganizing the programme to boost wages and capital expenditure.

site_title: Singapore shares bounce back as China, regional indices rise
summary: Singapore shares rebounded 15.26 points to 2,745.17, boosted by China's rise in major stock indexes and regional markets. China deactivated its circuit-breaker mechanism, seen as exacerbating anxiety. Active stocks like Ezra Holdings and Keppel Corporation gained, after slumping in recent sessions. The 5-day rally comes ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Alitrip-STB tie-up set to boost Singapore's online travel products
summary: Alibaba's online travel platform Alitrip has formed a strategic collaboration with the Singapore Tourism Board to boost Singapore's online travel products. Singapore will become the first overseas destination for Alitrip, featuring the country's tourism offerings on its platform. Local travel companies, including airlines, hotels, and hospitality, will set up retail outlets on the platform, creating opportunities for growth and enhancing the travel experience for Chinese outbound tourists.

site_title: Seoul: Shares stay defensive on China concerns; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares retreated 0.1% to 1,902.95 points, their lowest intraday level since September 8, 2015, amid concerns over China's financial markets and North Korea's increased frontline troop strength. China's yuan strengthened for the first time in nine trading days, but investors remained cautious. Defence industry-related shares surged after South Korea prepared to resume propaganda broadcasts into North Korea. Foreigners were net sellers, offloading 86.6 billion Korean won worth of shares by midday, while the South Korean won rose 0.4% against the dollar.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower, extend global equities rout
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, extending a global equities rout, due to signs of a slowdown in China. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.15% to 17,562.23, while the Topix index fell 1.04% to 1,442.85. The decline follows a sell-off in global markets, with investors seeking safety amid concerns about China's economic slowdown.

site_title: UBS looking past turmoil says China remains key to expansion
summary: UBS' new Asia head, Kathryn Shih, says the bank is committed to China despite market turmoil, citing the country's vast wealth and growth potential. China's market volatility is expected to persist, but UBS plans to expand its presence in wealth management, investment banking, and asset management. Shih aims to capitalize on China's 700 IPOs and tap into the country's largest pool of wealth resources, with the goal of winning a bigger slice of the US$19.8 trillion held by wealthy Chinese. UBS has invested heavily in China, including a $2.5 billion investment in Postal Savings Bank of China.

site_title: China: Stocks rise 2% at market open after Beijing turns off circuit breakers
summary: China's major stock indexes rose 2% at market open after Beijing deactivated a circuit breaker mechanism blamed for aggravating market crashes this week. The CSI300 index rose 2.4% to 3,371.87 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.2% to 3,194.63 points. The move comes after weeks of volatility, with the CSI300 slumping around 12% in 2016.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric, Triyards, Ascott, CapitaLand
summary: Noble Group's credit rating was reduced to junk by Standard & Poor's, while Fitch Ratings maintained a positive outlook due to improved liquidity. China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings saw two independent directors resign, affecting its Singapore residency requirement. Triyards Holdings reported a 25% decline in net profit despite higher revenue. Ascott formed a partnership with Alibaba's Alitrip to cater to Chinese tourists, while CapitaLand's serviced residence business unit expands globally.

site_title: Gross says China shares likely to fall up to 6% on Friday
summary: Bill Gross predicts China's stock markets will drop 5-6% on Friday, following a circuit breaker shutdown for the second time this week. The move adds to concerns about China's economic growth and volatility, with global stocks heading for their worst start to a year. Analysts warn of further turmoil when markets reopen, citing policy uncertainty and potential manipulation by Chinese regulators.

site_title: China central bank firms yuan guidance rate for first time in 9 trading days
summary: The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.5636 per dollar, firmer than the previous day's closing quote, marking the first time the yuan's guidance rate was firmed in 9 trading days. The move came after the yuan's biggest fall in five months, which pressured regional currencies and global stock markets. This firming of the yuan's guidance rate may signal a shift in China's monetary policy and raise pressure on policymakers to address slowing GDP growth.

site_title: CES has a gadget for everyone. Even pets
summary: CES 2016 unveiled various innovative gadgets, including a 184 passenger drone, a CleverPet game console for dogs, a coffee art machine, a fashion-forward wearable Bluetooth earbud bracelet, and an In&Motion Ski Airbag Vest. These devices showcase the growing influence of technology in daily life, from entertainment to safety. The event highlights the potential for technology to reach new areas, such as transportation and pet care, and may signal the emergence of new trends in consumer electronics.

site_title: China flip-flops on stock crash rule and adds to sense of chaos
summary: China's circuit breaker rule, designed to stabilize the stock market after a $5 trillion loss in 2015, was suspended after just four days due to concerns it was exacerbating declines. The rule, which triggered halts for 15 minutes after a 5% drop and for the rest of the day after a 7% retreat, was criticized for deepening losses as investors scrambled to exit positions. Regulators acknowledged the "magnet effect" it had, where investors traded ahead of the trigger, and suspended the mechanism, citing its negative impact outweighing the positive effect.

site_title: China problems could hurt Thai exports: finance minister
summary: Thailand plans to boost domestic consumption and state investment this year due to China's economic problems, which will impact the country's traditional growth engine of exports. Exports account for over 60% of Thailand's economy, and China, its second-largest market, accounted for 11.1% of total exports from January-November 2015. The finance minister and deputy prime minister expect the Thai economy to slow to 2.0% in 2016 from 2.5% last year, and officials are counting on tourism from China to remain high. The central bank is expected to keep the baht at a level "appropriate for the economy."

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q4 profit likely US$5.1b, misses expectations
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a likely Q4 operating profit of 6.1 trillion won (S$7.3 billion), up 15% from the previous year, but missed analyst expectations. Revenue is expected to rise 0.5% to 53 trillion won. The company did not elaborate on its earnings, with a detailed disclosure expected around the end of January.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares in dramatic swings
summary: Shanghai shares experienced dramatic swings in opening trade on Friday, reversing early gains as the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.68% and 1.80% respectively. The suspension of China's "circuit breaker" mechanism, which was meant to calm volatile markets, is seen as a contributing factor. Authorities also set the yuan currency slightly higher against the US dollar, ending an eight-day fall. Market sentiment remains uncertain, with analysts attributing the swings to the economic fundamentals and the government's policy decisions.

site_title: Noble awarded offer to sell premium diesel to Petroecuador: traders
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based firm, has been awarded a tender by Ecuador's state-run oil firm Petroecuador to buy 3.12 million barrels of premium diesel at a price of $1.57 per barrel. This deal follows Noble's previous successful bid to sell 2.88 million barrels of diesel to Ecuador in November. The award comes as Noble faces liquidity concerns, with a total of $2.5 billion worth of loans due in 2016. Analysts expect this downgrade to put more pressure on Noble.

site_title: UK permanent starting salary growth hits two-year low in December: REC
summary: UK permanent starting salaries grew at the weakest pace in over two years in December, according to a survey by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation. The growth was the sharpest slowdown since late 2011, with starting salaries touching their lowest level since October 2013. Despite this, the labor market remains in "great shape" and businesses are expected to link annual pay awards with low levels of inflation, leading to wage growth of 1.5-2.5% in 2016, below forecasts of 3%.

site_title: Top hedge fund says China should have waited on stock crash rule
summary: APS Asset Management Pte, a Singapore-based hedge fund, believes China's authorities should have waited before suspending the circuit-breaker rules, which suspend stock trading if losses exceed a certain threshold. The rules were suspended for a second time this week after the CSI 300 Index plummeted 7.2% on Thursday. APS founder Wong Kok Hoi stated that retail investors will eventually adapt to the rules, leading to irrational investor behavior to disappear. Despite the suspension, APS remains bullish on China's economy, predicting the CSI 300 Index to reach 7,000 within the next five years.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slip on continued China worries; ahead of data, sales
summary: Taiwan's stocks slipped 0.2% on Friday, amid concerns over China and ahead of key data releases. The main TAIEX index closed at 7,834.99. Exports in December likely fell for an 11th straight month, according to a Reuters poll. Tech giants TSMC and Hon Hai Precision are expected to report December sales figures, which are closely watched for their impact on the US tech giant Apple. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to its weakest levels in over six years, while shares in Hon Hai and TSMC declined 0.8% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: Australia: Shares head for worst start to a year on China seesaw
summary: Australian shares fell for a sixth straight session, headed for their worst start to a year on record, amid concerns over China's economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.4% in early trading, recovering briefly when China's exchanges opened higher. Financial stocks, including Commonwealth Bank and National Australia Bank, were the biggest drag. Dairy exporters and some mining stocks rose, while energy stocks also gained. The benchmark is down 6% for the year, with a possible China hard landing exacerbating the economic concerns.

site_title: Saudi considers IPO for oil giant Aramco: report
summary: Saudi Arabia is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for state-owned oil giant Aramco, the world's largest oil company, as the country seeks to address the economic consequences of low oil prices. Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman stated that a decision on the IPO would be made in the next few months, which would generate cash for the kingdom while increasing transparency. Analysts expect a small stake to be made available to the public, with limited impact on the oil market.

site_title: China may find it difficult to continue buying yuan: Aso
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that China may struggle to continue buying yuan due to its significant decline in foreign currency reserves. China's reserves, the world's largest, dropped by a record in 2015, amid concerns over currency depreciation. Aso emphasized that China's decision on its currency policy is its own responsibility.

site_title: Japan's Aso: China may find it difficult to continue buying yuan
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso warned that China may struggle to continue buying yuan to support its currency due to a record decline in foreign currency reserves. China's reserves fell $512.66 billion in 2015 to $3.33 trillion, the biggest annual drop on record. Aso expressed concern about the disparity between onshore and offshore yuan rates caused by China's frequent currency intervention, which could trigger further capital flight and competitive currency devaluations globally.

site_title: Risk shunned as Asia eyes week's end with Kiwi stocks sliding
summary: Asian markets slid on the last day of the week, with New Zealand's benchmark dropping 1.3% and US stocks ending their worst four-day start to a year. China's stock market turmoil and oil's 12-year low low fueled concerns over global inflation and central bank policy. The S&P/NZX 50 Index and MSCI All-Country World Index fell for a fourth day, with global equities shedding US$2.5 trillion in value so far this year.

site_title: Yuan jumps as central bank guides rate up for first time in nine days
summary: China's yuan strengthened in early trade on Friday after the central bank set a firmer official rate for the first time in nine days, rising 170 pips to 6.5700. This followed the biggest fall in five months on Thursday, which pressured regional currencies and global markets. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.5636 per dollar, and the offshore yuan traded 1.29% away from the onshore spot. The move aimed to stabilize the currency amid concerns of competitive devaluations.

site_title: United Airlines fined US$2.75m over treatment of disabled, tarmac delays
summary: United Airlines has been fined $2.75 million by the US Transportation Department for violating rules governing tarmac delays and assisting passengers with disabilities. The airline was found to have failed to return wheelchairs promptly or provide adequate assistance at five US airports in 2014. United will use $375,000 of the fine to improve plane parking systems and $500,000 to expand its mobile application for disability-related requests.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally amid return to risk as Chinese assets rebound
summary: Asian stocks rallied amid China's decision to refrain from cutting the yuan's reference rate, providing reassurance to investors concerned about a potential global crisis. Chinese assets rebounded, and high-yielding currencies jumped, including the South African rand and Korean won. US crude oil rose beyond $34 a barrel, while the yen fell with bonds and Treasuries. Global equities have lost over $2 trillion this week due to concerns over China's economy, fueling anxiety over policy makers' ability to manage the slowing economy.

site_title: HDB, AHTC locked in disagreement over choice of accountant
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) and Housing and Development Board (HDB) have expressed disagreement with Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) over the choice of accountant, following a Court of Appeal order for AHTC to appoint accountants to rectify contraventions of the Town Councils Act. HDB disputed AHTC's selection of Business Assurance, citing concerns over the firm's expertise and capacity. The court had ordered AHTC to appoint accountants to examine all non-compliances and recover improper past payments, not just those involving former managing agents.

site_title: Oil prices hits 12-year low
summary: Oil prices hit a 12-year low, falling 2.1% to $33.27 a barrel, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and European benchmark Brent North Sea crude oil also plummeting. The drop was triggered by China's market turmoil and concerns over global oversupply, with investors worried about the return of Iranian barrels. The Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries effectively dropped output limits in early December, contributing to the market's fragility.

site_title: Volkswagen chief to meet with top US environmental regulator
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller is set to meet with US Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Gina McCarthy on January 13 to discuss the emissions-cheating scandal. The meeting follows a lawsuit filed by the US Justice Department, which could result in a $20 billion fine or more. VW has admitted to using emissions-cheating technology on 11 million diesel engines worldwide, leading to the resignation of its former CEO. The meeting aims to pressure VW to accelerate recall efforts and accelerate efforts to address the environmental damage caused by the scandal.

site_title: Triyards' Q1 profit down 25% to US$6.2m
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a 25% decline in Q1 profit to US$6.2m, despite a 38% increase in revenue to US$78.1m. Lower-margin projects and the absence of a one-time gain contributed to the decrease. The company attributed the decline to a different mix of projects and a lower gross profit margin. Triyards has made efforts to diversify its clientele base and expand its product offerings, expecting continued demand for its services in a challenging environment.

site_title: Renault-Nissan alliance plans self-driving cars over next four years
summary: Renault and Nissan plan to launch over 10 self-driving cars in the US, Europe, China, and Japan over the next four years. The alliance, led by CEO Carlos Ghosn, will debut self-driving technology in single-lane control on highways this year, followed by multiple-lane control by 2018 and full autonomy in cities by 2020. The partnership will also launch an app for mobile device interaction with cars by 2018. Renault and Nissan, despite operating as separate companies, will integrate their engineering teams to develop the autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Brazil government underestimated crisis: Rousseff
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff admitted her government underestimated the economic crisis, citing uncertainty in China and severe drought in Brazil. She cited this as her "biggest mistake" in 2014. Rousseff aims to rein in inflation and bring Brazil back to a budget surplus, with a target of 6.5%. She also plans to debate pension system reforms, citing the rising average retirement age of 55 years old. Rousseff faces calls for impeachment and her approval rating has slipped to single digits.

site_title: New technology puts health care in palm of your hand
summary: New technology is revolutionizing healthcare by putting it in the palm of your hand. Smartphone-enabled apps and wearable sensors can examine, diagnose, and even treat various conditions, such as diabetes, pain, and stress. Companies like VisioMed and MedWand have introduced virtual checkup suites and devices that measure vital signs, temperature, and oxygen levels, allowing for remote doctor consultations. These innovations aim to provide more precise and continuous health monitoring, reducing the need for in-person visits and costs associated with traditional medical care.

site_title: Fitness tech steps up its game at Consumer Electronics Show
summary: Fitness technology has made significant advancements at the Consumer Electronics Show, with new products that analyze muscle, fat, and other measures. Companies like HS Innovation, Zepp Labs, and Qardio are developing connected systems that provide detailed insights into performance and health. These systems include wearable devices, such as smart scales and eyewear, that track data like heart rate, speed, and muscle quality. The goal is to help athletes and weekend warriors optimize their performance and achieve their fitness goals.

site_title: Mexico fears currency war after China's yuan move
summary: Mexico's Finance Minister Luis Videgaray warned that China's weakening of the yuan could trigger a global currency war, as the peso hit new lows against the dollar. China's yuan reached its lowest level since March 2011, prompting concerns over a cycle of competitive devaluations. The peso surpassed 18 pesos to the dollar, with Mexico's stock market falling 2.47% for the ninth consecutive day amid global concerns over the Chinese economy.

site_title: Dow, S&P lose over 2%, Nasdaq 3% as global rout deepens
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the Dow falling 2.32% and the S&P 500 shedding 2.37%, as concerns about the Chinese economy and weakening yuan currency deepened. The Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 3.03%. A seven percent Chinese stocks plunge and a 12-year low in US benchmark oil also contributed to the selling. Technology and banking shares were particularly hard hit, while exceptions included Wal-Mart Stores and Macy's.

site_title: China's woes rattle global markets
summary: Global stock markets plummeted Thursday, with the US S&P 500 index falling 2.4% and shedding nearly 5% for the year, marking the worst four-day open to a year. China's woes, including a 7% drop in the yuan and a second suspension of trading on the Shanghai exchange, triggered a "tidal wave of losses" across global bourses. Analysts warn of reduced-risk exposure and a potential financial crisis reminiscent of the 2008 crash, while others attribute the volatility to interest rate cycles.

site_title: Boeing orders fall by half in 2015 but deliveries hit record
summary: Boeing's commercial aircraft orders dropped by half in 2015 to 768, behind Airbus, which is expected to report over 1,000 orders. However, Boeing delivered a record 762 aircraft, surpassing its forecast and the previous record of 723 deliveries in 2014. Despite lower orders, Boeing's deliveries underscore a likely strong year for earnings, with third-quarter revenues up 8.7% and net earnings 25.1% higher. The company's backlog of 5,795 orders, representing seven and a half years of production, supports future deliveries.

site_title: BlackBerry joins self-driving car race
summary: BlackBerry has entered the self-driving car market with its QNX software division, providing a central platform for automakers to build their own features. The technology enables demo cars to scan for obstacles, stay on lanes, and communicate with nearby vehicles. BlackBerry is not developing its own autonomous algorithms, but rather providing building blocks for other companies. This move may offer an alternative to companies like Apple and Google, which have been investing heavily in autonomous car technology. The market remains open, and BlackBerry's entry is seen as a potential game-changer.

site_title: Yen surges to 4-month high as yuan slides further
summary: The yen surged to a 4-month high against the dollar as investors sought a safe-haven following China's aggressive devaluation of the yuan, fuelling concerns about its economy. The People's Bank of China set its official yuan midpoint rate 0.5% weaker than Wednesday's fix, leading to a decline in global stock markets. The Chinese yuan's decline and foreign exchange reserves' record monthly drop of $512.66 billion amid rising foreign capital outflows have raised uncertainty about China's economic state.

site_title: Ascott partners Alitrip to attract 'independent' Chinese travellers
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business of CapitaLand, has partnered with Alitrip, Alibaba's online travel platform, to cater to independent Chinese travelers. Over 26,000 apartments in 60 cities will be made available on Alitrip, with the partnership expected to tap into China's growing outbound travel market. The move follows a shift towards independent travel by Chinese tourists, with 70% of outbound travelers booking trips on their own in 2014. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to capture a significant share of the market.

site_title: US dollar falls amid Chinese-driven market turmoil
summary: The US dollar fell against other major currencies on Thursday due to China's market turmoil, sparking concerns about the country's economy. China suspended equities trading for the second time in four days and devalued its yuan currency, raising talk of a currency war. Analysts believe the yuan will continue to depreciate this year, and investors fled to the yen and euro, which rose against the dollar. The US dollar's decline was attributed to uncertainty about the Federal Reserve's interest rate tightening policies, with the US payrolls report for December set to provide further clarity.

site_title: Blackstone, Gaw Capital mull bids for Ascendas Hospitality Trust
summary: Private equity firms Blackstone Group LP and Gaw Capital Partners are considering separate bids for Singapore's Ascendas Hospitality Trust, valued at US$600 million. The potential offers come amid falling market valuations and higher interest rate expectations, conducive to sector consolidation. The trust, comprising 11 hotels with over 4,100 rooms, has outperformed its peers, with total returns of 17.5% in 2015. However, the Singapore hospitality sector faces challenges, including weak visitor numbers and rising room supply.

site_title: Top Morgan Stanley exec quits after another is promoted
summary: Morgan Stanley's top executive Gregory Fleming has quit after being passed over for a promotion to chief executive by James Gorman, who instead elevated Colm Kelleher to the No 2 position. Fleming, 52, had been seen as a leading candidate for the top job and had expressed impatience to succeed Gorman in the past. His departure is the latest in a series of leadership changes aimed at improving the firm's profitability, which has been struggling under new regulations and market changes.

site_title: Fed watching China stocks rout, Republicans slam yuan slump
summary: The US Federal Reserve is closely monitoring the sell-off in Chinese stocks, which has led to a significant decline in the value of China's currency, the yuan. US Republican presidential candidates have criticized China's policies, claiming they are designed to gain a trade advantage. Analysts believe China's efforts to prop up the yuan with foreign reserves may be undermining its true intentions, and this could complicate the Fed's decision on interest rates. Despite this, Fed officials say they will continue to monitor the global situation and are unlikely to raise interest rates until March or April.

site_title: Eating a path to better health
summary: The documentary "PlantPure Nation" aims to promote a plant-based diet and its benefits on health, the environment, and social justice. The film, directed by Nelson Campbell, will be screened in Singapore and features a panel discussion with experts. Campbell's father, Professor T Colin Campbell, wrote the bestselling book "The China Study" on the connection between diet and health. The documentary highlights the power of plant-based nutrition and encourages viewers to take control of their diets, with the goal of inspiring a paradigm shift in the way people think about food and health.

site_title: 'Brexit' suspense clouds Carney's decision on when to raise UK interest rate
summary: The Bank of England's decision on raising interest rates has been delayed due to uncertainty surrounding the UK's planned vote on its membership in the European Union. The vote, known as "Brexit," has cast a cloud over the economy, leading economists to push back their forecasts for the first increase in over eight years. The Bank of England's governor, Mark Carney, is struggling to offer a clear timeline for rate hikes, and officials are considering holding off on policy changes until the implications of the referendum become clearer.

site_title: Apple sinks below US$100 on news of slowing shipments
summary: Apple's shares dropped below $100 for the first time in nearly five months due to reports of slowing iPhone 6S and 6S Plus shipments, potentially marking the first annual decline in sales since the iPhone's launch. Analysts predict annual sales will fall, and the stock has declined 20% over the last six months. Despite this, Apple CEO Tim Cook's compensation rose 11.5% to $10.3 million in 2015, and the company reported strong sales in China.

site_title: BOC Aviation announces order for US$3b worth of Airbus A320 aircraft
summary: BOC Aviation, a Singapore-based aircraft leasing firm owned by Bank of China, has ordered 30 Airbus A320 aircraft worth over $3 billion. The order includes 18 A320neo and 12 A320ceo aircraft, solidifying Airbus' top 10 customers. This marks BOC Aviation's 306 existing orders from Airbus, comprising 12 A330s and 294 A320 Family aircraft. The order reflects the A320 family's popularity among customers for short- and medium-haul routes, and BOC Aviation's continued confidence in the aircraft's reliability and operational efficiency.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: M'sia anti-graft agency finds corruption in bauxite mining
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency has found "elements of corruption" in bauxite mining, prompting a three-month ban on mining in Pahang state. The ban aims to curb environmental pollution and prevent illicit operations. Exports will be allowed during the moratorium to reduce port inventories, and the government will limit production to the nation's capacity after the suspension. The move is expected to have minimal impact on global prices, as China's smelters appear to be slowing down and there is a large stockpile of material.

site_title: German factory orders up amid solid domestic demand
summary: German factory orders rose 1.5% in November, exceeding economists' expectations, driven by solid domestic demand and a weaker euro. Orders for basic goods surged 4.8% and total domestic orders increased 2.6%. Exporters are benefiting from a shift in focus away from slowing emerging markets, with shipments to the US jumping 20% in the 10 months through October. The economy is expected to continue growing, with private consumption driving growth and government spending adding extra stimulus.

site_title: Scandal-hit VW to press on with diesel marketing campaign in US
summary: Volkswagen will continue its diesel marketing campaign in the US despite a massive government lawsuit over its pollution-cheating scandal. CEO Matthias Mueller stated that the company has no reason to stop trying to grow its diesel market in the US, citing the need to reach carbon-emissions targets. Mueller acknowledged the mistake of installing rogue software but argued that diesel vehicles are necessary for the auto industry until electric vehicles become cost-efficient. The company is scheduled to recall 8.5 million affected vehicles in Europe and faces potential penalties, including buying back affected cars in the US.

site_title: Merkel's leadership lands her in refugee challenge
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's leadership on the European refugee crisis has been put to the test, with some questioning whether the EU can survive the crisis. However, Merkel has demonstrated compassion and quick action, taking in Syrian refugees and supporting liberal asylum policies. Despite growing radicalism and controversy, Merkel's party has recovered from recent lows, and she was reaffirmed as party leader at a recent congress. Merkel's leadership is seen as a key factor in maintaining stability in Germany and the EU, and she has been praised for her fortitude and perseverance in the face of public pressure.

site_title: Finding the middle way to strike a Japanese-gaijin balance
summary: Tokyo's Niseko resort has become an Australian enclave, with English as the primary language spoken by staff and locals, a stark contrast to the rest of Japan where foreigners are rare. This "Australianisation" has brought prosperity to the area, with bustling streets, lively shops, and numerous restaurants. However, it also highlights Japan's cultural homogeneity and the challenges of embracing the outside world. Experts argue that a "middle way" is needed to balance Japanese culture with global influences, potentially leading to more opportunities for Japanese people in rural areas and the preservation of traditional ways.

site_title: Will nationalism be the big winner in 2016?
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump and other populist leaders are transforming national politics and geopolitics. The rise of nationalism, driven by identity politics and ethnic, religious, and racial sentiments, is a reflection of the decline of secular ideologies. This trend is seen globally, with leaders like Putin, Erdogan, Modi, and Xi Jinping in power, and is expected to impact geopolitics in 2016. The economic factors contributing to this shift are overstated, with populist parties exploiting voters' anxiety over immigration and terrorism, rather than addressing economic inequalities.

site_title: Singdollar volatile, with more instability ahead
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) experienced volatility on Thursday, falling 0.6% against the US dollar amid weaker-than-expected yuan fixing by China's central bank. The yuan's depreciation has triggered concerns about China's economic outlook and further depreciation of the RMB, affecting Asian currencies, including the SGD. Economists expect the SGD to weaken further, with DBS predicting a fall to 1.47 by the end of Q3 and UOB anticipating a decline to 1.46 by the end of the second quarter.

site_title: Tanah Merah site triggered for tender
summary: A 2.4-hectare site near Tanah Merah MRT Station in Singapore has been triggered from the Ministry of National Development's reserve list, with a successful applicant committing to a minimum bid of S$580 per square foot of potential gross floor area. The site, which can yield 570 private homes, will be launched in two weeks. Analysts expect developers to apply for more reserve list sites in the next few months due to depleted landbanks. The site's proximity to the MRT station and established suburban residential enclave are expected to attract bidders, with prices forecast to range from S$600-750 psf ppr.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Call for GIC to invest CPF in local stocks stirs debate
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) proposed that sovereign wealth fund GIC invest Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies in the local stock market, sparking a debate. While some market participants supported the idea, others argued that Singapore's market is too small to meet GIC's mandate to preserve purchasing power and that CPF monies should be ring-fenced in risk-free investments. Experts emphasized that the roles of the CPF and GIC cannot be conflated, and that diversification is crucial for GIC's long-term returns.

site_title: HDB resale prices flat in Dec as volume falls: SRX
summary: Singapore's HDB resale prices remained flat in December 2015, unchanged from November, while resale volume fell 4.3% compared to the previous month. Prices have fallen 1.3% year-on-year, with a 10.7% drop from their peak in April 2013. Consultants expect either a flat performance or slight decline in HDB resale prices in 2016, driven by increased price stability and more reasonable asking prices by sellers.

site_title: S&P, Fitch differ on Noble ratings
summary: Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings have differing opinions on Noble Group's credit rating. S&P cut Noble's investment credit rating to "BB+" from "BBB-", citing depressed commodity markets and risk aversion by lenders. Fitch Ratings maintained a stable rating, citing Noble's improved liquidity following asset sales and manageable collateral requirements. Noble shares fell 3.5 Singapore cents to 34.5 Singapore cents amid a global commodity rout, but the company remains confident its proposed disposal of Noble Agri will improve its rating metrics.

site_title: More layoffs on the horizon for Malaysian oil & gas sector
summary: Malaysia's oil and gas sector is facing further job cuts, with 10 industry players planning to slash at least 2,700 jobs. Shell Malaysia is set to lead the cuts with 1,300 job losses in two years, while other companies, including ExxonMobil, Murphy Oil, and Petrofac-RNZ, plan to cut between 80 and 600 jobs each. Petronas, the country's leading oil company, has opted for salary cuts rather than layoffs. The job cuts are attributed to low oil prices forcing reviews of staffing costs as part of restructuring efforts.

site_title: Storied Bahamas luxury estate Kilkee House to be put up for auction
summary: The 11,000-square-foot Kilkee House, a luxurious oceanfront estate on Paradise Island in the Bahamas, is set to be auctioned off on January 14 with a starting bid of $10 million. The estate, which has a storied history, was once owned by Richard Harris and Frank Sinatra, and features breathtaking views, private beach, and a stone bridge over a rock grotto pool. After years of restoration, the property is now being sold with a reserve price of $10 million, and is considered one of the best-priced properties in the area, with two pre-auction offers already received.

site_title: Yen keeps rising in growing threat to Abenomics
summary: Japan's yen continues to rise, reaching a 4.5-month high against the US dollar, threatening Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index dropped 2.3% on Thursday, while Asian stocks and most currencies slid. Analysts predict the yen will reach 110 to the dollar this year, potentially prompting the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policies further, including increasing its purchases of Japanese Government Bonds. This could push the BOJ's inflation target further out of reach, as other Asian currencies, including China's yuan, continue to depreciate.

site_title: Carmakers pushing ahead with battery-powered vehicles
summary: Car manufacturers, including General Motors, are moving forward with battery-powered vehicles despite struggling sales of electric and hybrid vehicles. The Chevrolet Bolt, introduced at the International CES, offers a 200-mile range and an affordable price of $30,000, with government incentives totaling $7,500. Luxury carmakers like BMW and Tesla are also expanding their electric vehicle lines, with Audi planning to have 25% of its US business be plug-in vehicles by 2025. Industry analysts question whether electric cars will catch on with consumers, but the Bolt sets a new benchmark for value and function.

site_title: SGX reprimands Abterra, chairman and CEO
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reprimanded Abterra, its executive chairman Cai Sui Xin and chief executive officer Lau Yu for breaches of listing rules. The reprimand is based on a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers, which found that Abterra failed to act in the best interest of shareholders in relation to an acquisition. Abterra also breached listing rules by failing to disclose material information related to a sale and purchase agreement. The company has been directed to hire a compliance adviser and referred to relevant authorities.

site_title: Exports up, but economist not impressed given ringgit's dive
summary: Malaysia's exports rose 6.3% to RM67.63 billion in November, driven by a weaker ringgit, but an economist believes the growth is muted due to weak global demand and depressed commodity prices. Despite the ringgit's devaluation, exports are still not competitive, and a further depreciation could make Malaysian goods more export-competitive. The trade surplus increased to RM86.3 billion, but an economist expects the gains to be short-lived as the ringgit is expected to stabilize.

site_title: Bill Gross urges exposure to developing markets on demographics
summary: Bill Gross, a prominent bond investor, recommends increasing exposure to developing markets due to demographic factors. He believes demographics will dominate financial markets for the next few decades, particularly as the US faces a growing number of retired baby boomers. Gross suggests investing in emerging markets to compensate for this trend, citing 10-year inflation-protected Treasuries as a suitable option.

site_title: Dishwashing firm GS Holdings heads for Catalist listing
summary: GS Holdings, a commercial dishwashing company, is set to list on Catalist with a S$6 million share placement. The company's revenue from the foodcourt chain Koufu Group made up 40% of its total revenue in fiscal 2014, but fell to 7% in the first half of 2015. GS Holdings expects strong demand for its dishware washing services due to labor shortages. The listing and trading of shares are expected to start on January 18, 2016, with net proceeds to be used for expanding operations and working capital.

site_title: Sell-off in Asian markets sends STI to its lowest since mid-2012
summary: Asian stock markets plummeted on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index falling 2.7% to its lowest since 2012, amid China's yuan turmoil and circuit breaker suspensions. The yuan's 0.51% drop triggered selling pressure, and Hong Kong and Nikkei stocks also took a hit. Futures markets were also affected, with the Dow Jones down 1.48% and the S&P 500 down 1.45%. The Singapore dollar is sensitive to expectations of currency fluctuations, and some analysts predict a "perfect storm" in 2016 with higher US dollar interest rates.

site_title: China's foreign reserves see record fall in push to aid yuan
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell by a record $108 billion to $3.33 trillion in December, marking the first-ever annual decline, as authorities sought to prop up a weakening yuan amid slower growth and plunging stocks. The yuan sank to a five-year low, and the government plans to allow for more depreciation and use reserves to stabilize the currency. Economists expect the yuan to continue to decline against the US dollar this year, with foreign reserves expected to drop to $3 trillion.

site_title: Australia building boom cooling at a bad time
summary: Australia's home building boom is slowing down, with a 12.7% drop in November approvals, the largest decline since 2012. The multi-unit sector saw a 23% drop, and analysts warn of a glut of unsold apartments. The Reserve Bank of Australia relies on the housing industry to boost economic growth, but it's expected to slow down in 2016. The decline in approvals could have broader economic implications, including reduced employment, retail spending, and finance.

site_title: Debt markets see more ECB rate cuts as oil slides, China stumbles
summary: Debt markets expect a 50% chance of a further European Central Bank (ECB) rate cut in March, following a 50 basis point drop in two-year bond yields and a 10 basis point drop in the overnight interbank lending rate. Sliding oil prices and China's market rout have dimmed inflation expectations, with eurozone inflation gauges hitting a 3-1/2-month low. The ECB launched a new round of monetary stimulus just over a month ago, but the recent market movements suggest it may need to act again to support the economy.

site_title: Bankruptcy filing being mulled for top client of Keppel and SembMarine
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine and SembCorp Marine, two major Singaporean shipbuilding companies, are facing financial uncertainty due to a struggling client, Sete Brasil. The company, which ordered deep-water rigs from the two firms, is considering bankruptcy protection. Investors are set to meet to decide on this course of action, which could impact Keppel and SembMarine's shares and financials. The companies have already collected 28% and 40% of the total contract value, but may need to absorb significant losses if the project is cancelled.

site_title: Weaker yuan punishes oil, copper and corn imports
summary: China's central bank cut the yuan's daily reference rate, guiding the currency lower amid tepid growth, and further weakened commodities. Oil, copper, and corn imports became more expensive, while global markets witnessed a slump. The Bloomberg Commodity Index dropped 0.6% to its lowest level since March 1999, and equities tumbled. China's mainland shares were forced to shut early, and investors are driven by emotion and panic rather than market fundamentals.

site_title: Retiring a UN building not so fit for world stage
summary: The United Nations' North Lawn Building, a six-year-old, $140 million temporary structure, will be demolished over the next five months as the $2.15 billion headquarters renovation is completed. The building, which housed critical operations, will be dismantled to recycle materials, with the goal of extracting as much value as possible. The site will be replaced by open space, including a restored lawn with the Berlin Wall and artworks. The demolition contractor, Gramercy Group, was incentivized to recycle materials, and the building will be replaced by a renovated General Assembly Hall.

site_title: Inflation now guiding light for Fed in rate-rise path
summary: The US Federal Reserve is focusing on inflation performance as it sets the pace for interest rate increases this year. Minutes from the December meeting showed policymakers are "reasonably confident" they'll reach their 2% inflation target over the medium term, but some officials expressed concerns about downside risks, including a stronger US dollar and global dis-inflationary forces. The Fed's strategy for future rate hikes is described as gradual, with the possibility of two or four additional hikes this year.

site_title: China dry-bulk shipping firms facing losses, liquidity woes
summary: China's dry-bulk shipping industry is expected to see a surge in bankruptcies this year due to record-low freight rates and decreased demand for imports. Over 60% of surveyed firms are struggling with long-term losses, and 40% face liquidity problems. Benchmark freight rates have hit an all-time low, further stretching finances for shipping firms. The Baltic Dry Index has plummeted to a record low of 468 points, with prices of thermal coal and iron ore also near multi-year lows, indicating a bearish sentiment in the industry.

site_title: Deja vu strikes ominous chords
summary: China's market turmoil has investors worldwide fearing the worst, with the yuan's 1.5% drop against the US dollar in less than four days triggering a sell-off in Chinese stocks. The latest slide has prompted renewed fears of a currency war, affecting commodity prices and global markets. Authorities claim the yuan's weakness is against the US dollar, but experts suggest China's economic predicament and loss of control may be behind the market upheaval. Investors are increasingly assuming the worst, citing China's previous bungled stock market intervention and unrealistic growth targets.

site_title: Eddie Redmayne thoroughly convincing as The Danish Girl
summary: Eddie Redmayne delivers a convincing performance as Einar Wegener, the world's first known transgender, in Tom Hooper's "The Danish Girl." Redmayne plays a dashing landscape artist who undergoes a sex change to become Lili Elbe, a woman whose paintings become a hit in the art world. Alicia Vikander shines as Einar's wife Gerda, who struggles with her husband's transition. Despite some controversy, the film is a visually stunning and sensitive portrayal of Lili's journey, with Redmayne and Vikander delivering Oscar-baiting performances.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Personal touch lets boutique banks run with big dogs of Wall Street
summary: Boutique investment banks, such as Centerview Partners, are gaining favor on Wall Street due to their ability to provide unbiased advice and avoid conflicts of interest. Unlike large banks, boutiques have smaller staffs and are less burdened by internal operations, allowing them to keep deals secret. This has led to a surge in fees for boutiques, with Centerview earning over $600 million last year. The firms are attracting top dealmakers and advising on major deals, including mergers and acquisitions, and are becoming a more powerful presence on Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: SMEs largely support SBF position paper
summary: Singapore Business Federation's (SBF) proposal for the government to consider investing pension funds in local SMEs and re-examining foreign manpower policies has received support from SME owners. The proposal aims to make the government a stakeholder in local businesses, boosting their branding and skills development. SMEs also welcome the recommendation to expand the Lean Enterprise Development (LED) Scheme and consider allowing larger quotas of foreign workers to address labor shortages.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Audit not a substitute for good corporate governance
summary: Non-profit organizations (NPOs) are under scrutiny for financial irregularities, with auditors playing a crucial role in preventing such issues. While auditors are not responsible for detecting fraud, they must identify control weaknesses that could lead to financial misstatements. Effective governance practices, including transparency and accountability, are essential in preventing abuse and conflict of interest. Auditors should exercise professional scepticism and remain vigilant for tell-tale signs of financial irregularities. Ultimately, an audit is not a substitute for good corporate governance, which is the responsibility of NPO governing boards.

site_title: Invesco, BlackRock cut SingPost stakes amid mysterious share plunge
summary: Invesco and BlackRock, two prominent asset managers, have reduced their stakes in SingPost, a Singaporean postal and e-commerce group, amid a mysterious 6.2% drop in its shares. Invesco sold 19.7 million shares, reducing its stake from 1.02% to 0.10%, while BlackRock pared its stake from 0.72% to 0.71%. The sudden sell-off, along with a spike in volume, has left SingPost unable to explain the unusual trading activity. The group has launched a new stamp set and is awaiting the outcome of an impending corporate governance probe.

site_title: IMF breakthrough seen bolstering US on world stage
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reached a breakthrough agreement with the US, ending a five-year stalemate over its governance structure overhaul. The surprise accord, reached last month, has eased concerns that the US is retreating from global economic leadership. The agreement, which includes restrictions on the IMF's bailouts of deeply indebted countries, has been approved by Congress and paves the way for the US to reassert its leadership role in the organization. The overhaul, which was first proposed in 2010, aims to reset members' quotas and voting shares to better reflect the current global landscape.

site_title: Woman power
summary: The M1 Fringe Festival in Singapore features a strong feminine presence, with many works by female playwrights and actors. The festival's director, Sean Tobin, notes that the "girl power" and "animal power" themes intersect, with human bestiary featuring five female actors and other productions exploring the connection between humans and nature. The festival also showcases the work of artist Lucy Davis, who created the multimedia installation "Railtrack Songmaps," which explores the sounds and stories of birds in Singapore. Additionally, the festival features "The Chronicles of Zero and One: Kancil," a retelling of a Malaysian cartoon series with a female lead, and "BITCH: The Origin of the Female Species," an exploration of the origins of the female species from a dog's and woman's perspective.

site_title: Soros sees crisis in global markets that echoes 2008
summary: Billionaire George Soros warns of a global market crisis similar to the 2008 financial downturn, citing China's struggling economy and currency devaluation as major concerns. China's major adjustment problem and a return to positive interest rates pose significant challenges for the developing world. Global markets have seen a decline in value, with nearly $2.5 trillion wiped from global equities this year, and measures of volatility surge. Soros notes that the current environment has similarities to the 2008 crisis, prompting investors to be cautious.

site_title: Sugar taxes can work, but effect is small, says UK professor
summary: UK professor Graham MacGregor's study suggests reducing sugar in sweetened drinks or taxing it can lead to a 16-39 calorie drop per day, potentially preventing 274,000-309,000 obesity-related type 2 diabetes cases over 20 years. A 40% reduction in free sugars added to drinks in Britain resulted in a 38.4 calorie drop per day, while a 10% tax on sugar-sweetened drinks in Mexico led to a 12% reduction in sales. However, experts say the effect is small, with Tom Sanders stating that a 300-500 calorie reduction per day is needed to prevent obesity.

site_title: China goes underground to expand its strategic oil reserves
summary: China is building underground caverns to expand its strategic oil reserves, with five sites identified, including a completed 19 million-barrel facility in Huangdao, Shandong province. The caverns, expected to hold around 130 million barrels, will account for nearly a quarter of China's 550 million-barrel SPR target by 2020. Underground storage is cheaper and less prone to sabotage, but construction is taking longer than expected due to technical problems and challenges in adapting to local geological conditions.

site_title: New platform for young shutterbugs
summary: A new exhibition, Undescribed, showcases emerging local artists and photographers at DECK gallery in Singapore. The inaugural exhibition features six young photographers, including Lyn Low, who captures intimate and emotional moments of her family members dealing with physical and mental struggles. The exhibition aims to support the next generation of image makers and provide a platform for emerging voices in Singapore photography.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: China's 7% plunge sends stocks reeling - again
summary: China's stock market plummeted 7% on January 7, 2016, triggering circuit breakers and suspending trading for the day. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,729.91, down 2.7% and its lowest close in 2.5 years. Global equities have been under pressure due to China's devalued yuan, excessive leverage, and slowing economy. The Dow futures plunged 250 points, and US stocks fell 1.3-1.5% on Wednesday. The incident marked the fourth consecutive session of selling, with Singapore's stock market experiencing its worst start to a year since 2008.

site_title: Two independent directors at China Gaoxian resign
summary: Two independent directors at China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings, Sydney Yeung Kin Bond and Roberto Fabbri, have resigned effective January 6, 2016, due to personal work commitments. This leaves the company with fewer independent directors in Singapore, a requirement of at least two. The board aims to appoint more independent directors within two months. The company faces challenges after its independent auditor raised concerns over missing financial records and unexplained differences between management accounts and audited statements in 2013.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit sells Roppongi property for 2.5b yen
summary: Starhill Global Reit sold its 2.5 billion yen (S$30.5 million) Roppongi Terzo property in Tokyo, yielding 4.4%. The sale proceeds will be used to repay loans and set aside for working capital. This is the third divestment in Japan in three years, as part of the reit's strategy to streamline its portfolio and focus on strengths.

site_title: Yahoo plans to cut staff as investor seeks changes
summary: Yahoo plans to cut its workforce by at least 10%, affecting over 1,000 employees, as activist investor Starboard Value urges changes to the company's leadership and direction. Starboard has criticized CEO Marissa Mayer and her leadership team, citing poor performance and deteriorating financials. The move comes after Yahoo abandoned plans to spin off its Alibaba stake, with Starboard suggesting a sale or spinoff of the core business is necessary to improve performance and regain shareholder confidence.

site_title: Managing CPF funds is one thing; reviving the stock market is another
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has proposed changing the way Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies are managed to boost the Singapore stock market. However, this plan could require CPF account holders to accept lower guaranteed returns or greater risk to their retirement funds. The proposal would also require the CPF pension fund to invest in riskier assets, which could compromise the safety net for Singaporean workers. Experts question the feasibility of this plan, citing concerns about the impact on returns and the potential for unequal benefits.

site_title: Jennifer Lawrence a Joy to watch as real-life firecracker
summary: Jennifer Lawrence shines in the biopic "Joy," a dark comedy about the life of Joy Mangano, a single mother who becomes a self-made millionaire after inventing the self-wringing mop. Director David O. Russell takes creative liberties with the facts, making the film feel less realistic. Despite this, Lawrence's performance is the heart of the movie, showcasing her talent as a strong female character. The film follows Mangano's journey from her dysfunctional family to her entrepreneurial success, but some may find the fictionalized account less inspiring than the real-life story.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: 25 under-the-radar artists in Gillman Barracks carpark
summary: A non-commercial pop-up exhibition called Scout is set to take place in Gillman Barracks carpark, showcasing works by 25 emerging Singapore artists. The show, which runs from January 18-24, features artists from various backgrounds, including overseas-based Singaporean artists and fresh art school graduates. The exhibition aims to provide a platform for these artists to gain visibility and feedback on their practice, with events including meet-and-greet sessions and talks by veteran artists. Admission is free, offering a unique opportunity for art lovers to discover new talent.

site_title: US jobless claims fall from five-month high
summary: US jobless claims fell to 277,000 in the week ending Jan 2, down from a five-month high, suggesting the labor market remains stable despite slowing economic growth. This marks the 44th straight week of claims below 300,000, the longest run since the 1970s. The four-week moving average of claims also decreased to 275,750. The data supports views of the economy's healthy fundamentals, which are expected to be reinforced by a report on Friday showing nonfarm payrolls increased 200,000 in December.

site_title: US carmakers enter 2016 facing slower growth after record year
summary: US carmakers enter 2016 with a sense of slower growth after a record year in 2015, with sales rising 5.7% to 17.5 million cars and light trucks. Despite incentives, sales missed predictions in December, with some companies, like Ford, keeping incentives steady. The industry projects another record year, but with slower growth, driven by a tougher market and higher incentives. The US economy is strong, with low unemployment and rising jobs, but interest rates have risen, affecting consumer spending.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings, a struggling yarn maker, has seen two independent directors resign, bringing the number below the minimum of two. Meanwhile, Starhill Global Reit has sold its Tokyo property for 2.5 billion yen, yielding 4.4%. The sale proceeds will be used to repay loans and for working capital.

site_title: China suspends 'circuit breaker' mechanism after stock trading halted again
summary: China's top securities regulator suspended the "circuit breaker" mechanism, which halted trading when share prices dropped more than 7% for the second time this week. The mechanism, introduced to reduce volatility, was deemed counter-productive, causing panic among investors. It will be lifted on Friday, with analysts stating that market stability was not maintained. The system, triggered by the CSI 300 index, was suspended after a seven percent drop was reached just one minute after trading resumed on Thursday, prompting an early halt for the rest of the day.

site_title: GS Holdings launches S$6m Catalist IPO
summary: GS Holdings, a Singapore-based company that provides dishwashing services to F&B outlets, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) worth S$6 million on the Catalist market. The company will issue 24 million shares at S$0.25 each, with net proceeds expected to be approximately S$4.1 million. Listing and trading are scheduled to begin on January 18, 2016.

site_title: Fed's Lacker urges higher rates as inflation heads back to goal
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Jeffrey Lacker urged higher interest rates, citing a gradual increase in rates of about 1 percentage point per year, as inflation is expected to return to the central bank's 2% target after oil prices and the US dollar stabilize. Lacker expressed confidence in the economy's growth of 2.2% this year, driven by stronger consumer spending and government outlays. He supported the Federal Open Market Committee's decision to raise interest rates and recommended a continued tightening of monetary policy, differing from some Fed officials who expressed concerns about the downside risks to the 2% target.

site_title: GE signs deals of US$157b as part of GE Capital divestment
summary: General Electric Co signed US$157 billion in transactions in 2015 as part of its efforts to divest most of its finance business, GE Capital. The company has closed US$104 billion in deals, reducing GE Capital to less than 10% of total earnings. GE Capital accounted for 42% of GE's profit in 2014. An active sales process is ongoing for the remaining international businesses.

site_title: The Republicans' civil war - or the Trump phenomenon
summary: The Republican Party is experiencing a civil war, with the Donald Trump phenomenon being a subplot of a larger issue: the party's internal class war. According to commentator David Frum, the party has traditionally run on a pro-business platform, but this is rejected by much of the party's voter base, who support entitlement spending and higher taxes on the rich. A Gallup poll found that nearly 30% of Republicans advocate for "heavy" taxes on the wealthy, contradicting the party's traditional elite. This economic and social chasm threatens the party's survival, as the Republican Party has historically overcome deep conflicts and contradictions among its supporters.

site_title: HDB, AHTC now locked in disagreement over choice of accountant
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) and HDB are in disagreement with Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) over the choice of accountant to rectify contraventions of the Town Councils Act. The Court of Appeal ordered AHTC to appoint accountants, but HDB disputes AHTC's choice of Business Assurance, citing a lack of expertise and experience. AHTC attempted to limit the accountants' terms of reference, but the Court disagreed. The parties will appear before the Court of Appeal again next week.

site_title: Luxury home sales drive already hot Vancouver market
summary: Vancouver's luxury home market saw a 66.8% increase in sales of homes over C$4 million in 2015, driven by international demand and limited inventory. The city's overall property value soared 16% to a record C$636 billion. Sales in the C$1 million to C$2 million range jumped 43.3% and those in the C$2 million to C$4 million range climbed 46.2%. The city's mayor, Gregor Robertson, has called for a speculation tax and luxury tax to slow flipping activity and address concerns about foreign investment and tax fairness.

site_title: US: Wall St opens sharply lower on China woes, oil
summary: US stocks opened sharply lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 189.94 points, or 1.12%, to 16,716.57, following China's yuan decline and oil prices hitting 12-year lows, raising concerns over the global economy. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes also fell, with the S&P 500 down 21.6 points, or 1.09%, to 1,968.66, and the Nasdaq dropping 103.30 points, or 2.14%, to 4,732.46.

site_title: Facebook Messenger app grows to more than 800m users
summary: Facebook's Messenger app has surpassed 800 million monthly users, with features such as video calling and money transfer on the way. The app has seen improvements in speed and user experience, and Facebook is testing its "M" digital virtual assistant. Messenger is also exploring partnerships with businesses and services, including Uber, to enhance its capabilities. The milestone marks a significant step for the app, with Facebook CEO Dave Marcus stating it's "early days" for Messenger.

site_title: Casting a net over the whole world
summary: Netflix has officially launched in Singapore, offering basic streaming for S$10.98/month and premium streaming for S$16.98/month. The service initially lacks the full US catalogue, but will offer a curated selection of titles, including local content, and aims to double its catalogue size in the first year. Netflix's success is attributed to its original content, including shows like Orange Is The New Black and Narcos, and movies like Beasts of No Nation. The company's global expansion aims to provide a global internet TV network, with plans to eventually offer a fully global service.

site_title: CEO of IHC retires, vice-president of investments to take over duties
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) announced that CEO Fan Kow Hin will retire at the end of the month. His responsibilities will be taken over by Lim Beng Choo, vice-president of investments. Lim has a direct interest in 618,906 IHC shares and a deemed interest in 534,032 shares held by her spouse. This change comes as IHC continues to provide healthcare services.

site_title: Monumental artworks set to stun public
summary: A monumental exhibition titled "Envision" is set to debut in Singapore next weekend, featuring 13 large artworks by 11 renowned artists at six different locations. The exhibition includes pieces by China's Gu Wenda, Taiwan's Ju Ming, and Singapore's Kumari Nahappan, among others. The artworks, which took years to create, will be displayed until April 15 and aim to enrich Singapore's landscape, with plans to make it an annual project. The exhibition is organized by iPreciation and supported by various government agencies and the Fullerton Heritage.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Record sukuk yields hamper budget balance
summary: Malaysia's budget deficit may worsen as Islamic bond yields rise to a record 5%, according to Maybank Islamic Asset Management Sdn. The bank predicts benchmark sukuk yields will increase due to rising US interest rates, which could impact the nation's largest lender. Prime Minister Najib Razak's goal to balance the budget by 2020 may be complicated, and companies in the syariah-compliant debt market face a bleak outlook.

images.alt_text: The current central bank governor is due to retire in April, clouding the policy outlook. Analysts say that the market is anxiously waiting for the announcement of who the next governor will be and the opportunity to gauge his or her hawkishness.

site_title: Catalist transfer rejected by SGX over ongoing debt restructuring: Ley Choon
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Ley Choon Group Holdings' transfer from the mainboard to Catalist due to the company's ongoing debt restructuring plan, which affects its 12-month working capital needs. Ley Choon had planned to transfer to Catalist to meet the SGX's requirement of a six-month average-weighted trading price of at least 20 Singapore cents. The company will re-apply after finalizing its debt restructuring plan and securing acceptance from financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Ley Choon Group Holdings, an engineering firm in the midst of restructuring its debt with lenders, on Thursday said the Singapore Exchange (SGX) had rejected its transfer from mainboard to Catalist due to its ongoing debt restructuring plan and the impact on its 12-month working capital needs.

site_title: DBS mum on reports of its suspension from China forex business
summary: DBS Bank has not confirmed whether it has been banned from trading foreign exchange in China, despite reports suggesting a suspension. OCBC and UOB have stated they face no ban on trading forex in China. The People's Bank of China has tightened regulations on cross-border arbitrage activities, which may have led to the suspensions of banks like Standard Chartered and DBS. The clampdown aims to prevent banks from "gaming the system" and comes amid China's economic turmoil, including a falling yuan.

images.alt_text: OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank (UOB) both confirmed on Thursday that they continue to trade foreign exchange in China, unlike several banks like compatriot DBS Bank that are said to have been banned from doing so.

site_title: Fifa ethics committee opens formal proceedings against secretary general
summary: Fifa's ethics committee has opened formal proceedings against secretary general Jerome Valcke, following an investigation that recommended a 9-year ban and a 100,000 Swiss franc fine due to corruption allegations involving the sale of World Cup tickets.

images.alt_text: The market for global soccer player transfers reached US$4.2 billion in 2015, up 2.6 per cent from the year before and largely attributed to the wealthy clubs in the English Premier League, according to Fifa's Global Transfer Market Report.

site_title: City buzz
summary: A city-focused exhibition in Singapore, "1000 Singapores: Eight Points of the Compact City," explores sustainable urban planning and compact city design. The show, featuring Singapore and Paris's planning strategies, is open until January 28. Additionally, the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra will perform Vivaldi's "The Four Seasons" at the Singapore Botanic Gardens on January 10. The Open Farm Community in Dempsey will host a social market with food, produce, and activities, while Rocks Urban Bar + Grill reopens at Marina Bay with its menu. Drum Tao's "Hyakka Ryoran - Hanabi" is also set to perform at The Theatre @ Mediacorp from January 7 to 9.

images.alt_text: The 1000 Singapores: Eight Points of the Compact City exhibition highlights the issue of liveability and offers solutions.
Six members of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra will be performing Vivaldi's The Four Seasons at the Botanic Gardens.
Food truck Kerbside Gourmet will be there to serve cooked food. Other vendors include Oh Chin Huat Hydroponic Farms, local cheesemaker Halloumi, and Casse-Croute.
Rocks Urban Bar + Grill is back in the same place at Marina Bay after a six month absence. Doors reopen next Tuesday
The Seafood Papillote pairs well with the Paul Pillot Bourgogne Rouge 2012.
Drum Tao 2016: Hyakka Ryoran - Hanabi

site_title: Singapore's BOC Aviation orders 30 Airbus jets worth US$3 billion
summary: Singapore-based aircraft leasing firm BOC Aviation ordered 30 Airbus A320s worth over US$3 billion at list prices, meeting growing demand. The order includes 18 re-engined A320s and 12 standard A320s. BOC Aviation becomes one of Airbus' top 10 customers, following a previous order of 22 Boeing 737 planes in November. The single-aisle A320 and B737 families are popular among low-cost carriers in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based aircraft leasing firm BOC Aviation said Thursday it has ordered 30 Airbus A320s worth more than US$3 billion at list prices to meet growing demand.

site_title: Global investment fund assets fell 5.9% in Q3: EFAMA
summary: Global investment fund assets fell 5.9% to 34.9 trillion euros at end-September 2015, down from 37.1 trillion euros at end-June 2015. This decline was attributed to concerns over global growth, particularly in China, and sharp falls in net inflows into long-term funds. In dollar terms, assets dropped 5.7% to US$39.1 trillion.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Reits and broker recommendations: Ascendas Reit's new equity raise dilutes FY2017-2018 distribution, but maintains a "Hold" rating with a target price of S$2.23. Noble Group's share price volatility persists after Moody's credit downgrade, with a "Hold" rating and target price of S$0.44. ISOTeam acquires TMG Projects, maintaining a "Buy" rating with a target price of S$0.73. CSE Global's earnings forecast is trimmed due to slowdown in large greenfield projects, resulting in a "Hold" rating with a target price of S$0.49. Analysts also comment on the upcoming change in OCBC's CEO.

site_title: Macy's to sell stakes in flagship store buildings
summary: Macy's Inc is selling stakes in its flagship store buildings, including its Manhattan store, to extract value from its property holdings amid declining sales and profits. The company has hired Eastdil Secured LLC to approach potential interested parties, with Tishman Speyer expressing interest in taking stakes in the four flagship stores. This move comes after Macy's rejected a proposal to form a real estate investment trust, which was endorsed by activist investor Starboard Value. The 34th Street store is considered one of the most significant retail buildings in the world, with high profile and visibility.

images.alt_text: Macy's Inc is seeking to sell stakes in its flagship stores, including its landmark building on West 34th Street in Manhattan's Herald Square, one of New York's top tourist attractions.

site_title: Britain's Osborne says interest rates will rise at some point: BBC
summary: British finance minister George Osborne stated that interest rates in Britain will rise at some point, potentially indicating economic strength. He emphasized the independence of the Bank of England's rate-setters and highlighted that Britain's economic recovery is not fueled by consumer debt, citing falling household debt levels and rising wages. Osborne's comments follow the US Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates from record low levels in December.

images.alt_text: British finance minister George Osborne said on Thursday there will come a point when interest rates rise from record low levels in Britain, and that could be interpreted a sign of economic strength.

site_title: Jazz diva pays tribute to heroes and legends
summary: Diana Krall, a renowned jazz diva, returns to Singapore in February for two concerts as part of her Wallflower World Tour. The critically acclaimed album, released in 2015, features a mix of pop classics and jazz standards, including songs by 10cc, The Mamas and Papas, and The Eagles. Krall will perform with her six-piece band, which includes her husband Elvis Costello, at the Esplanade Concert Hall on February 16 and 17. The concerts will feature a mix of songs from the album and others outside of it, showcasing Krall's versatility as a performer.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
For a change, Wallflower doesn't feature Diana Krall playing the piano; instead she left that task to her producer-arranger David Foster so she could concentrate on just singing for a change.

site_title: Oil falls to lowest since 2003 as yuan drop shows China turmoil
summary: Oil prices plummeted to a 12-year low of $32.10 a barrel in New York, driven by speculation of slower economic growth in China, which could curb fuel demand and worsen the global oversupply. China's central bank reduced the yuan's fixing to its lowest since March 2011, triggering a selloff and closure of Chinese stock exchanges. The move has further fueled concerns about China's economic turmoil, leading to a bearish outlook for oil prices.

site_title: UK house prices surge more than expected in Dec: Halifax
summary: British house prices surged 1.7% in December, exceeding expectations, to reach a four-month high. This marks the 9.5% growth over the past three months, stronger than economists' predicted 9.0% increase. The UK housing market is showing signs of growing momentum, with homebuyer demand rebounding to a six-month high.

images.alt_text: British house prices surged more than expected in December to hit a four-month high, mortgage lender Halifax said on Thursday, another sign of growing momentum in the housing market.

site_title: UK new car sales hit all-time high in 2015: SMMT
summary: UK new car sales reached an all-time high in 2015, with 2.63 million registrations, a 6.3% increase from the previous year. The industry body attributes this to rising consumer confidence, the strong pound, and cheap car loans. Volkswagen saw a 4% increase in full-year sales, while Skoda and Seat experienced declines of 1% and 11% respectively.

images.alt_text: British new car registrations hit an all-time high last year, an industry body said on Thursday, helped by rising consumer confidence, the strength of the pound and cheap car loans.

site_title: As markets crash, Fed-watching has turned to PBOC-watching
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has fixed the onshore yuan 1.6% lower versus the US dollar, year to date, amid a market crash and worries about a China slowdown and rising US interest rates. The yuan's depreciation has sparked global turmoil, with analysts warning that a 10% depreciation could have dramatic effects on financial markets. The PBOC's actions have made it a key player in global markets, with investors closely watching its moves, much like they did with the US Federal Reserve in the past.

site_title: Koh Brothers injects construction arm into listed subsidiary
summary: Koh Brothers Group is injecting its construction arm, Koh Brothers Building & Civil Engineering (KBCE), into its listed subsidiary, Koh Brothers Eco Engineering (KB Eco), for S$19 million. This move aims to streamline businesses and focus on property development, building materials, and leisure and hospitality. The enlarged KB Eco will become a one-stop engineering solutions company with greater cost efficiencies. The injection will also shore up KB Eco's stake in the group from 41% to 70.1-72.3%, with plans to expand into mechanical and electrical engineering through mergers and acquisitions.

images.alt_text: "Since Koh Brothers Group acquired a stake in KB Eco, KB Eco's financials have turned profitable. . ." says Mr Koh.

site_title: Oil slides below US$30 to near 12-year low as China turmoil rattles investors
summary: Oil prices slid below $30 a barrel, a 12-year low, due to turmoil in Chinese markets and a global commodities rout. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) members' daily basket price fell to $29.71 a barrel, with West Texas Intermediate crude and Brent crude also declining. Analysts attribute the slide to weakening demand, particularly in Asia and China, which is experiencing its slowest economic growth in a generation, and a storage overhang of excess oil supplies.

images.alt_text: The price of crude sold by Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) members slid below US$30 a barrel, the lowest level in almost 12 years, as turmoil in Chinese markets deepened the global commodities rout.

site_title: Consumer comfort rises as Americans turn more upbeat on economy
