summary: US consumer confidence reached a 12-week high, increasing to 44.2 in the week ending January 3, driven by improved attitudes towards the economy and personal finances. This marks the fifth consecutive rise in the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index, the highest level since October 11. The gain was led by optimism in the Northeast and Midwest, while confidence in the South and West declined. Steady labor market gains and low prices may be contributing to the increased consumer comfort.

site_title: UBS Asset says China volatility spells continued bond boost
summary: China's stock market turmoil is expected to extend a bull run in the nation's bonds, as investors channel funds into debt securities to avoid equity volatility. The yield premium on corporate notes has fallen eight basis points this week, while China's CSI 300 Index has dropped 12% this year. Rising demand for fixed-income securities will help Chinese companies raise money amid debt repayment struggles. Borrowing costs are falling, with the overnight repurchase rate declining 17 basis points this year.

images.alt_text: UBS Asset Management said turmoil in China's stock market will help extend a bull run in the nation's bonds, as investors channel more funds into debt securities to avoid equity volatility.

site_title: Koh Brothers injects construction arm into listed subsidiary
summary: Koh Brothers Group is injecting its construction arm, Koh Brothers Building & Civil Engineering (Pte) Ltd, into its listed subsidiary, Koh Brothers Eco Engineering (KB Eco), for S$19 million. This move aims to streamline businesses and focus on property development, building materials, and leisure hospitality. Post-restructuring, KB Eco will become a one-stop engineering solutions company with greater cost efficiencies. This deal will increase KB Eco's stake in the group from 41% to 70.1-72.3%, depending on outstanding warrants.

site_title: German industry orders rise more than expected in November
summary: German industrial orders rose 1.5% in November, beating expectations and indicating a stronger-than-expected upturn in the manufacturing industry. This follows a 2.6% increase in domestic demand, compared to a 0.6% rise in foreign orders. The data suggests a shift towards more domestic activity in the German economy, which could help the country better weather a slowdown in emerging markets. This marks the second consecutive monthly rise in industrial orders and reinforces positive sentiment indicators for the industry.

site_title: Volkswagen expects to buy back 115,000 diesel cars in US: report
summary: Volkswagen expects to buy back approximately 115,000 diesel vehicles in the US due to the pollution-cheating scandal, which affects around 580,000 vehicles. The buy-back could take the form of a cash payment or a new vehicle at a large discount. The US authorities will decide on the method in January. This move comes as Volkswagen is facing global fines and lawsuits over the scandal, which has impacted sales and could cost the company billions of euros.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen Chief Executive Matthias Mueller has cast doubt on a report which last week said many managers at the German carmaker knew of, or were involved in, developing emissions test-rigging devices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 12.84 points to close at 1,655.13, with 3.05 billion lots valued at RM2.27 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 253-721. No specific reason for the decline was mentioned.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIAN shares ended lower on Thursday with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 12.84 points to close at 1,655.13.

site_title: China keeps 2014 GDP growth rate unchanged at 7.3%
summary: China maintained its 2014 GDP growth rate at 7.3% in the final verification, with a revised GDP of 63.591 trillion yuan (US$9.65 trillion). The revision downed the services sector size, but overall growth remained unchanged. This decision comes ahead of the release of 2015 full-year GDP data on January 19.

images.alt_text: China kept its annual economic growth rate in 2014 unchanged at 7.3 per cent in its final verification of the data though it revised down the value of gross domestic product slightly, the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) said on Thursday.

site_title: Change in investment grade status will not have material impact: Noble
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, has seen its investment grade status downgraded to junk status by credit ratings agency Standard & Poor's. Despite this, the company believes the change will not have a material impact on its operations. Noble attributed the lack of significant impact to reduced collateral calls and improved liquidity following asset sales. The company remains confident that a proposed deal will close before the end of February, substantially exceeding investment grade credit metrics. Its share price slumped 9.2% to 34.5 Singapore cents after the downgrade.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slump more than 3% by close
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.09% to 20,333.34, following a seven percent collapse in mainland markets. The yuan-dollar value hit a five-year low, causing trading to be suspended after 30 minutes. This marks the fourth consecutive trading day of losses, with the Hang Seng Index down over seven percent for the year.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks rose Friday, at the end of a tumultuous week dominated by sharp sell-offs in Chinese markets that fuelled a worldwide rout on raised fears about the global economy.

site_title: China's stockmarket circuit breaker slammed for stoking volatility
summary: China's circuit breaker, designed to halt trade when the market plunges, has been criticized for stoking volatility instead of calming it. Introduced on Jan 4, the mechanism suspends trade for 15 minutes when the market falls 5% and halts it for the day after a 7% fall. Analysts say the trigger levels are too low and too close together, leading to selling pressure rather than cooling it. Experts recommend adjusting the threshold levels and considering alternative approaches, such as Singapore's dynamic limit system.

site_title: George Soros sees crisis in global markets that echoes 2008
summary: Billionaire George Soros warns of a global market crisis, citing similarities to the 2008 crisis, as China struggles to find a new growth model and its currency devaluation affects the rest of the world. The yuan's devaluation and China's sluggish manufacturing sector have led to a decline in global equities, with over $2.5 trillion wiped from their value this year. Soros calls the current environment a "serious challenge" and a "crisis" for the developing world, urging investors to be cautious.

site_title: Indonesia, S Korea sign US$1.3b fighter jet development deal
summary: Indonesia and South Korea signed a $1.3 billion deal to jointly develop the Korean Fighter Experimental (KF-X) fighter jets, replacing the country's aged fleet of F-4 and F-5 fighters. Indonesia will invest $1.3 billion, accounting for about one fifth of the total cost, with up to 100 Indonesian workers involved in development and production. The deal aims to produce new fighter jets by 2025 to guard against threats from North Korea. Indonesia will receive one prototype plane and technical data.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall sharply as worries over China intensify
summary: European shares fell sharply on Thursday, with the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index and the euro zone's Euro STOXX index declining 2% and 1.4%, respectively. China's yuan depreciation accelerated, with the official midpoint rate set at 6.5646 per dollar, the lowest since March 2011. Stock markets in China were suspended for the day due to a circuit-breaking mechanism, fueling concerns that China's economy may be weaker than previously thought. Investors expressed worries about the slowdown in China, citing fragile investor sentiment.

site_title: Opec switches to Argus from Platts for energy price data
summary: Opec has switched to Argus Media as its energy price data provider, replacing Platts, starting January 1. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will use Argus's prices for evaluation, analysis, and reporting. This decision comes after Opec producers such as Saudi Arabia continued to set their own prices based on Platts's benchmarks. Argus's chairman Adrian Binks expressed confidence in the quality of their price reporting, while IHS Energy Insight's Victor Shum noted that Platts remains the dominant player in the market.

site_title: Samsung warns of a challenging 2016 amid competition
summary: Samsung Electronics Co expects a challenging 2016 due to weak global economic growth and intensifying competition in the industry. The company's vice chairman, Kwon Oh Hyun, emphasized the need to adapt to changing market conditions by focusing on software and platforms. Samsung has replaced its phone operations head with an executive who helped develop mobile payment and security platforms, signaling a shift in priorities. The company's shares have declined 5.1% in the past year, and analysts project its lowest profit in four years.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co expects global economic growth to remain weak this year and urged employees to brainstorm ways to handle intensifying competition in an industry where software and platforms are eclipsing hardware.

site_title: European banks set for more job cuts in Asian equities as China meltdown hits profits
summary: European banks are set to cut more jobs in Asian equities as China's meltdown hits profits, with BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank, and Barclays likely to trim operations in non-core markets. Weaker revenue and tighter regulations have dulled returns in the Asia equities business, making it less attractive. Industry insiders say banks will focus on more profitable markets, such as the US, and assess the profitability of businesses in Asia. The cuts follow a tough 2015 for brokers, with turmoil in Chinese stocks and unpredictable central bank action.

site_title: Noble Group cut to junk at S&P following downgrade by Moody's
summary: Noble Group's credit rating was downgraded to junk by Standard & Poor's, following a similar move by Moody's Investors Service. The downgrade affects the company's local and foreign currency ratings, BB+ from BBB-, amid financial challenges and attacks on its accounting. Noble Group lost almost two-thirds of its value in 2015 and agreed to sell its agricultural unit to China's Cofco Corp for at least US$750 million to bolster its finances and reduce debt.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd's credit-rating was reduced to junk by Standard & Poor's and placed on watch for further cuts, deepening the challenges facing Asia's top commodity trader as it seeks to sustain investors' faith amid the raw-materials rout and attacks on its accounting.

site_title: Opec crude oil plunges below US$30 for first time since 2004
summary: Opec crude oil prices have fallen below $30 a barrel for the first time in 12 years, hitting a record low since 2004. The price slump is attributed to turmoil in Chinese markets and concerns about the nation's economy, which has also affected Opec's weaker members like Venezuela. Opec, the world's largest oil supplier, left its production limits unchanged, and Saudi Arabia, its largest producer, may reconsider its strategy if low prices don't lead to significant cuts in non-Opec supply by 2018.

site_title: M&S CEO Marc Bolland to retire in April
summary: M&S CEO Marc Bolland will retire in April, ending six years of struggling to revive the British retailer. Despite efforts to redesign products and improve logistics, the company reported poor Christmas trading, with like-for-like sales in its general merchandise division falling 5.8%. Bolland will be succeeded by Steve Rowe, current head of non-food business, who has been praised by Bolland as a great leader for M&S. The weak trading highlights the company's struggles to compete with rivals such as Next and John Lewis.

site_title: China to remove gold import license for industrial purposes: customs
summary: China will no longer require a central bank permit for gold imports for industrial purposes starting this year, according to the General Administration of Customs. This change applies to gold processing for watches, coins, and other industrial uses. The move aims to reduce regulatory hurdles for gold importers and support the country's growing industrial sector.

site_title: Oil producers have US$100 billion wiped out in worst start to year
summary: Oil prices have plummeted, wiping over $100 billion from the Bloomberg World Oil & Gas Index, marking the worst start to a year on record. Crude oil has dropped 5.6% and is nearing $30 a barrel, driven by concerns over China's economy, a global supply glut, and record production levels. Companies are slashing spending, reducing jobs, and suspending dividends to ride out the slump, with many expecting a prolonged downturn. Brent crude has hit an 11-year low, and analysts warn of further price drops, citing an imbalance in the market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China accelerated yuan depreciation, causing regional currencies and stock markets to tumble as investors feared competitive currency devaluations. Noble Group, Asia's largest commodity trader, fell to its lowest since 2008. The Singapore dollar slid to a six-year low after China's central bank reduced its reference rate for the yuan. Global markets face a crisis, with billionaire George Soros warning of a 2008-like scenario. The Straits Times Index closed 2.7% lower, marking its lowest close in about three and a half years, amidst concerns of economic slowdown and currency fluctuations.

site_title: Global stocks extend rout with commodities as Soros sees crisis
summary: Global stocks declined, with European and Asian shares hitting three-month lows, amid concerns over China's weakening yuan. The yuan's reference rate fell 0.5% for the first time since August, and the offshore yuan plummeted to a five-year low. US crude oil slid 4.2% to its lowest close in two decades, while copper and nickel also dropped. Billionaire George Soros warned of a crisis, citing a major adjustment problem in China's economy. The crisis has wiped $2.5 trillion off global equities since the start of the year.

site_title: Fitch: Noble able to manage increased collateral requirements
summary: Fitch Ratings says Noble Group Limited can manage increased collateral requirements following a series of credit events in 2015, despite a downgrade to sub-investment grade. Noble's asset sales have improved its liquidity, allowing it to cover additional margin requirements of $100-200 million. Fitch will continue to monitor the situation and may take negative rating action if collateral needs or funding costs increase significantly.

site_title: Malaysia palm output seen at 10-month low, trims stockpiles
summary: Malaysia's palm oil production has fallen to a 10-month low, with inventories dropping 5.2% to 2.76 million metric tons in December. Production slid 18% to 1.36 million tons, while exports fell 6% to 1.41 million tons. The decline is expected to continue, with analysts predicting a further drop in production in January and February. Futures prices have already risen, and experts predict a 14-18% increase in prices this year due to tightening supplies and sluggish demand from buyers such as China and India.

site_title: SGX reprimands Abterra chairman, CEO over breaches in listing rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Abterra's chairman, Cai Sui Xin, and CEO, Lau Yu, for breaches in listing rules. The reprimand is based on a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers and responses from Abterra, which failed to act in the best interest of shareholders in acquiring a 22.8% stake in Zuoquan Xinrui Metallurgy Mine Co Limited and failing to disclose material changes in the terms of a sale and purchase agreement. Abterra has been directed to appoint a compliance adviser and referred to relevant authorities.

site_title: Brent crude hits new 11-year low as China worries add to glut
summary: Brent crude prices hit a fresh 11-year low of $33.09 per barrel, following China's yuan devaluation and concerns over its economy. The decline is attributed to a global glut of oil, near-record production, and slowing demand. Global benchmark Brent crude futures have fallen 70% since mid-2014, with US storage overhangs struggling to cope with excess oil. Analysts predict cheap prices for much of this year due to the shaky global economy and lack of coordinated production cuts from major producers.

site_title: About 760 more govt-funded buses added to public bus fleet
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has added 760 government-funded buses to Singapore's public bus network as of December 31, 2015, part of the Bus Service Enhancement Programme (BSEP). This brings the total to 1,000 buses by 2017. New bus services were introduced, including 80 weekly peak-hour trips, and existing services were extended. The BSEP aims to expand the public bus fleet by 35% through government funding and partnerships with private operators.

site_title: Euro-area economic confidence increases to highest since 2011
summary: Euro-area economic confidence has risen to its highest level since 2011, increasing to 106.8 in December from 106.1 in November. Unemployment fell to 10.5% and joblessness in the region reached its lowest in four years. Retail sales declined 0.3% for the third consecutive month, but economists attribute this to seasonal factors. The European Central Bank's stimulus efforts appear to be providing some impetus to the region's fragile recovery, with inflation remaining at 0.2%. This increase in confidence offers some respite to the bank after investors expressed disappointment over its latest stimulus effort.

site_title: China to see a market-based yuan currency mechanism in 2016
summary: China plans to introduce a market-based yuan currency mechanism in 2016, according to the China Foreign Exchange Trade System. The yuan was stable against a basket of currencies in 2015, and China has sufficient foreign exchange reserves. Economic fundamentals are expected to support the yuan in the long term, with no basis for continuous depreciation.

site_title: Singapore dollar's slide approaching band limit, Barclays says
summary: Singapore's dollar slid to a six-year low against the US currency, reaching S$1.4431, after China's central bank reduced its reference rate for the yuan. Barclays predicts the local dollar is near the bottom of its policy band and further declines are unlikely. Analysts forecast the currency will trade at S$1.44 by the end of the first quarter and S$1.47 by year-end.

site_title: Olam partners French firm to develop animal feed expertise in Nigeria
summary: Olam International has partnered with French feedstock company InVivo Animal Nutrition & Health to develop animal feed expertise in Nigeria. The two-year partnership will combine Olam's Africa experience with InVivo's proficiency in animal feed, focusing on technical assistance and expertise to develop solutions and products. Nigeria's commercial feed market is expected to grow at over 10% annually for the next five years, supporting the local economy and Olam's expansion into the space.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares touch 2-1/2-year lows on China free-fall
summary: Hong Kong's main stock indexes dropped to 2-1/2-year lows on January 7, 2016, as panic from China's 7% market free-fall spilled over to Hong Kong. The Hang Seng index fell 3.1% and the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index dropped 4.4% as all main sectors declined. China's CSI300 index slumped 7% after less than 30 minutes of trading, triggering the circuit breaker mechanism, and fears of an equity supply glut and weakening yuan contributed to the downturn.

site_title: Private housing site in Bedok South triggered for launch from Reserve List
summary: A 99-year-leasehold private housing site in Bedok South, Singapore, has been triggered for launch from the government's Reserve List after a developer committed to bid at least S$320 million, approximately S$580 per square foot. The 2.4-hectare site is expected to yield around 570 homes.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China lets yuan fall faster, share trading suspended as prices tumble
summary: China's central bank set the official midpoint rate of the yuan at 6.5646 per dollar, the lowest since March 2011, causing the currency to tumble 0.5% and triggering a halt in trading at China's stock markets. Regional currencies, including the Australian dollar, also fell sharply. The yuan's depreciation has raised concerns of a competitive devaluation to help China's struggling exporters, potentially leading to greater volatility and financial instability.

site_title: Fitch: China Fishery's winding-up risks reduced; uncertainties remain
summary: Fitch Ratings has reduced the risk of China Fishery Group Limited being liquidated after the High Court of Hong Kong ordered the removal of its provisional liquidators. The company's parent, Pacific Andes International Holdings Limited, has reached an agreement with majority club loan lenders to restructure China Fishery, including an independent accounting review and disposal of key assets. Fitch will review the ratings for China Fishery and consider positive rating action if the outcomes of upcoming court hearings and coupon payment are favorable.

site_title: OCBC, UOB confirm they can trade forex in China
summary: OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank (UOB) have confirmed they can continue trading foreign exchange in China, contradicting reports that several banks, including DBS Bank, were banned from doing so. DBS is among banks suspended from some forex business in China, with Standard Chartered and Deutsche Bank also affected. The clampdown was reportedly due to the growing offshore-onshore spread, making it profitable to buy and sell currency in Hong Kong and Shanghai.

site_title: Singapore shares close sharply weaker after China stocks plunge 7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted 2.7% on Thursday, marking its fourth consecutive session of selling, after China's stock market crashed 7% due to circuit breakers triggered by the significant drop. The index finished at 2,729.91 points, its lowest close in about three and a half years. The Dow futures also plummeted 250 points, indicating a rough start for Wall Street. The four-day loss for 2016 is now 153 points or 5.3%. Global equities have been under pressure due to China's devalued yuan, interest rate hikes, and concerns over the country's slowing economy.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 2% as China share markets halt trading on slump
summary: Singapore stocks fell 2% on Thursday due to a sharp decline in Chinese shares, triggering the automatic circuit-breaker mechanism and leading to a trading halt. The Straits Times Index dropped 56.58 points to 2,747.69, with top losers including Singapore banks and real estate companies. The Shanghai and Shenzhen markets will remain closed for the rest of Thursday, following a slump in Chinese shares.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks drop to three-month low as China weakens yuan
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted to a three-month low on January 7, 2016, after China's currency was weakened, sparking concerns about its economy. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 2.33% and the Topix index fell 2.08%. This move followed China's decision to weaken its yuan, fueling fears of a potential economic downturn. The drop in Tokyo shares was the lowest level since early October, as investors reacted to the weakening of the Chinese economy.

site_title: Thai Dec consumer sentiment rises to highest in 8 months: survey
summary: Thai consumer confidence rose to its highest in eight months in December, driven by a temporary tax break aimed at boosting domestic consumption. The 15,000 baht tax deduction allowed during the holiday season may lift 2015 GDP growth by 0.1-0.2 percentage point. This marks the highest level of consumer sentiment since April 2015.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump as weak data, China concerns unnerve investors
summary: Australian shares plummeted 2.2% on Thursday, the largest drop in three months, due to weak domestic economic data and concerns over slowing Chinese growth. Building approvals fell 13% in November, four times forecast by analysts. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 112.8 points to 5,010.3, marking its fifth consecutive decline in 2016, which is now 5.4% for the year.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks sink at open
summary: Stocks in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and the US plunged at the open, extending losses in Europe, as investors worry about China's economy. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.55%, the Shenzhen Composite Index slid 1.84%, and the Hang Seng Index dropped 0.99%. This follows a mixed day in Europe and the US, where mining and healthcare stocks rose, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged towards fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Flight to safety sends gold to 9-week high as stocks slump
summary: Gold prices rose to a 9-week high of $1,102.80 an ounce amid a global stock market rout, worries over the Chinese economy, and heightened geopolitical tensions. China stocks fell 7% and the yuan was guided sharply lower, prompting investors to channel money into safe-haven assets. The World Bank cut its global economic growth forecast, and North Korea's nuclear test added to market fears. Gold, silver, and platinum rose, while palladium slid to a 5-year low.

site_title: Turbulence in China punishes oil to copper as gold haven emerges
summary: China's central bank cut the yuan's daily reference rate, guiding the currency lower and exacerbating market turmoil. The move, intended to stimulate the export sector, has made commodities such as oil, copper, and corn more expensive to import. The Bloomberg Commodity Index dropped 0.5% to its lowest close since 1999, while energy and resource shares plummeted. Gold, seen as a haven, rose 0.5% to its highest daily gain since October. The move heightens concerns about a deeper slowdown in China's economy.

site_title: Mitsubishi to close US auto plant after failing to find buyer
summary: Mitsubishi Motors announced the closure of its US auto plant in Normal, Illinois, after failing to find a buyer. The plant, which produced the Outlander Sport SUV, laid off 1,000 workers in November and will continue to make car parts until the end of May, when 250 workers will be made redundant. The move is attributed to dwindling sales in North America and the strong US dollar, which has stymied returns. Mitsubishi Motors has shifted its focus to production in Japan, Southeast Asia, and Russia, and is exploring buyers from other industries for the Illinois plant.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group tumbles to 2008 low as investors shun mining shares
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodity trader, fell to a 2008 low after its stock tumbled 9.2% to 34.5 Singapore cents, its lowest since 2008. The decline follows a 6.3% drop in the Bloomberg World Mining Index, amid investor skepticism over the global commodities market. Noble's 12-month price target was cut to 44 Singapore cents from 54 cents, and its credit rating was downgraded to junk by Moody's Investors Service due to liquidity concerns. The stock's decline persists despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: Blackstone, Gaw Capital weigh bids for Ascendas Hospitality Trust: sources
summary: Private equity investors Blackstone Group LP and Gaw Capital Partners are weighing separate bids for Singapore's Ascendas Hospitality Trust, a 'stapled trust' with a market value of US$600 million. The trust's managers are reviewing options after receiving an unsolicited expression of interest to buy out its stapled securities. The potential offers come as bankers expect a rise in mergers and acquisitions in the city state's property trust sector due to falling market valuations and higher interest rate expectations. The companies declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Google seeks to hire more than 50 to expand its China workforce
summary: Google is seeking to hire over 50 people in China for various roles, including software engineers and creative consultants, to expand its presence in the country. The hiring effort comes after Google scaled back its operations in China over five years ago due to censorship concerns. The company already has a few hundred employees in engineering and business roles in China, who work on developing products for global use and helping Chinese entrepreneurs go global. This move may signal Google's return to China, following its 2010 decision to stop self-censoring content.

site_title: DBS, Standard Chartered said to face China currency suspensions
summary: DBS Group Holdings and Standard Chartered are among banks suspended from foreign-exchange business in China due to the country's growing offshore-onshore currency spread. The suspensions, which run through March and are shorter for DBS, coincide with turmoil in Chinese markets, including a 7.2% drop in the CSI 300 Index and a weakening of the onshore yuan. The People's Bank of China imposed the clampdown last month to curb transactions in the onshore market, allowing banks to profit from buying currency in Hong Kong and selling it in Shanghai.

site_title: Australia home building boom to cool, just at wrong time
summary: Australia's home building boom is slowing, with 12.7% drop in new home approvals in November, the largest decline since 2012. The multi-unit sector was particularly affected, with a 23% drop in high-rise developments. This decline comes at a time when the economy needs a boost from the housing industry to offset slumping mining investment. The Reserve Bank of Australia is counting on the housing industry to help fill the gap, but analysts expect aggregate approval volumes to slide in 2016, potentially exacerbating economic challenges.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at 4-month low; won down on China rout
summary: South Korean shares and the won currency fell on Thursday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ending 1.1% down at a four-month low. The won slipped 0.2% to 1,200.6 per dollar. The decline was attributed to a rout in Chinese stock markets, with offshore investors selling 3.9 trillion won worth of KOSPI shares for the 24th straight session. The selling streak extended the losses in the won, which had previously weakened due to Beijing's decision to let the yuan drop.

site_title: Update: Chinese stock markets suspended for day after shares slump 7%
summary: China's stock markets were suspended for the day after shares plummeted 7% in less than 30 minutes, triggering a circuit breaker mechanism. The CSI300 index fell 7.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 7.3%. The yuan's slide to its lowest level since 2011 contributed to the selling pressure. The market closures will remain in place for the rest of the day.

site_title: Hyundai unveils hybrid-dedicated car to take on Toyota's Prius
summary: Hyundai Motor unveiled its first dedicated gasoline-electric vehicle, the IONIQ, to compete with Toyota's Prius. The compact car achieves 22.4 kms per litre of fuel economy and will be priced at 22.9 million won (S$27,480) in Korea. Hyundai aims to boost green car sales due to stringent emissions regulations, despite low petrol prices reducing demand for fuel-efficient vehicles. The IONIQ will offer three electrified versions and is the first car from Hyundai to be made from scratch.

site_title: Yahoo looking to slash 10% or more of its workforce
summary: Yahoo Inc is reportedly planning to cut its workforce by at least 10% due to pressure from activist investor Starboard Value LP. The layoffs, which could affect over 1,000 people, are expected to impact Yahoo's media business, European operations, and platforms-technology group. The move follows a letter from Starboard, which has been pushing for changes at the company since 2014, including separating its Asian assets and auctioning off the core business. Yahoo will provide more details on its turnaround plan before its fourth-quarter earnings call later this month.

site_title: China: Stock markets suspended after shares fall 5%
summary: China's stock markets were halted for 15 minutes on Thursday after shares fell more than 5% due to an automatic "circuit breaker". The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 5.45% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 6.77%. This is the first time the circuit breaker has been triggered in China since 2015.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after Wall St declines
summary: Tokyo shares declined 0.28% on Thursday, following a weak lead from US and European markets due to concerns over China's economy. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index opened at 18,139.77, down 51.55 points. This comes amid worries about weakening economic conditions, particularly in China.

site_title: HDB resale prices flat in December; volume down by 4.3%
summary: HDB resale prices in December 2015 remained flat compared to November, with a 0.3% and 0.1% increase for three-room and four-room flats, respectively. Five-room and executive flats fell by 0.4% each. Year-over-year, prices dropped 1.3% from December 2014 and 10.7% from the peak in April 2013. Resale volume decreased 4.3% from November, with 1,404 units sold, a 8.4% increase from December 2014, but down 61.5% from the peak in May 2010.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 3-week low as China woes, weak data dampen spirits
summary: Australian shares hit a three-week low, falling 1.5% to 5,048.9, due to weak domestic economic data, concerns about slowing Chinese growth, and a slump in oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped for a fifth consecutive session, with financial and mining stocks leading the decline. Shanghai shares also fell 7%, while US stocks hit a three-month low. The benchmark index is down 4.7% for the year so far, with investors jittery about China's economic woes and global growth.

site_title: Malaysian anti-graft agency finds corruption in bauxite mining
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency found "elements of corruption" in bauxite mining, prompting a three-month ban on mining in Pahang state. The ban, effective from January 15, aims to curb environmental pollution and illicit operations. Exports will be allowed to prevent inventory buildup, but production will be limited to the nation's capacity to ship the material. The ban is expected to have minimal impact on global aluminum prices, as China's exports and global prices surged in 2015. The government will extend the moratorium if the industry fails to take necessary steps within three months.

site_title: Ringgit falls as China slowdown spurs risk-off across markets
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell to a three-month low as concerns about China's slowdown triggered a risk-off in emerging markets. The offshore yuan hit a five-year low, fueling speculation of a Chinese economic revival through depreciation. Global stocks declined, and the ringgit weakened 0.8% to 4.4270 a dollar, marking its worst annual loss since 1997. The decline follows a 16.7% advance in October and is attributed to the unstable China economy and lower oil prices.

site_title: Rebound seen for global aerospace, defence sector
summary: The global aerospace and defence sector is expected to return to growth in 2016, with total revenues projected to expand 3% after contracting in 2015. This outlook is driven by increased defence spending and large commercial aerospace orders.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SingPost not aware of any information that may explain unusual trading activity
summary: SingPost shares plummeted 6.2% on Wednesday, closing at S$1.51, their lowest since May 2014. The company responded to Singapore Exchange queries, stating it's unaware of any unannounced information that could explain the unusual trading activity. SingPost has been accelerating transformation efforts and pursuing growth opportunities, with no material developments requiring announcement.

site_title: Vallianz to buy two vessels for US$21.8m
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore and marine service provider, is purchasing two new-built vessels for US$21.8 million, paid in shares and cash. The acquisition, part of its ongoing business, involves 70.5 million shares at 4.43 Singapore cents each and US$2.18 million in cash, funded by internal resources and bank loans.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall sharply following rout in Chinese shares, yuan
summary: Taiwan's stocks plummeted 1.9% on Thursday, following a sharp decline in Chinese shares and a weaker yuan. The TAIEX index fell to its lowest level in over four months, with electronics and financial subindices also experiencing significant losses. Apple suppliers, such as Hon Hai and Pegatron, were hit hard due to concerns over iPhone demand. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar, but remains at its weakest level in over six years.

site_title: Fed raised rates even as inflation debate continued: minutes
summary: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates last month as policymakers became increasingly confident inflation would rise to 2% over the medium term. However, some members expressed concerns that inflation could remain low. The decision was seen as a close call, particularly due to uncertainty about inflation dynamics.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 3.38 points to 1663.36. The index saw 49.4 million lots traded worth RM21.7 million, with 107 gainers and 105 losers.

site_title: State of emergency declared in California gas leak
summary: California Governor Jerry Brown declared a state of emergency in Porter Ranch due to a massive gas leak that has forced thousands of residents from their homes. The leak, detected in October, is spewing 30,000-58,000 kilograms of methane per hour and poses significant environmental impact. Officials estimate it may take until March to complete repairs. The California Air Resources Board estimates the leak increased the state's greenhouse gas output by 25% at its peak. State agencies are mobilizing to stop the leak and protect public health.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Silverlake Axis, Annica, Vallianz
summary: Singapore Post (SingPost) responds to market closure drop in shares, citing no undisclosed information. Silverlake Axis clears allegations of wrongdoing after Deloitte review. Vallianz Holdings buys new vessels for $21.8 million. Annica Holdings appoints new CEO and COO amidst probe into penny stock crash.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall more than 3%
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell over 3% in morning trade following a slump in Chinese share markets, triggering an automatic "circuit breaker" that halted trading on the mainland for the rest of the day. The Hang Seng index plummeted 3.05%, or 639.48 points, to 20,341.33. This was in response to a decline in Chinese stocks, which sparked a circuit breaker in Hong Kong.

site_title: Industry to draw lessons from first public project using PPVC technology
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for regulations and cross-agency collaboration to boost construction productivity in Singapore. He made the point during a tour of new student hostels at Nanyang Technological University. This comes as the country looks to improve its building productivity.

site_title: Australian dollar drops to worst start on record as China angst intensifies
summary: The Australian dollar plummeted to its worst start on record, falling nearly 3% through Wednesday, amid concerns over China's struggling economy. The country's central bank cut its yuan reference rate for the seventh day in a row, sending China's currency to a five-year low. This has led to a surge in demand for safe-haven assets, including the yen, which has benefited against the US dollar. Analysts warn the Australian dollar remains vulnerable to further declines due to its sensitivity to Chinese factors.

site_title: Annica sees changes in chairman and CEO positions
summary: ANNICA Holdings has appointed Sandra Liz Hon Ai Ling, 49, as its new CEO and executive director, effective January 6. Chairman and executive director Edwin Sugiarto resigned and was invited to continue as chief operating officer. Both changes took effect on the same day.

site_title: Time Warner Cable says up to 320,000 customers' data may have been stolen
summary: Time Warner Cable reported that up to 320,000 customers' email passwords may have been stolen through malware or data breaches of other companies. The company was notified by the FBI, and it is sending emails to customers to update their passwords as a precaution. Time Warner Cable's systems were not breached, and the company is investigating the incident.

site_title: AirAsia plans US$1b bond programme to finance debt and buy planes
summary: AirAsia plans to raise up to $1 billion through a multi-currency bond programme to refinance debt and buy planes, following a third-quarter net loss in 2015 due to the plunge in the Malaysian ringgit. The airline's AirAsia Global Notes Ltd unit can issue bonds in US dollars or other currencies. This move aims to stabilize the company's finances and support its expansion plans.

site_title: China's securities regulator restricts big share sales as stocks nose dive
summary: China's securities regulator has issued rules restricting share sales by major shareholders, aiming to stabilize market expectations. The new rules, effective January 9, limit major shareholders to selling up to 1% of a listed company's share capital every three months through the centralized bidding system. Major shareholders must also file their sale plans 15 trading days in advance. The move does not signal an exit of the "national team" of investors, but rather aims to maintain market stability.

site_title: China central bank sets yuan midpoint 0.5% weaker, biggest daily fall since Aug devaluation
summary: China's central bank set the yuan midpoint 0.5% weaker, its biggest daily fall since August 2015, to 6.5646 per dollar. This is the weakest level since March 2011. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to loosen the yuan's peg to the US dollar, shifting towards a trade-weighted exchange rate. The decision follows China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: UK finance minister warns of "dangerous cocktail" of threats for 2016
summary: UK Finance Minister George Osborne warned of a "dangerous cocktail" of global threats to Britain's economy in a New Year's message, citing slower growth in China, Brazil, and Russia, as well as tensions in the Middle East. Despite two years of solid growth, Osborne urged against complacency, citing public borrowing above forecasts and stagnant manufacturing exports. He also highlighted potential risks from oil price falls and the EU referendum, which could delay business investment.

site_title: China trading suspended; Asian stocks, currencies, oil sink on latest yuan fixing cut
summary: China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 5.45% due to a circuit breaker, halting trading for 15 minutes. The yuan's reference rate was cut by the most since August, further weakening the currency. Asian stocks and currencies sank, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index hitting a three-month low. Oil erased gains, while the yen strengthened. China's economic slowdown and policy makers' tolerance for a weaker yuan are raising concerns over global growth and disinflation. The World Bank cut global growth forecasts, citing China's economy impact.

site_title: Donald Trump to scrap US$1.4b of investments in Britain if barred from entering country
summary: US billionaire Donald Trump plans to scrap $1.4 billion of investments in Britain if he is banned from entering the country. Trump's business empire, the Trump Organization, said any travel restrictions would force them to end all future investments in the UK. The move comes after an online petition calling for Trump's ban gathered over 570,000 signatures, citing his alleged "hate speech" remarks. Parliament is set to debate the issue on January 18, with Prime Minister David Cameron opposing a ban.

site_title: Morgan Stanley names Kelleher president; Fleming departs
summary: Morgan Stanley has promoted Colm Kelleher to president, making him the heir apparent to CEO James Gorman. Kelleher, a 27-year veteran, will also oversee wealth management, which Fleming departed from. Analysts say the move aims to balance power between wealth management and securities units. Kelleher's elevation comes after a management reshuffle in October and Fleming's departure, which was prompted by a challenge to Gorman's leadership.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 21.78 points to 2,782.49, following concerns over China's growth. The offshore and marine sector was downgraded by Macquarie Group, affecting stocks like Sembcorp Industries and Keppel Corporation. Silverlake Axis was the lone top-20 stock to open higher after clearing allegations. The market saw 69.1 million shares traded worth S$129.5 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 88 to 39.

site_title: North Korea nuclear test poses sanctions dilemma for major powers
summary: US presidential candidates and Congress demand more sanctions on North Korea after its latest nuclear test. However, major powers, including China, are reluctant to take tough steps, fearing destabilization in the region. China may support additional UN sanctions, but within limits, to maintain a physical buffer between itself and South Korea. Diplomats expect a discussion on adding to existing sanctions, but a full economic offensive remains unlikely, similar to the approach that forced Iran to negotiate.

site_title: Euro area set for robust growth this year
summary: The euro area is expected to experience robust growth this year, according to Markit Economics, with a manufacturing and services Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 54.3 in December, the highest in 4.5 years. This suggests a strong final quarter of 2015, with companies likely to expand capacity to meet increasing demand.

site_title: Interplex prepares to redeem notes if takeover becomes unconditional
summary: Interplex Holdings, a precision engineering firm, is seeking bondholder consent to include a call option in its 2019 notes. If approved and the takeover offer becomes unconditional, Interplex may redeem the notes at 102% of the principal amount with interest accrued. The offer is part of a S$450 million acquisition by Baring Private Equity Asia, with Metcomp Group Holdings and the StanChart private equity arm also backing the deal. DBS Bank and Standard Chartered are joint solicitation agents.

site_title: China goes underground to expand its strategic oil reserves
summary: China is expanding its strategic oil reserves by building underground caverns, aiming to hold up to a quarter of its total reserves by 2020. The underground sites, currently under construction, will hold approximately 130 million barrels of oil, accounting for nearly a quarter of China's 550 million-barrel target. The move aims to improve energy security and reduce costs, with underground storage being up to two-thirds cheaper than above-ground tanks. Despite technical challenges and delays, the project is expected to be completed by 2016 or early 2017.

site_title: Asia: Stocks decline after global rout on China growth concerns
summary: Asian stocks fell for a fourth consecutive day due to concerns over China's economy, deepening a global rout. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index declined 0.1% to 126.87, wiping over $2 trillion from global shares in 2016. China's increasing tolerance for a weaker yuan sparked concern, and the World Bank cut its global growth forecasts. Futures on the Hang Seng Index and FTSE China A50 Index declined 0.8%, while US stocks fell to a three-month low.

site_title: Sing dollar falls sharply; market 'shocked' by weaker yuan fixing
summary: The Singapore dollar plummeted 0.5% to 1.4320 against the US dollar on Wednesday, its lowest level since October 2015, following China's weaker-than-expected yuan fixing by its central bank. This move has left the market "shocked" and has significant implications for the region's economy and currency markets.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales enjoy record-breaking year
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales reached a record-breaking 1.16 million units in 2015, with a 2.9% increase in December sales to 99,616 units. This surpasses the previous record set in 2013. The growth is attributed to consumers' confidence in spending on big-ticket items.

site_title: Apple paid CEO Tim Cook US$10.3m in 2015
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook received a total compensation of $10.3 million in 2015, a 11.5% increase from the previous year. Cook's base pay rose 14.4% to $2 million and non-equity incentive compensation increased 19% to $8 million. The company had a mixed year, with shares falling 4.6% and reaching a record high for the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus. Cook also held approximately 3.1 million unvested shares, potentially worth over $310 million, set to vest between 2016 and 2021.

site_title: Macy's seeks potential buyers for stakes in flagship stores
summary: Macy's Inc is seeking potential buyers for stakes in its flagship stores, including its iconic 34th Street store in Manhattan's Herald Square. The company hired Eastdil Secured LLC to approach interested parties, with Tishman Speyer expressing interest in taking stakes. Macy's aims to capitalize on its real estate as sales and profit decline due to unfavorable market conditions. The 34th Street store is considered one of the most significant retail buildings in the world, and its sale could be a lucrative opportunity for a buyer.

site_title: Yuan worries sink ST Index 1.06%
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 1.06% on Wednesday, its third straight decline, due to weak sentiment in the local market. The People's Bank of China's surprise cut to the daily fixing of the yuan to its lowest level since April 2011 rattled regional markets, with the Hang Seng Index ending 1% lower and Europe's markets opening in the red. The yuan's 0.6% fall in Hong Kong's freely traded market also contributed to the market's weakness.

site_title: HK High Court halts China Fishery winding-up process
summary: The Hong Kong High Court has halted the liquidation process of China Fishery Group, a beleaguered upstream fisher and fishmeal producer. The decision came after three of the company's lenders agreed to support the case, potentially providing relief for shareholders and bondholders. The court action follows a series of financial struggles for the company.

site_title: HK's huge property gains may reverse in 2016
summary: Hong Kong's luxury residential market is forecast to decline by an estimated 5% in 2016, according to a Knight Frank report, making it the weakest-performing market among the 10 cities analyzed, surpassing Singapore. This decline is attributed to a reversal of the market's recent record-breaking climb.

site_title: S'pore dividend growth forecast among worst in Asia-Pac
summary: Singapore's dividend growth forecast is among the worst in Asia-Pacific, according to Markit, with a 0.3% rise in payout this year. The city-state is expected to distribute S$15.865 billion in ordinary dividends, a 0.3% increase from last year, and S$16.2 billion in special dividends, a 2.5% decrease. Local banks will still account for the largest share of the dividend pool, despite the modest growth.

site_title: China corn farms already tainted by GM seeds
summary: China's north-east farmers are illegally growing genetically modified corn, contradicting Beijing's efforts to ensure a safe food supply. Despite spending billions on GMO crops, the government has not yet approved commercial cultivation due to deep-seated anti-GMO sentiment. Greenpeace's report raises concerns about the government's ability to supervise GMO cultivation, potentially leading to widespread contamination of the food chain with GM varieties.

site_title: SingPost shares dive inexplicably to 20-month low; prompts SGX query
summary: Shares of Singapore Post plummeted to a 20-month low, closing 6.2% down at S$1.51 after an unexpected decline in the late morning and mid-afternoon trading sessions. The sudden drop drew a query from the Singapore Exchange about its unusual trading activity. The company did not respond by press time, leaving investors and regulators puzzled.

site_title: Nordic property deals hit a record driven by overseas interest
summary: Nordic property deals reached a record in 2015, driven by overseas interest. According to Pangea Property Partners, there were 905 transactions valued at 39.4 billion euros across Sweden, Norway, Finland, and Denmark, a 36% increase from 2014. This surge in demand could propel the Nordic market to new heights in 2016.

site_title: Pioneer Natural bets on demand for more shale oil stock with new shares
summary: Pioneer Natural Resources Co plans to sell up to 12.1 million new shares to finance a 14% budget increase and a sixth consecutive year of production increases. The public offering would expand the pool of available shares by about 8% and help the Dallas-based shale driller maintain its production despite a $400 billion decline in oil company market value.

site_title: Wall St watchdog focuses on high frequency trades to fight spoofing
summary: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) is increasing its focus on high-frequency trading firms to combat sophisticated market manipulation. The regulator will examine how well these firms protect their systems from unscrupulous traders. This move comes as high-frequency trading technology is being used to manipulate US markets. FINRA's 2016 examination priorities will scrutinize firms' cybersecurity measures and their ability to detect and prevent market manipulation. The regulator's efforts aim to maintain market integrity and protect investors.

site_title: GuocoLand inks pact with AccorHotels to manage two hotels
summary: GuocoLand Limited has partnered with AccorHotels to manage two new hotels: the 222-room Sofitel Singapore City Centre in Singapore's Tanjong Pagar Centre and the 312-room Sofitel Kuala Lumpur Damansara in Malaysia's Damansara City.

site_title: Productivity guidelines for tunnel builders this year
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore plans to expand its "buildability appraisal framework" to include tunneling projects, expected to be rolled out in the second half of 2016. This move aims to increase productivity among tunnel builders. The guidelines will apply to all tunnelling projects, following the existing framework for property developers.

site_title: New Fitbit smartwatch fails to impress analysts
summary: Fitbit unveiled its "smart fitness watch" with upgraded fitness tracking features, priced at $199. However, its share price plummeted amid concerns about its ability to keep pace with rivals like Apple Watch. The watch is set to be available for pre-order and in stores globally in the coming months. Analysts expressed disappointment, leading to a significant drop in the company's prospects.

site_title: Twitter 10k? Twitterati say save it for 'War and Peace'
summary: Twitter is reportedly planning to increase its character limit from 140 to 10,000, sparking widespread criticism from users who value the platform's concise nature. The hashtag #Twitter10k trended on Twitter, with many users pleading to keep the limit as is. The move is seen as a potential change that could disrupt the platform's unique character and user experience.

site_title: In.Corp Global on acquisition path
summary: In.Corp Global, a Phillip Capital-backed firm, has acquired Raffles Corp's asset as part of its expansion plans to become a global player within five years. The company aims to expand to ASEAN within three years and the Asia-Pacific region in four years. This acquisition is part of its strategy to diversify its services and increase its presence globally.

site_title: S$9,000 drop in Cat A COE surprises car dealers
summary: Singapore's Category A COE (Certificate of Entitlement) for cars below 1,600cc or 130 hp plummeted to a 41/2-year low of S$9,299 in the first COE bidding exercise of 2016. This marked a drop of over S$9,000 from the previous year. Category B, the "big-car" category, remained flat at S$54,920. The decrease in COE premiums is expected to bring relief to replacement buyers, although Cat B prices remained unchanged.

site_title: Shares of Apple and suppliers hit by report of cut in iPhone production
summary: Apple is expected to cut iPhone production by 30% in the January-March quarter due to a mounting inventory pile-up. This move aims to let dealers clear their current stock, according to a report by the Nikkei. The production reduction is expected to impact suppliers in the US, causing concern among investors. The decision is a response to the high inventories of the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus models, which were launched last September.

site_title: Host of events to mark Shakespeare's 400th anniversary
summary: The Shakespeare's Globe Theatre in London is marking the 400th anniversary of the bard's death with a "Wonder Season" featuring some of his most famous plays, including works at The Globe. The theatre's new artistic director, Emma Rice, aims to celebrate Shakespeare's brilliance through this event.

site_title: Microsoft faces new scrutiny from Chinese regulators
summary: Microsoft faces new scrutiny from Chinese regulators after a recent meeting with President Xi Jinping and Internet czar Lu Wei. A Chinese regulator has demanded answers about Microsoft's business practices in China, marking a shift in harmony between the two parties. The meeting, which took place months ago, was seen as an attempt to strengthen ties between the US tech giant and the Chinese government. The development raises concerns about Microsoft's operations in the country and its compliance with Chinese regulations.

site_title: Desperate S'pore property agents plug income gap as Uber drivers
summary: Singapore property agents, facing declining sales volumes in the slow housing market, are turning to alternative income streams, including driving for ride-hailing services like Uber. Many, like Billy Loh, a 50-year-old former property agent, are now driving to make ends meet. The sluggish market, marked by government curbs and plummeting transaction volumes, has led to a two-thirds decline in sales since 2012. This shift highlights the financial struggles of those in the property industry.

site_title: Huge medical debt woes loom even for insured Americans
summary: A new survey found that even insured Americans struggle with medical debt, with health plans often requiring significant out-of-pocket payments. The Affordable Care Act has led to a 15 million decline in the uninsured population since 2013, but insurance remains inadequate as a safety net. Many households face financial troubles due to these payments, highlighting the need for improved healthcare systems to address this issue.

site_title: Big world power, small mindset?
summary: China has released plans for its military development, including a second aircraft carrier, amid a need for a stronger military due to growing international cooperation and greater global responsibility. The country's military overhaul includes the creation of a General Command of the Army, a Rocket Force, and a Strategic Support Force. This move aims to enhance China's military capabilities in response to "new conditions" that require a stronger military to maintain regional and world peace.

site_title: US production a 'game changer' in oil market
summary: US oil production is being hailed as a "game changer" in the oil market, with the country now the world's top crude-oil producer. The American Petroleum Institute says this shift is a result of increased production, but also claims that the Obama government's regulations are stifling the industry. The API's president, Jack Gerard, stated that US production will remain a dominant global player, a shift that was previously unseen just a decade ago.

site_title: Expect currency wars in 2016, DBS chief warns
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta warns of a "currency war" in 2016, predicting a yuan depreciation that could lead to corporate defaults by unhedged Chinese companies. The Singapore economy will undergo its "trickiest and most sensitive" transformation in years, with Gupta forecasting the US dollar could weaken as early as the second quarter.

site_title: Saudi-Iran dispute won't cause lasting oil price rally
summary: Oil prices surged on the first trading day of 2016 due to Middle East tensions, despite the oversupply and depressed market. Saudi Arabia's mass execution of 47 prisoners, including a prominent cleric, sparked global condemnation and protests in Iran. Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei vowed "divine retribution" against Saudi Arabia. The tensions are unlikely to lead to a lasting oil price rally, as oil markets remain oversupplied and geopolitical disruptions have historically had a short-term impact.

site_title: Build entrepreneurial spirit early in schools: SBF
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) suggests introducing programming, engineering, and robotics in primary and secondary schools to foster an entrepreneurial mindset and culture in Singapore. This could start as early as primary school, allowing students to develop skills in creating solutions. The SBF aims to equip students with the necessary skills to succeed in the competitive business world, setting Singapore up as a global hub for advanced industries.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: China's services growth in December hits 17-month low
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at its slowest rate in 17 months in December, according to a private survey, indicating the country's economy may be losing steam. The Caixin gauge showed a 17-month low, contradicting expectations of a boost from Beijing's push to restructure the economy with a greater emphasis on services and consumption. This finding raises concerns about the country's economic growth and pressures policymakers to take action.

site_title: US scraps fair value accounting rule that distorted bank performance
summary: The Financial Accounting Standards Board has voted to scrap the 2007 "fair value accounting rule" that allowed stressed banks to book profits on distressed bonds, distorting their performance. The rule, which took effect as the financial system was crumbling in 2007, was meant to provide a safety net for banks during times of financial stress. Its removal aims to restore a more accurate picture of bank performance.

site_title: Weiye's spinoff Eindec launches Catalist IPO
summary: Eindec Corporation, a spin-off from Weiye Holdings, has launched its initial public offering (IPO) on Catalist, raising S$7.5 million with the sale of 35.8 million shares at S$0.21 each. Weiye will retain a 66.8% stake in the company after the placement.

site_title: Wanda to invest 15b yuan in hospitals
summary: China's Wanda Group will invest 15 billion yuan (S$3.3 billion) in hospital developments across the country, partnering with International Hospital Group to build three hospitals in Shanghai, Chengdu, and Qingdao. The investment aims to tap into a healthcare reform drive, giving private firms a larger role in the sector. The deal marks Wanda's entry into the healthcare industry, marking a significant expansion into a previously untapped market.

images.alt_text: Wanda's billionaire chairman Wang Jianlin said the developments would help satisfy ''the growing healthcare needs of the country's affluent population''.

site_title: Netflix becomes 'global TV network' in 190 countries
summary: Netflix has expanded its global footprint to 190 countries, offering its Internet TV service in 130 new markets, including India. The streaming pioneer, which began as a mail-order DVD service in 2007, now has 70 million subscribers. CEO Reed Hastings described the move as the "birth of a new global Internet TV network." The service is not available in China, a notable exception.

images.alt_text: "Today you are witnessing the birth of a new global Internet TV network," cofounder and chief executive Reed Hastings said at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

site_title: Singapore's APS a star performer in 2015
summary: Singapore-based APS Asset Management is expected to top Asia-focused funds in 2015 with a 20% return on its long-only China A Share Fund, which had assets under management of $2.3 billion at the end of November.

images.alt_text: Mr Wong says that on the whole, Asian equities are not expensive and are more attractive than bonds and real estate.

site_title: Lumosity's brain training claims are bogus: US FTC
summary: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has charged Lumosity with making false claims about its "brain training" products, which allegedly misled consumers. The company has agreed to pay $2 million to settle the charges. Lumosity's advertisements claimed that its games could help prevent age-related cognitive decline, but the FTC found no scientific evidence to support these claims. The settlement requires Lumosity to stop making these claims and to clearly disclose that its games are for entertainment purposes only.

site_title: Apple shares drop below US$100 for first time since August
summary: Apple shares dropped below US$100 for the first time in nearly five months, closing at US$100.70 on Wednesday, amid reports of slowing iPhone 6S and 6S Plus shipments. This marks the first time the stock has traded below US$100 since October 20, 2014. The decline comes as a result of a broader lower stock market.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc shares dropped below US$100 for the first time in nearly five months on Wednesday following reports of slowing shipments of the tech company's iPhone 6S and 6S Plus.

site_title: Silverlake issues review to rebut claims of wrongdoing
summary: Silverlake Axis, a Singapore-based investment firm, has released a 55-page review that found no impropriety in three related party deals highlighted by an anonymous short-selling report six months ago. The review did note one acquisition, worth RM118 million, seemed larger than it should and underperformed based on the transaction price. The review was conducted by an independent consultant and aims to rebut claims of wrongdoing.

site_title: Exempt smaller firms from sustainability reporting
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has exempted smaller firms from sustainability reporting, a move seen as a step towards promoting transparency and integrity in the industry. This decision is part of the SGX's efforts to support socially and environmentally responsible businesses, aligning with the global expectations set by the Paris Climate Change accord. The exemption is expected to help smaller companies focus on material information that affects their long-term performance and strategies, ultimately contributing to the growth of sustainable business practices.

site_title: Rising bad debts posing a threat to Indian banking industry
summary: India's banking industry faces a crisis due to rising bad debts, which grew to 5.1% of gross advances in the six months between March and September 2015. The Reserve Bank of India's financial stability report reveals that "stressed advances" increased to 11.3% during the same period. Most of these bad loans are from public sector banks, and if economic conditions deteriorate, bad debts are expected to rise to 6.9% by March 2017.

site_title: Ultra-thin, high-def TVs battle for CES crown
summary: LG unveiled a new ultra-thin, high-definition TV at CES, measuring 2.57 mm, thinner than four stacked credit cards. The TV features an OLED Signature panel and was touted as "quite literally, a picture on glass" by LG Electronics US marketing vice-president David VanderWaal. This innovation aims to revolutionize the TV industry and compete with other manufacturers for the title of best new television.

images.alt_text: Director Ridley Scott speaking about the commercial he is creating for LG flat-screen OLED TV technology which will be aired during The Super Bowl, as LG US executive David VanderWaal (right) listens.

site_title: Bank of Japan continues to signal further easing
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is signaling further monetary easing, potentially as early as this month, to combat deflation. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated Japan has not yet escaped deflation, prompting the yen to surge to a three-month high against the dollar and several-month highs against other currencies, which could derail Japan's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: "We are not in a situation where we can say deflation has been beaten," Mr Kuroda said in a TV interview on Wednesday, again stressing the dangers to the economy of a return to deflation.

site_title: World Bank flags China risk to Asian economies
summary: The World Bank's latest Global Economic Prospects report warns that China's slowing growth will impact Asian economies, with global growth dependent on advanced economies' strength. Emerging economies like India are seen as bright spots, while others, such as Russia and Brazil, remain in recession. China's GDP growth is expected to slow further this year, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: With China's growth expected to slow further this year, even as some other major emerging markets remain in recession, global growth will depend critically upon continued strength in the advanced economies, the World Bank said in its flagship report on Wednesday.

site_title: Sainsbury shakes up British retail landscape with Home Retail bid
summary: Sainsbury, a British retailer, has made a bid for Home Retail Group, shifting its strategy in a competitive retail landscape. The bid, rejected by Home Retail, marks a departure from the industry's avoidance of consolidation. Analysts view this move as a sign of desperation in the UK food retail sector, which faces challenges from discounters and online retailers like Amazon.

site_title: Value of shophouse deals rises 8% in 2015
summary: The value of shophouse transactions in Singapore rose 8% to S$655.6 million in 2015, with 103 caveats lodged. This represents a decrease in transactions from 112 in 2014. Ultra high net worth investors and family funds are showing interest in heritage properties, willing to accept low entry yields for long-term capital appreciation.

images.alt_text: The row of three adjoining freehold shophouses at 42, 44 and 46 Joo Chiat Road, which sold for S$23 million in Q4 last year

site_title: Workplace diversity policies don't help: study
summary: A study published in the Harvard Business Review found that workplace diversity policies, such as diversity training and hiring initiatives, have limited impact in increasing representation of minorities and women. The study, written by Tessa L Dover, Cheryl R Kaiser, and Brenda Major, suggests that these efforts often fail to effectively promote demographic diversity. The authors questioned whether these programs are truly working to address the issue of underrepresentation in the workplace.

images.alt_text: "We found evidence that it not only makes white men believe that women and minorities are being treated fairly - whether that's true or not - it also makes them more likely to believe that they themselves are being treated unfairly."- Co-authors Tessa Dover, Cheryl Kaiser and Brenda Major

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerage firm UOB Kay Hian recommends buying Singapore Aviation stocks SATS and Singapore Airlines (SIA) due to improved earnings, cost savings, and incentives. SATS is expected to generate 17% returns (net of dividend) in 2016, while SIA is expected to generate 13% returns. SIA Engineering Company is recommended as a top sell due to expected underperformance.

site_title: Malaysia palm oil output seen at 10-month low, trims stockpiles
summary: Malaysia's palm oil production has fallen to a 10-month low, with output decreasing 18% to 1.36 million tons in December. Stockpiles also dropped 5.2% to 2.76 million metric tons, the lowest since June. The decline is attributed to a seasonal decrease in production, which may help trim stockpiles and counter sluggish demand from buyers like China and India.

images.alt_text: Palm oil stockpiles in Malaysia probably fell for the first time since June after production in the world's second-largest supplier slumped to a 10-month low.

site_title: LVMH's PE, real estate arms to merge with Catterton
summary: LVMH's private equity and real estate arms are merging with US firm Catterton to form the world's largest global consumer-focused investment firm, L Catterton, which will be 60% owned by the new partners. LVMH and Groupe Arnault will hold the remaining 40%. The combined company will focus on investments in the consumer sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.27 points to close at 1,667.97 on Wednesday. A total of 2.43 billion lots worth RM2.331 billion were traded, with 595 gainers and 321 losers.

site_title: US women-owned businesses growing but most are one-person firms: research
summary: US women-owned businesses have grown by 27% since 2007, reaching 9.9 million, with most being one-person firms. These businesses generated $1.4 trillion in sales, accounting for 88% of the $1.6 trillion generated by women-owned companies with employees. Despite the growth, the majority of women-owned businesses lack employees, highlighting the need for support and resources to help them scale.

images.alt_text: More than a third of US businesses are now owned by women, a marked increase from previous years, but the vast majority of these are one-person companies, new research shows.

site_title: Twitter may allow tweets with 10,000 characters soon, says report
summary: Twitter may soon allow tweets with 10,000 characters, a solution for users frustrated by the current 140-character limit. According to a report, this change could be implemented as early as March. This move aims to provide more space for users to express themselves, particularly for those who prefer to write lengthy messages. The change is expected to address the growing need for more comprehensive communication on the platform.

site_title: US: Wall St drops to 3-month low; China, energy weigh
summary: US stocks closed at a 3-month low on Wednesday, weighed down by concerns over China and energy shares. Oil majors Exxon and Chevron fell, and energy shares dropped 3.6% as oil prices plunged below $35 a barrel. Apple's stock briefly dipped below $100 for the first time since August and ended down 2% at $100.70. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US vehicle sales in 2015 likely to smash records
summary: US vehicle sales in 2015 are expected to break records due to easy credit, new models, and consumer confidence. General Motors, Ford, Fiat Chrysler, and Toyota reported strong December sales, forecasting continued growth in 2016.

site_title: S'pore firms face fragile export demand in coming months
summary: Singapore firms face a fragile export demand in the coming months, despite a 7th consecutive month of positive business conditions, according to the latest Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index. Rising costs and stagnant new orders contribute to the economic uncertainty, as the country's export market weakens. This fragile economic climate may impact the private sector's performance in the months ahead.

site_title: US dollar drops as Fed cites currency as risk to its inflation goal
summary: The US dollar dropped after the Federal Reserve's December meeting minutes cited the dollar's strength as a risk to the central bank's inflation goal of 2%. The dollar weakened against the euro and yen, while the yen reached a four-month high against the dollar due to concerns about China's economy and North Korea's nuclear claims. The Fed raised interest rates for the first time in almost a decade, citing a "close call" for some policymakers. The dollar's decline reflects growing discomfort among the Fed regarding the dollar's strength.

site_title: Fed's Fischer says four rate hikes in 2016 'in the ballpark'
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer stated that the predicted four interest-rate hikes in 2016 were "in the ballpark," despite the exact number being uncertain. This comes after the Fed's first rate hike in nearly a decade in December. Fischer emphasized the Fed's need to adjust its policy as circumstances change, citing the upcoming release of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting minutes.

site_title: World Bank lowers 2016 global economic growth forecast
summary: The World Bank reduced its 2016 global economic growth forecast by 0.4 percentage points to 2.9%, citing disappointing growth in emerging markets such as China and Brazil. This is slower than the 2015 growth of 2.4%. The reduction is a concern for achieving poverty reduction and shared prosperity goals, as these countries have been significant contributors to global growth.

images.alt_text: "There is greater divergence in performance among emerging economies. Compared to six months ago, risks have increased, particularly those associated with the possibility of a disorderly slowdown in a major emerging economy," said Kaushik Basu, World Bank chief economist.

site_title: Improve disclosure when SGX rejects transfers to Catalist
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has clarified its assessment process for Mainboard companies seeking to transfer to the Catalist board. The regulator will now require issuers to disclose reasons for rejected transfer applications, aiming to protect the Catalist board's quality. This move aims to prevent the Catalist board from being seen as a "dumping ground" for Mainboard rejects, as it was intended for less mature but potentially faster-growing companies.

site_title: MAS baggage blunder leaves passengers fuming
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) prohibited check-in luggage on flights to Amsterdam, London, and Paris due to headwinds, sparking passenger outrage. The airline initially made the announcement, but later scrapped the restriction. The move was seen as another baffling decision from the struggling carrier, which is facing concerns over its recovery.

site_title: Bid to keep yuan stable to get costlier
summary: China's policymakers face increased pressure to keep the yuan stable as investors rush to exit the currency, despite the central bank's efforts to stem the yuan's drop. Analysts warn that the cost of maintaining a stable exchange rate is rising, and the PBOC may need to spend down its foreign exchange reserves to manage the spot rate. The yuan has declined almost 5% since August, and officials are struggling to execute an orderly currency adjustment, with some estimating it could fall by up to 2% per month.

site_title: IDA arm launches programme to train potential VC managers
