summary: The Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) of Singapore has launched the first venture-capital management training programme in Asia, selecting seven "entrepreneurial youths" from 190 applicants. The programme aims to boost the startup ecosystem in Singapore, marking the first of several talent-development initiatives to be rolled out this year.

images.alt_text: Asia's first programme to train people in venture-capital management has been launched, marking the first of many talent-development initiatives to be rolled out in Singapore this year, which will go towards boosting the startup ecosystem.

site_title: Global stocks sink in worst start since 2000 amid China concerns
summary: Global stocks declined 3.3% in the first three days of 2016, their worst start since 2000, amid concerns over China's economic strength. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell over 250 points, while emerging markets and US oil prices plummeted. The dollar pared gains after the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes were released, and Treasuries jumped, with yields on 10-year notes dropping to 2.17%. The decline was driven by China's unexpected weakening of its currency, which fueled fears of a global economic slowdown.

site_title: Nov trade deficit narrows as goods imports fall sharply
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed 5% in November to $42.4 billion, primarily due to a sharp decline in imports. New orders for factory goods also fell, indicating a sharp slowdown in economic growth in the fourth quarter. This marks a reversal from the wider-than-estimated deficit in October.

site_title: Indonesian consumers remained optimistic in December: central bank survey
summary: Indonesian consumers remained optimistic in December, with the central bank's consumer confidence index rising to 107.5, up from 103.7 in November. Consumers were more optimistic about economic conditions and job availability, but expected price pressures to increase in the first half of 2016. Indonesia's annual inflation rate eased to 3.35% in December from 4.89% in November, a decline that contributed to the improved consumer sentiment.

site_title: Fed declares end to debt crisis, world turns wary
summary: The US Federal Reserve has declared the end of the debt crisis, with interest rates set to rise by 0.25 percentage point. This move, considered the "normalisation" of monetary policy, will impact global economies and politics, particularly for emerging markets dependent on US funds. Higher interest rates may make these markets less attractive for foreign investors. The Fed aims to counteract the financial crisis and subsequent recession through monetary policy, marking the end of seven years of loose monetary policy.

site_title: Yuan sinks; safe haven yen strengthens
summary: China's yuan fell to its lowest since 2010, weakening by almost 2.5% in three days, prompting investors to seek the safety of Japan's yen. Global banks forecast a 7-10% decline in the yuan over the next 12 months, mirroring the 2015 devaluation that led to a global stock market selloff. This decline is part of a broader concern over China's slowing GDP growth, which is putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Opec unity under fresh strain amid Iran-Saudi crisis
summary: Tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia have strained Opec's unity, hindering the cartel's response to low oil prices. The cartel, which produces a third of the world's oil, has seen crude values tumble 60% since mid-2014, falling below $40. Experts say the crisis, combined with market share disputes, threatens Opec's ability to coordinate a unified response to the low oil prices. The cartel's struggles come as global oil demand is expected to remain stable for the next four years.

images.alt_text: Escalating diplomatic tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia have added fresh strains on Opec's unity as the cartel grapples with a common response to rock-bottom oil prices, experts said.

site_title: Singapore "gravely concerned" by North Korea's hydrogen bomb test announcement
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressed "gravely concern" over North Korea's hydrogen bomb test announcement, calling it a "dangerous and provocative act" that breaches UN Security Council resolutions. The ministry urged the DPRK to desist from further actions and abide by international obligations.

site_title: Oil dives below US$35, lowest in 11 years, as US supply swells
summary: Crude oil prices plummeted 6% on Wednesday, dropping below $35 per barrel for the first time in 11 years, due to a massive 10.6 million-barrel surge in US gasoline supplies. This marks the biggest one-day drop for global benchmark Brent futures since September. The decline is attributed to worsening Chinese economic data, a Saudi-Iranian row, and a potential global surplus. The US supply swell has led to a 10% loss for oil prices this year, with traders fearing a prolonged glut.

images.alt_text: Crude oil prices plunged 6 per cent on Wednesday, diving below US$35 per barrel for the first time since 2004 as data showing a shockingly large build-up of US gasoline supplies fed fears that a global surplus was still growing.

site_title: Apple reports over US$1.1b in App Store sales in holiday season
summary: Apple reported over $1.1 billion in App Store sales during the holiday season, exceeding the previous record. Customers spent over $144 million on New Year's Day alone, breaking the previous single-day record. The App Store generated nearly $40 billion for developers worldwide since 2008, with over $20 billion in 2015.

site_title: Recent fall in RM could set tone for more weakness
summary: The Malaysian ringgit plummeted over 1% to 4.3925 against the dollar, its lowest level since November 8, amid fears of a slowing China impacting commodity-reliant Malaysia. Analysts predict the ringgit may continue to weaken, with some forecasting a drop to 5-6 dollars by the first quarter. However, others, like Maybank's Saktiandi Supaat, expect the ringgit to stabilize around 4.15 by the end of 2016. The currency's weakness is attributed to a combination of factors, including a commodity slump and rising US interest rates.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Malaysia imposes three-month ban on bauxite mining
summary: Malaysia has imposed a three-month ban on bauxite mining starting January 15, citing environmental concerns. The ban comes after public outcry over water contamination and environmental damages due to the rapid expansion of the mining industry. The move is expected to impact China's stockpiles of the aluminium-making ingredient. The ban is a response to a lack of regulations in the industry, which has boomed in the past two years to meet China's demand for bauxite.

site_title: Message apps pose growing risk for China securities regulator
summary: China's securities regulator is concerned about the growing use of messaging apps, such as WeChat, for trading and instructing brokers. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) is struggling to monitor trades and prevent activities like insider trading and market manipulation. Institutional investors are using WeChat to instruct brokers, making it harder for regulators to track trades. The CSRC has fined brokerages for failing to collect client information and shut down third-party trading software that skirted regulations. The trend highlights the challenges of regulating mobile trading in a country where 80% of share market volume is driven by retail investors.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks surge after two-day plunge
summary: Shanghai stocks surged more than 2% on Wednesday after a two-day slump, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 2.25% to 3,361.84. Reports indicated that state cash was used to support the market. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 2.61%. The rally comes after a two-day decline that saw the Shanghai Composite Index drop 3.88%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Share index falls to 3-month low on weak private sector activity
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index fell 1.0% to a 3-month low of 20,980.81, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.9% to a 3-year low. Private sector activity in Hong Kong contracted for the 10th month in a row, with the steepest rate of decline since September. Despite a rebound in mainland shares, analysts question if the decline is overdone, citing sufficient tools to continue a "muddle-through" approach.

site_title: Oil hits 11-year low, Saudi-Iran row cuts chances of output restraint
summary: Oil prices hit their 11-year low of $35.07 a barrel on Wednesday due to the escalating row between Saudi Arabia and Iran, making cooperation on output cuts unlikely. Economic slowdown in China and India fuels fears of excess crude, and US crude futures dropped 88 cents to $35.09 a barrel. Shale oil production from the US and Iran's expected increase in oil exports contribute to the oversupply, with some producers pumping harder to maintain market share.

site_title: SBF calls for bold and decisive steps to energise Singapore economy
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has released a position paper calling for bold and decisive steps to energize Singapore's economy. The paper proposes investing Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies in the local bourse and appointing a minister to oversee the development of local enterprises. Other recommendations include investing in suitable firms to expand overseas and exploring a new market platform for "middle-class" companies. The SBF aims to encourage the government to take action to strengthen Singapore's position in the global economy, particularly in addressing rising costs, a shrinking workforce, and a lackluster global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Key Yahoo investor Starboard demands management change
summary: Activist hedge fund Starboard Value is demanding a management change at Yahoo, citing the company's struggling core Internet business. The investor claims investors have lost confidence in management and the board, and that the company needs to sell off the core business to other investors. Starboard warned that if the board does not undertake significant changes, an election contest may be needed to replace the board with directors representing shareholders' interests. This comes after Yahoo reversed its decision to sell its Alibaba stake and instead plans to spin off its core business.

site_title: Mexico's car market is so hot, even Volkswagen's sales volume is jumping
summary: Volkswagen's annual sales are set to decline worldwide for the first time in 11 years due to a cheating scandal on emissions tests, but the German carmaker is bucking the trend in Mexico, where sales jumped over 10% through November. Mexico's domestic car market is experiencing a surge, with the sector expanding almost 20% in 2015, driven by record-low inflation, cheaper credit, and the government's crackdown on illegal used-car imports. Carmakers are adjusting to the brighter outlook, with Mazda boosting production for Mexico to meet rising demand.

site_title: Will 2016 be the year Cameron finally turns pro-EU?
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron is facing a crucial year in 2016 as he prepares to decide on the UK's EU membership. Cameron's long-held Euroscepticism has led to a populist plebiscite on EU membership, which could be lost if he doesn't change his stance. The article suggests that Cameron's party has been in a "cul-de-sac" of anti-European rhetoric for 20 years, and that he must convince his party and the press to find virtue in the EU. A Brexit would have significant consequences for the UK and the EU, potentially leading to further centrifugal forces and the erosion of the European Union.

site_title: US services sector growth slowed in December
summary: The US service sector expanded in December, but at its slowest pace in 20 months, according to the Institute for Supply Management. The non-manufacturing activity index fell to 55.3, just below expectations of 56.0. The business activity index rose to 58.7, while employment and new orders also increased. However, the prices paid index fell to 49.7. This marks a contraction in the service sector, contrasting with the earlier report that showed the manufacturing sector contracting further in December.

site_title: Australia shares end lower for fourth day; North Korea tensions in focus
summary: Australian shares fell 1.18% to 5,123.1, marking the fourth consecutive day of losses, amid concerns over China's slowing growth and heightened North Korean nuclear tensions. New Zealand's benchmark index also declined 0.25%. The S&P 500 in the US and the STI in Singapore edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Eindec launches its IPO
summary: Eindec Corporation launched its initial public offering (IPO) on January 6, 2016, with 35.8 million new shares priced at S$0.21 apiece, totaling S$7.5 million. Chinese property developer Weiye Holdings will retain a 66.8% stake in Eindec after the placement. The shares will be listed on the Catalist and trading will start on January 15.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: European stocks fell at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index dropping 0.3% to 6,120.7 points. The decline was attributed to geopolitical risk, particularly after North Korea's successful miniaturized hydrogen bomb test. Asian shares mostly fell, but Chinese markets rallied after the People's Bank of China pumped cash into the financial system to shore up stocks. Analysts warned that China's economy, the world's second-largest, is heading for its worst annual performance in a quarter of a century.

site_title: Hong Kong on holiday health alert after China bird flu death
summary: A 26-year-old woman in Shenzhen, China died from H5N6 bird flu, prompting Hong Kong to issue a health alert ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday. Disease prevention measures have been implemented at border checkpoints and the airport. The government has not banned poultry imports from the mainland, but had previously culled chickens and suspended imports after a H7 bird flu strain was discovered in 2014.

site_title: Key recommendations by business community for Singapore's economic future
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has released a position paper outlining recommendations for the country's economic future. The report, backed by 28 trade associations and 70 top-level executives, calls for the government to review business costs, particularly manpower and lease costs, to ensure Singapore remains competitive globally. The SBF also recommends reviewing the foreign worker levy system, growing local companies, and making the securities market more vibrant. Additionally, the report suggests empowering local enterprises to expand overseas, investing CPF funds in the local stock market, and deploying public scholarship holders to private enterprises to improve the workforce's attitudes and values.

site_title: Business leaders call for CPF monies to be invested in Singapore shares to help 'moribund' market
summary: Singapore business leaders are urging the government to invest Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies in local shares to boost the "moribund" stock market. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) argues that CPF funds, currently invested abroad, could provide a significant boost to the market. Unlike other countries, Singapore has a policy of keeping CPF funds abroad, which is seen as a barrier to market revival. The SBF's call comes as the stock market lags behind other regional markets, sparking concerns about the country's economic growth and competitiveness.

site_title: In.Corp Global buys certain practices of Raffles Corporate Advisory
summary: In.Corp Global Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based corporate services provider, acquired Raffles Corporate Advisory's secretarial, accounting, and tax practices as part of its expansion plans to become a global player within five years. The company aims to expand to ASEAN within three years and reach a revenue target of S$100 million. In.Corp has over 60 clients from organic growth and plans to acquire three more companies to augment its niche services. The acquisition comes as the industry struggles to implement tightened regulations to combat money laundering and terrorism financing.

site_title: Saudi cuts crude price to Europe, hikes it for Asia
summary: Saudi Arabia has cut the price of its crude oil to Europe by $0.60 a barrel, while raising it for Asia by 60 cents a barrel, amid a huge oil glut and tensions with Iran. The move aims to maintain market share. European benchmark Brent oil prices dropped to $34.83 a barrel, the lowest level since 2004. The cuts come as Iran prepares to resume oil exports to Europe after sanctions are lifted. The crisis between Saudi Arabia and Iran has led to diplomatic ties being severed.

site_title: US factory orders, inventories fall in November
summary: US factory orders fell 0.2% in November, in line with economists' expectations, and inventories declined for a fifth straight month. This suggests that economic growth slowed in the fourth quarter of 2015, with economists slashing their GDP growth estimates by up to one percentage point. Manufacturing, which accounts for 12% of the economy, is likely to remain under pressure, with a survey showing manufacturing activity contracted in December for the second straight month.

site_title: ECB flags banks' business model as key risk area; eases focus on capital
summary: The European Central Bank's Single Supervisory Mechanism has shifted its focus from capital adequacy to business model and profitability risk as its top priority for 2016. This move reflects a changing approach to risk management, where banks' ability to meet regulatory requirements is seen as less critical than their overall business model and risk exposure. Key risks identified include credit risk, non-performing loans, and conduct and governance risk, with capital adequacy ranking lowest. The ECB aims to move away from an era where capital levels dominated regulators' agendas.

site_title: First taste of 2016 currency swings has traders hungry for more
summary: The global currency market experienced significant volatility in the first two trading days of 2016, with foreign-exchange swings reaching their most in a month. The jump in volatility was driven by Chinese stock markets plummeting and tensions escalating in the Middle East. Analysts at Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank expect the dollar to strengthen during the first quarter and predict more turmoil from China and rising US interest rates. Currency markets are poised for high asset volatility, with some currencies expected to benefit, such as the yen, while others, like commodity producers and emerging nations, are expected to weaken.

site_title: JPMorgan warns firms could pull UK jobs in event of 'Brexit'
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co warned that financial services firms could pull jobs out of the UK in the event of a Brexit vote, citing higher funding costs and potential loss of passporting arrangements. The US bank's analysts fear a negative impact on employment and the economy if Britain fails to maintain its EU ties. This warning comes ahead of a UK referendum expected later this year, where Prime Minister David Cameron is seeking concessions from EU counterparts.

site_title: My Tinder date with 'Pharma bro' Martin Shkreli
summary: A writer went on a date with Martin Shkreli, the infamous "Pharma bro," after matching on Tinder. Despite initial skepticism about the authenticity of his profile, they met at a Japanese restaurant in TriBeCa and had a surprisingly open and genuine conversation. Shkreli discussed his family, philanthropy, and the pharmaceutical industry, showcasing a more complex and vulnerable side. However, the evening took a humorous turn when he ordered a $120 cup of tea, which the writer jokingly considered a price-gouging moment. The date ended with a ride home courtesy of Shkreli's driver, leaving the writer with mixed impressions of the charismatic but polarizing figure.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore dollar plummeted to a 52-week low, reaching 1.4324 to the US dollar, amid concerns over the weaker yuan fixing. The small car category saw a significant drop in the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium, falling over S$9,000 to a 41/2-year low. Meanwhile, business leaders raised concerns over the need for a "deep review" of Singapore's strategies and regulations to boost building productivity. The Straits Times Index recorded its third straight fall as investors were affected by weak sentiment due to yuan worries.

site_title: 3 Spottiswoode Park Road shophouses up for sale for S$24-25m
summary: Three restored conservation shophouses on Spottiswoode Park Road have been put up for sale with an asking price of S$24-25 million. The properties, located in the Blair Plain Conservation Area, are within walking distance to the Outram Park MRT and future Thomson-East Coast Line. Two of the shophouses are zoned "residential with first storey commercial" and have a combined land area of 7,203 square feet. Foreign buyers are subject to Land Dealings (Approval) Unit consent due to the property's residential component. The sale closes on February 4 via an expression of interest exercise.

site_title: Brent crude drops below US$35 before US releases stockpile data
summary: Brent crude oil prices dropped below $35 a barrel to an 11-year low before US weekly stockpile data, amid rising tension between Iran and Saudi Arabia. Oil prices have been influenced by risk aversion, with analysts predicting crude may approach $30 in the coming months. US fuel supplies rose, while crude-oil stockpiles fell, but inventories remain above the five-year average. The slump in oil prices has raised concerns about economic data and has led to a decline in European equities.

site_title: HSBC downgraded by JPMorgan as bad loans in Asia set to surge
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has been downgraded by JPMorgan Chase & Co. due to rising bad loans in Asia, with analysts predicting non-performing loans in the region may jump to $5.4 billion by year-end. This is a significant increase from $2.2 billion in June, and could surge to $15.3 billion in a tougher scenario. The downgrade has led to a 3% drop in HSBC's stock price, with JPMorgan targeting 500 pence, down from 580 pence.

site_title: White House vows response to any North Korea 'provocations'
summary: The US White House has vowed to respond to any North Korean "provocations," despite skepticism over Pyongyang's claim of a hydrogen bomb test. The White House is investigating the claim, which is the fourth suspected nuclear test by the hermit state. Officials condemn any UN resolutions violations and will protect and defend allies in the region. The administration is cautious about implementing new punitive measures due to existing sanctions and regional interests.

site_title: Brokers' take: Macquarie downgrades Keppel, SembMarine, Sembcorp Industries
summary: Macquarie Research downgraded Keppel, SembMarine, and Sembcorp Industries due to the structural decline of Singapore's offshore and marine sector. The sector faces a "triple whammy" of low rig orders, high cancellation risk, and customer delays. Macquarie believes that 70% of the companies' current US$8-10 billion order book is at high cancellation risk, making their current valuation unsustainable. The research firm predicts immense pressure on the sector's business models in the next five years.

site_title: Najib faces testing year as Maybank arm sees record sukuk yields
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak faces a testing year as Maybank Islamic Asset Management predicts record borrowing costs, with benchmark sukuk yields expected to rise to 5% due to rising US interest rates. This could complicate efforts to fund a US$444 billion development program and cut the budget deficit. The prediction is based on a US interest rate increase to 1.25% by the end of 2016, which would drive up borrowing costs for companies in the world's top Shariah-compliant debt market.

site_title: Volkswagen is confident it can fix US cars in wake of lawsuit
summary: Volkswagen is confident it can fix US cars affected by the diesel scandal, despite the US Department of Justice's lawsuit and Environmental Protection Agency's skepticism. The company's chief, Herbert Diess, stated that significant progress has been made and repair solutions are being developed, with some cars potentially fixed with a simple software upgrade. Volkswagen aims to emerge from the crisis with new models, including an emissions-free concept van, and invest heavily in electric cars to woo back buyers.

site_title: Standard Chartered among banks in China forex ban: sources
summary: Standard Chartered, along with Deutsche Bank and another lender, was suspended by China's central bank from conducting foreign exchange business until the end of March, according to sources. The suspension, part of China's efforts to stem capital outflow, targets banks with large-scale cross-border forex businesses. Standard Chartered, which made $720 million from foreign exchange trading in 2015, has asked the People's Bank of China to shorten the suspension, but a response has not been received.

site_title: Kia sees autonomous cars by 2030
summary: Kia plans to introduce an autonomous car using its own technology by 2030 under its "drive wise" initiative. The company aims to commercialize partially autonomous driving technologies by 2020 and invest up to $2 billion in developing necessary technologies by 2018. Analysts see this as a gradual process starting with automating functions like parking and crash avoidance, with reducing sensor technology costs being a key factor in making autonomous driving more accessible.

site_title: Shareholder bodies like SIAS needed in developed capital markets
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has faced criticism for its funding model, which receives funding from corporations it regulates. However, SIAS has evolved over the years, pursuing missions such as investor education and corporate governance improvement. The organization has successfully advocated for minority shareholders, including in the case of Singapore Airlines' subsidiary Tiger Airways. To address concerns about independence, SIAS has applied to become an institution of public character, which could reduce its reliance on corporate sponsorships. A strong shareholder advocacy body like SIAS is essential in developed capital markets to protect minority interests.

site_title: VW repositioning may take 2-3 years: CEO in Wirtschaftswoche
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller stated that repositioning the company, following an emissions scandal, will take 2-3 years. He aims to focus on profitability over volume sales, shifting away from the strategy of his predecessor Martin Winterkorn, who prioritized record-breaking car sales. Mueller plans to continue the diesel offensive in the US market despite challenges, and will travel to the US for the first time since the scandal broke nearly four months ago. This overhaul will involve adjusting the strategy of VW's brands and adopting a new company structure.

site_title: The case of the missing cases: Malaysia Airlines suffers latest snafu
summary: Malaysia Airlines has faced criticism for banning checked-in baggage on flights to Paris and Amsterdam due to strong headwinds, citing fuel concerns. The airline initially enforced the ban, but reversed it after public backlash. The move has raised concerns about passenger safety and the airline's ability to manage operations during challenging weather conditions. The incident adds to Malaysia Airlines' recent string of public relations disasters, including a website hack and insensitive advertising campaign.

site_title: Sing dollar falls sharply; market 'shocked' by weaker yuan fixing
summary: The Singapore dollar fell sharply to 1.4324 to the US dollar after China's central bank set a weaker-than-expected yuan fixing, causing market shock. The People's Bank of China cut its daily fixing to a five-year low, sparking concerns of 'competitive devaluation'. This move led to a 150 basis-point jump in the USD-CNY fixing, causing investors to short the SGD. The yuan's fall raised pressure on policymakers, with GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: North Korea quake a 'suspected explosion': China seismologists
summary: A 4.9-magnitude earthquake in North Korea on January 6, 2016, was reported by Chinese seismologists as a "suspected explosion", sparking fears of a nuclear test. This is similar to a 2013 incident where China condemned a nuclear test. The tremor was detected near North Korea's Punggye-ri nuclear test site.

site_title: North Korea says tested hydrogen nuclear device
summary: North Korea announced the successful testing of a miniaturized hydrogen nuclear device, its fourth nuclear test, following a 5.1 magnitude earthquake near its known nuclear test site. The test is under US and UN sanctions for its nuclear and missile programs.

site_title: China to allow mainlanders to make transit stops in Taiwan
summary: China has announced plans to allow mainlanders to make transit stops in Taiwan for onward flights, potentially interfering with Taiwan's upcoming presidential elections. The move is seen as an attempt by China to boost the ruling Kuomintang party, which is expected to lose the polls to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party. The transit plan, which could benefit Taiwan airlines, has been discussed for some time but was only recently agreed upon.

site_title: Shuttered up: As China slows, Hong Kong company closures hit record
summary: Hong Kong recorded a record 122,479 company closures in 2015, a 17% decline in new firms, as China's economic growth slowed to its lowest in a quarter century. The city's economy remains heavily reliant on mainland China, with spending by mainland visitors drying up. Experts warn of potential financial troubles, citing China's lingering economic health issues and the risk of a bigger crisis. China's economic slowdown may leave a deeper scar on Hong Kong, similar to the impact of SARS in 2003.

site_title: Malaysia to ban bauxite mining for 3 months to fight pollution
summary: Malaysia will suspend bauxite mining for three months to combat pollution, starting January 15. The ban allows for exports during the moratorium period. The move comes after concerns over environmental damage, including red dust affecting air and water sources. The suspension aims to curb illegal operations and ensure sustainable mining practices. Malaysia, the largest shipper of bauxite to China, has supplied over 40% of the country's aluminum imports.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall for third day as yen surges on North Korea test
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for the third consecutive day as the yen surged following North Korea's nuclear test, exacerbating concerns about China's economy and Middle East tensions. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.99% to 18,191.32, while the Topix index fell 1.05% to 1,488.84. The yen's strength weighed on exporters, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo publishes special edition a year after jihadist attack
summary: French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo published a special edition on the eve of the one-year anniversary of a jihadist attack that killed eight staff members, featuring a provocative cover lampooning God. The Vatican criticized the cover for failing to acknowledge or respect believers' faith in God. The special edition reflects on secularism, the attack, and the team's resilience in the face of death threats. Despite past attacks, Charlie Hebdo has continued to publish without self-censorship, fueling debate over the power of satire and free speech.

site_title: AirAsia sets up US$1b funding programme to shore up finances
summary: AirAsia has established a US$1 billion financing plan through a multicurrency medium-term note programme to shore up its finances amid tough operating conditions. The funds will be used for working capital, debt refinancing, and financing aircraft equity. This move comes after the airline's major shareholders began evaluating strategic options following reports of the CEO seeking investors to take the airline private. Barclays is the sole arranger for the funding programme, with CIMB and RHB Investment Bank as joint dealers.

site_title: US private sector adds most jobs in a year in December: ADP
summary: US private employers added 257,000 jobs in December, exceeding economists' expectations of 192,000, the largest gain since December 2014. The ADP National Employment Report, released Wednesday, also revised private payroll gains for the previous month to 211,000. Economists forecast US private payroll employment to grow by 195,000 jobs in December. The unemployment rate is expected to remain at 5.0%.

site_title: Silverlake Axis says independent review shows "no impropriety" in transactions
summary: Silverlake Axis has released the results of an independent review by Deloitte Singapore, which found "no impropriety" in transactions between the company and related parties. The review was prompted by an anonymous report in August that alleged wrongdoing in these transactions. The company's shares fell in response to the report, but the review has cleared the company of any wrongdoing. A shareholders' meeting has been scheduled for January 25 to discuss the report.

site_title: UK service growth slows in Dec, economic pickup weaker than thought: PMI
summary: The UK services sector experienced a slight slowdown in December, with a services purchasing managers' index of 55.5, down from 55.9 in November. This suggests the economy expanded modestly in the fourth quarter, with economists expecting a 0.5% growth rate. The services sector remains a key driver of the UK economy, but factors such as government spending cuts and uncertainty about the global economy pose risks to economic growth. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in the second quarter, but may face challenges due to sluggish earnings growth and low inflation.

site_title: Mexico auto sales to rise between 5 and 6% in 2016
summary: Mexico's domestic auto sales are expected to grow 5-6% in 2016, reaching over 1.4 million vehicles, according to the Mexican Association of Automobile Distributors. This represents a 19% increase from 2015, setting a new record. The growth is attributed to an increase in auto loans, which has boosted the domestic market.

site_title: Thai Q4 GDP growth may have been higher than Q3's 2.9%: deputy PM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Somkid Jatusripitak suggests Thailand's fourth-quarter GDP growth may have been higher than the 2.9% expansion in the third quarter, potentially leading to a 2.9-3.0% full-year 2015 growth. This recovery in confidence is attributed to overall economic trends.

site_title: After record year for M&As, privatisation to sustain Vietnam's deals blitz
summary: Vietnam's economy, which grew 6.68% in 2015, is expected to sustain its deal-making flurry this year, with foreign firms capitalizing on the country's privatisation drive. The sale of a 45% government stake in Vinamilk, valued at $3.1 billion, is on the cards, along with a potential $900 million sale of Mobifone. Other deals in various sectors, including textiles and construction, are also likely. The country's relaxed rules for foreign investors, including the ability to own up to 100% in listed firms, are expected to attract more investment.

site_title: Oil M&A seen picking up as further pain forces producers to sell
summary: Oil and gas producers are expected to increase mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals this year due to the financial pain caused by low crude prices. Consultant IHS Inc. reports that the value of M&A transactions fell 22% in 2015, with only one major deal exceeding $5 billion. Energy companies with heavy debt burdens will be forced to sell assets or face restructuring, making them vulnerable to takeover targets. This could lead to increased consolidation in the oil and gas industry.

site_title: US: Walls St opens lower on China, N.Korea worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on January 6, 2016, amid concerns over China's currency weakening and oil prices hitting an 11-year low. North Korea tested a hydrogen bomb, and Saudi Arabia cut ties with Iran. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 159.84 points, the S&P 500 19.19 points, and the Nasdaq Composite 73.90 points.

site_title: Gold advances in longest rally since October on haven demand
summary: Gold prices surged for a third consecutive day, reaching a 3-day rally since October, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid concerns over China's slowdown and North Korea's nuclear test. The price gained 0.5% to $1,083.42 an ounce, with a private Chinese services gauge hitting a 10-year low. Analysts attribute the rally to safe-haven buying amid China concerns and a global equity rout triggered by the North Korea nuclear test.

site_title: Trade gap in US narrowed in November on bigger drop in imports
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed 5% in November to $42.4 billion, exceeding economists' forecasts. Imports decreased 1.7% to $224.6 billion, driven by lower consumer goods and industrial supplies. Exports fell 0.9% to $182.2 billion, also due to a strong dollar and weak global markets. The trade deficit is expected to have little impact on the US economy, with the global economy softening and a strong dollar making US exports less competitive.

site_title: Update: Malaysia Airlines resumes checked baggage on Europe routes
summary: Malaysia Airlines has resumed checked baggage allowances on its flights to Europe after temporarily banning it due to strong head winds on longer routes. The airline took this measure as a precautionary measure following safety concerns. The ban was implemented on flights operated by Boeing 777 aircraft to Amsterdam and Paris. All baggage is being shipped to affected customers in Europe, with the airline citing its daily risk assessment as the basis for the decision.

site_title: German private sector set for strong growth in early 2016: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector experienced its fastest growth in nearly 1.5 years in December, with the Markit composite Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 55.5 from 55.2 in the previous month. Service sector activity reached a 17-month high, driven by robust growth in new business and optimism about the outlook for the next year. The strong expansion is expected to continue into 2016, with companies likely to remain in expansion mode.

site_title: Fifa ban of top official Jerome Valcke extended by 45 days
summary: Fifa's secretary general Jerome Valcke has had his 90-day ban extended by 45 days, taking the total ban to 135 days, the ethics panel ruled. Valcke was initially banned for nine years and fined $99,100 for violating Fifa's general rules of conduct. He has denied wrongdoing and claims the penalties are a "self-serving public relations effort."

site_title: North Korea test 'grave challenge' and 'serious threat': Japan's Abe
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe condemned North Korea's hydrogen bomb test, calling it a "serious threat" to Japan and a "grave challenge" to nuclear non-proliferation efforts. Abe suggested the UN Security Council would take up the case, and Japan would take resolute measures with the US, South Korea, China, and Russia. The test violates past sanction resolutions and undermines international efforts for non-proliferation.

site_title: Chinese farmers are illegally growing GMO corn: Greenpeace
summary: Chinese farmers are secretly growing genetically modified corn in the country's northeast, with 93% of samples testing positive for GMO contamination, according to a Greenpeace report. The unauthorized cultivation has raised concerns about the government's ability to regulate the food supply and has intensified public opposition to the technology. The agriculture ministry has not commented on the report, but Greenpeace is calling for an investigation into the matter and stricter supervision of GMO crop research and cultivation.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks open higher, with investors on edge
summary: Shanghai stocks opened higher on January 6, 2016, after tumbling over seven percent in the first two days of the new year due to economic concerns. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.11 percent, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.51 percent. In contrast, the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong fell 0.33 percent. The market's cautious opening reflects investor uncertainty about China's economic outlook.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares fall on wobbly China markets, North Korea
summary: South Korea's won and shares fell sharply on Wednesday, driven by China's yuan losses and reports of a possible North Korean nuclear test. The won dropped 0.7% and the KOSPI index fell 0.7%, with foreign investors continuing to sell KOSPI shares for a 23rd straight day. The decline was exacerbated by a weak Chinese services sector, as indicated by a PMI of 50.2 in December, the lowest in 17 months.

site_title: India set to extend central bank term for Rajan's lieutenant
summary: India's government is set to extend the term of Deputy Governor Urjit Patel, who has been instrumental in reducing the country's high inflation, at the Reserve Bank of India. Patel's reappointment is expected within days and could signal confidence in Governor Raghuram Rajan's team. Patel's extension could also pave the way for Rajan's own term extension, which ends in September. The move is seen as a sign of continuity in policy and a positive development for the RBI.

site_title: Singapore business conditions healthy for 7th straight month in December
summary: Singapore's business conditions have remained healthy for the 7th consecutive month in December, according to the Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 52.1. Despite rising costs and stagnating new businesses and export orders, the rate of expansion in private-sector output slowed slightly. Companies increased selling prices marginally and passed on only part of their higher cost burdens. Growth projections for 2016 remain muted due to weak client demand, according to Markit economist Annabel Fiddes.

site_title: Yuan sinks to five-year low as PBOC surprises with weaker fixing
summary: China's central bank cut the yuan's reference rate to its lowest level since April 2011, marking a five-year low, as the currency continues to depreciate amid economic slowdown and rising US interest rates. The move, seen as a sign of policy makers becoming more tolerant of depreciation, has sparked market confusion and raised concerns about the impact on global markets and China's economy. The yuan's depreciation risks spooking global markets, with some analysts warning of a potential impact on export prospects across Asia.

site_title: China may allow car dealers to sell multiple brands
summary: China is considering allowing car dealers to sell multiple brands, a move that could boost dealers' competitiveness as the country's economy slows. The draft rules, posted for public comment, would give dealers more flexibility to operate and protect them from being dumped by manufacturers. Manufacturers would need to authorise dealers for at least five years and agree on sales quotas and inventory limits. The rules also extend protections to consumers, banning force selling and excess fees. The move is seen as a response to the country's slowing economy, which has forced dealers to discount heavily.

site_title: China may have 'hard landing' amid credit bubble, Faber says
summary: Marc Faber warns China may face a "hard landing" due to its record credit bubble, citing a 7% selloff in the stock market and a significant buildup of debt. Faber believes China's economy could experience weakness in sectors like steel production, potentially leading to a cut in investments in research and development. He also predicts a global asset market crash, likening it to the Titanic. The Chinese government has intervened in the stock market to prevent a collapse, but Faber is cautious about the country's economic prospects.

site_title: China's anti-graft body investigates Changjiang Securities chairman
summary: China's anti-graft body is investigating Changjiang Securities chairman Yang Zezhu for possible discipline violations. The move comes as authorities work to restore confidence in the stock market following market turmoil in June. Yang was not given a specific reason for the investigation, which is a euphemism for corruption. Changjiang shares fell 2% in early trading, and the brokerage stated its operations were normal. This is the latest Chinese brokerage to be targeted by the anti-graft watchdog, following similar investigations into senior executives at CITIC Securities.

site_title: Eurozone business growth picks up in Dec as firms take on staff: PMI
summary: Eurozone business growth accelerated in December, with firms taking on staff at the fastest pace in almost half a decade, according to a survey. The Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI) rose to a four-month high, indicating mild economic growth in the final quarter of 2015. However, companies cut prices, and inflation remained below the European Central Bank's 2% target. The data may lead to renewed calls for further stimulus, and the ECB's quantitative easing has been deemed ineffective in lifting inflation. GDP growth is expected to be 0.4% in the fourth quarter, a 1.5% increase for 2015.

images.alt_text: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls warned on Thursday that it would be a "very bad thing" if Britain left the EU, but warned that British demands cannot be met at any price.

site_title: Ringgit falls as China's lower fixing spurs Asia risk aversion
summary: The ringgit fell to a seven-week low after China cut the yuan's fixing for a seventh day, sparking concern about a slowdown in the region's biggest economy. This move fueled risk aversion across Asian markets, with North Korea's suspected nuclear test also contributing to the decline. The currency dropped 0.6% to 4.3705 a dollar, its lowest level since November 19. Malaysia's exports may be impacted by China's economic slowdown, with shipments from the Southeast Asian nation expected to rise 12% in November from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's ringgiterased losses in late trading on Monday as a rebounding yuan damped concern a currency war will heat up in the region.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to expand mobile payments to new countries, smartwatches
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to expand its mobile payments service, Samsung Pay, to three new countries: Australia, Brazil, and Singapore. The service, launched last year in South Korea and the US, aims to differentiate Samsung phones from competitors. The company will also introduce Samsung Pay on its Gear S2 smartwatches, starting in South Korea and the US in early 2016. The move is seen as a bid to protect market share and generate revenue. Samsung Pay's compatibility with magnetic stripe card readers is an early advantage over Apple's Apple Pay.

site_title: South Korea's FDI pledges hit record US$20.9b in 2015, up 32.3%
summary: South Korea received a record US$20.9 billion in foreign direct investment (FDI) pledges in 2015, a 32.3% increase from the previous year. The majority of the pledges came from the US, China, and the Middle East, with service sector businesses attracting US$14.7 billion. Construction investments from the Middle East surged 514.1% to US$13.8 billion, while manufacturing sector investments declined 40.3% to US$4.6 billion due to low global oil prices and a weak Japanese yen.

images.alt_text: South Korea received a record high US$20.9 billion in pledges of foreign direct investment (FDI) during 2015, government data showed on Wednesday, on surging interest from the United States, China and the Middle East.

site_title: Huawei smartphone shipments soar 44% in 2015
summary: Huawei shipped 108 million smartphones in 2015, a 44% increase from the previous year, becoming the first Chinese handset vendor to surpass 100 million annually. The company's strong sales in China and Western Europe helped it challenge leaders like Samsung and Apple. Huawei's revenue for its consumer business group jumped 70% to $20 billion in 2015, despite a tough market environment. Analysts question whether Huawei can become a serious rival to Samsung and Apple, citing the competitive Android ecosystem and smaller Chinese players like Xiaomi.

images.alt_text: Huawei Technologies Co has become the first Chinese handset vendor to ship more than 100 million smartphones annually, defying a market slowdown to challenge leaders such as Samsung Electronics Co and Apple Inc.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 2.17 points to 1667.87. Gainers outnumbered losers 124 to 33, with a trading volume of 20.7 million lots worth RM8.9 million.

site_title: Takata air bag victim's family cites skewed data to reopen lawsuit
summary: A Virginia woman's family is seeking to reopen a $3 million lawsuit settlement over her death from a shrapnel injury from a Takata air bag, citing new allegations that the company knew the device was defective. The family claims Takata manipulated test results before the settlement, but the company denies the claims. This is the first time plaintiffs have sought to reopen a long-settled claim based on new evidence. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has confirmed eight US fatalities and over 100 injuries linked to the defective air bags.

images.alt_text: The family of a Virginia woman who was killed by shrapnel from a Takata Corp air bag is seeking to reopen a lawsuit it previously settled over her death based on allegations the company knew the device was defective.

site_title: Regulations, agencies' collaboration needed to boost building productivity: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for regulations and collaboration among agencies to boost building productivity in Singapore. He cited the successful use of prefabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) technology in three new residential halls, but noted that further issues need to be ironed out. These include land requirements, higher costs, and limitations on building heights. Tharman aims to resolve these issues by next year, with the government playing a key role in facilitating collaboration across agencies such as the Ministry of Manpower and Building and Construction Authority.

images.alt_text: Regulations and collaboration among various agencies still need to be ironed out as Singapore's builders continue to improve their construction productivity, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker on yuan worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.06% on Wednesday, marking its third consecutive drop, amid concerns over the Chinese yuan's sharp decline. The yuan's unexpected cut by the People's Bank of China led to a 0.6% drop in Hong Kong's freely traded market and Shanghai. The STI's 1.06% loss brings its year-to-date decline to 2.7%. Market analysts attribute the weakness to the yuan's impact on regional markets, with some speculating that Beijing's recent market intervention may be confusing investors.

images.alt_text: The local stock market continued to be plagued by weak sentiment on Wednesday as the Straits Times Index recorded its third straight fall, albeit in slightly improved volume.

site_title: Lotte said to explore over US$500 million IPO for Malaysia arm
summary: Lotte Chemical Corp, a South Korean plastics manufacturer, is exploring an initial public offering (IPO) of its Malaysian petrochemicals arm, Lotte Chemical Titan Holding, which could raise over $500 million. The IPO could happen in the second half of 2016, with shares of Lotte Chemical Corp jumping 4.4% in Seoul. This would be the first IPO in Malaysia over $500 million since 2015's Malakoff Corp. listing, and would mark a significant fundraising event for the country.

site_title: Australia: Shares down 1.2% as China concerns linger
summary: Australian shares fell 1.2% on Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive day of losses, amid cautious sentiment as investors watch China's slowing growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 62.13 points to 5,122.3. Major banks led the losses, while the materials sector was pressured by a 2.8% fall in iron ore prices. The only gain was seen in Ardiden Ltd, which jumped 71% after being acquired for a Canadian lithium project.

images.alt_text: China will keep in effect its ban on share sales by listed companies' major shareholders until the government publishes new rules on such share disposals, the Shanghai Securities News reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asia ahead of US crude inventories report
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia ahead of a US report on commercial crude inventories, increasing by six cents to $36.03 for West Texas Intermediate and $36.48 for Brent. Analysts expect a 500,000-barrel increase in US stockpiles, which will likely keep the market bearish. The ongoing diplomatic row between Iran and Saudi Arabia also affects prices, with traders looking to sell amid a supply glut and weak global demand. The market is expected to remain bearish, with prices potentially continuing to drop in the first half of 2016.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged higher in Asia Wednesday, ahead of the release of a US stockpiles report, with investors also keeping an eye on a worsening diplomatic row between Iran and Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall on China yuan, economy worries
summary: Asian stocks fell on Wednesday as the People's Bank of China set the yuan's midpoint rate at its weakest level in 4-1/2 years, sparking concerns about China's economy. A survey showed China's services sector expanded at its slowest rate in 17 months, and the yen drew support from risk aversion. The MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan lost 1% and Australian shares fell 1.3%. China's equities saw modest gains as authorities unveiled stock-supportive measures.

site_title: China's Wanda to invest US$2.3b in hospital developments
summary: China's Wanda Group will invest 15 billion yuan (S$3.27 billion) in hospital developments in Shanghai, Chengdu, and Qingdao, partnering with British-based healthcare operator International Hospital Group. The investment is part of China's healthcare reform drive to attract private money and reduce the burden on public hospitals. Construction of two hospitals will start in 2016, while the third is already underway and expected to be completed by 2018. The move aims to elevate healthcare standards in China and bring overseas experience into the market, with Wanda's chairman citing the need to satisfy the growing healthcare needs of the affluent population.

images.alt_text: China's Wanda Group will invest 15 billion yuan (S$3.27 billion) in hospital developments around the country, the property and investment firm said in a statement on Wednesday, tapping into a reform drive to give private firms a larger role in healthcare.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental to acquire Boston hotel and property for US$140m
summary: Mandarin Oriental International is acquiring a Boston hotel and its freehold land for US$140 million. The 148-room hotel, managed by Mandarin Oriental since 2008, was offered for sale through auction and the company's management contract allowed it to acquire the property at the highest bid. The acquisition will be funded through a mix of existing cash reserves and debt, expected to positively impact earnings, and is set to be completed by the first quarter of 2016.

site_title: Disney kicks off 2016 company debt with US$3 billion issue
summary: Disney raised US$3 billion in debt, marking the fifth consecutive year of over US$1 trillion in investment-grade corporate bond sales. This follows a record US$1.31 trillion in bond sales last year, driven by acquisition-related financing. Despite higher borrowing costs, analysts predict continued issuance, with Bank of America forecasting US$1.22 trillion and Morgan Stanley predicting US$1.05 trillion.

images.alt_text: Disney, the world's largest entertainment company, sold US$3 billion of debt in five parts, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: Bollywood star shames man watching pirated film on flight
summary: Bollywood star Kriti Sanon publicly shamed a passenger on a flight for watching a pirated copy of her film "Dilwale" on a phone projector. The incident occurred 10 days after the movie's release, with Sanon tweeting about the passenger's behavior and expressing her frustration with piracy. The passenger was seen enjoying the movie despite Sanon's polite request to watch it in a theater. The incident sparked Sanon's awareness campaign against piracy, with her urging fans to support the film industry by watching movies in cinemas.

images.alt_text: A Bollywood star posted a series of angry tweets after a passenger sitting next to her on a flight brazenly started watching a pirated copy of one of her films.

site_title: AusGroup seeks bondholders' approval to amend bond covenant
summary: AusGroup is seeking bondholders' approval to amend the financial covenant in its 2016 bonds due to a delayed fuel facility start-up. The Port Melville facility's start was delayed due to environmental and regulatory approval issues, which may impact operations. AusGroup proposes an "Interest Service Reserve Account" to ensure interest payments, even if the 2:1 interest coverage ratio threshold is not met. The company remains confident in its ability to service all payments on the notes.

site_title: Wall Street to get graded on how much spoofing it enables
summary: US regulators, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (Finra), plan to grade Wall Street firms on how much spoofing occurs within their order books, aiming to curb market manipulation. The report cards, set to be issued this year, will assess firms on their role in facilitating fake bids to buy or sell stocks. Finra expects brokers to use the assessments to root out misconduct, and the reports will not be made public. This move follows high-profile cases, such as the 2010 flash crash, and comes as regulators worldwide seek to reduce spoofing.

site_title: China to keep share sales ban in effect until new rules promulgated
summary: China has extended its ban on share sales by major shareholders until new rules are published, amid concerns that a six-month ban expiring on January 8 could lead to a significant influx of shares worth 1.24 trillion yuan. The Securities Regulatory Commission is studying new rules to restrict major shareholder share sales and maintain an orderly exit, following a 7% slump in the stock market on Monday. The ban was initially imposed during last year's market rout to prevent a sudden increase in shares on the market.

site_title: Samsung Electronics at risk of 2016 profit drop on components headwinds
summary: Samsung Electronics may face a profit drop in 2016 due to slowing demand for consumer electronics, eroding prices of memory chips and displays. Analysts expect the company's fourth-quarter profit to rise 26% from a year earlier, but some brokerages have cut forecasts citing weaker-than-anticipated components sales. The firm's CEO warned of challenges from weak global growth and emerging market uncertainties. Samsung's commanding market position and cash reserves will help it weather the downturn, but it faces pressure from losing smartphone market share to rivals.

images.alt_text: Tech giant Samsung Electronics may be due for another profit drop in 2016, as slowing demand for consumer electronics saps momentum for the less-glamourous components businesses that offset last year's smartphone struggles.

site_title: Small car COE premium falls by over S$9,000
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) for small cars in Singapore plummeted by over S$9,000 in the first bidding exercise of 2016, reaching a 41/2-year low. Category A (cars below 1,600cc or 130 hp) fell to S$45,002, while Category E (open category) decreased to S$55,089. Category C (goods vehicles and buses) also dropped to S$42,036, while Category D (motorcycles) rose to S$6,889.

images.alt_text: Replacement car buyers rejoiced on Wednesday when the small car category got off to a good start in 2016 - it plunged more than S$9,000 to a 41/2-year low in the first Certificate of Entitlement (COE) bidding exercise of the year.

site_title: France's Orange, Bouygues in telecoms tie-up talks
summary: France's telecommunications giant Orange is in talks to buy its smaller rival Bouygues Telecom, potentially consolidating the European telecom market. The talks, which have been ongoing, are not bound to a specific timeframe and are not guaranteed to result in a deal. If successful, the merger would create a dominant player in France's telecom market, sparking concerns over competition and prices. The deal would require approval from competition authorities in France and the European Union.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Terratech, Tritech, Mandarin Oriental, Qian Hu, OKH Global
summary: Terratech Group, a premium marble producer, will no longer be a unit of Tritech Group after the engineering firm sells its 29% stake in the firm. Mandarin Oriental International acquired a Boston hotel for $140 million. Qian Hu Corporation expects to make a loss for its fourth quarter but remains profitable for the year. OKH Global's CEO and executive chairman received an Interpol notice over a charge of providing false statements for an official document.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales break records in 2015
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales broke records in 2015, reaching 1.16 million units, a 1.7% increase from the previous record in 2013. December sales rose 2.9% compared to 2014, with sports utility vehicles accounting for 35% of the market. Toyota retained the top spot, followed by Mazda, Holden, and Mitsubishi. The sector's growth suggests consumer confidence and may signal firmer business investment.

site_title: Hong Kong's New World Development makes second attempt to take China unit private
summary: Hong Kong-based New World Development Co Ltd plans to take its 69%-owned China property unit, New World China Land, private with a deal worth up to HK$21.45 billion (S$3.95 billion). The offer of HK$7.80 per share represents a 25.6% premium over the previous closing level. This is the second attempt by New World Development to take the unit private, following a 2014 offer that was rejected by independent shareholders. The deal is subject to shareholder approval and will be financed by New World's cash reserve and a credit facility from HSBC.

site_title: Asia: Stock futures mixed after muted rally with oil below US$36
summary: Asian stock futures are mixed, following a muted rally, with oil below $36 a barrel. New Zealand stocks rose 0.3%, while Chinese stock-exchange-traded funds rebounded after the government intervened to stabilize local markets. Futures on Japanese, South Korean, and Hong Kong equity indexes indicate minimal gains, and the euro maintains losses amid signs of disinflation in Europe. The modest recovery in global equities is attributed to China's government funds propping up share prices, as concerns about the ongoing slowdown in China drag on global growth.

site_title: Apple expected to cut iPhone 6S, 6S Plus production
summary: Apple is expected to cut iPhone 6S and 6S Plus production by about 30% in the January-March quarter due to high inventories. This move aims to let dealers clear their current stock before production resumes in the April-June quarter. Several Japanese and Korean parts suppliers, including Japan Display Inc, Sharp Corp, and LG Display Co Ltd, are likely to be affected by the production cut. Apple and the suppliers were not immediately available for comment.

site_title: US dollar, yen add to gains amid trader caution
summary: The US dollar and yen strengthened against other currencies amid caution over China's economic troubles and Middle East tensions. The US dollar reached its highest level in 12 years against the Canadian dollar, while the yen rose nearly 1% against the euro. Despite China's reported $20 billion intervention in capital markets, investors remain nervous about the Chinese economy, with some analysts citing a resumption of the dollar as a safe harbor trade. The greenback's gains were largely driven by a rally in US bonds.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.86 points to 2,835.09. This follows a positive end to US equity markets on Tuesday. Some early movers included Terratech Group and Singapore Post, which opened on a negative note. As of 9:02am, 46.6 million shares worth S$39.7 million were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 90 to 48.

images.alt_text: The local stock market continued to be plagued by weak sentiment on Wednesday as the Straits Times Index recorded its third straight fall, albeit in slightly improved volume.

site_title: 30 listed Chinese firms say big shareholders to extend selling ban
summary: Thirty Chinese listed companies have announced that their controlling shareholders or senior executives will not sell shares on the secondary market for the next six or 12 months, aiming to stabilize China's stock market. The move follows a 7% slump on Monday, triggered by fears of a ban expiration on January 8, which could unlock an estimated 1.24 trillion yuan (S$271.5 billion) worth of shares. Most of the companies are privately-run firms, including Zhejiang Century Huatong Group Co Ltd and Shandong Sun Paper Industry Co Ltd.

site_title: Update: Malaysia Airlines bans checked luggage, citing strong headwinds
summary: Malaysia Airlines has banned checked luggage on long-haul flights due to strong headwinds affecting its ability to reach European cities with a full load of fuel. Passengers are advised to carry only one carry-on bag weighing up to 15 pounds in coach and two pieces totaling 14 kilograms in business class and first. The airline is taking the measure to prioritize safety, following the downing of one of its jets over Ukraine in 2014. The ban applies to flights to Paris and Amsterdam operated by Boeing 777 aircraft on Tuesday and Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore business leaders raise concerns, issues in SBF position paper
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has released a 32-page position paper to strengthen the country's global competitiveness. The paper, prepared by 71 top business executives, calls for a "deep review" of existing strategies and proposes new responses to tackle challenges. It aims to help businesses navigate rising costs, manpower issues, and near-term economic headwinds. The SBF also urges the government to create an economy that leverages technology and intellectual property to become a hub for innovation, growth, and research. The paper's recommendations focus on immediate and medium to long-term solutions.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has issued a raft of proposals and recommendations that it hopes the government will consider in order to strengthen Singapore's global competitiveness.

site_title: The antidote for Japan CEO malaise: more pay and even more nerve
summary: Japanese CEOs are underpaid, with median salaries 10% lower than US counterparts, and incentive pay making up only 14% of total compensation. Experts, including former Japan Exchange Group Inc. CEO Atsushi Saito, recommend increasing CEO pay to encourage risk-taking and attract better talent. Saito advocates for linking compensation to share price and abolishing cushy advisory roles after retirement. Japanese businesses should offer at least 200 million yen per year to CEOs, a move seen as crucial for revitalizing a stagnant economy and business environment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after US, European markets stabilise
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following the stabilization of major financial markets in the US and Europe. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 finished with modest gains, while the Nasdaq Index ended down. Analysts attribute Beijing's reported 130 billion yuan intervention in capital markets as a factor in calming global financial markets. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.20% to 18,410.57, while the Topix index gained 0.27%. The dollar strengthened to 119.12 yen, while the euro edged down to US$1.0744.

site_title: Oil prices drop despite Middle East tensions
summary: Oil prices dropped by 79 cents to $35.97 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and 80 cents to $36.42 a barrel in London, despite tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran. The oversupply of oil, with US petroleum inventories near record levels, is overshadowing geopolitical risks in the Middle East. Analysts believe the market is looking for a build of around one million barrels, which is likely to further discount oil prices, despite the diplomatic crisis.

site_title: Fitbit 'smart fitness watch' disappoints market
summary: Fitbit unveiled its "smart fitness watch," the Fitbit Blaze, aiming to compete with Apple's smartwatch. The device, priced at $199, features fitness tracking, GPS, and notification capabilities, with a high-resolution color display and up to 5-day battery life. Despite the upgrade, Fitbit shares plummeted 18% due to concerns that the device may not be enough to counter rivals, including Under Armour's new connected fitness devices. Analysts question the device's limited functionality and software platform, suggesting Fitbit needs to improve its offerings to compete in the market.

site_title: Tritech to sell off Terratech; latter may face board, management changes
summary: Tritech Group, an engineering firm, announced it will sell its 29% stake in marble producer Terratech Group for S$12.5 million. The sale will allow Tritech to unlock value in its marble resource business and reallocate resources to focus on engineering services and new investments. Terratech will continue normal operations, and Tritech plans to divest its remaining 33.9% stake in the company. The sale is expected to result in a net gain of S$8.6 million for Tritech.

site_title: Tenaga plans US$3b global sukuk to fund overseas investments
summary: Malaysia's Tenaga Nasional Bhd plans a US$3 billion global sukuk issuance to fund overseas investments, including a 30% stake in Turkish power firm Gama Enerji AS. The move comes after global sukuk offerings slumped to a five-year low in 2015. Proceeds will be used to finance the purchase of Gama Enerji AS and add 5,000 megawatts of regional capacity. The issuance is expected to boost investor confidence and support the ringgit currency.

site_title: China intervention soothes US, European stocks
summary: US and European stocks stabilized on Tuesday after China injected 130 billion yuan into the money market to ease concerns over the slowing Chinese economy. The S&P 500 and major European markets finished with modest gains, reversing Monday's decline. Analysts expressed uncertainty over the long-term impact of China's economic slowdown and rising tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran.

site_title: UK ministers free to campaign either way in EU referendum
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron has announced that his ministers will be free to campaign for or against Britain's membership in the EU during a planned referendum, set to take place by the end of 2017. The move is seen as a major concession to eurosceptics in his party, but Cameron has signaled he will not resign if the in-or-out vote goes against government recommendations. Several high-profile ministers are expected to campaign for Britain to leave the EU, despite Cameron's own intention to campaign to stay in the bloc if he secures the necessary reforms.

site_title: US production a 'game changer' in oil market: API
summary: The American Petroleum Institute (API) says US oil production has been a "game changer" in the oil market, making the US the world's number one crude-oil producer. The industry supports about $1.2 trillion in gross domestic product and could create up to one million additional jobs with the right policies. The API criticizes President Barack Obama's administration for burdening the industry with regulations, and calls for amending or repealing the renewable fuel standard program. Despite this, the group emphasizes the importance of allowing all energy sources to compete and notes that fossil fuels will account for 80% of US energy consumption through 2040.

site_title: Global logistics index shows confidence at lowest in nearly four years
summary: A global logistics index measuring confidence in the industry fell to its lowest level in nearly four years in December, hit by overcapacity in shipping. The Transport Intelligence Stifel Logistic Confidence Index declined 1.8 points to 44.3, mainly due to low freight rates and margins for European freight forwarders. However, future expectations were slightly improved, with companies expecting overcapacity to lessen. Major shipping companies such as Maersk Line and CMA CGM have taken steps to decrease capacity, including vessel lay-ups and mergers.

site_title: Valeant plans to appoint new CEO as Pearson remains hospitalised
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals plans to appoint a new CEO amid Chief Executive Michael Pearson's hospitalization for severe pneumonia. Pearson, who has been on medical leave, is being treated at a hospital. The new CEO, likely to be either CFO Robert Rosiello or former CFO Howard Schiller, would replace the current committee running the company. The appointment's permanence remains unclear, and Valeant declined to comment on the matter. Pearson's hospitalization has led to a 6.6% drop in Valeant's US-listed shares.

site_title: China Dec Caixin services PMI falls to 17-month low as new business cools
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at its slowest rate in 17 months in December, with the Caixin/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 50.2 from 51.2 in November. The sector's new business index also declined to 50.6, citing subdued demand. The findings contradict an upbeat official services survey, which showed a 16-month high in December. The slowdown in services sector growth may impact China's economy, which is expected to cool from 7.3% in 2014 to 6.9% in 2015.

images.alt_text: Activity in China's services sector expanded at its slowest rate in 17 months in December, a private survey showed on Wednesday, in a further indication that the world's second-largest economy may be losing steam.

site_title: That Uber driver might just try to sell you a home in Singapore
summary: Singapore's property market, hit by government curbs, has led to a decline in sales volumes and a long losing streak in 17 years. Many property agents, including Billy Loh and Terence Tham, have switched to driving for Uber or GrabCar to supplement their income, earning around S$3,000 a month. The industry group, Institute of Estate Agents in Singapore, is offering courses to help agents acquire alternative skills, such as property management. The decline in sales has also led to a surplus of rental cars, with Uber and GrabCar attracting a growing number of property agents.

site_title: ST Engineering is top sell in industrials sector with S$46m
summary: Global mutual funds sold more Singapore industrials stocks than they bought in the three months to December 20, with net sells of S$82.8 million and net buys of S$1.7 million. Singapore Technologies Engineering was the top sell, with a volume of S$46 million, while United Engineers was the top buy, with a volume of S$900,000.

site_title: US: Stocks regain footing after China-sparked crash
summary: US stocks stabilized on Tuesday after a China-sparked crash on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rising 0.06% and 0.20% respectively. Apple's 2.5% drop was attributed to a report of iPhone production cuts due to weak sales. Chinese markets steadied after the People's Bank of China pumped money into the market, and investors are awaiting clarity on the China-Saudi-Iran rift.

site_title: Flash: Singapore Nikkei PMI falls 0.1 to 52.1 in December
summary: Singapore's Nikkei PMI fell 0.1 to 52.1 in December, marking the 7th consecutive month of healthy business conditions. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and the country plans to seize approximately RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. In other news, Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, and the UK economy contracted for the second month in a row. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident that his daughter will be cleared as Thai PM in an ethics case.

site_title: Ultra-thin, high-definition TVs battle for CES crown
summary: LG unveiled a new ultra-thin OLED TV at CES, measuring 2.57mm, with deeper blacks and a wider color range than LCD TVs. The TV also features Dolby Vision technology, creating a lifelike picture. Samsung introduced its new SUHD Quantum Dot TVs, which can stream games and smart home devices, and will allow for seamless control of devices with no setup needed. Both brands showcased their Ultra-High Definition Premium Certification, a new standard for 4K ultra-high definition televisions.

site_title: Gaze in wonder at the plant kingdom
summary: British naturalist Richard Mabey's book, "The Cabaret of Plants," challenges readers to care about the lives and experiences of plants. Mabey explores how plants solve the problem of staying alive and reproducing, and how they demonstrate "different models of being alive." He highlights the fascinating adaptations of plants, such as the Amazonian megaflower and the Patagonian vine, which can change their appearance to blend in with their surroundings. Through his engaging writing style and scientific expertise, Mabey encourages readers to see plants in a new light and appreciate their unique qualities.

site_title: Twitter considering 10,000-character limit for tweets
summary: Twitter is reportedly considering a new feature that would allow users to post tweets up to 10,000 characters, significantly longer than the current 140-character limit. The expansion could enable tweets with over 1,000 words. Twitter's CEO Jack Dorsey has expressed a desire to build more utility and power into the platform, despite initial opposition from some users. The new feature may be launched by the end of the first quarter, but an official date has not been set.

site_title: US sues Volkswagen for cheating on emissions tests
summary: The US Justice Department sued Volkswagen for cheating on emissions tests, accusing the company of installing illegal devices in nearly 600,000 diesel engine systems to impair emissions controls. The civil complaint, filed in Detroit, seeks penalties, including fines up to $19 billion, and follows a pledge by the Justice Department to hold executives accountable.
