summary: Singaporean real estate agents are offering unique promotions to attract buyers in a quiet market, including a free car wash during an open house for a three-storey bungalow. The quiet year-end festive season is expected to see the opening of showflats for launch-ready residential projects, but it remains to be seen if buyers' interest will be piqued.

site_title: Vale takes the brunt of anger over mine tragedy
summary: Brazil's Vale takes the brunt of public outrage and criticism over the country's worst environmental disaster, a mining spill that killed 17 and left hundreds homeless. The company's slow and clumsy public response, including denying responsibility and blaming Samarco, a joint-venture partner, has fueled social media outrage and street protests. In contrast, BHP, another joint-venture partner, has focused on offering condolences and explaining the facts, limiting its direct liability. Vale's market value has plummeted 25% since the disaster, while BHP's has also declined.

site_title: More GCB transactions in 2015
summary: In 2015, at least 34 Good Class Bungalow (GCB) transactions totaling S$730 million were recorded, the highest since 2012. Despite softer prices, the sales figure represented a 25% increase from the previous year. Experts attribute the price drop to weaker global and Singaporean economic sentiments, as well as higher interest rates. Prices are expected to ease further this year, with forecasts suggesting a 5-10% decrease.

images.alt_text: PRICE RETREAT: An option has been granted for this two-storey bungalow along Dalvey Road at S$26 million. The freehold property, which comes with five bedrooms and a swimming pool, was said to have had an asking price of at least S$30 million a year ago.

site_title: Twitter faces backlash over its new diversity leader
summary: Twitter faces criticism over its new diversity leader, Jeffrey Siminoff, a white man hired to address the company's lack of diversity. Despite being a go-to example of the issue, Twitter has 60% white employees and 72% white leadership roles, with fewer than 2% black employees. Siminoff's appointment has been met with skepticism, with some arguing that his hiring doesn't demonstrate the company's commitment to racial diversity.

site_title: Treasuries set for measured losses with Fed in rate-raising mode
summary: Treasuries are expected to decline in the first half of 2016, with the 10-year Treasury note yield rising to 2.55% and the two-year note yield reaching 1.33% by the end of June, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. The forecast is driven by the Federal Reserve's gradual rate-raising policy, which is expected to moderate yield increases. Traders anticipate a sub-2% US inflation rate for the next 30 years, citing tame inflation and economic growth. Historically, long-term Treasuries have performed well in rising-rate environments.

images.alt_text: Treasuries are forecast to decline during the first half of 2016, with yield increases moderated on speculation the Federal Reserve's monetary-policy normalization will prove more gradual than central bank officials foresee.

site_title: Judge rejects GM bid to dismiss first ignition switch trial
summary: US District Judge Jesse Furman has rejected General Motors' bid to dismiss the first "bellwether" case over defective ignition switches in its vehicles. The case, involving Robert Scheuer's 2003 Saturn Ion, will proceed to trial on January 11. The judge found that Scheuer presented sufficient evidence to justify a jury decision on whether the alleged ignition switch defect caused his injuries from a 2014 crash. This decision clears the way for six bellwether trials scheduled in the GM litigation for 2016.

site_title: Updated: Germany lifts alert of imminent attack in Munich
summary: German police lifted an alert of an imminent attack in Munich, hours after evacuating two key train stations due to fears of a New Year suicide bomb assault by the Islamic State group. The alert was issued following a tip-off, coming after the Paris attacks in November that sparked concerns of further IS attacks. The move was made in an atmosphere of unprecedented security as Europe prepared to ring in the New Year.

site_title: Tech IPOs expected to make a comeback in 2016
summary: Tech IPOs are expected to make a comeback in 2016, but investors will demand more profitability and cash flow. After a slow year in 2015, market-bound companies will need to show profitability alongside sales growth to attract investors. The backlog of private tech companies has increased, with over 144 valued at more than $1 billion. Companies like Atlassian Corp and Etsy Inc have shown that being consistently profitable can lead to successful IPOs, while others like Square Inc and Pure Storage Inc have struggled. Investors will focus on strong growth and fundamentals rather than market timing, with enterprise software makers expected to remain a popular group.

site_title: Getting the right mix
summary: The State Buildings in Perth have successfully curated a heritage complex with a mix of artisanal shops, renew-concept restaurants, and bars. Notable establishments include The Honeycake, Sugarplum Sweets, Sue Lewis chocolatier, and Aurelio Costarella's fashion boutique. The hotel's food and beverage options, such as Post and Wildflower, offer modern Australian cuisine and healthy options. Other eateries like Long Chim and Petition Kitchen provide unique dining experiences, including Thai street food and inventive uses of fresh produce. The complex also features a coffee counter, rooftop restaurant, and late-night drinking spots.

site_title: Delhi's 'odd, even cars' trial gets underway
summary: New Delhi has begun trialing a "car rationing" system to reduce pollution, where only cars with odd-numbered licence plates are allowed on the road on odd-numbered dates. Over 1 million private cars were banned from January 1 to 15 as part of the trial. The restrictions aim to cut smog in the world's most polluted capital, with the government considering making the system permanent if successful. Critics warn the plan may fail due to widespread disregard for traffic rules, but officials report a surprisingly high level of compliance.

site_title: UK banking regulator ditches review of industry culture
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has scrapped a public review of Britain's banking culture, opting instead to work individually with lenders to address concerns. The decision comes after the departure of a regulatory hardliner and a dilution of impending rules to hold senior bankers accountable. Critics, including lawmakers, say the move is a "surrender to big banks" and fails to address the industry's culture of excessive risk-taking and misbehavior, which led to scandals and fines.

site_title: Two to go
summary: Audi's new Q7 2.0 model boasts an efficient two-litre engine, weighing 1,975 kg, 55kg less than the 3.0-litre V6 variant, and producing 252 hp. The eight-speed tiptronic automatic transmission delivers smooth gear changes, and the car handles well despite its large size. The interior has been optimized for spaciousness, with good driveability and a clean, elegant design. The Q7 2.0 starts at S$304,600, including COE, and emits 172g/km of CO2.

site_title: China factory activity contracts for 5th month
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted for a fifth straight month in December, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.7, below 50 points indicating contraction. The economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace in a quarter of a century, with growth forecasted to cool from 7.3% in 2014 to 6.8% in 2016. The services sector, however, showed a rebound in December, with the non-manufacturing PMI rising to 54.4. The government is expected to step up support in 2016 to revive activity, with potential easing measures including interest rate cuts and reserve requirement ratio reductions.

images.alt_text: WEAK DEMAND: Export orders shrank for the 15th month.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters air grievances on New Year's day
summary: On New Year's Day, over 1,600 Hong Kong protesters gathered in downtown Hong Kong, calling for city leader Leung Chun-ying's resignation and voicing grievances over expensive construction projects and internet freedoms. The protesters, estimated to be over 3,000, carried yellow umbrellas and signs demanding universal pension and an end to "white elephant" projects. The rally follows mass pro-democracy rallies in 2014, which failed to bring concessions on political reform from Beijing and Hong Kong authorities.

site_title: BOJ rate cut no solace for top Japan fund that's staying in cash
summary: The Bank of Japan's negative interest rate move has not alleviated investor anxiety, according to J Flag Investment Co, a top Japan fund manager. Despite a 24% gain in 2015, the firm expects volatile stocks over the next three to six months and has no plans to re-enter the market. Concerns over a global recession due to China's economic slowdown have led to a 10% decline in major Japanese indexes this year. CEO Hisashi Osezawa attributes gains as unsustainable due to unclear market outlook.

site_title: Trip of a lifetime
summary: Travelers are shifting from superficial sightseeing to experiential travel, seeking tangible experiences that leave a lasting impact. Luxury travel companies, such as Quintessentially Travel and Insight Vacations, report an increase in demand for unique experiences, citing destinations like Croatia, Mongolia, and Cuba as top picks for 2016. Experts attribute this trend to popular culture, such as Game of Thrones and Mission Impossible, and the desire for a "trip of a lifetime." In contrast, destinations like France and Nepal may see a decline in tourism due to security concerns, but are expected to rebound in the following weeks or months.

images.alt_text: OFF THE BEATEN TRACK: There's been a recent shift in travel demand to incorporate elements of experience, travel industry veterans say; (above) Antarctica; Cuba; Croatia; and Morocco.
OFF THE BEATEN TRACK: There's been a recent shift in travel demand to incorporate elements of experience, travel industry veterans say; Antarctica; (above) Cuba; Croatia; and Morocco
OFF THE BEATEN TRACK: There's been a recent shift in travel demand to incorporate elements of experience, travel industry veterans say; Antarctica; Cuba; (above) Croatia; and Morocco
OFF THE BEATEN TRACK: There's been a recent shift in travel demand to incorporate elements of experience, travel industry veterans say; Antarctica; Cuba; Croatia; and (above) Morocco.

site_title: Culinary milestones
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Industry leaders in Singapore reflect on the highlights of 2015 and share their observations on trends and plans for 2016. The year saw the opening of several notable restaurants, including Odette at the National Gallery, which received critical acclaim. The industry is expected to shift towards consolidation, with a focus on quality and authenticity. The tapas trend is expected to continue, as well as the use of sustainable ingredients. The Michelin Guide's launch in Singapore is predicted to have a significant impact, sparking a revival of fine dining. Casual dining and local flavors are also expected to gain popularity.

site_title: Biggest US investors predict ho-hum bond returns in 2016
summary: Biggest US investors, including JPMorgan, Fidelity Investments, and Goldman Sachs, predict average bond returns in 2016, cautioning against excessive optimism. They forecast benchmark US 10-year yields to rise to 3% by year-end from 2.3% currently. This suggests a relatively stable interest rate environment, which could impact investment decisions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open sharply higher on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened sharply higher on Monday, driven by a weaker yen and the Bank of Japan's surprise interest rate cut. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.03% to 17,699.60, while the Topix index gained 1.12% to 1,448.04. Investors reacted positively to the rate cut, lifting exporters and boosting market sentiment.

site_title: Zen temple seeks business enlightenment
summary: A 13th-century Japanese Zen temple is seeking to boost tourism and financial stability by partnering with a Tokyo skyscraper builder to develop a US$11 million hotel and modern path leading to the site. The temple, which once fascinated Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, aims to increase visitor numbers from less than half a million to 500,000 by 2025 and double this number by 2025. The redevelopment project, valued at 1.3 billion yen, is part of a broader effort to revitalize rural areas and attract foreign tourists to Japan's western coast.

site_title: China's shift to services industry
summary: China's economy is undergoing a transition from a manufacturing-driven, export-oriented growth model to a more service-based, middle-class consumption-driven model. This shift has raised concerns about slowing growth rates, greater volatility, and potential consequences for the country's housing and infrastructure build-out. However, experts also see the transition as a potentially positive outcome that will bring structural changes and new opportunities. China's policymakers face challenges in managing the passage of this transition, but the country's long-term prospects remain uncertain.

site_title: US car industry sales explode as foreign brands up market share
summary: US car industry sales reached a record high in 2015, with total sales exceeding 17.4 million, driven by pent-up demand, low petrol prices, and low interest rates. However, the Detroit Big Three's dominance has slipped to 45% of the market from nearly 66% in 2000, as foreign brands like Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Hyundai, and Kia have gained significant market share. Industry analysts attribute the shift to the Detroit companies' downsizing due to financial pressures, and the rise of crossover models, which now account for nearly 24% of the market.

site_title: Japan household spending, output slump as BOJ meets
summary: Japan's household spending plummeted 9.4% in December, the largest annual decline in nearly a year, and factory output slumped 1.2% more than expected. This weak data raises pressure on the Bank of Japan to ease policy further to support the fragile economic recovery. Policymakers are debating whether to take immediate action due to volatile markets and slowing global growth, which could lead to downward pressure on prices if the economy shrinks.

site_title: SIHH 2016: Year of the Diva?
summary: The SIHH 2016 watch show is expected to feature a range of new models from Richemont brands and independent watchmakers. Jaeger-LeCoultre is launching three collections to celebrate the 85th birthday of its iconic Reverso timepiece, while Roger Dubuis has dubbed 2016 the "Year of the Roger Dubuis Diva." Cartier, Vacheron Constantin, Piaget, and Montblanc are also showcasing new lady's watches, including the Velvet collection from Roger Dubuis and the Limelight Gala from Piaget. Other brands, such as Panerai and A Lange & Sohne, are also releasing pre-SIHH teasers, including a new men's watch from Piaget featuring a hybrid quartz-mechanical movement.

site_title: China's Xi vows to push reforms while expanding global role
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for stable growth and reforms in 2016, aiming to open up its markets and improve the lives of its 1.3 billion people despite a slowing economy. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Xi's New Year's Eve speech stressed the importance of reforms, marking a shift towards greater international engagement.

site_title: Vacancies, oversupply revive debate on ECs
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) market is experiencing increased vacancy rates and oversupply, sparking debate over the relevance of public-private housing. Despite a 6% increase in eligible buyer pool, EC sales remain low, with 3,435 units remaining unsold as of Q3 2015. Some owners are treating ECs as investment homes, locking up funds for extended periods, while others argue that buyers are still purchasing ECs for lifestyle reasons. The government's continued supply of EC land and lack of mitigation measures are exacerbating the issue, with a total of over 7,000 units expected to be launched in 2016.

site_title: Saudi Arabia didn't make output cut proposal: report
summary: Saudi Arabia denies being the source of a proposal to cut oil production, contrary to a report by al-Arabiya television. However, the kingdom expressed willingness to cooperate with other oil producers to support the market, according to an unnamed Saudi source.

site_title: House-hunting in Silicon Valley's an ordeal
summary: In Silicon Valley, the median home value is 5 times higher than the national average, making house-hunting an ordeal. Barry and Katie Templin, a couple with two young children, have been searching for a suitable home with reasonable commutes and good schools, but face extremely high prices. They found a house priced at $1.5 million, despite being in disrepair, due to the area's high demand. The couple's experience highlights the challenges of buying a home in one of the nation's most expensive housing markets.

site_title: Taleban suicide attack targets French restaurant in Kabul
summary: A Taliban suicide car bomber targeted a French restaurant in Kabul, Le Jardin, on New Year's Day, injuring at least four people and causing a building to engulf in flames. The attack marks the latest in a series of brazen insurgent assaults in the city.

site_title: This guy had a great year taking on ETF investors
summary: David Miller, a Michigan native, successfully bet against exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in 2015, turning his Catalyst Mutual Funds into one of Wall Street's top players. Miller's strategy paid off, making his fund one of the most successful in 2015.

site_title: Indian stocks gain after worst year since 2011
summary: Indian stocks rose on the first day of trading in the new year, marking the end of the worst year since 2011. The benchmark gauge, the S&P BSE Sensex, gained 0.2% to 26,160.90, after a three-day decline. Key gainers included Tata Motors, State Bank of India, and carriers InterGlobe Aviation, Jet Airways India, and SpiceJet, which rallied more than 8% each after a cut in fuel prices. The Sensex rose for a third straight week, marking a 1.3% gain.

site_title: Update: India 2030 bonds reverse losses as govt meets auction goal
summary: India's government met its target in a bond sale, alleviating concerns about weakening demand for sovereign debt. The 7.88% notes due March 2030 saw a yield drop to 7.93%, while the 10-year benchmark yield declined three basis points to 7.73%. The administration sold 140 billion rupees of securities, including 60 billion rupees of notes due 2030, after a two-week break. This sale comes as part of a plan to increase foreign-investment limits in phases, and follows a quarterly advance in benchmark 10-year yields.

site_title: Board changes at EDB, A*Star and IE Singapore
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry has announced changes to the boards of the Economic Development Board (EDB), A*Star, and IE Singapore. At the EDB, assistant secretary-general Patrick Tay Teck Guan has been appointed, while Tan Pheng Hock and Jean-Luc Butel will be re-appointed. Three EDB board members will step down on January 31, including Kwek Mean Luck, Cham Hui Fong, and Bruno Guilmart. The changes take effect on February 1.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Floods choking everything from oil to grain in US Midwest
summary: Deadly flooding across the US Midwest is disrupting oil and agriculture, forcing pipeline closures and killing thousands of pigs. At least 20 people have died and hundreds of roads are closed in Missouri and Illinois due to record-breaking rain-swollen rivers. The floods have also closed 50 miles of the Illinois River and 81 miles of the Mississippi River, affecting various industries and infrastructure.

site_title: French economy grew 1.1% in 2015, fastest in four years
summary: France's economy grew 1.1% in 2015, its largest increase in four years, according to official statistics. This growth was in line with the government's predictions but lagged the expected 1.5% growth in the wider eurozone. The full-year growth figure marked a turnaround from years of economic stagnation, with the fourth quarter posting a 0.2% increase.

site_title: Pilots blamed for 2014 TransAsia crash on Taiwan island
summary: Taiwan's aviation authorities have blamed the 2014 TransAsia Airways plane crash that killed 48 people on the pilots' reckless decision to fly too low during a typhoon. The pilots attempted to land on an island despite poor visibility, violating minimum altitude requirements. The crash occurred on July 23, 2014, and was the airline's second fatal accident in a year.

site_title: German Bunds lose safe-haven status
summary: German Bunds lost their safe-haven status in 2015, with 10-year yields reaching 0.64% at the end of the year, a 10-bp increase from the previous year. This marks the most volatile year for Bunds since 2011. The failed bid to break below zero raised questions about the effectiveness of ultra-easy monetary policy in providing a safe-haven asset.

site_title: Exciting calendar ahead
summary: The article looks back at the golfing world's major events in 2016, highlighting the dominance of 20-something golfers, particularly Jordan Spieth, who won the US Masters and US Open at 21 years old, setting records and breaking records. This year's golf calendar in Singapore is also expected to be exciting, with key events to look forward to.

site_title: Fox News holds its lead in cable news
summary: Fox News maintained its lead in cable news in 2015, according to Nielsen. CNN saw significant improvements in ratings, while MSNBC experienced a slight increase in viewers. The year featured notable news stories, including the presidential campaign, terrorist attacks, and Pope Francis's visit to the US. Despite a challenging economic environment, the top cable news channels saw an increase in viewership, indicating a continued interest in 24-hour news coverage.

site_title: Wall St suffers feeble end to turbulent 2015
summary: Wall Street ended 2015 with a feeble performance, as the S&P 500 dropped marginally for the year despite record highs. The energy sector was the lone gainer, with oil shares rising 0.34%. The consumer discretionary sector was a star performer, but other sectors like technology and industrials declined. The year marked a reversal of trends, with the energy sector's performance contrasting with the major selloff seen earlier in the year.

site_title: Smaller US media-content producers likely to feel merger pressure
summary: US media-content producers are expected to feel pressure to merge in 2016 and beyond, with cable companies and distributors having bulked up in recent years. This trend is seen following Comcast's failed attempt to seal a deal with Time Warner Cable. In contrast, Disney is large enough to sit out the merger market, but other producers may feel compelled to join forces to remain competitive.

site_title: Oil falls as Asia economies slow, prospect of crude output cut dims
summary: Oil prices fell in early trading on Monday, dropping 1.2% to $35.55 per barrel, as South Korea posted its weakest export data since 2009. The prospect of a coordinated production cut by leading crude exporters seemed remote. US West Texas Intermediate fell 32 cents to $33.30 per barrel. The decline in oil prices follows a bearish outlook due to Trump's tariff threats, which have kept markets on edge.

site_title: M'sia anti-graft agency sends fund probe report to A-G
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency, the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC), has sent two reports to the attorney-general's office regarding probes into large sums of money transferred into Prime Minister Najib Razak's bank accounts and the 1MDB state fund. The MACC did not disclose its findings or determine if any wrongdoing occurred, leaving it up to the attorney-general to decide further action.

site_title: Firefighters tackle Dubai blaze after all-night effort
summary: Firefighters in Dubai largely extinguished a blaze that engulfed the 63-storey Address Downtown Dubai hotel and residential block on New Year's Eve. The building was evacuated, with 14 people lightly injured and over 60 treated for smoke inhalation and crowd-related issues. The cause of the fire is not specified.

site_title: Spain nurtures its truffle trade - for the French
summary: Spain's truffle trade thrives, with buyers gathering in a parking lot to purchase the prized foodstuff from local farmers. The market, located in the small village of Sarrion, is unusual due to the clandestine nature of the sale, but the high demand for truffles justifies the secrecy. Despite being in arid and thinly populated hills, the truffle trade is a significant contributor to the local economy, with farmers selling their produce to buyers in the dark, using flashlights to inspect the truffles.

site_title: Trader who made 6,200% on China futures says go short or get out
summary: Huang Weimin, a 45-year-old Chinese hedge fund manager, advises investors to sell their shares before it's too late, citing a 35% return through Jan 22 and predicting a 15% drop in China's Shanghai Composite Index in the first half of 2016 due to economic slowdown and a weaker yuan. He recommends shifting into cash for average Chinese investors, while sticking with bearish futures bets for his own fund.

site_title: From drab to fab
summary: Perth's State Buildings, a set of historically significant Victorian-era buildings, have undergone a long-awaited restoration. After 20 years of inactivity due to bureaucratic hurdles, the restoration work began in 2012, addressing the severe deterioration of the 140-year-old structures. The buildings, which include the General Post Office and treasury, were once the state's most important public offices but had fallen into disrepair. The restoration, led by FJM Property, aimed to bring the buildings back to their former glory, overcoming financial and logistical challenges along the way.

site_title: Iraq exported more than 1 billion barrels of oil in 2015
summary: Iraq exported over 1 billion barrels of oil in 2015, generating $49.079 billion in revenue. The country sold 99.7 million barrels of oil in December at an average price of $44.74 per barrel, following a record 100.9 million barrels sold in November. Despite lower oil prices, Iraq needs to continue increasing crude output to meet its revenue needs, as the country's oil reserves are among the world's largest.

site_title: How wealthy Americans stay even wealthier
summary: Wealthy Americans, including hedge fund magnates, have employed a sophisticated "income defence industry" to exploit tax manoeuvres and shield their fortunes. This high-priced apparatus of lawyers, estate planners, lobbyists, and anti-tax activists helps them route money to Bermuda and back, saving millions in taxes. As public debate rises over inequality and potential higher taxes on the wealthy, this "income defence industry" has effectively shielded the very richest Americans from government response, exacerbating the issue of wealth inequality.

site_title: Dubai probes cause after fire engulfs hotel
summary: A fire engulfed a 63-storey luxury hotel in Dubai on New Year's Eve, with smoke still rising as authorities investigate the cause. The blaze, which occurred at The Address Downtown hotel, sparked panic but no reports of serious injuries. The fire broke out around 9:30pm on Thursday and was extinguished by 10:30pm. The Dubai authorities are working to determine the cause of the fire, which is currently under investigation.

site_title: Football: John Terry to leave Chelsea at end of the season
summary: Chelsea captain John Terry announced he will leave the club at the end of the season, following talks that his contract will not be renewed. Terry, 35, has made 696 appearances for Chelsea and is the club's most successful captain, having won multiple titles including the 2012 Champions League. He stated it won't be a "fairytale ending" and will not retire at Chelsea.

images.alt_text: Chelsea captain John Terry announced on Sunday that he will leave at the end of the season after the club told him that they will not be renewing his contract.

site_title: Barclays, Credit Suisse pay US$154.3 million in dark pools probe
summary: Barclays and Credit Suisse have agreed to settle allegations of misleading investors about their private trading platforms, known as dark pools. Barclays will pay US$70 million and Credit Suisse will pay US$84.3 million, with US$24.3 million going to the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The banks were accused of not disclosing enough information about their dark pool trading practices, with Barclays misrepresenting monitoring and Credit Suisse routing orders to its own pool without disclosing the preference. The settlements are the largest levied on a dark pool operator.

site_title: Flash: Retail property prices dip 0.1% in Q4 2015, while rentals fall 1.3%
summary: Singapore's retail property prices decreased 0.1% in Q4 2015, while rental prices dropped 1.3%. This marks a contrasting trend to the overall property market, which has seen steady growth. The drop in rentals may indicate a shift in consumer behavior or changes in market demand.

site_title: Rollercoaster ride leaves Shanghai investors flat
summary: The Shanghai market experienced extreme volatility from January 1 to mid-June, surging 60% before slumping nearly a third in three weeks. Despite the fluctuations, the Shanghai Composite Index closed at 3,539.18 on Thursday, up 9.4% for the year, marking the most volatile year in the quarter-century history of the modern Chinese stock market.

site_title: Qualifying criteria for elected presidency should be reviewed: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has called for a review of the qualifying criteria for the elected presidency, citing the need to update the details. The criteria, which include holding key appointments or running large companies with a paid-up capital of S$100 million, were established in the Constitution. The next presidential election is set for August 2017, and the review is seen as a necessary step to ensure the elected presidency remains relevant.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Cosby faces big financial threat from civil lawsuits - legal experts
summary: Bill Cosby faces significant financial threats from civil lawsuits, regardless of the outcome of his criminal prosecution. Over 50 women have accused him of sex abuse, with at least seven ongoing civil suits filed by 13 women. These lawsuits could do major damage to Cosby's wealth, with lawyers who have handled similar cases stating that the financial assets of accused individuals in similar cases have been significantly reduced. The criminal charge against Cosby carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a $25,000 fine.

site_title: India's smog-shrouded capital pulls cars off roads
summary: New Delhi, India's capital, has implemented a trial ban on over 1 million private cars to combat smog, restricting odd-numbered plate vehicles on odd-numbered dates and even-numbered plates on even-numbered dates, except on Sundays. The restrictions, set to run until January 15, are part of a broader effort to reduce pollution levels, including shutting coal-fired power plants and vacuuming roads.

site_title: Malaysia arrests 7 militants suspected of planning attacks
summary: Malaysian police arrested 7 suspected IS militants in a 3-day operation across the country, ahead of an international conference on deradicalization. The suspects, all Malaysian men aged 26-50, were linked to Syrian-based IS members and received instructions to carry out attacks in Malaysia. They were allegedly planning terror attacks in strategic locations and channelling funds to join IS in Syria. Items seized included bullets, jihad books, and propaganda videos. The arrests follow the capture of a suspected militant who confessed to planning a suicide attack in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: India 2030 bond yield rises to 4-mth high as supply looms
summary: Indian sovereign bonds maturing in 2030 fell, pushing the yield to a 4-month high, as the government sold 60 billion rupees of debt at an auction. The yield on the 7.88% debt due March 2030 rose to 7.97%, its highest since August. Concerns over India meeting its budget-deficit targets led to a decline in investor sentiment, causing demand to falter at the last two auctions. The government plans to sell 140 billion rupees of debt, including the 2030 notes, as sales resume after a two-week break.

site_title: Japan rides huge, income-boosting tourism boom with a weak yen
summary: Japan experienced a significant tourism boom in 2015, with 19.7 million visitors and $41.7 billion in spending, quadrupling the number of tourists over the past decade. The weakness of the yen since 2013 has been the main driving force behind the growth, with the number of travelers from Asia more than doubling. The government aims to reach 20 million annual visitors by 2020, but there are concerns over Japan's ability to accommodate large surges in tourism, particularly with regards to hotel and accommodation supply.

site_title: Foreign banks in Malaysia raise their cost of borrowing
summary: Foreign banks in Malaysia have raised their base rates and effective lending rates, with OCBC, UOB, and HSBC increasing their rates in response to a liquidity crunch caused by a shortage of ringgit and US dollars. Despite the central bank maintaining the overnight policy rate at 3.25%, the hikes are aimed at attracting depositors and mitigating the impact of a weak economy. Analysts attribute the move to the underperforming ringgit and the increasing preference for foreign-currency deposits.

site_title: China's POLY-GCL completes gas appraisal wells in S-E Ethiopia
summary: China's POLY-GCL Petroleum Group Holdings Ltd has completed two appraisal wells in Ethiopia's southeast, marking a significant step towards determining the size of gas deposits in the Calub and Hilala fields. The wells are expected to show 4.7 trillion cubic feet of liquid natural gas and 13.6 million barrels of associated liquids, discovered in the 1970s. Production is expected to start in 2016, with five wells planned to be drilled in the region.

site_title: Moody's puts 120 energy firms on review over bleak oil outlook
summary: Moody's has placed 120 energy firms on review for downgrade due to a "substantial risk" of a slow oil price recovery, which would compound stress on firms already reeling from a 75% drop in oil prices since June 2014. The ratings agency also cut its oil price forecasts, expecting Brent crude to average $33 a barrel in 2016, down $10 from previous estimates. The review includes major oil and gas companies and reflects weakening global demand and oversupply, which will significantly stress the credit profiles of oil and gas companies.

site_title: Oil prices bounce back from 12-year lows
summary: Oil prices rose from 12-year lows on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) for February increasing 72 cents to $31.20 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude gaining 72 cents to $31.03 a barrel. The price bounce is seen as a technical rebound after prices fell below $30 a barrel amid ongoing global oversupply and uncertain demand outlook. Analysts expect the gains to be short-lived, citing a physical supply and demand surplus and ongoing sanctions relief in Iran.

site_title: JTC awards tender for industrial site at Tuas South Link 2
summary: JTC awards tender to Hiap Shing Construction for a 5,050 square metre industrial site at Tuas South Link 2 (Plot 5) with a tendered price of S$3.0 million, beating two other bidders. The site has a gross plot ratio of 1.4 and a 20-year tenure zoned for Business 2 use. Two other tender attempts for plots at Tuas South Link 2 and Tampines Industrial Drive were rejected due to non-compliant bids or too-low prices.

site_title: Aussie vineyards expecting better earnings as their hedges wind down
summary: Australian exporters, such as wine producer Casella Wines, expect improved earnings as the country's weaker exchange rate benefits their businesses. The Australian dollar has declined by 30% over the past three years, and exporters are now locking in the weaker exchange rate with new contracts. This is expected to spur investment and spending decisions, particularly in non-mining sectors, and could add to the economy's competitiveness, with some predicting a 1% increase in gross domestic product over two to three years.

images.alt_text: Casella Wines, which exports Yellow Tail wine, has expanded its sales and marketing team, adding eight new roles over the past year and a half. It recently acquired Brand's Laira Winery.

site_title: Superhero CEO
summary: Quintiles, a global clinical or contract research organisation (CRO), is expanding under the leadership of CEO Tom Pike, who aims to target market share and grow the company despite the pharmaceutical industry's challenges. Pike, who lost his parents to cancer, is driven by a desire to create better solutions in healthcare. Quintiles has seen significant growth in the Asia-Pacific region, with unlimited growth potential. The company is also focusing on data analytics to lift its integrated healthcare services segment. Pike's priorities include developing new drugs faster and more effectively, and winning the war on talent in the industry.

site_title: Bank of Korea cuts growth, inflation forecasts on instability
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) cut its growth and inflation forecasts, citing instability from China's slower growth and its impact on global financial markets. The seven-day repurchase rate remained at 1.5% for a seventh month, and the BOK lowered its inflation projections for 2016 to 1.4%. Governor Lee Ju Yeol emphasized the need to spur inflation to 2% and shored up the South Korean economy, which faces challenges including declining exports and high household debt. The BOK's decision was unanimous, but economists expect a potential rate cut in the first quarter.

site_title: Arab nations eye China for tourism revival
summary: Arab nations, including Egypt, Morocco, and Jordan, are seeking to revive their tourism sectors by developing domestic tourism and attracting Chinese visitors, who have shown increased interest in the region despite security concerns. Egypt's visitor numbers from China doubled to 135,000 in 2015, while Morocco's domestic tourism market accounts for 33% of its total tourism activity. The region aims to reach 195 million international tourists by 2030, but faces challenges from safety and security concerns.

images.alt_text: The number of Chinese visitors to Egypt more than doubled from 60,000 in 2014 to 135,000 in 2015 despite a series of security blows to the Arab country's key tourism sector, because Cairo began to allow charter flights from the Asian country, Egypt's tourism minister said.

site_title: What's fuelling China's stock market sell-off?
summary: China's stock market is experiencing a sell-off due to the actions of relatively affluent retail investors who trade frequently and are prone to herd behavior. The volatility is not a sign of a meltdown in China's economy, which is expected to grow at 6.4% this year, but rather a result of the market's dominance by domestic, retail investors who are sensitive to policy signals. The recent circuit-breakers, which were intended to halt panics, actually heightened volatility, and regulators have since scrapped them. Despite the turmoil, China's middle class remains untouched, and the country's economy is expected to continue growing, albeit slowly.

site_title: No need for Thailand to cut rates as fiscal stimulus drives growth: central bank gov
summary: Thailand's central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, stated that the country does not need to cut interest rates due to fiscal stimulus driving slow but steady economic growth. Despite China's slowdown affecting Thai exports, the central bank maintains its forecast of 3.5% economic growth for the year. Growth is expected to pick up slowly, with potential revision if global oil prices continue to fall. The Bank of Thailand will monitor the situation closely.

site_title: Yuan opens firmer ahead of China GDP data
summary: China's yuan strengthened ahead of the release of quarterly GDP data, trading at 6.5795 per dollar in early trade. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.5596 per dollar, firmer than the previous day's closing quote. The offshore yuan was trading 0.19% softer than the onshore spot. The GDP data is expected to show the weakest economic growth in nearly seven years, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed at the open on Tuesday, ahead of the release of quarterly GDP data which is expected to point to the weakest economic growth in nearly seven years.

site_title: Travel revolutionary
summary: Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshahi emphasizes the importance of technology in the travel industry, likening his company to Google, which is a technology-focused search company. However, he also acknowledges that travel is a people-centric business, requiring personal relationships with hoteliers and suppliers. Expedia has invested heavily in technology, rebuilding its platform and hiring top programmers and sales and marketing professionals. The company aims to empower the travel industry, democratize travel distribution, and provide a platform for smaller players to connect with consumers. With a target of reaching $100 billion in gross bookings, Expedia sees itself as a disruptor in the industry, but also as a partner to travel suppliers, aiming to create a healthy and competitive market.

site_title: Beyond bridging US-Japan ties (Amended)
summary: Glen Fukushima, a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, shares his experience as a Japanese-American who has lived in both the US and Japan. He believes that Japanese Americans should play a key role in bridging the US-Japan relationship. Fukushima notes that many Japanese view him as more American than Americans and more Japanese than Japanese, due to his characteristics such as being logical, analytical, and self-confident. He emphasizes the importance of Japanese Americans in fostering closer ties between the two nations.

site_title: Making a complex subject entertaining
summary: The Big Short, a film based on Michael Lewis' book, depicts the 2008 US sub-prime mortgage market collapse and its aftermath. Director Adam McKay uses humor and unconventional methods to explain complex financial concepts, making the film an entertaining economics lesson. The story follows several characters, including Michael Burry, Mark Baum, and Jamie Shipley, who predict the market's downfall and profit from betting against it. The film reveals that the crisis was caused by ignorance, greed, and irresponsible institutions, with most events depicted actually occurring.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: In drab year, SMEs warm to innovation and bristle on costs
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are pessimistic about the business outlook in 2016, with 35% of respondents expressing pessimism, compared to 25% in 2015. The study, conducted by the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI), found that 44% of SMEs expect a drop in profit margin, and most cite rising costs, stiff competition, and labor market pressures as major challenges. The government is urged to review rising costs, increase subsidies for innovation and hiring older workers, and ease compliance costs. The SCCCI also recommends setting up a committee to examine major rising costs and adjusting foreign-worker quotas based on sector needs.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower after China data
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on Monday after China's manufacturing activity index fell to its lowest level in three years. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.24% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.28%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also declined 0.27%. The decline follows a weak manufacturing report from China, which may indicate a slowdown in the country's economy.

images.alt_text: [HONG KONG] Shanghai and Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday after an index of Chinese manufacturing activity fell to its lowest level in three years last month.

site_title: After a dull year, 2016 promises more action from US tech IPOs
summary: US tech companies are expected to have a more active year in 2016, with a focus on enterprise software companies and those with annual revenue exceeding $100 million. Investors and bankers are optimistic about digital security, data management, and cloud companies going public, citing predictable revenue and cash flows. A list compiled by Bloomberg highlights several companies, including those with strong margins or recurring revenue metrics, which may be suitable for an IPO in 2016. This shift is seen as a response to a slow year for technology companies going public in 2015.

site_title: Wordsmith at the helm
summary: Grey Group's chief creative officer, Tor Myhren, believes that failure is a precursor to success and encourages risk-taking through the Heroic Failure awards. Under his leadership, Grey's New York office has tripled in size and the agency won 113 awards at the 2015 Cannes Lions. Myhren's unconventional background in journalism and his decision to pursue an advertising career despite a lack of knowledge about the industry have contributed to his success. He attributes his ability to write quickly and succinctly under pressure to his journalism training. Myhren thrives on the advertising industry's competitive culture and enjoys pitching to clients. Despite a major failure in 2006, he learned from the mistake and redeemed himself with a successful campaign for E*Trade. The Heroic Failure awards aim to celebrate failures of daring and audacity, and have changed the company's culture, encouraging employees to take risks.

images.alt_text: 'It was this big production - very expensive, very fashiony. And at the Super Bowl, what I learnt very quickly was that people don't want big, fashiony things. They want funny, or they want bombastic, or they want explosives. But not the cool fashion thing. It just totally tanked...I always say: Fail fast. The long, extended failure - not so good.'

site_title: Apsil moves into China property via RTO deal
summary: Apsil, a Singapore-listed funeral services provider, has announced a "very substantial acquisition" of a Chinese real estate firm, China Real Estate Development Union Investments (Credui), for S$33.3 million. Apsil will pay 80 million yuan (S$17.5 million) in cash and issue 2.6 billion new shares to finance the acquisition. Tycoon Oei Hong Leong will become a new substantial shareholder, owning 29% of the enlarged capital. The deal requires shareholder approval.

site_title: New World's US$350m misstep may yet pay off
summary: New World Development has agreed to take its Chinese unit, New World China Land, private for $2.7 billion, a $350 million increase from its initial offer. The deal comes after the company's earlier attempt was rejected due to a regulation known as the "headcount test". Despite a 17% drop in shares since the initial attempt, New World's balance sheet remains strong, and the deal may benefit from rising Chinese house prices and demand for homes.
